Digital tools are increasingly being connected to physical infrastructure, and properly securing the critical systems that result is essential. Organizations will have to make use of machine learning and artificial intelligence in order to better measure and report cyber risk, as they confront issues associated with the proliferation devices powering smart cities and the Internet of Things. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Benjamin Fung, Canada Research Chair in Data Mining for Cybersecurity, Associate Professor, School of Information Studies, McGill University.

name: Digital Communications
description: The digital communications industry is facilitating unprecedented levels of global internet use, online social interaction, and financial inclusion. As the industry is transformed, effective policy and regulation that support businesses could boost productivity. At the same time, the industry must be open to new models of collaboration and governance, in order to better address challenges like data privacy and growing demands on infrastructure. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with A S Madhukumar, Associate Professor, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore.

name: Digital Economy and Society
description: By the end of 2018, about half of the world’s population was connected to the internet - roughly 30 years after the invention of the World Wide Web. The expansion of internet access is slowing, however, and digital divides reflect economic and social divides. By 2022, an estimated 60% of global GDP will be digitized, yet a minority of people believe technology will make their lives better. While digital technology has the potential to enhance economies, societies, and the environment, if related risks outweigh these benefits it could further exacerbate exclusion, the concentration of power and wealth, and social instability. Coordinated, multi-stakeholder action is required to create a digital future that is inclusive and sustainable.

name: Digital Identity
description: Having a trusted, verifiable identity is essential. As digital interaction brings information online at an unprecedented rate, the data comprising our identities are being widely shared - creating both opportunities and vulnerabilities. If designed right, digital identities can provide countries with economic value equal to as much as 13% of GDP by 2030, save 110 billion hours through streamlined e-government, and save businesses up to $1.6 trillion, according to the McKinsey Global Institute. And for the estimated 1 billion people who have no official proof of identity (not to mention the 3.2 billion people unable to effectively use an identity on digital channels), collaborative and user-centric digital identity models guided by shared principles have the potential to be empowering.

name: Drones
description: Drones can grant anyone access to airspace, with very low barriers to entry. These unmanned aircraft systems are creating value as they increase crop yields, lower chemical footprints, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and act as a lifeline for rural populations in hard-to-reach places. Advances in battery development, sensor miniaturization, and computational power are making drones a common tool; Goldman Sachs estimates that the related market opportunity between 2016 and 2020 will amount to $100 billion. Longer term, autonomously-piloted drone systems are being developed to transport people within cities. However, the prevalence of drones may be limited by flight time capability, regulatory hurdles, and public perception of risk and privacy.

name: Education and Skills
description: Technological innovation is fundamentally transforming education, and updating the skills required for the contemporary workplace. Building future-ready education systems requires designing curricula fit for the 21st century, coupled with the consistent delivery of a basic education for everyone that builds a solid foundation for a lifetime of adapting and developing new abilities. Specialized education should provide in-demand skills, and address the disconnect between employer needs and existing instruction.

name: Electricity
description: Global electricity systems are undergoing the most profound set of changes since Thomas Edison’s inauguration of the Pearl Street Station, the world’s first commercial power plant, in 1882. In developed economies, distributed energy resources and digital technologies are transforming system planning and operations. These technologies are also creating opportunities to bring electricity to the more than 1.1 billion individuals who still lack access to an essential commodity. The threat of climate change has initiated a push for electricity decarbonization, and spurred efforts to electrify industry and transportation. Meanwhile efforts are underway to expand regional markets and create greater geographical interconnections, and to ensure the security of supply in the face of cyber threats and natural disasters.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Ignacio Perez Arriaga (Director of Energy Training, Florence School of Regulation at the European University Institute; Visiting Professor at the Centre for Energy and Environmental Policy Research, MIT; and Professor and Director of the BP Chair of Energy and Sustainability at Comillas Pontifical University (ICADE)), and his team.

name: Electronics
description: The electronics industry serves as a showcase for the innovation underpinning the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Industry stakeholders, including private companies and public entities, must find more ways to work together constructively in order to foster developments that actually provide significant benefit to society - in the form of human-centric solutions, and methods of information processing that are increasingly energy-smart, secure, and reliable.

name: Emerging Multinationals
description: A relatively new type of company has been capitalizing on the growing global middle class by leveraging technology and competing effectively for natural resources: multinationals from emerging markets. These firms are gaining influence thanks to their strength at home, and their ability to penetrate new markets abroad. They are relatively well-equipped to cope with geopolitical risk, although they can face difficulties when it comes to attracting talent. They are also developing new governance and managerial structures, and are poised to become major competitors to established global corporations. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Mauro Guillén, Zandman Professor of International Management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

name: Entrepreneurship
description: Entrepreneurship is arguably the most fundamental driver of economic value creation, whether it manifests in the form of a new startup, or as a regenerating force within an established company. As they discover opportunities, and mobilize the resources necessary to exploit them, entrepreneurs unleash the forces of creative destruction to transform existing industries and create new ones; entrepreneurs can also serve as arbitragers, capable of bringing markets back into competitive equilibrium. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Wong Poh-Kam, Director of the Entrepreneurship Center at the National University of Singapore.

name: Environment and Natural Resource Security
description: Global environmental risks related to extreme weather events, the potential failure of climate change mitigation efforts, and natural disasters rank among the top ten in terms of likelihood, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Risks Report. The tangible impacts of climate change are increasingly evident - and developing adequate and innovative responses will require new forms of cooperation between the public and private sectors.

name: Ethiopia
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Ethiopia based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: European Union
description: European Parliament elections in 2019 underlined the fragmented state of the bloc, as both far-right nationalists and their pro-Europe adversaries scored local victories (in the United Kingdom, slated to leave the EU, the vote indicated a popular desire to reverse course and remain). Divisions among European countries are wider than they have been for a generation, and existing institutional arrangements complicate policy responses; some European countries are in NATO, others are within the Schengen area of opened borders, and still others are European Economic Area members but not in the European Union. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Mark Leonard and Ulrike Franke, Director and Research Assistant, respectively, at the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR).

name: Family Businesses
description: Family businesses are estimated to account for more than 70% of global GDP. The ability of the family business sector to thrive is therefore vital for the long-term health of the global economy. In order to both grow in the short term, and to be sustainable for future generations, family businesses must effectively manage several unique challenges including a relative lack of innovation, ownership that may be shared across several branches of a family, a need to effectively transition to new generations of company leaders, and a potentially inhibiting emotional attachment to a founder’s legacy.

name: Financial and Monetary Systems
description: International financial and monetary systems are intimately connected to geopolitical maneuvering and geo-economic one-upmanship. As emerging markets have become bigger contributors to global GDP, and home to an expanding middle class, that has drawn the attention of global banks. Meanwhile populist movements are questioning monetary institutions like the euro, and China is offering alternatives to traditional development funding sources like the World Bank. As policy-makers try to keep international financial waters calm by pulling back post-financial crisis measures and tackling new challenges such as crypto-assets, their decisions will have a decisive impact on global prosperity.

name: Finland
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Finland based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: Forests
description: Humanity is inextricably linked to forests. The livelihoods of roughly one billion people depend on forested areas, which play a critical role in absorbing and storing carbon, providing food, water, wood products, and vital medicines, and supporting much of the world’s biodiversity. Deforestation, degradation, and fragmentation are all diminishing the ability of forests to provide ecosystem services such as air purification and climate regulation. Illegal logging, clearing, and related corruption are meanwhile causing the loss of public revenue and stirring conflict; in order to retain and replenish cultural identity and biodiversity, we need to safeguard and sustainably manage the world’s forests. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with World Resources Institute.

name: Fourth Industrial Revolution
description: The Fourth Industrial Revolution represents a fundamental change in the way we live, work, and relate to one another. It is a new chapter in human development, enabled by technology advances that are commensurate with those of the first, second and third industrial revolutions, and which are merging the physical, digital, and biological worlds in ways that create both promise and peril. The speed, breadth, and depth of this revolution is forcing us to rethink how countries should develop, how organizations create value, and even what it means to be human; it is an opportunity to help everyone, including leaders, policy-makers and people from all income groups and nations, to harness technologies in order to create an inclusive, human-centred future.

name: France
description: France plays a significant role in global affairs thanks to its political, economic, and cultural influence. The tenure of President Emmanuel Macron, who ran as a pro-Europe, pro-business candidate, provides a unique opportunity for the country to help address the rise of populism on the continent, and lead the international battle to contain climate change. However, the gilets jaunes (“yellow vests”) protests against his administration that began in 2018 have undermined his authority. Other significant domestic challenges include a need to make the country’s education system fairer and more efficient, and to better adapt its labour market to the digital era. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Institut Montaigne.

name: Future of Consumption
description: By the year 2027, annual consumption in China is expected to reach $8.2 trillion, or nearly twice what it had been just a decade earlier. In India, annual consumer spending is expected to rise even more dramatically, from about $1.5 trillion currently to $6 trillion by 2030. In order to enable people who deserve to have their hard work translate into an ability to buy the things they need, and want, more infrastructure is necessary - more roads enabling access to urban areas, and more bank branches to access cash. However, increased global consumption will inevitably have an environmental impact. People need to be educated about making sustainable choices, and those choices need to become more accessible and affordable.

name: Future of Economic Progress
description: Global economic progress is falling short of expectations. The uncertainty caused by technologies associated with the Fourth Industrial Revolution, dramatic shifts in international cooperation and trade, and political upheaval have left many disillusioned - and triggered social tension, worsening inequality, and a more urgent need to foster cooperation on addressing climate change. One means to achieve better protection of the environment, more inclusive development, and revived productivity growth could be greater public-private collaboration.

name: Future of Energy
description: Energy consumption and production account for about two-thirds of global greenhouse gas emissions, and 81% of the global energy mix is still based on fossil fuels - the same percentage as 30 years ago. A transition to a more inclusive, sustainable, affordable, and secure global energy system that addresses global challenges while creating value is needed. This must be done without upsetting the balance of the “energy triangle”: security and access; environmental sustainability; and economic development and growth. The World Economic Forum aims to accelerate the public-private cooperation required to enable this transition.   This Transformation Map is informed by the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Scott Burger, Research Associate and MIT energy fellow, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Simon Engelke, PhD Candidate, University of Cambridge.

name: Future of Food
description: Nearly 800 million people go hungry every day around the world, more than 2 billion lack the nutrients required for a healthy life, and one third of the global population is expected to be overweight or obese by 2030, according to the Global Panel on Agriculture and Food Systems for Nutrition. Rapid population growth, increasing urbanization, and an expanding global middle class will have profound impacts on food and nutrition security, and will place intense additional pressure on the environment. The agriculture industry remains one of the biggest sources of greenhouse gas emissions, and is particularly vulnerable to drought and rising sea levels triggered by climate change.

name: Future of Health and Healthcare
description: The global population will balloon from 7.6 billion to 9.7 billion by 2050, according to the United Nations - while the number of people over the age of 60 will increase to roughly 2 billion by that point. The world is currently ill-equipped to respond to these trends, and the global health system will have to undergo major transformation, and attract greater amounts of investment in disease prevention and health promotion, in order to ensure that an expanding global population can live better and longer lives.

name: Future of Mobility
description: Mobility is a fundamental human need, and an essential enabler of prosperity. But the current mobility paradigm is not sustainable; car travel causes millions of deaths every year, a significant amount of greenhouse gas emissions are transport-related, and congestion causes heavy financial losses. There is hope on the horizon, however - the global mobility system is in the early stages of massive transformation, as new technologies enable innovative related businesses, and as policy-makers seek out ways to foster mobility that is smarter, cleaner, and more inclusive.

name: Gender Parity
description: The progress made in closing gender gaps when it comes to education has helped to expand global talent pools. However, persistent barriers remain - hindering both women’s entry into the labour force, and their subsequent progression. In order to galvanize further necessary action, we need to continue to make the case for gender equality; more attention must be paid to the re-balancing of family care responsibilities and careers, and a greater focus must be placed on changing prevailing gender dynamics in the workplace.

name: Geo-economics
description: Intensifying international competition has made geo-economics - the use of economic tools like sanctions or trade deals to achieve political goals - common practice. One particularly visible impact has been a shift in international trade relations, as large economies use what advantage they can to protect politically important industries while hampering those of rivals. However, the increased strategic use of economic tools by states, or state-owned enterprises, promises to have even broader consequences. Increasingly, directed cyberattacks, devastating economic sanctions, and government investment in strategic infrastructure abroad will dominate the global agenda.

name: Geopolitics
description: Geopolitics, or the implications of the distribution of power among the world’s nation states, has changed dramatically during the past half century. In an increasingly multipolar and multi-conceptual world, singular ideas about how best to look after global affairs have been replaced by a diffusion of power and political values. This is unlikely to be a passing phase. The fractured geopolitical landscape creates new risks, and calls into question alliances and multilateral institutions that have been cornerstones of the global order since World War II. It also threatens humanity’s ability to respond to pressing global challenges like climate change, economic interdependence, and the impact of the Fourth Industrial Revolution.

name: Germany
description: Germany’s economic and political strengths have traditionally reinforced its prominent role within the European Union. However, challenges including an influx of refugees have left the country divided, and are testing its stability and EU leadership. Federal elections in 2017 demonstrated dissatisfaction with Chancellor Angela Merkel who, after announcing she would not seek another term as Chancellor, stepped down as leader of her party in 2018. In addition to political and migration-related difficulties, Germany also faces the strain of an ageing population, and the heavy cost of transitioning to a low-carbon energy supply.

name: Ghana
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Ghana based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: Global Governance
description: Global governance is a means to manage public issues that cut across national borders. Though traditionally centred on interstate diplomacy and international organizations, now a wide variety of public and private actors engage in cross-border governance - and the work itself has expanded beyond treaty-making and international law, to include formal and informal rule-making, monitoring, enforcement, and financing. Effective governance is essential to secure peaceful and prosperous societies, particularly in the face of recent, dramatic geopolitical shifts and nationalist backlash against globalization. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Thomas Hale, Associate Professor in Public Policy (Global Public Policy), Blavatnik School of Government, University of Oxford.

name: Global Health
description: Powerful forces are undermining efforts to protect and improve global health, necessitating changes in how we prevent, track, and respond to risks and disease outbreaks. Global demographic shifts, mounting environmental degradation and climate change, escalating humanitarian emergencies, technology innovation, and a growing global commitment to a universal right to healthcare are all driving change. These forces are being addressed by global health governing bodies, and by multi-stakeholder partnerships that increasingly recognize the links between health, poverty, and sustainable development. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Heather Wipfli, associate director at the USC Institute for Global Health and associate professor of preventive medicine at the Keck School of Medicine of USC & School of International Relations.

name: Global Risks
description: According to the 2019 iteration of the World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report, global risks - of events or conditions that may cause serious problems for entire countries or industries in the coming decade - are intensifying. Yet, the collective will to tackle them appears to be lacking. Instead, divisions are hardening as the idea of taking back control, either from domestic political rivals or from international organizations, is resonating in many countries. That is because while globalization has brought great prosperity, it has also led to pronounced inequality.

name: Healthcare Delivery
description: Global healthcare delivery systems are being developed in a fast-changing environment that is spawning both technological advances and ethical challenges; while developments like precision medicine create exciting opportunities, uncertainty and risk remain. Inequality, in terms of healthcare access and utilization, remains a global concern. Policy-makers have the difficult task of formulating evidence-based rules that can move the needle on related issues, including a troubling shortage of skilled healthcare workers.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Dana Goldman, Kukla Vera and Stephanie Hedt, respectively the Leonard D. Schaeffer Director’s Chair, External Affairs Director, and Policy Communications Associate at the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California (USC).

name: Human Enhancement
description: Human enhancement: just another buzzy term, or a very real phenomenon triggering effects that will soon be felt by everyone? Technology can now be deployed to extend and increase aspects of performance beyond natural limits, which may in turn transform the experience of being human. Although restoring bodily function has long been a common and generally accepted aspect of medical treatment, the emerging potential to go well beyond restoration calls for thoughtful reflection on potential consequences - both for individuals, and for society as a whole. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Simone Schuerle, Branco Weiss Fellow and Head of the Responsive Biomedical Systems Laboratory at the Institute of Translational Medicine at ETH Zurich.

name: Human Rights
description: Human rights are inherent regardless of sex, national or ethnic origin, religion, or language. They are grounded in the concept of equal moral status, which underpins legal rights both internationally (the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and related treaties) and domestically (in the form of Bills of Rights). All human rights are interrelated, interdependent, and indivisible. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Miles Jackson, Departmental Lecturer in International Law, Faculty of Law, University of Oxford.

name: Humanitarian Action
description: More than 130 million people - more than ever before - are in need of emergency aid. But humanitarian action is being hampered by political threats and bureaucratic barriers. Humanitarian law is being flouted, as hospitals, refugee camps, and aid workers become military targets. More than 68 million people have been left forcibly displaced by conflict and climate-related disasters, and the $25 billion raised annually to help them isn’t enough. However, a rotating cast of aid providers and funders is exploring new ways to reform ageing systems and save more lives. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Heba Aly, Director, and Ben Parker, Senior Editor, The New Humanitarian - an independent non-profit news organization based in Geneva.

name: Illicit Economy
description: Organized crime may prevent the achievement of nearly one quarter of the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals, according to the Global Initiative against Transnational Organized Crime. Illicit trade in people, goods, drugs, money, intellectual property, and natural resources has made criminal networks into multi-billion-dollar syndicates - undermining legitimate companies, the integrity of governments, and public security. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Mark Shaw and Tuesday Reitano, Director and Deputy Director of the Global Initiative against Transnational and Organized Crime.

name: Inclusive Design
description: Inclusive design is a people-centred strategy for innovation, rooted in progressive, post-World War II ideas about providing ways for the marginalized and excluded - whether economically, culturally or technologically - to gain greater access. Although they both have a similar purpose, it is important to recognize how inclusive design, which focuses on collaboration resulting in ‘one size fits one person,’ is different from “universal” design and its ‘one size fits all’ mandate. Current issues in the world of inclusive design that merit close attention include accessibility and disability, sustainability, human dignity, and the inclusiveness of cities. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the Smithsonian Institution.

name: India
description: About 1 million people join India’s workforce every month, and this country of roughly 1.3 billion is poised to hit a demographic sweet spot in about two decades - when the percentage of its population that is of working age reaches historic proportions. However, in order for India to successfully graduate from lower-middle-income status and comfortably take over from China as the world’s fastest-growing major economy, its government institutions must be rewired, its labour force and infrastructure must be better nourished, and its economy must become more open. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the IDFC Institute.

name: Information Technology
description: Information technology is at the core of a widespread democratization of innovation, and advances in the industry are having an impact on all continents and in every business. A number of related factors merit close scrutiny: the social aspects of impending and fundamental changes in employment; trust and privacy; “cyber-resilience”; and shifts in digital policy and governance.

name: Infrastructure
description: Infrastructure development is essential for economic development. Providing necessary infrastructure can boost health, wealth, access to education, and public safety - though for decades now, related investment has been stifled by shortages of skilled professionals, mismatched risk expectations, corruption, a lack of genuinely bankable projects, and disagreement on the proper role of private capital. More must be done to address these issues, and better ensure that the world has the infrastructure it needs.

name: Innovation
description: Innovation is the process of turning new ideas into value, in the form of new products, services, or ways of doing things. It is deceptively complex, and goes beyond mere creativity and invention to include the practical steps necessary for adoption. New innovations tend to build on earlier versions and, in turn, to lay foundations for others. It is now widely accepted that innovation fuels the majority of the world's long-term productivity and economic growth - and that innovative firms significantly outperform non-innovators, in terms of both revenue and employment growth.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Geoff Mulgan, Chief Executive of Nesta, and Christopher Haley, Head of Startups and New Technology Research, Nesta.

name: Institutional Investors
description: Institutional investors such as pension funds, insurers, and sovereign wealth funds find themselves in a changed world roughly a decade after the global financial crisis. As they more actively monitor standards and behaviour at the firms they invest in, invest based on long-term themes like ageing populations, and increasingly focus on environmental and social issues, institutional investors are playing a key role in the distribution of capital, the growth and sustainability of the private sector, and the promotion of strong corporate governance. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Bernardo Bortolotti, Professor of Economics and Finance, Università degli Studi di Torino and Director of the Sovereign Investment Lab at the Paolo Baffi Center of Central Banking and Financial Regulation at Bocconi University in Milan.

name: Insurance and Asset Management
description: The income earned by insurance companies in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries through gross premiums doubled between 2000 and 2016, to slightly more than $5 trillion, according to OECD data. For 2019, the global industry is expected to see a steady increase in premiums (excluding life insurance) of about 3%, with emerging markets providing much of that growth, according to a report published by Swiss Re. In order for the insurance industry to take full advantage of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and its associated technological advances, however, it must develop new risk assessment methodologies - and work together with a broad spectrum of stakeholders to reshape its role in society.

name: International Security
description: States, international organizations and trans-national actors all seek to ensure their vital interests and survival. Some of the most relevant current trends in international security include the return of great power competition, the spurring of a new arms race as a result of the military application of cutting-edge technology, the rising influence of non-state actors, and the expansion of domains of conflict at an unprecedented rate into space, cyberspace, the oceans and the Arctic.

name: International Trade and Investment
description: Global trade and investment are in flux, as major initiatives are either formed or renegotiated. The very legitimacy of the current global trading system, with the World Trade Organization at its core, is in focus - as policy-makers try to respond to the economic, social, and technology upheaval wrought by the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Trillions of dollars in additional investment needs to be unlocked if the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Paris Agreement are to have any chance at succeeding, and a genuinely inclusive global trade agenda could help make this a reality. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the World Trade Institute.

name: Internet Governance
description: The internet can continue to broadly aid social progress and businesses, drive innovation, and help governments address policy concerns - but only as long as its essential integrity remains intact. Responsible governance of the internet, however, is no simple task; stakeholders from around the world have varying interests in how the internet is segmented into accessible domains, how personal data is secured, and how the global companies that do most of their business online are taxed.

name: Internet of Things
description: The Internet of Things, or the “IoT,” surrounds us with networks of smart, web-connected devices and services capable of sensing, interconnecting, inferring, and acting. It is enabling the development of new products and business models, while creating ways for governments to deliver more useful services and better engage with the public. Some of the most important issues related to the IoT include technology architecture and standardization, safety and security risks, threats to privacy and trust, potentially missed opportunities for broad social benefits - and a need for responsible governance. This briefing is based on the views of a range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Joshua Siegel, Assistant Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at Michigan State University.

name: Italy
description: Italy is now run by a coalition government formed by the anti-establishment Five Star Movement (a party founded by comedian Beppe Grillo) and the centre-left Democratic Party. Following clashes between the previous government and the European Union over heavy spending plans that promised to tack on tens of billions of euros to the government’s budget, and potentially derail years of progress made in taming the deficit, the current coalition is expected to be more cooperative with the EU as it seeks to right the country's finances. While Italy’s unemployment rate declined during 2018, falling below 10%, the European Commission has projected that the country’s GDP growth will also decline - to 1.1% in 2019, from 1.5% in 2017. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Francesco Daveri, SDA Professor of Economics at Bocconi University.

name: Japan
description: Japan is tackling serious challenges that other countries are bound to face in the future, such as a shrinking and ageing population. Other issues are more uniquely Japanese - like a culture of overwork, and mounting pressure to open the labour market to foreign workers. As the country grapples with these matters, it has prompted a need to revisit value systems and to seek out a shared understanding of Japan's future.

name: Jordan
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Jordan based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: Justice and Legal Infrastructure
description: Legal rules provide the fundamental infrastructure required for economic growth and stable societies. But the legal systems historically developed for industrialized nations are now under enormous pressure, due to the economic and social complexities tied to globalization and technology advancements. Government-based legal systems have developed gaps in their ability to provide justice and order, contributing to political instability and backlash. Meanwhile regulatory complexity is growing exponentially, and creating demand for clearer global standards, more agile governance, and legitimate private-sector alternatives. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Gillian Hadfield, the Richard L. and Antoinette Schamoi Kirtland Professor of Law and Professor of Economics at the University of Southern California.

name: Kenya
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Kenya based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: Latin America
description: Trade tensions, volatile commodity markets, and general uncertainty in several large Latin American countries have dulled projections for economic growth in the region. Local policy-makers continue to search for more sustainable sources of long-term growth, for measures to more effectively promote integrity and transparency, and for ways to better prepare the labour force for a more technology-driven future. While some countries in Latin America are seeing action on long-awaited reforms, persistent inequality calls for a greater focus on inclusive growth and efficiency. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the Inter-American Development Bank.

name: Leadership in the Fourth Industrial Revolution
description: Many aspects of the ways that governments and businesses operate are in flux, due in large part to the sweeping technology changes propelling the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Leadership is no exception. As a new generation of leaders take on challenges such as striking a healthy balance of views expressed on their social media platforms, developing private efforts to fill gaps in public social protections, and crafting public policies that govern technology access, an ability to apply responsibility and purpose will be key.

name: Media and Entertainment
description: The global media and entertainment landscape has been upended by new business models, consumer-driven content, and digital consumption and distribution. This instability has a direct impact on media output - and influences cultures and broader societies. As boundaries that once defined media companies further dissolve, new technologies will shape habits and raise expectations. Restoring trust will be critical, particularly amid demands for greater transparency on the use of personal data. The ways that organizations seek to rebuild that trust, and better protect data while also creating quality content, will shape their futures.

name: Mental Health
description: The global cost of mental health conditions (and related consequences) is projected a rise to $6 trillion by 2030, from $2.5 trillion as of 2010, according to a study published by the World Economic Forum and the Harvard School of Public Health. That would make the cost of poor mental health greater than that of cancer, diabetes, and respiratory ailments combined. While mental health-related issues continue to have a serious impact on productivity and economic well-being, opportunities to improve awareness, analysis, and treatment abound.

name: Mexico
description: Mexico's economy is the second biggest in Latin America and among the largest in the world, but oil price uncertainty and government spending cuts have weighed on its economic health. GDP is expected to grow by just 1.6% in 2019. Government reforms appear to be making headway, though economic and social disparities persist among the country’s 32 states - as trade openness and the NAFTA agreement (now known as “USMCA”) have mainly created opportunities only in regions with geographic or logistical advantages. The government must address gaps that exist between the country’s modern productivity and its traditional, unregulated economy, while also tackling corruption, the impunity of unscrupulous officials, and organized crime. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the Inter-American Development Bank.

name: Middle East and North Africa
description: The Middle East and North Africa is home to a youthful population, unique energy resources, and some of the fastest-growing economies in the world. However, the region is also now undergoing fundamental political, economic, and social change, and experiencing a period of great geopolitical uncertainty. This promises to radically reshape the regional landscape, and will have profound global implications.

name: Migration
description: The United Nations has estimated that as of 2017 there were 258 million international migrants globally, equal to 3.4% of the world’s population - compared with 155 million as of 2000, or 2.8% of the population. Most international migrants move for work; one analysis found that there were 164 million migrant workers in 2017. When internal migration is taken into account, roughly one-seventh of the world’s inhabitants are estimated to have migrated at least once in their lives. Emigration and immigration provide tremendous opportunities, though there are related challenges tied to integration, social cohesion, labour, and border management. In addition, migration is a topic where potentially helpful information and data remain fragmented - and often under-analysed. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Marie McAuliffe, Head of Migration Policy Research at the International Organization for Migration (IOM).

name: Mining and Metals
description: The mining and metals industry is recovering from one of its most difficult periods in decades. Market volatility and a downturn in commodity prices have created a new normal where cost cuts, automation, and operational efficiency are a must. Meanwhile industry-specific issues related to regulation, geopolitical risk, legal limits on natural resource use, shareholder activism, and public scrutiny have created additional challenges. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Perrine Toledano, Head of Extractive Industries, and Nicolas Maennling, Senior Economics and Policy Researcher, at the Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment - a joint center of Columbia Law School and the Earth Institute at Columbia University.

name: Neuroscience
description: Healthy brain function is an essential foundation for childhood development, education, social interaction, and professional life. The prevalence of brain disorders has imposed a heavy financial and emotional burden throughout the world, and will only worsen as global populations age. However, progress made in terms of understanding the structure and function of the brain, as well as the genetic and environmental bases of brain development, is providing us with significant insights into the causes of disorders. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with John Maunsell, Director of the Grossman Institute for Neuroscience, Quantitative Biology & Human Behavior at the University of Chicago.

name: Nigeria
description: Nigeria is endowed with immense potential, but has been constrained by ineffective leadership, weak governance, limited infrastructure development, a high rate of youth unemployment, and outsized impacts of climate change. With its population of roughly 190 million the country has the biggest, and one of the youngest, consumer markets in the region. And while oil and gas remain the primary source of government revenue, there are other natural resources in abundance, such as gold and copper. With committed leadership, the country should be able to effectively address its challenges, diversify its economy, and achieve more sustainable, inclusive growth. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Franklin Nnaemeka Ngwu, Chris Ogbechie, and Olayinka David-West, of Lagos Business School.

name: Nuclear Security
description: At a time of increased geopolitical tension, an international focus on nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament is as important as ever; the possibility of a new arms race cannot be ruled out. Little has been achieved in terms of reducing existing nuclear stockpiles - and the administration of US President Donald Trump has signaled a desire to develop new nuclear weapons capabilities. Meanwhile the emergence of nuclear energy programmes in a number of countries around the world merits close attention. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Man-Sung Yim, Professor at the Nuclear Energy Environment and Nuclear Security Laboratory, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST).

name: Oceans
description: Oceans are a critically important source of nutritious food, income, inspiration, and stability. A 2017 estimate published by the consultancy BCG valued global “ocean assets” at more than $24 trillion. However, marine ecosystems face dangers that put this value at risk, like climate change, ocean warming, increased acidification, oxygen depletion, pollution, overfishing, and illegal fishing. Innovative policies, strong business leadership, and disruptive technologies will all be essential to navigate towards a cleaner and safer future. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Douglas McCauley, Marine Biologist and Assistant Professor, University of California, Santa Barbara.

name: Oil and Gas
description: Oil and gas have been critical for global economic growth and development for more than a century. They are still being used to meet more than half of the world’s primary energy needs, though the industry is fraught with challenges: geopolitical stress, boom-and-bust investment cycles, market uncertainty, and the need for greater environmental sustainability. While the sense of urgency about these issues varies in different parts of the world based on regional history, levels of economic prosperity, and adoption of technology, the industry will nonetheless continue to play a critical role in the transformation of the global energy landscape.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Kenneth B. Medlock, Senior Director, Center for Energy Studies, Anna Mikulska, Nonresident Fellow in Energy Studies, and Michael D. Maher, Senior Program Advisor, at the James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy, Rice University.

name: Pakistan
description: Pakistan, with its population of nearly 200 million and blend of social classes, is still striving to realize the vision of its founder - of an inclusive nation where everyone is treated equally. While unemployment continues to result from the country's structural shift to a services-based economy, its recent history of prolonged power outages is being addressed with newly-built capacity. Pakistan is meanwhile navigating a lack of trust in the West, as it aims to resolve outstanding issues with India and collaborate with China (not least through China’s Belt and Road Initiative). Efforts are also being made to more effectively curb extremism, better protect natural resources, narrow gender gaps, and address high levels of domestic abuse. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Dr. Abid Qaiyum Suleri, Executive Director of the Sustainable Development Policy Institute.

name: Peru
description: Peru is a middle-income country with aspirations to join the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. However, a decline in global commodity prices has weighed on its economic and social advancement, and the country ranked 72nd out of 137 measured in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018. The challenges facing Peru will require institutional modernization, improved public governance, expanded infrastructure development, and better natural resource management. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the Inter-American Development Bank.

name: Plastics and the Environment
description: About 350 million tonnes of plastics are produced annually, and more than half of that is dumped in either a landfill or the oceans every year. Plastics - whether soluble, disposable, or durable - cause pollution at almost every stage of their lifecycle, starting with the use of fossil fuels for their production. However, they are also essential for a cleaner and more sustainable future, thanks to practical applications ranging from water-purification to medical devices. New non-petrochemical feedstocks and materials, policies, and regulations are required in order to responsibly reduce plastic consumption and transition to a more circular plastics economy. Emerging technologies, such as chemical recycling, may accelerate this transformation.   This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with the Oxford Martin Programme on the Future of Plastics, a collaboration of the Faculty of Law, Department of Chemistry and Smith School of Enterprise and Environment at the University of Oxford.

name: Portugal
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Portugal based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: Precision Medicine
description: The ultimate goal of Precision Medicine, also referred to as Personalized Medicine, is to enable the use of information about a patient’s genes and environment. Physicians and scientists can utilize this data to more accurately identify or predict disease, delay or prevent the onset of disease, and develop more effective treatment. This could be aided by sciences like genomics, developing technology to better parse massive data sets, and by improving our understanding of the relationship between differences in DNA and basic biological mechanisms. Precision Medicine faces challenges, however, related to the healthcare workforce, costs, equal access to care, and data privacy. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with David H. Perlmutter, MD, executive vice chancellor for medical affairs and dean of Washington University School of Medicine.

name: Private Investors
description: Private investors such as hedge funds, private equity firms and venture capital firms act as intermediaries by deploying capital on behalf of limited partners. They are vulnerable to shifts in regulation, changing levels of trust and the disruption of their business models - particularly now, amid the upheaval caused by the Fourth Industrial Revolution. In recent years, the major source of funding for private investors has shifted from high-net worth individuals to institutional investors. The fortunes of private investors are therefore now more closely tied to the trends that have traditionally affected institutional investors, like pension reform, changes in monetary policy and fluctuating demand for alternative assets.

name: Public Finance and Social Protection
description: Many countries in both the developed and the developing worlds face serious challenges when it comes to providing retirement security for the elderly, opportunity for young people, and broader financial well-being for everyone. As life expectancy rates increase, and government participation in benefits programs declines, new approaches are needed in order to support ageing populations. Meanwhile the methods adopted to stabilize national economies must better account for resulting impacts on vulnerable populations, and the systems we use to identify those most in need must be improved.

name: Real Estate
description: Developments in the real estate sector can reflect broader social issues; rising house prices can trigger debates about wealth inequality, and the same sort of technology innovation now reshaping the real estate industry and related financial markets is nurturing entrepreneurship and economic gains around the world. The real estate market can be a source of broader instability, in the case of housing bubbles, but can also provide tools for mitigating risk and combatting corruption. Green technology and big data are fostering sustainable urban living and healthy environments, while the science of real estate development is helping shape global infrastructure investment, logistics, and transportation. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Yongheng Deng, Professor, Department of Real Estate and Urban Land Economics, Wisconsin School of Business, University of Wisconsin-Madison.

name: Republic of Korea
description: Since 1960, when GDP per capita in the Republic of Korea (South Korea) was just $158, the country has been on a path of extraordinary economic, political, and social development that has now established it as the 11th largest economy in the world, according to the World Bank. The country’s expertise and exports have evolved from light and heavy industries, to higher value-added sectors like semiconductors, mobile phones and even pop culture. As South Korea recovers from a bout of political instability following former President Park Gyun-hye's ouster in 2017, it must grapple with increased risk on the Korean Peninsula emanating from its northern neighbour, in addition to demographic and social changes that threaten its economic competitiveness.

name: Retail, Consumer Goods and Lifestyle
description: The 21st century consumer landscape is remarkably different from its 20th century predecessor. Material goods sitting in stores once defined the market, but people now expect more. The wealthy are seeking out luxury experiences, and are spending heavily on long-term investments like education and retirement. Meanwhile much of the middle class's spending has actually been limited by the sort of wage stagnation affecting the US and the United Kingdom - though today's global middle class consumer is as likely to come from Mumbai as Minnesota. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Elizabeth Currid-Halkett, Professor and James Irvine Chair in Urban and Regional Planning at the University of Southern California (USC).

name: Role of Religion
description: Religion is everywhere on the global stage. From Pope Francis to the Islamic State, and from the forced migration of refugees from the Middle East to the related responses made by populist politicians in Europe and elsewhere, many contemporary global issues have some relationship to religion. Both presently and throughout history, religion has been both a cause of a great many ills, and a force for hope and good. ﻿This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Shaun Casey, Director, Berkley Center for Religion, Peace & World Affairs, Georgetown University.

name: Russian Federation
description: The Russian Federation boasts the 12th largest economy in the world, and is a significant power at the crossroads of Europe and Asia. The country has grappled with declines in commodity prices, and the effects of economic sanctions imposed by the US and other nations - clarifying a need to rethink its future development and its place within a new geo-economic reality. This may result in much-needed reform of the country’s economy and its institutions, and in the further development of its small- and medium-sized businesses and non-energy sector economy.

name: Saudi Arabia
description: Saudi Arabia is a nation of roughly 30 million people, where about half of the population is under the age of 25. Some three-quarters of the value of Saudi exports are still accounted for by petroleum, and about 60% of government revenue is oil-based - prompting recent efforts to diversify, particularly amid a global shift towards greater sustainability. Regional geopolitical developments have meanwhile raised questions about Saudi Arabia’s place in the world. Under its current leadership, the kingdom is making efforts to develop a new social contract, by fostering the infrastructure and liberalization necessary for a knowledge-based economy fuelled by technology innovation.

name: Social Innovation
description: Social innovation is driven by purpose, partnership, and accountability, in order to develop solutions that enable traditionally excluded people to participate in the economy. It is the process of applying new solutions to global problems, by creating or improving products, services, business models, and markets - and more effectively responding to unmet needs. Collaboration among businesses, the government, and civil society that cuts across boundaries is essential for social enterprises to increase the scale of their impact. These enterprises can be non-profits like First Book, which provides books for children in need, or for-profits that embed a social mission in their business, like outdoor clothing company Patagonia.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Vanina Farber, Professor and elea Chair for Social Innovation, IMD Business School.

name: South Africa
description: Following the end of the apartheid, South Africa held its first democratic elections and pursued sound economic policies. Now, the country of roughly 56 million people faces significant challenges including relatively high rates of corruption, unemployment, and inequality - and a decline in demand for the commodities on which its economy has relied. More than half of the population lives below the poverty line, and the legacy of apartheid is apparent in the spatial division between rural, non-white communities and economic hubs. Still, the country remains one of the most competitive in sub-Saharan Africa, and it boasts one of the region’s most innovative economies.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Haroon Bhorat, Professor of Economics in the School of Economics and Director of the Development Policy Research Unit (DPRU) at the University of Cape Town.

name: Space
description: Space is more relevant to our daily lives than ever before. It offers the potential for a future economy, enhanced social and cultural development, international peace and security, and natural resources. The orbits around Earth provide critical satellite infrastructure for communications, networking, imaging, weather monitoring, and navigation - though commercial and defence-related activity could potentially fuel a hostile space race. Greater collaboration in space, in the form of rules-based governance, may help ensure a more prosperous and peaceful future. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Ram Jakhu, Associate Professor at the Institute of Air and Space Law in the Faculty of Law at McGill University.

name: Sri Lanka
description: Since the end of Sri Lanka’s civil war in 2009, the country has sought to regain stability with the aid of government reforms. Efforts have been made to rebuild international alliances, strengthen foreign policy, and restore genuine non-alignment (the policy of maintaining a neutral distance from global powers). Other priorities include ethnic reconciliation and peace-building. With its potentially promising economic outlook, increasing infrastructure development, enviable location for trade, and educated work force, Sri Lanka is at a crucial juncture. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Kithmina Hewage, Research Officer at the Institute of Policy Studies of Sri Lanka (IPS).

name: Supply Chain and Transport
description: Supply chains are the circulatory system of the global economy, providing access to the things we need to support commerce and sustain life. Despite their vital importance, most people have little appreciation of the complexity of supply chains, and only notice them when they are disrupted and become problematic. While the economic performance of supply chains has steadily improved, their environmental impact and vulnerability have become major sources of concern. The responsibility for much of the physical movement, handling and storage of products has been outsourced to specialized logistics service providers, and their task grows more complex as global economic activity expands. According to Allied Market Research, the global logistics market is growing 3.5% annually, and will be worth $12.3 trillion by 2022. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Professor Alan McKinnon and colleagues at Kühne Logistics University.

name: Sustainable Development
description: The good news is that the global middle class is expanding, and millions of people are being lifted out of poverty. The bad news: wealth inequality within countries, in both the industrialized and developing worlds, is actually worsening. Meanwhile many people (23 million in 2017 alone) are already being displaced by natural catastrophes aggravated by the effects of climate change. While a number of public-private partnerships have been formed to tackle these issues, more must be done to restructure development finance in such a way that makes it more attractive to a wider array of investors. Excluding people from the benefits of economic growth can undermine the sustainability of that growth - and failing to address serious environmental issues, like threats to biodiversity and natural resources, is a formula for disaster.

name: Sustainable Development Impact Summit 2019
description: Every day, new evidence emerges of humanity’s negative impact on the environment and growing inequalities within society. The latest statistics show that 30% of the world’s population lacks access to clean water, global warming is creating more frequent and deadly weather patterns, 262 million children are not in school, and income inequality is on the rise, with 3.4 billion people living on less than $5.50 a day. These crises highlight the fragility of human existence, and we have just over a decade to resolve them. The Sustainable Development Impact Summit is the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting for integrating and leveraging the best examples of public-private cooperation, systems thinking and Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies to progress the Sustainable Development Agenda. The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Paris Agreement provide the architecture for resolving the world’s challenges, by fundamentally shifting the way society produces, consumes and operates. Realizing this opportunity requires the cooperation of multiple stakeholders, worldwide. Taking place during the UN General Assembly, the summit engages the most relevant and influential leaders across business, government, civil society, NGOs and academia, to collaborate and address the world’s most pressing problems.

name: Switzerland
description: Switzerland benefits from stable economic and political environments, low unemployment, above-average income levels, and a top-flight education and research environment; it was ranked fourth out of 140 countries in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index for 2018. However, Switzerland is also facing a number of challenges: constant, upward pressure on the Swiss Franc that can hinder exports and economic strength; regular political referendums that put the country at risk of becoming more isolated and less globally competitive; and an expanding, ageing population that may test the limits of the country's labour market, healthcare system, and infrastructure. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Dr. Thomas Bieger, President, University of St. Gallen, and Dr. Peter Vogel, Professor of Family Business and Entrepreneurship, IMD International.

name: Thailand
description: This Transformation Map explores key issues for Thailand based on its rankings in the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index (a full version of the 2018 Index is available under the “Data” tab below). Unlike the expert-curated Transformation Maps for other economies and topics, these Index-based maps zero in on six areas where a country has the greatest room to improve - based on rankings that reflect a “progress score,” or distance from an ideal policy situation. While some individual rankings may appear unusually high or low, that can merely be the result of a large number of peers having identical progress scores in a particular category - which may group them into a single ranking at one end of the spectrum.

name: Turkey
description: Turkey is a crucial existing or coveted ally sitting at the dividing line between East and West. The country has experienced rising populism and unrest, drawing scrutiny from both watchdog organizations and allies. Meanwhile it has struggled to set an optimal course when it comes to monetary policy and industrial transformation, made strides to more eagerly embrace new technologies, and found it difficult to maintain a healthy relationship with the European Union - where full membership remains a goal - on its own terms. Regionally, the country’s location beside an ongoing civil war in Syria has made it both a key player in that conflict, and home to the largest population of refugees in the world. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Selva Demiralp, Professor of Economics, and Şuhnaz Yılmaz, Professor of International Relations, Koç University, together with Seda Demiralp, Associate Professor, Faculty of Economics and Administrative Sciences, Işık University.

name: United Arab Emirates
description: The United Arab Emirates (UAE), a federation with a collective population of about 10 million, aims to foster one of the most diversified economies in the Middle East and North Africa region. The country is already recognized as a leading global financial and transportation hub with world-class infrastructure, and it is shaping a development agenda that looks beyond oil dependency by prioritizing the adoption of renewable energy and greater investment in innovation. According to the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index, the country boasts the most competitive economy in the MENA region, and the 27th most competitive in the world.

name: United Kingdom
description: The United Kingdom is seeking to forge a new relationship with its biggest trading partner, the European Union, following the 2016 decision by UK voters to leave the 28-nation bloc. The UK government has sought to negotiate the terms of its divorce from the EU with mixed results, while also seeking to reassure voters that their quality of life and economic standing will not suffer as a result. Other challenges for the UK’s leadership include addressing widened social and economic divides, fostering a greater independence from fossil fuels, and preserving and revitalizing the country's National Health Service.

name: United States
description: The United States remains an economic and geopolitical powerhouse, though new questions about its role on the world stage have surfaced during the presidency of Donald Trump. While the US economy is still widely admired, uncertainties about unemployment, inequality, and the country’s ability to remain competitive loom large. The US must try to capitalize on the opportunities that come with global leadership, while minimizing the pitfalls - amid ongoing domestic political and social upheaval.

name: Values
description: Values are the basis of personal and collective judgments about what is important in life - influenced by culture, religion, and laws. They are factors in our decision-making on social, environmental, and political matters, and on the best uses of our time, money, and natural resources. One of the most essential values in the midst of the disconcerting changes wrought by the Fourth Industrial Revolution is trust; between the governed and governments, and between civil society and the private sector.

name: Viet Nam
description: In the more than thirty years since Viet Nam implemented the so-called “Doi Moi” reforms opening up its centrally-planned economy, the country’s achievements include decades of average annual economic growth above 6%, and a more than two thousand percent increase in income per capita (from about $100 in the 1990’s to $2,215 by 2016). The country has joined the World Trade Organization, and has participated in several free trade agreements. However, unlike China, where global economic integration has spurred development miracles, Viet Nam has struggled with instability. Issues include weakness among state-owned enterprises, uneven foreign investment, a fragile banking sector, rising public debt, sluggish productivity, and widespread corruption. Living conditions have improved, the middle class has expanded, and startup activity has developed, but a truly prosperous Viet Nam will only be made possible through fundamental reforms. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Nguyen Xuan Thanh, senior lecturer at Fulbright University Vietnam and senior fellow at Harvard Kennedy School, and Do Thien Anh Tuan, lecturer at Fulbright University Vietnam.

name: Virtual and Augmented Reality
description: Virtual reality was dreamed up in science fiction, and began to emerge in concrete form via an immersive film-viewing cabinet created in the 1950s. Now, commercial applications for virtual and augmented reality (VR and AR) are flourishing, and fundamentally altering the way individuals interact with each other and their environments. While technological barriers and a lack of content have prevented mass adoption, VR may soon become the next generation platform for communication, displacing our need for physical travel and impacting related energy consumption. VR can also reduce the time required for product development cycles, and increase online sales. New forms of immersive games, cinematic experiences and news media will emerge, and captivate audiences by putting them in the middle of events.  This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with Hao Li, Assistant Professor of Computer Science, University of Southern California (USC), USC Institute for Creative Technologies, and Founder and CEO of Pinscreen.

name: Water
description: Securing an adequate supply of clean water despite the damaging effects of climate change is one of the world’s most urgent challenges. Billions of people are going without safe drinking water and sanitation, while the shrinking of significant water bodies like Lake Chad is spurring migration and heated competition for resources. Agriculture accounts for roughly three-quarters of global freshwater withdrawals, and agriculture-related nutrients are depleting and polluting watersheds in the world’s breadbaskets. Dam building, meanwhile, is increasing geopolitical tension. These issues can be addressed with more prudent planning and cooperation, and through greater investment, data analysis, and technological innovation. This briefing is based on the views of a wide range of experts from the World Economic Forum’s Expert Network and is curated in partnership with J. Carl Ganter, Managing Director, Circle of Blue, Brett Walton, Water News Correspondent, Circle of Blue, and Cody Pope, Senior Producer, Circle of Blue.

name: Workforce and Employment
description: The world of work is changing fast; recognizing and mapping new work models will be essential for channelling that change into the creation of stronger labour markets. Job creation is a constant on the global agenda, as are policies intended to ensure greater protections for both workers and their employers. The most successful approaches will utilize a firm understanding of demographics, of shifting job roles, and of the evolving demand for skills - and will leverage disruption as a means to design ideal contemporary workplaces.

name: Youth Perspectives
description: Young people account for more than half of the world’s population, yet are under-represented in global affairs. The World Economic Forum’s Global Shapers Survey, an assessment of nearly 25,000 people aged 35 and under, is designed to help better align their needs and expectations with global governance - by measuring their perceptions of the way the world works, and examining how they feel they might become more involved. The most recent edition of the survey reflected optimism, a desire for honesty and integrity, a sense of shared destiny that transcends borders, and a cautious embrace of technology.

name: name
description: description

name: 21st Century Curricula
