So-called vehicle-to-everything connectivity, or V2X, is an area of particular interest when it comes to implementing standards, as it underpins several important automotive industry trends including ride-hailing and autonomous driving. A particular area of concern relates to the use 5G wireless technology as opposed to WiFi. While telecommunications giant Vodafone favours 5G, for example, not all companies in the auto industry are on the same page when it comes choosing a standard.

name: Autonomous Transportation
description: Large drones, originally invented for military missions, are almost ready for general transportation use. These drones are expected to be integrated into civil airspace after 2020, when the International Civil Aviation Organization releases rules for worldwide operation. Meanwhile smaller drones are already gaining popularity, thanks to their low operating costs and low risk. Agencies such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in the US are developing a new drone traffic management system, and we may soon see crowds of drones in the sky that resemble scenes from a science fiction film. These machines are expected to create new job opportunities in some cases, and to take away jobs in others. Autonomous cars, unlike drones, are not yet ready for prime time. The latest self-driving cars, however, are equipped with sensors that can see in night time darkness and scan their surroundings more than 10 times per second, with extreme accuracy. Their brains are state-of-the-art computers that can make trillions of calculations per second, and communicate both with other cars and with the cloud in order to receive the latest traffic updates.  Self-driving cars compute an optimal path by sensing their environment and predicting the movement of obstacles. During this process, artificial intelligence views human life as a cost in its calculations. But it is very difficult to represent the value of human lives as a cost function in a mathematical equation. And no matter how sophisticated the on-board artificial intelligence, it is very difficult to assess how much collateral damage a potential collision will cause beyond impact. Only when autonomous cars’ accident rate is proven to be significantly lower than that of human drivers will they be broadly welcomed and deemed safe enough to carry human passengers. In 2016, Airbus announced plans for an autonomous air taxi - and later that year Uber announced its own plans for an autonomous air taxi. In the meantime, however, Uber has had to deal with safety issues; in 2018, an Uber autonomous car struck and killed a pedestrian in Arizona. If and when autonomous drones and cars are granted equal right of way in civil airspace and on roads, it will prompt an interesting question: should robotic workers be granted similar privileges at work that protect them from discrimination?

name: Avoiding Disparities
description: Important health discoveries have been made using genomic technologies such as those used to sequence and analyse DNA. However, it is necessary to capture genomic information (related to all of the genetic code within a cell) from a wide range of people in order to avoid increasing health disparities. Early genomic research focused primarily on populations with European ancestry; in 2009, 96% of the people accounted for in genome-wide association studies (or GWAS) were of European descent. By 2016, diversity in GWAS studies had improved - 19% were of non-European ancestry, with most of the growth among those of Asian ancestry. GWAS studies have shown that different genes among different ethnic groups may be implicated in both genetic and communicable diseases. In the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute’s Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) program, which began in 2014, African American genomes make up 26% of the total analysed, while Hispanic/Latino genomes make up just 10% - non-European genomes clearly remain underrepresented. Unless genomic research becomes more inclusive, minority populations will not realize the promise of Precision Medicine, and health disparities will only continue to grow.  Genomic architecture can vary widely across populations, and rare variants - important for determining disease risk and drug response - tend to be population-specific. However, incorporating diverse populations in genomic research presents methodological and analytical challenges. The research community must therefore develop and incorporate new research designs and analytic tools necessary to overcome these challenges. The inclusion of diverse populations in the design of a research study must also be rewarded. Advances in genomics research should help to ameliorate, rather than contribute to health disparities among diverse populations. In addition, it is possible that the inclusion of diverse populations will bring the benefit of identifying important genes and pathways for a variety of diseases, and improve overall human health.

name: Balance of Care and Careers
description: In many societies, even as women have entered the labour force, they have also retained primary responsibility for unpaid work such as family care-giving and household chores. In this way, gender gaps in terms of paid work are partly a reflection of gender gaps in unpaid work. In advanced economies, men do just 34% of the unpaid work that women do, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization data show that this imbalance starts early, with girls spending 30% more of their time on unpaid work than boys. On average, women work 50 minutes more per day than men, in terms of both paid and unpaid work combined, according to the data. There is growing interest in better facilitating women’s integration into the workforce. According to a report published by the OECD in 2017, a number of countries have sought to increase fathers’ care-giving workload, such as the Czech Republic and Turkey, which in recent years have introduced statutory, paid paternity leave, while ten OECD member countries have begun offering financial incentives in order to encourage fathers to take parental leave for at least two months; South Korea offers as much as 100% wage replacement for three “daddy months,” according to the report.   Other care-related policies have included financial arrangements to facilitate care for elderly relatives, family benefits and other subsidies, career breaks, remote work programs, and flexible and reduced hours - in addition to services like home care for the elderly, and nursery care for small children. Such practices often represent long-term public and private investments, though they have the potential to generate strong social and economic returns. They can also produce sizeable spill-over effects. According to the International Trade Union Confederation’s 2016 report Investing in the Care Economy, if 2% of a country’s GDP were to be invested in its care industry, there would be corresponding increases in overall employment that range from 2.4% to 6.1%, depending on the location. This would equate to nearly 13 million new jobs in the US, 3.5 million new jobs in Japan, nearly 2 million in Germany, 1.5 million in the United Kingdom, and 1 million in Italy.

name: Bangladesh’s Infrastructure Deficit
description: Bangladesh has been investing in power generation capacity, port services, transportation infrastructure like road and rail networks, and expanded internet access. The percentage of the population with access to electricity increased to nearly 76% by 2016 from 50.5% in 2006, according to World Bank data, while the percentage of the population with a mobile broadband connection is expected to grow to 82% by 2025 from 29% in 2017 (according to the GSMA). Still, in order to boost economic competitiveness, Bangladesh must take steps to address a lingering infrastructure deficit. The poor state of infrastructure affects the movement of people and goods, productivity, and efficiency. According to the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Index for 2018, Bangladesh ranked 109th out of 140 countries in terms of quality of infrastructure. Capacity at the country’s international airports and sea ports must be increased, and urban transportation networks and intercity links remain weak. Significant investment is needed to address urban congestion and insufficient traffic management. The World Bank estimated in 2013 that Bangladesh will need to invest as much as $100 billion between 2011 and 2020 in order to develop sufficient infrastructure (the country’s GDP was about $250 billion as of 2017). The government’s Seventh Five Year Plan (covering the fiscal years through 2020) prioritizes infrastructure development. Bangladesh’s rail network, long neglected, is now receiving the attention it deserves. In recent years, government allocations for rail infrastructure have been on the rise. Between fiscal years 2011 and 2016, Bangladesh invested $21.4 billion in key infrastructure elements including transportation, communication, fuel, and energy. As it invests, Bangladesh must pursue development strategies that are as environmentally sustainable as they are economically viable. Projects will have to be tightly managed to rein in costs, and governance and management will need to be generally improved (as will transparency and accountability among government bodies and development institutions). If Bangladesh is to maximize its potential as a regional transport hub and gateway to the Bay of Bengal, the country must coordinate the development of transportation networks that are closely aligned with its long-term vision. In addition, the country must proactively explore new sources of financing - such as the BRICS Development Bank, and public-private partnerships.

name: Bangladesh’s Place in the World
description: In the early 1990s, Bangladesh made policy shifts in favour of trade liberalization, deregulation, and privatization. These have led to stronger global integration, and significant economic gains. According to the country’s central bank and the Bangladesh Export Promotion Bureau, the share of the country’s economy dedicated to importing and exporting (a measure of openness) rose to 34.9% by fiscal 2015-16, from 16.8% as of 1990-91. Bangladesh has benefitted from preferential market access to developed countries, thanks to its United Nations designation as a Least Developed Country. According to data published by the International Trade Centre, the country has emerged as the second largest exporter of apparel after China. It is strategically situated between China and the other rising power of the 21st century, India, and serves as a gateway to the Bay of Bengal. The country is a member of the South Asian Free Trade Area, it has joined a number of initiatives including the Bangladesh, China, India and Myanmar (BCIM) Economic Corridor, and is a participant in China’s massive Belt and Road infrastructure-building initiative. There is much progress yet to be made. Bangladesh’s exports are still overwhelmingly concentrated in apparel (more than 80% of the country’s global exports in fiscal 2016-17). In addition, markets in North America and Europe account for 72% of Bangladesh’s exports, which calls for diversification. According to the International Trade Centre data, members of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation account for just 6% of Bangladesh’s global trade; this region could become a significant importer of the country’s goods, with improved transportation logistics and trade facilitation. Some projects could reduce the cost of doing business with neighbours, such as the Bangladesh-Bhutan-India-Nepal (BBIN) motor vehicles agreement, which aims to open up members’ roadways to one another. Other projects could be enabled by financing from India, China, or the recently-established Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and help Bangladesh exploit its location and better explore its maritime resources. In recent years, Bangladesh has taken a number of important steps to attract more foreign direct investment, for example by establishing the Bangladesh Investment Development Authority, and by setting up Special Economic Zones. Initiatives are also underway to enhance local workforce skills.

name: Bangladesh’s Workforce
description: Bangladesh is expected to benefit from its relatively young, potentially productive workforce. According to the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics, people aged between 15 and 29 represented about one-third of the country’s working population of 62.1 million as of 2016 - and the median age of the broader population was just 26. This presents Bangladesh with a crucial window of opportunity, and the country’s ability to achieve its goal of transforming into a developed economy by 2040 will depend on not wasting that opportunity. Every year, on average, about 2 million additional people enter Bangladesh’s labour force, according to the government’s Seventh Five Year Plan published in 2015. The creation of new jobs in sectors like agriculture, ready-made garments, construction, fisheries, and services has accommodated a significant number of these new entrants. In addition, in a welcome related development, more women have been joining the labour force; according to labour force surveys, the female participation rate rose to 35.6% in 2015-16 from 26.1% in 2002-03. Bangladeshis working abroad make a significant contribution; more than half a million have been leaving annually to become migrant workers, mostly to countries in the Middle East. The remittances they sent home in 2016 amounted to about $13.6 billion, equivalent to roughly 7% of annual gross national income, according to Bangladesh Bank. The portion of that migrant workforce considered to be skilled rose to 42.1% as of 2016, from 22.7% in 2001, according to the country’s Bureau of Manpower, Employment and Training. In order to maximize its youthful workforce at home, Bangladesh must invest heavily in education, skills development, and technology. While education receives a significant share of the national budget (12.6% in fiscal 2017-18), attention should be paid to what those funds are providing. According to a 2016 International Institute for Labour Studies report, the country’s labour productivity is significantly lower than some of its competitors in the global apparel market (apparel accounts for more than 80% of Bangladesh’s exports). In addition, because 87.2% of the labour force toils in the unregulated, informal economy, creating well-paid, decent jobs is a daunting task.

name: Bankable Project Pipelines
description: The global infrastructure investment gap, or the difference between what is needed to build new infrastructure every year and what is actually being committed, is projected to reach $800 billion by 2040, according to the Global Infrastructure Outlook, a tool developed by the Global Infrastructure Hub and Oxford Economics. There is a general lack of bankable project pipelines (or programmed series of infrastructure projects), which are critical for drawing in essential private investment. While this issue is not necessarily new, it has become far more urgent due to increasingly strained public finances and continually mounting infrastructure demands. In the US alone, for example, the infrastructure investment gap is projected to grow from about $116 billion in 2020 to roughly $207 billion by 2040, according to the Global Infrastructure Outlook. Some of the obstacles to project bankability include a lack of skills and capacity, mismatched expectations for risk, and a lack of proper government planning. Public and private entities have been working together with governments to help improve the viability of project pipelines. These efforts range from creating national and regional project preparation facilities (which provide technical assistance for the structuring, financing, and execution of infrastructure projects), to initiatives like the World Economic Forum’s National Infrastructure Acceleration project - which takes a multi-stakeholder approach to helping governments deliver infrastructure. The G20 Eminent Persons Group on Global Financial Governance, established in 2017 to help promote economic stability, has proposed a raft of related measures, including asking governments to refocus efforts on building capacity and developing “human capital” (the attributes that can make people valuable to a company or a country), creating government-owned national investment platforms to mobilize development partners, and forming regional investment platforms that can facilitate multinational mega-projects. Potentially, increased attention to improving infrastructure project pipelines will boost the ability of governments to deliver infrastructure - and in turn boost social development and standards of living.

name: Batteries and Energy Transformation
description: The widespread deployment of batteries in power systems could enable some 600 million under-served people to gain access to energy by the year 2030, according to the Global Battery Alliance. Progress has been made in terms of enabling greater global access to electricity; according to the World Bank, as of 2019 the total number of people without access had declined to about 840 million, from 1 billion in 2016. However, the World Bank also reports that by 2030, some 650 million people may still be going without - and nine out of 10 of those people will be located in sub-Saharan Africa. In order to help address this issue, microgrids are being deployed throughout the region that are powered by batteries. In one example, the South African electric utility Eskom launched a pilot project designed to provide electricity to the 81 people in the rural Wilhelmina community in Ficksburg via a solar-powered microgrid. In a 2018 press release, Eskom said the microgrid deposits energy from the panels in three sets of lithium-ion batteries that offer 90 kilowatt hours of storage.                       The use of advanced battery technology could also help reduce air, water and land pollution. Replacing traditional, lead-acid batteries with more modern equivalents could help address serious related pollution issues, for example. According to a report published by the World Health Organization in 2017, the recycling of used lead-acid batteries is a public health concern because there is no known safe level of exposure to lead. As of 2016 data, nearly half a million deaths were a result of lead exposure, according to the report, with the heaviest related impacts on low- and middle-income countries, and on young children and women of childbearing age. Ultimately, the environmental benefits of greater battery use could include contributing to progress made towards achieving the goals set out by the Paris Agreement on climate change (in particular, the goal of limiting global warming to 2°C above pre-industrial temperatures) thanks to the decarbonization of both transportation via electric mobility, and of the power sector via the deployment of batteries to facilitate renewable energy. Emissions produced as part of the production of batteries must also be addressed. According to the Global Battery Alliance, greenhouse gas emissions intensity in the battery value chain could be nearly halved by 2030 by applying a more circular, sustainable approach.

name: Batteries in Cars, Batteries in Grids
description: By the year 2030, passenger cars will account for the biggest share of global battery demand, at about 60%, followed by commercial vehicles (23%), according to the Global Battery Alliance. Also by 2030, consumer electronics (think iPhones and tablets), will shrink from more than a fifth of the global battery market to only a “marginal” share, according to the alliance. As global battery demand grows by an expected 25% annually from now until 2030, they will power not only increasingly electrified transportation, but will also facilitate a shift from fossil fuel power generation to more sustainable models - via the deployment of batteries in power grids (and more decentralized, off-grid applications). Renewable energy sources tend to be intermittent (the sun is not always shining on solar panels, for example), creating an important role for batteries as a “balancing solution” capable of storing renewable energy until it is needed. In many ways, batteries are better suited to this role than, for example, pumped hydroelectric power - because of their flexibility (they can be installed in just about any environment) and relatively quick response times. Between 2015 and 2018, energy-storage battery demand grew by as much as 70% per year, and by the year 2030 roughly 220 gigawatt hours-worth of grid-connected batteries are expected to be installed, according to the Global Battery Alliance. Tesla installed a $96 million “big battery” in South Australia that is now used to provide storage and stability for the local power grid, and the company has indicated that the project has since led to even larger orders. Research is underway to bolster the safety of energy-storing technology - and mitigate incidents like the 2019 explosion and fire at a battery storage system installed by an Arizona utility to capture solar energy near Phoenix, which injured several people. Work is also being done to further develop so-called vehicle-to-grid, or V2G technology, which could coordinate power sharing between grids and plugged-in vehicles - and feed necessary energy into a grid during times of peak demand or emergencies. While this technology is still a work in progress, hopes are high that it could help answer questions about how to feed more intermittent - but necessary - sustainable energy into public power systems.

name: Battery Demand and Production
description: The cost of batteries essential for manufacturing electric vehicles has plummeted during the past decade, from about $1,400 per kilowatt hour to roughly $100 per kilowatt hour - enabled by a massive scaling-up of production. In 2019, a Volkswagen executive told the New York Times that the German automaker was paying less than $100 per kilowatt hour for batteries - a price generally accepted as the point where electric cars can start becoming more affordable than internal combustion models. Tesla was also reportedly on track to reach a cost of less than $100 per kilowatt hour as of 2018. Between 2010 and 2018, total battery demand grew by 30% annually, reaching a total volume of 180 gigawatt hours, according to a report published in 2019 by the Global Battery Alliance. The market is expected to continue growing by 25% annually until 2030, ultimately reaching a volume of 2,600 gigawatt hours, according to the report. The main drivers of demand growth: the electrification of transportation, and the deployment of batteries in electricity grids (by 2030, passenger cars will account for 60% of global battery demand, according to the report).  Car and battery manufacturers have been establishing a growing number of production facilities, such as Tesla’s Gigafactory near Reno, Nevada in the US, which the carmaker jointly owns and operates with its battery supplier Panasonic. According to a 2019 media report, Tesla, which has indicated that a lack of available batteries from outside vendors has constrained its production, is also working on a means to manufacture its own battery cells. Northvolt, a Swedish battery maker, raised $1 billion in funding in 2019 from investors including Volkswagen and BMW in order to help it complete Europe’s biggest lithium-ion battery plant, at roughly the same time that Chinese battery cell manufacturer CATL (Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd.) disclosed plans to invest €1.8 billion in a production facility in Germany (more recently, CATL disclosed an agreement to supply batteries for Daimler trucks). This increase in production could help curb carbon emissions as it creates jobs. Increasing electric vehicle production may result in the creation of 10 million jobs, and about $150 billion in economic value as it contributes to progress related to the Paris Agreement on climate change, according to the Global Battery Alliance.

name: Battery Recycling and Second-Life
description: In 2018, the total number of electric cars in the world exceeded 5.1 million, an increase of 2 million compared with the prior year, according to the International Energy Agency. This surge in popularity has brought with it corresponding growth in demand for lithium-ion batteries required to power these vehicles—promising a potential environmental reckoning once these batteries are spent. Different parts of the world have taken different approaches to tackling the issue; China, for example, has implemented measures that hold car manufacturers responsible for the “end-of-life treatment” of vehicle batteries, according to the IEA’s report, while the European Union has set standards for battery waste management since 2006 including a ban on landfilling - and has mandated companies to collect and recycle batteries. Lithium-ion batteries now predominantly used for automobiles (in addition to consumer electronics) can collect and discharge electricity for up to ten years after they are taken off the roads, according to a Bloomberg report published in 2018 - which noted that potential second-life applications for them include storing electricity from solar panels and wind turbines. These second-life applications can have practical, everyday uses. In Amsterdam, for example, an energy storage system at Johan Cruijuff Arena uses the equivalent of 148 new and used Nissan LEAF batteries to capture energy from 4,200 solar panels and store up to 3 megawatts of power - or enough to charge a half a million iPhones - for back-up purposes. To be sure, regardless of their post-vehicle uses, batteries should ideally be used as efficiently and for the longest duration possible. In order to help drivers be more strategic about optimizing energy consumption, big data and machine learning can be deployed; one study published in 2019 outlined an approach involving real-time prediction and a dashboard display to optimize braking. Machine learning can also be used more generally to better understand the current health of a battery in use, and to schedule replacements. Ideally, replaced batteries will become part of a circular economy approach; Audi and the technology firm Umicore, for example, have developed a related, “closed-loop” system meant to use valuable elements from the used batteries in Audi’s e-tron for new products.

name: Battery Research and Development
description: Cobalt, a raw material necessary for the lithium-ion batteries that make electric vehicles and cutting-edge mobile phones possible, can be problematic. For one thing, it may be in short supply relatively soon. For another, its extraction can be environmentally damaging and controversial - and the bulk of it takes place in one developing country, the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Whereas most lithium (another essential battery element) occurs as a “primary product” in the form of brines or ores, most cobalt must be produced as a by-product of copper and nickel mines, according to a report published by McKinsey & Company in 2018. Now, the growing adoption of electric vehicles means that demand for cobalt should increase by 60% by 2025, according to the report - and research & development efforts to find technologies capable of mitigating or even eliminating it as a necessity are crucial. Related efforts are underway, for example in terms of the development of the NMC 811 battery (“nickel, manganese and cobalt”), which uses three times less cobalt than existing models. Lingering issues with the practical use of the relatively energy-dense NMC 811 (including a limited number of charge-discharge life cycles) are expected to be ironed out in the coming years. Other types of advances are also being made. New materials for the cathodes that underpin batteries are being explored, for example; scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York reported in 2018 that they had synthesized a cathode material from iron fluoride that increases battery capacity. New concepts like lithium-air batteries, which can potentially enable relatively high energy density thanks to requiring fewer chemicals inside of a battery than traditional models, are also being explored. Funding is essential to make significant progress in battery technology, as are dedicated institutions and initiatives. The Faraday Institution in the United Kingdom, founded in 2017 to focus on electrical storage technologies for the automotive and other industries, announced in late 2019 it would grant up to £55 million to consortia trying to improve batteries for transportation and storage. Meanwhile the European Commission’s “Battery 2030+” initiative aims to mobilize researchers around the development of new battery technologies.

name: Behaviour and Decision-Making
description: Although we like to view ourselves as rational beings, in fact our behaviours are often far from optimal. This is clear when conspicuously bad choices are made, as in drug addiction and crime, but psychologists and economists have long been aware that our daily decisions about minor purchases or interactions with others are frequently biased and suboptimal. Our brains have deeply-rooted mechanisms that have served us well throughout evolution, but which can keep us from performing optimally in the modern world. There is increasing interest in whether the social sciences, including economics, can benefit from neuroscience sights into behaviour.   The ability to observe and record brain functions in combination with new tools such as virtual reality, machine learning and miniaturized recording devices is dramatically increasing our understanding of how the activity of billions of brain cells creates cognition and behaviour. This research is leading to a better understanding of the brain structures that underlie decision making, how they weight rewards and payoffs, and how those weights change when we learn. For example, a report from Yale University in a 2016 issue of Trends in Neurosciences suggested that specific regions in the frontal lobe are specifically involved in social decision-making. Progress in this area could guide better decision-making and promote better understanding of human nature, with implications ranging from public policy to law to interpersonal relations. Results from psychological studies of human behaviour have practical applications for undertakings as diverse as schooling, household economics, politics and policing. Neuroscience has the potential to provide a much richer view of how people learn, live and interact. For example, a deep understanding of the molecular, cellular and circuit mechanism of learning could improve the strategies we use for education. Integrated work that combines results from Neuroscience, Cognitive and Social Psychology and Behavioural Economics has the potential of revolutionizing approaches to optimizing human behaviour and decision-making to help people make rational choices.

name: Benefits for Society
description: Space applications have moved well beyond narrow, government-related purposes. India’s space-related investments, for example, have been directed at telecommunications systems that can provide education and other services to rural populations. European companies have meanwhile pursued space applications to profit from commercial ventures; Spot Image, a subsidiary of Germany-based Airbus Defence and Space, was among the first commercial firms to successfully disseminate images taken by Earth observation satellites. A wave of emerging space-based services, most still at the startup stage, tend include both a commercial and a social focus. For example, Planet Labs, an American company, provides imagery via hundreds of satellites that helps to monitor the environment, the management of resources, and potential human rights abuses (the company’s images were used in 2017 to help Amnesty International identify locations in Myanmar where members of the Rohingya minority group were targeted by systematic fires). OneWeb, a startup with offices in the US and the United Kingdom, aims to use satellites to deliver broadband services to underserved markets, while in remote villages in drought-stricken areas of northern Kenya, a satellite technology-based smartphone app called Afriscout is helping cattle farmers locate water and green pastures - which are becoming rarer due to climate change. These new space-based services may benefit those who are on the other side of the so-called digital divide, separating those with internet access from those who are deprived. That is because traditional telecommunications networks, based on terrestrial cables, are limited to those people fortunate enough to be living in relatively stable, wealthy societies. Satellite services, on the other hand, can provide access in conflict zones and in so-called least developed countries, which face extraordinary development challenges. Such services, often dubbed Space 2.0, are opening up new horizons for those in desperate need of information and access. They may also benefit developing countries economically thanks to increased foreign investment directed at local, space-related operations. For example, in 2017, the Australian communications satellite firm SpeedCast established an office in Papua New Guinea (classified by the United Nations as a lower-middle-income country), where it can contribute to the local economy and provide jobs. Meanwhile space agencies are working together to monitor greenhouse gas emissions; pursuant to the 2016 New Delhi Declaration, agencies from more than 60 countries are pursuing this effort. This may be bolstered by the growing number of organizations either operating or planning to operate satellites for this purpose.

name: Big Data Analysis
description: The growing availability of detailed data about weather, geography, vehicle performance, and customer behaviour, thanks to the broad use of internet-connected devices, social media platforms, and sensors, presents a significant opportunity for insurers to improve the accuracy of their underwriting. It can also help them explore new business models - such as so-called usage-based insurance, which ties the cost of coverage to discrete periods when it applies. In order to best take advantage of this deluge of data, however, insurers must develop the means to sift through large amounts of unstructured information in order to glean useful insights. One means of acquiring such potentially useful data is via smart home networking and the Internet of Things (which strings together devices and appliances with internet connectivity). Nest Labs, a Google-owned maker of internet-connected home devices, has partnered with insurance companies to provide data generated by its smart smoke detectors, for example, including battery status and a device's location. In return, partnering insurance companies have lowered premiums for Nest device users by as much as 5%. As insurers gather more behavioural data, traditional risk-pooling may give way to individualized insurance products, more targeted incentives, and the more efficient acquisition of customers. Life insurers, for example, have been able to eliminate the need for some prospective customers to take blood tests, by instead using other health data and answers supplied on applications, according to analysis published by the consultancy Bain & Company in 2016. Meanwhile Allstate has provided an app to customers that can track things like speed and braking, in order to potentially reward less-risky driving behaviour with reduced auto insurance pricing. While greater use of behavioural data can help insurers and their customers, it has also raised questions about privacy and security. The General Data Protection Regulation, being implemented in Europe, is expected to affect how insurance companies are able to handle personal data. Under the regulation, customers will be able to ask insurers to delete personal data not being used for its original purpose, according to the consultancy PwC. Ultimately, increased data gathering and analytics may even call into question the very need for insurance - as in-depth screening can result in extremely accurate risk profiling.

name: Big Data and Mining
description: Collecting and processing massive amounts of data will be essential for mining companies as they digitalize and automate operations. Increasingly, governments in countries where mining companies are publicly traded are approving regulations that require these firms to publish project-by-project data on payments they make to governments in the countries where they operate - in order to reduce corruption, properly disclose taxable subsidiaries, and increase transparency regarding the handling of particularly problematic minerals. Host-country governments have meanwhile adopted data-driven frameworks to bolster their evidence-based policy-making. Mineral buyers including the technology and transportation sectors and jewellers are also making use of big data, to gain insight into the provenance of minerals and to try to ensure compliance with their environmental, social, and governance standards. Investors are using the proliferation of non-financial data (like potential water scarcity in mine locations) in order to better assess the risks tied to their mining-related portfolios. Mining companies have been pressed to go beyond the global standard established by the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (which is funded by governments and corporations) when it comes to transparency on contracts and environmental impact assessments; local communities affected by mining are particularly interested in accessing data on issues including water quality readings, for example, though current corporate reporting only focuses on water intake. While the data revolution provides mining companies with an opportunity to better address reputational risk and attract investors, it will be essential for them to work together with other stakeholders in order to understand exactly which data should be made available, and the appropriate format for data disclosure - in order to ensure standardization and impact (blockchain technology and geographic information systems can be particularly useful in this regard). If data transparency requirements are not standardized, the amount of time and resources required for mining companies to provide the important information they are required to disclose may increase, to no one’s benefit. Other risk associated with the increased collection and reliance on data include cyber security breaches, and the misuse of vital information.

name: Big Spending, Bigger Deficit
description: Italy has made overall progress in recent years in reducing its budget deficit, even as it has been hindered by persistently weak economic growth and low inflation (often, measures aimed at fiscal prudence and cutting deficits have had the unfortunate effect of constraining growth). According to Eurostat, Italy’s budget deficit climbed to 5.3% of GDP in 2009, in the wake of the global financial crisis - subsequently, it was brought below the 3% threshold specified by the European Union Stability and Growth Pact. More recently, though, a big-spending economic program put forward by the previous government appointed in 2018 included measures aimed at expanding assistance programs for the poor, and dismantling the pension system while lowering the age when retirement benefits can be received. The erstwhile government also pushed for a universal basic income scheme. These measures were likely to add tens of billions of euros to the government’s budget, and potentially keep its deficit at a level deemed unsatisfactory by investors and the European Commission. Carlo Cottarelli, a former senior International Monetary Fund official and one-time prime minister in charge of a caretaker government, publicly estimated that the measures would have cost €126 billion. The government did not fully explain how it would fund its plans, with the exception of a reference to cutting tax deductions and a plan for a tax amnesty for individuals less than €100,000 in arrears. As a result, the planned spending could have caused deficits to balloon. The mere prospect of this caused Italy’s sovereign bond yields (a measure of perceived risk for its creditors) to spike, and the government collapsed in August 2019. The previous Economy Minister had sought to make public assurances that public accounts would not be blown up in order to keep campaign promises, though they were met with scepticism. The government also sought to explain that it might finance its proposed measures by discontinuing or rationalizing some benefits currently in place. Potential candidates for this had included the “baby bonus” used to incentivize prospective parents and address the country’s declining birth rate, and financial incentives for making environmentally-friendly home renovations.

name: Bio Big Data and Machine Learning
description: The biomedical sciences are transforming into big-data science. Thanks to next-generation genomic sequencing technology, there has been a dramatic data explosion; by 2016, more than 100,000 human genomes had been sequenced from normal and diseased tissue, and petabytes of raw sequence data are now being produced and deposited in public genome data repositories such as International Cancer Genome Consortium data portal. This is transforming the scientific landscape, and entire healthcare systems. Currently-archived datasets represent only a small fraction of the genome-related big data yet to be produced in the future, as sequencing capacity will continue to grow. If the current growth rate continues, doubling capacity about every seven months, exabytes-worth of genome data (one exabyte is equivalent to about 250 million DVDs worth of video) will be yielded in the next 5 years. As the global population pushes toward 8 billion within the next decade, it is possible that 15% or more of it will have their genome sequenced. In addition to genomics, high-resolution imaging, medical records, and lifestyle-related datasets will add new dimensions to bio big-data, and provide a foundation for next-generation healthcare. However, there is a long road ahead before big data can help deliver precision medicine based on a patient’s genetic makeup and environmental circumstances to the masses. There are immense challenges when it comes to data storage, distribution, and proper interpretation in biomedical contexts. Large-scale machine learning systems need to be integrated with vast computing infrastructure in order for deep learning, one of the most promising branches of artificial intelligence, to help better enable the navigation of big data and detect things that are impossible to catch manually. Machine learning could facilitate the mining of gene-to-gene interaction, the classification of cellular images, and finding links between datasets. Yet, machine-learning algorithms require large-scale, high-quality “ground truth” data for algorithm training - which is difficult to acquire. In addition, machine learning can be biased, and understanding exactly how machine learning algorithms are classifying the features in datasets can be challenging. Still, the analysis of big data will eventually have an enormous impact on disease prevention, on the ability to cure and care, and on the global healthcare system.

name: Biodegradability
description: Mechanical recycling is the only method now commonly used for the large-scale treatment of solid plastic waste. Because every type of plastic differs in terms of chemical composition, mechanical behaviours, and thermal properties, however, conventional mechanical recycling requires pre-sorting to separate non-plastic items and different varieties - which can be costly and time-intensive. In addition, the two types of plastic that can currently be mechanically recycled, polyethylene terephthalate, or “PET,” and some grades of polyethylene, together make up less than half (46%) of all annual plastic production. In order to make recycled plastic products, old PET or polyethylene is blended with virgin plastics in an expensive, energy-intensive process that ultimately results in lower-quality finished material. Further innovation is therefore essential, ideally with a focus on both mixed mechanical recycling and chemical recycling. The latter uses thermolysis (applying heat) or catalysts to break down plastics into their component parts, which can then be re-built into new plastics. Complete depolymerisation involves breaking a plastic down to monomers (molecules), which can enable multiple recycling loops with lower energy requirements - all while maintaining the material properties of the finished product. In general, chemical recycling is under-explored - though it is also the most feasible approach for dealing with PET (it is also expected to become possible for biodegradable and compostable polyesters). Innovative recycling technologies that enable the direct processing of mixed plastic waste without pre-sorting may offer other potential solutions. This would require a means to stabilize the behaviour of mixed plastic waste during the recycling process - and would have to be facilitated by better design of the ways that plastic products reach their “end-of-life.” Plastics additives and impurities can interfere with recycling, and policies that make plastic producers responsible for the impact of the entire product lifecycle may help commit more manufacturers to better design, while improving the economics of current end-use options. Some positive related signs include Unilever’s pledge that by 2025 all of its plastic packaging will be fully reusable, recyclable, or compostable. Moves like this are more necessary than ever before, as new plastics can create problems for mixed waste recycling; for example, PET and the bio-polymer PLA (polylactic acid) can each compromise the recycling of the other if they are mixed.

name: Biodiversity
description: Forests cover nearly one-third of Earth’s land area, and house more than 80% of terrestrial biodiversity. Tropical forests are home to the highest number of species per unit of land area, with particularly high rates of biodiversity in the Amazon basin of South America, the Congo basin of Central Africa, and the tropical rainforests of Southeast Asia. In addition, forests with unique compositions, such as those on isolated islands, or with varied topography, host high numbers of endemic species that are found nowhere else in the world. Any change to these habitats can lead to the extinction of the species that depend on them. Regions rich in both biodiversity and endemic species include Madagascar, the Hindu Kush-Himalayan region stretching from Afghanistan to Myanmar, and the highlands of Borneo. According to Enough is Enough, a report published by Eyes on the Forest in 2018, forest blocks in Indonesian Borneo and Sumatra, which were some of the last remaining habitats of critically endangered species like tigers, elephants, and orangutan, continue to be converted to palm oil plantations. Detailed information about the location of areas with rich biodiversity, as well as highly threatened areas, can be used to better prioritize conservation and protection efforts. Biodiversity may be best conserved by minimizing human intrusion into intact and relatively un-fragmented habitats, and by restoring biodiverse areas that have been highly altered. If areas like this can be identified, continuous monitoring of them could measure progress towards greater biodiversity conservation. Many efforts are already underway to protect biodiversity and mitigate the destruction of forested habitats. International mechanisms designed to help conserve species include the Convention on Biological Diversity’s Strategic Plan for Biodiversity 2011-2020, the Aichi Biodiversity Targets designed to be met by 2020, and the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals adopted in 2015. Others, such as The Consumer Goods Forum, Tropical Forest Alliance 2020, and the New York Declaration on Forests, are focused on achieving zero net deforestation by 2020, and focus on the production of commodities (such as beef and palm oil) that is driving deforestation within tropical forest regions rich in biodiversity.

name: Bioprinting
description: While 3D printing (or “additive manufacturing”) promises to revolutionize the manufacturing industry, it could also have a similar impact on public health. For example, 34,770 organ transplants were performed in the US in 2017, setting a fifth consecutive record yearly high, according to the US Department of Health and Human Services. However, there were also more than 114,000 people on the US waiting list for a transplant as of early 2018, and 20 people die in the country every day as they wait, according to the DHS, which notes that only about three out of every 1,000 people die in a way that allows for organ donation. Some countries and regions have considered and passed opt-out laws; in England, for example, a system where people will be presumed to have consented to donation is expected to come into force by 2020. Still, a shortage of donors is just one obstacle. Others include a need to develop more reliable organ preservation techniques, and a constant need for biological compatibility between donors and potential recipients. Bioprinting could be the solution to these problems. The process of bioprinting organs uses 3D printing’s layer-by-layer method, and consists of a medically designed 3D bio-printer and bio-ink - a substance usually made from stem cells. Depositing layers of bio-ink on top of one another leads to creation of tissue that can eventually form an organ. This organ, because it can be created using a patient’s own cells, is much less likely to be rejected. That means that a patient would not need potentially dangerous immunosuppressant therapy, which can create susceptibility to diseases. Bioprinting could also be applied to drug discovery and toxicology. It could provide more reliable results than animal testing, for example, and would be safer than clinical studies. However, bioprinting is a time-consuming process and cells have to be kept alive throughout (tissues demand a constant supply of oxygen and nutrients). In this regard, vascularization, or the process of supplying blood through capillaries to living tissue, could help. In 2018, US-based company Prellis Biologics announced it had developed “pre-vascularized” tissue scaffolds that can be used to grow cells in 3D formats.

name: Blockchain-based Legal Platforms
description: Blockchain technology is likely to emerge as a critical legal platform, offering a distributed and reliable mechanism for verifying information such as the ownership of an asset or the accuracy of a claim. Many blockchain legal platforms will require a sound supervisory layer supplied by government, even as they are likely to play a role in the shift from exclusive reliance on government-based systems for law and regulation. So-called smart contracting is already in use, as a mechanism for automatically executed financial trades. A smart contract can be self-executing and coded directly into the blockchain, which functions as a digital register. Smart contracts still require human judgment, but they can substantially reduce the cost, insecurity, and failures associated with existing systems. One of the most transformational roles for blockchain as a legal platform relates to the enforcement of judgments. Parties with assets or rights assigned in the blockchain could satisfy judgments with these assets or rights by agreeing to a smart contract, conditioned on the entry of an order from a designated adjudicator. Companies doing business globally could benefit from blockchain enforcement by reducing their reliance on international agreements, or on courts that may have local biases. Blockchain-based platforms could help overcome weaknesses in the verification of the ownership of property used as collateral for credit - which could potentially be performed outside of government systems, with private providers verifying claims. Alternatively, governments could deliver their own systems for recognizing property claims through a blockchain platform, and reduce the potential for corruption. A similar benefit could be realized by moving other administrative procedures, like permitting for businesses or construction, or providing access to public utilities, onto a blockchain. Large numbers of people around the world, including migrants and refugees, currently lack a means to verify their identity, keeping them outside of formal legal systems. The lack of identity can result from a missing proof of birth, or citizenship, or educational credentials. Private blockchain systems are in development that could help these people establish a secure record of facts, which a private organization could verify. Other blockchain-based systems in development include tools for tracking the origin of goods, granting permission for access to health data, resolving disputes, and ensuring a means by which data can be stored, shared, and analysed with minimal loss of privacy.

name: Bolstering Human Dignity
description: The world is getting richer, but wealth is being concentrated in fewer hands. According to the 2019 Oxfam Inequality Report, the 26 richest people on the planet had the same collective net worth as the poorest 3.8 billion people - a group equal to half of the global population. In addition, 2,200 of the world’s billionaires saw their wealth increase by 12% in 2018 compared with the prior year, even as the poorest half of the global population saw their wealth decrease by 11%, according to the report. In 2017, meanwhile, global real wage growth fell to 0.4% - its lowest growth rate since the 2008 global financial crisis - according to the International Labour Organization’s Global Wage Report. The issue of inequality relative to economic development is receiving renewed public attention, as it has only worsened in many parts of the world since the financial crisis. That in turn has helped trigger the rise of populist political movements that exploit fears about job security and immigration. The successful campaign to encourage people in the United Kingdom to vote to leave the European Union is one example, and Donald Trump’s presidential campaign is another. According to the United Kingdom’s Race Disparity Audit, most recently revised by the government in late 2018, one in five children in black households in that country live in persistent poverty, compared with one in 10 children in white households. Meanwhile in the US black workers make 82.5 cents for every dollar earned by a white worker, according to a report published by the Economic Policy Institute in 2018. The risks created by persistent inequality threaten to trigger long-term problems, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2019 Global Risks Report; it noted that while global inequality has generally declined, inequality within countries has continued to rise. Coupled with political polarization, this threatens to erode these countries’ social fabric. In addition, the Forum’s Risk Report has in the past noted that the global gender parity gap in terms of health, education, politics, and the workplace only continues to widen. These developments have a very real human cost, not least in the form of psychological and emotional strain. Young people are increasingly suffering from mental health problems; in the US, for example, the proportion of people aged between 12 and 17 with depression rose to 12.7% in 2015, from 5.7% in 2005, according to the 2018 Risks Report.

name: Brazil's Business Climate
description: Improving Brazil’s business environment is necessary to boost the country’s long-term productivity. Brazil ranked 109th out of 190 countries in terms of ease of doing business in the World Bank report Doing Business 2019, 16 notches higher than where it had placed in the previous year’s edition. In particular, Brazil has showed improvement in terms of expanding access to electricity and to credit, and in terms of facilitating trading across borders. Meanwhile the country’s score for the ease of starting a business locally moved closer to the global average, thanks to the development of an online system for company registration. Brazil’s tax system, however, is a serious impediment for the country’s business environment; it is both complex, and hard to comply with. According to the World Bank, the average Brazilian firm spends 1,958 hours per year (equivalent to nearly 82 days) preparing and paying taxes - the highest of any country in the world, and more than eight times the global average. The costs of unnecessary bureaucracy strongly discourage companies from entering Brazil, which stifles productivity growth and encourages the unregulated, informal economy. According to the World Bank’s Doing Business 2019 report, Brazil ranked 140th out of 190 countries in terms of starting a business - with 20.5 days required for the process. Brazil also suffers from relatively burdensome regulation compared with both Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development members and with other large emerging economies. According to the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index published in 2018, Brazil ranked last out of 140 countries in terms of the burden of government regulation. Brazil also ranked near the bottom (117th) of the index in terms of product market - due to a lack of market competition, distortive subsidies, and relatively poor integration with global markets. Policy-makers have acknowledged a need for reforms that address taxes, labour markets, and the overall regulatory environment, and the administration of President Jair Bolsonaro, who was elected in late 2018, has declared an interest in addressing related shortcomings in hopes of unleashing the private sector’s potential.

name: Brazil's Foreign Trade
description: Economic openness can boost a country’s long-term development and growth, help to spread the use of new technologies and enable state-of-the-art production. Brazil’s legacy of trade protectionism, meanwhile, has limited its competitiveness. Despite a period of trade liberalization in the 1990s, policy constraints in the country remain significant. By 2017, Brazil had the world’s eighth-largest economy; yet, it ranked 26th in terms of global merchandise trade that year, and 35th in terms of commercial services exports. The World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index ranked Brazil 125th out of 140 countries in terms of trade tariffs, and 136th in terms of non-tariff barriers. The country’s relatively limited presence in global markets is long-standing; according to a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank in 2014, Brazil commanded just 1.4% of total world trade (less than half of its overall 3% participation in global GDP). Meanwhile in terms of global value chains, measured as the percentage of foreign-value-added that is embedded in a country’s exports, Brazil’s figure stood at roughly 10% - while the average for Asia was about 30%. Brazil is one of the few countries in the world that has not significantly reduced trade tariffs over the past 20 years. Its tariffs on capital goods are particularly punitive. President Jair Bolsonaro’s administration has expressed an intention to address this situation, and has argued that greater openness will be key for boosting productivity. Historically, Brazil’s occasional periods of increased trade openness did contribute to productivity gains and increased investment. Detailed analysis has shown that Brazilian manufacturing productivity accelerated in the second half of the 1990s, for example, following a process of trade liberalization that exposed firms to foreign competition and improved access to foreign materials and labour, while also lowering the cost of capital goods. Officials in Brazil have in the past laid out a vision in which trade and economic integration plays a significant role in supporting economic growth. The country’s foreign policy has been focused on establishing more proximity with the US and developed countries, while the Mercosur bloc (which includes Brazil) has been negotiating its own trade and investment agreements - including a potentially significant agreement with the European Union. In addition, Mercosur may pursue closer collaboration with the Pacific Alliance, which includes Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.

name: Brazil's Infrastructure Gap
description: The World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index published in 2018 ranked Brazil 81st out of 140 countries in terms of the quality of its overall infrastructure, down from 73rd the in the prior year's index. In terms of the quality of roads, the country ranked 112th in the most recent index, while for efficiency of seaport services it ranked 105th, and for efficiency of train services it ranked 97th (a bright spot was airport connectivity, for which it ranked 17th). Inadequate infrastructure investment can hinder growth, raise the cost of doing business domestically, constrain technology adoption, and limit engagement in international trade. According to a report published by the consulting firm Oliver Wyman in 2018, Brazil’s inadequate infrastructure is reflected in indicators such as the percentage of households with access to sewage (just 55%), internet services (less than half, at 43%), and water (83.5%). The report noted that by investing the equivalent of only about 2% of GDP in infrastructure per year, the country is failing to maintain existing infrastructure, much less build new projects (China invests roughly 7% of GDP in infrastructure, by way of comparison, while India invests about 5.5%).   Ineffective long-term planning, and a lack of an integrated strategic vision, have hindered the efficiency of infrastructure investment in the country. Project selection, screening, and planning are all inadequate, while clear criteria are not being applied to project selection and there is a disconnect between long-term plans and annual budgets. Regulatory uncertainty has also hindered investment, and financing options are limited. Burdensome procurement and environmental-licensing processes have slowed down projects, while proving ineffective at reducing corruption (which has dogged the country more broadly; two former presidents have now been jailed in relation to the Car Wash scandal stemming from a bribery and money laundering probe launched in 2014), or safeguarding the environment. The government has tried to strengthen the interaction between the state and the private sector as a means to improve local infrastructure. Since 2016, following the creation of the Investment Partnership Program (PPI), more than 100 infrastructure projects have been completed worth more than 250 billion Brazilian reals - and the program has a pipeline of dozens of projects lined up that could be worth an additional 130 billion reals. In the first quarter of 2019 alone the PPI expected to conclude projects including the concession of 12 airports, part of the North-South railway, and ten port terminals.

name: Brazil's Macroeconomic Challenges
description: Brazil has made significant progress on reducing poverty and inequality since the beginning of the 2000s. However, the recession that lasted from 2014 to 2016 revealed that many of these social gains cannot be sustained without corresponding productivity growth, and some level of economic dynamism. Also essential: efficient public spending that genuinely improves the quality of public services, and benefits the most vulnerable. In 2017, Brazilian respondents to the Latinobarometer survey ranked “improving social policies and social inclusion” and “ensuring equal opportunities for all” as the two most important development issues for the country. According to data from the country’s National Household Sample Survey compiled by the Institute for Applied Economic Research, the portion of Brazilians living in poverty declined from 35.7% in 2003 to 13.3% in 2014. However, according to a report published by the World Bank in 2018, related progress came to a halt in 2015. Between 2015 and 2016, the mean labour income for the poorest 30% of the population actually decreased, even as it increased for everyone else. Inequality in Brazil decreased significantly between 2000 and 2014 thanks to higher employment rates, higher real wages, and redistributive social assistance programs. According to a World Bank working paper published in 2014, Decomposing the Recent Inequality Decline in Latin America, Brazil’s improvement in labour income had accounted for nearly half of the reduction in inequality up to that point, as measured by the Gini coefficient; meanwhile government policies directed at education, health, and social assistance accounted for much of the improved conditions for Brazilians living in poverty during the period. Recent reductions in labour income, caused by a slowdown in economic growth, may therefore undermine efforts to maintain and advance equality in the country. Bolstering structural elements that can support long-term, sustainable improvements in living standards, such as the quality of education, the amount of household savings and investment, and the allocation of labour and capital markets, will be critical for spurring healthy economic growth and sustainable development.

name: Breakdown of Trust
description: In early 2018, the RAND Corporation published a report describing a phenomenon that the US-based think tank described as “Truth Decay.” According to the report, Americans’ reliance on facts to discuss public issues had declined significantly during the prior two decades, amid a blurring of fact and opinion, and an evaporation of trust in formerly respected sources of information. The report noted previous US eras of Truth Decay, including the rapid industrialization and inequality of the 1880s, the mistrust of financial institutions tied to the Great Depression of the 1930s, and the Viet Nam War-era 1960s - and found that the trend is even more pronounced now (the ends of previous periods of Truth Decay were marked by improved government transparency, changes in policy, and a resurgence of responsible investigative journalism, according to the report). Current symptoms of the decline in trust include a dip in voter turnout in the US, where just 58% of eligible voters turned out for the 2016 presidential election (a 20-year low), challenges posed in recent years by some European Union members states, such as Hungary and Poland, to the bloc’s established values, and a Brexit vote in the United Kingdom in 2016 that delivered a defeat to a government that hoped to remain in the EU.    There is a strong perception among many people that some established political leaders and international institutions have pursued an economic agenda based on the idea of free trade, and a social agenda based on the idea of the free movement of people across national borders, that have combined to create greater inequality, unemployment, and disruptive cultural change. A profound mistrust of institutions has surfaced, as people increasingly lose faith in governments seen as prioritizing business interests over the interests of individuals. According to the 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer, which is based on an online survey conducted in 28 countries during late 2017, the portion of the “informed public” expressing trust in non-governmental organizations slipped to 64% from 67% in the prior year, while the portion of those expressing trust in government remained flat at 53%. The Edelman report reflected a wide variety of sentiment recorded around the world; the average level of trust among the general population in the institutions of government, business, media, and non-governmental organizations registered at 74 percentage points in China, 49 in Canada, 43 in the US, and 36 in Russia.

name: Building Climate Coalitions
description: Effective climate action requires commitments from businesses, organizations, cities, and regions. Several coalitions have already emerged in the private sector. For example, We Mean Business, a coalition of non-profit organizations dedicated to partnering with the private sector, has engaged more than 800 different companies (representing about $17 trillion in market value), to act on climate change. More than 150 of the affiliated companies have committed to a goal of 100% renewable power, and about 500 have committed to establishing science-based targets for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases in their operations. Public-sector coalitions engaging local and regional governments are also becoming more prominent. The C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group is made up of more than 90 cities that have committed to 10,000 “actions” to combat climate change. C40 cities represent about one quarter of the global economy and roughly 8% of the world’s population, and aim to stir a global conversation that hastens progress towards a low-carbon economy. The Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate & Energy provides a similar platform for more than 9,000 cities, comprising about 10% of the world’s population. In the US, the We Are Still In coalition has gathered signatures from more than 3,500 leaders across the country in support of a pledge to uphold the Paris Agreement on climate change. This initiative, which was started after the Trump Administration announced its intention to withdraw the US from the agreement, represents about half the US population. Climate Action 100+ is meanwhile an example of a global initiative led by more than 300 investors with $32 trillion in assets under management; it is systematically engaging with major corporate greenhouse gas emitters around the globe that now have a significant opportunity to shape the clean energy transition and support the Paris Agreement - which aims to limit global warming to less than 2°C above pre-industrial levels. In addition, the World Economic Forum’s Alliance of CEO Climate Leaders aims to foster public-private collaboration that can support the Paris Agreement and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. By joining forces with these coalitions, policy-makers, organization, and companies can demonstrate a real commitment to climate action, share best practices, and demonstrate leadership.

name: Building Peace
description: After more than half a century of violence, the Colombian government and Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) guerrillas reached a peace agreement in 2016. A revised peace deal was subsequently signed and ratified by congress, though critics argue that it provides excessive political and judicial benefits to former FARC leaders. The FARC, which has retained its acronym as a political party, performed poorly in national elections held in March 2018 - though it was guaranteed a handful of seats in congress as part of the peace agreement. In addition to guarantees for the political participation of ex-combatants, the peace agreement includes measures to support social and economic development in rural areas, to provide reparations, and to eliminate the illicit drug production that was one of the former guerrilla group’s main sources of funding. The end of the armed confrontation with the FARC promises to improve security and respect for human rights in Colombia, while curbing drug trafficking. A Colombian government study estimated that achieving peace would boost annual GDP growth by up to 0.3% over the following decade, thanks to increases in foreign and domestic investment, increased consumption, the redistribution of military resources, a tourism boost, and business expansion into more remote regions. The peacebuilding process also entails complex challenges. Dissident factions of the FARC have refused to demobilize. In addition, achieving the right balance between peace and justice, and integrating thousands of former combatants into society will require public faith in political processes, and efficient institutions. The government must increase its capacity to deliver basic social services across the country (in conflict-affected regions, in particular). Public-private partnerships should play a role in the process, by catalysing broad economic and employment growth. The Colombian government has estimated that the implementation of the peace agreement may involve spending the equivalent of 15% of GDP over the course of the coming decade. A truly comprehensive approach to improving domestic security in Colombia will also require dealing with the powerful criminal groups known as Bacrim - such as the Urabeños, and the still-active National Liberation Army (ELN). Government talks with the ELN resulted in a ceasefire, though the guerrilla group committed a series of attacks when the deal expired in January 2018, aimed at infrastructure and the military.

name: Building Sustainable Industries
description: The unintended consequences of human activity have placed the environment under extreme stress - and threaten to undermine future economic growth, and sustainable development. However, significant, widespread efforts to create a more circular economy, where materials are re-used and more waste is eliminated, are underway. For example, the lithium-ion battery industry, which is expected to grow dramatically in order to match increasing demand for electric vehicles and renewable energy storage, is working to clean up its supply chains, better safeguard workers, ban child labour, eradicate pollution, and promote re-use and recycling. Other industries must follow suit. Rapid population growth, increasing urbanization, and an expanding global middle class will place potentially catastrophic amounts of pressure on the environment, barring radical and responsible industrial reform. Enlightened companies recognize that reliable growth and long-term relevance are contingent upon pursuing social and environmental benefits that go far beyond traditional corporate social responsibility programmes. Cisco, for example, topped a 2018 Barron’s ranking of the most sustainable companies in the US, by reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 41% since 2007, getting to a point where 80% of its electricity is derived from renewable sources, and implementing initiatives like a training programme designed to place 1.3 million students in IT jobs. A strategic approach to accomplishments like this is crucial, in order to provide ways to unlock value. Such an approach is increasingly attractive to the investing community; a growing number of investors are signing on to United Nations guidelines that commit them to incorporating environmental, social, and governance criteria in their portfolio selection. In general, however, more efforts must be made to create conditions that genuinely incentivize and enable industries to grow sustainably.

name: Business Disruption
description: As a result of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, the relationship between businesses and their customers is shifting to an on-demand, always connected model powered by digital communication. In early 2018, the Facebook-owned mobile communication service WhatsApp reported that its users were sending 60 billion messages every day, and when Chinese internet commerce giant Alibaba Group staged a “Singles Day” in 2015, it led to $14 billion of online transactions in China alone, with 68% of those sales completed through a mobile device. Places where connectivity has lagged are catching up; the GSM Association expects sub-Saharan Africa to add 240 million mobile internet users between 2014 and 2020. Businesses must understand the ways that products can have their value enhanced digitally. The electric car maker Tesla, for example, has deployed over-the-air software updates that help maintain the value of its cars after they have been purchased. New ways to value services can also be created. Analytics can be used to measure a service’s performance over time, for example, in order to improve the accuracy of pricing. For physical assets, too, such as an elevator, pricing could be based on performance over a given period, excluding the downtime required for maintenance. The Fourth Industrial Revolution is also spurring new forms of collaboration. Established incumbents often lack sensitivity to evolving customer needs, while younger firms are in need of the capital and rich data enjoyed by older counterparts. When firms share resources, significant value can be created for both parties as well as for broader economies. As they consider new partnerships, organizations will increasingly pivot to open operating models that can capitalize on network effects. One model that has proven as disruptive as it is profitable is the so-called platform strategy, designed to broaden influence by encouraging peers to build on top of a company’s established tools and infrastructure. According to a report published by Accenture in 2016, the top 15 public platform companies already represented $2.6 trillion in market capitalization worldwide. Regardless of the model they choose, organizations that focus on being flexible and open can position themselves within a fluid ecosystem of value creation, while lowering costs and making more efficient use of energy and automation.

name: Business Dynamism
description: Bolivia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the willingness of companies to embrace disruptive ideas, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 27.10, resulting in a rank of 139th out of 140 countries; and in terms of the growth of innovative companies where it has a progress score of 33.30 that results in a rank of 133rd out of 140 countries. One indicator reflects a better performance: the cost of starting a business, where it has a progress score of 73.00 that results in a rank of 130th out of 140 countries.

name: Business Integrity
description: Recent cases of corporations acting without integrity have proven to be extremely costly, and have become so ingrained in public perception that the mere mention of these businesses will conjure unfavourable images for years to come. In June 2018, German authorities slapped a €1 billion fine on Volkswagen for installing software in diesel engines designed to cheat emissions tests. The company had already agreed to a $4.3 billion settlement with US regulators related to the same issue. Petrobras, the Brazilian oil giant once estimated to be the largest company in the Southern Hemisphere by market capitalization, is now much reduced in size; its name is now tied to the Car Wash corruption scandal, and many Brazilians view it as complicit in the derailing of their country’s development trajectory. Building integrity in business goes beyond merely avoiding large and costly scandals. While integrity is often considered in combination with compliance, as both offer strategies for getting employees to act in accordance with ethical standards, there is a difference.
