While compliance is top-down, draws on a language of rules, and encourages norms of obedience, integrity relies on bottom-up, participatory processes, willing employee engagement, and the internalization of moral codes. Fostering a culture of integrity has advantages over a culture of compliance. It develops greater internal cohesion and trust within teams, and improved prospects for the correction of problematic behaviour in the absence of oversight from senior management. Over time, companies that foster integrity are likely to become more attractive to individuals who value integrity in the workplace. Surveys of millennials suggest that such intangibles are given increasing weight by highly skilled young people when deciding where to build their careers. A report published by a University of Manchester professor in 2013 described the loss of public confidence in British banks between the early 1980s and 2009 as the biggest change ever recorded by the British Social Attitudes surveys, which had been conducted since 1983; the majority of the decline actually occurred prior to the global financial crisis. Other surveys show strongly negative public reactions to multinational corporations that pay taxes outside of the countries where they have a considerable presence, even if they do so legally. Such surveys present opportunities for business leaders to address the causes of public concern, and increased integrity in the corporate world can give businesses a greater voice in political and global affairs.

name: Business Model Disruption
description: Historically, the space sector was solely the domain of governments and large telecommunications companies. Satellites were large and expensive, and required years to develop and launch, while related technologies evolved over periods lasting decades. Related private sector activity was largely limited to television broadcasting. Now, more than 60 countries have more than 1,900 satellites in operation, and the bulk have commercial rather than military purposes. Some countries have granted private entities relative freedom by softening regulatory control; the private spaceflight company Virgin Galactic, for example, has received clearance from the US Federal Aviation Administration to operate. Still, it is common for commercial space startups to face an uncertain and burdensome regulatory environment, because governments have generally not yet determined how much freedom they want to grant. Many areas of space activity are subjected to suffocating regulatory regimes, or face a legal void - and the number of affected companies is expanding as space commerce becomes increasingly important. Government and defence industry spending helped trigger a flood of information technologies and related investment that is now increasingly being directed at commercial space ventures - thanks to increased commoditization and miniaturization driven by Moore’s Law (which dictates that an increasing number of transistors piled onto chips leads to smaller and more powerful devices). Cloud computing and cheaper processing power are enabling data analysis previously only available to governments, while 3D printing is enabling the building of structures in space that would not be possible to launch from Earth. Some of the startups innovating in the space sector include SpaceX and Blue Origin, which are attempting to make reusable launch vehicles a reality - and to dramatically reduce the cost of spaceflight. DigitalGlobe, PlanetIQ, and dozens of other companies are meanwhile trying to point the way forward in terms of how we use satellites to better understand the planet and human activity, and Planetary Resources, Deep Space Industries, and other private companies are attempting to extract resources such as water and minerals from the far reaches of the solar system with mining operations. These efforts could improve our collective odds of securing desperately needed natural resources that may soon be depleted on Earth.

name: Business Model Innovation
description: Many successful innovators are said to have re-written the rules of their industry - which usually means that they managed to change accepted practices, and to disrupt established relationships. Although not all business model innovation involves new technology, a lot of it has been driven by information and communications technologies that both enable the rapid reconfiguration of value networks and give rise to new forms of value creation. The internet has altered distribution channels (compare Netflix’s online content distribution with now-antiquated video rental stores), and enabled supply chain disintermediation; Dell and Amazon can now bypass traditional retail space and sell directly to consumers (according to a report published by Deloitte, a record annual total of 6,885 physical stores had already closed in the US during 2017 by December 1 of that year). The internet has also given rise to the “freemium” model for services and software; Dropbox, for example, makes basic file storage free but charges for additional capacity. Offshoring has also been a result, as things like basic IT functions move to relatively low-cost places like Bangalore. Another result: a proliferation of businesses, like Facebook, trafficking in personal data and advertising. Business model innovation often flows from a unique take on customer needs, and on the best ways to satisfy them. The idea of software-as-a-service, for example, represented by offerings like Salesforce tools for businesses or Gmail, was driven by firms that realized customers do not necessarily care about owning software outright. Customer needs, however, are multi-faceted and often poorly articulated, making it a challenge for firms to judge whether or not a business model innovation has delivered what people actually want. As Clayton Christensen wrote in his 1997 book The Innovator's Dilemma, disruptive innovation of any sort will often first gain traction with a customer base that is difficult to identify (which is why many firms fatally ignore the threat of disruptive innovation until it is too late). There is some evidence that business model innovation may provide greater competitive advantage, and shareholder returns, than product or service innovation. However, successful business model innovation often requires simultaneous change in multiple parts of an organization, the development of all new competencies, and, potentially, the cannibalization of existing products or services. ​

name: Business Model Shifts
description: The increasing pace of life, technology innovation, and evolving customer expectations are creating demand for new business models that provide access to cars, rather than ownership - and this is already having an impact on vehicle sales volumes. Millennials, for example, have proven to be more pragmatic about car buying than previous generations, and have a relatively lower rate of car ownership. It is possible that we may have even reached peak auto sales, at least in developed markets. Sharing economy-related mobility services include e-hailing (US-based Uber, or China-based Didi), carpooling (France-based BlaBlaCar), and parking and fleet management (US-based Luxe or Netherlands-based LeasePlan). The technologies underpinning these services are empowering consumers, and challenging the traditional sales and servicing model relied upon by car dealerships. As urban populations expand - 66% of the world’s population will be living in cities by 2050, compared with 54% in 2014, according to a United Nations estimate - demand for urban transport and automobile access (if not automobile purchases) will only increase. That will present a new set of social and environmental challenges, which can be addressed with an intelligent mix of new operating models that are based on sharing and increased asset utilization. Relatively young companies are also applying technology innovation in order to revamp traditional auto industry models. The website TrueCar, for example, is bringing transparency to the new car-buying process by showing people how much others have paid for a car they are interesting in purchasing. Meanwhile a new generation of automotive insurers are offering peer-to-peer products that leverage social media in order to enable group purchasing of policies, thereby reducing administrative costs and dividing up risk.

name: Canada and Global Trade
description: Trade represented 64% of Canada’s Gross Domestic Product as of 2017, compared with less than 51% in 1987, according to World Bank data. Since 2000, Canada has been at the forefront of so-called preferential liberalization, or giving better trade terms to formal partners; it is the only country to have a trade deal with all (other) G7 members. Canada’s ability to increase global trade, attract foreign investment, and develop more ties with growing markets is key to its future economic growth. The Canadian government has singled out the Asia-Pacific region as a priority for future trade development. Currently, Canada’s exports to East Asia represent less than 10% of its total, however, and Canada’s share of China’s imports is declining. Declining foreign direct investment from China suggests that Chinese companies perceive a high cost of doing business in Canada, as well as a restrictive regulatory environment with significant domestic trade barriers - such as inter-provincial labour and trade restrictions. Beyond China, Canada signed the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) in 2016. The US later withdrew from the pact, though Canada and other remaining countries signed a revised, Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership in 2018. In 2018, the US announced it would impose tariffs on aluminium and steel imports from allies including Canada; Canada responded by announcing new tariffs on a range of US goods including whiskey and toilet paper. The US under Donald Trump has also overhauled the North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. In 2016, the Canadian Government signed the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with the European Union, Canada’s second-most-important trading partner after the US. The agreement seeks to facilitate trade through expanded market access including for services, remove customs duties, and protect labelling that shows where a product is from. CETA covers a relatively broad scope of trade issues and strengthens market access for Canadian products into the EU, which is a much larger market than the US. However, before CETA can take full effect, national parliaments within the EU must also approve it. To date, a number of EU countries have ratified the deal, including Sweden, the Czech Republic, and Spain, according to the European Parliament.

name: Canada and Sustainable Energy
description: Canada is an established energy producer that exports uranium, oil, natural gas and electricity around the globe. Now, the country is working to wean its own domestic energy market from fossil fuels - which provided about 77% of the energy consumed domestically in 2015 (the remaining 23% came from hydropower, biomass, nuclear, wind and solar). Canada’s national figures hide profound differences among its provinces and territories, which have different energy resources at their disposal, and various ways of using resources to support their economies. Canada’s oil and gas sector has been a magnet for investment, with three provinces - Alberta, Newfoundland and Labrador, and Saskatchewan - producing 97% of all Canadian oil. At the same time, in 2013, British Columbia, Manitoba, Newfoundland and Labrador and Québec generated hydro-electricity with emissions of less than 1 metric ton of CO2 equivalent per capita. Models that explore Canada’s energy future generally suggest that successfully moving to sustainable energy systems will rely on enhanced low-carbon electrification, deployment of alternative fuels, and better energy efficiency and conservation; currently, roughly one-third of Canada’s domestic energy is lost as it is converted to power various service technologies. Renewable energy resources abound in Canada. Calgary, Edmonton and Saskatoon, which currently rely on high-carbon sources of electricity, receive over 2,200 hours of sun per year. And when it comes to wind, the Pan-Canadian Wind Integration Study has indicated a potential for increased energy generation in all Canadian regions. Tidal and wave energy might become part of future energy mixes, while nuclear is another low-carbon option for both heat and power; it is a significant source of electricity in New Brunswick and Ontario. Advanced biofuels also show promise. They are now being demonstrated at commercial scale, with one major plant in operation in Alberta. Canada’s forestry sector, in particular, may benefit from a biorefinery strategy. Canada is targeting a 30% reduction in economy-wide green-house gas emissions from 2005 to 2030; in April 2017, the country’s government launched Generation Energy, a country-wide consultation on how energy systems could evolve to meet that climate change goal. Unique challenges include a carbon-intensive economic and social structure, which is the legacy of exploiting plentiful land and resources, and a large fossil fuel production sector that remains a source of wealth. Additionally, complex arrangements between governments and indigenous peoples can make coordinated action difficult.

name: Canada on the International Stage
description: Canada has played a proactive role in a number of efforts to improve general well-being and the environment around the world. The Canadian government has participated in international bids to support environmental protection, to improve international responses to conflict, crises, and disasters, to promote human rights, global health, and development, and to prioritize gender equality and women’s empowerment in international assistance. The government aims, for example, to promote what it has dubbed a “feminist international assistance policy,” in order to advance gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls.  In the area of climate change, Canada balances its own exploitation of fossil fuel resources with support for various international environmental measures. The country has signed the Paris Agreement on climate change, and joined the Climate & Clean Air Coalition. Due to its geographical location, Canada has a significant stake in the effective resolution of environmental issues that impact polar regions, including climate change, trans-boundary pollution, and ozone depletion. The Canadian government has also pledged to support the implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples - which aims to spur innovative transformation for domestic and international governmental institutions. In many ways, Canada’s international priorities are a reflection of the country’s own domestic commitments to promote human dignity, inclusive governance, and sustainable growth.

name: Canada's Workforce and Talent
description: Canada’s steady rise in employment is an immigration story. In 2016, for the first time, the country’s population of those 65 and older exceeded those under the age of 15. The greying trend has noticeably reduced the labour supply. Even female labour force participation, which rose considerably from the mid-1970s to the early 2000s, has since stabilized. In recent years, labour force growth has therefore rested on rising immigration. The number of arriving immigrants has risen from about 100,000 per year in the 1980s, to nearly 300,000 by 2010. Now, the government has set an annual immigration target in excess of 300,000. The quality of Canada’s workforce - its talent - is bolstered by a secondary school system that performs well. The most recent Programme for International Student Assessment ranked Canada 7th out of 70 places. However, a significant component of the workforce was educated elsewhere. Canada’s immigrants are mostly highly educated. Many, though, have neither French nor English as a mother tongue. The most recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Program for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC) study, conducted in each country’s official languages, ranked Canada in roughly the middle of the 23 countries included. Immigrants, who were mostly tested in a language other than their mother tongue, pulled Canada’s score down a bit. Canada has one of the larger postsecondary sectors, consisting of universities, two- or three-year colleges and apprenticeships, in the OECD. Despite the sector’s overall strength, there are problems. Evidence suggests some disconnect between what the sector supplies and what employers need. The PIAAC found that about 25% of university graduates had much poorer cognitive skills than one would expect with that level of education. In addition, apprenticeships have a mixed history in Canada. A substantial, prolonged influx of immigrants with trade skills meant the country did not develop a strong apprenticeship system. Those who complete apprenticeships generally do well, however; their average yearly earnings in 2015 were almost CAD 70,000. The overall size of the apprenticeship sector is relatively small, and there is a widespread view among policy-makers that Canada would gain from a strengthened capacity to supply trade skills.

name: Canada’s Infrastructure Development
description: After a period of relatively low investment, Canada slipped to 25th place out of 140 countries in the infrastructure category of the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index for 2018, down from 10th place as of 2009. The country’s Advisory Council on Economic Growth has noted an estimated infrastructure funding shortfall ranging from CAD 150 billion to CAD 1 trillion, though the Canadian Public Policy Forum expects infrastructure spending at all levels of government to be between CAD 500 billion and CAD 750 billion over the next decade. Some of this spending has already begun, and the average age of Canada’s infrastructure is declining for the first time in a generation. The Canada Infrastructure Bank, charged with investing at least CAD 35 billion in revenue-generating infrastructure projects, is designed to operate at arm’s length from the government. The entity is supposed to attract private funding to infrastructure investment, and to serve as a centre of expertise. Currently, private ownership of infrastructure is comparatively low in Canada. Some innovative public-private partnerships have been completed successfully, however, such as the Canada Line rapid rail project in Vancouver. Others are in the works, such as the REM automated rail system in Montreal, which has the second-largest pension plan in Canada as its main investor. These projects reflect a sea change for Canada, towards large projects with an equity structure that could be attractive for large investors like pension funds. Consistently drawing in such private investors will require other changes. One example: while Canada's infrastructure is now almost exclusively maintained by tax revenue, the Canada Infrastructure Bank's focus on revenue-generating projects suggests a potentially far greater role for infrastructure funded by user fees in the future. The fee model could both promote private sector involvement, and reduce traffic jams by introducing costs similar to the congestion charges now levied on vehicles within certain areas of London and Singapore. The Canada Infrastructure Bank is intended to promote evidence-based decision-making, and collect and share data. And if it turns out to be sufficiently independent from government, it has the potential to greatly improve infrastructure decisions by insulating them from politics. It is not yet clear whether it will develop a national infrastructure plan, as other countries have. Even so, it is designed to catalyse private sector involvement, and ensure rigorous project development, execution, and operation.

name: Canada’s Innovation Agenda
description: Rohinton Medhora, the president of Canada-based think tank the Centre for International Governance Innovation, recently identified “a malaise in innovation.” Canadian productivity, he noted, had not improved in 20 years, and so-called total factor productivity - a central measure of the economic contribution of innovation - had been flat or even negative in recent years. An op-ed written in 2017 by Jim Balsillie, former co-CEO of BlackBerry-maker Research in Motion, for The Globe and Mail, pointed to Canada’s “reliance on outdated economic theories” as a reason for this shortcoming, and cited a need to better enable Canadian firms to retain intellectual property rights as they compete in major markets. Another Globe op-ed from 2017 advocated for standards that put Canadian technology at the heart of developments in diverse fields, university-industry partnerships that create deeply embedded knowledge that attracts firms to Canada (rather than selling its knowledge to other countries) and direct support from university alumni networks to help firms augment expertise and international intellectual property strategies. Canada has never had an innovation strategy, preferring instead to rely on trade agreements that open up markets but have an uncertain impact on innovation. There are signs that this blind spot is being addressed. Under Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, in 2015 the Canadian Ministry of Industry was rebranded as the Ministry of Innovation, Science and Economic Development. In 2016, Minister of Innovation, Science and Economic Development Navdeep Bains launched consultations with the aim of developing a national Innovation Agenda, and the government’s 2017 budget included a call to develop an Intellectual Property Strategy. In 2018, the federal government announced the winners of an innovation funding program committing CAD 950 million to five industry consortiums drawn from hundreds of companies and research institutions - and focused on concepts such as artificial intelligence-powered supply chains, in order to help spark a “made-in-Canada Silicon Valley.” Canada ranked 18th out of 140 countries in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index in terms of its population’s digital skills, 2nd in terms of time required to start a business, and 18th in terms of patent applications per million people.

name: Central Banks and Regulation
description: The effects of the US subprime mortgage crisis spread rapidly throughout banks, markets, and corporate balance sheets, touching off a global calamity. More recently, the euro crisis reinvigorated fears of financial contagion. Systemic risk remains, and changes in monetary policy at the world’s most significant central banks are a potential source of volatility. Modern banking and capital markets cannot be understood without first understanding central banking and monetary policy. The Bank of Japan has a balance sheet equivalent in size to more than 70% of that country’s GDP, and quantitative easing (when a central bank buys up securities in an effort to lower interest rates) in the US and the United Kingdom has expanded the balance sheets at central banks in those economies to the equivalent of more than 30% of local GDP. In addition, low or negative-interest-rate central bank policies have impacted banking models, asset prices, and wealth inequality. Central banks face constant political pressure to keep interest rates low, but as rates inevitably rise it will have global consequences. That has spurred calls from many central bankers in emerging markets to prepare by coordinating national policies. There is a need for more effective financial regulation, and central banks have addressed this to some degree by expanding their mandates to include safeguarding financial stability. They do this by setting capital and leverage requirements, and requiring banks deemed too big to fail to undergo stress tests. The more stringent regulation in recent years has led many financial institutions to reconsider their business models, and lower shareholder expectations for returns. Meanwhile regulators have their own reasons for concern; the growing prevalence of non-bank financial intermediaries has become an issue, for example. The concentration of risk they represent could trigger significant shocks during a period of distress - which could in turn be compounded if financial institutions trade in a manner that is similar to one another. In addition, financial firms are still free to engage in so-called regulatory arbitrage; the amount of protective capital a bank needs to stockpile might be different in one country than in another, for example. Roughly a decade after the financial crisis, there have been shifts towards financial deregulation - most notably in the US. While that is intended to bolster economic growth, it may come at the expense of long-term stability.

name: Challenges to Governing Institutions
description: The industrialized, global economy was built on a platform of hierarchical institutions: legislatures, regulatory agencies, courts, and international bodies such as the United Nations and the World Trade Organization. These grew in sophistication and scope throughout the 20th century. Still, in the developing world, they frequently struggle to deliver the same benefits realized in more advanced legal environments - often due to corruption and limited resources. Weak governance is widely recognized as a critical factor in the failure of economic development. Even in advanced settings, the traditional institutional framework is under duress - as the capacity for deliberative, expertise-based public bureaucracies to govern increasingly complex economic and social systems is limited. Change happens at a rate much faster than most formal institutions can move, and the gap between the data and technology available to private industry and that available to governments puts regulators at a major disadvantage; the Volkswagen emissions scandal of 2015, where the company was found to have installed technology in engines that could dupe regulators, was evidence of this. Technologies are generally developing with a speed and sophistication that it is beyond the ability of publicly-funded bureaucracies to monitor with 20th century regulation. Governing institutions are under pressure. Global supply chains, international capital markets, and digital networks limit the abilities of nation state-based governments with territorial authority. Meanwhile international governing institutions are generally under threat. The US has withdrawn or threatened to withdraw from international trade and climate agreements, and Great Britain is withdrawing from the European Union. In addition, the rise of nationalist, anti-immigrant, and anti-globalization forces has destabilized conventional policy-making, while mass migration in response to economic need and violence has created mounting challenges for democratic governments. Polarized politics within the US and the EU make governance even more uncertain. All of this upheaval is fuelled by technology that is transforming what we need and expect from laws and regulation. The dramatic rise of social media, for example, has amplified voices and views well outside of the mainstream - while attacks on traditional media undermine our ability to achieve a common understanding of facts. Cyberattacks by independent hackers and governments have manipulated political opinion and election results, de-legitimizing leaders and electoral outcomes - while data-driven management tools have reduced demand for conventionally-trained workers, and injected greater insecurity into employment. That has widened inequality, and frayed the social contract essential for trust in government.

name: Changing Demographics
description: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is home to a young, literate, and aspirational population; growing urbanization and prosperity mean consumers there are demanding higher-quality products and services. The consultancy BCG estimates that Indonesia’s population of middle class and affluent will top 140 million by 2020, which presents an opportunity for businesses hoping to tap growing consumer markets. However, this is not necessarily a straightforward proposition throughout ASEAN, as demographic trends vary greatly across the region. Singapore has a wealthy but ageing population, where the number of people over the age of 65 is set to double by 2030, according to the Singaporean Department of Statistics. Meanwhile Indonesia’s young population is a promising sign for ASEAN economic growth, though creating good jobs for the millions of young people joining that country’s workforce is a challenge. Regional high unemployment rates and variation in the standard of living could lead to pockets of social unrest. Within the Philippines, for example, in 2017 the Southern Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao had a regional GDP per capita of $571, while the National Capital Region around Manila had a regional GDP per capita of $8,703, according to data from the Philippine Statistics Authority. Governments must help prepare young people to meet the demands of an increasingly integrated economic region. Current efforts by ASEAN countries may not be adequate. For example, Indonesia allocated only 3.6% of its GDP to public education in 2015, according to World Bank data, despite having one of the region’s youngest populations. ASEAN members also differ in terms of urbanization. As of 2015, about 20% of the population in Cambodia was urbanized, compared with more than 50% in Thailand and almost 75% in Malaysia, according to the World Bank. As more people migrate to cities such as Manila or Jakarta in search of better opportunities, they place added pressure on infrastructure and job markets. Related issues ranging from affordable housing, to low-cost, quality healthcare and education call for ASEAN governments to work closely with private sector and non-government organizations. Every development in the ASEAN region needs to be calibrated to meet local demographic particularities, and governments need to be sensitive to local needs while promoting greater international collaboration. Businesses may have to invest now, in order to one day reap the benefit of ASEAN’s rising young generation.

name: Changing Energy Landscape
description: Oil has underpinned the socio-economic development of Saudi Arabia for decades, while ensuring abundant government revenue via exports. The kingdom boasts 16% of the world’s proven oil reserves, according to the US Energy Information Administration, it has the world’s largest crude oil production capacity, and it is the biggest exporter of total petroleum liquids (three-quarters of the value of all of its exports were accounted for by petroleum exports as of 2016). Recently, however, geopolitical and global energy market developments have created uncertainty for the Saudi economy. Increasingly, natural gas is being used for power generation, while the declining cost of renewable energy technologies has made sustainable power more economically viable. Mobility, in the form of cars and public transportation, is meanwhile being electrified. The Paris Agreement on climate change, which entered into force in 2016, has much of the world moving more aggressively towards a low-carbon economy. Saudi Arabia’s own domestic energy dynamic has also affected its finances; while local energy demand has grown steadily over the past decade, fuel subsidies cost the Saudi government an estimated $61 billion in 2015. The World Economic Forum’s 2017 Energy Architecture Performance Index, which measures energy system performance in terms of environmental sustainability, access, and security, ranked Saudi Arabia 121st out of 127 countries. The kingdom has made significant progress in terms of where it needs the price of oil to trade on global markets in order for the country to balance its budget. In addition, it aims to diversify the fuels used for electricity generation (in part to free up oil for export), and to better monetize its natural gas reserves. Saudi Aramco, the national oil giant, has indicated plans to invest in developing shale gas resources. While an initial public offering of shares in Saudi Aramco had been expected to raise a significant amount of funding for further economic diversification efforts (among other things), the offering has since been put on hold. The ultimate success of efforts to diversify will depend on market conditions, the long-term resolve of the government, the transparency and perceived fairness of reforms, and adequate communication with both the public and the private sector.

name: Chemical Restructuring
description: In a world where resource consumption is coming under increasing public scrutiny, companies in the chemical and materials sector have been pushed to find new ways to grow. The sustained pace of mergers and acquisitions activity between 2015 and 2018 was both an indication of structural changes afoot in the industry, and of the increased need for these transactions as sources of growth. Consolidation, the expansion of product portfolios, and efforts to specialize are major M&A drivers, with the highest rates of activity observed among commodities, fertilizer, and agricultural chemicals businesses. M&A has been one means for growth in an environment of declining margins, product commoditization, and growing competition in emerging markets. However, it has proven to be insufficient to drive sustainable growth. In 2019, M&A activity is expected to continue apace, albeit differently - by shifting to a situation where more mid-sized companies are acquiring the non-core assets of mega-companies, in a strategic way that fits their well-defined portfolios and business models. Meanwhile a great deal of attention will be focused on the expected mega-deals like Sinochem Group's merger with China National Chemical Corporation (ChemChina).   Social expectations, regulation, and new technologies are all affecting chemical and materials firms. The concept of the circular economy, where materials are re-used rather than disposed of, is increasingly gaining traction; the Circular Economy Package introduced in the European Union in 2018 is accelerating the recycling of waste plastics, and the use of recycled plastic content in new products. Some plastics materials suppliers are keying on this trend by exploring models that incorporate recycling facilities into their operations (for example, Borealis’ acquisition of Ecoplast Kunststoffrecycling in 2018). In parallel, many large oil and gas companies have invested in petrochemical capacity, and their ”crude oil-to-chemicals” businesses are expected to have a significant impact. Several related projects are being constructed or planned in Saudi Arabia and Asia. Integration, alliances, and organic growth will still be important parts of the industry - though additional research and development capacity will be needed in order to guarantee economic sustainability, and to help chemical companies recover their status as innovation leaders. Profit opportunities may be found in R&D breakthroughs that help respond to challenges like poor air quality and energy efficiency, and to greater needs to reduce waste while expanding the use of technologies like sensors and robotics.

name: Chemical and Materials Sustainability
description: The environmental sustainability of the chemical and materials industry is already a significant concern in many wealthy countries, and is increasingly a concern in Asia. In China, environmental standards are becoming more stringent, and emissions restrictions are helping to shut down thousands of operating sites every year. While curbing emissions and discharges is essential, the industry must also generally become able to utilize resources more responsibly and efficiently. The industry, after all, is a critical factor for countries that are trying to meet their obligations regarding mitigating and adapting to climate change. Companies have generally been using energy and materials more efficiently and making sustainability a part of their product innovation. The sector is also enabling other industries to follow through on their own sustainability commitments, in the form of solutions for energy-efficient buildings, sustainable transportation, and water purification, and in terms of exploring alternative feedstocks and biotechnology processes. In addition, the sector is developing more transparent and accurate ways to assess the sustainability of production. Demand for more credible and verifiable analysis tools will only increase. The concept of the circular economy, where materials are reused and recycled rather than disposed of, is gaining significant political and industry momentum. The chemical and materials industry is best positioned to contribute to this through innovation that helps address mounting concern regarding plastics pollution, for example. Every year, millions of tons of plastic are disposed of, and a very small fraction is recycled. Related pollution may only get worse as plastics production further expands. Addressing the issue of plastics pollution requires global, coordinated action from both the public and private sectors. The chemical and materials industry should help define a new plastics economy, where materials do not end up in a landfill or in the oceans. In order to do this, the industry has to work hand-in-hand with governments in order to help devise policies that enable a truly circular economy of plastics, and mitigate environmental vulnerability.

name: Chemical and Materials Talent
description: The chemical and materials industry faces two serious challenges when it comes to its workforce: the first is a need to redefine and adapt in the context of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and its associated evolving technologies, and the second is related to attracting and retaining talent. The technological transformation of work is changing reality for millions of workers and companies, and the chemical and materials industry is no exception. Technologies like robotics and artificial intelligence are creating exciting opportunities in terms of productivity for businesses, and in the ways that they can replace unhealthy, dangerous, and repetitive tasks with high-skilled labour. In order to best take advantage of related opportunities and minimize risks, a redefinition of work is required across the industry, and proactive collaboration between governments and companies is necessary. Industry leaders generally see a shortage of the right skills as one of their most serious challenges when it comes to keeping up with innovation. Most of these leaders therefore recognize a need to foster different skill sets in order to make their organizations more agile, and better equipped to embrace new technology developments as they arrive. For incumbent players in the industry to be able to fully exploit Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies to maximum benefit, there is an urgent need to invest in employees. Organizations are exploring mechanisms to develop and acquire the right skill sets, to enhance diversity, and to develop greater agility within their workforces - though these same organizations sometimes struggle to identify which key competencies they will need in the future. According to the results of a survey published by the American Chemistry Council and Accenture Talent Management in 2016, recruiting and retaining top talent was a major concern for the industry and a high priority for management; 87% of respondents highlighted the fact that the industry is suffering from a perception (or image) issue, which can make it unattractive to new graduates. Companies in the sector have to recognize the need to rethink their workforce models in ways that can better attract and retain the sort of employees who can help boost their performance in the future.

name: Circular Business Models
description: People are increasingly embracing businesses that see them as users, rather than consumers - by enabling them to access services rather than having to own the products that deliver the services. As these business models move away from ownership, they are moving towards performance-based models underpinned by reusable products. Enabled by new technologies, these businesses have expanded quickly. BlaBlaCar, the French ride-sharing company, grew from a presence in one country in 2006 to 22 countries, and 25 million members, by 2016. And, according to Robin Chase's 2015 book Peers Inc., by its fourth year of operation AirBnB was already able to offer 650,000 rooms, compared with the 645,000 rooms made available by the Intercontinental Hotel Group by its 65th year. Rental and performance-based companies are generally able to support their pay-per-use customers with remote assistance; Bundles, for example, offers high-end washing machines for rent in the Netherlands, including installation and maintenance, in order to limit the prevalence of high-energy-use machines that are discarded after short periods. These success stories have pushed more businesses to develop sharing models and extend them into new markets. The worldwide number of carsharing service members reached nearly 24 million by 2017, for example, and is projected to total nearly 61 million by the end of 2022, according to a report published in 2018 by market research firm Berg Insight; by that point, the total carsharing fleet should include more than 700,000 cars, according to the report. An analysis published by the consultancy BCG showed that the number of sharing economy-related, venture capital-backed startups in the world (ranging from pet sitting to workspaces) increased to 420 by 2016, from 40 in 2007. Emerging markets are increasingly hotbeds of sharing economy activity, thanks to growing smartphone use in these areas - 81% of respondents to a BCG survey in India had used Uber, according to the analysis, and 93% had used Ola Cabs, an India-based company. The rate at which these business models are expanding has strong implications for the broader adoption of circular economy principles, which are designed to enable the use of technology to minimize the negative impact of consumption.

name: Circular Materials Economy
description: Resource scarcity, and the need for better environmental responsibility, have long served as motivation for sound materials use. Now more than ever before, the principles of a so-called circular economy - where materials are re-used rather than disposed of - need to be included in all of the stages of materials fabrication and utilization. To that end, new sustainable sources of raw materials, and methods for recycling, are being actively sought out and developed. The landscape for the sourcing of the critical mineral components for use in high-tech devices is being changed by the advent of new processes such as bio-mining, where the use of modern gene editing technologies enable the manipulation of organisms in a way that increases extraction yields. The chemical and physical transformation of raw materials into functional forms should always take sustainability into account; one positive example of this in action is the use of agricultural crops such as maize being made into biodegradable polymers for packaging, and being integrated into the production of new medical devices. 3D printing, and manufacturing in general, will likely continue to be optimized in order to better reduce waste - while techniques such as self-assembly (the putting together of final products, like a piece of Ikea furniture) and biosynthesis may open up new avenues. However, for a true materials-related circular economy to flourish, it is important that we eliminate the concept of "end-of-life," especially for metals. Urban mining initiatives are now complementing established (but insufficient) efforts related to recovery and re-purposing metals - as waste streams are increasingly becoming clogged with discarded electronics and other potentially functional systems. For soft matter, biological degradation may see a renaissance due to an enhanced ability to modify organisms capable of breaking chemical linkages; however, additional research is required, especially in the development of new enzymatic systems. Technologies like blockchain may enable a more accurate traceability of materials through their entire lifecycle, informing us with greater accuracy about the sustainability of substances. Closed-loop systems, water re-use, and low carbon emissions from industrial processing are lingering challenges for the extractive and transformative industries. As dynamism increases due to rapid technological change and demand for new applications, the materials sector should take every opportunity to develop a more circular economy.

name: Civic Space
description: The importance of civil society and civic space to the health of society has long been recognized. Charities, citizen’s groups, religious associations, trade unions and other non-governmental organizations play a critical role in protecting rights, enhancing good governance,, and fostering pluralism. The scope of civic space is affected by infringements of a number of rights. Of these, three in particular are notable: the right of peaceful assembly, the right to associate with others, and the right to freely express and exchange opinions. Without these rights, civil society and civic participation cannot flourish. However, the scope of civic space has been restricted in recent years. CIVICUS’ annual State of Civil Society Report 2017 documented the pressure, across states, on civic space and civil society. Threats emanate most obviously from the state itself, but also from private security forces, business actors and organized crime. The report details the introduction of a range of measures that restrict the funding, organization and activities of civil society organizations; physical and verbal attacks on activists, journalists and NGO representatives; and a creeping criminalization of legitimate activities. As often occurs, repressive measures in one state are replicated by others. Indeed, to focus on measures that relate to the funding and activities of civil society organizations, an n April 2017 Comment by the Council of Europe’s Commissioner for Human Rights noted that since 2012, more than 60 countries have passed or drafted laws seeking to impose greater restrictions. Limits on international funding, the imposition of excessive administrative and bureaucratic requirements, and harsh licensing processes are increasingly popular. Measures of this kind gravely threaten civic space. These measures have prompted a range of responses from other states and international bodies. For instance, the European Parliament’s Directorate-General for External Policies published a policy document in early 2017 setting out the ways that the EU can respond to shrinking civil society space. But these developments also raise the question of the role of business. Of course, at a minimum, business should neither undertake nor be complicit in repressive measures and actions that threaten civil society and civic space. This is entrenched in the United Nations Human Rights Council’s Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and other private and public regulatory frameworks. But beyond this, recent commentary has emphasized the ways that business can play a more proactive role in this context. For instance, the 2016 Beyond Integrity report, published by the Charities Aid Foundation together with academics from the London School of Economics, argued that companies ought to use their influence with governments to protect civic space. It sets out ways that civil society actors can build commitment from business, and steps that business can take to build capacity in order to defend civil society. Likewise, a report published in December 2015 by the Institute for Human Rights and Business examined how business can engage with human rights activists and leverage their influence to push back against the pressure on civic space. Its recommendations included measures aimed at improving internal operating procedures, establishing dialogue with affected communities and organizations, and intervening in individual cases of government abuse. The protection of civil society and civic space will be critical in the upcoming decade. Business has an important role to play in responding to new challenges.

name: Climate Action in Latin America
description: Latin America accounted for only about 5% of global carbon emissions as of 2017, according to the Global Carbon Project - compared with the roughly 15% of emissions generated by the US, and the roughly 27% generated by China. However, the region has traditionally relied on natural resource-intensive industries including agriculture, mining, and forestry. Resource-intensive growth and rapid urbanization have exacerbated environmental issues including habitat loss, contamination, and water shortages - while driving unsustainable demand on the energy sector. Additionally, heightened vulnerability to impacts of climate change such as extreme weather events, drought, and sea-level rise have raised concerns about population displacement, food security, and damaged infrastructure. Two of the highest-ranking locations in the Germanwatch Global Climate Risk Index published in 2018, Puerto Rico and Dominica, are located in the region (both had been severely hit by hurricane Maria in late 2017). According to the index, which measures the impact of extreme weather events, Puerto Rico suffered roughly $82 billion related losses in 2017, equivalent to about 63% of the US territory’s GDP.  Latin America is considered a global leader on Paris Agreement commitments - 14 countries from the region were among the first to ratify the deal, which was adopted in 2015 and aims to limit warming to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. According to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, multiple countries from the region include carbon pricing mechanisms in climate action plans submitted as part of the agreement. According to a report published in 2016 by the International Finance Corporation, low-carbon investments including those made in climate-resilient infrastructure and in clean, renewable energy represent a “trillion dollar opportunity” in Latin America. Brazil alone represents $152 billion in renewable energy investment opportunity by the year 2030, according to the report. Greater international collaboration and coordination among local civil society groups, as well as strong monitoring and reporting mechanisms, will be necessary to follow through on related commitments.

name: Climate Change Impacts
description: The oceans are being hit hard by climate change. Effects include ocean warming, ocean acidification, and oxygen depletion. A future ocean that is hotter, more acidic, and a more difficult place for ocean life to breathe presents serious challenges. The oceans have absorbed more than 90% of the heat produced via greenhouse gas-associated warming since the 1970s - and according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the five warmest years on record have all occurred since 2010. Ocean life is largely accustomed to stable temperatures, and is vulnerable to related changes. Coral reefs, for example, which can house millions of species, are being bleached from overheating. Back-to-back extreme ocean heat waves in 2016 and 2017 caused massive bleaching of the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia, killing half of its coral. Potential related economic impacts, not to mention environmental impacts, are significant - a 2013 Deloitte study found that the Great Barrier Reef was generating about $7 billion in revenue for Australia, largely via tourism. As an ocean warms, its oxygen levels drop. Oxygen content in the oceans declined by an estimated 2% between 1960 and 2010, according to a study published in the journal Nature in 2017. In addition, since the First Industrial Revolution, the acidity of the oceans has increased by roughly 30% as a result of carbon dioxide dissolving in marine waters; this makes it more difficult for many organisms to form healthy skeletons and shells. Scientists from the University of British Columbia's Institute for the Oceans and Fisheries have predicted that if climate change continues unchecked, global fisheries may suffer $10 billion in annual revenue loss by 2050. Global warming-driven sea level rise may be the most impactful form of ocean-related climate change - scientists predict that half of the population in 25 megacities (cities with more than 10 million inhabitants) will be affected by sea level rise if climate change is not slowed; Miami, Shanghai and dozens of other cities have already suffered related effects. Climate change must be aggressively checked in order to enable natural adaptation and evolution, and scientists typically agree that the best way to do this is to confront the difficult task of directly reducing global carbon emissions.

name: Climate Change Science and the Arctic
description: The Arctic is warming at least twice as fast as the rest of the planet. A rapidly-changing climate has many ripple effects, from declining food supplies and new strains on indigenous communities, to the opening up of new shipping routes and natural resource development amid melting ice and infrastructure damage. Climate change does not happen in isolation - warming in the Arctic can multiply the impacts of climate change felt globally. Arctic sea ice plays a critical role in moderating Earth’s climate, for example, and research suggests that periods of extreme cold in North America and Europe are tied to changes in the jet stream partially attributable to declines in Arctic sea ice. The high “albedo,” or reflective capacity of sea ice enables it to reflect solar radiation instead of absorbing energy and accelerating surface warming. Sea ice with snow cover can reflect up to 90% of solar energy, which preserves ice for longer periods, according to the National Snow & Ice Data Center in the US. The loss of Arctic sea ice therefore means the ocean is absorbing more solar energy, causing water temperatures to increase and triggering a feedback loop of more melting. Sea ice also influences ocean circulation, as freshwater from melting ice disturbs the density of the thermohaline currents that keep Earth’s temperatures stable. Record lows for the extent of Arctic sea ice are regularly being broken; the four lowest maximum ice cover measurements ever were taken between 2015 and 2018. Warmer temperatures have also made Arctic areas more prone to wildfires, which release sooty black carbon and carbon dioxide that exacerbate climate change (the historic Arctic wildfires in summer 2019 produced the equivalent to Sweden’s total yearly carbon dioxide emissions). In addition, particulate matter from fires can cover ice, diminish its reflective capacity and cause more melting. Thawing permafrost (frozen ground) presents another destabilizing feedback loop, by releasing methane (among other greenhouse gases) into the atmosphere that is capable of trapping more heat than carbon dioxide. Each of these feedback loops is amplified by the fact that a warming Arctic enables more oil and gas extraction, which in turn contributes to climate change and worsens the impacts already being felt both in the Arctic and elsewhere.

name: Climate Change and Ecosystems
description: Climate change is affecting the availability and quality of water resources. On an increasingly warm planet, extreme and irregular weather events such as floods and drought are expected to become more frequent. Warmer river and lake temperatures will reduce the amounts of dissolved oxygen contained in freshwater, and make habitats more lethal for the fish that rely on it to breathe. Warming waters are also more prolific incubators of harmful algae that is toxic for aquatic life and for humans. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C, published in late 2018, noted that by limiting the global average temperature increase to 1.5°C above preindustrial levels, instead of 2°C, we could significantly reduce the risk of severe negative outcomes for ecosystems and human development. For example, at a limited 1.5°C temperature increase, sea level rise by the year 2100 would be 10 centimetres lower than it would be at a 2°C increase - posing less of a threat to coastal cities, and lessening the risk of severe heat waves and torrential storms. A mere half-degree of extra warming, at a 2°C increase, would also mean a ten-fold increase in ice-free summers in the Arctic, and a doubling of the rate of crop loss, according to the report. The report also identified important links between climate change and safe drinking water access - but cautioned that socio-economic factors like governance and wealth also play significant, related roles. Ecosystems such as tropical forests, ocean systems and corals, and wetlands are particularly vulnerable. More extreme variation in terms of rainfall and drought are likely in both a 1.5°C-rise and 2°C-rise scenario; in many cases, that will lessen the quality and quantity of water available for agriculture and other human activity. Limiting warming to 1.5°C will be difficult, but possible, according to the IPCC report, though it indicated that more breakthroughs in terms of carbon sequestration may be necessary to complement existing efforts to reduce emissions. Implementing emerging technologies and adaptation practices can help reduce the vulnerability of people and the environment to climate change, and help to increase the resilience of water resources and systems. Further research is needed, in order to increase awareness and understanding of climate change and to better adapt to a changing environment.

name: Climate Impact in Viet Nam
description: Viet Nam is among the most vulnerable countries when it comes to suffering from the effects of climate change. It ranked 8th on a list of countries most impacted by climate change between 1997 and 2016 compiled by the think tank Germanwatch, with more than 300 related deaths and an estimated $2 billion in related damage. A combination of extreme drought (the worst recorded in a century, which brought the Mekong river to its lowest level since 1926), and natural disasters has wreaked havoc in the country, according to Germanwatch. Projected increases in population, urbanization, and economic growth will all only place more pressure on the environment and natural resources. Energy-inefficient growth has increased greenhouse gas emissions, and undermined the sustainability of economic development. Projections show that by the end of the 21st century, about 40% of the Mekong Delta will be submerged under water, as will one fifth of Ho Chi Minh City, the country’s biggest population centre and a vital economic engine. At least one in ten people in Viet Nam are expected to be directly affected by these changes, which would come at a cost equivalent to about 10% of the country’s GDP. Other environmental factors, including deforestation, the uncontrolled exploitation of natural resources, and the decline of underground water supply are profoundly affecting development. Viet Nam lost more than one third of its area under mangrove cover between 1983 and 2012, due to expanded shrimp farming, industrial development, and increased urbanization - which has in turn increased vulnerability to tidal surges and hurricanes, and to water salinity, according to a report published in 2017 by researchers from the University of Leeds, Vietnam National University, the Institute of Marine Sciences in Zanzibar, and the Centre for Advanced Amazonian Studies in Brazil. In addition, the supply and quality of water have been greatly affected by climate change. The Vietnamese government has sought to address climate change for decades, and has actively participated in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (1994) and the Kyoto Protocol (2002). In 2005, the country passed an environmental protection law, and subsequently approved national targets for adapting to climate change. The government has also sought to generally increase awareness about the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and to shift the country’s economic model from one that relies heavily on fossil fuels to one that better utilizes renewable energy sources.

name: Climate Impact on Nigeria
description: Nigeria has experienced the blunt impact of climate change. According to the Global Climate Risk Index 2018 compiled by the non-profit Germanwatch, Nigeria suffered 77 climate-related fatalities in 2016, and about $94 billion in climate-related losses. Flooding has resulted in property destruction and injury, widespread infection, vector-borne diseases, food insecurity, and ravaged farmland. Given that Nigeria is still a developing country of nearly 200 million people, the majority of whom are poor and uneducated, a broad appreciation of the impacts of climate change might not be possible. This problem might be further exacerbated by limited planning and a reactive approach on the part of the government to climate change mitigation. Urgent action is required, as related impacts are only becoming more devastating. By September 2018, nearly 200 people in the country had been killed by flooding in the year to date, and thousands had been displaced. The government declared a national disaster that month, and the country’s two major rivers - the Niger and the Benue - burst their banks and swept away homes. By November 2018, a Red Cross official reported that flooding was so extensive in some areas of Nigeria that it was impossible to see dry land on the horizon. While Nigeria’s federal government seems to appreciate the challenges stemming from climate change, a concrete, comprehensive plan to address the problem has yet to be developed and implemented. However, there have been some encouraging signs. The federal government’s Department of Climate Change, which was established within the Federal Ministry of the Environment in 2011, has established programs for the implementation of a 20% unconditional reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, and for the issuance of green bonds meant to finance low-carbon opportunities. In addition, Nigeria is a party to the 2016 Paris Agreement on climate change, which aims to limit the global temperature rise to well below 2°C above preindustrial levels. Meanwhile individuals and civil society organizations in Nigeria are making related efforts. The Climate Change Network of Nigeria, a non-profit coalition of more than 150 civil society organizations, was formed in 2007 and has sought to galvanize collaboration between the public and private sectors.

name: Collective Action
description: A low-corruption environment is a public good. Once established, low levels of corruption are there for everyone to enjoy. But generating a low-corruption environment where one does not already exist is extremely challenging, not least because even when corruption is widespread, corrupt transactions tend to be concealed from all except those who are directly involved. Fighting corruption is in the collective interest, and requires collective action. It does not follow, however, that it is in anyone’s individual interest to be the first to take a stand where corruption is widespread. In systemically corrupt societies, solo efforts on the part of civil society activists, businesses or NGOs are likely to meet some form of punishment, and are unlikely to achieve lasting success. That is why coordinated, group action is needed for anti-corruption drives, in order to create a real chance of fostering genuine change. As more relevant actors participate, individual costs of participation are reduced, and the odds of success rise - and, it becomes in more actors’ interests to join the effort to create a low-corruption environment. This logic underpins initiatives where different actors club together and promise to abide by shared anti-corruption policies. For example, companies have publicly committed to anti-bribery policies in accordance with Transparency International’s Business Principles for Countering Bribery. Many banks have partnered with the Joint Money Laundering Intelligence Taskforce, which has instigated thousands of bank-led investigations of clients suspected of money laundering. Shipping companies sign up to the principles of the Maritime Anti-Corruption Network, while mining companies adhere to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI). Coordinated responses to corruption can be impaired by uncooperative agents, however. As a public good, low corruption environments do not exclude those who do not contribute to their establishment; free-riding off of others’ efforts can therefore cause problems. If one member of a group seeks preferential treatment by offering bribes behind other members’ backs, it can damage the net effectiveness of group action. Sanctioning by naming and shaming, suspension, or expulsion from a group are strategies that both the EITI and the anti-money-laundering Financial Action Task Force employ. The G20/B20 platform is a great example of the far-reaching impact that public-private collective action can have. The G20 Anti-Corruption Working Group has provided a number of recommendations for member countries that commit to fighting corruption, including tools to build a capacity to combat corruption and to foster integrity initiatives.

name: Combatting Climate Change
description: The Paris climate change conference in 2015 saw countries adopt the first-ever universal, legally binding global climate deal (which was generally viewed as a significant French diplomatic success). As a member of the European Union, France shares the EU’s Intended Nationally Determined Contribution, and has committed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to at least 40% below 1990 levels by 2030. The French economy is not particularly carbon-intensive, as it accounts for only 1.2% of global greenhouse gas emissions while contributing the equivalent of about 4% of global annual GDP. Total energy-related carbon dioxide emissions and per capita emissions in France are relatively low compared with other G20 countries, and are steadily declining. The country’s low carbon intensity stems from its use of nuclear power and hydro energy for electricity generation. However, in order to achieve its voluntary 2020 objectives established as part of the Paris Agreement, and to remain on track to limit warming well below 2°C above preindustrial levels, France must significantly reduce its consumption of fossil fuels; the country ranked 15th in the Climate Change Performance Index for 2018, which identified significant gaps in the implementation of policies at the national level. The French Minister for the Ecological and Inclusive Transition set a target of carbon neutrality, or net zero carbon emissions, by 2050. Sectors that emit the most greenhouse gas include transportation (28% of national emissions) and heating (20% of emissions), according to the Ministry of Ecological and Inclusive Transition. Fossil fuels still account for more than two-thirds of final energy consumption in the country, and the government aims to phase coal out of the electricity sector by no later than 2023, and to ban the sale of cars that run on gasoline and diesel starting in 2040. Currently, 75% of the electricity produced in France comes from nuclear, and roughly three quarters of the country’s nuclear capacity is expected to wind down operations during the 2020s. The need to plan new capacity, or at least revamp existing capacity, is critical. The share of renewable energy in France’s total energy supply has been increasing slowly during the past decade, but is still relatively low compared with other G20 members. Renewables represented about 13% of the country’s total energy consumption as of 2015, according to World Bank data, compared with less than 9% as recently as 2006.

name: Commodities and Supply Chains
description: The Consumer Goods Forum, an industry association, estimates that four agricultural commodities - beef, palm oil, paper and pulp, and soy - account for about half of all tropical deforestation. Demand for these commodities is only expected to increase, particularly in emerging markets. Public-private partnerships like the New York Declaration on Forests, which aims to halve the rate of deforestation by 2020, the 2010 Consumer Goods Forum, which pledges to achieve zero net deforestation by 2020, and the Tropical Forest Alliance 2020 have set ambitious goals; however, a more precise understanding of related social and environmental risks presented by supply chains is required. More clarity is needed on links between agricultural expansion and forest impacts, for example. Monitoring systems can facilitate the implementation of protection efforts, while increased transparency can encourage accountability. Improved land tenure data, related to concessions, farm boundaries, and sourcing information can make environmental impacts clearer to everyone interacting with a supply chain. Meanwhile more frequently-updated data on forest changes (now available annually, or as often as weekly across the tropics), could provide a powerful tool to identify supply chain risk, and monitor compliance with deforestation commitments. Companies must actively monitor the areas where they are sourcing, and make related disclosures; where information proactively disclosed is unavailable, civil society groups and research organizations have filled in the blanks through their own investigations. Non-governmental organizations have been working with companies and governments to develop environmental assessment tools, while certification systems for anti-deforestation requirements have advanced the sustainability agenda. Moratoria on purchasing commodities grown on deforested land have been successful under some conditions, notably in the case of Brazil’s Soy Moratorium in the Amazon, though they have been difficult to extend sector-wide. Approaches that take into account the needs of producers, and are adapted to different geographies and supply chains, are necessary to foster agricultural production that minimizes forest impacts. Regional processes, such as those tied to Tropical Forest Alliance 2020, have showcased the power of collaborative efforts; a regional pledge signed by seven African governments to shift to sustainable palm oil production, called the Marrakesh Declaration, is one such example. Hastening the implementation of jurisdictional programs that have a state or regional focus could further bolster progress towards achieving sustainable development goals. A Tropical Forest Alliance 2020-commissioned study published in early 2017 identified 34 different jurisdictional programmes that were being planned or implemented.

name: Competition from Institutional Investors
description: As institutional investors continue to grow and evolve, they have begun to develop their own in-house investment capabilities. Services that were once performed only by private investors - such as private equity, real estate investments and infrastructure investments to name a few - in an outsourced or advisory capacity are now increasingly being done using internal personnel. Institutional investors are now pursuing several models of direct investing, including  co-investment, where an asset manager allows the institutional investor to invest alongside their investments without an additional asset management fees; partnerships, where an institution may partner with other institutional direct investors or with an asset manager, and partners may make an informal agreement to pursue an asset together; and a solo model, where all investment decisions and strategizing are done within the organization, allowing for the highest degree of asset owner engagement. A major factor in the move toward more direct investing has been dissatisfaction with the prevailing fee structure, usually a variation of the  ‘two and twenty’ model – wherein fund managers charge 2% of assets managed and claim 20% of any profits. With many institutional investors publically accountable to large interest groups it is difficult to justify paying the large fees often demanded by private investors. This has been compounded by the fact that in recent years hedge funds and private equity firms that have handled institutional investor assets have underperformed. According to the 2016 Prequin Global Hedge Fund Report, only around two-thirds of hedge funds posted positive returns, with an average of only 2.02% in 2015, the same year 33% of investors said their performance expectations were not met. These factors have contributed to an increased desire for control in investing decisions by institutional investors, pushing them to be much more aggressive with building out in-house investment teams, which allows them to dictate investment strategies. Competition from institutional investors has caused private investors to adapt their offering to provide their capital providers with more control over investment decisions, and the reduction or elimination of some fees.  New partnership models have also emerged, especially in private equity.

name: Computational Confrontation
description: Technology plays a profound role in shaping the global risks landscape. Massive data fraud and theft, cyber-threats and manipulation, advancements in quantum research, and advanced and pervasive forms of surveillance and "dataveillance" are all related factors. This was highlighted in the World Economic Forum’s Regional Risks for Doing Business Report 2018, with cyber-risks consolidating their position as the top risk in regions including Europe, East Asia, and North America. Around two-thirds of the respondents surveyed for the Forum's 2019 Global Risks Perception Survey expected the risks associated with fake news and identity theft to increase, while three-fifths said the same about loss of privacy to companies and governments. Malicious cyber-attacks and lax cybersecurity protocols led to massive breaches of personal information in 2018. The largest was in India, where the government ID database, Aadhaar, suffered multiple breaches that potentially compromised the records of all 1.1 billion registered citizens. Elsewhere, personal data breaches affected around 150 million users of the MyFitnessPal application, an initially estimated 500 million Marriott hotel guests, and around 50 million Facebook users. Cyber vulnerabilities can emerge in unexpected places, as demonstrated in 2018 by the Meltdown and Spectre cyber-threats - which targeted weaknesses in computer hardware, rather than software. These threats potentially affected every Intel processor produced in the last 10 years. A failure to adequately understand and address risks related to technology, like the potentially cascading effects of cyber-attacks or the breakdown of critical information infrastructure such as cryptography, could have far-reaching consequences. In addition, as technology progresses, workers around the world are increasingly likely to see their jobs automated. Robots will move beyond from completing manual tasks in warehouses, to handling projects in industries like tourism and healthcare - affecting so-called knowledge workers, who may have once had engineering or design jobs that were deemed safe from automation. Technology can also create a dividing line that exacerbates inequality. While 94% of young people in developed countries use the internet, according to International Telecommunications Union statistics published in 2017, just 30% of young people in the least developed countries as defined by the United Nations are online. Meanwhile the internet penetration rate among men worldwide is 50.9%, compared with just 44.9% for women, according to the statistics.

name: Conflict Zones and Fragile States
description: The theft of nuclear material dates back at least to 1957, and the pilfering of uranium-235 from a nuclear scrap recycling plant in Pennsylvania at the height of the Cold War, according to the Nuclear Age Peace Foundation. During any period of conflict, there is an increased risk of the theft of nuclear material and weapons. Due to the proliferation of nuclear technology in recent years and heightened global instability, related risks have spread to some of the world’s least stable territories. Reports made to the Nuclear Security Summit held in the US in 2016, for example, noted that conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia, and within Ukraine, have ratcheted up the risk of nuclear material being smuggled across borders. Fragile or breakaway states like Transnistria, between the Dniester River and Ukraine, and South Ossetia (officially a part of Georgia), provide both a safe haven for smugglers and sources of illicit nuclear material; significant amounts of highly enriched uranium have gone unaccounted for in the region since the breakup of the Soviet Union. In 1995, the International Atomic Energy Agency began compiling related information about unauthorized movements of nuclear or other radioactive material, by establishing a dedicated Incident and Trafficking Database. Nuclear reactors have become key targets. According to media reports, an aborted Islamic State attack in Belgium in 2016 was likely meant to target a nuclear power plant, and suspected state-sponsored Russian hackers targeted nuclear facilities in the US in 2017 - as tension mounted over alleged Russian meddling in American elections. Live conflict zones add another layer of danger, as nuclear reactors can become targets of direct attacks. In 2014, Hamas, the Palestinian group that controls Gaza, launched three Iranian-designed rockets that targeted but narrowly missed the Dimona reactor in Israel. Amid renewed exchanges of violence during 2018 between Israel and Iranian proxies in Lebanon and Syria, and civil unrest in Gaza and the West Bank, a repeat attack became increasingly possible. The ongoing conflict in Syria is also a major risk factor, as nuclear material generated by the country’s former nuclear weapons programme is largely unaccounted for. A March 2018 report published by the Institute for Science and International Security suggested that this material may include enriched uranium and related equipment, potentially providing the necessary elements for a so-called dirty bomb.

name: Conflict and Peacebuilding
description: We know very little about the exact role that religion plays in conflict situations, or in peacebuilding efforts. Religion intersects with related economic, social, and political factors in complex ways, and religious communities are often arrayed on opposite sides of the same issue. Still, evidence suggests that religion plays a significant role in both the causes of conflict, and in the path to peace and reconciliation.
