Enacted or proposed related laws seek limits or restrictions on the storage, transfer, or processing of data, or require local data storage ownership (while others have local government procurement requirements). Localization laws passed in countries such as China apply to broad segments of industry and require data to be stored on servers placed within borders, while other countries, such as Germany and Australia, have industry-specific laws that require types of information such as medical records to be stored on local servers, according to an article published by the American Bar Association in 2017. Data localization laws are not necessarily new. Sensitive government data has long been subject to local requirements, in the US and other countries. In addition, more extensive laws applying to all forms of data have long been a feature of authoritarian governments. However, Edward Snowden’s release in 2013 of classified information, which described US government efforts to collect relatively unprotected data about the citizens of other countries, encouraged many governments to at least begin considering data localization laws. The proliferation of restrictive rules governing internet use, including data localization measures, threatens to hinder global commerce, however - and to hinder globalization more generally. A survey of more than 400 chief information officers and chief technology officers, published in a 2017 report by Accenture, found that 74% of respondents expected to exit a geographic market, delay market-entry plans, or abandon market-entry plans in the next three years as a result of increased barriers to globalization. For companies, the complexity of international operations will generally multiply in the near future as a result of measures like data localization rules, according to the Accenture report.

name: Data Privacy
description: Attitudes towards data privacy online are evolving; while prioritizing security above all may threaten the basic human right to privacy, prioritizing privacy over security may undermine our safety. Governments are pressing ahead with a variety of efforts to address data privacy. In the European Union, for example, the so-called General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) came into force in 2018. It applies to companies that process the personal data of anyone living in the EU - no matter where that processing takes place. Under the regulation, companies will have to simplify their requests for consent to process a user’s data, and can be fined as much as the equivalent of 4% of annual revenue for not gaining sufficient consent. The regulation will also enable internet users to confirm whether their data has been processed, and why, and to receive a copy of their collected personal data upon request. In the US, by contrast, an internet user’s data privacy may depend upon the type of user, where the user is (which state), the type of data in question, and where the data has been deposited. Twitter, for example, has a feature specific to the company that provides a download of a user’s personal archive of activity on the social media service. The Children’s Online Privacy Protection rule, which enforced by the US Federal Trade Commission, requires companies operating websites directed at children younger than 13 to obtain consent from a child’s parent before collecting and using a child’s personal data. In China, data privacy protections are minimal, and internet users regularly face criminal charges including subversion based on their online activity, according to the watchdog organization Freedom House. The ability to remain anonymous online has been restricted in China, according to Freedom House, and companies and municipalities in the country have been testing ways to assess someone’s online activity alongside other personal data when that person applies for a loan or other type of service.

name: Data Sharing and Permissions
description: Data provide important insights, and we are witnessing a revolution in the ways that we collect, manage, and share these insights. The value of can data accrues as it accumulates, and even apparently unrelated datasets can deliver insights when they are juxtaposed. Combining multiple varieties of health data, for example, can yield benefits for preventive health and precision medicine (which is also known as personalized medicine, and involves using information about a patient’s genetic code and environment to predict and potentially prevent disease). The power of genomics-enabled health care is proportional to the amount of patient data that can be accessed and analysed, according to an article published in the journal Health Affairs in 2018. As a result, France has committed the equivalent of roughly $700 million to fund a genome-sequencing centre, and China has committed up to $10 billion to fund its precision medicine initiative, according to the article. For private health companies, such efforts could help them develop more sustainable and effective models for treatment. The greater sharing of information about cyberthreats and vulnerabilities could aid companies and governments in their ongoing battle for better resilience. However, opportunities for greater sharing must be balanced with several other important goals - not least the protection of individual privacy, and the enabling of internet users to make informed decisions on how information about them is being used. As cyberattacks have increased, the number of cyber information sharing organizations has expanded into an international network of about 350 recognized Computer Emergency Response Teams, a number of international cyber coordination organizations, and two dozen information sharing and analysis centres, according to a working paper published by the MIT Sloan School of Management in 2017. However, information sharing on cyber threats is still being hindered by privacy concerns, a risk of disclosing trade secrets and reputational damage, and potentially prohibitive costs (including those related to false positives), according to the working paper. Priorities for collaboration: Sharing policy frameworks based on guidelines like the fair information practice principles Advancing prototypes and pilots in areas like health and humanitarian work Developing new legal and market approaches that facilitate data sharing

name: Data and Analytics
description: The International Organization for Migration’s Migration Data Portal, launched in late 2017, is designed to provide consolidated, timely information about migration in order to better inform policy-makers and the public. The potential results of improved data collection and analysis related to migration include more accurate measurement of the progress being made towards achieving the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, a set of targets designed to set a healthy global agenda which includes a number of migration-related elements. In late 2017, IOM Director-General William Lacy Swing noted during a speech that cultivating better data could also help to demystify migration. The use of so-called big data, or massive data sets that enable a more exact analysis of patterns and trends, can be an effective tool to help better understand changes in migration patterns, and migrant behaviour. There is no denying that huge amounts of relevant data are available; sources include proliferating mobile phones, GPS systems and internet-based platforms. New geospatial mapping and analysis technology can also offer the ability to more accurately predict, and better react to, displacement events as a result of extreme poverty, health crises, environmental impacts and conflict. As migration flows are liable to increase abruptly in response to outbreaks of armed conflict, threats to health or extreme weather events, organizations need to be as well-equipped as possible in order to provide assistance. As heavy flows of migrants were making their way through the Balkans on their way to points west in 2016, for example, the International Committee of the Red Cross asked the UN Refugee Agency if it could receive estimates of daily arrivals in order to ensure that it had an appropriate number of volunteers on hand. The UN Refugee Agency used data about daily arrivals to the Balkans it had been capturing since 2015, in order to create a dashboard that combined information about those arrivals with the current status of relevant borders and timely news articles, and was able to provide roughly accurate models of travel times (about three days in order to travel from the Greek Islands to Macedonia as of early 2016, for example, and about two to three days on top of that to reach Austria). Those models were in turn used to create daily forecasts. However, the agency quickly found that unexpected events like border closures could drastically impact the accuracy of their forecasts.

name: Data, Security and Privacy
description: The automobile is becoming the fourth screen for information, entertainment and communications; General Motors, for example, offers 4G data connectivity in all of its new cars sold in North America. By 2025, there should be about 470 million connected cars in the European Union, China and the US, according to research published in 2017 by the consultancy PwC. Ultimately, transport-related data generated in a car may actually become more valuable than the car itself - particularly as self-driving vehicles increasingly liberate people from driving and enable them to focus more on their devices while on the road. However, questions have emerged about who owns this data. Consumers, car dealers, original equipment manufacturers, and telecommunications carriers could all claim ownership in some way. Even more questions regarding data governance and ethics are raised by the fact that an increasing number of applications require artificial intelligence to manage related data flows. Data security is important for car buyers. Results of a survey published in 2017 by Thales e-Security showed that connected cars ranked behind only home security cameras or doorbells in terms of devices seen as most vulnerable to hacking, while nearly half of the survey’s respondents in the United Kingdom and the US feared related viruses or malware. Some 87% of survey respondents in the US, and 92% in the UK felt the government should implement stricter data security regulations for connected cars. Related security incidents can have significant financial repercussions. Following press reports in 2015 about the hacking of a Jeep’s dashboard, Chrysler issued a recall for 1.4 million vehicles that involved providing a USB drive with a security patch to customers.

name: Data-enabled Business
description: According to a 2017 white paper published by the World Economic Forum, digitalization is expected to create up to $305 billion in additional value for the travel industry between 2016 and 2025, while reducing the industry’s environmental footprint, and migrating $100 billion in value from traditional players to new competitors. Digitalization will also result in a net displacement of current jobs in the industry, as it is expected to only be partially offset by the creation of next-generation jobs, according to the report. Online travel aggregators and travel service platforms have shaken up the industry. All travel providers are now seeking ways to develop stronger interaction with customers, and adapting operations to try to both better understand their customers and to boost their own financial performance. Connected devices and artificial intelligence provide ample opportunities to make operations more effective, and enable collaboration and asset-sharing among travel enterprises. Ericsson’s 2017 Mobility Report counted 3.9 billion smartphone subscriptions worldwide, and projected that number to grow to 6.8 billion by 2022 - while more than 3 billion people around the world are using social media every month, according to an early 2018 estimate from the digital agency We Are Social. The combination of voice recognition, augmented reality and artificial intelligence will likely have a profound impact on the travel industry, by enhancing people’s ability to discover the world. To remain competitive, industry players must complement a high-touch approach with high-tech applications. Consumers want to feel special and expect the personalization of services and experiences. Digitalization could also have a potentially positive environmental impact, by contributing to a more sustainable industry footprint through innovation in manufacturing, and through more efficient resource use. Intelligent automation will change the nature of some travel jobs, and put other jobs at risk. It will also generate new employment opportunities that could outpace the automation of existing roles, especially as the industry is expected to maintain its growth. A concerted effort among industry players, governments, educational institutions and civil society will be required to best mitigate potential negative impacts.

name: Decentralized Asset Management
description: The growth of the sharing economy, which provides everything from vacation rentals to car service, can be better enabled through the use of blockchain. Thanks to its transactional capabilities, the technology is able to help co-ordinate loosely coupled assets, companies, and individuals, and can help dramatically reduce the transaction costs associated with both sharing business models and so-called “as a service” models. It also allows for radically new forms of ownership to emerge. In 2017, for example, the non-profit Crypto Valley Association in Switzerland introduced the concept of a Blockchain Crypto Property, or purely digital property rights registered on a blockchain that can be transferred around and carry out functions. Blockchain can also play a fundamental role in re-configuring how utility services are provided. For example, it can redefine how telecom network services are constructed and delivered, by changing how spectrum, or the radio waves needed for mobile phones and wireless networks to function, and physical infrastructure are delivered, managed and paid for. In addition, energy and water systems can utilize blockchain to create peer-to-peer energy markets that provide greater flexibility to users and infrastructure owners. A key challenge is presented by the need to measure the economic output of digital systems with large numbers of decentralized assets. Blockchain can assist in this task, through its ability to capture a record of transactions and bolster the data collection used to measure the digital economy. An increasingly digitalized world, however, means that the number and variety of cyberattacks are growing. In addition, data breaches are becoming more common, as reduced storage costs mean more data are being held for longer periods. The sensors that are increasingly a part of our daily lives also multiply the possibility of an attack. A clear understanding of the privacy policies and regulation associated with blockchains and similar digital technologies is required. Security concerns specifically tied to blockchain include the potential to take control of enough participating nodes in a ledger to tamper with the validation of transactions (a so-called “51% attack,” in the case of Bitcoin), and distributed denial of service attacks that increase processing time, according to a report published in 2017 by the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security.

name: Deepening Interdependence
description: Once distant peoples and places are increasingly tied together by globalization, which involves not only the creation of economic links through cross-border trade and investment, but also stronger social ties, increased communication, and heightened shared risk tied to epidemics and the depletion of natural resources. As globalization has advanced, the ability to create peace and prosperity for any given society is increasingly affected by decisions made elsewhere. The creation and distribution of problematic mortgages in the US can lead to workers in Iceland losing their jobs, for example, while poultry market regulations in Hong Kong SAR can affect the health of citizens in Delhi. Meanwhile carbon emissions that occur in any single place in the world will affect the future of the climate everywhere. Managing this interdependence is the central task of global governance. However, the task is only getting harder. As globalization progressively spread following World War II, global governance became increasingly robust; the result was that it created the necessary conditions for globalization to further expand. When businesses branched out into foreign markets, for example, they developed multinational business models and value chains, which increased their need for, and creation of, effective governments and regulation wherever they operated - that, in turn, enabled other businesses to successively become more globally distributed. The result: a profound, self-reinforcing interdependence. But while a political issue like trade was once primarily tied to elements like tariffs, quotas, and other border issues, it now involves broader public concerns like health and environmental regulation, anti-trust laws, and privacy. To a greater extent than ever before, the economic prosperity, basic security, quality of health, and environmental well-being in any given locale now depend on decisions that are made abroad and applied across borders. This calls for strong, legitimate forms of global governance - though it remains unclear whether existing institutions are capable of managing this new reality.

name: Defence and Security
description: The importance of securing airspace has only increased, due to the deepening interdependence of all domains of war, including air, sea, land and cyberspace. Communications and guidance systems, at least to some degree, depend on maintaining control of airspace; satellite communication, and the use of electromagnetic spectrum more generally, are essential. The US alone had 803 operating satellites as of 2017, including 159 designed for military use, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists. Increasingly small and cheap unmanned aerial vehicles, or drones, coupled with piloting and targeting systems that can be controlled with artificial intelligence, mean that a broader range of actors, with a broader set of motives (including war, surveillance, and terrorism) can now avail themselves of this technology. Meanwhile the traditional, offence-defence balance theory is tilting in favour of conventional air defence systems - as mobile, ground-based systems become both more capable, and more widespread. Long-range missile systems can detect even stealthy aircraft, while new related technologies such as laser weapons are becoming more prominent. Interest in missile defence has increased of late, amid concerns about North Korea’s weapons capability; in a related move, the US approved the sale of anti-ballistic missiles to Japan, which was in turn criticized by Russia. While space is becoming increasingly militarized in the form of so-called ASAT weapons designed to incapacitate satellites, and missile-defence systems, new capabilities such as hypersonic glide weapons are eroding the distinction between space and airspace. China, for example, has reportedly carried out tests of missiles propelled by a hypersonic glide vehicle, designed to fly at blistering speeds while remaining at a relatively low altitude, in order to elude missile defence systems.

name: Defending Humanitarian Principles
description: International humanitarian action rests on four principles: humanity, neutrality, independence, and impartiality. Aid work should be protected under international law, but once-reliable taboos seem to be fading: more hospitals are being bombed, more refugees attempting to cross the Mediterranean are being condemned to drown, more aid workers are being targeted by armed fighters, and more civilians are being starved into surrender. All of this is occurring with few consequences for perpetrators. Humanitarian principles themselves seem to be under attack, and the international community seems short of ideas to protect them. The world’s most vulnerable people are at risk of a vicious cycle where inequality and warfare drive them into destitution, while rising xenophobia and protectionism deny them of hope and relief. If aid is politicized - in order to further stem migration, lubricate alliances, or kowtow to domestic politics - that cycle could worsen. International humanitarian aid relies on shared values, collective action, and mutual support among states and aid organisations. But the international consensus is showing cracks across the board, whether it is related to forming alliances on climate change, human rights, migration, or the rules of war; opting out is in. Despite overwhelming pressures, some 570,000 people work every day on helping others in their hour of need. Humanitarian work relies on a general acceptance that it is well-intentioned, and has no hidden agenda. Preserving this trust requires maintaining high standards at aid agencies, and persuasive advocacy. It also relies on an international consensus to uphold humanitarian action and principles. Aid work amid war and human rights abuse, as in Syria and Myanmar, is especially vulnerable to accusations of bias, deliberately destabilizing authority, or aiding an enemy. Without a broad coalition of supporters, predatory governments or armed groups may feel entitled to block, intimidate, or even harm relief operations and aid workers. The same pattern plays out at the geo-strategic level; while the guardians of the Geneva Conventions - the International Committee of the Red Cross and Switzerland - have tried to formulate a mechanism to help monitor possible violations of humanitarian law, international division on the issue has doomed it to failure. Humanitarian action, busy mopping up man’s inhumanity to man, could use a little aid itself - because for all its flaws, it is doing vital work.

name: Defining Corporate Purpose
description: Business Roundtable, an association of CEOs of the largest American companies, has departed from a longstanding view that corporations exist to serve their shareholders. In 2019, the organization declared that companies should benefit all stakeholders, including customers, employees, suppliers, and communities - in addition to shareholders. This strongly reinforced the idea that profits are not the sole purpose of a business, and that corporations should exist to solve problems and provide services. If they are successful at doing this, long-term shareholder returns can increase, as society in general is better served. Establishing purpose is not an abstract exercise; it has proven to be essential for guiding decision making and for establishing priorities. London Business School Professor Alex Edmans has noted that as virtually all of the major decisions a company makes involve trade-offs, one of the main benefits of having a strong purpose is to guide these trade-offs. Purpose must not only be explicitly defined, however - it must also be implemented. Shareholders must understand the organization’s purpose, and be able to identify the metrics (both quantitative and qualitative) related to delivering on it. Some of these metrics incorporate the traditional concepts behind corporate social responsibility (CSR), such as maintaining positive working conditions and employee satisfaction, cultivating workforce diversity, and focusing on client satisfaction and product quality. But purpose can go well beyond CSR - one example is the clothing company Patagonia, which states that its reason for being is to help protect life on Earth. This is (presumably) understood by its investors, and implemented by designing, producing and selling products in the most environmentally sustainable way possible, and by building its supply chains and customer service around the circular economy ideas of repairing, reusing, and recycling. Responsible corporations create value for society and are motivated by the desire to do so. Survey results published by researchers at Stanford Graduate School of Business in 2018 showed that 65% of Americans believe CEOs at large companies should use their positions to address broad social, political, and environmental issues. That is to say, most Americans realize that corporations need to be committed to providing solutions and value to everyone - and that businesses have a responsibility to society.

name: Deforestation and Climate Change
description: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change estimates that 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions result from tropical deforestation. Because of the role that forests play in regulating climate, sustaining livelihoods, and supporting biodiversity, increasing deforestation in the tropics is a critical issue. Ten thousand years ago, forests covered about half of earth’s land. Roughly a third of these forests have since disappeared, converted for agriculture and other uses. Most forests still standing are degraded or fragmented; less than 20% are intact. Deforestation is concentrated in tropical, developing countries and is driven by the expansion of human settlement and the production of commodities such as palm oil, soy, and beef. International initiatives to reduce deforestation include the New York Declaration on Forests, which has had 180 nations, companies, indigenous groups and other organizations commit to cutting global natural forest loss in half by 2020 - and ending it completely by 2030. The Consumer Goods Forum, which includes global agricultural commodity companies and consumer goods firms, has pledged to work with suppliers and governments to eliminate deforestation from their supply chains by 2020. Forests are increasingly recognized in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. A related, voluntary program, REDD+, incentivizes developing countries to reduce emissions related to deforestation and degradation, and to increase conservation and sustainable management in exchange for results-based payments. The Paris Agreement, entered into force in 2016, has participating countries set voluntary targets to combat climate change; land including forests was accounted for in targets set by 82% of tropical countries. The Nature Conservancy has estimated that better land stewardship could achieve 30% of the climate mitigation needed to limit global warming to less than 2oC, an overarching goal behind the Paris Agreement. Eliminating deforestation in the tropics, particularly in places such as Brazil and Indonesia, would be a relatively low-cost, effective and natural way to address climate change. Despite decades of investment in combating deforestation, however, 2016 saw the largest amount of annual global tree cover loss in the 21st century to date, according to Global Forest Watch. Climate feedback triggered by climate change, such as a high incidence of wildfires, makes the need to reduce deforestation urgent. For efforts to succeed, however, greater vigilance on the part of governments, the private sector, and non-governmental organizations is required.

name: Demand Evolution
description: The 34 industrialized nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development account for just 1.3 billion of the world’s 7.7 billion people. Non-member, developing countries are therefore poised to dictate the future of global energy markets. The pace and structure of economic growth in China, India, and the ASEAN nations (collective population: 642 million) will shape global energy demand, and will exert significant influence on trade patterns and geopolitics. While global oil demand is widely expected to continue growing well into the coming decade, there is a sense that passenger vehicle fuel demand in particular may peak soon - due to the adoption of electric vehicles, and to efficiency gains for internal combustion engines. While this could slow the pace of overall demand growth, a lack of alternatives to oil means it will likely remain a staple of heavy truck and air travel, which are poised to increase alongside economic growth. In addition, oil as a feedstock for plastics and petrochemical production is expected to increase. Global demand for natural gas is expected to continue growing, with the only uncertainty related to by how much - mainly due to its role in power generation. Gas-fired generation is often touted as an environmentally-suitable complement to renewables. However, there is a geopolitical aspect of demand to consider; a lack of local supply is making developing Asian economies more dependent on liquefied natural gas imports from China, while Europe is seeing a politically-motivated diversification away from Russian supply - which in turn is encouraging new entrants like the US (where both natural gas and renewables are continuing to replace coal-fired power plants). Technology also plays in potentially unpredictable ways into future demand. The electrification of transportation systems, for example, coupled with the increasing affordability of renewable energy technologies, may have a transformational impact. Policies and regulations related to these technologies, and to energy security, domestic resource development, and environmental protection, will also have an effect on oil and gas markets. In developing countries, related uncertainty and potential impact can be significantly greater than in the developed world, because local market structures and legacy infrastructure are relatively immature.

name: Demand Shifts
description: Demand for banking and capital market services is growing in developing countries, due to increasing affluence in these places. For financial firms to gain a meaningful foothold there, however, they require an inclusive strategy that can serve both large multinational companies with broad ambitions, and domestic clients aiming to tap new sources of wealth. The speed of financial democratization in these regions is tied to increasing rates of financial literacy and access to the internet; nearly half of the global population is now using the internet, according to a report published by the International Telecommunication Union in 2018, compared with just over a quarter of the global population as of 2009. Demographics, chiefly the ageing populations in many countries, also play a role in increasing demand for new financial products. The traditional world of pension funds, for example, was not long ago shaken up by the advent of low and even negative interest rates, which curbed the financial returns that can be delivered to pensioners (rates have more recently begun to increase); attempts to bridge this gap and find new ways to deliver returns generate risk for the entire financial system. During the financial crisis, there was a global increase in bank deposits - as a growing number of anxious people opted to park their wealth in the relative safety of a deposit account (rather than pouring it into generally more risky, interest-bearing investments). However, that trend has slowed in recent years, according to a report published in late 2018 by BBVA Research. While commercial bank deposits grew at an average annual rate of 6.6% between 2011 and 2015, that fell to 4.4% between 2016 and 2017, and then to 2.9% as of mid-2018, according to the report. While most banks have been able so far to avoid raising the interest rates that they pay on deposits in order to make them more attractive, that should change, according to the report - particularly as traditional banks also face increased competition from online players that have lower costs and more ability to entice depositors. Ultimately, banks with dwindling deposits could have trouble meeting loan demand, and may seek out alternative funding; that, in turn, could add more risk to the banks’ operations and hurt their profitability, and potentially hurt broader economies, according to the report.

name: Demand from Institutional Investors
description: Institutional investors are challenging their traditional relationship with private investors as they demand better performance and smaller fees for their investments. Institutional investors are also demanding more specialized products as opposed to the standardized options they have traditionally been given, forcing a major change in the asset owner–asset manager relationship. A large part of this change is driven by pressure on institutional investors to meet growing financial obligations in a low-yield environment. In response, many have increased their investment professional staffs and reviewed their relationships with private investors with a more critical eye. There is a growing sense among asset owners that asset managers are not doing enough to take their needs into account, with private equity limited partners believing the alignment of interests could be improved in areas such as management fees (54% of respondents) and carried interest (28% of respondents) according to a 2014 World Economic Forum report on Direct Investing by Institutional Investors. As a result of the changing market landscape and relationship dynamic, institutional investors have both demanded changes in the fee structures charged by the private investors, while becoming increasingly more active direct investors.

name: Demographic Changes and Agriculture
description: Demographic shifts are creating an older, wealthier, and increasingly urban-dwelling global population, and dramatically affecting the agriculture, food and beverage sector. About 140 million people are joining the middle class every year, according to a 2017 report published by the Brookings Institution, and that number should grow to 170 million in about five years - creating more consumers with more disposable income to spend in supermarkets and at restaurants. In addition, by 2050, a dramatically greater number of these consumers will be elderly and living in cities, portending significant changes in related consumption patterns; according to figures published by the United Nations, more than 2 billion people in the world will be older than 60 by 2050, and about 66% of the global population will probably be living in urban areas - compared with 54% as of 2014. Expectations for how products are delivered will evolve, as these demographic shifts bring about changes in how individuals consume, and what they consume. The food and beverage sector is expected to be highly impacted by trends including an increased demand for personalization, and for automatic replenishment via technologies like the Internet of Things, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2017 report Shaping the Future of Retail for Consumer Industries. According to the results of a survey published alongside the Forum’s report, more than one third of respondents wanted services that automatically send them food and beverage products when they are running low.

name: Demographic Differences
description: Perhaps never before have there been so many issues on which the perspectives of the young and old diverge. Young people in many countries are typically more concerned than their elders about climate change, for example, or about the future of work, minority rights, the availability of education, and the availability of future funding for retirement schemes. The World Economic Forum’s annual Global Shapers Survey for 2017, conducted with young people in more than 180 countries, found that government accountability and corruption topped the list of concerns for those between the ages of 18 and 35, followed by inequality (in terms of both income and discrimination), and then by lack of economic opportunity and unemployment. Meanwhile the elderly tend to place greater importance on issues including terrorism and the solvency of existing retirement schemes, according to a 2016 study published by the Pew Research Center. The fact that many young people have become deeply immersed in social media means they may have been presented with a different picture of reality than their elders, and they may begin to treat social media as a substitute for real participation in civic life. These generational differences could have serious consequences for the future of civic participation. In some public policy areas, such as climate change and LGBTI rights, young people have led the way in terms of fashioning political discourse. For example, the US-based organization GLSEN, which focuses on making schools inclusive and safe, named 18 young people as a “student leadership” team for the 2016-2017 school year; the group included a 16-year-old who led their high school’s Inclusive Queer Alliance in Dayton, Ohio, and a 17-year-old Chicana and intersectional feminist in Houston, Texas. While the internet has the potential to help young people express their views on social and political issues, and to organize around the issues most important to them, it also has the power to distract them from healthy participation in the public sphere - as its cacophony of unmediated information sources makes it hard to separate fact from fiction. Efforts implemented now to develop the ability of young people to distinguish among reliable and unreliable online influences could pay significant dividends in the future.

name: Demographic Push
description: Africa’s population is the fastest growing in the world, and also one of the youngest - while Europe’s features the highest proportion of people older than 60, according to a report published in 2017 by the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Demographic disparities between developed and developing parts of the world promise to exert a powerful influence on migration and mobility patterns in the very near future. Geographically proximate regions, such as Africa and Europe, which feature growing demographic and economic disparities, are likely to be acutely affected by this trend during the second half of the 21st century.  Even when accounting for reductions in fertility rates in both developed and the least-developed countries, global population growth remains on track to present challenges for many countries and regions, which are likely to struggle with feeding, educating, housing and providing employment opportunities for expanding numbers of people. The incentive to migrate due to demographic pressure is likely to increase in many parts of the world, at least until improved education for girls and greater gender parity improve development outcomes and reduce both fertility rates and entrenched poverty. Meanwhile other countries and regions faced with rapidly ageing populations have a need to replace retiring members of their workforces and active contributors to their economies. This issue is most acute in Europe, where countries including Germany and the United Kingdom are among those where fertility was actually below the population replacement level between 2010 and 2015, according to the UN. Japan, where more than one quarter of the population was over the age of 65 by 2016, according to the World Bank, also faces a significant related challenge. International migration could provide a strategic benefit to such countries in need of replenishing their populations for economic, social, and political reasons. However, the ability to match labour market needs to migrant skills is likely to remain limited in many countries for the foreseeable future.

name: Demographic Shifts
description: Historically, travel was a luxury available only to those who could afford it. But falling costs, and increasing disposable income for the expanded global middle class, have fuelled a surge in international travel. International tourist arrivals rose to more than 1.3 billion in 2017, from 25 million in 1950, according to the World Tourism Organization; international arrivals are expected to reach 1.8 billion by 2030. By that point, most growth in international travel will come from outside of traditional markets in North America and Europe, and from markets in Africa, Asia and the Middle East. As emerging economies become larger sources of tourism they will also become more attractive destinations. The World Travel & Tourism Council has projected that between 2016 and 2026, the top 10 fastest-growing destinations for leisure travel spending will be India, Angola, Uganda, Brunei, Thailand, China, Myanmar, Oman, Mozambique and Viet Nam. Meanwhile roughly 140 million people join the middle class every year, according to a report published by the Brookings Institution in 2017, and about 88% of the next 1 billion people to join the middle class will be living in Asia. In China, travel is already increasingly popular even though as of 2016 less than 10% of Chinese nationals had passports, according to government figures. Millennials have made a unique contribution to the travel boom. According to a report published by travel news and data service Skift in 2016, travellers between the age of 18 and 34 tend to splurge selectively, by doing things like taking low-cost flights but going all out on experiences and restaurants. Millennials tends to want more control over their travel experiences, and they are willing to share their personal data to tailor those experiences, according to the 2016/2017 ITB World Travel Trends Report. Baby boomers also have a desire to discover. Unlike millennials, they have more disposable income to use on travel. The demographic is spending about of $6,000 on travel annually, according to the 2018 Travel Trends report published by the AARP, a US-based organization focused on the elderly. In addition to luxury, adventure, and eco-tourism travel, a growing number of boomers are pursuing medical travel. According to the publication Patients Beyond Borders, the total market for medical travel is between $45.5 billion and $72 billion, with as many as 16 million cross-border patients spending an average or as much as $6,000 per visit.

name: Demographic and Demand Shifts
description: Demographic shifts are having a dramatic impact on global demand for food. The global population is expected to grow from 7.6 billion as of 2017 to 8.6 billion by 2030, and then to 9.8 billion by 2050, according to the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Most of this growth will occur in developing countries. In Africa, for example, the populations of 26 countries are projected to at least double in size between 2017 and 2050, according to the UN. Global food systems will need to be prepared to meet a significant increase in global food demand, while also providing for high-quality diets. Global urbanization is also affecting food demand. According to the UN’s World Urbanization Prospects report, the percentage of people living in urban areas will increase from 55% in 2018 to 68% by 2050 (in 1950, just 30% of the world’s population was urban). Of the 2.5 billion people projected to enter the urban population by 2050, nearly 90% of them will be in Asia and Africa. As societies become more urbanized, fewer people pursue farming, and lifestyles change; the share of resource-intensive food, which has a stronger environmental impact as it is produced, becomes more prevalent in people’s diets, and their calorie intake increases significantly. The rapidly-growing middle class in developing markets is now ignoring previous staples as it consumes more processed foods, meat, fish, poultry, and dairy. In the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations’ 2012 working paper World Agriculture Towards 2030/2050, the authors argued that the combined impacts of a growing population and an exploding middle class could increase world food demand by 60% by 2050, compared with 2005/2007 levels. Some potential ways of addressing growing demand have been identified. Research published by the University of Minnesota’s Institute on the Environment in 2013 found that only 55% of global crop calories were being consumed by humans, as 36% were being used for animal feed and 9% were being committed to biofuels and industrial uses. Growing more food exclusively for direct human consumption could increase available food calories by as much as 70%, and feed an additional 4 billion people, according to the study.

name: Demographics Shifts in Switzerland
description: Like many industrialized countries, Switzerland’s population is getting larger, older, and more diverse. Over the past 150 years the population has tripled in size, with 450 inhabitants per square kilometre now packed within a narrow strip running between Lake Geneva in the west and Lake Constance in the east - one of the most densely populated parts of Europe. Since 1995, the Swiss population has increased by 18% to 8.3 million, and is projected to reach 10 million by 2035, according to the Swiss Federal Statistical Office. The population growth of recent years has been mainly attributed to net immigration. Foreigners represent about one quarter of Switzerland’s permanent resident population, and more than half of the foreign population was either born in the country or has been living there for 10 years or more. This proportion of foreigner to national is one of the highest of any country in the world, and the majority of foreign residents come from a European Union (or European Free Trade Association) country. Switzerland’s communities share at least one attribute: ageing. According to the government publication Statistical Data on Switzerland 2017, the segment of the population aged 65 and over is projected to rise from 18% as of 2015 to over 26% by 2045; if it was not for the immigration of younger people to cities like Zurich, Geneva, Basel and Bern, the ageing effect would be even more pronounced. Average life expectancy among men is expected to increase from 81 years to 90 years by 2100, while for women it is expected to grow from 85 to 93 over that same period. The Swiss population has one of the highest rates of life expectancy in the world, which presents major challenges for the country’s pension system, healthcare system, and labour market. As in other developed economies, the pension system is at risk of collapsing. In 2017, voters rejected a pension reform plan proposed by the government, mainly because it placed a large burden on future generations. Switzerland is also witnessing growing wealth inequality. According to government data, in 2013 the top half of earners took home 80% of total income, while the bottom half brought home the remaining 20%.

name: Demographics, Ageing and Real Estate
description: Before the “silver tsunami” of ageing populations has maximum impact within the next couple of decades, real estate experts and urban planners must find innovative ways to construct environments that are better prepared. According to the United Nations, the global population of those aged 60 or older is expected to grow to 2.1 billion by 2050, from 962 million in 2017 - while the population of those over 80 years old is expected to grow to 425 million from 137 million over the same period. For planners, designers, and developers, this will have a significant impact on the ways that they approach their work. A transformation of the urban landscape that better caters to a rapidly ageing population, with neighbourhoods that are equipped with integrated senior housing, assisted healthcare facilities, and arrangements to facilitate increased mobility, is sorely needed. In addition to physical planning, there is a need for social welfare measures tailored for elderly populations, and for increased financial literacy and flexible financing plans such as reverse mortgages - which can provide financial support during the twilight years. Real estate can also provide a potentially ideal, relatively low-risk investment for the pension funds that elderly people rely on for their income. A report published by real estate investment firm JLL in 2016 suggested that global real estate transaction volumes would reach $1 trillion by 2020 (compared with $700 billion in 2015), largely due to greater interest from institutional investors like pension schemes.

name: Design for Additive Manufacturing
description: 3D printing (or “additive manufacturing”) can produce lightweight structures with unprecedented, complex geometries, integrated sensors, and efficient, hollow and lattice structures. However, using 3D printing for parts can be challenging for designers. In the past, traditional guidelines for designers dictated that part shapes and features be kept as simple as possible, in order to reduce the number of required processing steps and the general cost of production. Entire generations of designers were trained to develop this mindset. Now, when designing for 3D printing, they are being advised to rethink traditional geometry and implement an approach inspired by lightweight, bionic concepts that can add significant value to a produced part. This requires an entirely new type of education (or re-education) in order to grasp all of the unique possibilities for using 3D printing to improve product functionality. Some related techniques include using dedicated software to reduce the weight of parts - which can be particularly useful in the aerospace and biomedical industries. While 3D printing can add value to parts design, certain constraints have to be taken into account. Parts always need to be designed for production while keeping their “build orientation” (the direction in which a part will be printed) in mind. This is one of the most important aspects of 3D printing, because it determines the anisotropy (the differences in a material’s physical properties when measured in different directions) of mechanical properties, surface quality, and the amount of support material that will be needed for the entirety of the printing process. The amount of support material should be minimized whenever possible, because it increases the total cost of material and lengthens the time required to remove material during post-processing. Large amounts of material usually add only a limited amount of engineering value to a part, and are also the main cause of increased residual stress (or stress that exists even after external force is removed). A study published in The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology in 2016 estimated that $667 million in value had been created by using 3D printing, equal to about 0.01% of total global manufacturing value added. Jabil, a US-based electronics manufacturing services firm, has reported that the use of 3D printing at one of its facilities led to a roughly 30% reduction in the cost of tooling, and an 80% decrease in the time required to make final tools and fixtures.

name: Designing a New Social Contract
description: Saudi Arabia’s oil wealth has traditionally been a key source of its political and social stability. The redistribution of this wealth has for many years provided well-paid jobs, a high quality of infrastructure, and good public services - while the House of Saud has maintained a stabilizing set of relationships with religious clerics, business elites, and tribal leaders. Efforts to maintain this social contract have been concerted; in response to the Arab Spring uprisings in the region in 2011, for example, the Saudi government increased its spending by about 25% over the prior year, which included roughly $130 billion in announced social spending that was meant to result in higher pay and bonuses for public-sector workers, according to Vision 2030 and Saudi Arabia’s Social Contract, a research paper published by Chatham House in 2017. Now, Saudi Arabia must come to terms with a future where oil plays a far less significant role in the economy - with inevitable consequences. Nearly two thirds of the Saudi population is under the age of thirty, and many young people are dissatisfied with the current, relatively conservative social structure. Increased global connectivity thanks to technology development has affected the way young people view the world, and the country has one of the largest social media markets in the Middle East. Meanwhile the King Abdullah Scholarship Program, initiated in 2005, has enabled many young Saudis of both sexes to study abroad and gain exposure to new cultures and ideas. A growing number of Saudi women have begun to bare their faces, and to let their headscarves fall back to reveal their hair, according to Saudi Arabia in Transition, a paper published by the Harvard Kennedy School’s Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs in 2017. An increasing number of women also now have jobs and are financially self-sufficient, according to the paper. The government’s “Vision 2030” plan, a sort of national blueprint, promises a significant degree of social liberalization and educational reform. However, government efforts to both pursue reforms and transform the Saudi economy may result in additional discomfort in the form of lower public subsidies, and higher taxes - for the very same constituents who must buy into reform efforts in order for them to succeed.

name: Destigmatizing Mental Health
description: As much as 85% of the people living in in low- and middle-income countries who suffer from mental disorders, and as much as half of the people suffering from these disorders in high-income countries, receive no related treatment, according to the World Health Organization. Stigma and discrimination can result in a lack of access to care and services related to mental health, according to WHO fact sheet published in 2018, and people with psychosis are at high risk of exposure to human rights violations including long-term confinement in institutions. The stigma attached to mental illness functions in the same way as racism or sexism, according to a co-author of Ending Discrimination Against People with Mental and Substance Use Disorders: The Evidence for Stigma Change, a report published by the National Academies Press in 2016. According to the report, examples of institutionalized stigma in the US include limits on people with mental illness when it comes to serving on a jury or running for public office. People with mental disorders are also overrepresented in the US criminal justice system (both a consequence and a source of stigma), according to the report. Most people who have to live with mental illness have at some point been blamed for their condition, according to the National Alliance on Mental Illness; their symptoms have been dismissed as a “phase,” and they have been discriminated against in violation of the law. The NAMI recommends several ways of fighting mental health stigma: talking openly about mental health; educating yourself and others about peoples’ experiences with mental illness; being conscious of the language used to talk about mental illness; encouraging people to equate mental illness with disease; showing compassion for those with mental illness (for example by engaging with homeless people struggling with mental illness); choosing empowerment over shame; being honest about the treatment received for mental illness; avoiding “self stigma” (by being as productive a member of society as possible), and by letting the media know when they have stigmatized mental illness via storylines or ignorant comments. In 2015, researchers from the University of Florida published results of a study on mental health de-stigmatization showing that negative perceptions based on a lack of information often fuel a fear of mental illness sufferers. These negative perceptions often came from negative portrayals of mental illnesses suffers in the media, according to the study.

name: Development Outcomes
description: Blended Finance enables the scaling up of financing for projects in emerging and frontier markets that would otherwise not be possible (or would be forced to develop at a slower rate, or on a smaller scale). As a result, it can deliver development impact through new jobs, access to affordable capital, and environmental and social benefits. One particular sector where Blended Finance offers the potential to mobilize finance on a significant scale for critical projects is infrastructure in developing countries. According to the 2010 World Bank report Africa's Infrastructure: A Time for Transformation, infrastructure development had been responsible for more than half of sub-Saharan Africa’s recent improvement in economic growth, yet less than half of the estimated $93 billion a year required to meet infrastructure needs in the region was actually available. Such imbalances are not limited to sub-Saharan Africa; a 2015 World Economic Forum blog post noted that infrastructure investment in Latin America needed to increase by an equivalent of between 2% and 3% of the region’s GDP in order to adequately facilitate long-term competitiveness. In addition, the Asian Development bank has estimated that there is a climate-adjusted annual infrastructure gap that impedes growth and is equivalent to 5% of GDP for developing Asian countries (excluding China). In addition to providing access to previously untapped commercial funding for projects, Blended Finance can also ensure better preparation of projects, and more efficient implementation for governments, by providing the discipline and expertise that can come with working alongside private sector partners. In addition, the mechanism can encourage further interest from institutional investors by creating new, large-scale opportunities for them. Currently, institutional investors such as pension funds, banks, insurance companies, hedge funds, mutual funds, and sovereign wealth funds allocate less than $2 trillion to the type of global infrastructure that can create significant benefits, despite an annual funding gap for United Nations Sustainable Development Goals development that runs to trillions of dollars. By making greater use of Blended Finance, governments, development finance institutions, donors, and other development funders can tap new capital pools necessary for making an impact in emerging and frontier markets - and for achieving Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Diffusion of Governing Power
description: Companies need to think through not only how they want to work with governments to help ensure social welfare - but also how, in some cases, they themselves will be on the front lines of technology governance. YouTube, for example, is assessing how its search algorithms can be refined in order to track instances of abuse like the use of video to spread extremist ideologies or images of terrorist acts. Meanwhile Facebook has come under increasing public scrutiny and criticism for its poor handling of user data. The media (and influential social media users) have key roles to play when it comes to communicating risks, opportunities, and concerns to the citizenry. The media will always be a target for criticism, as it has been with vigour under the Trump Administration in the US (both from the left and the right). In addition, media platforms have found it increasingly challenging to address broad audiences with coverage that is generally viewed as balanced, and so have sought ways to tailor news for specific communities - without having the resulting product degenerate into an echo chamber. The backdrop for all of this is the emergence of technologies that are shifting power and influence away from governments, and towards companies and non-state actors. This in turn is shifting and expanding the traditional view of governance. Even without a political mandate, technology pioneers are increasingly involved in developing private rules, certification schemes, standards, social norms, and policies that end up by default governing the ways that societies work, according to a report published by the World Economic Forum in 2018. These default norms and rules are often unrestricted by national borders. If government alone can no longer provide sufficient governance of emerging Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies, whether related to the commercialization of artificial intelligence, or the use of social media to influence elections, governance will have to come from new sources of authority and new models of collaboration.

name: Digital Fluency and STEM Skills
description: Technology is rapidly altering the ways we interact and work, linking communities and workers in increasingly sophisticated ways and opening up new opportunities. Young people therefore need to develop digital fluency, and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) skills from an early age if they are to be equipped to thrive in the modern workplace - and in modern society. Learners need a deeper understanding of how to apply technology and innovation in order to achieve desired results. Education systems, meanwhile, need to ensure technology curricula are kept up-to-date, while teachers need to have the opportunity to refresh their own skills and knowledge in order to keep pace with external developments. The use of technology should be embedded across the educational experience, to mirror the ways in which technology is now relevant to all sectors and careers. Most jobs of the future will require a basic understanding of math and science. Ten-year employment projections by the US Department of Labor, for example, anticipate that of the 20 fastest-growing occupations for the period between 2016 and 2026, many will require an increasing understanding of math or science. Given the importance of STEM in the growth of future workplaces, it is important to ensure access to related education for all socio-economic groups. Girls and women are particularly underrepresented within high value-added STEM disciplines, and it is crucial to find ways to increase their presence.

name: Digital Inclusion and Opportunity
description: According to the World Bank, more than 1 billion people have no legal identity, with about half residing in sub-Saharan Africa. Nearly 40% of the total population in low-income countries has no legal identity (compared with less than 10% in middle-income countries), while one in two women in low-income countries have this problem. There are several ongoing efforts to help integrate excluded populations through digital means. The World Bank’s ID4D initiative, for example, provides countries with technical assistance and expertise to help them implement inclusive digital identity systems. Meanwhile the UN Refugee Agency and the World Food Programme are using iris scans to register refugees and displaced people, and help provide humanitarian aid. The UN estimates that scaling up these efforts could help about 66 million displaced people worldwide. However, there are risks associated with collecting biometric data - especially if a government is inclined to use it to surveil and subdue dissidents, or to exclude people from their rightful access to food and shelter. In addition, if an individual’s sole form of identity comes from a humanitarian agency it can complicate recognition from their home or host country. Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, is using digital health cards, biometrics, text messages and a mobile identity platform to improve vaccine delivery in developing countries. And the estimated 40 million victims of modern slavery, according to the International Labour Organization, could be helped by digital identity systems that track worker conditions throughout global supply chains. Austin, Texas is trying to help homeless people, who struggle to maintain physical forms of identification and often have fragmented health data, by developing MyPass, a blockchain-based solution that enables access to healthcare, employment or housing by attaching digital health records and other data to a person’s phone number or email address. While digital identity can better integrate populations, poorly-designed systems can worsen exclusion; fingerprints used for a biometric identity system can erode due to manual labour, for example, while systems that collect DNA and record ethnicity or religion can be misused to discriminate. Participatory design is key for any system serving vulnerable populations. Ultimately, every solution should account for differences in age, digital literacy, and internet access. Stakeholders in all sectors and industries should engage in evidence-based research supporting human-centered identity, engage civil society and the public in its design, and launch prototypes and pilots addressing identity challenges faced by vulnerable populations.

name: Digital Infrastructure for Growth
description: The German government has made its digital agenda a priority, as evidenced by the addition of a digital infrastructure portfolio for the Minister for Transport in 2013. However, in reality, the responsibility for the country’s digital infrastructure remains divided among at least five ministries, in the hands of three different political parties. The Minister of Economic Affairs and Energy holds responsibility for startups and the digital economy, the Minister of the Interior holds responsibility for e-government and cybersecurity, while the Minister for Transport and Digital Infrastructure bears responsibility for the deployment of broadband infrastructure. In addition, the Minister of Justice and Consumer Protection plays a role when it comes to data privacy, while the Ministry of Health works on the introduction of e-health systems. This blending of oversight makes it difficult to push reforms, and results in persistently vague political measures. It also potentially hinders the rollout of cutting-edge digital infrastructure, which is crucial to both maintain Germany’s digital competitiveness, and to address the public’s concerns over privacy. Germany’s Minister for Transport and Digital Infrastructure is further hobbled by uncertainty regarding the financing of broadband infrastructure. In addition, Chancellor Angela Merkel has warned against over-regulating the commercial use of big data, which is an important element of data privacy measures. After a first draft was withdrawn amid criticism in 2017, in 2018 Germany became the first European Union member state to successfully pass legislation implementing the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) - which harmonizes and strengthens data protection for individuals within the bloc.

name: Digital Policy and Governance
description: The internet has been a principal contributor to the growth of the global economy for decades, and has the potential to continue to be a positive force for both the private and public sectors. But regulators must address concerns about the treatment of online data, and the security of networks. While leaders continue to struggle with the implications of technological transformation, businesses and ministries urgently need new reference models and organizational structures. While national digital policy frameworks can provide a foundation for innovation-led growth, their effectiveness relies upon models that are appropriately tailored for specific countries. A key digital policy focus for any country is an ability to better deliver public services. Digitally advanced governments, like Estonia, have achieved promising results as they structure policy to accommodate businesses, citizens and government agencies alike. To replicate this type of success, governments must develop a coherent plan for using personal data, and make that planning process transparent and inclusive in order to establish better digital policy and governance.

name: Digital Teleportation
description: With the emergence of virtual reality (VR), we can now fully immerse in any virtual environment that can be rendered in real-time using today’s graphics engines. New cinematic experiences recorded using spherical 360-degree camera systems enable us to have the experience akin to teleporting ourselves into arbitrary physical locations and time. Existing communication and internet infrastructures already further social interactions by bringing multiple remote users into a common virtual space. Through VR, collaborative tasks can be made more efficient and VR-enabled multiple player games become more compelling than their traditional counterparts. Nevertheless, VR presents a significant transformative opportunity where systems can go beyond just displaying 3D content by digitizing our appearances and mapping our physical actions faithfully into virtual worlds in real-time. When the day comes, where VR feels like a real physical experience and the gap between users and their digital avatars disappears, this technology will have the potential to become the next generation platform for face-to-face communication, social interaction, and even self-presence. In 2015, the MIT Technology Review reported that  a team of researchers at the University of Southern California, in collaboration with Oculus and Facebook, demonstrated the first prototype VR head-mounted display with facial performance sensing capabilities that mapped facial expressions onto digital avatars for immersive two-way communications. This emerging technology has not only sparked the interest of researchers in the computer graphics community and resulted in many follow-up projects by researchers at the University of Southern California, the University of Kentucky, North Carolina Central University and others, as well as start-ups such as Pinscreen, Loom.ai, BinaryVR, FOVE, AltSpaceVR, and High-Fidelity. Established VR companies such as Oculus & Facebook, Google VR, Microsoft, Huawei, and Tencent are also eager to explore social VR capabilities using virtual avatars. As the real-time rendering and simulation of digital humans is close to surpassing the “uncanny valley” – the idea that replicas of humans that are very close to actual humans elicit revulsion from some observers - a digital and immersive form of transportation could dramatically decrease communication-related modes of physical transportations (air, train, and car travel) and hence reduce energy consumption by several orders of magnitude. For instance, a 2017 call for proposals issued by the US Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E) noted that roughly 8% of the energy consumption in the United Stages is related to travels for in-person communication. Current telecommunications technologies such as conventional video conferencing cannot fully displace physical face-to-face meetings due to the lack of essential human interaction characteristics. A study published by researchers from Ghent University in the Journal of Information Technology and Management in 2016 reported that the limitations of existing systems included the ability to build trust, communicate feelings, resolve conflicts and negotiate deals. However, with the recent advancements in VR, dramatic improvements in telecommunication technologies could enable highly effective “in-person”-like interactions that are actually conducted remotely. Transportation costs, time, and energy could be significantly reduced, while increasing work productivity. Such technology may also have a benefit for combatting some persistent challenges faced by telecommuters, such as remote workers feeling isolated or ineffective communications. By promoting efficient and multi-tasking telecommuting, employees can spend more time with their families, and businesses can reduce costs for office spaces. As a result, there will be fewer incentives to outsource. Similar to the effect of smartphones on modern society, in which our lives are impacted by constant connectedness, VR is likely to alter interpersonal communication and relations. While mobile devices and text messaging tend to reduce face-to-face interaction and family conversations, immersive telecommunication could potentially bring us closer again, though in digital form.

name: Digital Trade
description: Some have called data the new oil, because so much modern economic activity cannot occur without it. However, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development noted a crucial difference in a report published in 2019: unlike oil, data are not scarce, and can be distributed at virtually no cost. Cross-border data flows have grown dramatically, now that nearly half of the world is online compared with just 20% only a decade ago, according to a report published by McKinsey Global Institute in 2019. The growing importance of data means they must be able to flow freely across borders; digital products and services like cloud computing, the Internet of Things, and artificial intelligence will depend on this. Yet, some authorities believe the free flow of information poses a threat to public order, while there are other, legitimate data-restriction policy objectives that relate to privacy. This has led to the erection of barriers that limit the storage, movement, and use of data across borders, or “data localization.” In 2018, for example, India’s central bank announced that foreign payment companies would have to store local transaction data exclusively on servers located within India. In a bid to avoid the negative impacts of restricting data flows, some countries have included provisions on the free flow of data in trade deals. Recent free trade agreements have included binding provisions on data flows, and have prohibited data localization measures (examples include 2018’s Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Transpacific Partnership, the updated Singapore-Australia free trade agreement in 2016, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement signed in 2018, and the Australia-Indonesia free trade agreement in 2019). These deals have also addressed other conditions that enable digital trade, such as permanent moratoriums on custom duties, electronic contracts, electronic payments, and paperless trading. There is a growing recognition of the importance of fostering digital trade, including in the European Union - which had previously taken a cautious approach to the topic. Experience gained through existing deals and the political will of the international community (evidenced by signals sent from dozens of countries including the US and China at the 2019 World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Davos) may now result in a new agreement on electronic commerce under the auspices of the World Trade Organization - though the ultimate form of that agreement is still under negotiation.

name: Digital Transformation of Bangladesh
description: The sweeping digitalization accompanying the Fourth Industrial Revolution promises significant benefits for developing countries like Bangladesh. The country’s government aims to digitally transform its economy by 2030 - and according to the Ministry of Finance, budget allocations for information and communications technology are now 3.5 times greater than they were five years earlier. Some related initiatives include establishing connectivity via submarine cables, biometric registration for the use of mobile phones, and the introduction of Smart National Identification Cards. In addition, the government has introduced electronic tenders, while e-payments have been introduced, and projects tied to the online payment of value added tax (VAT) and the e-submission of tax returns are being implemented. The government is also promoting multimedia-equipped classrooms, paperless communication is being encouraged for inter-governmental communication, and initiatives are being undertaken to make the government more transparent through the online posting of documents and information. A relatively high rate of mobile phone penetration (87.7% of the population, according to the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics) has meanwhile enabled the e-payment of utility bills. Mobile-based financial services such as bKash and Rocket have helped bring banking services to low-income groups, and have proven to be convenient, affordable, and reliable.   However, Bangladesh has a long way to go. According to World Bank data, only 18% of the population was using the internet as of 2016. Online-based businesses and services face difficulties outside of the capital, Dhaka, and there is a general lack of know-how regarding cyber security. The use of social media is expanding, though users are generally not well informed about the reliability of information they are exposed to. A strategic expansion of Bangladesh’s e-commerce industry is critically important; the country needs to remain engaged in World Trade Organization negotiations regarding e-commerce, in order to help ensure that measures are put in place that help developing countries build capacity. The country also needs to guard against the negative social issues that can be generated by social media, and to improve the use and analysis of big data in order to better understand consumer behaviour. The government’s introduction of new mobile technologies needs to be swiftly implemented, while education systems and curricula (and skills training) must be redesigned in order to better facilitate the country’s digital transformation.

name: Digitalization and Chemicals
description: As it did in previous industrial revolutions, the chemical and materials industry is playing a major enabling role in the Fourth Industrial Revolution. It is largely through the industry’s contributions that other sectors can turn their innovative ideas into products like touch screens, rechargeable batteries in portable devices, organic light-emitting diodes in flexible electronics, or the lightweight materials used to build drones. At the same time, the industry itself is being transformed through digitalization. Previously, the industry made use of digital technologies for process optimization and efficiency. Now, the digitalization of chemicals companies has expanded to focus on everything from the laboratory, to marketing and sales (through the extension of traditional product offerings with digital components), and new means of interaction with customers. The chemical and materials sector is generally seeking to stay abreast of pockets of digital disruption, including digitally-accelerated biotechnology that enables the direct-route production of chemicals, and the disintermediation of players from platforms. For example, large multinationals in the sector like BASF, Evonik, Covestro, and Solvay have launched online stores on Alibaba’s B2B platform 1688.com. Meanwhile startups such as ChemSquare, a global B2B matching platform for buyers and sellers of raw materials and ingredients used in food, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and animal nutrition, may disrupt the industry’s traditional procurement and sales processes. On the research and development side, companies such as BASF, Dow Chemical, and Evonik have announced partnerships with IBM and Hewlett-Packard related to data management, machine learning, and quantum computing technologies that could accelerate innovation. As the timing and scale of digital disruption is hard to predict, the industry operates with an awareness that it could be fundamentally altered at any time.

name: Digitalization and Innovation Capacity
description: According to the World Economic Forum’s 2016 Networked Readiness Index, the Russian Federation placed 41st out of 139 countries, ahead of China, Brazil and India, but behind Kazakhstan, Chile and Saudi Arabia.
