The country was rated relatively highly in terms of readiness and usage, but is constrained by a deteriorating regulatory environment, according to the index, which notes that local infrastructure development is not keeping pace with demand. The challenges and opportunities of the Fourth Industrial Revolution mean that the Russian Federation must take steps that account for new realities. The country’s solid scientific legacy means that if it puts in place necessary collaborative efforts, it could be well-positioned to thrive. Investing in technology and innovation must be prioritized. According to Russia’s National Technology Initiative, which was launched in 2014, the country currently has only a 0.28% share of the $773 billion global market for services for so-called factories of the future, though it aims to increase that share to at least 15%. Meanwhile the consultancy BCG found in 2016 that the Russian automotive sector, a key part of the country’s economy, invests significantly less in research & development than foreign peers; Russian automaker AvtoVAZ, for example, was found to spend less than 1% of its revenue on R&D, compared with 4% at most global manufacturers.  According to the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018, the Russian Federation ranked 38th out of 137 economies - an improvement compared with 43rd the previous year, and 45th the year before that. This was due to gains made in education, infrastructure and technological readiness. With its recently-implemented Digital Economy programme, the country is aiming to further promote the development of technologically advanced businesses, while other programmes are designed to modernize manufacturing and improve labour efficiency. The country's National Technology Initiative intends to position it as a global technological leader by 2035. The initiative covers several industries; in terms of the automotive industry, Volgabus is developing commercial driverless vehicles, while in the nuclear power sector the Rosatom State Atomic Energy Corporation is designing new management systems for complex engineering facilities. These and other industries will require talent that can thrive in technology-infused environments. However, Russia’s labour market is currently defined by skills more aligned with the Third Industrial Revolution than the Fourth. According to some estimates, by 2035, most production and supply chains will be fully automated. Given that between 60% and 70% of Russians are now directly or indirectly employed in mass production, the social and economic consequences of such a shift will be enormous, unless Russia takes steps to sufficiently prepare its labour force.

name: Digitalization in Electricity
description: The power sector is becoming increasingly digitalized, as computation and control technologies are embedded in systems around the world. This is spurring value creation, while creating cyber security risks. Digital technologies make it easier to communicate the value of electricity services with greater accuracy, as consumers become increasingly price sensitive and engaged. Meanwhile sensors and metering technologies are providing new visibility into power system conditions, and digitally-enabled power electronics and infrastructure are providing grid operators with an ability to act on newly-available information. Digitally-enabled demand-side resources, such as heating and air conditioning units and water heaters, are now active participants in the PJM market, which is the largest electricity market in the US. Nearly 11 gigawatts of demand-side resources provided electricity services in the PJM market in 2015 and 2016, and were the source of roughly $825 million in revenue in 2015. Meanwhile, companies including Amazon and Google sold more than 4.5 million digital “smart” thermostats in the US and Europe in 2016, enabling home and business owners to take greater control of their electricity use; increased participation like this provides a case study for the potential impact of the Internet of Things, which strings household devices together with online connectivity.   Greater digitalization is also expanding the deployment of advanced metering infrastructure. Over 60 million smart meters now measure the consumption of more than 40% of the buildings in the US. Smart meter deployments in the European Union are expected to reach 72% of consumers there by 2020, while China alone had deployed roughly 350 million smart meters as of 2016. Digitally enabled meters, paired with mobile technologies, are enabling new payment models that help bring power to some of the least electrified parts of the world. Digital grid infrastructure and data collection are meanwhile enabling more active network management; in the United Kingdom, UK Power Networks has developed a program to actively manage the output of wind power plants, enabling it to more quickly and economically interconnect generators and demand. Increased digitalization of the power system has also created new vulnerabilities, however - as demonstrated by the 2015 cyber attack on the Ukrainian power grid. As digital technologies collect valuable data, it creates the need for rules regarding how to securely manage this data, and new regulations that ensure utilities, and other power sector stakeholders, are adequately prepared for cyber threats.

name: Digitalization of Supply Chains
description: The management of supply chains is radically changing as a result of digitalization, the use of big data, and artificial intelligence; blockchain technology and the Internet of Things will also likely have a transformative impact. Major logistics providers like Maersk, UPS and FedEx are actively exploring blockchain in particular, which can provide an immutable record of contracts, assets and payments. Big data analytics, involving the detection of useful patterns in massive data sets, is made possible by the proliferation of sensors and tracking devices, and is both improving operational efficiency and spurring new business models. Meanwhile cloud computing has enabled more effective managing of inventory, and rerouting consignments or switching to alternative modes of transport at short notice; it also enables real-time information sharing that is helping companies collaborate. The global freight forwarding market, which generated more than $140 billion in revenue in 2016, according to a white paper published by the Focused Cargo Network, is being disrupted by online platforms that enable shippers to procure logistics services more flexibly and at better rates. Increasingly, to protect their margins and market share, traditional forwarders are embracing digitalization. Innovations in warehousing, such as robotization (automation) and the use of augmented reality, are increasing the speed, efficiency and accuracy of order picking operations. On roads, the electronic coupling of convoys of trucks into platoons to closely coordinate their operation has been shown to cut fuel consumption between 5% and 10%. The International Road Transport Union predicts that by 2030, around 10% of European long haul trucks will be travelling in platoons. The International Transport Forum suggests that a quarter of all trucks could be automated by 2040, while in the maritime sector, ship automation is being trialled. Road infrastructure is also becoming “smart” in ways that increase speed, reliability, capacity utilization and resilience. In addition, surface delivery robots (or “droids”) and aerial drones are being deployed for the so-called “last-mile,” or the final stages of a delivery - though their long-term impact on supply chains is difficult to predict. As news and entertainment media go digital, physical transportation of newsprint or discs is less prevalent, while 3D printing (which can be done outside of a traditional factory) offers the potential to significantly reduce freight traffic. The thousands of IT-related logistics startups listed in the Crunchbase registry indicate that many more digital innovations will impact supply chains in the near future.

name: Direct Investing
description: As the holders of “patient” capital, institutional investors play an important role in by helping to stabilize global markets while also funding long-term corporate growth, infrastructure development, and real estate. Any changes to the ways that asset owners allocate long-term capital can have a broad impact on society, and significant potential impacts on infrastructure and urban development. In the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, volatile, uncertain, and relatively unattractive returns on traditional investments encouraged investors to increase focus on illiquid assets - which are typically private equity-, real estate-, or specialized funds. US private equity funds, for example, have yielded relatively stellar annualized, compounded, net-of-fees returns over the past decade of close to 12%, outperforming all other asset classes. However, the potential for improved returns in illiquid asset classes has also led many institutional investors to explore the extent to which they can make these investments directly - and save management fees, while gaining greater control. There are constraints on the adoption of large-scale, institutional direct investing, however - particularly related to size. Only a very large institution can afford to run sophisticated, internally operated direct-investing teams at a lower cost than what would be incurred by fund managers. Direct investment will therefore not likely become the dominant institutional model, and instead will grow steadily in popularity, particularly for large institutions with flexible mandates and long-term horizons. State-owned sovereign wealth funds, for example, have increased their allocation to illiquid assets like real estate and infrastructure such that it now accounts for more than half of their total investment. These sovereign wealth funds have also displayed an increasing desire to team up with other investors, particularly as institutional investors in general move away from expensive, often ineffective external fund management towards internal portfolio management. Collaboration is a way to leverage limited personnel, to learn from investment partners, and to spread risk. Increased direct investment has implications for the global economy - it fosters long-term bets and therefore has a stabilizing, counter cyclical effect on markets. However, institutions as direct investors face daunting organizational challenges; whether or not they can succeed will depend largely on their ability to execute, source the right deals, and find the right talent.

name: Disruption to Jobs and Skills
description: As business models are disrupted, employment is being profoundly impacted. The result will be significant job creation and job displacement, in addition to both heightened labour productivity and widening gaps between the skills that employers need, and those that potential employees have. During previous industrial revolutions, it required decades to adapt - by building the training systems and labour market institutions necessary to develop new skill sets. Given the relatively faster pace and broader scale of disruption brought about by the Fourth Industrial Revolution, an interlude like that may not be an option this time around. The World Economic Forum’s 2016 Future of Jobs report suggests that mismatches may emerge not just between the current supply of, and demand for, contemporary skills but also between those contemporary skills and those that will be required in the future. Closing these gaps will require a solid understanding of the existing skills bases in particular countries and industries, and of how disruptive change will dictate new skills requirements in every case. Amid concern about high rates of unemployment in much of the world, mismatches and gaps in education systems are hindering the effective redeployment of underutilized, latent talent - at great human and economic cost. Workers need to be repurposed, across industries and with an eye to the skills required for the fastest-growing fields. According to the Forum’s Human Capital Report 2017, the number of people in the world with skills developed at a university or school is rising, but our understanding of how formal qualifications are distributed across industries and locations remains limited. Detailed skills information is critical for employers and employees, to better grasp what may be most transferable across industries. For example, an employer in the financial services industry facing a shortage of data analysts could reasonably expect to be able to consider applicants from a different industry - if there are identifiable, overlapping skills. Employers will need to increasingly think about how to tap this skills “adjacency,” in order to uncover hidden talent pools. Proactive talent management strategies are called for, as well as sustained dialogue and collaboration among businesses, governments, education providers, and civil society. As the where and how of work is transformed, it will lead to new management and regulatory challenges; and in an evolving labour market, preparing for the future is increasingly critical for seizing opportunities and mitigating undesirable outcomes. In the United Kingdom, artificial intelligence is poised to eliminate 7 million jobs by 2037, according to a report published in 2018 by PricewaterhouseCoopers - though it is also expected to create about 7.2 million new jobs in the country by that time, in healthcare, science and education. Business model disruptions will have a profound impact on the employment landscape, leading to both significant job creation and elimination, potentially heightened productivity, and almost certainly wider skills gaps. Given the likely depth of technological disruption to jobs, there is a pressing need to come up with more effective ways to facilitate the acquisition of skills and address job loss. During previous industrial revolutions, it has often taken decades to build the training systems and labour market institutions needed to develop new skillsets on a large scale. Given the pace of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, however, such a relatively comfortable interval may not be an option this time. In order to rise to the challenge that this presents, businesses will have to recognize human capital investment as an asset rather than a liability, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2018 edition of its Future of Jobs report. Many regions struggle with unemployment and inactivity, creating sizable economic knock-on effects. Skills gaps and innovation lag make labour markets less agile, and due to increasing rates of job disruption this trend is set to become worse. Meanwhile related regulatory and managerial challenges will only be exacerbated by gaps in knowledge. Real solutions will require that proactive talent management strategies be deployed by companies, alongside deep and sustained dialogue and collaboration among businesses, governments, and education providers. Workers in fields that are facing significant job reductions must be re-skilled, and provided with viable job transitions. The Forum’s Global Human Capital Report 2017 noted that gaining formal qualifications alone will not equate to necessary re-skilling; lifelong learning opportunities such as short-cycle courses, experience on the job, and exposure to new projects will be important in this regard. Any effort aimed at closing the skills gap will need to be grounded in a solid understanding of a particular country’s or industry’s current skills base, and of changing skills requirements due to disruption. Anticipating and preparing for future skills requirements will be critical for anyone who wants to seize new opportunities and new markets.

name: Disruptive Technologies
description: In 2017, the commander of US Strategic Command disclosed a growing threat during congressional testimony: unauthorized drones, flying over Navy and Air Force installations and imperilling the security of nuclear weapons and personnel. The Air Force and Navy, he said, were working up plans to track and potentially “engage” these unmanned aircraft - which are among a number of emerging, technology-related threats to nuclear security. There is a lack of adequate defense against drones launched for nefarious purposes; shooting them down can be difficult, while jamming their operation could threaten the operations of the nuclear facilities on the ground below. In addition, conventional radar cannot detect small drones flying close to the ground. In France, nuclear power stations were subjected to a mysterious and disturbing epidemic of unmanned drone flights in late 2014 and early 2015. While French authorities insisted that the facilities were designed to withstand security risks including drones, the flights raised fears of potential terrorist attacks. The actual motive for the drone flights has yet to be identified, however. Greenpeace has warned that even a medium-sized drone is capable of carrying an explosive charge large enough to damage the pools of cold water where spent nuclear fuel is stocked - and potentially releasing radioactive material in the process. In France, which is more dependent on nuclear power than any other developed nation (the World Nuclear Association has reported that nearly three-quarters of the country’s electricity is nuclear-generated), such an attack could be particularly disastrous. The key to countering this potential threat could come from an unlikely source: more drones. As the security-minded begin to think creatively about countering drones, including celebrities keen to better protect their privacy from paparazzi, a number of efforts have been made to develop unmanned aircraft that can disable other unmanned aircraft. A bid to develop a drone dubbed “Rapere,” which could safely disable the rotor blades of intruding aerial unmanned vehicles, surfaced in the US in 2015. Other startups have taken different approaches; a French firm, MALOU-tech, has developed quad copters equipped with nets to intercept drones in the air, while UK-based OpenWorks Engineering has developed a handheld cannon that can launch disruptive netting at drones flying above.

name: Doing No Digital Harm
description: Humanitarian action has only just begun to experience the kind of digital disruption that has already upended other sectors. The digitalization of aid will have far-reaching effects on a sector that is still structured around post-World War II institutions. While this could help meet needs more effectively, humanitarian managers are nonetheless focused on a new dictum: “do no digital harm.” Digital technologies offer new ways of helping and monitoring developments on the ground - and keeping track of people, money, and supplies. They also give new agency and options to people affected by crises. The internet and open data can shed light on even the most isolated parts of the world, for example, even when official sources of information are patchy. Data analysis techniques can help form new insights and spot trends; the data analytics firm Palantir, while better known for its work in defence, has also been working with humanitarian agencies’ datasets in order to help monitor conflict and food supplies. Meanwhile the World Bank has called in some of the world’s biggest technology companies to help it use artificial intelligence to predict famine. People affected by humanitarian disasters need smartphones to keep in touch, find out where to go, or call in family support. Supplying WiFi and battery charging have therefore become a routine part of humanitarian response; connectivity is becoming a recognized need, if not (yet) a human right. But there is a risk in all of this digital development, and tightening up data protection has therefore become a priority. Aid sector technology systems have often been built ad-hoc, and lack the robust data protection and cybersecurity that are standard in the private sector. The need for a framework for responsibly handling new digital ID systems is becoming urgent, as personal details about more than 20 million vulnerable people are sitting in cloud-based databases run by aid agencies. These records contain data about family circumstances, income, and place of origin - as well as fingerprints and iris scans. Such technology-based systems can offer compelling advantages; by digitally removing duplicates and ghost entries, a recount of refugees in Uganda in 2018 reduced the official headcount from 1.4 million to 1.1 million, for example. On the flip side, however, personal data can be hacked or misused by governments and criminals, creating new problems for people who are already among the most vulnerable.

name: Domain Name System
description: Responsibility for the domain name system, a sort of phone directory that makes the internet accessible via designations such as “.com” and “.net,” was shifted in 2016 from US Department of Commerce oversight to a global, multi-stakeholder community made up of the non-profit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and international organizations. The move was seen as important for preserving international support for, and contributions to, internet governance by diminishing the influence of the US - though ICANN itself remains headquartered in California. ICANN’s job has become more complicated in recent years, as the variety of so-called “top level” domains has expanded well beyond “.com” to include more specific designations that may offer security and operational benefits. Amazon.com, for example, has sought to secure the “.amazon” domain, over the objections of governments in South America that argue that a designation related to the Amazon rainforest should not be assigned to a private company. There were 332.4 million domain name registrations across all top level domains as of the end of 2017, or a 0.5% increase compared with the third quarter of that year, according to VeriSign, a private company that contracts with ICANN. VeriSign said that “.com” was the most popular designation overall, with nearly 132 million reported domain names, followed by China’s domain “.cn,” which had 21.4 million reported domain names, Germany’s “.de,” at 16.3 million, and “.net,” at 14.5 million. The “.tk” domain, which belongs to the small, island country Tokelau, was actually the third-most-popular designation behind “.com,” with 19.9 million reported domain names - as it has been used to provide domain names free of charge.

name: Domestic Political Pressures
description: In many countries, the politics of national identity are intersecting with geopolitical trends in disruptive ways, and creating potentially destabilizing feedback loops. Many politicians have secured power, or are seeking it, on the basis of promises to redress imbalances attributed to globalization, by prioritizing the demands of the domestic population - particularly in relation to jobs and migration. In a growing number of countries, populist platforms have been blended with the use of identity politics in order to win or maintain support, often by aggravating grievances and exacerbating fears; examples from around the world abound, including in the US, India, various European Union member states, and Turkey, and have been intensified by social media - which in just a relatively short space of time has evolved into an important driver of political polarization. Domestic identity politics is both cause and effect when it comes to the current, tumultuous phase of geopolitics. A growing number of political leaders who owe their domestic positions to assertively nationalist or protectionist stances are now shaping the interaction among states at the global level. This has eroded global institutions and alliances, and hindered efforts to create new alternatives. At the same time, there is increasing evidence that intensifying geopolitical competition is an amplifier of divisive domestic political trends. In part this is because it encourages leaders to double down on nationalist narratives, but it also reflects the fact that there can be geopolitical incentives to exploit the political, social, and ethno-religious divisions that exist in other countries. Foreign intervention of this kind can take many forms, such as active support for a preferred political candidate, or efforts to destabilize entire political systems in rival states. Increasingly prevalent technologies and tools, including social media platforms and big data analysis, are an important part of this story - particularly with respect to cyberattacks and the spread of disinformation. In fragile states in particular, outside interference in domestic politics tends to sustain and harden existing divisions, drawing out political or even violent conflicts and hurting the chances for reconciliation, while sometimes reversing a country’s healthy transition to democracy.

name: Domestic and Foreign Security
description: The election of President Emmanuel Macron in 2017 strengthened France’s global engagement and influence, propelling the country to the top of the annual Soft Power 30 index that year (it subsequently slipped to 2nd place in 2018). France is playing a leading role in fostering international cooperation and integration, defending democratic values abroad, and campaigning for a stronger, more united Europe with a common defense force and budget. As a permanent member of the UN Security Council, France has deployed thousands of soldiers across Africa as part of peacekeeping operations addressing complex humanitarian, political, and security crises. The country has also joined the international coalition effort to combat the Islamic State militant group. Security issues are among the primary concerns of French citizens; more than half believe France ought to be better prepared for external threats, according to a Jean Jaurès Foundation and Sciences Po poll conducted in 2017. France’s history and expressed values, coupled with its military interventions in Africa’s Sahel region and the Levant, make the country particularly vulnerable to domestic and foreign security issues. Since 2015, France has been the victim of a series of terrorist attacks targeting civilians and soldiers. As a result, national security and terrorism are at the heart of domestic and foreign policies. Macron has set a goal of meeting NATO’s defense spending target of 2% of GDP by 2025, which would be an increase from the current level of 1.5%. The human, material and financial resources needed to meet France’s domestic security and military commitments are considerable, and the current budget does not allow the country to ensure its international presence in this respect. However, a defense budget increase could have serious implications for the rest of the economy. Over the past decade, 40% of France’s spending cuts were related to defense; if the country allocates additional annual funds to its military budget as it plans to, it is vital that the money be wisely spent. According to the French think tank Institut Montaigne, the country’s current priorities should be restoring military capability, modernizing and replacing military equipment, strengthening participation in nuclear deterrence, and increasing investment in research.

name: Driving Africa’s Growth
description: Entrepreneurs in Africa inhabit a fragmented, dynamic space that hovers between legitimate and illegitimate economies. That is in part a reflection of a society that is relatively less engaged with formal banking and payment services. As recently as 2014, only 34% of the population in sub-Saharan Africa had access to any financial services, according to the World Bank’s Global Findex Database; the version of the database published in 2018 found that in eight out of 10 economies in the region, more adults reported having saved money semi-formally than “formally” - that is, with a bank account. The interest rates on loans from traditional banks are generally prohibitive for regulated small businesses, while those operating in the informal economy are often ineligible for financing. That has had a limiting effect, but has also been an impetus for technology innovation; the 2018 World Bank database found that 21% of the population in sub-Saharan Africa had a mobile money account, the highest percentage of any region in the world. The further development of basic communications technologies and infrastructure is essential for lowering African entrepreneurs’ operating costs. Globally, Africa is contending with a changing landscape - as traditional trading partners have faced economic slowdowns and economic interest from large emerging economies, particularly China, has grown. While Africa’s economic growth in recent decades has been impressive, high levels of inequality and youth unemployment have persisted. That could breed social discontent, and threaten political stability. A Boston Consulting Group study examined income per person, jobs, governance, health, and inequality, and found that general well-being in significant areas of sub-Saharan Africa is relatively low. Meanwhile 17 of the 20 lowest-ranked economies in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index are in sub-Saharan Africa, and most economic activity still takes place in the informal (illegitimate) economy; 66% of all non-farm employment in sub-Saharan Africa was informal as of 2015, as was 52% in North Africa, according to International Labour Organization estimates. Sub-standard access to education and health care for those living in poverty further aggravates inequality, making it harder for the disadvantaged and their children to improve their economic status. And yet, inequality is not always an explicit focus of African governments.

name: Drought and Energy Mix
description: Water is a significant factor in most economic activity, in addition to being a vital life source - and South Africa is a water scarce country. In 2017, drought conditions forced Cape Town to designate “Day Zero,” a point in August 2018 when all taps in the city would run dry; it was subsequently pushed back to 2019. The Department of Water and Sanitation has reported an overall decline in water quality between 2012 and 2014, and millions of people in rural areas still lack access to clean drinking water. While municipalities supply water and maintain infrastructure, they are dependent on the federal government and decentralized water boards for water supply. As a result, charges applied to water users lack a systematic relationship to costs - even though appropriate pricing could be an effective mechanism for ensuring efficient and productive use. Since 2005, demand for electricity in South Africa has outstripped supply, resulting in rolling blackouts. Over the past two decades, the government estimates it has provided electricity to 6 million poor households; however, the last mile of connectivity between the central grid and homes requires added infrastructure. It is essential to diversify South Africa’s energy mix, in order to lower pollution and ease the effects of climate change - and there is potential to tap renewable and clean energy from wind farms in the Eastern Cape. Meanwhile food security can only be attained when everyone has access to sufficient, nutritious food, and South Africa has many households that are classified as food insecure (the Department of Agriculture has estimated that between 1999 and 2009, more than one third of the country’s households were food insecure). However, it is difficult to assess the actual extent of food insecurity, and to adequately address need; it is therefore necessary to standardize related data collection and analysis. Climate change poses a threat to sustainable domestic food production in the country, while productive land is not always optimally utilized. Small-scale farmers are faced with the challenge of limited access to processing facilities and markets. In addition, rising input costs such as electricity, water, and labour affect the ability to sustainably produce food. Efforts to increase market linkages and access to electricity and water are essential to ensure sustainable food production, and potentially boost rural development.

name: E-commerce and Demand Chains
description: According to research firm eMarketer, global online retail sales will reach almost $5 trillion by 2021, and account for nearly one fifth of total retail spending. The supply chain challenges presented by this trend stem not only from expanding sales, but also from the increasing expectations of customers. Product range, and speed of delivery, have become major competitive differentiators. A survey conducted by the publication Business Insider found that the portion of US online retailers with a same-day delivery capability more than tripled between 2016 and 2017, to 51%. This emphasis on rapid fulfilment and product customization is now making the term “demand chain” more appropriate than “supply chain.” The demand chain impact is most visible on the so-called “last mile.” In the early days of online retailing, this largely entailed van deliveries to homes. Today, shoppers can receive orders at gas stations, train stations, lockers and even in the trunk of their car. Servicing such dispersed demand has required the development of new “omni-channel” distribution systems that require the careful coordination of IT, inventory, handling and transport. This is a particular challenge for traditional retailers diversifying into the online market and adapting their legacy infrastructure accordingly. ﻿Last-mile delivery has become a fertile area for innovation. Online “crowdshipping” platforms are engaging people in the delivery of parcels, often in the course of their everyday travel, while drones and surface delivery robots, or “droids,” can provide automated delivery. The roll-out of the Internet of Things permits automatic replenishment to smart refrigerators and cupboards, while Amazon now offers what it claims is secure “in-home” delivery. Radical change is also occurring in less visible parts of the supply chain. E-commerce has enabled manufacturers to bypass traditional wholesale and retail outlets and sell directly to customers, for example. And manufacturers can use both the platforms and logistical systems deployed by large online retailers such as Amazon and Alibaba, in order to extend their own reach. The fulfilment of international orders remains a challenge, however, as smaller players with modest volumes face relatively high shipping rates and cross-border administration hassles. Large online retailers are exerting increasing influence on the global freight market. Amazon has acquired its own fleet of dozens of Boeing jets, and is establishing its own airfreight hub. Meanwhile JD.com, China’s second largest online retailer, is partnering with China Eastern airlines to build national and international logistics networks.

name: Economic Diversification
description: The unpredictability of global energy supply and demand creates significant uncertainty for the Russian Federation’s economy. Other aggravating factors of late include a depressed ruble, and economic sanctions imposed by Western countries. The country has responded with a policy of import substitution, or shifting from reliance on imports to producing more goods at home in order to generate growth. The policy provides an opportunity for self-sufficiency and local industries, particularly agriculture. However, true self-sufficiency will take time. In addition, some Russian manufactured goods are not competitive on global markets. Logistics remain key to the economy, and the further development of ports in the east could provide an important gateway for Europe, with increased related infrastructure investment. Meanwhile climate change-induced warming in the Arctic is opening up opportunities for increased Russian shipping and resource extraction in that region. The Russian Federation will ideally transition its industry to what has been referred to as “Russia 4.0,” or a state of production that efficiently leverages the business models and technologies of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. In this regard, Russia could adopt a tailored, asymmetrical approach to production development, with increased investment in select technology areas and regions that can in turn support infrastructure and the labour force. Refocusing the government on creating efficient and transparent conditions for industry development, and on the diffusion of emerging technologies, while better aligning the interests of commercial and research institutions, will be key. The country currently suffers from several barriers to technology adoption in production, including restricted access to foreign technology, a shortage of financing options, and outdated regulation. However, the Russian Federation also has distinct advantages that could help it overcome these barriers: its relatively late entrance into high-tech production may enable it to leapfrog to state-of-the-art standards and processes; it has successful, innovative companies that can champion technology development and adoption; and the government has unveiled several initiatives that make technology transfers and innovation priorities. Russia’s workforce lacks the skills necessary to meet the production demands of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Both government and business leaders have prioritized short-termism over innovative approaches. Even if leaders wanted to invest in upskilling workers - which many do not - there is a dearth of programmes in the country capable of providing necessary training. If proper steps are taken, however, Russia’s labour force could represent a competitive advantage. The country’s education system already prioritizes science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) courses, and the population is relatively digitally-literate. By aligning education more closely with the needs of industry, and by incentivizing creative thinking and collaboration, Russia could better leverage its labour force in the future.

name: Economic Diversification and Sophistication
description: Colombia continues to depend heavily on natural resource-intensive industries for economic growth. According to the CIA World Factbook, as of February 2018 Colombia was the fourth-largest oil producer in Latin America, and one of the world’s main producers of coal. Rents and royalties paid by the mining and energy sectors have enabled the Colombian government to increase funding for public programs. However, because industries like oil and coal account for over half of the country’s exports, Colombia is particularly susceptible to commodity market fluctuations. A shift towards higher value-added activities could reduce the country’s related exposure. One obstacle to lessening dependence on extractive industries, however, is Colombia’s limited participation in trade agreements. Colombia’s agricultural sector has stagnated. Agriculture as a share of total GDP fell from 8% in 2000 to 6.3% as of 2017. While the economy has grown by 4.1% per year on average over the past decade and a half, agricultural sector growth has been just 2.3% per year. More closely tying the sector to global value chains is essential to diversify Colombia’s economy and help reduce inequality. Farmers and indigenous communities also need to develop sustainable land-use practices and forest conservation mechanisms. The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) recommends directing more public investment to the sustainable development of rural areas, greater formalizing of land ownership titles, and the expansion of credit for small farmers. Colombia’s services industry, particularly the travel and tourism sector, represents an important opportunity for economic diversification. The number of foreign tourists traveling to Colombia has surpassed global and Latin American averages; international arrivals increased by 16% in 2015 compared with the prior year, according to the World Tourism Organization. That was significantly higher than the 8% increase for Latin America as a whole, and 4.3% increase worldwide during the same period. According to the Colombian Ministry of Trade, Industry and Tourism, tourism accounted for 1 in every 11 jobs in the country in 2015, and was the third-most-important source of foreign currency earnings after oil and coal. A 2018 report published by the IDB cited access to finance as one of the greatest potential obstacles for companies in Colombia, particularly small- and medium-sized enterprises. This issue is not trivial; the IDB reported in 2015 that while small- and medium-sized firms represented 99% of the country’s business sector that year, 80% of private employment and 35% of GDP, these companies only received 14% of all commercial loans. Causes include shortages of eligible collateral and weak contract compliance. The cost of taking out a loan is high in Colombia, compared with other emerging economies. According to the World Bank’s World Development Indicators, the spread between the average active rate paid by borrowers and the passive rates paid by lenders exceeds 7% in the country; it is around 1.8% in Chile, and close to 3% in other, similar economies. This situation is partly caused by the distortions such as the concentrated nature of Colombia’s banking sector.

name: Economic Institutions
description: Traditional balances of power are being disrupted, as emerging economies both create new international development organizations, and seek to gain more influence over existing institutions. China, for example, has actively promoted the development of alternatives to the Bretton Woods institutions, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which have been used since World War II to govern the international economic system. The Washington, D.C.-based IMF manages financial crises and balance of payments problems (the organization supplied a $50 billion loan to Argentina in order to help that country avert a crisis in June 2018, for example), while the World Bank (also headquartered in Washington, D.C.) provides loans to countries in order to build infrastructure. Both institutions are often perceived as furthering US policy. In order to provide an alternative to the World Bank, China, along with its partners, helped to lay the groundwork for the BRICS bank, now known as the New Development Bank, which was established in 2014 with its headquarters in Shanghai. At that time, an Op-Ed published by the Brookings Institution described the new institution as a potentially positive way to address shortages of infrastructure investment in developing countries, though it cautioned that China’s economic heft relative to its partners in the endeavour threatened to make coordinating funding priorities difficult. China’s influence on the IMF has been growing. Since October 2016, China’s Renminbi has been included in Special Drawing Rights, an IMF international reserve asset backed by a basket of currencies in order to provide liquidity to countries in need - alongside the US Dollar, Euro, Japanese Yen, and Pound Sterling. In addition, since 2011, a Chinese national has served as an IMF deputy managing director. Critics from emerging markets have generally argued that such changes are occurring too slowly. However, a recent shift in US policy has created even greater opportunity for countries such as China to gain more sway when it comes to the IMF and World Bank, as the US takes a more adversarial approach international institutions generally. Alternative economic institutions had already tested relations between the US and traditional allies; for example, the US had sought to discourage the participation of Germany and France in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which began operations in 2016.

name: Economic Integration
description: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) region is a more open and accessible market than both the European Union and the US, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2016 Global Enabling Trade Report. That same year, 2016, ASEAN as a cohesive unit gained its highest share of world trade since 2010, accounting for 7% of the world’s total merchandise trade, according to the World Trade Organization’s World Trade Statistical Review 2017; the region’s positive trade balance that year was $62 billion. As of 2015, the main recipients of ASEAN exports were China (12% of the total), the US (11%), and the EU (11%), according to the WTO publication. Overall, total merchandise trade in ASEAN rose by about 50%, to $1.14 trillion, between 2006 and 2016, according to the publication. As the trade in goods and services between ASEAN and the rest of the world has increased, so has the movement of workers abroad. The numbers of both men and women from ASEAN living abroad each increased to more than 9 million respectively by 2013, from less than 4 million each as of 1990, according to data published by the International Labour Organization. Following the launch of the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) in 2015, ASEAN member states have formed a tighter economic grouping. The AEC aims to foster a single market and industrial production capacity, increase competitiveness, support inclusive growth, and further integrate the region into the global economy. Developments since the formation of the AEC include plans announced in 2018 by firms in Malaysia and Indonesia to jointly develop and manufacture what would be the region’s first automobile. The AEC comes at a delicate time for global trade, however. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which includes ASEAN countries, Australia, Canada and others, was reformulated in 2018 following the withdrawal of the US from the agreement, for example. ASEAN is seeking a more important role in negotiating the proposed Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), which in addition to ASEAN countries includes Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea, and New Zealand. At the RCEP’s intersessional ministerial meeting held in Tokyo in July 2018, attending ministers recognized the importance of swiftly concluding negotiations in light of the current global trade environment and the heightened risk of unilateral trade actions and reactions, according to a joint media statement.

name: Economic Reform in Viet Nam
description: Viet Nam’s economic growth, following market reforms implemented by the communist state in the 1980s, has been impressive - though it has recently slowed. For the past decade, average annual growth has been about 6%, compared with 6.6% during the decade prior to that. Efforts to recapture higher growth rates have seemingly been exhausted. While the government has set a target of between 6.5% and 7% annual growth between 2016 and 2020, this will be challenging due to lingering structural weakness in the banking sector (and in state-owned enterprises), and excessive levels of public debt. Viet Nam’s credit boom roughly a decade ago was accompanied by uncontrolled lending, the poor handling of credit risk, inactive internal auditing, and compromised supervision. The credit rating agency Fitch Ratings noted in a report published in 2017 that the Vietnamese banking system’s officially registered ratio of non-performing loans at that point, 2.5%, probably understated the severity of the issue. High levels of bad debt have seriously weakened the banks’ balance sheets, and related regulation and supervision should be improved. The privatization of state-owned enterprises in Viet Nam began more than a quarter of a century ago. While several conglomerates have since been privatized, the state still holds major ownership stakes in key sectors such as banking and aviation. Successful examples of enterprises that have benefited from privatization include the dairy company Vinamilk, and coffee maker Vinacafe. However, the privatization process has slowed in recent years, as proposals have been queuing up for approval. A revamp of the privatization process could enable greater participation among foreign and domestic investors in the country’s economy, and improve the performance of large firms that consume a large portion of Viet Nam’s natural resources. Meanwhile the country’s deficit and public debt levels have raised concern. Public debt as a percentage of GDP reached 61.5% in 2017, according to the International Monetary Fund, nearing the 65% ceiling established by Viet Nam’s National Assembly. Borrowing by state-owned enterprises and public investment projects have made it challenging to remain below this target. Maintaining a high debt-to-GDP ratio contributes to economic instability, and increases the risk posed to businesses. Comprehensive fiscal reform, and more sustainable management of public debt, should be priorities.

name: Economic Sanctions
description: Economic sanctions restrict or eliminate another country’s international trade and financial interaction, in order to achieve foreign policy or security objectives. Sanctions can be applied by individual nations, groups of states, or international organizations, and targets can be countries, specific industries within a country, or individuals - denying them entry abroad, freezing their assets, or restricting their financial dealings. However, sanctions regimes often fail to quickly produce results; if they persist over long periods, perceptions of their purpose can shift. For example, US and European Union bans on the sale of military equipment to China imposed in 1989, in the wake of the Tiananmen Square protests, remain in place - leading many to suspect their purpose is now simply to restrain Chinese military development. In addition, many remain convinced that western sanctions imposed on the Russian Federation in 2014, with the purpose of reversing Russian policy on Ukraine, were really aimed at undermining Russian leadership and slowing the country’s economic growth. Meanwhile restrictions that the Russian Federation imposed on Georgian agricultural products in 2006 have been interpreted by some people as intended to deter the smaller country from aligning with western countries. Sanctions regimes can be organized through international agreements and institutions - as is the case with the control of commodities, technologies, and equipment linked to the development of nuclear weapons, and implemented through the Non-Proliferation Treaty and the International Atomic Energy Agency. The United Nations Security Council has used sanctions to back up its resolutions with force, as it has confronted terrorist organizations, armed groups in Africa, and the North Korean nuclear programme. Regional blocs like the EU also make use of sanctions; in 2014, the EU hit Russia with sanctions that included asset freezes and visa bans for 149 people, and a cancellation of bilateral EU-Russia summits, in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The US has applied its own sanctions against Russia, in response to alleged cyberattacks and interference with the 2016 presidential election. The US has punished entities for violating its sanctions, aided by the importance of its financial industry to the international system. In 2014, the US fined French Bank BNP Paribas $8.9 billion for violating its sanctions on Cuba, Iran and Sudan.

name: Economic Shifts
description: A deep and rapid integration of the global economy has rebalanced economic power, and created complex new economic and financial interconnections. In the two decades leading up to 2017, the share of global output accounted for by developing economies jumped to 59.3% from 42.8%, with much of that shift accounted for by China - which alone went from contributing 6.6% of global output to 18.7% over the period. China’s integration into the world’s economy has been one of the most significant global developments since the end of World War II. Changes in relative economic power have led to accompanying shifts in the global balance of geopolitical power, though the influence of economics on geopolitics is not restricted to GDP growth. Increasingly, governments reach for economic and financial policy levers in order to advance national ambitions, in both the economic and political realms. The dividing line between economics and national security has therefore blurred, sometimes as a matter of policy - as in the case of the US Department of Commerce’s strategic plan for 2018-22, which states that “economic security is national security.” The increasingly domestic lens through which states assess their international economic policies and priorities has weakened support for the global economic governance framework in place since World War II. Efforts made over decades to deepen global trading relations have given way to a patchwork framework that is showing signs of systemic fragility; the US’s blocking of new appointments to the World Trade Organization’s Appellate Body is one such sign. Meanwhile some countries are taking more mercantilist approaches to trade, and see their bilateral relations as part of a geopolitical zero-sum game with winners and losers (the successive rounds of tariffs levied by the US and China on one another during 2018 are a case in point). Trade is not the only economic policy area being used to advance broader national ambitions. For example, there has been a resurgence of the use of economic and financial sanctions, while foreign direct investment, long a key channel through which states create cross-border links, has also been affected. China’s massive, infrastructure-focused Belt and Road Initiative is an ambitious, and controversial, example of a strategy of concerted outward investment with geopolitical ramifications; the flipside of this is the growing number of countries creating barriers to inward investment which is perceived to threaten strategically-sensitive industries.

name: Economic and Social Complexity
description: Rules governing behaviour are the fundamental platform on which human economic and social relationships are built. Taken together, the formal rules of a legal system, informal cultural rules, and the formal and informal institutions that determine whether these rules are followed constitute a form of infrastructure. This infrastructure dictates property issues, contracts, freedom of action, entitlement to compensation, physical security, and other building blocks of economic activity. It is a mechanism used to ensure that economic activity is efficient, sustainable, and consistent with social values, and that governments do not exploit their powers - and that they do help us strive for equality, fairness, dignity, and peace. As societies grow more complex, they require different legal infrastructure; that is, new rules and systems that can better respond to changing economic activities, environments, values, beliefs, and a shifting understanding of how societies work generally. Today, we are faced with exponential growth in complexity. Globalization is connecting economic actors, individuals, and communities in increasingly dense webs of interaction - generating unpredictable dynamics. This challenges assumptions about how things should be done. The speed and scope of technological innovation on multiple fronts, like artificial intelligence and robotics, 3D printing, cryptocurrencies, space travel, and genetic engineering, create a constant stream of novelty and uncertainty for the legal world. Meanwhile growing income and wealth inequality, and a burgeoning need to participate in the so-called knowledge economy, is creating backlash against long-held policies in advanced economies. Social media platforms allow groups regardless of size or distance from the mainstream to voice, spread, and act on their views, in a landscape that shifts on a daily basis. The global scale of threats such as climate change, terrorism, and autonomous weapons calls for shared policies across an enormous range of communities. Theorists define complex adaptive systems as networks of interactions between independent agents, each making predictions, following rules, and adapting in order to achieve goals and produce what theorist Stuart Kauffman has termed a “dancing landscape.” This process, which can be almost impossible to predict, represents the landscape in which our efforts to shape the transformations of the Fourth Industrial Revolution while maintaining economic and social progress are taking place. Developing smart, adaptable legal infrastructure that can handle the economic and social complexity of the modern world is perhaps the most fundamental challenge we face.

name: Economic and Social Structures
description: Blockchain is the first truly digital economy technology - one that brings economics and technology together in a genuinely novel way. It enables the redefinition of trust not just within industries, but also across societies. Many aspects of current interaction on the internet could be improved by blockchain, for example, thanks to its ability to handle verification and transactions in a peer-to-peer, secure way that does not rely on large intermediaries. Supply chains, the essential circulatory system that ensures that global commerce can carry on uninterrupted, may receive a healthy re-balancing between local and global due to the use of blockchain; as a mechanism for exchanging value and creating an immutable record of transactions, even small companies could use blockchain to better collaborate and in some cases even compete with global players. The technology could also help to reduce environmental damage, by cutting down on the unnecessary transport of goods around the world. The so-called “greening” of global supply chains will require greater traceability and transparency, according to a report published in 2017 by the International Finance Corporation (IFC). Blockchain, as a system that effectively cannot be tampered with, can provide more reliable information on where food originated and how it was produced, according to the IFC report.  Blockchain can also create new insights for regulators, who may in some circumstances and at certain times need to see the provenance of different elements within a supply chain. For example, within a food supply chain, the technology can provide greater transparency when it comes to food scandals or contamination, enabling regulators to see exactly what areas have been affected and to better direct their efforts at solving problems. A number of startups are working on related issues, including a United Kingdom-based company that launched a pilot program in Indonesia that uses blockchain-enabled tagging to track tuna fishing, according to the IFC’s 2017 report. A key challenge with blockchain is ensuring that industrialized systems based on the technology are robust and secure enough to handle the volume of transactions that occur in large supply chains. For example, transactions on blockchain in the Bitcoin cryptocurrency currently require an average of 10 minutes to be confirmed, and the system is limited to a throughput of around seven transactions per second - due a trade-off between scalability and resilience against malicious actors.

name: Economics and Finance
description: Behavioural insights are starting to have serious implications for individuals’ savings accounts, corporate balance sheets and national budgets. They key on the fact that humans, even when making consequential financial decisions, do not always act rationally - but are instead prone to biases. A typical example is the so-called “anchoring effect” during negotiations; offers have a tendency to be strongly influenced by the first number tossed out. If a buyer therefore gets to make his or her offer first, and offers a relatively small sum, this should draw the ultimate, agreed-upon towards the lower end of the spectrum. One prominent intervention, “Save More TomorrowTM,” developed by behavioural economists, leverages a decision bias dubbed “hyperbolic discounting” to help people increase retirement savings. Hyperbolic discounting has two components: people strongly wish to avoid costs they have to incur sooner than costs they can delay, and this preference for later becomes less pronounced over time. Consequently, employees are more willing to sacrifice a fraction of their current salaries to increase their retirement savings, if the sacrifice is delayed. As part of “Save More TomorrowTM,” an employee is approached by a financial consultant as early as possible, before a future pay raise, and asked if he or she wants to increase their contribution to a pension fund with the first pay check after the raise. Contributions are then increased with each raise up to a predefined maximum, unless the employee wishes to opt out, which they can at any time. The program has helped millions of people increase their retirement savings. Governments can benefit from behavioural insights, too. People can be motivated to pay their taxes, if states acknowledge and reward good behaviour, and demonstrate good public use of tax money. A 2017 working paper published by the Inter-American Development Bank cited a study in which 400 individuals from a municipality in Argentina were randomly selected from a pool of 72,000 people who had paid their property taxes. The selected taxpayers were publicly recognized in a highly visible way, when the government built new sidewalks in front of their houses. Those who received the new sidewalks were 7% more likely to pay their property taxes over the following three years, according to the study. In addition, the neighbors of those who received the new sidewalks were also more likely to pay their taxes in the future.

name: Economics of Environmental Sustainability
description: In late 2018, the UN’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change issued an alarming report noting that global temperatures are on track to be 1.5°C higher than the preindustrial era as soon as 2030. Currently, at 1°C warmer than the preindustrial era, we are already experiencing severe consequences of climate change including forest fires in the Arctic, and the increased intensity of hurricanes. A 1.5°C increase would mean more rapid sea level rise, hot extremes in most inhabited parts of the world, a higher probability of drought, and other risks to human security and economic growth, according to the UN report. Climate change, pollution, and resource depletion have been impacting the economic productivity of both countries and private companies. These forces also disproportionately impact the poor, exacerbating socio-economic inequality. According to an edition of the International Monetary Fund’s World Economic Outlook published in 2017, the per capita GDP in a typical low-income country will be 9% lower by 2100 than it would have been in the absence of climate change-related temperature increases. A subsequent edition of the outlook published in late 2018 noted that robust global economic growth will require better buffering low-income countries against the effects of climate change, with things like climate-smart infrastructure. While weather shocks tied to climate change have an immediate impact on agricultural production, they also have broader impacts related to labour productivity, mortality, health, and conflict - as threats to food security aggravate already-simmering issues in fragile states. According to IMF calculations, a temperature increase of 1°C to the median, low-income developing country temperature of 25°C can reduce crop production and agriculture value added (the processing of raw materials) by between 1% and 2% annually. Agriculture and farming in the oceans also face significant climate-related challenges. Climate change-related changes in marine fisheries production may be just as large as those in crop agriculture, according to a report published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations in 2018; primary production of the global ocean is expected to decline by 6% by 2100 (and by 11% in tropical zones), according to the report. Economic policies and business practices need to better take environmental constraints into account, in order to make stable growth and freedom from conflict realistic possibilities for future generations.

name: Economics of the Fourth Industrial Revolution
description: Responses to technological change can determine the shape of economic progress. Technology that can serve to automate tasks now performed by significant portions of a country’s existing workforce, for example, can potentially do at least as much damage to the social fabric as the good it can do for productivity metrics. According to a report published by the McKinsey Global Institute in 2017, as much as 14% of the global workforce will need to switch occupational category by the year 2030 as a result of increasing automation. In addition, according to the report, all workers will have to adapt as their occupations evolve alongside increasingly capable machines, by attaining a higher level of education or by spending more time on honing the human aspects most difficult to automate - like creativity, and emotional skills. The Fourth Industrial Revolution presents a turning point for human development, as the rapid pace of technological change tests social cohesion, and demands bold policy responses in order to better foster innovation, develop sound economic policy, and prudently increase productivity. According to market-research firm Gartner, the total number of connected devices is expected to more than double between 2017 and 2020, reaching 20.4 billion. New technologies can help generate economic growth; the Internet of Things, which strings together myriad, everyday devices with online connectivity, can for example help cities more efficiently use power needed to light streetlamps, by sensing when they are really needed and when they are not (Barcelona is an example of a city deploying the technology for this purpose). Meanwhile companies in countries including China and Japan are developing robotic exoskeletons designed to boost worker productivity. On the one hand, such devices could help address the problem of ageing workforces (particularly in countries with demographics like Japan’s), by keeping more workers on the job for more years than they would be able to manage otherwise. On the other hand, greater automation via robotics may also add further downward pressure on wages earned by low-skilled workers. Leveraging the potential benefits of technology in the interest of more inclusive growth will require active preparation for possible future economic and social repercussions – such as increased unemployment, and the widespread failure of overwhelmed welfare systems.

name: Ecosystem for Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurship
description: As global competition becomes increasingly innovation-driven, a vibrant innovation ecosystem can be a critical national or regional competitive advantage. Silicon Valley provides an illustration of the necessary elements: universities and public research labs that not only generate cutting-edge knowledge, but also facilitate commercialization through licensing or spinoffs; a prevalence of experienced angel investors and early-stage venture capital firms; large, dynamic companies that are willing to work with startups by providing corporate venture funding and buying their products and services; and a diverse culture that tolerates failure. Also critical are policies that help protect intellectual property rights and efficient bankruptcy laws - in order to better facilitate serial entrepreneurship. Where critical elements are missing or underdeveloped, government participation in the form of co-funding schemes to stimulate angel investing, and subsidies for incubators and startup accelerator programs may help to fill the gap.

name: Education Gender Gaps
description: The development and deployment of female “human capital” (a way of describing the knowledge, creativity, and other measures of a worker’s value) is a critical element of global economic growth. As successive generations of educated women now enter the workforce, economies can only fully utilize their talent if there is a corresponding narrowing of the economic gender gap, or the nagging difference between women and men when it comes to making an economic impact. Progress made in addressing the education gender gap could set the pace for the erasing this disparity. According to the World Economic Forum’s 2017 Global Gender Gap Report, young women and men entering the labour force around the world have nearly identical educational qualifications, with some regional variation. There is near parity in terms of participating in primary and secondary education, for example, though there is a 7% gap when it comes to participation in tertiary (such as a university or technical training) education. According to the report, on a country-by-country basis, primary education gaps have been closed in 67 countries, secondary education gaps have been closed in 101, and tertiary education gaps have been closed in 93. However, girls comprise a marginally larger proportion of children (under the age of 15) not attending school, according to the report, and a much larger proportion of youth (older than 15) not attending school - 23% of girls, compared with 15% of boys. Among women and men who are over the age of 25 and already in the workforce, the educational gender gap is even bigger: 11% for primary education attainment, 17% for secondary education, and 14% for tertiary. However, gaps have narrowed significantly among those currently enrolled in education, which should be reflected in the composition of the future global workforce. An important point raised in the Forum’s report is that the core, post-secondary disciplines where women continue to remain under-represented are in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, or STEM, fields. Just 6% of women study engineering, construction and manufacturing, compared with 19% of men, for example, while 3% of women study information, communication, and technology, compared with 6.5% of men. This discrepancy is commonly attributed to negative stereotypes, a lack of role models, and hostile work environments. It is a key gender parity issue, as STEM-related careers will likely be among the most sought-after as the Fourth Industrial Revolution progresses.

name: Education Innovation
description: Technological innovation is changing the way educational materials are generated, the manner in which educational content is distributed, the way learners engage with materials, and the processes used to evaluate educational outcomes. Technology companies such as Amplify and Knewton are digitizing textbooks and creating content based on gamified learning. Other companies such as Coursera, edX, and Khan Academy are revolutionizing education delivery through so-called Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs). Still, some education systems, especially at the primary and secondary level, have been slow to incorporate even the most basic, widely available learning technologies. Technology presents opportunities to deliver learning in new, gamified, and personalized ways, which could change the traditional role of teachers and facilitate a blended learning experience. Technology has been proposed as a solution for resolving issues related to unequal access to education, for example in rural or hard-to-reach communities that nonetheless have digital access. New research from pedagogy, psychology, and other fields indicates areas that are ripe for innovation, especially when it comes to personalized learning. However, research has also highlighted that new learning tools do not always enable engagement with hard to reach groups - and it is critical that the drive towards education innovation is matched by a monitoring of its effectiveness in providing the right returns. Funding should be strategically allocated to trials, and successes can be grown to scale. Greater public-private collaboration aimed at expanding this opportunity would be beneficial.

name: Education in Brazil
description: Brazil ranked 121st out of 140 countries in terms of quality of vocational training in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index published in 2018, 124th in terms of the skill sets of all graduates, and 125th in terms of the digital skills of its population. While access to education in the country has expanded in recent decades, improving its quality remains a challenge. Data from international assessments demonstrate that Brazilian students perform significantly below their peers when it comes to reading, math, and science. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s PISA survey conducted in 2015, for example, ranked Brazil 59th out of 72 countries in reading, 63rd in science, and 65th in math. A World Bank report published in 2018 suggested that at the current rate of improvement, it would take more than 260 years for 15-year-olds in Brazil to reach the rich-country average score in reading - and 75 years to reach the average score in math. There are large and lingering education inequalities among Brazil’s regions and socio-economic strata, as well as between the sexes. Despite the fact that the literacy rate among women between 15 and 24 years of age in Brazil increased to 99% by 2017, from 84% in 1980, and the fact that roughly two-thirds of university graduates in the country are women, female labour force participation in the country rose by just one percentage point between 2005 and 2017, according to a report published by the World Bank. Inequality is still evident in the country’s educational infrastructure, in the training of its teachers and administrators, in the availability of materials and technologies, and in the degree of involvement of civil society groups and the private sector. Investment in education in Brazil should involve a more strategic focus on quality and equality, accompanied by better coordination among each level of government. Private sector participation in education is expected to grow, as the government seeks out more innovative ways to deliver results.

name: Education, Science and Technology
description: Access to primary and secondary education in Colombia has improved, and post-secondary education opportunities such as university programs have expanded. However, according to Fedesarrollo, a research institute, persistent inequality in terms of both education access and the quality of education have particularly affected low-income populations in marginalized rural areas, and members of ethnic groups. That means the country’s talent pool is not being fully utilized, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)’s Colombia Country Note Education at a Glance 2017. While only 22% of adults in the country have a tertiary (from a university or trade school) degree, too many students have been enrolled in higher education programs relative to more practical technical education programs. There are also inequalities between socio-economic classes when it comes to academic performance. The World Economic Forum’s Inclusive Growth and Development Report 2015 noted that just 1.5% of students from poor backgrounds in Colombia placed in the top quartile on the OECD’s PISA math assessment, compared with figures ranging between 12% and 15% in countries such as the Republic of Korea and Singapore. In order to improve the quality of education in Colombia, both increased investment and the efficient and equitable use of those funds is essential. The Colombian government should implement policies aimed at attracting, developing and retaining the best teachers, and teachers' salaries should be comparable to those offered by other competitive professions. Guidance should also be provided to the lowest-performing schools and teachers, and priority should be placed on rural areas with higher rates of poverty. Total research & development investment in Colombia in 2015 was equivalent to just 0.2% of GDP, well behind the OECD average of 2.5%. The Forum’s 2017 report Bridging the Skills and Innovation Gap to Boost Productivity in Latin America suggested providing tax incentives to firms that conduct R&D, regardless of their size, supporting public-private funding schemes for basic and applied research and skills development, and forging stronger links between academia and businesses. Other issues that must be addressed include a lack of access to venture capital funding, and a need to strengthen intellectual property rights.

name: Educational Disparities
description: While average education levels in South Africa have risen since 1994, the majority of students still receive inadequate schooling. According to a 2017 report published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the average math and science scores for South Africa’s 9th grade students were found to be more than two years behind the average for OECD countries - and less than half of all students were able to complete secondary school. The Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study published in 2015 ranked 9th grade students in South Africa 38th out of 39 countries surveyed for mathematics, and last for science. In addition, too few South African students are majoring in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) subjects, which involve the sort of problem-solving and critical thinking that will only become more in demand as a result of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. While the South African economy needs more high-skilled workers, the labour force is relatively low-skilled and less-educated. Due to the quality of schooling in the country, people who have attained prestigious degrees are being employed to do things that could have been done by workers with lower levels of education. According to a report published in 2014, so-called Further Education and Training (FET) colleges in South Africa are not producing graduates with relevant skills. A review of the skills in demand in the country is necessary, in order to help FET colleges develop more beneficial curricula. Providing access to quality primary and secondary education for the majority of South Africans is a significant challenge. Only about 20% of the country’s schools are wealthy and able to prepare students for a university education. In lower-quality schools, teacher absenteeism is high, infrastructure is crumbling, and resources are inadequate. A study published in 2016 by Stellenbosch University showed that 73.1% of white students complete a college degree, compared with 53.5% of black students; this reflects the legacy of apartheid. The affordability of higher education has also become a major issue. According to estimates published by the newspaper City Press in 2015, it costs the equivalent of about $7,000 to finance a year at university, in a country where household disposable income per capita was less than $9,000 as of 2014.

name: Elder Caregiving
description: As older populations expand faster than younger populations, it is disrupting traditional social structures where younger family members have had primary responsibility for caring for their elders - and creating more dependence on hospitals and institutions.
