The gap between the need for elder caregiving and existing supply is widening; by 2060, there will be only one caregiver in Europe for every 51 people aged 80 or older, according to a European Commission projection. As elder caregiving needs increase, a so-called “caring economy” is emerging. It is having a significant impact on the workforce, as it leads to increased absenteeism and decreased productivity, hinders gender parity efforts by having a disproportionately negative effect on female employees (as women make up the majority of elder caregivers), and slows overall economic growth. Working caregivers must often take time off, pass up promotion, or leave the workforce altogether. Meanwhile employers are losing valuable talent, and greater pressure is being placed on social systems. Other impacts: decreased earning and purchasing power; and negative effects on caregivers’ health and well-being, which in turn further drives up overall healthcare costs, according to the Global Coalition on Aging’s 2016 report The Value of Home Care. The need to provision quality care for the elderly is already disrupting national economies. Countries in Europe and North America, as well as Japan and the Republic of Korea, are looking to implement significant reforms in order to meet the needs of ageing populations. In addition, as emerging economies such as Brazil, China, Turkey, and South Africa grow older at a faster rate than they become wealthier, the socio-economic impact of elderly care in those countries could be particularly devastating. New solutions are essential. Greater prominence for the home care industry, for example, could help alleviate the impact of health and social care costs on public budgets. The industry in turn can spur economic growth, and provide employment opportunities for women and minorities, according to Caring in America, a 2011 report from the Paraprofessional Healthcare Institute. In addition, in order to sufficiently adapt to the new realities of ageing, incentives for saving for long-term care, more training and education for elder caregivers, and the application of innovative technologies will all be critical.

name: Electricity Decentralization
description: Distributed energy resources such as solar photovoltaics (PV) that turn light into power, energy storage units, electric vehicles, and microgrids are transforming electricity systems. While these resources still play a relatively minor role in the provision of electricity services, their deployment is increasing and their impact is being felt. Germany’s power system is one of the most striking examples of decentralization; 98% of the country’s solar PV resources are connected to the distribution grid there, according to a report published in 2017 by the research organization Fraunhofer, and 85% of this capacity comes from installations that are smaller than 1 megawatt. Meanwhile one in five customers in Hawaii, and one in 10 homes in California, now have a rooftop solar PV system. As of 2016, distributed solar PV accounted for nearly 13% of all US generation capacity additions, according to the US Energy Information Administration. Decentralized power is not always clean, however; the same trends driving the deployment of distributed solar affect other energy sources. Natural gas-powered combined heat and power units and fuel cells, for example, accounted for 8% of all US generation capacity as of 2015, and provided more than three times the capacity of solar in the country, according to GTM Research. Distributed energy storage resources are being used to defer investments in transmission and distribution networks, replace natural gas- and petroleum-fired “peaker” power plants, and reduce customer bills. Decentralization is not limited to the developed world; microgrids and off-grid energy resources are electrifying areas of India and sub-Saharan Africa that centralized utilities cannot reach. Decentralization enables consumers to better express their preferences, improves the production and delivery of power, and brings electricity to communities that are in dire need. However, if not deployed with care, distributed energy resources can result in dramatically increased power system costs, and foster inequality among resource owners and non-owners. In addition, due to the power lost when charging and discharging, energy storage resources may actually increase emissions. This calls for a sound regulatory framework, which includes a system of pricing and charges that accurately reflects the value of consuming or producing power at different times, and locations - and which also changes the way distribution utilities are remunerated, enabling them to take full advantage of distributed energy resources. Organized electricity markets must be reformed, in order to enable these resources to compete effectively and to reflect the new power sector reality.

name: Electricity System Integration
description: There is a global trend towards the integration of national, state, and local electric power systems in order to create supranational or regional electricity entities. These entities are referred to as “pools,” “interconnections,” or “regional markets,” depending on their organization. While decentralized energy resources (any resource connected to a distribution system that is capable of providing electricity services) are becoming increasingly present in power systems, the systems themselves are becoming more interconnected - both physically and in terms of ownership and management structures - across vast territories. The efficient utilization of electricity generation resources that are too large for a single country, as is the case with some hydro projects, or are too intermittent, like large-scale solar or wind farms, is made possible by the creation of regional markets with enough size to exploit economies of scale and dilute intermittency. Regional markets also make it possible to extend the use of natural resources, such as wind or solar, which are abundant in some territories but not others, across larger geographical areas. Regionalization also enables the creation of liquid, efficient markets in individual provinces, states, or countries which would otherwise be too small to sustain effective competition. Power pools in the US, created in the 1970s, were the first regional organizations of this kind, and were later turned into true regional markets. They were followed by the National Electricity Market (NEM) in Australia, the European Internal Electricity Market (IEM), the Regional Electricity Market (Mercado Eléctrico Regional, or MER) in Central America, the Southern Africa Power Pool (SAAP), and others. Some have reached an advanced level of maturity and integration, while others are still at early stages. Regional power trade, and the efficient utilization of large generation projects, require strong, cross-border network interconnections. Regional trade also requires careful market design, and clear rules for transmission investment planning, cost allocation, and congestion management. Markets must be supported by technical, economic, and institutional analyses of both current systems and likely future iterations. The creation of regional markets and the construction of expensive, cross-border interconnectors, which in some cases may deserve the classification “supergrids,” requires significant amounts of political will and the careful assessment of trade-offs; regional electricity markets are usually just one component of wider regional agreements that encompass other economic sectors.

name: Electrification of the Economy
description: In order to hit carbon dioxide emission targets set out in the 2016 Paris climate change agreement, it will be critical to electrify energy uses now powered by fossil fuels. According to a 2017 International Energy Agency (IEA) report, the energy sector could reach carbon neutrality (the elimination of new emissions) by 2060, through a combination of electrification and energy efficiency. Market forces alone will not push related technological development sufficiently, and will have to be complemented by public policy and clear rules. Only a few energy technologies enjoy favourable policy support, such as PV (solar photovoltaics), onshore wind, electric vehicles, and energy storage. Areas with untapped potential include energy efficiency, bioenergy, and carbon capture and storage. Increased financial support is needed in order to build stronger and smarter infrastructure, including transmission technologies. Heating and cooling in buildings, and industrial activity, currently account for approximately 40% of final energy consumption, according to the IEA report. Buildings can therefore play a major role in transforming the global energy system; increased efficiency in terms of heating, cooling, lighting, and materials could substantially ease demand, which would in turn ease the burden on the system as a whole. The electrification of the transport sector could significantly effect the global energy system, though there is still a long way to go for it to have a real impact on the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions. Speeding up the electrification of the transport sector, through improved urban planning and increased public transportation, as well as the integration of grid edge technologies, will require major technological development, investment, and policy support. Industrial energy demand is projected to increase by about two-thirds by 2060, according to the IEA report, and particular focus should be placed on strategic sectors such as iron, steel, and chemicals. In addition to introducing electric power into industrial processes whenever possible, many opportunities exist to curb demand growth - such as bolstering manufacturing efficiency, and optimizing locally available resources and materials. Both national and global policies must support energy technology innovation at all stages, from research to commercial deployment, in order to reap the security, environmental, and economic benefits of energy system transformation. Globalization allows for the faster deployment of proven related technologies, and can enable the private sector to build sustainable business models that both boost the electrification of the global energy system, and mitigate climate change.

name: Emerging Economies
description: About 30 countries, including both developed and developing economies, are considering, planning, or actually starting nuclear power programs, while roughly 20 more have expressed a related interest, according to an April 2018 report published by the World Nuclear Association. In total, there are already 447 operational nuclear power reactors in the world, spread across 30 countries, and nuclear continues to gain prominence as a power source; the 392 electrical gigawatts of installed nuclear power as of the end of 2016 was the highest level recorded to date, according to a July 2017 International Atomic Energy Agency report. The same IAEA report indicated that of the 60 nuclear reactors under construction worldwide, more than half were in the rapidly developing countries of Asia - a region that had accounted for 85 of a total of 105 construction starts since 2000. As electricity demand in developing economies is on track to surpass that of industrialized countries, there is a corresponding push to develop new generating options including nuclear, according to the IAEA report. The agency reported that it has sought to strengthen related safety in the wake of the accident at Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in 2011, which was triggered by an earthquake and forced the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of people. The transfer of nuclear technology to emerging economies should help to decouple their economic growth from carbon emissions, improve their resource security, and support the economic resilience of energy-exporting countries in particular. Saudi Arabia, for example, plans to build 16 nuclear power reactors in the next 20 to 25 years, at a cost of more than $80 billion, according to the World Nuclear Association, and the United Arab Emirates has accepted a $20 billion bid from a South Korean consortium to build four commercial nuclear power reactors by 2020. However, the implications for the established global nuclear non-proliferation regime will be significant, particularly if mitigating measures are not implemented. Policy-makers must focus on preventing nuclear terrorism, promoting measures to secure high-risk nuclear material, and preventing the illicit trafficking of material. The ability of authorities even in advanced economies to manage related risk has come into question. A Centre for Public Integrity investigation in 2017, for example, showed that the US struggles to maintain appropriate levels of safety at privately-managed nuclear weapons research facilities.

name: Emerging Market Entrepreneurship
description: Emerging and frontier markets are home to significant wealth creation and an expanding middle class, thanks to their capacity to spawn new businesses. But for those businesses to successfully hone in on untapped markets abroad, they need to adapt to unique needs of new customer segments around the world. By leveraging the power of the internet and other digital technologies, entrepreneurs in emerging markets can better understand how to enter new markets that may show promise, but are also different from those in advanced economies. For example, the poorest, so-called "Bottom of the Pyramid" markets pose significant challenges including a lack of distribution and energy infrastructure, and underdeveloped institutions - including those institutions tasked with protecting intellectual property and providing product quality certification. In addition, consumers in many emerging economies have specific cultural preferences, and adhere to social norms that may be different from those in more developed nations. Penetrating these markets therefore calls for innovation that can affect affordability and form a good cultural fit. Social impact-driven, entrepreneurial businesses may be more suitable than others for tapping into Bottom of the Pyramid markets in developing countries.

name: Emerging Markets
description: Emerging economies have outstripped their more advanced peers in terms of overall economic growth in recent years, and they present significant market opportunities for insurers. In China, for example, private health insurance premium revenue may more than double between 2015 and 2020, to CNY 5 trillion, according to the consultancy EY; a report published by EY in 2016 noted that the country’s expanding middle class is increasingly demanding high-quality medical services from a strained public health care system. In Mexico, a country of nearly 130 million people, the insurance penetration rate (a measure of the prevalence of insurance in a domestic economy) is only 2.3%, according to a separate report published by EY in 2018; the same report noted that Chile’s penetration rate of 4.2% is the highest in the region. By 2016, emerging markets had already accounted for one fifth of global insurance premiums, according to research published by Swiss Re, compared with just 5% in 2000. In these markets, insurers are addressing a significant need. Only 11% of economic losses stemming from natural catastrophe events in emerging markets were covered by insurance in 2016, according to Swiss Re. The trend of insurers looking increasingly to emerging markets comes as growth opportunities in developed economies become rarer. That will lead to a global balancing for the industry. According to a projection from Munich Re published in 2017, the growth in insurance premiums in emerging markets will almost fully compensate for the relatively more moderate growth being experienced in industrialized countries, and emerging markets’ share of anticipated additional premium volume will jump to 47% by 2025, from 20% in 2016. Emerging markets show particular promise when it comes to so-called microinsurance policies, which are designed for low-income people and can cover everything from illness to agricultural yields. In addition, emerging markets offer opportunities to sell complex corporate risk policies associated with major infrastructure projects. Infrastructure development in emerging markets can also be a good fit for insurers’ investment portfolios. Long term, fixed income instruments tied to such infrastructure projects can match up well with the long-dated liabilities of insurance companies, according to a feature story published by the World Bank in late 2017. However, the story noted, insurance companies still allocate less than 2.5% of their overall assets under management to infrastructure investment, due to an insufficient understanding of related risk.

name: Emerging Ocean Technologies
description: Emerging technologies are changing the way we harvest food, energy, minerals, and data from the ocean. Rapid innovation in marine robotics, artificial intelligence, low-cost sensors, satellite systems, and methods for collecting and analysing data may yet create a cleaner and safer future - though these developments also present potential challenges for ocean health. Ocean mining is one example; portions of the seafloor are rich in gold, platinum, cobalt, and rare-earth elements, though these resources have up until now been out of reach. New, 300-ton mining machines have been developed that can harvest minerals in some of the deepest parts of the sea. Japan has completed its first large-scale mineral extraction from the seabed, and plans to begin commercial mining in its waters within the next decade. Meanwhile on the high seas, the Jamaica-based International Seabed Authority has issued more than 1 million square kilometres of mining exploration claims to 20 different countries. However, much of the seabed within these claims remains unexplored, and new species are frequently being discovered in the vicinity. It remains unclear if and how sediment plumes from seabed mining will affect the health of oceans generally, and fisheries specifically. Finding a way to properly balance mining interests against potential impacts on ocean ecosystems and marine industries remains a challenge. A revolution in our ability to collect and process ocean data has now enabled the detection of illegal fishing from space, empowered sustainability-focused companies to more efficiently connect with people, and helped build intelligent zoning plans that better balance the needs of fishermen, marine transportation, and ocean conservation. In addition, new technologies are being developed to plug into the ocean’s enormous stores of green energy (possibilities include wave energy, tidal energy, thermal energy, and offshore wind). A record 4,331 megawatts of new offshore wind power was installed around the world during 2017, according to the Global Wind Energy Council, which increased the size of the market by 95%. While remaining hurdles to harvesting ocean energy include cost efficiency and the potential impact of new ocean power plants on ocean life, other exciting innovations are on the way: a robot that swims like a tuna, underwater data centres, autonomous self-driving ships, and geodesic spheres that can serve as offshore fish farms, for example. Properly embraced, disruptive technologies can help us take more from the oceans while damaging them less.

name: Emerging Technological Risks
description: Emerging threats like cyber-terrorism and other cybercrime are both complex, and offer limited amounts of related historical data - which can in turn create challenges for insurance companies aiming to accurately price related risk. The World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report published in 2018 listed cyberattacks among the top ten risks in terms of both likelihood and impact; related incidents noted in the report include the WannaCry attack, which affected 300,000 computers in 150 countries in 2017. A number of insurers are writing related policies, and cyber insurance premiums probably totalled between $2.5 billion and $3.5 billion in 2016 - and may reach $14 billion by 2022 - according to Swiss Re’s annual global insurance review and outlook published in 2017. One factor driving the purchase of cyber insurance is the General Data Protection Regulation, which is being implemented in Europe in 2018 and is spurring improvements in cyber risk management more generally, according to Swiss Re, which estimated that as of only a few months prior to the regulation’s enforcement just one in ten firms believed they were fully compliant. One area of the insurance industry particularly exposed to both technological risks and opportunities is the motor insurance market, according to an article published by insurance broking and advisory service Willis Towers Watson in 2017. Over the course of about 15 years, the article noted, roughly 10% of American drivers agreed to provide personal data about their driving (in order to receive a cheaper motor insurance policy) - in turn bolstering the marketing, underwriting and pricing of so-called usage-based insurance, which can tie costs to specific use of a car. According to the article, the downside for insurers in adopting this approach is the need to efficiently sort through the ever-expanding volumes of data that it generates. Health insurance may also potentially undergo significant change as a result of related technology developments; some insurers have developed online communities where customers can access resources, and wearable devices are providing a growing stream of real-time data that can help health insurers personalize offerings. In addition, technology developments have spurred a proliferation of “insuretech” startups - investors put $167 million into the sector during the third quarter of 2016 alone, according to Dow Jones Venturesource.

name: Emerging Technologies
description: Cutting-edge technologies, like observation satellites and artificial intelligence, are enabling the real-time monitoring of global forest change. The increasing availability and resolution of satellite imagery are resulting in more (and more detailed) pictures, while advanced algorithms are able to quickly process these images in order to detect changes with enough accuracy to inform local forest management. Advancements in parallel processing, or the division of computer programming among multiple processors, enable these algorithms to be run increasingly cost-effectively, making the continuous monitoring of changes around the globe possible. Meanwhile breakthroughs in data visualization are enabling decision-makers and other non-scientific users to easily access related information, and to act on it. Increasing internet connectivity, and the proliferation of mobile technology, have also improved the ability to alert law enforcement or local communities about illegal logging or burning taking place in protected forests or moratorium areas. Other technologies are facilitating timber tracking and the tracing of wood products from forest to consumer, while anatomical analyses and other methods are enabling the identification of the species and origin of wood being used in supply chains, in order to bolster accountability. Technological developments are also addressing challenges in terms of interpreting data - for example, when it comes to identifying statistically significant hotspots for forest change, or quickly identifying changes occurring within important forest areas. Artificial intelligence is augmenting the examination of forest change, by helping to better predict where change may occur in the future. A significant amount of innovation is being made possible through open data policies and initiatives related to satellite imagery, such as NASA’s Landsat program, which has been amassing millions of images for research and applications, NASA’s Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) monitoring, used to measure everything from cloud cover to photosynthesis, and the European Space Agency’s Sentinel systems. Radar satellites launched in the recent past can even enable change detection through clouds and smoke, which have presented a significant challenge for tropical forest monitoring in the past. High-resolution satellites developed by private companies including Planet, DigitalGlobe, and others should enable the monitoring of the earth’s surface in incredible detail, and at high frequency, providing daily, high-resolution coverage for the first time. In order to properly analyse the massive volume of resulting data, increasingly sophisticated artificial intelligence will be crucial.

name: Emerging and Frontier Capital Markets
description: Development projects in emerging and frontier markets face unique, fundamental challenges that tend to limit the funding made available by the private sector for necessary financing - such as local currency volatility, frequently soft sovereign credit ratings, a lack of investment guarantees, limited local liquidity, and uneven access to affordable capital. This means that projects that should be more attractive may not be financed, and has contributed to a widely shared shortage of necessary investment. In Nigeria, for example, there is currently a $221 billion gap between what the country should be investing in infrastructure between 2007 and 2040, and what is currently being invested, according to the Global Infrastructure Hub, an organization started by the G20; the gap for Egypt is $230 billion, while for Bangladesh it is $192 billion. Blended Finance, an increasingly popular funding mechanism, can alleviate some of the constraints placed on development projects in developing markets by allocating risk to individual investors based on their respective ability to manage it. This reduces the dependence on sovereign guarantees, which can elevate a country’s debt-to-GDP ratio, and helps provide additional capital and liquidity to local markets. As debt levels and budget deficits have risen in developing economies, the use of Blended Finance to access new capital sources can help alleviate rising borrowing costs, and facilitate investments that demonstrate the viability of developing markets for the private investment community. One particular area that could benefit from Blended Finance is the so-called pay-as-you-go sector, which uses mobile financial technology to help people with cell phones in regions such as sub-Saharan Africa gain access to clean and efficient energy, according to a brief published in 2018 by the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor. More than 160 Blended Finance facilities have been launched since 2000, and about $81 billion was mobilized from the private sector by utilizing Blended Finance between 2012 and 2015, according to the brief.

name: Emissions and Pollution
description: The biggest factor shaping the future of transportation is related to carbon dioxide and nitrogen dioxide emissions, and related impacts on climate change and urban pollution. A typical passenger vehicle emits roughly 4.7 metric tons of carbon dioxide a year, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency, while the World Health Organization estimates that 3 million people are killed annually by outdoor air pollution. Another way to measure of the effects of transportation on the environment is through “bio capacities,” or the ability of a natural area to generate resources while absorbing waste; by 2050, urban mobility systems will use five times more of the planet’s bio capacities than they did in 1990, according to a 2014 report published by the International Association of Public Transport (UITP). A significant amount of emissions related to cars and transport is being generated in emerging markets; about 80% of the projected increase in road transport carbon dioxide emissions between 2015 and 2030 is expected to come from countries that have not gained admittance to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, according to the UITP’s report. Already, nearly one quarter of global carbon dioxide emissions from fuel combustion are generated by transport (as opposed to electricity and heat, or industry), according to a report published by the International Energy Agency in 2017, and three quarters of transport emissions come from the road sector. Reducing emissions of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide from exhausts could help to build a more sustainable model for safe, clean and affordable mobility that can support the needs of a growing population. However, related regulatory systems are highly fragmented, particularly at the level of city government, driving up complexity and related costs.

name: Employment and Employability in Sri Lanka
description: According to the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report 2017-2018, Sri Lanka is relatively weak compared with economies at similar stages of development when it comes to labour market efficiency and technological readiness. The state of Sri Lanka’s labour market is holding back economic growth; inefficiencies are preventing the creation of good jobs, and marginalizing women and young people. Archaic labour laws, social security linked to employment, and resistance from unions have prevented the government from restructuring the market to enable more flexibility in the form of merit-based promotions and raises, and mobility between jobs. The country’s informal, or unregulated, economy remains large; it accounted for about 60% of the total workforce as of 2015, according to the annual Labour Force Survey published by the Department of Census and Statistics. Meanwhile demographic changes are slowing the growth of the labour force, as the population both shrinks in size and ages. Many people are simply leaving the country for foreign employment, creating domestic shortages of both low- and high-skilled workers, and hindering economic expansion. Sri Lanka needs to increase labour force participation and productivity. Participation is traditionally low for women and young people, due in part to discrepancies in terms of access to quality education. Remittances from abroad have also contributed to lower labour force participation, by increasing the lowest wage for which a potential worker is willing to take a job. Limited access to tertiary (university or vocational) education, and poor quality of education, have reduced the employability of workers; many with tertiary-level education are either under-employed or are absent entirely from the labour market. Sri Lanka’s government has recognized the need to improve the quality of education generally, and to expand tertiary education - but reforms in terms of enhancing the stock of available teachers and establishing more private universities in the country are taking shape very slowly. Sri Lanka ranked 78th out of 137 economies in terms of higher education and training in the Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report 2017-2018 - due to particularly pressing issues such as low tertiary education enrolment and a low level of internet access in schools generally.

name: Employment and Wages
description: After 1994, legislation was introduced in South Africa to counteract discrimination in the labour market, and to better protect the rights of workers. This initially focused on securing workers’ constitutional rights to unionize and strike, and on establishing basic standards - for example, collective bargaining and a constitutional right to strike. In 1997, minimum work conditions were established, and after 1999 minimum wages were established in certain sectors (followed later by a national minimum wage). The unemployment rate reached 27.2% as of mid-2018, while the unemployment rate for those between 15- and 24-years-old was 31.6%. Evidence suggests that labour laws in South Africa are not particularly strict in comparison to international laws. Labour market policy debates in the country should therefore be about nuance, rather than substantial change. In addition, non-compliance with existing labour legislation is widespread, as many workers earn sub-minimum wages, and do not receive the benefits to which they are legally entitled; current legislation therefore exists in theory, but not always in practice. Simply applying stricter legislation could have detrimental effects on job creation. An important piece of legislation in this regard is the national minimum wage, passed by parliament in May 2018 and setting a rate of R20 (about $1.40) per hour for all workers, regardless of age - which supersedes existing, sector-based minimum wages. Available research suggests that this will result in at least some job losses in the short term, though any impacts are contingent upon the extent to which the legislation is enforced. However, even in the case of limited enforcement, there are concerns about employment effects in an environment of low growth and high unemployment, particularly for specific groups such as young people. A recent policy intervention that aims to tackle the inordinately high level of youth unemployment in South Africa is the Employment Tax Incentive (ETI), informally known as the youth wage subsidy. It was signed into law in 2013, to offset the costs of hiring young and typically inexperienced workers. The scheme functions as a two-year tax incentive for firms that hire these workers, and when compared with other job-creation programs in the country, it is extremely cost-effective. It is also the only demand-side policy mechanism that aims to absorb excess labour supply. Evidence from the national tax database suggests that the ETI is having positive effects.

name: Empowered Consumers
description: People can now instantly compare prices, review products, and share information on social networks about prospective purchases using their mobile phones. Mobile broadband prices have declined sharply during the past three years, while the number of mobile-broadband subscriptions has increased by more than 20% over the past five years, according to a 2017 report published by the International Telecommunications Union. Companies must now accommodate more digitally literate consumers, while also managing misinformation about their brands that can occasionally spread online. Advances in technology have led to increased scrutiny for the food and beverage industry. Companies are under greater pressure to establish responsible and traceable processes, and to share them openly with the public. Legislation has been crafted to enforce requirements related to consumers’ right to information, including a labelling requirement for genetically-modified ingredients passed in the US in 2016, and a European Union regulation on the provision of food information (including through labelling and advertising) to consumers, which went into effect that same year. In 2018, the European Commission adopted new rules on the labelling of primary ingredients in food, which require that the origin of primary ingredients must be indicated if different from the origin of the food itself, in order to not deceive consumers. The new rules are expected to go into effect in 2020.

name: Encompassing Innovation
description: The Republic of Korea’s (South Korea’s) economic development was historically fuelled by prioritising export-oriented industries like information technology, automobile making and ship building. But due to intensifying competition from emerging economies, Korean products that once dominated the global market have rapidly lost their competitive edge. Under pressure to revitalise and diversify the economy by reducing its current over-reliance on a handful of large conglomerates, the country’s political leaders have sought to foster entrepreneurship and innovation. The country’s leadership has embraced the Fourth Industrial Revolution; President Moon Jae-in established a presidential committee on the Fourth Industrial Revolution in October 2017, and has pursued related educational and labour reforms. President Moon has also singled out the development of “smart cities” as a priority for investment.   According to data from the UNESCO Institute for Statistics, the Republic of Korea’s expenditure on research and development as a percentage of GDP was among the highest in the world as of 2015, at 4.2%, just behind Israel’s 4.3% but well ahead of the 2.8% in the US.

name: Energy Access
description: Ensuring access to energy is a moral imperative. Nearly half of the global population is affected by energy poverty, and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals established in 2015 make energy access a priority. The roughly 1 billion people without access to reliable, modern electricity and the roughly 3 billion people who lack access to clean, safe cooking fuels need more help to escape from poverty. Enabling access to clean energy is also a climate imperative; global emissions must peak before 2030, even as energy access is dramatically accelerated in the developing world. And, clean energy access is an element of energy security - because a lack of access functions like a threat multiplier. In 2017, access to electricity in sub-Saharan Africa expanded faster than population growth for the first time in history; however, a continued lack of access to clean cooking fuels contributed to more than 4 million premature deaths during that same year. Still, overall progress has been made in expanding energy access via sustainable sources - wind and solar accounted for more than half of all capacity additions in emerging markets for the first time ever in 2017, according to BloombergNEF’s report Climatescope 2018. There is a massive urban-rural divide in terms of access to energy for cooking and electricity. Nearly 87% of the people in the world going without electricity live in rural areas, according to a report published by the International Renewable Energy Agency in 2018. Working towards ensuring universal access is an enormous wealth creation opportunity. Mini- and micro-grid companies like Powerhive, Mera Gao, and Husk Power Systems have raised hundreds of millions of dollars in private funding, and companies with business models that rely in part on expanding power access like Facebook and Microsoft are investing in related initiatives. In total, foreign direct investment aimed at supporting clean energy in emerging markets rose to $21.4 billion in 2017, from $13.9 billion the previous year, according to the Climatescope 2018 report. While efforts to expand access have historically been made through extensions of centralized systems, this is changing - as the number of decentralized solar home systems, solar irrigation systems, and microgrids in use expands.

name: Energy Crisis
description: Pakistan’s economy has been hindered by an energy crisis for more than a decade. Power outages have affected manufacturing, in particular, which in turn has led to a loss of potential GDP expansion. However, some improvements have been made; power generation capacity increased to 29,573 megawatts by 2018, up from 22,812 megawatts as of 2013. In addition, energy projects with a cumulative capacity of 17,045 megawatts are in the pipeline, as part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (an element of China’s massive Belt and Road infrastructure initiative). In addition to shortages faced due to generation capacity issues, structural issues have also haunted the power sector. Still, on average, the sector’s rate of recovery of costs through billing improved to 91.2% between 2014 and 2018, from 85.6% between 2009 and 2013. The system’s reliance on expensive fuels has also declined; oil consumption in the power sector declined to 33% in 2018 from 43% in 2014, for example, as oil is replaced by gas, and as the use of renewable energy powering the system has increased to 2% from nearly zero (there has been a similar increase in the use of nuclear energy). While the energy sector is one of the major contributors of greenhouse gas emissions within Pakistan, the country accounts for just about 0.8% of global emissions - and cleaner domestic energy production is being actively encouraged. The State Bank of Pakistan introduced a refinancing scheme for renewable energy in 2016, for example, which seeks to promote the better utilization of alternative energy sources like solar, wind, and biogas. The central bank has also approved funding for 18 renewable energy projects with a cumulative generation capacity of 618 megawatts. Commercial banks have also contributed, through investment in sustainable agriculture and solar power infrastructure. Tax exemptions are also being granted to promote renewable energy consumption. In terms of oil, more foreign direct investment in exploration is necessary; Pakistan can meet only 15% of its oil demand with domestic sources, and importing the rest weighs on the federal budget. If new sources are not discovered, reserves will become stressed. One way for Pakistan to help ensure access to cheaper gas resources in Central Asia would be to actively help restore peace in neighbouring Afghanistan.

name: Energy Directions
description: In 2015, the United Kingdom announced plans to close all of its coal-fired power plants and shift its energy mix to gas, renewables, and nuclear by 2025. However, the UK’s dependence on energy imports has grown over the years, from 20.5% of the total as of 2007, to 37.4% by 2015, according to Eurostat figures - which adds a significant twist to the country’s 2016 Brexit vote, and its related need to now refashion its international trade relationships. The World Energy Council ranked the UK 5th in its 2017 World Energy Trilemma Index, and cited challenges including the possibility that an exit from the EU single market could significantly increase its energy import costs. While the index cited the UK’s increased electricity generation from renewables as a positive, it also noted that the increase has not fully matched the decline in generation from conventional sources. In one potentially encouraging sign for the country’s energy future, the UK managed to go for more than three days without using any coal-fired power in April 2018; that marked a new record, and was the longest such stretch since the 1880s, according to the National Grid. The UK ranked among leading countries in terms of improvements in carbon emissions and general readiness to transition to a more sustainable, reliable, and affordable energy system in the World Economic Forum’s Energy Transition Index published in 2018 (the UK ranked 7th in the index overall). On aggregate, Brexit (which is expected to occur in 2019) should have a limited energy system-related impact on the European Union, according to a 2017 study published by the European Parliament. The study also noted that as a member of the World Trade Organization, the UK should be able to continue to import and export its own energy to and from other WTO members free of tariffs. However, the study also noted a number of potential downsides, including a possible Brexit effect on the energy system in Ireland, which operates a joint electricity market with Northern Ireland - a country that sits within the UK - while buying a significant amount of gas from Britain. A worst-case scenario would have the UK, including Northern Ireland, drop out of the EU’s internal energy market while Ireland remains, according to the study.

name: Energy Efficiency and Mobility
description: Transportation accounts for 23% of global carbon dioxide emissions, a figure that is expected to nearly double by 2050 if policy-makers continue to prioritize speed over accessible, compact and connected development, according to a paper published by the LSE Cities centre at the London School of Economics in 2019. In response, transportation systems are rapidly changing - thanks to the application of energy-efficient technologies to engines and fuels, and the general adoption of more sustainable behaviour and less-energy-intensive modes of transportation (such as ride sharing). Many governments have meanwhile succeeded in shifting spending away from road-building and maintenance to public transportation. In Colombia, for example, Bogota has developed a Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system that has won plaudits, while also paving hundreds of kilometres of new bicycle paths and closing many roads to cars on Sundays. Meanwhile legacy private transportation is frequently being optimized by technology; in 2018, DHL announced it was deploying an Internet of Things-based system in India to optimize trucking routes and potentially cut transit times by 50%. New rules and regulations can help maintain positive momentum, by mandating the further reduction of carbon footprints and limiting more energy use where possible. Mandatory energy efficiency regulation had already been applied to as much as 30% of global consumption by 2015, according to the International Energy Agency’s World Energy Outlook report. Those legal safeguards are necessary, as global energy use is expected to grow by 48% between 2012 and 2040, according to the US Energy Information Administration (one positive aspect of this growth is that the amount of energy spent on the transportation of people and goods is expected to remain constant over the period, accounting for about 19% of total demand). Particularly in non-Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, which are home to 80% of the world’s population and 61% of global transportation consumption, there is tremendous potential to implement smarter and more efficient means of mobility - through emerging technology, new business models, increased consumer literacy, and informed regulation.

name: Energy Finance and Investment
description: Stabilizing global greenhouse gas emissions, meeting future energy demand, and increasing access to reliable electricity will all require substantial additional private investment. The International Energy Agency has estimated that about $53 trillion in energy-related investment will be necessary between 2014 and 2035 in order to achieve the Paris Agreement’s stated target of limiting warming to less than 2°C above pre-industrial temperatures. However, the 2016 agreement only calls for $100 billion in annual investment over its first five years. Electricity markets will require more renewables in order to achieve the Paris Agreement goals, and electricity infrastructure will have to receive substantial related funding. By some estimates, the power system alone will require roughly $55 trillion to hit the 2°C target. With national budgets generally constrained, private investors will have to play a more prominent role. Creating the right investment environment for them - one that takes into account different risk appetites for different classes of investors - will be key. This is especially true for institutional investors like pension funds, which have historically avoided the clean energy sector. Public policy can help create the right market environment, by setting long-term targets and enacting mechanisms to help hit them. For example, California’s historic legislation passed in 2018 calling for 60% of all of the state’s energy to be renewable by 2030, and 100% to be renewable by 2045, creates a stable financial framework for achieving this. The value of similar mechanisms has been proven in many clean energy markets by helping to drive deployment, increase confidence, and decrease both risk and the cost of capital. Increasing digitalization and transparent access to information could have important effects on financing models for future energy systems. As digital technologies capable of monitoring and predicting the performance of energy infrastructure proliferate, the resulting data will become important elements of attracting financing - and parts of an investment portfolio could become more easily segmented according to risk profile. In addition, the small-scale nature of many clean energy resources (like solar in sub-Saharan Africa, for example) means they can be made widely-available via financing done through a mobile phone.

name: Energy Geopolitics
description: Changes in the global balance between supply and demand for oil and gas promise to impact geopolitics - and, in turn, feed back into energy markets. International efforts to adopt policies aimed at mitigating the use of fossil fuels, for example, create geopolitical challenges not only for oil- and gas-rich countries, but also for developing economies where energy demand will continue to grow alongside increasing industrialization. In addition, the ongoing global push for greener energy systems impacts the geopolitical calculations of countries aiming to become significant exporters of things like solar panels, wind turbines, and the lithium and cobalt used to make batteries that power electric cars. This may lead to trade conflicts, the application of tariffs, and more aggressive pushes to exploit raw materials. Another geopolitical fact of life related to oil and gas: as reserves and production grow in North America, so does the ability of the US to check the geopolitical power of countries in other regions that rely on oil and gas exports. The Vienna Alliance (also known as “OPEC+”) between the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and Russia is intended to coordinate production and stabilize the price of oil at a level deemed acceptable by exporting nations; OPEC’s inability to control prices by itself can be attributed to the growing supply of oil from the US. Rapid production growth in the US has also led some to question that country’s future role in the Middle East. A reduced role could open the door for increased engagement by developing countries like China and by large oil and gas exporters such as Russia. In Latin America, meanwhile, lingering political risk has investors keeping a watchful eye on developments in Mexico and Brazil. The collapse of the Venezuelan oil industry will require years of rebuilding to regain the levels of crude production the country’s enormous resources can support. Natural gas also presents new geopolitical challenges and opportunities. Trade in liquefied natural gas is growing, and connecting previously fragmented markets. The globalization of this market has implications for the ability of traditional suppliers to control regional markets - and to benefit from their dominant positions.

name: Energy Independence
description: Many countries are particularly vulnerable to conflict when it comes to their energy needs. Ukraine, for example, is a transit point for Russian natural gas to European nations - though conflict between governments in Kiev and Moscow has disrupted the energy supply in the region, and negatively impacted those countries dependent on imports. Russian President Vladimir Putin announced in December 2014 that his government would halt construction of the South Stream gas pipeline, which would have circumvented Ukraine by bringing Russian gas to Bulgaria under the Black Sea. In response, Bulgaria’s government has since sought to attract investors to build the Belene nuclear power project, which would be the country’s second such power station - highlighting the potentially important role that nuclear energy can play, as nations seek to gain energy independence. Even in the resource-rich Middle East, nuclear can be an attractive option. In March 2018, the United Arab Emirates, which holds 6% of the world’s proven oil reserves, completed the construction of the Arab world’s first nuclear reactor. Constructed with South Korean assistance, the UAE’s reactor illustrates how even energy-exporting nations are demonstrating an eagerness to diversify away from fossil fuels and transition their economies to more sustainable footing. Saudi Arabia, the world’s largest oil exporter, has announced similar plans; it seeks to build at least 16 nuclear power plants, with American support. That comes despite the country’s immense potential to develop solar energy systems. In addition, Saudi Arabia’s longstanding regional rivalry with Iran, and the Trump administration’s withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal (which has limited Iran’s ability to enrich uranium, and enabled closer monitoring of its nuclear capabilities) highlight the potential danger of spreading related technology and know-how across borders. Nuclear technology transfer is often irreversible, and the stability of several of the states now adopting it is far from certain. Motives for acquiring it can also change, according to the geopolitical context. In light of increased geopolitical volatility, more innovative approaches to governing related technology transfer are needed, in order to mitigate risk. While speculation has mounted regarding Saudi Arabia’s intention to develop nuclear weapons, according to a report published by the Carnegie Middle East Center in March 2018, the country is unlikely to do so as the potential consequences (including potentially damaging its relationship with the US) would outweigh any benefit.

name: Energy Reform in Mexico
description: Mexico’s oil production has declined sharply in recent years; as of early 2019, production was expected to fall to an average of 1.78 million barrels per day that year, from 3.26 million barrels per day in 2006. Greater investment is required in order to boost production and modernize the state oil company, Petróleos Mexicanos (Pemex). As of 2017, Pemex was still providing 16.7% of the country’s federal budget, though that was a sharp decline from 37% in 2005, according to the National Institute of Statistics and Geography. Also by 2017, private firms were participating in Mexican oil and gas production, and government reforms were focused on renewable energy as a means to increase access to electricity. A 2018 Climatescope study ranked Mexico 8th in the world in terms of clean energy investment opportunities, and within Latin America it ranked 3rd (behind Chile and Brazil). According to a World Energy Council report published in 2016, Mexico had the world’s fourth-largest capacity for geothermal electricity production, and according to a World Economic Forum report published in 2017 it has generally improved its development of sustainable, accessible, and secure energy systems - due in part to the phasing out of fuel subsidies. Mexico’s government energy reforms present an opportunity to boost investment in hydrocarbon production and electricity generation capacity, and to reduce costs in order to improve competitiveness. However, the reform effort has been undermined by excessive bureaucracy, a lack of a healthy corporate culture in the energy sector, and political obstacles. The government’s introduction of a steep, 20% hike in gas prices in January 2017 was an effort to deal with a dramatic imbalance between its tax revenue and its debt obligations - which in turn had been a result of economic shocks including a severely weakened peso, declining domestic oil production, and a rise in energy imports. The gas price increase (and the government’s broader move towards full energy price liberalization) was met with public outrage and violent protests. This unrest was a reflection of the government’s inability to publicly articulate the need for reforms likely to cause discomfort. While the sort of energy subsidies that kept gas prices low for Mexicans can provide short-term economic benefits by improving energy access, numerous studies suggest that they actually have significant downsides - because they serve as a regressive tax on the poor, while disproportionately benefiting higher-income groups.

name: Energy System Governance
description: The global energy system is still governed by institutions like the International Energy Agency, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), and the Energy Charter Treaty, which were created after the oil crises of the 1970s. But the energy world looks very different now. New issues include an intensifying race to further exploit Arctic resources, turbulence in oil markets, an uncertain future for natural gas, the transition to low-carbon energy, and renewed concern about nuclear safety. Too much discussion about international energy is being dominated by the concerns of developed countries, and not enough is about the opportunities for (and threats to) emerging economies - which will have the most influence on driving demand, innovation, and patterns of energy trade and investment in the future. In addition, international energy matters are often being viewed through a country-specific lens that frames energy security as a zero-sum game - which in turn results in the inefficient use of resources, and in missed opportunities to cooperate on energy-related research & development, investment, and commercialization. Many threats to the global energy system have emerged, including climate-related risks for energy infrastructure due to coastal flooding, cyberattacks on increasingly integrated electricity grids, a risk of financial collapse for energy firms, and a risk of restricted access to minerals like cobalt that are essential for new energy technologies. A number of energy-related threats to health, productivity, and equality result from the lack of access to electricity that still plagues roughly 1 billion people, and from the lack of clean cooking fuel affecting another 3 billion; however, this is often overlooked by global governance systems. The changing geopolitics of energy has also re-shaped related risk. The re-emergence of the US as a major oil producer has tilted the balance between OPEC and oil-consuming countries, the emergence of shale oil and gas has created a new dynamic that will shape energy markets for the foreseeable future, and the growing popularity of wind and solar technologies has made China the primary manufacturing centre for renewables (China is also making significant investments in technologies such as storage and power-sector automation). As more economies electrify and become reliant on local, low-carbon energy sources like wind, solar, geothermal, and nuclear power, it will further alter governance and geopolitical systems that were originally designed for fossil-fuel-based energy markets.

name: Energy Technology and Innovation
description: If global warming continues at its current pace, a 1.5°C temperature rise above pre-industrial levels could occur as soon as 2030 - triggering catastrophic drought, floods and poverty, according to a 2018 Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report. Renewable energy technologies are desperately needed to help address this situation. While the cost of solar energy decreased to $0.37 per watt by 2017, from $79 per watt in 1976, turbine costs have fallen by more than 30% since 2010, and battery costs fell by more than 70% between 2010 and 2016 - all enabled by technological advancements. This has created opportunities in regions without centralized electricity systems; lithium-ion batteries have been deployed to help meet peak demand in places like Australia, for example, providing alternatives to gas “peaker” plants. And while some countries are now revisiting the use of coal, more are discussing phasing coal out completely. Bloomberg NEF has estimated that coal will shrink to 11% of global electricity generation by 2050, from 38% currently. Many countries have also set targets for phasing out fossil-fuel-powered cars. By 2018, about half of the cars being sold in Norway were electric. However, only a small percentage of traditional energy providers’ revenue is now being invested in low-carbon energy alternatives. And there are other potential drawbacks; conventional lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars, for example, contain cobalt - the mining of which has been marred by the use of child labour, and by health and safety hazards. This has prompted interest in finding alternative technologies to reduce or even replace the cobalt used in batteries. Multi-stakeholder initiatives like the World Economic Forum’s Global Battery Alliance provide platforms to address such challenges. While some progress has been made, the adoption of technologies that can help replace fossil fuels must become more widespread. This calls for greater support for research and development in both academia and the private sector. A new workforce has to be trained for the clean energy transition, and augmented by resources like artificial intelligence as it pushes forward on scientific discovery.

name: Energy Transition
description: The German “Energiewende,” or the country’s policy of transitioning to more renewable energy sources, has raised concerns about related costs for households and industry. The security of the energy supply must be maintained at a high level, as more energy production relies upon renewable sources; the Energiewende program aims for 80% of electricity produced by 2050 to be derived from renewable sources. According to the Fraunhofer Institute for Solar Energy Systems, about 38% of the German energy supply came from renewable sources as of 2017. The portion of nuclear power in Germany’s energy mix declined to 14.1% in 2015, from 28% as of 2003, according to the Energy Transition project run by the Heinrich Böll Foundation. According to the same source, Germany was a net exporter of electricity in 2015, with export amounts similar to those of France. A 2016 report on the quality of the energy and gas supply published by the Council of European Energy Regulators noted that Germany enjoys reliable security of its energy supply, with low levels of unplanned interruptions - only about 25 minutes were lost during all of 2014. This comes at a high cost for customers, as there are a growing number of charges and taxes added to energy bills. One reason for this is related to infrastructure. While energy was traditionally produced close to consumption areas, most of Germany's new renewable power (particularly wind power) is generated in less densely populated, and remote coastal areas and in the east of the country; this energy surplus must then be transported to industrial areas in the southwest. Planning and permitting procedures for a new power line can easily take eight to ten years, or more, in Germany. The growing prominence of renewable energy in the market can lead to a mismatch between the physical needs of the system and the profitability of power plants. It is questionable whether the current system allows for sufficient incentives for investment in production capacities that are flexible enough to balance the fluctuations of renewable energy. In addition, the more renewable energy produced at almost zero cost, the less profitable the production of gas power plants becomes.

name: Energy and Water
description: Traditional energy production based on fossil fuels and nuclear power requires large volumes of water. On the other hand, the heating, transport, purification, and use of water consume vast amounts of energy. Policies that successfully account for both energy and water use can therefore potentially produce multiple benefits. An urban water conservation mandate implemented during a period of drought in California, for example, which mandated a 25% reduction in water use, resulted in electricity savings that were 11% greater than what was achieved by dedicated electric utility efficiency programs during the same period - while resulting greenhouse gas emission reductions that were equivalent to removing 111,000 cars from the road for a full year. The fossil fuel economy is particularly water-intensive and polluting. The waste products generated by burning coal send toxic heavy metals into groundwater and rivers. Recently, water demand for fracking in the US has soared, increasing by as much as 770% per well between 2011 and 2016 in the Permian Basin; that level of demand can severely limit local freshwater availability. Thermal power plants account for more water withdrawals (used for cooling) than any other sector in the US, though much of that water is eventually returned - at a warmer temperature - to rivers and lakes. These energy systems rely on consistency in terms of river flow and temperature, and severe drought in France and in the southern US have resulted in power plant deratings or shutdowns as water temperatures have become too high. Some alternative energy options also have drawbacks; ethanol-based biofuels require land and water to grow corn, switchgrass, and other feedstocks, for example. The reservoirs associated with hydropower dams in arid regions are losing substantial amounts of water to evaporation, while dams in tropical regions are generating methane emissions. In terms of water treatment and purification energy use, Saudi Arabia, by some estimates, dedicates 10% of domestic oil consumption to desalinating water - while in Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, desalination accounts for roughly 30% of electricity use. By way of contrast, wind turbines and solar panels require little to no water to produce electricity. Energy choices and solutions can have serious consequences for water availability - and need to be tailored to specific challenges that vary by region. Even those policies designed to mitigate climate change can potentially exacerbate water scarcity.

name: Energy, Water and the Environment
description: Chile’s economic development over the past two decades has relied heavily on the country’s raw materials and natural resources. Chile is the world’s top producer and exporter of copper, while agriculture, forestry and fisheries are also important contributors. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) 2016 Environmental Performance Review, Chile’s economic structure and resource-intensive growth has exacerbated environmental issues like air pollution, water shortages, habitat loss and water contamination. The report also highlighted Chile’s vulnerability to impacts of climate change such as declining water availability, extreme weather events, worsening water quality and extreme heat. Government efforts to address these issues include the creation of a national system to monitor greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, regional adaptation plans, and measures to achieve the country’s 2015 Paris Agreement commitments (including a 30% reduction of GHG emissions by 2030). In addition, a long-term strategy (through 2050) for water resource security is being developed. Between 1990 and 2010, GHG emissions in Chile increased by 83.5%, according to government data. 34% of energy-related emissions were tied to electricity generation, 30.5% to transportation, and 18.1% to manufacturing and construction. The development of Chile’s power supply has been instrumental in enabling the country’s extraordinary economic growth. However, its energy mix poses environmental challenges, and is conducive to high electricity prices that impact national productivity - something that both past and present governments have acknowledged. In 2015, Chile’s National Energy Commission estimated that electricity demand would increase by 3.72% annually until 2030, pointing to a need to expand short-term and medium-term energy generation projects. Chile not only needs more energy, that energy needs it to be cheaper, cleaner and more efficient. Government efforts have been made to promote renewable energy sources like wind, solar, and biomass, which now represent 15% of the country’s energy mix; that is projected to reach 70% by 2050. The Ministry of Energy is carrying out power auctions that allow all types of renewable energy firms to bid for specific hourly blocks of providing electricity to the country - a structure that helps providers of renewable sources compete. The country also recently passed a so-called carbon tax. According to the European Solar Thermal Electricity Association, in 2016 solar power was sold in Chile at the lowest price ever recorded at that time: $29 per megawatt-hour. However, fossil fuels and hydropower will also continue to be important components of the country’s energy mix, which calls for high efficiency and environmental standards for these sources. Chile’s water resource availability varies greatly between the north of the country, which has less than 1,000 millimetres of rainfall per person a year, and the south, which enjoys more than 10,000 millimetres per person a year. Underground water availability is ample, but less accurately measured, and prices for water rights vary greatly among regions. Agriculture accounts for 81% of the water use in the country, and the remainder is distributed about evenly among domestic, industrial and mining uses. Chile is among the top 30 countries in the world that face water security risks tied to climate change, based on a 2015 technical note from the World Resources Institute. Already, extreme weather events that produce flooding in cities and affect public services have increased greatly in the country during the past decade. Design policies are being studied that could help adapt to this risk, such as building additional desalination plants and water reuse facilities.

name: Energy-Related Emission Reduction
description: The energy consumption required to support human activity is responsible for about three quarters of the world’s greenhouse emissions, which are in turn causing climate change. Energy demand grows alongside population growth, and alongside increasing standards of living; improvements in energy efficiency meanwhile act as a counterbalance. The portion of global energy demand served by electricity is already substantial, and expanding further. There is therefore a clear need to decarbonize the electric power sector itself, in order to help guarantee the sustainability of human development. How and when this is achieved will have important implications for the broader process of decarbonizing the global economy. There are good reasons to prioritize the decarbonization of electricity over other energy carriers, such as hydrogen; electricity can be more easily decarbonized, for example, and it can be produced in many different ways with low associated emissions of greenhouse gases. It is technically viable, and economically affordable, to produce electricity from renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, geothermal, hydro, and biomass. Nuclear generation of electricity is another proven and powerful alternative - though it is often associated with problems like nuclear proliferation, nuclear waste, and accidents. Electricity is wonderfully versatile, and can replace the utilization of fossil fuels in numerous areas. Mobility is one promising example - in the form of electric vehicles including light road vehicles, and railways. Cooling or heating buildings, with the use of heat pumps, is another. Other trends, such as decentralization and digitalization, may have a significant influence on decarbonization. Disruptive advances in storage technologies such as batteries may be a key factor in full electricity decarbonization, for example, as they can mitigate the intermittency effects of some renewable energy production resources. However, the extent to which storage technologies will be required in decarbonized power systems is an area of active research. The decarbonization of economies is a global endeavour. Countries must collaborate, particularly the three that make the largest collective contribution to greenhouse gas emissions: the US, China, and India. Far-sighted policy measures, developed with adequate regulatory approaches, will be essential to guide market forces and private investment towards decarbonization, while innovative business models can contribute to this transformation process.

name: Enhanced Bodies
description: Ageing, accidents, and illness might diminish physical capability, but emerging technologies are improving restorative and therapeutic interventions. For example, exoskeletal suits have been developed that enable paralysed patients to be mobile again; companies including US-based SuitX are now offering robotic exoskeletons which can enable people with spinal cord injuries to move around and enjoy an improved quality of life, but which also cost tens of thousands of dollars. However, as the technology powering solutions such as bionic legs that can be used following amputation to enable greater physical ability improves, that could have dramatic implications - not least, by raising the possibility of self-induced disability for the purposes of enhancement (in the form of higher endurance, or faster speed). Certain prosthetics have already raised related issues. Blade prostheses, such as those used by South African sprinter Oscar Pistorius, are believed to potentially provide competitive benefits as they weigh less than legs and feet, making them theoretically easier to move faster with less effort, according to an article published in Scientific American in 2016 (that belief resulted in the disqualification of Olympic hopeful Markus Rehm, according to the article). As we start to push the boundaries of our natural evolution with such technological add-ons, the monitoring of potential long-term consequences will be crucial. As fully-functioning humans seek to bolster their performance, more products will be made available to them that fall outside of the restorative, medical regime. Exoskeletal suits that enable people to do things like lift extremely heavy objects are already being provided by employers in Japan to increase worker productivity. This raises the possibility of further efforts to increase performance on the job via technologies like novel joint and muscle implants - and the possibility that increasing numbers of people will start to feel it is necessary to undergo such interventions, in order to compete on the job market. Other potential cybernetic enhancements include sensory and wireless activation implants, like RFID tags, which can be implanted in the body and used to open a locked car door - and which have triggered related safety and security concerns about making things like this available to the broader public. If we are to foster the further development of tools that are both restorative and performance enhancing, we need to be mindful of the potential social implications.

name: Enhanced Genes
description: Medical researchers are seeking to eradicate disease in increasingly sophisticated ways, including through human genome editing. Genetic modifications that can potentially be made in order to address neurological and metabolic diseases, and to affect ageing, are of particular interest. However, this raises serious questions about how much we should be interfering with natural human development. For example, scientists are currently developing genetic regenerative medicine that targets age-related muscle loss, also known as sarcopenia - yet, it is not exactly clear whether we should even view sarcopenia as a disease that needs to be treated, or simply as a normal side effect of ageing that we should accept. In addition, while gene therapy used to treat an individual by targeting bone marrow or blood cells cannot then affect that individual’s children, so-called “germline” gene therapy, which involves targeting egg and sperm cells and enables an inserted gene to be passed on to future generations, has proven to be controversial, according to a guide published by the US National Library of Medicine in 2018. In addition to preventive and therapeutic enhancements, non-therapeutic genetic enhancements are also becoming available. As a result, we may become able to select things like eye colour for our babies yet to be born, or our future children’s height or muscle strength. Related ethical questions about selection and discrimination should be considered. In 2017, in the journal Nature, scientists published the results of a procedure where they had successfully used gene editing to rid embryos of a mutation linked to heart disease; that raised questions about the potential impact if, for example, instead of simply eliminating a heritable disease, prospective parents wanted to eliminate undesirable traits like being short, or having an introverted personality. Genome editing for enhancement could potentially worsen social inequality, and create social pressure to make use of related technologies - which in turn could hinder individual freedom and autonomy. Related questions to consider include what alterations that enhance well-being should be made widely available, and whether or not these alterations should not only be applied to individuals, but also to their offspring.

name: Enhanced Longevity
description: The fear of death, and the dream of eternal youth, are both constant. Alongside the increased prevalence of biotechnology and an improved understanding of ageing, new methods are being developed to decelerate the decline of biological processes - resulting in prolonged lives. According to an article published in the medical journal The Lancet in 2017, there is a high probability that life expectancy will continue to increase in all industrialized countries, and a more than 50% chance that by 2030, national female life expectancy in South Korea will surpass 90 years - a level deemed unattainable by some as recently as the turn of the 21st century. However, with a greater possibility for human enhancement, there is also a greater risk of prolonged living with a lower quality of life - and relatively low functional capability. In addition, while only some individuals will truly benefit from longer lifespans, the increased resulting burden on health care systems will be borne by all. In the case of “boundless” life expectancy, where potential medical inventions could conceivably extend our lifespans to around 150 years, the question of how to earn enough money to live off of in old age suddenly becomes very different, as noted in an article published by the Brookings Institution in 2016. Developers of emerging technologies and regulators must explore how people can live well, both physically and mentally, as the enhancement options available to them proliferate - and also how these options can potentially strengthen social connections and general well-being. In addition, better social integration of the growing elderly demographic must be better facilitated, and technologies should be deployed to help the elderly stay connected and as autonomous as possible. Smart homes with sensors that can trigger alerts when medical issues arise are important in this respect, though the importance of human interaction should not be de-emphasized. However, as medical and technology advances are extending longevity for large numbers of people, there is a worsening shortage home health care workers needed to look after them. In the US, for example, the available jobs in the field of direct care workers (including home health aides) is projected to increase by 48% between 2010 and 2020, while the availability of people to fill those jobs is projected to decline, according to a discussion paper published by the National Academy of Medicine in 2016.

name: Enhanced Minds
description: Thanks to scientific and technological progress, it is now possible to enhance human cognitive functions over the course of a lifespan. The brain is the most complex part of the body, and our computational core for processing and interpreting sensory input; while cognitive skills like memory generally start to decline during our 20s, the pace varies from person to person.
