Advances in understanding the functioning of the brain are enabling novel behavioural, pharmacological, and neuro-technological interventions designed to help preserve cognition. In 2018, scientists from the University of Southern California and Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center published a study in the Journal of Neural Engineering demonstrating the success of implants that sharply improved short-term memory performance. The technology made use of a patient’s existing brain cell code, or pattern for memory, in order to artificially bolster so-called episodic memory, which is useful for recalling practical details such as where you have parked your car. The scientists behind the study noted at the time of publication that they aimed to eventually help people hold on to specific memories such as their home address, even as their overall memory begins to fail. Companies around the world are researching other new ways not only to preserve, but to improve cognition, and to potentially enable us to perform at higher levels for longer periods. Non-invasive brain stimulation, or neural implants, could ultimately help us become more attentive, improve our decision making, and help us think faster; basically, make us smarter. Kernel, a company founded with a $100 million investment in 2016, is attempting to develop ways to augment the human brain by applying the principles of computing; it says it ultimately aims to use technology to interpret the brain’s workings, and create applications for cognitive enhancement. However, there are several related questions that must be addressed - regarding where the limits of such enhancement should be, to what extent cognitive enhancement can be both personally desirable and socially acceptable, and to what extent a decision that is made with the aid of a device should be considered to have been manipulated. In addition, we need to consider to what extent such advances will influence behaviour, alter social cohesion, and create a need to prevent related abuse.

name: Ensuring a Sustainable UAE
description: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has the world’s seventh-largest proven crude oil reserves, oil remains the biggest component of its energy mix, and the sale of oil accounted for a critical portion of government revenue in 2017. However, strategic efforts to diversify the country’s economy are showing results; it ranked in the top quartile globally in terms of innovation capability in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index, for example (35th overall, out of 140 economies). Besides being a regional technology and innovation hub, the UAE is emerging as a leader in the Arab world in terms of sustainability. The economic boom that the UAE has experienced over a relatively short, recent period of time has had a significant impact on its natural resources, leading to land degradation, desertification, soil deterioration, and water scarcity issues. The country implemented its first environmental protection legislation in 1999, and it has actively sought to address its environmental challenges, which are likely to be further exacerbated by the impacts of climate change. Recent efforts include the UAE Green Agenda 2030, and the National Climate Change Plan 2017-2050.  The UAE has sought to channel its booming economy into “green growth,” as part of the country’s Vision 2021 National Agenda. Among the most ambitious related initiatives, the government’s Energy Strategy 2050 aims to reduce the national carbon footprint by 70%, and increase the contribution of clean energy to 50% of the total energy mix, by the middle of this century. Already, Abu Dhabi’s Estidama (“sustainability” in Arabic) program involves rating the environmental impact of new buildings, while Dubai’s Green Building Regulation is designed to improve efficiency in the energy consumption of new buildings. In addition, major projects for developing renewable energy capabilities include Abu Dhabi’s Sir Bani Yas wind farm, home to the world’s largest wind turbines, and Dubai’s Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park, which is the world’s biggest. Waste production, in particular, remains a significant challenge for the UAE; the rate of production is three times higher here than the global average. In late 2018, the UAE’s Minister of Climate Change and Environment joined the World Economic Forum’s Platform for Accelerating the Circular Economy, which could support existing UAE efforts to improve efficiency in waste processing.

name: Entrepreneurial Leadership
description: Successful startups and innovative corporations have demonstrated how to transcend existing leadership methods in a way that creates new ways of functioning as an organization. Startups, for example, often go through multiple iterations of ideation (the process of generating ideas) as they approach a problem, followed by relentless prototyping. The vast majority of these prototypes fail. However, the relatively limited amount of time and resources spent on developing them (including the handful that actually succeed) makes the process not only sustainable, but often highly effective. This ability to move quickly from design to implementation is characteristic of entrepreneurial leadership - which emphasizes mobilizing external resources, pushing through previously-assumed boundaries, and building new business models in the process. These new models, whether they involve crunching big data to pursue criminal probes, or distributing electric scooters throughout a city centre, are a defining feature of the Fourth Industrial Revolution; they have captured public attention through the ways that they disrupt, and the ways that they transmit the influence and impact of individual entrepreneurs. Creating and running an innovative business in the mold of Amazon or Uber requires a greater effort to understand how technology can impact traditional civic and business structures. One particularly appropriate flavour of leadership was described more than half a century ago by anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss in his famous 1962 essay The Savage Mind, as “mythical thought.” Mythical thought, Lévi-Strauss wrote, expresses itself by means of a reliable but limited repertoire of skills and abilities - the person in possession of this repertoire must use it for the task at hand, as nothing else is available. Kevin Systrom, the co-founder of Instagram, illustrates the concept of mythical thought well. Systrom had studied management science and engineering at Stanford University, but was a self-taught programmer when he built Burbn, the product that led to the development of Instagram in 2010. Systrom was savvy enough to be able to use these limited skills (in combination with others) to build something that almost instantly drew millions of users, and was acquired by Facebook for $1 billion in 2012.

name: Entrepreneurship and Innovation in Argentina
description: A number of Latin America’s most successful technology companies have come from Argentina, including the Nasdaq-listed online retailer MercadoLibre and Buenos Aires-based digital marketing software-developer Globant. Some of the active players in Argentina’s startup scene include the venture capital firm KaSZek Ventures, which is focused on Latin America, and Endeavor, an international non-profit organization supporting entrepreneurs. However, the number of new companies being created annually in Argentina has actually declined since 2007, according to a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank. This is generally the result of a lack of access to financing, and of a lack of legal predictability. There are also challenges related to finding workers with the necessary skills. The World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report 2018 ranked Argentina 54th out of 140 countries in terms of innovation capability, and 51st in terms of the skills of its workforce. However, it also ranked 95th in terms of the protection of intellectual property, and 78th in terms of the digital skills of its population. Low levels of private investment into innovation and technical training are factors behind Argentina’s relatively poor “total factor productivity,” a measure of available technology and know-how in a country that can make production more efficient. A shortage of early-stage venture capital funding and regulatory and tax burdens also present major challenges for entrepreneurs. Argentina ranked 128th out of 190 countries in terms of the ease of starting a business in the World Bank report Doing Business 2019. The report noted that the country had made the process easier by introducing an expedited process for limited liability companies - part of a broader government effort to simplify bureaucracy and reduce the number of administrative processes necessary in order to be able to operate locally. Government reform efforts have also included measures intended to simplify legal procedures, speed up public procurement, and increase the focus on digitalization. Buenos Aires is particularly well positioned to become a hub for technology and innovation; the local government there has pioneered effective policies to support entrepreneurs such as co-investment schemes for startups, and incubator programs.

name: Entrepreneurship for Growth
description: Entrepreneurship is the essential fuel for job creation efforts in the Middle East and North Africa region, which has a relatively small, but vibrant startup scene. Notable outcomes for local startups include the sale of Souq, a Dubai-based online retailer, to Amazon for $580 million in early 2017. The region has now witnessed dozens of major “exit events” (a way of describing a sale of, or a public listing of, a young company) for local entrepreneurs since 2000 - that includes Rocket Internet’s acquisition of Kuwait-based food delivery service Talabat for about $170 million in 2015, and Delivery Hero’s purchase of Kuwaiti rival Carriage in 2017 for a reported $100 million. More recently, Samsung Electronics acquired Egyptian artificial intelligence startup Kngine for an undisclosed sum in early 2018. These experiences have helped the local venture capital and angel investment scene to further evolve. The number of startup investors in the Middle East and North Africa region increased by 30% between 2015 and 2017, according to a report published by McKinsey & Company in 2018, while total funding in the region more than doubled during the same period. Across the Middle East, the digital economy’s contribution to GDP remains low compared with other regions of the world, according to McKinsey’s 2018 report; the digital contribution in individual countries ranged from 0.4% in Qatar, to 3.8% in Saudi Arabia, 4.3% in the UAE, and as high as 8% in Bahrain (a figure that was driven by digital exports). Overall, the Middle East’s digital contribution to GDP was 4.1%, according to the report, compared with 6.2% in Europe and 8% in the US. Regional startup hubs such as Amman, Beirut, Cairo, and Dubai are now awash with a diverse array of international and local investors, including 500 Startups, BECO Capital, and Wamda Capital, as well as institutional backers like the European Investment Bank and the International Finance Corporation - which make funds available specifically for entrepreneurs. In addition, corporations, particularly in industries like telecom, have also set up venture capital arms (Zain and Saudi Telecom Company, or STC, have been particularly active). According to the McKinsey report, 14 new, significant corporate venture capital funds appeared in the MENA region between 2015 and 2016.

name: Environmental Biotechnology
description: Metabolic and bioprocess engineering can be used to treat waste water and tackle serious environmental problems - including plastic pollution. The production and incineration of plastic will add more than 850 million metric tons of greenhouse gases to the atmosphere during 2019, equivalent to the pollution caused by 189 coal-fired power plants, according to a report published by the Center for International and Environmental Law. Plastics like polyethylene terephthalate (PET) pervade our daily lives because they are cheap to manufacture and highly durable. This durability causes serious damage; as much as 8.8 million metric tons of plastic waste is estimated to enter the ocean every year, where it will remain indefinitely. Microorganisms, which have mostly been used for the production of chemicals and materials, can also be applied to the biodegradation of plastics in a way that enables a highly-sustainable recycling system. In 2016, a Japanese research team from the Kyoto Institute of Technology and Keio University published a report in the journal Science about a bacterium called Ideonella sakaiensis, which contains an enzyme, PETase, that was found to be able to degrade PET. A Korean research team from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science & Technology (KAIST) and Kyungpook National University further delved into this PET-degrading enzyme and determined its 3D crystal structure, while predicting a molecular mechanism of the PET degradation. They published their research in the journal Nature Communications in 2018 - and the approaches behind it can now be applied to the study of enzymes that could degrade other types of plastics. Recent research on the biodegradation of plastics has created potential for synergy with the sort of microbial production of biodegradable polymers that have long been studied by microbial engineers. Microorganisms can now be engineered to produce polyhydroxyalkanoates (polyesters that can store carbon), polylactic acid (a biodegradable polyester), and, as of recently, aromatic polyesters that use renewable biomass feedstock as raw material. One lingering challenge has been to find a way to improve microbial production performance at an economically viable scale - which will need to be overcome in order to significantly mitigate plastic pollution and establish sustainable plastic recycling.

name: Environmental Dangers
description: The decline and fall of some of the world’s most sophisticated civilizations has been linked to environmental factors, from Mayans succumbing to deforestation and drought to disruptions to Roman food supply networks. In 2018, the World Meteorological Organization reported that the previous five years had been the hottest on record, and a spate of forest fires that devastated parts of California, Greece, Siberia, and even the Arctic in the summer of 2018 were linked to human-induced climate change. The intersection of environmental pressures with an issue like migration can illustrate just how vulnerable modern, globally integrated societies can be to a shock to one of their component parts. Humanity’s ecological impact on the world is increasingly visible and increasingly deadly; while ancient civilizations were largely the victims of environmental forces over which they had no influence, and had few tools to soften their economic and social impact, contemporary societies are both the primary cause of the environmental threats to life on earth and have the scientific and technical know-how required in order to understand and mitigate them. Yet, the global cooperation required to develop necessary solutions remains elusive. From food security to climate change, the spiralling environmental pressures that the world will increasingly face are not being met by system-level policy responses. On the contrary, the world appears more politically fragmented than ever. These trends - the worsening of environmental threats and an increasingly fragmented international community - are causing fragility on a grand scale. The unpredictable and profound nature of environmental pressures will only magnify many existing vulnerabilities. In 2018, changing rainfall patterns sparked an international dispute over the Tigris and Euphrates rivers and forced Iraqi farmers to abandon their land, while in the future, a loss of land mass to rising sea levels may displace millions of people, and the loss of biodiversity could cripple economies and lead to political collapse in fragile states. Hardening geopolitical divisions are both fuelling these systemic risks and preventing work that could be done towards devising collective solutions. In a world of divergent values and visions, the way we manage growing environmental pressures will increasingly depend on our ability to find new and effective forms of cooperation.

name: Environmental Footprint
description: Increased demand for food, due to a rapidly growing global population, will only worsen the negative environmental impact of food systems. Water availability, climate volatility, and deforestation are among the most pressing related issues. While the global population increased by 340% between the years 1900 and 2010, global water withdrawal grew by 630% over the same period, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. In 2018, the Water Resources Group estimated that, under a business-as-usual scenario, global water requirements would increase by 2030 to a level that is 40% above current accessible, reliable supply. Optimizing the efficiency of water use in production and distribution is critical. Climate change will increasingly affect food systems; rising temperatures and shifting rainfall patterns will put crop production at risk, leading to yield losses and higher food prices. A 2013 World Bank report, Turn Down the Heat, argued that 2°C of global warming above preindustrial levels could reduce total crop production by 10% (current temperatures are about 1°C above preindustrial levels), though some crops will be more affected than others - just 1.5°C of warming by the 2030s could result in a 40% loss of areas for growing maize in sub-Saharan Africa, for example. Climate change-related extreme weather events like drought, flooding, and heat waves increase agricultural price volatility, trigger food crises, and disrupt global supply chains. The implications of this are more severe for less-resilient countries; drought in the Horn of Africa in 2011 exposed 13.3 million people in the region to extreme food insecurity, for example, resulting in high levels of malnutrition and a high risk of infectious disease. Agriculture can also be a major driver of land degradation, deforestation, and greenhouse gas emissions. According to a 2016 World Resources Institute working paper, the production of animal-based foods (such as dairy products and meat) was responsible for about two-thirds of production-related greenhouse gas emissions in 2009 (a 2014 study found that halving meat and dairy consumption in Europe could reduce emissions from agriculture by as much as 40%). Meanwhile an estimated one third of all arable land is degraded, due to the overuse of agrochemicals, soil mismanagement, and poor farming techniques, while deforestation has emerged as an issue of growing importance. Industrial agriculture accounted for 80% of the deforestation in tropical and subtropical countries between 2000 and 2010, according to Yale University’s Global Forest Atlas.

name: Environmental Health and Climate Change
description: Nearly one quarter of all global deaths are a result of the environment, according to the World Health Organization’s (WHO) 2016 report Preventing Disease Through Healthy Environments: A Global Assessment of the Burden of Disease from Environmental Risks. One of the greatest environmental threats to human health is air pollution. Many low- and middle-income countries do not monitor air quality, and either lack effective emission control legislation or simply fail to enforce legislation. As a result, their populations face a disproportionate disease burden. In addition to outdoor exposure to air pollution, WHO estimated in 2016 that almost 3 billion people around the world were still burning biomass fuel and coal indoors, in order to cook or to heat their homes, which resulted in more than 4 million deaths annually. In 2018, WHO estimated that more than 80% of people living in urban areas (that monitor air pollution) are exposed to air quality levels that exceed the organization’s limits - and that 97% of cities in low- and middle-income countries with more than 100,000 inhabitants do not meet WHO air quality guidelines (the figure falls to 49% for high-income countries).  Air pollution is also a primary contributor to climate change, which has generated global health risks including changes in vector-borne disease patterns, water scarcity, food insecurity, and violence. These threats are most severe for vulnerable populations like children, the elderly, and the poor. Additional measures are needed in order to reduce exposure to air pollution and mitigate the effects of climate change, and decrease disease rates and mortality. United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, and the Paris Agreement on climate change, have recognized this need and provide goals and targets in order to prioritize action (though one of the world’s biggest sources of carbon emissions and pollution, the US, has announced plans to withdraw from the Paris Agreement). New and expanding research disciplines, including Planetary Health (which takes into consideration all the natural systems that human health depends upon) and the collaborative approach known as One Health, have drawn increased focus to the complex, interconnected relationships between the earth’s natural systems and species. These approaches recognize that the health of humans, animals, and the environment are closely interrelated, and promise to broadly advance our understanding of environmental impacts.

name: Environmental Preservation
description: Drones provide a new tool to help better understand and address the existential threats posed by changes to our environment, whether it’s the mass extinction of large mammals, the acidification of bodies of water, or deforestation. Unmanned aircraft systems are already being employed to monitor sea ice flows in the Arctic, migration patterns of whales and illegal fishing vessels that endanger species in the Atlantic Ocean. However, the same regulatory and social issues that could hinder broad deployment of drones may also impact our ability to use them for environmental protection. Drones can enable high resolution, remote monitoring and data collection across regions and climates at lower cost - and lower risk - than manual methods. While most discussion about drones focuses on aerial applications, their use in water, on land and in space is also important. Deep sea drones, for example, can conduct long-term inspections of oil pipelines that supplant extremely dangerous diving operations and increase inspection frequency. Meanwhile drones can trawl the edges of space, in order to remove debris from an increasingly congested exosphere.

name: Environmental Remediation
description: After decades of heavy industrial development, China’s environmental challenges are nearing a tipping point, which if not corrected in a timely way could inflict significant costs on the country’s social fabric and economy. Throughout the country, worsening air, water, and soil pollution caused by industrialization, vehicle emissions, and power plants threaten to cause serious damage to China’s environmental ecosystem. In response, the government has declared a “war on pollution,” and has taken steps to dismantle coal-fired power plants, reduce emissions levels, and lower particulate-matter emission rates. There has also been a shift in societal awareness, with more public attention being paid to China’s worsening pollution, agricultural conditions, and food safety standards, which has in turn led to more citizens demanding a cleaner environment. The 2015 report Green Finance Reform and Green Transformation, released by the China Council for International Cooperation on Environment and Development, estimated that China will need to invest between RMB 40.3 trillion and RMB 123.4 trillion during the period 2014 to 2030 in order to adequately finance a transition to a greener economy. China is actively seeking ways to diversify its energy consumption away from coal and fossil fuels, to renewables and nuclear. The government’s 13th Five-Year Plan, released in 2016, calls for as much as a 65% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions compared with 2005 levels. In 2014, the International Energy Agency reported that China was poised to become the global leader in low-carbon technology deployment. According to the US Energy Information Administration’s International Energy Outlook 2016, Chinese coal consumption will decline between 2016 and 2040 as demand decreases. The Five-Year Plan acknowledges the Fourth Industrial Revolution, by calling for the deployment of the latest technologies and environmentally-friendly techniques; specific targets for 2020 include reducing the number of days where people experience heavy pollution by 25%. Meanwhile the sharing economy can help decouple economic growth from resource use. The National Information Centre has estimated the Chinese sharing economy was worth about $229 billion in 2015, and would grow 40% annually until 2020 - when it could account for as much as 10% of GDP. Increasing the general awareness of environmental problems and strengthening the enforcement of related standards will be challenging, however, due to the vested interests of key state-owned enterprises in the oil, gas and coal industries. Strong public-private partnerships will therefore be needed.

name: Environmental Risks
description: A dizzying array of large, natural catastrophic events in 2017, including the Hurricanes Harvey (Texas), Irma (Florida), and Maria (Puerto Rico), all of which hit within a four-week span, drained the capital out of the global property & casualty insurance and reinsurance sectors, according to Swiss Re’s global insurance review and outlook published in 2017. Total insured losses resulting from the three hurricanes alone amounted to more than $90 billion. Catastrophic loss events are becoming more common, and more devastating for more regions of the world. According to the so-called Clausius-Clapeyron equation, every half degree celsius of global warming results in a roughly 3% increase in atmospheric moisture. In addition to climate change, other contributing factors to the worsening weather situation include overbuilding in vulnerable locations, inadequate infrastructure, and increased pollution in densely-populated urban areas. The start of 2018 only brought more examples of extreme weather, including the “bomb cyclone” that brought heavy snow and strong winds to the east coast of the US, and Storm Eleanor, which hit the United Kingdom with gusts of up to 90 miles per hour. Extreme weather events rank first among global risks in terms of likelihood, according to the World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report published in 2018 - and second among global risks in terms of impact. The insurance industry can actually play a positive role in terms of promoting better preparedness for climate change and related catastrophic effects; an article published in the Harvard Business Review in August 2017 suggested that private property insurers could, for example, better differentiate on policy pricing based on the risk that a property may be subjected to coastal flooding, thereby discouraging building in vulnerable areas, or offer discounts to homeowners who proactively protect their houses from potential wildfires. Another element examined in the article is what insurers can do to prompt local governments to better prepare for climate change-induced environmental disaster. Swiss Re, for example, has partnered with a company to offer a new type of catastrophe bond that rewards municipalities for investing in disaster protection, by lowering the rates that municipalities must pay bondholders based on the amount of risk reduction achieved.

name: Environmental Stewardship
description: On March 15, 2019 an estimated 1.6 million students in more than 120 countries, inspired by 16-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg, walked out of class and marched in the streets to demand a more aggressive response to climate change. Their climate strike followed the 2018 publication of a report by the United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change warning that, barring unprecedented action, the planet was just 12 years away from a climate catastrophe. Climate change caused by human activity has already dramatically intensified drought and flooding, and promises to make such extreme weather conditions more common. According to a study published in the journal Nature in 2017, drought recovery times are getting longer everywhere - and, without new restrictions on greenhouse gas emissions, the time between droughts will grow shorter as the time required for recovery only grows longer. As people begin to think about and engage with these issues more, one metric to keep in mind is the so-called Seventh Generation Principle - an American Indian concept that holds that decisions made now should help to guarantee well-being for the next seven generations.     In addition to climate change, other environmental issues that must be addressed include the depletion of animal species, forests, and other natural resources (according to a report published in 2018 by the World Wildlife Fund, the global wildlife population decreased by 60% between 1970 and 2014). Businesses can help societies tackle these problems. In many cases, they may not have a choice - as large institutional investors increasingly attach values-based conditions. Norway’s sovereign wealth fund, the holder of shares equal to an average of 1.4% of all publicly-traded companies in the world, has pushed the firms it backs to more actively report their carbon dioxide emissions, for example. Choosing to take a leadership role on environmental issues can pay geopolitical dividends, as well. China, for example, has increasingly been looked to by other nations as a leader when it comes to international efforts to address climate change due to its heavy investments in renewable energy, and due to indications that the US has a decreasing desire to play such a role under the administration of President Donald Trump.

name: Environmental Sustainability
description: The environmental impact of some blockchain technologies - especially those that rely on “mining,” or confirming transactions by using computing power to solve difficult math problems - is a source of controversy. The mining employed to support the Bitcoin cryptocurrency, for example, sucks up enough electricity to power about 6.4 million US households, a consumption level roughly equivalent to that of the Czech Republic, according to the Bitcoin Energy Consumption Index published by the website Digiconomist; a single Bitcoin transaction could power nearly 33 US households for an entire day, according to the index. As the price of a single Bitcoin rose from about $2,300 in May 2017 to more than $7,000 roughly one year later, demand for cryptocurrency mining surged. Despite projected advances in the energy efficiency of mining hardware, cryptocurrency miners have sought out cheaper, more abundant energy sources in places such as the Nordic countries in Europe and rural areas of the US. Some utilities have expressed reservations about providing energy for mining. Still, utilities have found their own internal uses for blockchain; in early 2018, European utilities disclosed plans to directly trade energy with each other using the technology.  So-called peer-to-peer energy markets are just one way in which blockchain technology can actually play a key role in better protecting the environment. The so-called circular economy, which involves re-using materials and resources in order to prevent waste, can benefit from the use of blockchain to better track of materials like wood or fabric throughout their stages of use, according to a report published in 2016 by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation. In addition, someone buying a bicycle, for example, could benefit from blockchain technology by automatically receiving an unaltered chain of details about materials used to build the bicycle, where it was built, and who built it, according to the report. Blockchain can also be used to facilitate carbon trading, or the practice of businesses buying credits that offset the greenhouse gas emissions caused by their operations through funding environmentally-friendly initiatives. Ice cream maker Ben & Jerry’s launched a pilot program in 2018 that uses blockchain to directly connect the sale of individual scoops sold over the counter to carbon credits that fund a forest conservation project in Peru.

name: Environmental, Social and Governance
description: A paradigm shift began after the financial crisis dramatically demonstrated the inter-dependence of individual financial choices, markets, economies, and global challenges like climate change. Meanwhile stagnant economic growth, mounting populism, and rising inequality all point to governments’ limited ability to provide effective solutions. Against this backdrop, new preferences are forming, particularly among young people. A growing share of consumption is focused on goods and services that provide a collective experience, for example, while an awareness of climate change is spreading, and sustainability has become a key buzzword as corporations increasingly observe so-called environmental, social and governance, or ESG, standards. Institutional investors have also started to embrace the ESG agenda. More than 1,500 investors and managers, representing nearly $60 trillion in assets under management, have signed the United Nations-backed Principles for Responsible Investment. Yet, many investors struggle to convert related commitments into practice. According to McKinsey, less than 1% of the total capital at the 15 largest US public pension funds is allocated to ESG-specific strategies, such as ESG-screened passive indexes. Many institutional investors continue to treat ESG as a marketing tool, rather than an integral part of a strategy. In recent years, a number of related initiatives have emerged that have boosted the adoption of ESG. One of the most promising developments is so-called “green bonds,” or traditional fixed income instruments used to finance exclusively environmentally sustainable projects. Another financial innovation gaining ground is impact investing, where commercial returns are coupled with socio-economic or environmental impact. Institutional investors such as endowments and sovereign development funds have been particularly active as part of this new investment model, which aims to achieve a triple bottom-line measured according to profit, environmental impact, and social benefit. Only time will tell if ESG can become mainstream. The extent to which institutional investors begin to access and promote ESG objectives requires an assessment of where they align with existing asset classes and investment products - and an understanding of strategies that can further specific ESG goals. This shift in perspective will enable institutional investors to play a larger role in shaping the future of various industries, as they incorporate these criteria into their investment portfolios.

name: Environmentally-Sustainable Consumerism
description: By 2027, about 65% of Chinese households will qualify as middle class, and annual consumption in the country is expected to reach $8.2 trillion - up from $4.3 trillion just a decade earlier - according to a report published by the World Economic Forum in 2018. Meanwhile annual consumer spending in India is expected to increase to $6 trillion by 2030 from $1.5 trillion in 2019, according to a separate Forum report. This increase will have a significant environmental impact, if it follows the path established by developed markets and involves vast conspicuous consumption and intensive resource use. Consumers everywhere need to be encouraged to help mitigate resource scarcity, combat climate change, curb plastics pollution, and eliminate food waste with their choices. In order to make this a reality, consumers need to be excited by the prospect of sustainability, and genuinely motivated to engage; too often, they may not see sustainability as relevant to their daily lives, or they may avoid more sustainable products often seen as relatively expensive or ineffective. Businesses must make sustainable choices more accessible and affordable, while redesigning product lines and increasing their portfolios of sustainable options. Sustainability-focused business models have been proven to have real value, and can be scaled up significantly. The sharing economy, for example, which generally provides access to things like cars and real estate rather than ownership, in the form of an Uber ride or an Airbnb stay, is a potential means to achieve more sustainable consumption by decreasing cars on the highway, for example, and related emissions (though serious questions have been raised about whether car-sharing services may actually aggravate issues like traffic congestion by encouraging people to avoid public transit). Another critical emerging business model is related to the “circular economy,” which involves minimizing waste by re-using materials rather than discarding them. Circular economy principles could help blunt the environmental impact of the consumer waste that will inevitably be generated by an expanding middle class, according to an article published by McKinsey in 2017. For example, old tires could be used as industrial fuel, according to the article, while applying liquid-chemical extraction to discarded electronics could multiply their value.

name: Equitable Growth and Opportunity
description: The United Kingdom saw a particularly sharp increase in income inequality during the 1980s, which has only been slightly reduced since then, according to the UK Office for National Statistics; measured in terms of a Gini coefficient, where zero represents equally-shared income across all households and 100 means one household holds all income, the UK’s score increased to 31.5 by 2017, from 27.3 in 1977. Meanwhile the country’s score based on the ratio of income for the richest 10% of its households to that of the poorest 40% increased to 127.2 by 2017, from 100 in 1977, according to data published by the Office for National Statistics. According to the charity The Equality Trust, unequal access to the benefits of globalization and innovation was a significant factor behind the UK’s popular vote to leave the European Union in 2016 (in addition to attitudes towards immigration and trade, and notions of sovereignty). Trying to convince someone struggling to put food on the table about the transformative power of the new sharing economy, for example, would be unlikely to be successful, the charity noted shortly after the Brexit vote. One particular disparity in the UK that merits attention exists between relatively wealthy and economically productive inner London, and other areas of the country. A report published by the Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce in 2014 showed significant discrepancies in terms of economic progress between 1998 and 2011, with 27% growth in East Inner London, 10% growth in West Inner London, and declines ranging between about 14% and 23% for outer London, Coventry, Southampton, and Leicester over the same period. The report also cited a large disparity in terms of labour productivity per hour worked; London scored 131.2 on a related index, compared with 96.4 for the east of England, 91.7 for the northwest, 87.1 for the West Midlands, and 85.2 for Wales. Within London, inequality is also pronounced. According to a report published in 2017 by Trust for London, a charitable foundation, about half of the city’s wealth is owned by just 10% of the population, and 27% of Londoners are technically living in poverty. The Trust for London report also noted that the top 10% of earners in London enjoyed an income that was eight times higher than the income earned by the bottom 10%, up from about 6.5 times higher as of 1997.

name: Equity and Social Justice
description: Scientific advances may enable humans to improve everything from their memory to their appearance. As new technologies and options for enhancement are developed, there arises a need for social systems that can ensure people will be granted affordable access. Inequality in terms of accessibility could cause social tension, and unfair competition - and potentially create twin tracks for those with only average abilities versus groups that have been enhanced. The divide between enhanced and non-enhanced could, for example, create unfairness in the ways that performance and specific capabilities are assessed, due to a division between humans who use enhancing technologies and those who do not. It is also possible that certain performance enhancing methods may come to be considered doping (or, at least, a lack of transparency on the use of these technologies could be considered doping). Meanwhile efforts to level the playing field could lead to the default implementation of certain enhancing technologies, and create pressure on competitors to implement enhancements just in order to keep up. Globally, a system could develop where regions with relatively loose related regulation push other countries to de-regulate, in order to compete. According to the results of a Pew Research Center survey conducted in the US and published in 2016, 73% of respondents believed inequality will increase if brain chips become available, as initially they would only be obtainable for the wealthy. In addition, 63% believed the ability to receive synthetic blood transfusions would make recipients feel superior to those who have not received them, according to the survey results. Due to our cultural, religious, and economic differences, we will likely face serious challenges in terms of regionally uneven distribution, and advancement, of these technologies - which in turn may yield greater social inequality. This will force us to confront questions about how we can prevent regional and cultural division through global governance, how we can best evaluate and contextualize results made possible by enhancing interventions, and how human enhancement can be obtained in an affordable way. There is also the question of boundaries; that is, how much enhancement is too much enhancement. As we enter into a “trans-human” era, guidelines must be clarified.

name: Ethics and Identity
description: Innovation triggered by the Fourth Industrial Revolution, in disciplines like biotechnology and artificial intelligence, is redefining what it means to be human by pushing the limits of lifespan, health, and cognition in ways once confined to science fiction. As knowledge progresses and new discoveries are made, a related moral and ethical discussion is critical - if people are to be able to appropriately respond to phenomena like life extension, so-called designer babies, and memory extraction. The biological domain in particular poses a range of ethical challenges when it comes to regulation and social norms. New technologies present questions about what it means to be human, what information about personal health should be shared, and what rights and responsibilities we have with regard to altering the genetic code of future generations. Many other questions are likely to arise with regard to human augmentation, and to how societies should deal with machines that have human-like qualities and an ability to autonomously make life-or-death decisions. Related privacy, data security, and identity issues are becoming increasingly important for policy-makers, regulators, and companies. There are also growing concerns that, as the Fourth Industrial Revolution deepens our individual and collective relationships with technology, it may negatively affect social skills - like the ability to empathize. We already see this happening. A 2010 study by the University of Michigan Institute for Social Research identified a nearly 40% decline in empathy among college students compared with counterparts 20 or 30 years earlier. Most of that decline occurred after the year 2000. According to results of a study published by Nielsen in 2017, millennials in the US spend about six hours per week on social media, while members of Generation X (age 35 to 49) spend nearly seven hours. As face-to-face conversation is crowded out by online interaction, there are fears that people will begin to struggle to listen, make eye contact, or accurately read body language. To combat these challenges, there is a need to ensure that the Fourth Industrial Revolution fosters individualism and humanity, and is an empowering force that fosters technology as a tool that is made by people, and for people. Individuals and organizations need to take collective responsibility for creating a future where innovation and technology genuinely serve the public interest.

name: Ethics and Legality
description: A serious downside to a fully-realized future for Precision Medicine (or "Personalized Medicine") is the fact that the genomic and other biological data included in personal medical records will be subject to potential misuse by bad actors with financial or other incentives. Without strong, enduring privacy laws, people with a certain genotype (or genetic makeup) may find themselves uninsurable, unemployable, or otherwise discriminated against. Genomic data can also accurately identify parentage, which could lead to invasions of privacy in cases such as adoption proceedings. Ethical and legal considerations regarding who may access individual genomic and other data, and how that data is used, are of paramount concern. In addition, rules governing the use of patient data for research purposes (often called "secondary use," as the data is used beyond the scope of immediate clinical care) are critical. Secondary use requires a balance between a person's right to privacy and the need to create a healthcare system where every patient encounter can be an opportunity to improve care. Efforts to achieve such a balance can be aided by improved informed consent and risk communication, and by robust data de-identification and synthesis techniques. The relative cost of Precision Medicine may be high, due to the technology required and the expense of developing individualized medicines and treatments. However, cost savings are also possible, as ineffective treatments may be avoided for some patients. Ensuring access to Precision Medicine for everyone is critical, so that disparities in health care outcomes are not exacerbated. Another potentially problematic aspect of Precision Medicine, from an ethical standpoint, is the use of genomic information that predicts disease where there is no actionable treatment or preventative available; advance knowledge of an untreatable condition may reduce the quality of life. The question of when people should be informed of their risk of untreatable disease promises to continue to present thorny ethical issues.

name: European Reforms
description: Europe is at a turning point. The 2016 Brexit vote, and the United Kingdom’s ongoing negotiations to withdraw from the European Union, have placed the potential deconstruction of the political bloc in the spotlight. The EU needs to find a long-term solution to its migration and refugee crisis, and to take a leading role in coordinating the global fight against terrorism. While the eurozone continues apace with its economic recovery, it remains to be seen if growth can be sustained. France’s GDP growth, for example, is projected to fall to 1.7% for 2018, from 2.2% in 2017, according to the European Commission. The Franco-German alliance has historically been the engine driving the European project forward, and pushing necessary reforms to address challenges confronting EU institutions. In a September 2017 speech delivered at the Sorbonne, recently-elected President Emmanuel Macron presented plans for a renewed EU that embraces globalization and innovation, promotes European interests and values, and protects Europeans from new security threats. Specific proposals put forward by Macron included putting up pan-European candidates for European Parliamentary elections in 2019, creating a European intelligence agency and a common military budget, and appointing a eurozone finance minister. A deeper financial integration within the eurozone, and a common eurozone budget, are also needed. In addition, the EU requires a clearer common foreign policy, while economic cooperation across European states must be deepened, in order to better foster digital business development. Meanwhile the sort of increased military coordination and budgets envisioned by Macron could conceivably better ensure the security of European citizens. In June 2018, Macron’s efforts were rewarded when nine EU member states including Germany, Spain, and Belgium agreed to set up a European military force designed to be rapidly deployed at times of crisis. This so-called European Intervention Initiative is structurally separate from the EU, meaning that Britain - which also signed on to Macron’s plan - could take part following the country’s planned exit from the political bloc in 2019.

name: Evolving Manufacturing Skills
description: About 65% of the children now entering primary school will eventually have a job that does not currently exist, according to a report published by the World Economic Forum; as more business models are disrupted, it will very soon have a broad, profound impact on employment. One of the biggest factors driving that change is the advancement of manufacturing technologies. This will transform manufacturing into a relatively sophisticated sector in need of fewer workers and more skilled engineers. Overall, as much as one quarter of the tasks currently completed by industrial workers in developed countries could be automated by 2025, according to the McKinsey Global Institute. Preparing these workers for the challenges of a transitioning labour market poses a serious challenge for both governments and companies, and is likely to require an inclusive, multi-stakeholder approach. In addition, schools and universities need to better anticipate the changes being brought about by disruptive innovation, and adapt accordingly - while outside of school, lifelong learning must become more common for workers in need of new skills for the future. Educational institutions also need to collaborate more closely with governments and companies, in order to identify essential skills and attributes for the future - particularly those related to science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), in addition to critical thinking, innovation, and organizational science (studying the hows and whys of the ways that organizations function). One example: there is currently a looming shortage of data scientists, making it a potentially ideal educational and career path. In general, most business leaders need to reorient their strategies in order to close the gap between employee supply and demand, and to better manage the advent of continuously evolving technologies. Innovative ways of upgrading employees’ existing skills must be integrated into businesses’ daily routines. At the same time, companies need to be prepared to accommodate the preferences and requirements of a new generation of digital natives. To that end, businesses can deploy digitally-enabled training that makes use of augmented reality (using a device to “see” virtual objects in a real space), virtual reality (a completely virtual simulation of a space), and mixed reality (a blending of virtual objects with a physical space).

name: Extremism and Security in Pakistan
description: After the 9/11 terrorist attacks in the US, Pakistan’s security situation became more tenuous due to its engagement in the broader war on terror. However, things have improved in recent years. According to National Internal Security Policy documents, incidents of terrorism in Pakistan declined to 175 in 2018, from 2,061 in 2010. Meanwhile the number of related casualties has decreased, while incidents of sectarian violence have fallen nearly to zero. The joint military operations Zarb-e-Azb (2014) and Radd-ul-Fasaad (2017) played major roles in helping to control terrorism by going after militant groups, sleeper cells, and hidden security threats. However, in early 2019 the Pakistan-based extremist group Jaish-e-Mohammed carried out a suicide bombing that killed 40 Indian security personnel in Kashmir. This occurred despite the Pakistani government’s National Action Plan, which aims to reduce extremism and terrorism by addressing hate speech and the glorification of terrorists, the registration and supervision of madrassas (Islamic religious schools), the financing of terrorism, and the regulation of cyberspace and the media.  The issue of security in the country remains pressing. Major areas of concern identified by authorities include the alienation and frustration of young people, regional inequality, a lack of justice and rule of law, and a lack of accountability. When it comes to extremism and security, Pakistani society is stuck between liberal and religious orders; both mindsets tend to undermine each other. Meanwhile foreign actors have used each group to pursue varying agendas, and Pakistanis are paying the price. Security risks persist in the province of Balochistan, where the Baloch Liberation Army has targeted China’s local influence. Pakistan has signed a number of memorandums of understanding on fighting terrorism and extremism with both developed and developing countries, though tackling the issue takes time; given its relatively recent transition to democracy after years of military rule, patience is required. Many of the country’s ills are by-products of the Soviet-Afghan war that began in 1979 and is ongoing in one form or another. Only greater cooperation and trust can help improve its security situation, and enable Pakistan to play a role in helping other countries in the region achieve a sustainable peace.

name: Fighting Poverty in Bangladesh
description: Despite the country’s healthy economic growth, inequality remains a significant concern in Bangladesh. (An added challenge has arrived in the form of more than 700,000 Rohingya refugees forced to flee from neighbouring Myanmar; Bangladesh will require significant international financial support to address their needs). The percentage of the country’s population living below the poverty line fell to 24.3% as of 2016, from 40% in 2005, according to the Bangladesh Household Expenditure Survey. There has also been some reduction in the rural-urban divide, and the country’s East-West divide, related to poverty. A high inflow of remittances from abroad to rural areas, social safety net programmes, and microcredit and social awareness campaigns led by non-governmental organizations have bolstered development. Yet, income inequality has in some ways actually increased since the early 1980s. In 2016, the country’s wealthiest 10% had income levels 2.9 times higher than the bottom 40%, a rate that was about 1.5 times higher than it had been in 1983-84. Still, the government’s fiscal 2017-2018 budget allocated an amount less than 1.5% of Bangladesh’s GDP to social safety net programmes (excluding pension components), lower than the 3% recommended by the government’s National Social Security Strategy. Bangladesh has committed to United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, which were established in 2015 and aim for zero poverty, zero hunger, and reduced inequality by 2030. Successfully reducing income inequality requires addressing its root causes: weak job creation; a skills gap between what is desired and what is available; unplanned urbanization; a lack of diversification of the economy; and corruption. Investing in people will be necessary to benefit from the demographic dividend arriving as a big portion of young people reach working age. More inclusive development will also depend upon improving access to quality primary and secondary education, and to health care, and altering societal norms regarding violence and domestic decision making. Skills training programmes for minorities and the transgender community could help these people successfully enter the job market, as could strong public-private partnerships. Successful implementation of the government’s “Digital Bangladesh” vision, and initiatives to strengthen good governance, will be essential, as will a stronger focus on gender-inclusive growth. In addition, since the poor are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, environmentally sustainable development is necessary.

name: Finance, Technology and the Economy
description: Technology has changed the ways companies communicate with and understand their customers - while customers have gained unprecedented options. The financial industry in particular can now serve customers who have not traditionally made use of its services, thanks to innovation (though the lingering effects of the 2008 financial crisis have caused many to wonder about the potential social costs of new technologies). As the global economy searches for new growth engines there is an increasing consensus, particularly in emerging economies such as China, that more people must play a more active role in economic development. Financial technology (fintech), and more inclusive finance, can facilitate this. Such fundamental global financial sector development is particularly critical for emerging economies, which might otherwise face problems with financial repression and a lack of capital formation. By taking leading roles in the development of fintech, countries like China and India have also demonstrated how emerging economies can help build a financial system that is drastically different from the traditional model, and can bypass some of the traditional elements that have featured in financial market development in the West. However, there are growing, related concerns. Healthy debate about the relationship between fintech and regulation, consumer protection, market power, data security, investor suitability, financial literacy, and education should be taking place. The recent tightening of China’s regulations governing once-booming, small, and relatively accessible cash loans highlights the potential shocks to the financial system and society that can result if financial innovation is allowed to grow without proper oversight. The exorbitant fees charged alongside these small consumer loans, the potentially violent repercussions for defaulting on them, and the exploitation of borrowers’ lack of financial literacy demonstrated how good ideas can be quickly tarnished, creating a negative impact far beyond the financial sector. Related questions have been raised about some of China’s recent public-private-partnership (PPP) experiments. It has become evident that a vast majority of PPP funds are tied to bond-like structures that promise safe and attractive returns. Investors are therefore not motivated by financial returns, as much as they are by the implicit guarantees offered by governments behind the projects. It was this type of dynamic that eventually led to the financial crisis, and has contributed to the rapid escalation of China’s national debt. This key issue is curated in partnership with Zhu Ning, PBC School of Finance and Associate Dean at the National Institute of Financial Research, Tsinghua University.

name: Financial Products and Services
description: Blockchain technology may be best known as the underpinning of virtual currencies such as Bitcoin, which have touched off a speculative fury as investors place bets on new, decentralized means of payment. But blockchains can help to efficiently address the need for multiple, cost-effective financial products and services that can comply with relatively exacting financial regulation. For example, transparency and auditability requirements can potentially be more easily met by using blockchain. Theoretically, instead of having to send requests for information to a bank or other type of organization, an auditor could simply verify transactions on a publicly-available blockchain ledger thanks to its fixed permanence, according to an article published by the consultancy Deloitte in 2017. In addition, because a high value financial transaction on blockchain can potentially require only about one hour to be cleared, whereas a traditional transaction of the same value might require as much as a month or more to be cleared, the technology could make more frequent audits possible, according to the article. More broadly, blockchain can be viewed as moving the financial services industry away from process-oriented approaches, and towards data-based workstreams. Insurance is another example of a service where blockchain could dramatically improve processes. In 2016, a group of insurance and reinsurance companies including Allianz, Swiss Re and Munich Re launched an initiative to explore ways to use blockchain technology to provide faster and more secure services. The following year, the group presented a prototype smart contract management system, designed to cover everything from setup to settling claims. When it comes to cross-border financial transactions, blockchain could also theoretically play a helpful role. In March 2018, the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication, or SWIFT, tested the use of blockchain technology to reconcile payments among accounts spread across 34 banks; the test showed that the technology has made significant progress in terms of security and governance, though it was not yet ready to support large-scale, mission-critical global infrastructures, according to SWIFT. Compliance with international trade regulations could also be improved through the use of blockchain, by creating immutable audit trails. In 2017, Deloitte and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced they had developed a blockchain technology proof of concept for trade finance, which included participants such as the Bank of China (Hong Kong), Hang Seng Bank and Standard Chartered Bank.

name: Financial Regulation
description: Regulatory changes implemented since the financial crisis roughly a decade ago, designed to protect consumers and economies, have created challenges for the insurance industry. One example: while insurers in the US had been relatively free to address cyber-risk in their own way, new regulations such as those implemented by the New York Department of Financial Services in 2017 now require firms to appoint a chief information security officer, and to have their boards approve a written data security policy, according to Deloitte’s 2018 Insurance Outlook. The Deloitte report notes that insurers must take into account multiplying additional compliance demands, which could be especially challenging for small and mid-sized companies. Another particular focus of insurance firms is the so-called Insurance Distribution Directive (IDD) being rolled out in Europe, which is designed to improve consumer protection and bolster competition. It will require companies to provide more information to customers, and limit product offers to only those made in response to actual customer need and demand, according to an information update published by the consultancy PwC in early 2018. Meanwhile IFRS 9, an international standard that came into effect in 2018, affects the ways that insurance companies can assess and present the value of the investment portfolios that underpin their businesses. There is ongoing debate about the so-called systemic relevance of insurance companies, or their size and the potential risk they pose relative to the economies where they operate (and the corresponding need to closely monitor their stability). In 2016, the Financial Stability Board published a list of nine insurers in the world deemed systemically relevant, including Germany’s Allianz, American International Group (AIG) in the US, and Ping An Insurance in China. The FSB did not publish an updated list in 2017, and noted that new ways to assess systemic risk in the insurance sector were being developed that could affect which insurers are identified as systemically relevant. One of the key metrics that regulators assess when it comes to the biggest insurance firms is their level of capital on hand relative to expected losses. Under Solvency II, a set of rules implemented in 2016, insurers in the European Union must be nearly 100% sure they have enough capital to deal with their worst expectations of losses over the course of a year.

name: Financial Risk and Resilience
description: The Panama Papers, a trove of documents detailing the efforts of financial and legal firms around the world to help clients avoid taxes (and in some cases facilitate corruption and launder funds), were publicly released in 2015. The following year, the consultancy Oliver Wyman published a report noting that a number of bankers being summoned before parliamentary committees had surged, and that reputation risk was increasingly a focus for supervisory boards and management; its research also showed that the share price impact of a bank’s disclosure of a sanctions violation could be six times the size of an actual fine. The Paradise Papers, a second trove of leaked documents, this time detailing the use of secret offshore investment structures, followed in 2017 - further increasing public scrutiny of the financial services sector. Some regulators have begun to take reputation risk into account as they develop rules and regulations for banks. The United Kingdom’s Financial Conduct Authority, for example, has introduced a Senior Managers and Certification Regime that requires firms to assess a senior management candidate’s honesty, integrity and reputation.     An increasingly significant threat to financial stability is related to cyber risk. According to an International Monetary Fund working paper published in 2018, the 49 cyber-attacks reported to the UK financial authorities during 2017 likely represented an under-reporting of successful attacks during the year, and noted that only 7% of thousands of annual reports filed by US firms in 2017 included references to cyber risk. The increasing inter-connectedness of networks used to transfer information means that anything an everything can be exposed, and critical infrastructure (and even basic human rights) can be compromised as a result, according to a report published by the International Telecommunications Union in 2017. In response to cyber-related and other means of financial crime, efforts have been made to better coordinate global anti-financial crime and anti-money laundering efforts. The Financial Action Task Force sets global standards for combatting money laundering, and regularly publishes a list of countries deemed to not be cooperating in international efforts to curb financial crime and terrorist financing. The CAMELS rating system is meanwhile used by regulators to score banks operating in the US on aspects including capital adequacy and management capability; a bank’s CAMELS score is not made public.

name: Financial System
description: Ghana’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the total market value of domestic, publicly-traded companies relative to GDP (referred to as "market capitalization" in the competitiveness index), where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 7.90, resulting in a rank of 96th out of 121 countries; in terms of insurance premium volumes as a percentage of GDP where it has a progress score of 19.00 that results in a rank of 92nd out of 135 countries; and in terms of domestic lending to the private sector where it has a progress score of 21.00 that results in a rank of 122nd out of 140 countries. Other indicators reflect a better performance: the discrepancy between current domestic lending to businesses and an anticipated long-term trend (referred to as "credit gap" in the competitiveness index), where it has a progress score of 100.00 that results in a rank of 1st out of 140 countries; and in terms of the protective capital held by banks relative to assets where it has a progress score of 100.00 that results in a rank of 40th out of 118 countries.

name: Financing Sustainable Development
description: No Description Available.

name: Fiscal Policy Measures
description: Roughly a decade after the global financial crisis, national debt levels in advanced economies are near their highest levels since World War II, averaging 104% of GDP, according to a study published in the International Monetary Fund’s quarterly magazine in 2018. That places significant pressure on governments to find ways to cut spending or increase tax revenue (or somehow do both), according to the study. This is particularly true now, as central banks seem poised to gradually increase interest rates, thereby potentially directing more government funds into making interest payments and leaving less for public services like infrastructure and education. Policy-makers must find ways to address deficits that do not hinder economic growth. Some economists argue that cutting government spending is best for restoring fiscal health and stirring growth, and others counter that it is only by increasing spending that economies can truly be reinvigorated. While raising taxes can also be necessary to tackle budget deficits, arguments have been made that tax hikes can choke economic growth by discouraging work, investment, and innovation.   While countries need to strike a balance between taxes and spending as they seek to balance budgets and preserve social protections, there is ongoing debate about which of the two elements to lean on more heavily. There are certain types of spending that can actually lower a budget deficit, primarily related to “program integrity” measures that target fraud, tax evasion, and bureaucratic mistakes, according to an analysis published by the Brookings Institution in 2015. Such spending aimed at curbing improper payments in the US’s Medicare health insurance program for people 65 or older could yield about $14 for every dollar spent, according to the analysis, while spending an additional $1 billion annually on reviews meant to determine whether or not to grant disability insurance could save the US’s Social Security Administration $43 billion. As policy-makers seek the best formula for addressing their country’s particular challenges, they must be mindful not only of the impact it may have on deficits and economic growth, but also of the potential impact on large parts of the population - and how the population may react. In France, for example, a government decision in late 2018 to increase gasoline taxes in order to reduce reliance on fossil fuels sparked regular street protests by thousands of gilets jaunes (“yellow vests”) for better wages and better public services.

name: Flexible Manufacturing
description: 3D printing means that the cost of making something has been liberated from a need to make a lot of it. Traditionally, manufacturers have been bound by the principle that the more they produce, the more costs decline. 3D printing can alter this dynamic, by for example reducing or even eliminating the need for tooling - the process of developing series of moulds and dies needed for production (traditional injection moulding, for example, requires a series of precision-machined moulds in which to inject heated metal or other material). 3D printing can therefore drastically decrease the time needed to bring a new product to market, slash the costs associated with making moulds, and lead to a situation where the cost-per-produced-part is not related to the potentially high overall cost of production including tooling and other elements. When a single 3D printing machine is able to produce complex parts requiring limited post-processing steps, the economy of scale associated with traditional large factories becomes obsolete - while more regional and local production becomes economically viable. In late 2017, Daimler Trucks North America announced a pilot program for making 3D printed truck and bus parts on demand. The move was designed to slim down management and reduce the need to maintain inventory, while re-directing capital saved in the process to the development of new products (shipping time and related costs are also eliminated as part of this process). A similar approach could be widely applied in the automotive industry, where large stocks of spare parts for older vehicles can be eliminated. In addition, because a number of products can be manufactured in a single batch using the same 3D printer (if they are made out of the same material), that creates an ability to produce highly-customized parts at almost no additional cost. This has been the case in the healthcare industry, for example, when it comes to the production of customized implants and stents, and in the fashion and apparel industries, which place a premium on customization.

name: Food Technology and Innovation
description: Billions of people around the world are poorly nourished, millions of farmers must live at a subsistence level, enormous amounts of food go to waste, and poor farming practices are taking a toll on the environment. Achieving United Nations Sustainable Development Goals will require the transformation of food systems, so that they become more inclusive, sustainable, efficient, and nourishing. This calls for improved policy, increased investment, and expanded infrastructure, in addition to building more capacity for farmers, changing consumer behaviour, and improving resource management. Until recently, the food and agriculture sectors were slow to adopt technologies driving the Fourth Industrial Revolution like the Internet of Things, artificial intelligence, and blockchain; there have been low levels of related investment, inspiring relatively few related startups. A total of just $14 billion was invested in about 1,000 food systems-focused startups between 2010 and 2018, according to the World Economic Forum report Innovation With a Purpose: the Role of Technology Innovation in Accelerating Food System Transformation. By way of comparison, $145 billion was invested in approximately 18,000 healthcare-related startups over the same period. Fragmented rural markets, poor infrastructure, and heavy regulatory burdens raise costs for food systems firms, while revenue is often constrained by customers’ limited ability or willingness to pay. In addition, much of the food systems startup activity to date has been concentrated on improving production in developed countries - which can result in less access to new solutions in developing countries. The Forum, in collaboration with McKinsey & Company, has highlighted technology applications that present emerging opportunities to improve consumer nutrition, increase supply-chain efficiency and transparency, and boost farmer productivity and profitability. While many are in early stages, they could deliver significant positive impacts for food systems by 2030. For example, if consumers were able to replace between 10% and 15% of the meat they consume with alternative proteins by 2030, total greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture could drop by between 5% and 8%, freshwater withdrawals for agriculture could be reduced by between 7% and 12%, and between 5% and 10% of the total land used for agriculture could be freed up for other uses.

name: Foreign Investment, Local Disconnect
description: Viet Nam, which began opening up its centralized economy in the 1980s, is now a party to 16 different free trade agreements, and is negotiating more. Foreign direct investment inflows soared to $12.6 billion as of 2016, from $2.4 billion in 1996, according to the World Bank - helping to move the country’s economy from one that relied heavily on exports tied to mining and raw materials towards an export mix associated with technology and manufacturing. However, despite investment inflows, local firms have struggled to capitalize on related opportunities. Not many local businesses participate in the same value chains and manufacturing networks that tie together multinational corporations, for example, and that limits potentially healthy interaction between local firms and multinationals in the country. ﻿The automobile industry provides a good example; while big names like Toyota, Honda, and Mercedes-Benz have established operations in Viet Nam, they mainly entail assembly facilities that employ relatively cheap labour. The locally-produced content in automobiles manufactured in the country remains relatively low. Toyota, for example, has a local content ratio for its Viet Nam production of less than 10%, according to a paper published by a Waseda University professor in 2017 - compared with a ratio of more than 80% for Japanese automakers as a whole in Thailand. The same trend is prevalent in Viet Nam among foreign producers of garments and technology products, where local firms tend to have no role in the production process beyond supplying packaging. Viet Nam needs to foster deeper ties between foreign and local firms operating in the country. That could involve being more selective in drawing particular types of foreign investment, and focusing on areas where Viet Nam may have competitive advantages. The government could also make efforts more generally to improve the business environment by upgrading infrastructure, and increasing spending on education, health, and R&D.

name: Forest Communities
description: The well-being of forest communities and Indigenous Peoples is closely tied to their environment; places where communities have strong land rights also have lower rates of deforestation and forest degradation. Few governments have established the legal protections needed to secure community land rights, however. As a consequence, Indigenous Peoples are losing their land to governments and corporations. Indigenous Peoples and local communities have the legal right to less than one third of the forests in low- and middle-income countries, according to Commodities and Forests Agenda 2020, published in 2017 by Tropical Forest Alliance 2020 and the World Economic Forum. Overall, Indigenous Peoples and local communities have legal rights to at least 513 million hectares of the world’s forests, or about one eighth of the total, according to the World Resources Institute’s 2014 report Securing Rights, Combating Climate Change. Much larger areas of forest are held by communities under customary rights, which are not legally recognized by governments. Most community-held forests are in low- and middle-income countries, where deforestation pressure is strong. When Indigenous Peoples and local communities have weak or no legal rights, their forests tend to be vulnerable to deforestation. According to the World Resources Institute’s 2014 report, in Indonesia, high levels of carbon dioxide emissions resulting from deforestation are due in part to weak or absent legal rights for forest communities.
