Another study of 80 forest areas in 10 different countries in South Asia, East Africa, and Latin America showed that community-owned and managed forests produce greater community benefits and improve carbon storage (the storage of carbon after it is emitted into the atmosphere). We will therefore forfeit an important opportunity to combat climate change, if we do not strengthen land rights for Indigenous Peoples and local communities. The Commodities and Forests Agenda 2020 report noted that a global consensus is emerging on the need for greater security of land tenure. The United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals commit member states to ensure that everyone has equal rights to ownership and control over land by 2030. In addition, nearly every country has endorsed the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, which guarantees land and territory rights. In some countries, communities have successfully lobbied for legal changes to recognize their land rights, while others are taking to the streets to voice their demands.

name: Forest Landscape Restoration
description: Most countries have an untapped resource: forest landscapes that could be restored and revitalized. Forest landscape restoration can revive “ecosystem services” (like air purification and climate regulation) and enhance human well-being in areas that have been cleared or degraded. In Ethiopia, for example, a government initiative resulted in more than 350 million trees being planted in a single day in 2019. Efforts like this can result in the establishment of dense forests, or high-yield agroforestry systems, as well as so-called mosaic systems - where wooded areas are interspersed among fields used for farming. Forest landscape restoration should not increase tree cover beyond what would be ecologically appropriate for a particular location - and should not introduce damaging, non-native species. More than two billion hectares of land have been identified as suitable for restoration around the world, which is an area equivalent to more than twice the size of China. Forest landscape restoration can diversify economies, reduce the damage caused by natural disasters, generate marketable forest and agricultural products, and support recreation and tourism. Restoration is therefore a growing investment opportunity; in Latin America and the Caribbean alone, related investments could yield roughly $23 billion in profit over a 50-year period, according to a report published in 2016 by the World Resources Institute. An additional $300 billion per year in global financing is needed for adequate forest restoration and conservation, which can in turn create jobs, help alleviate local poverty, and increase food security. Restoration can meanwhile improve soil and water quality, conserve biodiversity, and help mitigate climate change. For example, reforestation bids such as Ethiopia’s concerted effort can bolster carbon capture and storage - and reduce the impact of emissions. Forest landscape restoration can also help governments meet the requirements of international agreements, such as the UN Convention on Biological Diversity and the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals. Thanks to the New York Declaration on Forests, and the Bonn Challenge, there is now a global effort underway to bring 350 million hectares of degraded and deforested land into restoration by 2030. These efforts are supported by commitments that have been made as part of regional restoration initiatives, including AFR100 in Africa, and Initiative 20x20 in Latin America and the Caribbean.

name: Forestry and Forest Products
description: The global forestry industry generates more than $60 trillion in annual revenue, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Demand for forest products is only increasing, due to population growth and improved living standards - which places added pressure on forest resources. While sustainable forestry efforts (including Ethiopia’s government-led initiative to plant more than 350 million trees in a single day in 2019) can help bolster and conserve resources, unsustainable practices persist. Illegal logging contributes to deforestation, biodiversity loss, and greenhouse gas emissions, while depriving governments of essential revenue. Logging in primary (old growth) forests and in intact forest landscapes typically leads to a cascade of human activity in remote regions, and eventual deforestation. Merely complying with existing laws could save almost 200 million hectares of natural forest in Brazil and Indonesia alone, according to a report published by the Tropical Forest Alliance 2020. Timber smuggling is not only an economic and environmental problem - it often involves criminal organizations and is tied to wildlife and drug trafficking, money laundering, corruption, conflict, and human rights violations. An increasing number of countries have put measures in place to reduce imports of illegally-harvested wood. These have increased incentives for private businesses to pay closer attention to their supply chains. However, truly effective measures to reduce illegal logging require broad cooperation among governments, the private sector, and civil society; efforts such as the World Resources Institute’s Forest Legality Initiative, WWF’s Global Forest and Trade Network, and The Nature Conservancy’s Responsible Asia Forestry and Trade Network are successfully combating illegal logging by supporting government bids to implement related policies, and by working with the private sector to both exclude illegal wood and implement independent monitoring. Some of the tools for sustainable forest management that have been employed include forest certification and tree plantations; while these plantations can supply some, but not all of the “ecosystem services” (such as air purification) that natural forests provide, they will have to play an increasingly prominent role in providing forest products in the future. Ultimately, though, it is essential that plantations do not completely supplant natural forests.

name: French Economic Competitiveness
description: France’s relatively high ranking in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index has remained stable since 2012. However, the country’s weak ratings in the most recent edition for its macroeconomic environment (63rd out of 138 economies) and labour market efficiency (56th) are concerning. These are areas where France has historically ranked below its European peers. While the country has made efforts to curb its budget deficit, government debt levels remain high. In addition, there has been a deterioration of its capacity to attract talent from abroad. The Forum’s Competitiveness Index highlighted problematic factors for doing business in the country that include tax rates, restrictive labour regulations, and inefficient government bureaucracy. France is less competitive than its European neighbours largely due to its labour costs. According to Eurostat, France has the sixth-highest labour costs in Europe, at €36 per hour, behind Germany (€33 per hour), Italy (€28), and the United Kingdom (€27). This makes it relatively difficult for French firms to hire, which partly explains the high rate of unemployment the country has been dealing with for the past 30 years. The unemployment rate in France was 9.3% as of August 2018, according to Eurostat. France also has a relatively high level of compulsory taxes, equivalent to 46% of the country’s GDP as of 2015 - compared with an average of 40% for the eurozone, according to the research institute Coe-Rexecode. President Emmanuel Macron has pledged to give more flexibility to firms by reducing employers’ social contributions for employees. In addition, the government aims to revive growth and employment by scrapping the tax on wealth, gradually reducing the corporate tax rate from 33.33% to 25% by 2022, and by introducing a flat tax of 30% on capital gains. However, public spending remains a burden; it was equivalent to 56.5% of GDP as of 2016, according to the OECD. France has many competitive strengths, however; these include agriculture, luxury goods, aerospace, construction, and advertising. It also has a relatively high quality of rail, road and air transport infrastructure. The country is becoming a prominent player in new technologies. According to a study published in June 2017 by the French railroad company SNCF, €2.2 billion had been raised by technology startups in France since January of that year, or double the amount raised in all of 2016.

name: From Siloes to Collaboration
description: Traditionally, institutions designed digital identity systems from the narrow perspective of their own interaction with users. For those users, that meant inconvenient interfaces with multiple, often interoperable systems. Now, institutions are starting to respond to the broader digital context of users by exploring collaborative approaches that cut across traditional boundaries. National identity systems that are interoperable and scalable can save money, improve service delivery, and promote financial inclusion. For businesses, this same approach can enable more personalized experiences for customers, deepened levels of trust, reduced costs, and shared liability with other stakeholders. The European Union’s eIDAS standards promote the harmonization and mutual recognition of the national identity systems in all member states - which is convenient for EU citizens who can do things like open a bank account within the bloc simply by using a national identity card. In another example, Estonia and Finland have made the respective data layers of their identity systems interoperable, in order to enable seamless cross-border data sharing about Estonians who live in Finland but are registered for benefits and services back home. As of 2018, some 1,000 organizations in Estonia and 81 in Finland were using their data exchange layers to more easily deliver services. The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa and the African Union Commission are working together to increase the regional harmonization of digital identity standards, as part of the process of developing the African Continental Free Trade Area - the largest free trade area in the world in terms of participants. Within the private sector, South Korean mobile phone operator SK Telecom has developed “T-Auth,” which is designed to streamline online shopping by linking it to users’ mobile numbers; 99% of the country’s websites accept the service, and by late 2016 it had 13 million monthly users making 650 million transactions annually, SK Telecom said in a report published in 2017. Meanwhile in Sweden financial institutions have developed “BankID” for things like identification and account access, tax declarations, and document signing. BankID has an estimated 8 million active users; however, in 2018 14 people were found guilty of stealing the equivalent of about $160,000 by calling users, pretending to be a bank representative, and having the users log in to BankID while on the phone. Stakeholders in all sectors and industries should create collaborative business models, shared principles, standards, frameworks, and identity systems that are genuinely interoperable.

name: Fusing Technologies
description: The Fourth Industrial Revolution is different from prior industrial revolutions, in the way that it builds from a fusion of technologies, and from a growing harmonization and integration of research disciplines. Nearly every new development in any field now leverages digital capability. Precision genome editing, for example, could not have happened without relentless improvement in computing power and data analytics. Similarly, advanced robots would not exist without new approaches made to artificial intelligence dependent on digital systems and processing power. The digital and physical worlds also collide in fields such as autonomous vehicles and 3D printing. Advances in sensors are enabling robots and autonomous systems to understand and respond better to their environments, and to engage in a broader variety of tasks beyond the factory floors where they have been most prevalent historically. These systems can now access information remotely via the cloud, and connect with one another to exchange information and learn collectively. As the next generation of robots emerges as an element of the Internet of Things, there will be an increasing emphasis on human-machine collaboration. The physical and biological worlds are merging partly thanks to the creation of new materials that are designed to emulate the biological world. The discovery of new classes of recyclable, thermosetting polymers called polyhexahydrotriazines is a major step towards a more sustainable economy, for example. New materials are now routinely being used in medical implants, for tissue engineering, and for the creation of artificial organs, and 3D printing is increasingly being used to create customized structures. The biological and digital worlds overlap most controversially in the world of genetic engineering. Widely-accessible and affordable gene sequencing and editing systems, such as CRISPR/Cas9, make it possible to reliably and precisely remove or replace sequences in the genome of plants and animals. The biological and digital worlds are also overlapping in the form of sensors used to monitor personal health and behaviour, and to understand and influence brain activity. Advances that might have once been confined to digital systems, like the application of cryptography to blockchain technology to create programmable, secure, and distributed records, are now having widespread impact in the real world. Blockchain, for example, while it may be best known as the framework for virtual currency, can provide new ways to manage land records and track deforestation.

name: Future Communications Systems
description: The Internet of Things facilitates a flow of information between smart devices, cars, and home appliances; an estimated 8.4 billion physical objects were actively connected via the technology in 2017, according to the research firm Gartner, or an increase of nearly a third compared with the prior year. The impact this has on peoples’ daily lives is considerable. One can now cut travel time by making better decisions and taking an optimal route with less traffic, for example, while remote health monitoring for elderly patients is now more feasible. The spread of connected devices, and increased social media use and general online activity, have paved the way for new marketing techniques and customization, and play vital roles in new wealth creation. However, an increasing number of connected devices may make it difficult for wireless service providers to guarantee quality; one way to reduce cost and latency for the Internet of Things might be to deploy decentralizing blockchain technology. The advancement of the Internet of Things and artificial intelligence has triggered a major shift in the interaction between machines and humans. Intelligent human-machine interfaces could be deployed among connected devices, as could virtual reality and augmented reality technologies, in order to enhance efficiency. The potential for blending these technologies is tremendous; examples of related application areas include real estate (where property could be “visited” by someone virtually), architecture (where someone could tour a building before its construction), and healthcare (enabling the remote monitoring of patients). However, there are challenges that need to be addressed before mass adoption is possible. The cost of devices needs to become cheaper, for example, and data privacy and protection must be addressed. Human-machine interface technology could also be hampered by the bulky size, price, and compatibility of virtual reality and artificial reality devices. Still, there are exciting possibilities. According to a report published by the trade group GSMA in 2017, about 30% of smartphone owners in Pakistan, Bangladesh, and India had never used the internet on their phones due to a lack of digital literacy; Internet of Things-based human-machine interfaces could help overcome such challenges, by enabling the use of simple human gestures to access digital services.

name: Future Conflict Domains
description: Just over a year after China test fired a missile into the higher level of geo-synchronous orbit (around 30,000 kilometres) in May 2013, the United States declassified details of a similar program and launched two Geosynchronous Space Situational Awareness Program satellites, capable of monitoring the high orbital layer and rendezvousing with other satellites at geo-synchronous level. The key role of space-based communications for modern defence was highlighted by the warning in 2015 from US Air Force Lieutenant General Jay Raymond that “soon every satellite in every orbit will be able to be held at risk”. This militarization of new domains – space, but also the seabed – was a risk identified in the World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report 2016. With space-based technology becoming critical for a larger proportion of human activity, the unwillingness of military space powers to play by a common set of rules is a potential source of problems. Until recently, the hostility of the Arctic and the deep sea to human life meant that huge expanses of ocean remained outside of any commercial or strategic domain. However, the combination of melting icecaps and the development of more capable artificial intelligence-enabled submersible drones are dramatically expanding the maritime domain. In a speech to the Naval Submarine League Symposium in 2015, director of the US Naval Nuclear Propulsion Program Admiral Frank Caldwell identified the imperative to develop unmanned vehicles in order to innovate new capabilities in undersea warfare. In 2014 the strategy and management consultancy firm Avascent projected a boom in international submarine procurement over the 2014-2024 period, from $6.3 billion to $16 billion. Robot submarines are being developed to crawl along the ocean floor, in order to better map the domain and secure deep-sea fibre-optic cables critical to the functioning of global communications infrastructure. However, the same technology can have commercial applications in mining deep-sea minerals and energy deposits. A similar trend can be seen in cyberspace: in July 2016, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization officially listed cyberspace as an arena for war, placing it alongside the traditional battlegrounds of land, sea and air. In February 2016, US Secretary of Defense Ash Carter told National Public Radio that the US military was deploying cyber tools in the fight against the Islamic State (ISIS). His description of dropping “cyber bombs” on the terrorist group constituted the first public admission of the offensive use of the internet domain by a state. To what extent do the basic rules governing international security –pertaining to sovereignty and the laws of war – apply to these new domains: space, the ocean, the Arctic, and cyber? Until recently, such questions could be settled between the few states wealthy and advanced enough to have access to these domains. However, when it comes to biotechnology and artificial intelligence, the number and types of stakeholders are much more diverse. For instance, a 2015 report in Scientific American explained that compared to the Cold War era, where mutual vulnerability deterred the space powers from extending combat into orbit, the situation today is more complex. Around 60 countries now have satellites in space, and both low- and high-Earth orbits are brimming with scientific and commercial activity. New approaches to governance that take this and the other factors driving the transformation of international security into account are needed.

name: Future Product Development
description: Production systems are at the brink of a new industrial revolution, thanks to a confluence of emerging breakthroughs in mobile connectivity, artificial intelligence, the so-called Internet of Things, next-generation robotics, wearables, genetic engineering, nanotechnology, advanced materials, and biotechnology. The combined swirl of these technologies will transform manufacturing and production systems with unprecedented speed and scope, and will impact economic growth, business models, employment and sustainability. This can result in significant efficiency gains, which represent the promise of the Fourth Industrial Revolution; it is also likely to have a particularly strong influence on the electronics sector. The move towards a more sustainable, circular economy, for example, will involve demand for electronics that can power industrial systems that are restorative and regenerative by design. In addition, a key enabler of the circular economy is the ability to access information about the condition, location, and status of assets, using electronics, in order to help maximize their re-usability and value. Emerging technologies will lead to greater customization, via tools like 3D printing and advanced additive manufacturing, and will spur further innovation in electronics. The industry will need to stay abreast of how these changes are impacting production. One example: tools like 3D printing are now bringing production systems into consumers’ homes.

name: Future of Energy Demand
description: Expanding populations, growing economies, and improving efficiency are all having a fundamental impact on energy demand. Significant change will occur in the next few decades, as the global population is expected to grow from about 7.6 billion to nearly 10 billion by 2050 (per a United Nations estimate), and global GDP is expected to nearly triple by that year (according to a report published by PwC). However, overall energy demand growth has actually been slowing - due to a global shift towards more services-driven economies, and to technology and process improvements that boost both productivity and efficiency. The specific shape of energy demand depends on geographic location. In the year 2000, for example, 40% of global demand was generated in Europe and North America while 20% was generated in developing economies in Asia. By 2040, the situation will be completely reversed - as China becomes by far the biggest energy consumer. This has implications for the production of primary energy, for trade, and for renewables and alternative fuels as countries try to secure their respective energy futures. Even as global energy demand growth slows, total demand is nonetheless expected to increase by more than 25% by 2040. Taking into account current and planned policies, and modelled under the International Energy Agency’s “New Policies Scenario,” an additional $2 trillion in annual investment will be required in new energy supply. Demand for natural gas in particular will likely increase, as a means to deal with the intermittency of renewables and with increasing demand from sectors like aviation, shipping, and petrochemicals. Managing this demand growth while also achieving the Paris Agreement on climate change’s target of limiting warming to less than 2°C above pre-industrial temperatures (especially in light of a more recent, 2018 Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report warning about the consequences of just 1.5°C of warming) will require a rethinking of the supply and use of energy. It also calls for better solutions for mitigating greenhouse gas emissions; carbon capture utilization and storage technology will likely have to play a significant role in the global energy system of the future.

name: Future of Power Systems
description: The planning for electricity systems was traditionally done according to investment cycles lasting as long as 60 years. However, this has now changed dramatically. Record levels of new investment are required for developed markets focused on rapid decarbonization, while fast-growing emerging markets must build electricity systems that can support increases in energy consumption per capita. Regardless of the location, the energy “trilemma” - a concurrent need for access and affordability, security, and sustainability - promises to be a source of tension. Developed markets will look to complete their transition to cleaner energy by supplementing renewable capacity with more decentralized generation, energy storage, and smarter digital grids; meanwhile in faster-growing markets, energy investment will be more heavily skewed towards the basic infrastructure needed to one day provide universal access. In order to help close this gap in power access between high- and low-income countries, developing markets will likely invest twice as much in generation capacity as Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development members. The challenges facing electricity systems in need of greater investment vary. In relatively wealthy OECD markets, policy-makers need to maintain popular support for their related objectives, and set up fair, transparent markets capable of attracting the necessary interest. The most dramatic related technological revolution will occur in energy storage - the growing popularity of electric vehicles will be instrumental for driving down storage costs, and ultimately enabling it to replace the thermal capacity that currently backs up (potentially intermittent) renewable energy generation. In non-OECD markets, there will likely be more of an emphasis on developing the right strategic roadmap for electricity systems, and on developing the regulatory frameworks necessary to support unprecedented levels of investment. The biggest challenge for these markets will be to attract the necessary capital by looking beyond domestic sources and tapping global markets. This in turn will likely require a greater number of effective public-private partnerships.

name: Future of Work
description: The Fourth Industrial Revolution is causing business model changes that will significantly disrupt labour markets. New categories of jobs will emerge, as others disappear. According to the World Economic Forum’s 2016 report Future of Jobs, most industries will require new skill sets from their workers, and 7.1 million jobs will be lost between 2015 and 2020 as a result of disruption. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reported in 2016 that a 20th century bias for skilled, rather than unskilled human workers has evolved into a complete replacement of workers with computers.  The OECD pointed out that even mid-level jobs that require some skill tend to be routine-based, and thus potentially automated. This deletion of mid-level jobs, combined with an expansion of low-skilled service positions, and heightened demand for high-skilled workers, is leading to increased social polarization. According to a 2016 report from the International Labour Organization, 200 million people were unemployed globally at that time, and more than 300 million additional jobs were needed by 2020 in order to provide a livelihood for the next generation of workers.  In a 2013 paper, Carl Benedikt Frey and Michael Osborne of the University of Oxford estimated that in the course of the next decade or two, nearly half of all occupations may be affected by automation and technology. New approaches to job creation and skills development, in both the private and public sectors, are therefore urgently needed.

name: Future of Work in the US
description: New ways of work in the so-called knowledge economy, and the rise of automation, portend a period of profound change for the US labour market. Increasingly diverse technology skills are required of US workers, in order to remain globally competitive. In addition, questions about the impact of new immigration and education policies on the workforce have emerged during the Donald Trump presidency. Just a few decades ago, a job in the US could easily mean a lifelong career with one employer, performing different versions of one role. The increasing integration of technology into the workplace - for both high- and low-skilled jobs - means an American worker may now potentially hold multiple jobs involving diverse skills over the span of a career. This evolution calls for greater flexibility, more training and broader skill sets. According to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics, by 2015, 15 million Americans were self-employed, or 10% of the entire US workforce. The Ubers and Airbnbs of the US sharing economy, for example, have disrupted the taxi and hotel industries, and altered the traditional relationship between employees and employers. The Fourth Industrial Revolution will feature many examples of new, disruptive business models that quickly emerge. The implications of this are significant. Increasingly prevalent technology will impact not just manufacturing workers and lower-level service employees, but also mid-level, highly-skilled professionals. Basic legal work, for example, is already being bundled and outsourced, eliminating the need for law firms to hire junior associates and paralegals, while news is increasingly being aggregated rather than produced through traditional reporting, and so-called Massive Online Open Courses, or MOOCs, may displace a significant number of college professors. According to a 2015 Pew Research Center poll, 65% of Americans anticipated that within 50 years robots and computers would “definitely” or “probably” take over most work previously performed by humans. US policy-makers will need to consider how best to regulate this new economy, where workers may have greater flexibility but less stability.

name: Gender Dynamics of Future Jobs
description: As the Fourth Industrial Revolution takes hold, it will affect female and male workers in distinct ways. Adequately preparing to adapt to related, disruptive changes will include tackling gender gaps - which could in turn unlock new growth opportunities for companies. Household work, for example, could be further automated, and relieve some of the current dual burden for working women. Changes to what have traditionally been men’s roles are also likely to reshape the division of labour at home, and a more holistic approach could be taken to workforce planning. Harnessed in the right way, new, more flexible work patterns and other trends could in theory result in a more gender-balanced workplace. However, there is a real risk that disruptive change impacting business models, and generating a labour market where jobs are being displaced, could actually worsen existing gender inequalities. The World Economic Forum’s 2018 edition of its report The Future of Jobs found that gender parity is one of the top trends driving growth in industries including mining and metals, and oil and gas. The oil and gas industry in particular has suffered from a serious gender imbalance in both its junior and senior ranks. According to a report published by the consultancy BCG in collaboration with the World Petroleum Council in 2017, women represent roughly one fifth of the industry’s workforce, which is a significantly smaller share than any other sector, and women have a very limited presence in both technical roles (often considered prerequisites for career advancement) and in senior management. In 2018, Bloomberg Businessweek published data showing that among 157 publicly-traded oil and gas companies in North America and western Europe, three had female CEOs, and 12 had female CFOs. Other sectors with high gender imbalances include architecture and engineering, and manufacturing and production. The technology industry, which has enjoyed tremendous growth and is often perceived as forward-looking, is also home to significant gender imbalances. According to data published by the World Economic Forum in 2017, both Microsoft and Google had total workforces that were less than one third female, while women held 24% of the leadership roles at Google, and 18% of the leadership roles at Microsoft. Facebook and Twitter, which were founded more recently, also had imbalances; 30% of the leadership roles at Twitter were held by women, and the figure was 27% for Facebook.

name: Gender Gap
description: Chile does not make good use of its available talent. The country has a relatively high level of female educational attainment, with more women than men enrolled in secondary and post-secondary (colleges and universities) programs. However, the country’s level of female economic participation and opportunity ranked 119th out of the 144 countries measured in the World Economic Forum’s 2017 Global Gender Gap Report. Chile’s failure to reap a return from its investment in female education is due to unaddressed cultural, structural and workplace factors: a lack of access to quality care facilities; traditional attitudes towards family and household roles; one of the widest gender wage gaps in the world (31.7% as of 2016, according to the National Statistics Institute of Chile); women’s limited presence in more productive sectors of the economy; and their underrepresentation in decision-making roles at firms including the biggest publicly-traded companies in the country. While they have advanced considerably in recent decades in terms of asserting themselves in the public space in Chile, women have largely maintained a primary caretaking role within families. A more modern labour code that emphasizes co-responsibility for family caretaking could create more opportunities for women, by encouraging their recruitment and job development. A greater prominence for women in the sciences, on corporate boards, and in politics could help prevent the gender biases that develop during early childhood and later impact the professional world. Greater female economic participation could also boost economic growth; a 2016 study by Chile’s Ministry of Economy estimated that for every additional 100,000 women entering the labour market, GDP would increase by an average of 0.65 percentage points. Chile’s government has focused on initiatives designed to reduce gender inequality, though a broader focus on this issue is necessary. Some related efforts worth highlighting include the creation of a Ministry of Women and Gender Equality in 2016, the development of programmes that encourage female labour participation through training and entrepreneurship, the establishment of a goal to attain 40% female participation on executive boards at public companies, and new regulation that promotes diversity. In order to accelerate the pace of change, the Chilean government has sought to foster collaboration between the public and private sectors. One example is a Gender Parity Task Force, launched in 2016 and supported by the World Economic Forum, the Inter-American Development Bank, the civil society organization ComunidadMujer and more than 80 companies. The task force seeks to increase the number of women entering the labour force, and the number of women progressing into management and senior leadership roles, to narrow the gender wage gap, and to raise awareness of the pragmatic business case that can be made for economic gender parity.

name: Gender Norms and Roles
description: The intersection of gender and religion can be controversial. While religion is often viewed as the source of traditional, “backward” attitudes related to gender, the reality is more complex. Many religiously affiliated organizations, for example, are working to improve gender-related development issues. In addition, women often have more influence on religious practices and gender-related standards than is generally recognized. Many development and humanitarian organizations recognize the importance of focusing particular attention on women and girls, by engaging in efforts to increase female access to education, employment, healthcare, and political and business decision-making. While many such efforts are led by religiously affiliated development organizations, this area of work remains problematic, as the role of religion in shaping gender roles is often viewed with suspicion by secular actors. Patriarchy is certainly an element of some religious traditions, though many traditions have women and men working together for gender equality. The diverse perspectives on gender and development issues among religious institutions run the gamut from the ultra-conservative, which seek the preservation of, or return to, ancient traditions and teachings on gender relations, to radical visions of new gender dynamics and relationships for the future. The relationship between secularism, democracy, religion, and gender equality is complex and contested, especially in western countries. In Europe, for example, support for gender equality and the rejection of religious authority have become common markers of identity for many people. Under these conditions, everyone is pressured to demonstrate a certain level of conformity to liberal values, in order to become legitimate, recognized members of national communities. Muslim women, in particular, are caught in the crosshairs of these European identity politics. They are assumed to be victims of patriarchy, expected to embrace western gender roles and dress, and, perhaps most ironically, are often silenced and deprived of influence by the very feminists who purport to defend them. The influence of religion is also evident in the development of women as peacebuilders (examples include the Liberian Women in Peacebuilding Network, which brought Muslim and Christian women together to advocate for peace), and in their leadership roles when it comes to questions of LGBTI (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and intersex) rights - though these roles tend to be highly nuanced.

name: Gene and Genome Engineering
description: As the 20th century drew to a close, biotechnology’s equivalent of Promethean fire appeared: the first detailed sequence of the human genome. Now, the ability to decrypt genetic sequences has empowered us - albeit while creating significant risks. The DNA structure discovered by Watson and Crick in 1953 begat a restriction enzyme that can cleave DNA within seconds, which begat the discovery of biochemical enzymes that process DNA, which begat gene-editing technology that could be used to directly control the expression of intracellular genes within a nucleus. However, it was neither cost-effective nor efficient to manipulate gene expression within the nucleus - a problem solved by the breakthrough discovery of the CRISPR-Cas9 system in the early 21st century. Researchers found that by attaching a specific sequence of guide RNA joined up with a protein called Cas9 to a genome, they could cut and delete (or add) DNA. Soon after its discovery, CRISPR-Cas9 became a global sensation due to its relative ease and compatibility with just about any type of organism. Genome manipulation techniques were eventually discovered that can eradicate or correct erroneous genes, to create recombinant embryos, treat cancer, or prevent infectious diseases. In the near future, gene therapy drugs could be injected, potentially eliminating the need for surgery to avoid genetic defects - such as the procedure the actress Angelina Jolie underwent to address her predisposition to breast and ovarian cancer. Epigenetics, or the study of genetic expression that doesn’t involve changing a DNA sequence, promises future innovation for genome engineering. Epigenetics could eventually enable humans to adapt to, and evolve in, environments such as the atmosphere of Mars. However, genome engineering comes with ethical issues. A Chinese scientist’s successful effort in 2018 to create genetically-engineered babies in order to endow them with a resistance to their father’s HIV infection shocked the scientific community and points to a need for greater global awareness of the perils of genetic engineering technology as a means of artificial reproduction (Chinese officials have since declared that the scientist’s conduct was illegal). Prometheus's gift, after all, had serious repercussions for civilization.

name: Generational Social Values
description: For millennial respondents in the most recent edition of the Global Shapers Survey, a measure of how young people view the world, identity is not about geography, religion, or ethnicity. Instead, most respondents (40.8%) simply saw themselves as “human”; they feel that existing together in the same world, and sharing concerns and desires, serves as more of a unifying force than any easy label. As a group, they are generally concerned about the well-being of others. When asked what would make them feel freer within their respective societies, more than half chose the reply “equal access to opportunities for all.” More than half of respondents said they strongly believe same-sex couples should be able to legally marry, though many young people from the Middle East and North Africa and sub-Saharan Africa strongly disagreed with this idea. One important factor behind the views expressed in the survey was the origin of the respondent. Many of those hailing from countries that score low on the Human Development Index (a measure of well-being based on life expectancy, education, and other factors) do not believe same-sex couples should be able to marry legally, for example, while 77% of respondents from very high HDI-ranked countries strongly believed they should be able to marry legally. Millennials are mostly confident the gender gap will be reduced during their professional lifetime (38.9% “somewhat” agreed with this in the survey, and 25.1% “strongly” agreed). When asked to complete the statement “I would welcome refugees in...,” more than one quarter of survey respondents answered, “my home.” The empathy of young people reminds us all that refugees are human beings in need. Only 7.4% of respondents said they would not welcome refugees in their country, and on a regional basis, young people from North America exhibited an extraordinary degree of openness, with more than 80% indicating they would be comfortable welcoming refugees in their neighbourhood. In terms of staying in touch, nearly 40% of survey respondents said texting or messaging was preferred, though voice calls were the first choice in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, and social networks were preferred in the Middle East and North Africa. Responses were overwhelming to a question about whether young people in general think that the news presented on social media is trustworthy; only 1.3% “strongly” agreed with that idea, while about 22% “somewhat” agreed.

name: Generational Transition
description: Transitioning the leadership and ownership of a family business from one generation to another has typically been a challenging exercise, and is not always well-executed. Successful transitions require a timely letting-go of responsibilities and authority by the senior generation, as successors take charge. Timely transitions help maintain a family’s motivation, and a company’s momentum. Companies and families must empower the next generation of leaders, and develop the resources and talent they need. Historically, this has been a difficult process, and has recently become even more complicated. The difficulty in making timely transitions has been exacerbated, for example, by the increased longevity and active lifespan of the senior generation. The issue is whether this generation decides to remain in place longer as leaders and controlling owners of a family business, or if it instead decides to pass responsibilities and control to the next generation when it is ready. There has also been a change in expectations and interests among younger generations. Members of both Generation X and Generation Y (Millennials) feel ready to assume leadership roles at an earlier age than their predecessors. This dynamic reduces the chance of finding a mutually agreeable period of transition. There is a significant risk that frustrated, next-generation family members will leave the company or lose motivation as members of the senior generation remain in their roles. Businesses are more frequently being disrupted by technological changes, and industries are maturing more quickly. Owners of family companies now need to decide more quickly and more often if they can play the game that their industries require; that is, do they have the capital, talent, and determination to succeed. More family companies will likely fail in the coming decades, in this fast-changing context. Talent, for example, is increasingly a factor in a company’s success, and family companies need both family and non-family wealth creators capable of making important bets on the future. If an owning family becomes incapable of making key decisions for its business, a family company is likely to stall. There is an enormous amount of capital prepared to buy or invest in family companies, held by other firms or private equity funds. A well-run family company could be attractive to these investors. If the transition of a family company to the next generation isn’t feasible, then families, now more than ever before, can decide to sell. This key issue is curated in partnership with John Davis, Founder and Chairman of the Cambridge Institute for Family Enterprise.

name: Genomics and Mental Health
description: Scientists are increasingly looking to genomics - the study of the function and structure of genetic material - in order to better understand the causes of conditions like autism, schizophrenia, mood disorders, and Alzheimer’s disease. Advances in technology have sharply reduced the cost of sequencing a genome in recent years, and now researchers must figure out how to best acquire, store, analyse, and distribute a growing amount of valuable information. Researchers have estimated that the computing resources needed to adequately handle genome data will exceed that required to run Twitter and YouTube; identifying signals for genetic risk in brain-related disorders requires both enormous amounts of data (made possible only relatively recently by technical advances), and the collaboration of a large community of scientists from around the world. In order to continue to advance our understanding of the relationship between genes and clinical traits, scientists need to gain increasingly accurate descriptions of symptoms, treatment outcomes, physiology, and behaviour. In recent decades, there has also been mounting interest in using imaging technology to visualize the brain - with the aim of identifying biomarkers (physical indicators of a disease state) that can help accurately predict a person’s risk of disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, addiction, schizophrenia, and other conditions. As with genomics, the challenges involved in imaging are significant; identifying meaningful signals that may indicate risk through the noise of the normal variation of human brain development and function can be daunting. For both genetics and imaging, cloud computing is easing the difficulty of storing and sharing the enormous amount of data required. Until relatively recently, it was a real challenge to be able to store and transfer just a few genomes, which sometimes required the physical delivery of hard drives. Now, cloud computing and on-demand delivery and pricing can make it a routine task for scientists to access huge datasets - securely, and collaboratively. The results of a 2017 survey of hospitals, academic medical centres, and other healthcare-related respondents published by the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society showed that 65% reported using the cloud or cloud services, with much of that use focused on clinical application and data hosting, and data recovery and backup.

name: Geo-strategic Competition
description: In terms of economic capacity and military capabilities, the gap separating the leading global power from the rest is narrowing as rising powers steadily convert demographic dividends and cultural confidence into economic strength and strategic influence. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, global military expenditure, which showed a brief decline in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, has now resumed its upward course. Spending continues to fall in North America, Western Europe, Africa, Latin America and the Caribbean, but is rising sharply in Central and Eastern Europe, Asia and Oceania and in the Middle East, reflecting a general shift of capability to the east. In spite of international sanctions, the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea is rapidly establishing advanced nuclear weapons capabilities.  The return of strategic competition between strong states with conflicting interests was identified in the World Economic Forum Global Risks Report 2016. Since the report was published, the trend of strategic competition has been confirmed by open expressions of suspicion. The US 2017 Defense Posture Statement identified the task of deterring Russian aggression in Europe as the principal challenge driving defence planning. The October 2016 Pew Research Center Survey of Global Attitudes found that the Chinese public named US power and influence as the top international threat facing the country. Also in October 2016, the Russian Federation Foreign Minister highlighted increasing US hostility towards Moscow, and complained about a series of aggressive US steps that threatened the country’s national security. A sharper sense of rivalry can also be seen at the regional level. As John Chipman, Chairman of the International Institute of Security Studies, wrote in the September 2016 Harvard Business Review, “ A second trend identified in the Global Risks Report 2016 is the relationship of geo-economics and international security. Economic policies continue to be “weaponized” through sanctions. Businesses encounter more obstructions as a result of anxieties around trade, technology transfer and intellectual property, calling into question the reliability of global supply chains, industrial partnerships and crossholdings. This power shift challenges norms of global leadership and institutions of global governance.  Advocates of United Nations Security Council reform such as Indian President Narendra Modi warn that unless these institutions adjust to the changing world, they risk becoming irrelevant. Meanwhile, the demand for wider power-sharing arrangements is reflected in the emergence of the G20 in parallel with the G7. Also in terms of finance, the BRICS New Development Bank and Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank now sit alongside the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

name: Geopolitical Shifts
description: The Arab uprisings of 2011 spurred political transformation that is still unfolding across the Middle East and North Africa region. Syria continues to be plagued by civil war, and split into areas controlled by various factions. In Iraq, the government has restored sovereignty over territory previously controlled by the Islamic State, though the country remains split along ethnic and religious lines. Libya meanwhile suffers from a high degree of polarization, while Yemen was transformed into a theatre of confrontation by a Saudi-led campaign targeting a rebel group with ties to Iran: Ansar Allah (also known as the Houthis). In addition, the refugee crisis has had a profound impact on regional stability. Prompted by economic hardship, widespread violence, sectarian persecution, and climate change, migrant flows remain high. The number of internally displaced persons in Libya was more than 193,000 as of late 2018, and nearly 1.9 million in Iraq, according to figures published by the International Organization for Migration. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, there were roughly 5.6 million registered Syrian refugees as of late 2018. The migrant flows from Syria have strained infrastructure and public services in neighbouring countries, tested the resilience of host communities, and led to more heated competition for limited resources. These geopolitical developments are affected by Western actors, but have led to greater regional influence for both Iran and Saudi Arabia; the countries’ regional struggle is the current defining feature of this part of the world. US disengagement from the region stemming from that country’s experiences in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Libya is likely to continue, if the so-called shale gas revolution makes the US increasingly less reliant on energy imports. In addition, for the European Union, a post-Arab Spring fervour for democratic progress has been replaced by a security-focused approach, particularly in light of the effects of the migrant crisis. As local responsibility shifts to countries within the region, Saudi Arabia has positioned itself as a key player through its partnership with Egypt, while Iran’s clout also remains significant in the context of the crises in Iraq and Syria. Meanwhile Qatar remains embroiled in the ongoing contest between the two.

name: Geopolitical Tensions
description: A nuclear non-proliferation success story suffered a critical setback in May 2018, when President Donald Trump fulfilled a campaign promise to pull the US out of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal - which limits Iran’s ability to enrich uranium, and enables closer monitoring of its nuclear activities, in exchange for greater access to global trade and investment. It is unclear whether the deal will survive among remaining parties. The European Union, for example, has sought to find ways to preserve an arrangement whereby Iran could continue to export oil, and European banks could continue to operate in the country. However, the Trump administration has also re-introduced sweeping sanctions on Iran, which promise to hinder the country’s economic ties to most third countries. The deal’s failure would have wide-ranging implications for regional dynamics in the Middle East, for the EU’s relations with the United States, and for efforts to conclude a similar agreement with North Korea. It could also fuel the already expanding roles played by China and the Russian Federation in international security. As the US turned away from the Iran deal, it focused on nuclear disarmament in North Korea. North Korea has expressed a reluctance to denuclearize in exchange for economic benefits, though a June 2018 meeting between Trump and North Korea’s Kim Jong Un seemed to raise the possibility of an agreement. The unravelling of the Iran deal illustrates how quickly such pacts can fall apart, however, creating potentially dangerous knock-on regional effects; analysts have long feared a nuclear arms race between Iran and Saudi Arabia, for example. In terms of existing nuclear agreements of note, in 2011, the US and Russia implemented an accord that curbed their respective numbers of strategic warheads, launchers and heavy bombers - though it is scheduled to expire in 2021. The issue of tactical nuclear weapons in Europe has meanwhile been sidelined, though a review commissioned by the German Parliament in 2017 found that the country could begin financing nuclear weapons programs in the United Kingdom and France, amid growing sentiment that the EU cannot rely on US security assurances. In the absence of progress on effective non-proliferation policies, a new nuclear arms race is possible. Deteriorating relations between the West and the Russian Federation, and rising tensions in the Middle East as well as between India and Pakistan, are all related causes for concern.

name: Geopolitical and Geo-economic Recalibration
description: Despite fractures opened in its relations with the West in recent years, the Russian Federation can take a leadership role in helping to address international issues. The Russian economy is still being hit by sanctions first imposed by the US and other Western countries in 2014, as a result of conflict in Ukraine. This has aggravated other geo-economic challenges, including relatively low oil prices - though the price of oil recovered in 2018. Capital flows into the Russian Federation remain unpredictable, as business leaders ponder how long political tensions with the West will linger, and how quickly relations with Asia can grow stronger. Prior to Donald Trump’s election as president, some predicted a new era of cooperation between Russia and the US. However, the Trump Administration issued fresh sanctions against the Russian Federation in 2018, for alleged cyberattacks and interference in the 2016 US presidential election. The US also expelled Russians identified as intelligence agents, in response to the Russian Federation’s alleged poisoning of a former Russian spy in the United Kingdom. Relations between the Russian Federation and Turkey have meanwhile improved, as the countries have increased coordination on efforts to deal with the ongoing conflict in Syria, where the US has armed Kurdish groups; Russia and Turkey have hosted related peace talks. Iran remains an important partner for Russia in terms of coordinating efforts in Syria and the broader Middle East. The Russian Federation has supported the international nuclear accord with Iran, though the US pulled out of the deal in May 2018 - and announced plans to renew sanctions against Iran.

name: German Economy and Public Finances
description: Two factors have been crucial for the stability of the German economy in recent history: the investment in infrastructure and modernization following the reunification of East and West Germany that fuelled growth and productivity in the 1990s; and a relatively low-wage workforce both from the former East Germany and other Central and Eastern European countries. Germany increased its federal minimum wage in 2017 to 8.84 euros per hour from 8.50 euros per hour, though that still trailed minimum wage levels in France, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Ireland, and Belgium. Overall, Germany ranked sixth among European Union countries in terms of private sector wages in 2017, and its employers paid 6% less than in France that year, according to data published by the German Federal Statistical Office. In terms of non-wage labour costs, such as pension and insurance contributions, Germany ranked 13th among EU countries, according to Statistical Office data. Germany has a working age population that fell to 65% of the total by 2014 from about 70% in 1990, according to OECD data, and has made potentially costly political decisions such as its effort to proactively transition to renewable energy. Still, Germany’s economy ranked 3rd out of 140 countries in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index, up from 5th in 2017, and the country has enjoyed its lowest unemployment rate in decades. Germany ranked 1st globally for innovation in the Forum’s index, 2nd in terms of business dynamism, but only 31st in terms of information and communications technology adoption. Overall, the country’s GDP grew by 1.8% in 2018, below the European Commission’s forecast 2.3% - though this still resulted in a budget surplus and lower levels of public debt. According a constitutional amendment introduced in 2009 (the “Schuldenbremse,” or “debt brake”), the German government is prohibited from running a structural deficit larger than 0.35% of GDP until 2020, and no structural deficit is permitted at all after that point. While this has contributed to solid public finances, some economists have deemed the policy to be counterproductive. That is because forward-looking public investment made now in digitalization, education, and the integration of newly-arrived immigrants could help solidify Germany’s long-term competitiveness.

name: Giving Money, Not Stuff
description: Planes, trucks, and tents are often what people imagine when they think about humanitarian aid. But from Indonesia to Yemen, people in need are increasingly receiving aid from an ATM or mobile phone. A number of studies have found that sending cash is better than sending stuff; it’s cheaper, more versatile, and more respectful. Donors and big aid agencies have committed to supplying more help in the form of cash. In 2016, cash transfers and vouchers increased by 2.5% compared with the year earlier, to $2.8 billion - or 10% of all international humanitarian aid. The international non-governmental organization World Vision, for example, expects fully half of its spending to be in the form of cash by 2020. Cash aid offers a practical solution for buying goods or renting a place to stay, and injects funds directly into local economies (though health care, counselling, and education can remain elusive, as commercial service providers are rarely an option in crisis zones). In practice, cash aid requires monitoring, and advisory and protective services, especially for those liable to fall through the cracks. As the provision of unconditional cash aid grows in scale, United Nations agencies and NGOs are having to redefine their purpose. Cash threatens the traditional “business model” of many aid groups, because a highly-specialized agency focused on supplying food or shelter, for example, makes little sense for families accustomed to making their own purchasing decisions. On the flip side, greater giving in cash means financial service providers are taking on a more significant role - alongside a percentage of the money transferred. In Turkey, for example, the European Commission provides cash transfers for 1.3 million Syrian refugees, in collaboration with the Turkish government, state-owned Halkbank, the Red Crescent, and the UN (their two-year contract is worth €650 million). Why not cash should be the first question asked before starting any aid project, according to a study published by United Kingdom-based think tank the Overseas Development Institute in 2015. Yet, institutional and technical hurdles remain, some based on misperceptions. For example, cash aid is not actually more exposed to fraud than boxes filled with goods and provisions. And, fears that recipients will spend cash unwisely - say, on tobacco or alcohol - have proven to be unfounded.

name: Global Development
description: While there is growing awareness that religion is a factor to be reckoned with when it comes to tackling environmental challenges, peacebuilding, improving education, and supporting economic growth, there is still a general lack of knowledge about the practical contributions of religious actors across the spectrum to international development work. This applies to the impact of beliefs and behaviour on development, and to the particular ways in which religion and religious actors factor into key development sectors. Education-related goals are at the centre of the global development agenda, though they tend to deal glancingly with religious dimensions, if at all. Religious institutions, however, play significant roles in national and international education systems and approaches; religiously affiliated schools fill critical gaps in rural areas, and in nations with underdeveloped government infrastructure, for example. However, Christian schools in particular have also been associated with colonization, and have often contributed to the marginalizing of Islamic and other minority communities, creating parallel and unequal systems. Islamic schools have meanwhile played an enormous role in providing education globally, but they have become a political flashpoint because they are (often unfairly) perceived as standing in the way of social progress in terms of gender equality, and other issues - and are also often viewed as radicalizing influences. Global health is another realm where religious actors provide key sources of aid, but may also contribute to related challenges - particularly if they are not properly recognized and engaged. One example occurred during the most recent Ebola outbreak in West Africa, when international health organizations failed to connect with religious actors and gain their help in suspending traditional burial practices, in order to limit the spread of the disease. The issue of antimicrobial resistance is another area where religious actors play a huge part. They are often on the frontlines of administering healthcare to rural populations around the world, though their lack of training and resources often contributes to the emergence and spread of drug-resistant bacteria. While religion and religious actors play significant roles in global development efforts, they are often absent from the formulation of mainstream development policy and practices. The development of better data, understanding, and engagement with these actors could help to more effectively aid the poorest and most vulnerable communities in the world.

name: Global Energy Shifts
description: Low energy prices can drain financial reserves, significantly curb public spending, and reduce investment across the Middle East and North Africa region. While oil prices recovered during 2018, there is still a need for industrial diversification in Gulf Cooperation Council countries (the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar and Saudi Arabia); calls for greater diversification, made in earnest during oil shocks, have mostly never been acted upon. For energy-importing countries in the MENA region, low prices presented an opportunity for structural and economic reform, as funds formerly earmarked for petroleum subsidies to help people pay for fuel could instead be used for funding things like education and health care. According to the 2015 International Monetary Fund working paper How Large are Global Energy Subsidies?, removing petroleum subsidies in 2013 could have resulted in approximately $1 trillion in total government savings. Egypt, for example, has committed to deep cuts in energy subsidies as part of an austerity program. That could in turn help the government there to apply any resulting financial benefit to broader economic and structural reforms. Arab oil exporters have historically relied on oil revenue to forge a social contract that guarantees public employment; stability has been achieved via subsidies, and free education and medical care. However, this creates an unsustainable fiscal position, and tends to benefit the well-connected at the expense of everyone else. In addition, it can lead to a lack of strategic development of a country’s labour force. Demand for energy within the Middle East is expected to increase by 60% between 2016 and 2035, according the BP Energy Outlook, creating an urgent need for a more diverse energy mix that includes renewables. Egypt has moved ahead on developing solar power installations, while Dubai completed work in 2017 on a 200-Megawatt solar plant that enables the lowest cost per kilowatt-hour for solar energy in the world. Geopolitical instability in the region poses a constant threat to energy supply. For example, the construction of a direct pipeline from Iraq to the Jordanian port of Aqaba was delayed in 2014 and then re-routed due to security concerns. In addition, fighting between rival rebel groups in Libya over oil infrastructure has put that country at risk.

name: Global Food Systems
description: The world’s population is projected to increase from about 7.6 billion as of 2017 to more than 9.7 billion by 2050, according to the United Nations’ World Population Prospects: the 2017 Revision. This increase, coupled with an expanding global middle class that is demanding higher-quality food, will require a near doubling of current food production levels, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, or FAO. As global food systems become increasingly interconnected, effective coordination among a diverse set of stakeholders will be required. There are significant inefficiencies in food systems. About one third of all the food produced in the world is lost or wasted post-harvest, according to the FAO, while about 815 million people the world remain chronically undernourished. A lack of storage and infrastructure, and a dearth of market information for small farmers, are key reasons for food losses that occur before goods can reach consumers. The potential to craft new, systemic approaches to food systems that include a diverse array of stakeholders presents opportunities to help sustainably feed the world well into the future. One related effort, a US government program called Feed the Future, has appealed to businesses and universities to get involved; according to Feed the Future, it has enabled more than 3 million children to live free from stunting, and helped farmers to generate more than $10 billion in new agricultural sales between 2011 and 2017.

name: Global Governance and Regulation
description: Travel and tourism are vital for the global economy, not least because of contributions from the dominant mode of international transport: aviation. Yet, despite the importance of international aviation, the airline sector has historically been segregated from broader international trade talks by antiquated, protectionist restrictions that remain relatively unnoticed and unchallenged. While the travel industry as a whole has undergone a wave of market liberalization that has benefitted travellers in terms pricing and services, restrictions on foreign investment in airlines have remained largely unchanged since the middle of the previous century. Under existing “nationality” rules, for example, most of the world’s airlines are severely restricted in terms of their ability to sell equity shares, seek out investors, and merge with other airlines. These restrictions increase the cost of capital for airlines, lead to higher prices for travellers, and reduce demand for travel services. This remains the case even as the aviation industry has evolved from a mix of national transportation systems into a complex global network fuelled by technological advances and globalization.

name: Global Health Governance
description: Historically, the government coalitions and non-governmental organizations that have sought to address global health challenges such as pandemics have been primarily motivated by foreign policy interests. However, organizations and initiatives have emerged that take a novel approach to focusing on global health issues. These entities incorporate novel, multi-stakeholder governance structures, and innovative financing models. Their ranks include Gavi, which was created in 2000 in order to combine public and private sector efforts to expand access to new and under-used vaccines for children in poor countries. Gavi estimates that it has helped to prevent more than 10 million future deaths since its inception, and has immunized more than 690 million children - including 65 million children in 2017 alone. According to a study published in the journal Health Affairs in 2016, for every $1 spent on immunization, $18 is saved in terms of healthcare costs, lost wages, and lost productivity due to illness. Gavi’s partners include Merck, GlaxoSmithKline, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which pledged an initial $750 million to set up the alliance in 1999. In addition, groups such as the Global Fund for HIV, Tuberculosis and Malaria and Unitaid have helped to boost participation across sectors, and helped generate sustainable private funding for programs in order to establish viable revenue streams. The rise of new, multi-stakeholder governance models and innovative financing calls for similarly novel approaches to accountability and transparency. As noted in an article published in The New England Journal of Medicine in 2013, the world faces threats that are difficult to address due to inequality and significant social, cultural, and political differences. To that end, the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, adopted in 2015 in order to guide global development through 2030, are central to the future of global health governance - and must be better supported through continued innovation in financing, micro-level programming within communities, and the harnessing of big data in order to increase efficacy. Sustainable Development Goal 3, Good Health and Well-Being, includes targets such as reducing premature deaths due to non-communicable diseases (such as cancers and diabetes) by one third by 2030. According to a UN progress report published in 2017, the decline in premature deaths from cancer, diabetes and other diseases was not occurring rapidly enough to meet the 2030 target.

name: Global Leadership and National Security
description: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been assertive on the international stage, and in 2016 the country hosted the G7 summit, which covered issues including security in the South China Sea. Prime Minister Abe has also advanced what has been dubbed the “Free and Open Indo-Pacific Strategy,” to improve connections between regions in Asia and Africa in order to bolster peace, stability and prosperity. Compared with China, Japan’s engagement with developing markets has been relatively limited. However, Japan has identified ways to better position itself for global leadership, and to that end in 2016 the country pledged $30 billion for infrastructure, healthcare, and education development in Africa. Japan's security strategy, which involves limited self defense together with a strong alliance with the US, relies on its American ally remaining strategically powerful and politically committed to preserving the regional and global status quo. Prime Minister Abe, whose coalition won a landslide election victory in 2017, appears to have formed a relatively strong relationship with US President Donald Trump. However, ties between the countries have been tested by the rising power and assertiveness of China, and the nuclear threat posed by North Korea. Trump’s questioning of the US's traditional alliances may align with Abe's long-held ambition to revise his country’s pacifist constitution, and further expand the role of military. However, Japanese public opinion still generally favours a pacifist identity. Meanwhile Japan's neighbours, especially in China and on the Korean Peninsula, harbour memories of 20th century Japanese aggression, and are mindful of the role that the US-Japan alliance plays in restraining Tokyo’s unilateral impulses.

name: Global Middle Class Consumers
description: As market-based, for-profit production expands into new regions, an expanding global middle class is emerging. While some economists identify members of this global middle class by their ability to purchase a car, the United Nations and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development define membership by the ability to spend, earn, or purchase between $10 and $100 per day. Regardless of how it is defined, the global middle class is clearly making a significant contribution to the global economy. According to a working paper published by the OECD, as recently as 2000 China accounted for just 1% of global car sales, while by 2010 that figure was on track to reach 13%; and while General Motors sold ten cars in the US for every one car in China as of 2005, that ratio was approaching one to one just five years later, according to the report. The mobile phone market tells a similar story - in the second quarter of 2018, Chinese device maker Huawei, which controls nearly one third of China’s smartphone market, surpassed Apple to capture the second-biggest global market share, according to a report published by IDC. Companies and retailers have much to gain from tapping into this expanding global middle class. Research has shown that consumers tend to remain loyal to the brands that they adopt early, and that brands that capitalize on their “initial consideration” can remain successful for decades to come. While in-store experiences and word-of-mouth play bigger roles in emerging markets, middle class consumers in developed countries are asking new questions about to what extent their consumer experiences reflect and enhance the quality of their lives. Some research suggests that economic development and happiness are often at odds. Known as the Easterlin paradox, named for the economics professor who first advanced this theory in 1974, it holds that increased economic options actually hinder the quality of life. As Easterlin himself has indicated in subsequent studies, China is perhaps most emblematic of his theory - as the emergence of a free market in that country since 1990 has occurred in tandem with a declining feeling of individual well-being among the population. The emergence of a global middle class consumer must therefore be accompanied by a consideration of important questions about how we all should best measure personal success.

name: Global Multipolarity and Regionalization
description: In recent years, national and regional priorities have generally overshadowed global interests. The Russian Federation has grown closer to Asia, as the Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) has advanced regional integration, the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation has expanded its membership and reach, and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank has launched its first investment projects. Now, concern is growing about whether regional integration is coming at the expense of global frameworks. The EEU, comprised of the Russian Federation, Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan, has signed a free trade agreement with Viet Nam - while dozens of other such agreements are under consideration, with countries including Egypt, Iran and Israel. In addition, expanded partnerships with regional organizations, including the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), have translated into benefits for the EEU. Chinese-Russian bilateral relations, meanwhile, are growing beyond energy agreements. The countries are cooperating on digital issues, in particular the quest for a more multi-polar internet governance structure. Chinese hardware providers are flourishing in the Russian Federation at the expense of Western companies, while China’s massive Belt and Road infrastructure initiative has involved Russia serving as a key partner in the building of roads, railroads, internet cables, and other telecommunications infrastructure.

name: Global Trade Architecture
description: The Trump administration's wide-ranging criticisms of international trade norms and institutions has affected the global agenda. US efforts to block the replacement of appellate judges at the World Trade Organization, for example, threaten the survival of its independent, third-party dispute settlement system - and no related breakthrough is expected anytime soon. When it comes to preferential trade agreements, a number of significant new deals have moved ahead, including the European Union’s Economic Partnership Agreement with Japan (which entered into force in early 2019), and the EU-Canada Comprehensive Trade Agreement (which entered into force provisionally in 2017). In addition, the African Continental Free Trade Area entered into force in summer 2019, as a means to create a single common market for the African continent. Meanwhile the US redesign of its existing trade deals continues; efforts are underway to ratify the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement in all three countries as a replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), for example. The US is also in ongoing trade negotiations with the EU and China - with most attention focused on the tensions underlying its efforts to seal a deal with China.
