The US has increased tariffs on Chinese goods in order to pressure China into speeding up trade talks and making concessions, while China has responded by raising additional tariffs of its own. The conflict has moved on to non-tariff measures, too. For example, the Trump administration has placed Chinese telecom giant Huawei on a trade blacklist restricting its ability to use American suppliers, based on national security concerns (Huawei has denied that it presents a security risk). Meanwhile, in Europe, the parliament of the United Kingdom has failed to accept a negotiated deal for future trade talks with the EU as part of a broader Brexit agreement. This has not only weakened the UK’s traditional political parties (as witnessed in the 2019 European Parliament elections and in the resignation of Theresa May as Prime Minister), but has also led to insecurity for financial investors and companies as the odds of a “hard” Brexit increase. These trade-related sources of global tension have a significant impact on financial markets around the world, and have sparked a fresh round of debate on the merits of globalization.

name: Global Trade and Production
description: As new markets develop, old markets adapt - and many industries have uprooted production from one location to another. According to recent World Bank data, some of the most popular destinations for offshore manufacturing now include Viet Nam and Cambodia. Meanwhile formerly low-cost locations are finding new competitive advantages; for example, every second industrial robot made is now being shipped to China. In contrast to the quickened pace of production within many regions, overall productivity growth has slowed in in recent years. In public remarks delivered in 2017, International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that another decade of weak productivity growth would seriously undermine global living standards and social stability. Reasons she cited for weak growth in recent years included trade restrictions and a failure to foster entrepreneurship. As they seek to reinvigorate productivity, developed countries are increasingly bringing manufacturing back from offshore locations. According to the US Reshoring Initiative, 338,000 manufacturing jobs were created in this way in the US between 2010 and 2016. In terms of attracting foreign direct investment, the US remains in the global lead, with China, Germany, and Brazil following. However, there has been an upswing in trade protectionism. In 2018, the US imposed tariffs on billions of dollars in Chinese goods, China responded in kind, and the two superpowers have since been locked into related conflict. Meanwhile the United Kingdom is still finding its way toward leaving the European Union, and it remains unclear what the future relationship between the two prominent trading partners will look like. Other regional shifts include the US, Canada, and Mexico preparing to cooperate under the terms of a new trade agreement expected to replace NAFTA, while the Russian-led Eurasian Economic Union is pursuing new forms of free trade cooperation with China and Iran, and the African Continental Free Trade Area is now a reality as dozens of countries have signed on to what may become the largest free trade area since the foundation of the World Trade Organization.

name: Global Value Chains
description: The declining cost of communicating with partners and subsidiaries, transporting items, and moving them across borders has encouraged companies of all sizes to deploy a series of global steps as they assemble and deliver goods and services. The reshaping of regulations via multilateral institutions like the World Trade Organization and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, and via trade agreements, has been an important driver of these global value chains. However, the global value chains in turn pose new policy challenges to these very same institutions and deals - in the areas of sustainability, tax structures, and labour markets. They also raise thorny issues in the context of disruptive trade policies like the US turn to protectionism, and weighty decisions like the Brexit vote. The growing importance of these international supply networks has even prompted some to suggest that trade negotiations should no longer be pegged to a geographic area, and should instead focus on trade along a particular supply chain - which would have negotiators addressing only those goods and services relevant to a single industry sector, such as clean energy or textiles. Global value chains can help facilitate the integration of developing countries into global markets, by enabling them to specialize in services and semi-finished goods rather than entire products. They also provide a means to spread knowledge and standards - and can therefore propagate more sustainable practices (a report published by the United Nations Global Compact in 2015 called supply chains one of the most important levers for business to create positive impact in the world). However, there is a risk that companies will simply opt to route supply chains through areas where sustainability standards are the lowest (it remains unclear whether self-regulation of sustainability standards is sufficient to achieve United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, which were established in 2015 and designed to guide development to 2030). Global value chains may also render national environmental policy less effective, as the environmental impact of a supply chain can be spread across multiple regulatory regimes. There are also concerns about their financial dimensions; value chains have been used to manipulate a company’s tax burden in less-than-equitable ways by targeting specific low-tax geographical areas of the chain in which to report profits, for example.

name: Globalization
description: Global trade was growing at a rate of 8% annually before the 2008 financial crisis; post-recovery, it has slowed significantly. Annual merchandise trade volume increased by just 3% in 2018, and is expected to slow further to 2.6% in 2019, according to the World Trade Organization. Meanwhile nationalist backlash in a number of countries has made global economic governance more difficult and uncertain. The United Kingdom’s planned exit from the European Union is impending, and the North American Free Trade Agreement, or NAFTA, has been reformulated as the “US-Mexico-Canada-Agreement” by the current US administration - which sharply criticized the World Trade Organization while blocking the re-appointment of a WTO body member in late 2018. These dynamics raise serious questions about the future ability of global institutions, already widely panned by those who feel they have been neglected, to provide assistance to those very same people - by coordinating improved international economic cooperation for the greater good. The United Nations sought to provide a framework for this, by putting forward Sustainable Development Goals in 2015 that include eliminating poverty and making cities inclusive and safe. Subsequent progress reports have found that while satisfactory progress had been made on some goals in some regions, insufficient progress had been made on others. Even in countries that have benefited from globalization, too many have been left behind. The US, for example, has successfully leveraged international trade and found countless overseas markets for its goods, while at the same many of the jobs producing those goods have moved to other countries. The number of manufacturing jobs in the US fell to less than 11.5 million by 2010, from 19.4 million in 1979, according to a report published by the Pew Research Center in 2017. The US is not alone; while global trade has helped to reduce inequality among countries, within countries inequality is increasingly problematic. According to the International Monetary Fund, more than half of the countries in the world have seen an increase in income inequality over the past three decades. While income distribution systems are severely under-performing due to neglect, this is not an inevitable result of capitalism. The insufficient attention paid to those denied the benefits of globalization has contributed to the weakening of the very political consensus that long supported it.

name: Good Digital Identities
description: Proving one’s identity is an essential part of everyday life. It is a prerequisite to vote, open a bank account, buy or rent a home, and access health care. In the analogue world, we rely on physical documents issued by trusted authorities, such as passports or driving licenses. In the digital world, our identities are evolving into a more complex construct - as a web of personal information is provided, collected, and shared across multiple devices and entities. The use of digital identifiers associated with people, devices like mobile phones, or sensors enabling the Internet of Things is poised to increase. This will also increase the volume of personally-identifiable information accessible in the digital realm. By the year 2020, the average internet user will have more than 200 online accounts, according to Dashlane (a company providing password management services). Technologies used for identity verification, from biometrics to distributed ledgers, are increasingly used across industries and regions. Yet, an estimated one billion people still have no formal identity, according to the World Bank, excluding them from effectively participating in society. To date there is no common view on what a “good” digital identity looks like. There are multiple models, from centralized varieties where a single institution controls identity-related data (such as India’s Aadhaar programme), to decentralized solutions that are controlled by users (such as the Maltese government’s system enabling citizens to control access to their education credentials). There are always trade-offs involved - between convenience, security, and privacy, and a government’s need to keep citizens secure while respecting that privacy. There is also a significant amount of fragmentation, and a lack of standardization; technology choices and governance frameworks are being figured out on an industry-by-industry, and country-by-country basis. There are risks involved in identity systems built without adequate safeguards, such as surveillance by totalitarian governments. Competing incentives are also possible, as a business model may rely on personal data monetization while a user may want to remain in control of that data. There are some user-centric principles for digital identities that are widely agreed upon: fit-for-purpose verification (such as passwords, or biometric proofs), inclusiveness, utility and ease of use, user control and choice, privacy, and security. Increased global adoption of these principles will be key for ensuring value for users, and for gaining their trust in the institutions that handle their identifying data.  Priorities for collaboration: Building awareness among policy-makers Creating a shared definition of a “good” digital identity Promoting standards for industries and regions Boosting innovation in privacy, security, interoperability, and user control

name: Good Governance in Bangladesh
description: Bangladesh’s achievements in terms of socio-economic development have been impressive. Yet, the country has not realized its potential due to a lack of good governance. The contrast between Bangladesh’s macroeconomic performance and its relatively weak governance even has a name: the “Bangladesh Paradox.” If it wants to sustain its growth momentum, the country needs to address this weakness and improve its institutions. According to Transparency International, Bangladesh has been denied economic growth equivalent to 2.4% of GDP because of bribery in its service sector alone. And, the extent of non-performing loans in the country’s financial system (equivalent to about 10% of all outstanding loans), speaks to weak financial management. However, the government has made some related progress; it adopted the National Integrity System in 2012 to improve accountability, while initiatives have been undertaken to improve public procurement through e-procurement and to increase the regulatory power of the Bangladesh Bank. The efficiency of government ministries has also been addressed, and efforts made to improve service delivery and tax administration through modernization programmes and digitalization. Measures are also being put in place to strengthen entities including the country’s Public Service Commission, Securities and Exchange Commission, and Anti-Corruption Commission. However, if Bangladesh is to increase gross investment as a percentage of GDP to 34%, as envisioned in the government’s Seventh Five Year Plan, and to significantly increase foreign direct investment, it requires more predictable policies and supportive regulation. The country also needs to ensure the separation of powers among its executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government, and the parliament (and its standing committees) must more proactively monitor economic performance. Local government institutions need to be vested with adequate power and resources, and the benefits of the digital economy and e-governance tools must be delivered to constituents. The Centre for Policy Dialogue, a Dhaka-based think tank, has proposed setting up a specialized Banking Commission, an Agriculture Commission to improve incentives and ensure fair prices for farmers, and a Statistical Commission to promote data integrity and reliability. An environment where the people have a voice, and the media is able to exercise press freedom, is essential. If Bangladesh is to have an inclusive society based on distributive justice, gender parity, and human rights, it will require demonstrated political will.

name: Good Governance in Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka has been pursuing institutional reform in the interest of good governance, following a 26-year civil war that ended in 2009. The 19th Amendment to the constitution, for example, passed in 2015, is meant to trim the powers of the so-called Executive Presidency in force since 1978, and share greater authority with parliament. However, public sector reform has been slow and sporadic, and factors including an entrenched bureaucracy have hindered efforts to improve performance. President Maithripala Sirisena was elected in 2015, and has pledged to crack down on corruption. The Right to Information Act, implemented in 2017, was seen as a vital means to improve government transparency and accountability. However, the government has been dogged by political difficulties, and Sri Lanka has failed to show improvement in Transparency International’s Corruption Perceptions Index; it scored a 38 for 2017, where zero equals highly corrupt and 100 is very clean, compared with a score of 40 in 2012. While the government has set goals of increasing tax revenue to the equivalent of 15% of GDP, and reducing the budget deficit to 4% of GDP, better revenue collection systems and more transparent management of public funds will be required. In 2015, Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Public Enterprise Development was established, with a mandate to restructure state-owned enterprises. There are roughly 250 such enterprises in the country. A number of them regularly incur financial losses, and rely heavily on government subsidies. They operate in areas such as energy and aviation, and often crowd out private investment in these sectors while limiting consumer choice. In 2016, the International Monetary Fund approved a $1.5 billion loan to Sri Lanka, and made the reform of state-owned enterprises a precondition for its assistance. A review published by the IMF in early 2018 noted that progress in reforming state-owned enterprises had been slow, though related financial liabilities had fallen from 13.7% of GDP in 2015 to 11.9% the following year. According to the IMF review, three closely monitored state-owned enterprises, electric utility CEB, Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, and SriLankan Airlines, recorded a combined loss for the first half of 2017 that was equivalent to 0.4% of Sri Lanka’s GDP; the enterprises had reported a combined profit equivalent to 0.2% of GDP for 2016.

name: Governance Challenges
description: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) has enormous entrepreneurial potential. Family-owned conglomerates in the region include Thailand’s Charoen Pokphand Group and Indonesia’s Bakrie Group, while Singapore’s SingTel (Singapore Telecommunications) is an example of a government-linked enterprise, and Viet Nam’s Vinamilk is one of its biggest milk producers. However, creating and maintaining a level-playing field for younger businesses is a major undertaking - albeit a necessary one, if these firms are to be integrated into the global economy. Frequently, it is difficult for smaller firms in the ASEAN region to compete against larger, entrenched rivals. In order for the region to fully develop into an economic powerhouse, regional governments need to better  support small and medium-sized enterprises and so-called micro-entrepreneurs, which together make up at least 89% of all business activity in the region, according to the ASEAN Secretariat. Examples of related government development schemes include productivity improvement grants in Singapore, Indonesia’s Start-up Innovator Program (with support from the Ciputra Group), and the Malaysian Global Innovation & Creativity Centre in Selangor. Widespread corruption is undermining the region’s business environment - and has a particularly hurtful impact on small enterprises. The same resources that enable large firms to compensate for weak regional capital markets also enable them to subvert competition; this can trigger a vicious cycle, as corruption undermines the institutions needed to promote innovation. ASEAN collectively ranks poorly when it comes to corruption (Singapore is a significant exception, according to Transparency International). Brunei Darussalam registered a moderate level of corruption in Transparency International’s Corruption Perceptions Index 2017, while Malaysia, Indonesia, Viet Nam, Cambodia, Myanmar, Lao People’s Democratic Republic (or Laos), the Philippines, and Thailand fared worse. Creating a level playing field for businesses can be made more difficult by political instability. Events in Thailand (civil rights concerns following a 2014 coup), Malaysia (a former prime minister facing charges related to a corruption scandal) and Indonesia (the criminal sentencing of a public official for blasphemy in 2017) point to greater precariousness for governing elites. There have been some encouraging signs in the region: in 2018, Malaysian voters ousted a ruling party that had held power since 1957, and the new prime minister has pledged to root out corruption and re-examine government contracts approved by his predecessor; and Thailand is expected to hold elections in 2019, following five years of military rule.

name: Governance Mechanisms
description: Corporate governance involves establishing mechanisms to align the goals of a company’s executive team with those of owners and other stakeholders (customers, local communities) in the interest of fostering sustainable and long-term development. One of the main mechanisms is the board of directors. It plays a vital role in keeping the executive team both accountable, and on track relative to its stated purpose and long-term goals. There has been a lot of discussion about the most effective structure for a board - which tends to depend on the nature of the organization, its market, and its regulatory environment. For a board to be truly effective it must decide on its optimal size, the independence of its members, the means to assess potential risks, and the renewal process necessary to maintain effectiveness. There has been heated debate about how to add diversity (in terms of both skills and backgrounds) to boards, in the interest of enhancing strategic guidance. Another high-profile topic is incentives, or setting the right type of compensation for top executives in order to encourage long-term decision making that is in line with the organization’s purpose. The compensation debate revolves around not only pay levels but also structure: short-term vs long-term, preferred stock vs. options, performance vesting options as well as discretionary bonuses. Research has shown that setting variable incentives tied to long-term horizons is conducive to long-term profitability, an increase in innovation, and increases in employee and client satisfaction. One key mechanism is the ability of shareholders to engage with management and discuss material matters, and to (most importantly) vote on proposals at annual meetings. Shareholders can include anyone from founding families to institutional investors like pension funds, and a significant share will likely be participating via retirement plans. Shareholder engagement keeps managers on their toes - and while not every form of activism genuinely adds value, making managers respond to shareholder pressure helps them to avoid becoming entrenched and insulated. There has been a marked increase in corporate responsiveness to shareholder pressure related to climate and gender equality issues in recent years, as well as a greater emphasis on long-term strategic plans - reflecting the fact that many shareholders now have longer-term investment horizons.

name: Governance and Law
description: Digital technologies have often outpaced the development of related regulation and legal standards, but blockchain has pushed this dynamic to a new extreme by fundamentally challenging the ways that governments manage economies and make policy, and by potentially altering the underlying framework for providing legal services. Blockchain challenges the very meaning of citizenship, and the ways that public goods have traditionally been delivered. It can enable central governments to devolve power to regions, while retaining stewardship over an overall system. The Dubai Land Department, for example, has developed a blockchain project intended to better share property data among multiple parties, including government entities, and secure related transactions, while Sweden’s land mapping and registration authority has tested using blockchain in order to make recording and transferring land titles more efficient. The effort in Sweden could theoretically eliminate fraud, and reduce the time required to complete transactions from several months to several hours. The use of blockchain in regulatory and legal spheres will have a big impact on multiple industries. In the US, for example, the business of title-insurance, which provides guarantees on property claims that might not be necessary if transactions are securely recorded in an immutable, digital ledger, may be significantly undercut by the expanded use of blockchain. In addition, new accounting practices will become generally required, and new auditing processes will need to be developed - as digital code will need to be audited in the same way that traditional legal contracts and financial documents are currently vetted. New means to manage and handle grievance procedures will also need to be developed, as blockchain has a potentially deep impact on accountancy and law, including on the ways that we think about required education for these professions. The Michigan State University College of Law’s Law School Innovation Index, unveiled in 2017, identified five different law schools in the US offering courses specifically devoted to law as applied to blockchains, cryptocurrencies, and smart contracts. Still, even as the World Bank acknowledged in April 2018 that blockchain has the potential to transform industries including manufacturing and energy, the technology remained too nascent for the organization to be able to make general recommendations on its use for international development.

name: Governance and Regulation
description: When more than 1 million asylum seekers arrived at the European border over the course of 2015, it tested the political bloc’s system of rules and regulations governing migration. That year, the European Commission proposed the European Agenda on Migration, designed to better foster a common asylum policy - and to save lives while securing borders. Globally, there is a recognized need to better manage international migration, both at the international and regional level. As migration patterns become increasingly irregular, related regulation - mostly implemented at a national level - is at risk of failure. In the absence of a coherent international regime, many aspects of the issue remain unevenly addressed; these include labour migration (everything from high-skilled technical workers to domestic migrant workers), family reunification, student migration, tourism, smuggling and human trafficking, refugee protection, and remittances. In 2018, an Intergovernmental Conference involving 164 United Nations member states adopted the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration. The compact was designed to better facilitate safer forms of migration, and provide for better cooperation on international migration in its various guises. It includes nearly two dozen objectives that offer a comprehensive approach, and each objective has several associated actions that could be pursued. The compact recognizes the different migration situations that exist globally, and reaffirms the sovereignty of states over their migration policies. Implementation of the compact, on the part of the private sector, community groups, international organizations, and individual countries, will be critical for achieving its objectives. In the lead-up to the conference that adopted the compact, there was a surge of far-right online activism and negative (at times false) depictions of the agreement and its potential impact. This appeared to be similar to the surge of far-right activism experienced during the European migration crisis in 2015 and 2016, according to research published by the University of Dublin.

name: Governance in Nigeria
description: According to World Bank Governance Indicators, which reflect dozens of data sources, Nigeria scored uniformly in negative territory (indicating poorer outcomes) on measures including “control of corruption” and “rule of law” every year between 2007 and 2017. In the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report for 2018, the country ranked 110th out of 140 countries in terms of budget transparency, and 125th in terms of incidence of corruption. In 2017, the Nigerian government launched an Economic Recovery and Growth Plan to focus on boosting economic growth, investment in human capital, and competitiveness. However, the government has so far struggled to deliver necessary reforms. Clearer focus and direction are now necessary, particularly at a time of when major economies including the US and China are adopting or reinforcing protectionist strategies. Ideally, the government will not only capitalize on the free and fair elections held in 2015, but also on the forthcoming general elections slated for 2019, by initiating enabling policies that jumpstart the economy. More fundamentally, however, Nigeria’s problematic governance reflects its colonial experience; economic resources including land, oil, and gas are still largely under the ownership and management of the government, for example.    There is a widely-held perception that Nigeria’s fight against corruption is being conducted with commitment by two agencies: the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission, established in 2003, and the Independent Corrupt Practices Commission, which was established in 2000. While their efforts have been commendable, they might not be sufficient. The country’s legal system in particular (including enforcement mechanisms) requires more robust, determined reform. Barring the resolution of related issues, including those tied to the ownership and management of natural resources, and to general economic and social well-being, the country risks the outbreak of internal conflict. It also risks a failure to redirect resources to areas of serious need; according to a report published by Chatham House in 2017, an estimated $400 billion was stolen from Nigeria’s public accounts between 1960 and 1999, and some $182 billion was lost through illicit financial flows from the country between 2005 and 2014. That misappropriated, common wealth was cumulatively enough to address funding gaps that have contributed to the country’s high maternal mortality rate and lackluster education system, according to the report.

name: Governance of Nature
description: Policy decisions can have a deadly impact on biodiversity. So it is worth carefully considering who, exactly, is in a position to govern the use of land, the oceans, and biodiversity - all of which we rely upon for survival. While the governance of nature was traditionally the domain of governments, a diverse mix of corporate and grassroots groups, along with both supranational and municipal governments, now play prominent roles. This multi-stakeholder governance arose in response to a recognition that complex global issues like biodiversity loss, species extinction, climate change, and the melting of polar permafrost cannot be tackled by national policy alone. In light of increased populism in many parts of the world, it is particularly important that these governing stakeholders now complement rather than compete with each other, in the interest of preserving biodiversity. A single piece of land with a river running through it might represent different things to different stakeholders, for example, based on potentially valuable natural resources like fresh water; while those interests must be accounted for, it must be done in a way that protects and preserves resources. The globalization of natural resources often results in a “tragedy of the commons,” whereby resources are exhausted and accountability for their use does not firmly lie with any single governing group or individual. One example of this is overfishing in the oceans; in regions with lax monitoring and ineffective regulation, fish stocks have been depleted. Off the coast of West Africa, several fish species risk becoming extinct - which in turn threatens entire marine ecosystems and fish-based economies. According to the World Bank, the proportion of fisheries that are fully fished, overfished, depleted, or recovering from overfishing increased to nearly 90% of the total by 2013, from about 60% in the mid-1970s. Additionally, the New Economics Foundation, a think tank, estimates that overfishing is resulting in a loss of more than 100,000 jobs and $4.3 billion annually (the World Bank estimates that exploitative fishing in general costs the global economy at least $80 billion every year). Better public-private cooperation is urgently needed to address related issues, because the way that nature is governed today will determine how much is available tomorrow.

name: Governing Disruption
description: A board of directors has a responsibility to drive the continuous reinvention of an organization - in a way that potentially ensures that it is fit for purpose relative to shifting customer demands and social expectations. Innovation impacts many of a board’s core responsibilities, including long-term planning, people and culture, executive compensation, corporate strategy, investments, and acquisitions. Technological innovation at the core of the Fourth Industrial Revolution now underway is changing the way we live, work, and relate to one another. It not only marks a new chapter in human development enabled by advances that are merging the physical, digital, and biological worlds - it is also forcing the decision-makers guiding organizations to rethink how they can create value and reinvent the ways that they function. While established incumbents are at risk of lacking sensitivity to evolving customer needs, and younger players need the financial resources and data enjoyed by older counterparts, each can gear their corporate governance efforts towards sharing resources in a way that creates value for both parties - and for broader economies.  New collaborative models may require entirely new corporate governance approaches that are much less based on traditional vertical control and siloed mechanisms - while still maintaining accountability to shareholders. The United Nations has emphasized the critical potential for breakthrough innovation to help achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, which are designed to enable a more sustainable global economy by 2030. It is a matter of corporate governance to consider how this innovation can both enable sustainable economic growth and help fulfil a specific organization’s purpose. In terms of investor stewardship, for example, shareholders must be engaged on the topic of innovation in order to better understand long-term prospects both for the business and for society as a whole. Some organizations have specific board committees dedicated to technology and innovation, while others bring on consultants or other external advisors. Boards at the most forward-looking companies consider the long-term prospects of a business alongside its internal capabilities - essentially looking into the future, in order to assess whether a company might be impacted by a paradigm shift in technology and business models, and whether there are related opportunities and risks.

name: Government Innovation
description: "Government" may not be the first thing that comes to mind when one thinks about innovation, but some of the greatest innovations - like space flight and the internet - have only been made possible because governments took risks and provided the resources needed to scale up big ideas. Governments themselves also require innovation. They are generally faced with significant expectations, shrinking budgets, and fragile public trust; adequately responding requires new tools, and entirely new models. Disillusionment has fuelled innovation aimed at making government more representative. Examples of “digital democracy” tools include systems that enable people to receive real-time notifications about issues important to them, new methods of crowdsourcing and collaboration, new means of participatory budgeting, and software that can make online voting secure. Some public-minded innovation draws on diverse pools of knowledge and expertise to solve complex problems. For example, a number of ambulance authorities now use GoodSAM, a mobile system that can alert trained first responders when someone in their vicinity may be suffering cardiac arrest, and also locate the nearest defibrillator. A lot of government innovation is being spurred by new approaches to digitalization, in the form of digital services, smart cities, and open data (made freely available for reuse). Estonia is perhaps a leading example; the country has established secure digital authentication and digital signatures, enabling more online interaction. On a more local level, city governments are weaving the Internet of Things, which ties devices together via internet connection, into the fabric of cities in order to better address hot spots for crime, or to determine where emergency responders should be positioned at different times of day. The London Datastore, a free, publicly-funded data portal, provides datasets to help enterprising members of the public develop solutions for London’s problems; one result is Citymapper, an app that makes use of open data from public transport operators to provide real-time alerts. Meanwhile citizen-generated data is being used by many governments to make processes more efficient. For example, some cities are using information delivered via apps like StreetBump to locate and prioritize potholes for repair. However, government innovation is often stifled by bureaucracy. For that reason, many governments have established dedicated innovation teams designed to overcome the inertia of large public entities and provide space for experimentation.

name: Government Policy and Consumption
description: Government decisions directly impact our ability to buy things. Austerity measures in the United Kingdom, for example, are suppressing incomes and expenditure by about £1,500 per person annually, according to an estimate published in 2019. In addition, central bankers are able to either raise interest rates and restrict the money supply in a way that crimps consumer spending, or to lower interest rates and encourage consumption (some countries have even set negative interest rates in recent years, sharply incentivizing people and banks to buy cars or make loans rather than keep cash on hand). In India, where private consumption accounted for more than 61% of GDP as of late 2018, according to data provider CEIC, faltering economic growth led the Reserve Bank of India to cut rates twice within two months in early 2019. Still, in both India and China savings rates remain relatively high, according to Credit Suisse survey results published in 2019, which can blunt consumer spending. Even among young people between 18 and 29 years of age, savings accounted for 23% of all monthly spending in India, and 29% in China, according to the survey.      While people have relied on governments to occasionally loosen monetary policy and bolster their willingness to take money out of savings and channel it into spending, governments have relied on consumption to draw revenue from value-added taxes, sales taxes, and excise taxes. Governments can use taxes to nudge consumer and corporate behaviour; the US has imposed taxes to correct for the excessive consumption of alcohol and tobacco since 1951, and in 2016 the UK announced a “Soft Drinks Industry Levy” aimed at reducing consumption of the sugar content in soda. In 2018, the UK government said the levy had resulted in more than half of manufacturers reducing the sugar content of drinks. Cross-border tariffs and excise rates can also have a big impact on consumption. As the US and China continue to wage a trade war, it may have a deep impact on global consumption while limiting trade and technology flows. In May 2019, the Trump administration increased tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports from 10% to 25%, affecting more than 5,000 consumer goods and passing on significant additional costs to American shoppers.

name: Government Role
description: Due to government spending cuts, growing investor interest, and a new generation of social entrepreneurs, more governments are experimenting with ways to harness private enterprise for the public good. This is increasingly seen as essential for achieving large-scale, systemic change while reforming public services. However, as neither a conventional business nor a traditional charity, social enterprises blur policy boundaries. Traditional corporate legal structures do not support the dual-purpose business models of social enterprises, and tax systems rarely distinguish between companies that benefit society and the environment and those that harm them. And, while traditional regulation is designed to protect investors from excessive financial risk, it does not recognize that risk can also stem from a desire to create a positive impact. A more innovative public sector could better enable social innovation, by supplying well-designed policy and incentives; governments can also invest directly in social enterprises, act as intermediaries for private investors backing social enterprises, and provide resources and technical assistance (in some countries, issues such as political upheaval and a lack of budgetary support create related obstacles).  One example of positive government support for social innovation is the social impact bond, a financing tool where creditors fund improved social outcomes for underserved communities - which in turn can result in public sector savings. These bonds are contracts signed by local governments, banks, and foundations to do things like help the homeless find shelters, or rehabilitate young criminal offenders. The repayment of related financing depends on how successful a program has been in achieving defined targets, and backers often recycle that repayment back into other projects. The bonds enable governments to partner with innovative service providers and private investors that are willing to assume the upfront costs and risk. Other policy instruments benefitting social innovation include Benefit Corporation and “B Corp” legal statuses, which help for-profit corporations create a public benefit, generate sustainable value, and more carefully measure their impact on society and the environment. Companies operating under these statuses must report to shareholders on how they are balancing interests. Benefit corporation legislation has been passed in more than 30 jurisdictions in the US, while Italy has also adopted related provisions; examples of the thousands of registered benefit corporations include Patagonia and Kickstarter.

name: Great Power Politics
description: Despite being a great power, the European Union has displayed shortcomings when it comes to great power politics. The bloc is based on a Kantian idea that democracies are bound to enjoy relatively peaceful foreign relations, after all; only slowly have member states begun to grasp the power politics now playing out around the world. In reality, there has never been one liberal order, but two. The “thin” liberal order 1.0 was an American project established after World War II, and Europeans added their own liberal order 2.0 after the end of the Cold War - which went beyond borders to consider the rights of individuals. Now, both the American-led security order and the European-inspired legal order are in decline, and no one seems to be lined up as replacements. The US is increasingly retreating from the world stage, while Eurasia is filled with political leaders pulling EU member states in different directions, including Vladimir Putin, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and Xi Jinping. The election of Donald Trump, the first US President in history who does not actively support the EU, has compounded these developments. A nightmare scenario would have Putin’s Russian Federation and Erdogan’s Turkey form an alliance against the EU, in order to weaken its unity. In the Middle East, the EU struggles to make efforts to stabilize the region, and so will continue to deal with repercussions of the instability and poor governance there. When it comes to flexing military might, Germany, the EU’s strongest economic power, currently spends only 1.2% of its GDP on defence - though it has pledged to increase military spending by 8% annually. All European North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) member states have agreed to spend 2% of their GDP on defence by 2024, although it is unrealistic to assume this goal will be achieved by everyone. The EU continues to struggle in a world of great power politics partly because it was not built to play that game. Its power has always been soft; the power of leading by example. The original hope was that the EU model would spread, and become universal. This did not happen, partly because the EU became too idiosyncratic for other countries and regional organizations to follow its example. To this day, many in the EU consider great power politics to be a thing of the past. Correcting this misperception will be crucial for the EU’s survival.

name: Greater Mobility, Bigger Security Risks
description: The cross-border movement of people involves risk, and the number of people now on the move is unprecedented. Global international tourist arrivals increased by 6% in 2018 compared with the prior year, to 1.4 billion, according to the United Nations World Tourism Organization. Technological innovation and demographic shifts have combined to create a situation where there is a general expectation for the free and safe movement of people and goods. Yet, geopolitical realities and security shocks like a pair of Boeing 737 Max crashes within six months of each other in late 2018 and early 2019 have put safety and security (both physical and digital) at the top of the agenda. Air travel is actually one of the safest modes of transportation; roughly 1.35 million people die each year in road accidents, mostly in lower income countries, according to the World Health Organization. Nonetheless, airports have been compelled to add new layers of security following the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Clear opportunities to use technology and data sharing to further enhance safety and security for air travel and other types of mobility exist. Better collaboration among governments, international institutions, and the private sector would be helpful in this regard. The movement of people within urban areas presents its own set of challenges. A 2014 McKinsey study showed that more than a third of people polled would not consider purchasing a car with internet connectivity due to privacy issues, for example, and more than half were afraid of being hacked through a connected car. Cyber breaches are a real threat and can be hard to detect; the US Department of Transportation, National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration and FBI have all warned drivers about over-the-internet attacks on cars and trucks. In recent years, efforts to create more sustainable urban mobility have resulted in their own safety issues. The growing popularity of electric scooters as a carbon-free means of navigating crosstown traffic has resulted in sidewalk crowding, legal dust-ups and fatalities; some cities, like San Francisco, were inundated with e-scooters before local legislators had an opportunity to try and regulate their use. In San Francisco, this resulted first in a temporary ban and then in the belated installation of a permitted system that excluded some of the biggest players in the market, including Bird and Lime. Bird, however, proceeded to purchase one of the approved e-scooter providers.

name: Green Finance
description: The green infrastructure sector is a promising investment class. Climate-smart infrastructure will require about $90 trillion in investment over the coming 15 years, most of it in developing and middle-income countries, according to a report published in 2017 by the International Finance Corporation. The World Bank noted in a 2017 report that in the ten years since it had issued its first so-called green bond (debt raised specifically for environmentally-focused investments), it had issued more than $10 billion in green bonds - and that global green bond issuances surpassed $120 billion in 2017 alone. In an environment of relatively slow economic expansion, lowered technology costs, and political interest in infrastructure investment as a means to boost productivity and create jobs, the appeal of sustainable infrastructure may only continue to grow. However, there are some troubling signs; only $10.3 billion had been pledged to the Green Climate Fund (a United Nations program) as of late 2018, for example, short of the $100 billion that was originally agreed to be provided annually by 2020. The continued, healthy expansion of sustainable infrastructure will require a new architecture of public-private investment, supported by overseas development assistance, government spending, and sovereign wealth funds. Much of the growth in green bond issuance has been driven by China, where the Bank of China and the Shanghai-based New Development Bank began issuing their first green bonds in 2016. Investment in renewable energy has actually faltered recently, according to the International Energy Agency; it reported that in 2017, following several years of growth, combined global investment in renewables and energy efficiency declined by 3% compared with the prior year. Investment in renewable power, in particular, declined by 7%, according to the agency, dampened by Chinese policy changes on supporting the deployment of solar technology. Several factors listed in the World Economic Forum’s 2016 Renewable Infrastructure Investment Handbook indicate that opportunities for increased investment in the sector remain. For example, among the top 500 asset owners including foundations, pensions, and endowments, only 0.4% of total assets under management were tied to low-carbon investments, indicating room for expanded interest. Cost may also play a positive role - in June 2016, the International Renewable Energy Agency estimated that the cost of solar may decrease by 59%, offshore wind by 35%, and onshore wind by 26% through 2026.

name: Growing Inequality
description: Recently, increased attention has been paid to growing economic inequality and to its relationship with current models of global governance and economic policy. Much of this attention has focused on the political and economic implications of inequality. Relatedly, inequality has serious implications for the realization of human rights. Two ideas are crucial to understanding the relationship between inequality and rights. The first is the general reorientation of human rights discourse to include a broader range of rights. Theoretical approaches are myriad, but unifying them is the recognition of the importance of social and economic rights to a wider conception of human freedom. These include the rights to education, healthcare and housing. The second is growing appreciation of the consequences of inequality and poverty for human rights. Though the links between inequality and poverty are complex, both factors affect the fulfillment of rights. Moreover, the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals include the elimination of poverty and reduction of inequality. The challenge then is to identify specifically how human rights are affected by growing inequality and to think through the ways that the human rights framework can be built into policy development. This challenge could not be more pressing. As Philip Alston, the United Nations Human Rights Council’s (HRC) Special Rapporteur on Extreme Poverty and Human Rights, argued in his 2015 Report to the HRC, a human rights framework that does not grapple with the connection between extreme inequality and extreme poverty is doomed to fail. There are a number of potential areas of focus along these lines. To give three: first, tax policy itself is a critical way that states can address economic inequality and protect rights. A comprehensive approach would address internal tax structure but also tax evasion and the presence of tax havens. Second, understanding the links between corruption, inequality, and human rights is crucial. Here, business has a central role to play. And third, the collection and disclosure of reliable data on inequality, disaggregated on the basis of certain markers of disadvantage, is crucial to addressing the problem. It also allows for the development of indicators aimed at measuring progress.

name: Harnessing the "4IR"
description: The Fourth Industrial Revolution will present environmental challenges; it may also help solve many of the environmental problems wrought by other periods of intense industrialization. This industrial revolution is characterized by new ways of thinking about broader systems, rather than individual technologies - it is also about empowering diverse networks of players rather than relying on top-down decisions, and incorporating humanitarian values. That means that the traditional, top-down approach to environmental governance led by experts is becoming obsolete. Effectively overseeing the oceans, atmosphere, forests, and water will require a new batch of leaders working together in an interdisciplinary way. Collaboration will be essential to help connect environmental expertise to others who have the practical know-how and means to develop, finance, and regulate new technologies. These partnerships could redefine both our understanding of problems, and the range of possible solutions. They may also enable stakeholders to better align, and ensure that promising new technologies and business models are not hindered unnecessarily or cut loose and allowed to operate in a way that is disconnected from community values and interests. Some environmental applications of Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies will have narrow commercial value. Others will be public goods, like the internet, and will enable platforms; these will need to be funded like any public good. New models of public and private financing may be needed, to ensure that both varieties are possible. Satellite-interfacing sensors, satellite imaging, data processing tools, and drone technologies are improving the quality of, and accessibility to environmental data. Initiatives like Global Forest Watch are putting data once only available to universities and researchers into the hands of anyone with a mobile phone, while blockchain holds great potential for carbon trading, managing water allocations, and tracking materials. Smart devices, which know when they need to be repaired, last longer and cut costs. Taken together, these new technologies can help us to better address environmental issues. However, this will largely depend on whether or not environmental data can be effectively democratized, and empower a wide range of people. Greater access could dramatically expand the ranks of engaged actors, and form a new global system of environmental management.

name: Health
description: Ghana’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of healthy life expectancy, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 56.00, resulting in a rank of 111th out of 139 countries.

name: Health Policy
description: Successfully transforming the delivery of healthcare will require evidence-based policies that address access and outcomes, while recognizing the importance of innovation - and the right incentives. A nimble approach is needed, in order to meet current challenges, and those that the future will certainly bring. Because of the increasing inter-connectedness of countries and communities, policy-makers must rethink how nations and organizations prepare for, and work together, to respond to both health emergencies and epidemics, and to the rise in antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Pandemics are now occurring with greater frequency, due to factors including increasing urbanization (the number of city dwellers will increase by 2.5 billion by 2050, according to the United Nations), more frequent global travel (the number of international tourists is expected to reach 1.8 billion by 2030, compared with roughly 25 million in 1950), and to the effects of climate change. Global health policies should be developed that ensure a robust infrastructure is established, in order to meet the next crisis with adequate resources for research and sufficiently brief response times. The HIV/AIDS epidemic provides just one example of how effective global health policies require continued diligence in promoting innovative therapies, supporting patients, and continuing to improve prevention strategies and the monitoring of the spread of disease. In most parts of the world, life expectancy is increasing as a result of better public health measures, nutrition, sanitation, medical practices, and technological innovation. According to the Global Coalition on Aging, the number of people in the world aged 60 or older will reach 1 billion by 2020, and 2 billion by 2050. This will create new demands on systems that are already stretched to capacity as they accommodate populations with diverse health needs including chronic diseases, age-related conditions, and disabilities. Addressing this will require new models of care and payment reform, robust data collection to analyse the outcomes and consequences of novel methods, and structural solutions for workforce development challenges. Alongside issues of capacity are related concerns about pricing and access. While medical advances have the potential to substantially improve health around the world, these benefits can only be truly realized if access is broadly available. Otherwise, disparities will only increase. One potential solution may be alternative payment models, which could serve to alleviate short-term budget issues and ensure availability, while still encouraging new research.

name: Health and Functional Ability
description: As people age, their health is determined by specific diseases, and by a combination of health conditions and the natural impact of ageing on their ability to function. According to the World Health Organization, measuring someone’s functional ability, or the combination of their physical and mental capacities together with their environment, is a stronger measure of overall health than disease states - and the WHO defines “healthy ageing” as maintaining functional ability across the life course. Health becomes more complex with age, in terms of physical and mental capacities (referred to as “intrinsic capacity”), and functioning; one may experience chronic disease, but that does not tell the whole story of one’s health, or the impact it is having on one's life. Certain conditions can be easily controlled with medication, for example, while others may require multiple treatments that lead to side effects. Still others may require corrective tools to perform simple tasks. In addition, so-called multi-morbidity, or experiencing numerous chronic conditions at the same time, can lead to health concerns that traditional disease classifications fail to capture. Despite the potential decline of functional capacity, healthy ageing can still be promoted by maintaining and building intrinsic capacity, and enabling older adults to continue to do the things that are important to them. Addressing conditions once viewed as normal deterioration as we age, such as declines in vision, hearing, and muscle mass, is critical for effective health policy. Preventive action is central to promoting healthy ageing, and caregivers, physicians, and other healthcare professionals share a responsibility to help maintain older adults’ functional abilities. The environments in which we live can also foster healthy ageing, by encouraging social participation. The role of the environment only becomes more important, as capacity declines. Community health services, for example, can promote healthy ageing by providing access to information and services. Assistance with mobility is another aspect of environment that can remove functional barriers. Transportation and infrastructure must become more age-friendly, to ensure mobility for older citizens - and in turn increase social participation, keep older citizens included in activities that bolster commerce, and help expand economies. Declines in functional ability affect us all, at some point. For older people with significant losses of capacity, long-term care systems will be critical for helping older adults everywhere age with the dignity and respect that they deserve.

name: Health and Wellness
description: The world is generally becoming more health-conscious. However, people continue to struggle with hunger, “hidden hunger” (a lack of vitamins and minerals one may not be aware of), and “overnutrition” (obesity). The problem of chronic hunger is growing worse; the estimated number of undernourished people in the world rose to 815 million as of 2016, from 777 million in the prior year, according to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization’s 2017 report The State of Food Insecurity and Nutrition in the World. The recent increase actually followed a steady decline, according to the report, and reflected worsened situations in sub-Saharan Africa, South-Eastern Asia and Western Asia - particularly in conflict zones affected by drought or floods. Stunting, or impaired growth as a result of poor nutrition, affected 155 million children under the age of five, according to the report, and wasting, or the lack of appropriate weight, affected one out of every 12 children as of 2016. Excessive weight is also a global problem. Childhood obesity is increasing in most regions of the world (41 million children under the age of five were overweight as of 2016), according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization’s report, and adult obesity is increasing everywhere. Non-communicable diseases, driven by risk factors including a poor diet, will lead to a cumulative loss of global economic output equal to $7 trillion between 2011 and 2030, according to a report released by the Harvard School of Public Health and the World Economic Forum. The roles that agriculture and the food and beverage industry can play in addressing health and undernourishment are significant. Through increased coordination and collaboration, there are opportunities to reduce malnutrition and create a positive impact. A number of companies are finding that delivering healthier products makes good business sense. Nestle, for example, created a Health Science unit to develop nutritional products, while sales in general of sugar- and salt-heavy packaged foods have declined. In the US, large sellers of consumer packaged goods (including packaged foods) saw their collective market share decline between 2011 and 2015, while small and mid-sized firms, including healthy food producers like protein bar maker Quest Nutrition, saw their collective market share increase during the same period, according to a report published by the consultancy BCG.

name: Healthcare Applications and Side Effects
description: Before the widespread release of commercial virtual reality (VR) headsets in the mid-2010s targeting mainly gaming and cinephile audiences, VR had been extensively used for a couple of decades in a wide range of medical applications, from healthcare training to physical rehabilitation to education. High-end immersive surgery simulators provide a risk-free setting for physicians to practice life-saving procedures. VR has also proven itself to be an effective and engaging tool for training practitioners for patient interactions and procedures, an improvement over conventional training materials. For instance, researchers at the University of Southern California Institute for Creative Technologies have developed artificial intelligence agents that clinicians can use to practice skills required to conduct diagnostic assessments. Since the late-1990s, VR has also been successfully used to treat patients with depression and anxiety, as well as conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in burn victims and war fighters. Studies conducted by Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Oxford and University College London, respectively, have also shown that VR treatments can be effective for the treatment of paranoia, drug addiction, as well as a variety of phobias. Due to the level of immersion it provides to users and the technology’s ability to block distractions from the physical environment, soothing VR experiences have also been beneficial for therapeutic treatments and pain management. In particular, they have been successful in easing the pain of burn victims or cancer patients undergoing treatment or rehabilitation. These palliative effects can be one of the greatest benefits of VR as survival rates can be increased through pain reduction. VR can also be a powerful tool for changing behaviors and building empathy; Planned Parenthood, for example, has created a VR film that relays the experience of a woman crossing a line of protestors in order to receive medical care. With VR technologies becoming mainstream, a shift toward safe, patient-centric and individualized healthcare is therefore promising in the near future. While VR can have a positive impact on the health of patients, concerns about its safety and potential danger to our health and social developments must be kept in mind as the technology develops. Beyond motion sickness and nausea caused by current technological limitations, long-term effects must be assessed, especially when the level of VR experiences become increasingly real. The ease of access with which pornography can be accessed means that sexual-themed VR content is already on its way. The immersiveness of VR sex could lead to severe addictions and potentially make real-world relationships less appealing for many people. Consequently, such technology could lead to a weakening of marital bonds and possibly a rise in divorce rates in the long term. Other addiction issues such as aggression, violence and isolation - similar to those observed in other technologies such as smartphones or video games which are not nearly as immersive as VR, need to be carefully investigated.

name: Healthcare Data
description: Medical researchers are increasingly make use of so-called DNA biobanks, or troves of genetic and medical record data that can be analysed relatively quickly thanks to increased computing power - in order to identify genes that are linked to specific health disorders. The Vanderbilt University Biobank in the US, for example, stores blood and tissue samples from roughly 2.8 million participants, and DNA samples from about 270,000 people; according to a blog post published by the Mayo Clinic in 2018, the effort could help identify ways to intervene sooner, and to offer earlier treatment for patients at risk of developing disorders. However, there are serious ethical questions to consider in relation to the widespread collection of data like genetic information: who should be authorized to gain access to someone’s personal genetic profile, for example, and how can genetic privacy be best protected. The private company 23andMe, for example, offers people the chance to both have their genetic information analysed, and to submit that data for the purposes of company research - raising concerns both about doing so without consulting with a trained medical professional, and about providing sensitive information like this to a private entity. The use of big data techniques, or the efficient sifting through massive, complex data sets in order to garner insights, is becoming increasingly prominent in the world of health care in ways that go beyond the use of genetic information. The growing use of wearable devices, for example, provides a means to directly connect things like glucose monitors to digital apps, which in turn can provide healthcare providers with ways to monitor an individual’s glucose profile over time. In addition, the combination of wearable devices and the Internet of Things, which can string multiple everyday devices together via an internet connection, creates a broad range of possibilities in terms of collecting and analysing data in order to study the health implications of daily habits, or monitor the elderly. However, there are important related legal and ethical issues. In The Fitbit Fault Line, an article published in the Yale Journal of Health Policy, Law, and Ethics in 2016, the author argued that because employers were beginning to collect and use employee health data mined from wearable devices in new and barely-regulated ways, it presented an opportunity to consider how best to legally protect these employees from the potential misuse of this data.

name: Healthcare Delivery Systems
description: People are living longer, and the quality of treatment for diseases like diabetes and cancer has improved, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. However, at least partly as a result of these improvements, healthcare spending has increased and now accounts for about 9% of GDP on average in OECD countries; meanwhile there is ample evidence of lingering inequality and inefficiency in terms of healthcare delivery, according to an OECD report published in 2017. According to the report, the percentage of the population covered by government and private health insurance for core services (such as doctor consultations and surgical procedures) is less than 95% in seven OECD countries, and is lowest in the US, Greece, and Poland. Greece, where 86% of the population was covered as of 2015, is still being affected by a lack of coverage for the long-term unemployed following the financial crisis, according to the report.   The cost of healthcare continues to be a serious impediment for many people around the world. The share of the population in OECD countries foregoing consultations due to cost is as high as 33% in Poland, according to the OECD report, 22.3% in the US, and 20.9% in Switzerland. The cost of prescribed medicines is also limiting access - 18% of the US population reported foregoing prescribed medicines, as did 11.6% in Switzerland, according to the report (the figure was as low as 2.3% in the United Kingdom, and 3.2% in Germany). In developing countries, the fact that health coverage tends to be paid for through taxes and salaries means it is inaccessible for the as much as 70% of the people in these places working in the unregulated, grey economy, according to an article published by the World Economic Forum in 2015. Coupled with a rise in chronic disease in these countries, there is a growing need to figure out ways to address related issues such as a lack of preventive care. Some solutions being developed involve bringing care directly to people - India’s Social Health Activist programme is designed to train 1 million community health workers, for example. Meanwhile digital solutions are also being devised; like many developing countries, Gabon is experiencing a surge in internet and mobile phone use - and it has sought to capitalize on that by boosting public access to health apps, according to a report published by the World Bank in 2016.

name: Healthcare Human Capital
description: In the US, about 2.3 million new health care workers will be needed by 2025 in order to adequately take care of the country’s ageing population, according to a report published in 2018 by staffing consultancy Mercer, while in the United Kingdom, the National Health Service is suffering from a severe shortage of nurses - with one part of England able to recruit just one nurse per every 400 vacancies, according to statistics published in 2018. While a lack of funding and poor pay have hurt the NHS’s ability to recruit, the result has negatively affected the quality of care and even threatened lives. Worldwide, an imbalance between available skills and market needs is having a tangible effect on healthcare system productivity and innovation. As political and business leaders assess a shifting disease burden landscape, the global shortage of health workers remains one of the biggest related challenges. In 2013, the World Health Organization projected that by 2035, the global shortage of health workers would increase from 7.2 million to 12.9 million. The constant migration of qualified health workers to countries that may have better working conditions or career opportunities has meanwhile left people in some regions with unequal access to health care, according to the WHO. The World Health Assembly adopted a Global Code of Practice in 2010, which aims to establish and promote ethical international recruitment of health personnel and to strengthen health systems; as of 2016, nearly one quarter of member states were considering changes to laws or policies to conform with code recommendations, and 70% reported that migrant health workers enjoyed the same legal rights and responsibilities as domestically-trained personnel. Ideas that have been proposed to help ease the burden on health care workers and health systems around the world include more flexible scheduling, efforts to specifically attract younger, more tech-savvy workers who might otherwise take jobs at firms like AirBnb or Google, and broader training and development programs that can expand a worker’s skills repertoire. Until adequate solutions for staffing issues emerge, the costs will be heavy in terms of both quality of care and financial well-being; in the US, the cost of so-called “travel nurses” who move from place to place to temporarily fill empty but essential positions doubled between 2014 and 2017, to $4.8 billion, according to Staffing Industry Analysts.

name: Healthcare Technology
description: Health technology innovation has given us basic tools like the electronic medical record, as well as futuristic developments like robotic surgery and precision medicine (which makes use of a patient's genetic profile and environment in order to diagnose and provide treatment). While biomedical research is offering up new medicines, devices, and mobile applications that can cure once-fatal diseases and more effectively manage chronic disease, many parts of the world still lack access to even the most basic healthcare. According to World Health Organization Global Health Observatory data, more than half of the deaths in the African Region during 2015 were the result of maternal, neonatal, and nutritional conditions. Expanding access to care and health technologies across the globe remains a challenge; the use of mobile technology presents intriguing related opportunities. The overall “mHealth” market was worth an estimated $23 billion by 2017, according to SNS Research, and is expected to grow significantly. In sub-Saharan Africa, which bears the highest disease burden in the world, and where mobile phone penetration rates have increased significantly in recent years, only 15% of the population has access to private health care, according to a report published by Deloitte in 2014, while more than 80% of private health care payments are made out of pocket. In response, mobile operators in sub-Saharan Africa have begun to better position themselves to facilitate health payments that are made via mobile devices, according to the Deloitte report; in Kenya, for example, the operator Safaricom has partnered with insurer Changamka Microhealth to enable health care payment via the M-PESA mobile money service. Meanwhile the deployment of so-called eHealth is also expanding. According to a report published by the World Health Organization in 2016, by 2015, 70% of European Union member states had national eHealth policies or strategies, and nearly all of them had financial support specifically for implementing these efforts. However, in 2018, the European Commission published a communication on the digital transformation of health and care, which cited slow and varied uptake of digital health solutions within the EU to date, and identified three areas for improvement: secure access to health data across borders; better access to advanced research; disease prevention and "personalized" health care (another term for precision medicine); and digital tools for citizen empowerment.

name: Heritage Protection and Cultural Sustainability
description: The Catalogue of Endangered Languages features entries from 180 different countries and territories; Germany has 11, including Upper Sorbian and Western Yiddish, while the US has 165, ranging from Aleut to Zuni. Elements of intangible heritage, such as language, customs, ceremonies, rituals and traditions, are under threat due to the politics and forces of globalization - as societies and technologies change at a faster rate than ever before. Both these intangible and "tangible" (art works and monuments) heritage contain the diversity of human experience, and a framework for both individual and community identity. They nurture resilience in the face of change or crisis. It is therefore vital to protect and sustain what has been handed down to us from previous generations, in the face of multiple threats: climate change; armed conflict; neglect; unrestricted development; unregulated agricultural practices; and unsustainable tourism. While these dangers exist worldwide, they tend to worsen exponentially under crisis conditions. Not since World War II has the world’s cultural heritage faced such a threat of destruction as a result of conflict. Recent examples include the demolition of shrines in Timbuktu, Mali, in 2012 by an Islamic extremist linked to Al Qaeda (for which the extremist was found liable for $3.2 million in damages by an international court in 2018), the destruction of the Mosul Museum in Iraq by Islamic State militants who released recordings of the carnage in 2015, and the targeting of the ancient Roman site of Palmyra, Syria by the Islamic State, also in 2015. As the physical manifestation of our shared history, these archaeological sites, archives, libraries and museums are powerful symbols, making them targets for violence designed to tear apart the fabric of communities. Cultural heritage sites are also damaged by the black market in stolen artefacts and cultural objects. Large-scale evidence of looting at archaeological sites and museums by the Islamic State suggests that this plays an important role in the group’s financing. According to the Iraqi State Board of Antiquities and Heritage, the Islamic State both steals and sells artefacts itself, and sells permits to loot artefacts. Preserving and protecting cultural heritage must be included in conflict and crisis planning; in regions suffering from conflict, cultural heritage can play a crucial role by providing a basis for rebuilding. This key issue was curated in partnership with Huib Schippers, Director of Smithsonian Folkways Recordings at the Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage, and Katharyn Hanson, Fellow at the Smithsonian Museum Conservation Institute.

name: Housing, Wealth and Affordability
description: The global inflation of real estate prices has helped to shine a spotlight on broader issues related to housing affordability, wealth inequality, and inclusive economic growth. Due in part to the upward creep of home prices relative to income levels in many markets around the world, central banks and governments have sought to put measures in place to ease the financial pain for potential buyers. While policy-makers must attempt to prevent a resulting onset of housing bubbles, and ensure that people do not accumulate excessive debt, they must also recognize property as a store of value and means of wealth (a report published by the US Federal Reserve in 2018 noted that household wealth in the country had reached a record level in the last quarter of 2017, due in part to a roughly $500 billion increase in real estate value in the period). The general affordability of housing and the ability to accumulate wealth through property ownership depend, in part, on access to sources of financing and the availability of mortgage products - and on individual homeowners’ financial behaviour. Government intervention can be essential for helping to ensure housing affordability, for example by making efforts to raise levels of financial literacy, by helping to facilitate capital markets, by providing alternative funding sources and ways to mitigate risk, and by provisioning adequate amounts of public housing.

name: Human Capital
description: The travel and tourism industry directly and indirectly accounted for roughly 10% of the jobs in the world in 2016, and is expected to account for 11% by 2027, according a report published by the World Travel & Tourism Council in 2017. For every 30 new tourists traveling to a destination, it is estimated that one new job is created.
