However, due the increasing online surveillance of activists, and to the severe punishments being handed out to whistle­blowers, many organizers of social movements are reverting to offline planning and coordination. According to the results of a study published in the Berkeley Technology Law Journal in 2016, revelations about US National Security Agency online surveillance in 2013 caused a significant decline in traffic to privacy-sensitive Wikipedia articles, demonstrating how government surveillance can impact online activity. The revelations about the NSA caused privacy advocates to wonder if the role of the internet as a whole as a tool for free speech and assembly might be diminished. The case of Edward Snowden, the whistleblower responsible for the NSA revelations who has evaded arrest and is now living in exile in Russia, is also believed to have had a chilling effect on the use of online tools to organize and draw attention to perceived injustices. DeRay Mckesson, an activist and supporter of Black Lives Matter in the US, told a reporter in 2015 that he assumed the government was reading all of the group’s communications. However, Mckesson and other Black Lives Matter activists have not shied away from social media, and continue to rely heavily on Twitter, for example. Some activists have actually proactively used social media to dupe authorities, and facilitate their offline activity; during Arab Spring protests in Bahrain and Egypt in 2011, for example, activists used Twitter to post where activity would supposedly be occurring in order to lure police there, then used phone calls or face-to-face communication to move the activity to another location, according to a report published by USAID in 2016. However, many activists and others interested in particular issues have simply avoided using the internet to organize or educate themselves, due to privacy concerns. A study published by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration in the US in 2016 found that 29% of households responding to a survey indicated they were concerned about government data collection, and therefore refrained from expressing controversial or political opinions online.

name: India’s Missing Infrastructure
description: Infrastructure development in India has been poorly planned and executed, hamstringing the country’s transition from lower-middle-income economy. According to the government’s 2017-18 Economic Survey, India requires nearly $4.5 trillion in investment by 2040 to meet its infrastructure needs. Based on existing trends, this is unlikely to happen. The consequences are many; adequate power and transportation infrastructure is essential for strengthening India’s troubled manufacturing sector, for example. Historically, countries like China and Japan have shown that heavy investment in infrastructure, coupled with a healthy manufacturing base, can generate rapid growth - while research has established the crucial role infrastructure investment has played in other countries around the world. The absence of infrastructure development means India’s export competitiveness is weakened, as is the ability of domestic Indian firms, which are predominantly small, to scale up. Not least, the failure to provide adequate infrastructure has a degrading effect on the quality of the labour force, by depriving people of the basic prerequisites for participating in a modern economy - such as the roads they need to commute, and the reliable electricity they need to keep the lights on at home. So far, India’s private sector has failed to bridge the infrastructure gap. While infrastructure companies’ high debt levels and an inability of banks to lend have slowed the pace of investment considerably, the public-private partnership model widely used for funding projects elsewhere has stalled; inefficient and inequitable allocation of risk may be a major factor in this failure. Over the past two decades, successive governments in India have attempted to boost infrastructure development. And, there has been reasonable progress in some areas - such as rural electrification, and the road and highway network. The government’s allowance of as much as 100% foreign direct investment in the domestic road sector may also help, particularly now that new, more viable infrastructure project funding models such as “hybrid annuity” are gaining steam. But significant challenges remain: public investment in infrastructure is constrained by simple fiscal math, and relaxing the norms of foreign direct investment, or floating new models for partnering with the private sector, will have limited impact without corresponding regulatory reform, the presence of strong dispute resolution mechanisms, and greater clarity on contentious issues such as land acquisition.

name: India’s New Data Economy
description: The datafication and digitalization of the global economy pose unique opportunities and challenges for developing countries like India. They can each play critical roles in catalysing financial inclusion, boosting innovation and productivity, and generating inclusive economic growth. But without the right regulatory frameworks and digital infrastructure, they also have the potential to create skewed markets where economic benefits accrue to the few and not the many. India’s digital economy has enormous potential. It is one of the fastest growing in the world and features the second-largest (behind China) digital consumer base - made up of more than 1.2 billion mobile phone users and 560 million internet subscriptions. The pace has been frenetic; over 207 million Indians got online between 2013 and 2017, as smartphone adoption quadrupled. The digital payments sector provides one demonstration of the economic effects of this mass digitalization. It is expected to more than double in size from $64.8 billion in 2019 to $135.2 billion by 2023, thanks to a compound annual growth rate of 20.2%. Regulating such markets can be tricky, because they possess unique attributes like vast economies of scale, network effects, and minimal marginal costs. A lack of clarity about data ownership and collection, and the complex, data-based business models of companies such as Google and Facebook that offer “free” products and services further muddy the waters. Regulation that is too lax can facilitate unhealthy business practices, skewed growth, and the creation of a digital elite. Overly harsh regulation, meanwhile, can stifle innovation and undercut the potential benefits of datafication. Indian policy-makers and industry groups have taken steps to address this challenge. They are putting the building blocks of soft digital infrastructure in place, including the Account Aggregator (for synchronizing financial information), the United Payments Interface, DigiLocker (cloud-based accounts for citizens), and Data Empowerment and Protection Architecture. This “IndiaStack” architecture has the potential to spur inclusive economic activity and empower people. Regulators are still grappling with critical issues such as personal data protection and digital competition, however, and much remains to be done to create regulatory frameworks that are tailored to India instead of simply borrowed from other economies. Given the rapidly growing nature of India’s digital economy, it is critical that policy-makers seek to maximize benefits while minimizing potential harm.

name: Indigenous Peoples
description: Australia’s First Peoples (Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders) constitute 3.3% of the country’s total population of roughly 24.5 million, and have one of the oldest living cultures in human history. White settlement has profoundly impacted all aspects of their lives. The legacy of 200 years of systemic racism is that the majority of Indigenous Australians, particularly in remote areas, remain disadvantaged and impoverished. Indigenous mortality rates are relatively high, as are reported rates of diabetes, heart disease, smoking-related cancer, alcoholism, and psychological distress. Unemployment and under-employment rates are also high, especially among young people in remote communities. Imprisonment rates are 12 times higher than those for Australia’s adult population as a whole, and juvenile detention is 24 times more likely than it is for non-Indigenous citizens. Meanwhile school retention rates are relatively low, as are the numbers of students completing university studies. Government programmes meant to address injustice and inequality are rarely based on actual consultation with affected communities, and are often criticized. In addition, government policy has failed to recognize the relevance of Indigenous cultural institutions and modes of governance to improving resource management and sustainable development. Since the 1960s, civil rights campaigns have drawn increasing numbers of Indigenous and non-Indigenous activists together to press for government action. In a 1967 referendum, Australians voted to include Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in the census; in the 1970s, legislation recognized Aborigines as traditional landowners; in 1992, the High Court of Australia recognized the historic land claims of Indigenous peoples in a landmark case; and, in 1996, the court ruled that pastoral leases (where public land is leased for grazing) do not necessarily extinguish native title rights. In 2008, then-Prime Minister Kevin Rudd formally apologized to Australia’s First Peoples for laws and policies that had inflicted suffering and loss, and committed to improving Indigenous life expectancy, child mortality rates, access to early childhood education, educational achievement, and employment. While an increasing number of non-Indigenous Australians see reconciliation and Indigenous rights as a national responsibility, progress has been slow. Adequately ensuring that First Peoples have a voice in public debate continues to be a point of contention. In 2017, a constitutional convention brought together more than 250 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leaders. The majority called for a “First Nations Voice” in the Australian Constitution (later rejected by former Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull), and for a process of related agreement-making and truth-telling.

name: Industrial Biotechnology
description: Industrial Biotechnology, also known as “white” biotechnology, involves the sustainable production of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, food, fibres, textiles, and energy. White biotechnology is often referred to as the third wave of biotechnology, following “red” biotechnology (medical-related) and “green” biotechnology (agriculture-related), and it has become a powerful means to address climate change, mounting energy demand, the depletion of fossil-fuel resources, and environmental issues including petroleum-based plastics and micro-plastics pollution. The field’s underpinning technologies are mainly based on the engineering of microbial hosts, and it has been boosted over the course of the past decade by scientific breakthroughs in metabolic engineering, synthetic and systems biology, and advanced cultivation techniques. In particular, the recent establishment of systems metabolic engineering (combining metabolic engineering with systems biology, synthetic biology, and evolutionary engineering) has led to a dramatic advances. Through the comprehensive optimization of existing methods, and the creation of new methods, the spectrum of possible commercial products has been expanded dramatically - including healthy food products that can be used to combat malnutrition in impoverished parts of the world. Compared with traditional, fossil fuel-based chemical processes, an industrial biotechnology process completed via a single fermentation can be a way to make relatively affordable products that help protect the environment. As a result, the total industrial biotechnology market is expected to grow at a rate of nearly 9% annually, and reach a total size of $472.3 billion by the end of 2025. According to a study published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, The Bioeconomy to 2030: Designing a Policy Agenda, industrial biotechnology will account for 39% of all economic value generated by biotechnology by the year 2030. Bioethylene, for example, is expected to account for as much as 40% of all plastic polyethylene production by 2035 - and production of biodegradable polylactic acid, usable for everything from decomposable packaging material to medical implants, is expected to reach 800,000 tonnes by 2020, according to the International Energy Agency and International Renewable Energy Agency. Ultimately, industrial biotechnology can make a major contribution to achieving United Nations Sustainable Development Goals related to fostering affordable and clean energy, sustainable cities and communities, and responsible consumption and production.

name: Industrial Model and Innovation
description: Germany’s innovation capacity is highly concentrated in the electrical, machinery and automotive sectors, making it particularly vulnerable to related shifts in market demand and disruptive technology. Germany was ranked 9th out of 127 countries in the 2018 edition of the Global Innovation Index, which is compiled by a consortium of business schools, unchanged from 2017 but a slight improvement over its 10th place ranking in 2016. The country ranked first in the 2018 index in terms of both logistics performance and patents by origin, and second in terms of private sector research & development spending. However, Germany’s innovation capacity varies greatly among states; the eastern states generally lag behind the industrially strong south, with the exception of the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt. Risk factors for Germany in relation to its innovation capacity include complacency on university reforms, and a growing exodus of highly-trained academics to countries with more internationalized research infrastructure - and better career prospects. In addition, the integration of the immigrant workforce in Germany needs to be improved, through better education and equality of opportunity. Education mandates in the country are decentralized to the German states, which results in a wide variety in terms of quality. A more coordinated, long-term approach to education is required to meet the changing needs of the German economy. Particularly when it comes to startups and startup culture, the country’s Ministry of Economic Affairs has identified significant risk-adversity in Germany’s economic culture as a key challenge - and is trying to facilitate cultural change.

name: Inequality
description: Worsening inequality, and a corresponding negative impact on social stability, is one of the greatest potential risks associated with the technology innovation propelling the Fourth Industrial Revolution. While new technologies can democratize access to employment and entrepreneurial opportunities, not to mention education and knowledge, the tendency of new global technology platforms to dominate winner-takes-all markets could exacerbate inequality and social fragmentation. According to the 2017 edition of the Global Wealth Report published by Credit Suisse, total global wealth increased 27% over the course of the prior decade, and slightly more than half of all of the household wealth in the world was owned by just 1% of the global population (when the current millennium had begun, 45.5% of total global wealth was owned by the top 1%, according to the report). Even within the member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, as of 2011 the average income of the richest 10% of their populations was about nine times that of the poorest 10%. Inequality within most countries is getting worse, even in places that have enjoyed rapid economic growth across income groups and corresponding declines in poverty. Rising inequality is an economic and a social concern. In their 2009 book The Spirit Level: Why Greater Equality Makes Societies Stronger, British epidemiologists Richard Wilkinson and Kate Pickett published data indicating that unequal societies tend to be more violent, to have higher numbers of incarcerated citizens, to experience greater levels of mental illness and obesity, and to have lower life expectancy. More equal societies, meanwhile, have higher levels of child well-being, lower levels of stress and drug use, and lower rates of infant mortality. The World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report 2018 showed strong interconnections between rising income disparity, unemployment or underemployment, and profound social instability. A more digitally-connected world has created higher expectations, which can generate significant social risk if people feel they have no chance to attain the prosperity they see others enjoying. If the Fourth Industrial Revolution does result in greater social exclusion, it may make it even more difficult to find meaning in the modern world - and it may create further disenchantment with established elites and power structures. This could further motivate extremist movements, and augment their recruitment efforts.

name: Inequality and Development
description: About 165 million of the world’s international migrants (nearly two-thirds of the total as of 2017) are being hosted in high-income countries, according to United Nations statistics, while just 11 million live in low-income countries. The most popular migration corridors clearly lead from poorer to wealthier places - as most of the people migrating are doing so in order to seek a better life. They are in search of better incomes and means of securing food and shelter, and they are motivated by factors that are fundamental to the operation of any healthy civil society: the rule of law; safeguards to help prevent or limit corruption; access to health and education services; and protections from human rights abuses. In countries that are significant sources of migration, inequality remains pervasive and in some locations is entrenched. The effects of economic inequality are far reaching; a person’s ability to earn a decent living is overwhelmingly determined simply by the country where he or she lives, and a typical worker in a poor country is about $10,000 less productive annually than he or she would be in a rich country, according to a working paper published by the Center for Global Development in 2016. Local populations have gained ever greater visibility of this inequality, as telecommunications services become increasingly available in traditionally poor and marginalized societies. In Afghanistan, for example, where GDP per capita was still only about $562 as of 2016 (compared with $1,359 in Bangladesh, or $1,710 in India), according to World Bank data, the mobile phone subscription rate surged from 5% as of 2005 to 62% by 2015 - and that was still one of the lowest rates recorded globally. A research paper published in 2012 by the International Migration Institute, based on dozens of interviews with migrants settled in the Netherlands, found that social media and services like Skype played a crucial role in helping people thousands of miles from home to maintain ties to family and friends - and that online media lowered the threshold for people interested in migrating, making it more attractive than it would be otherwise.

name: Informed, Agile Governance
description: The institutions that have traditionally been responsible for shaping the social impact of new technology are struggling to keep up. At the same time, a sharp decline in public confidence is occurring around the world, as trust in mainstream institutions reaches a low point. According to the Edelman Trust Barometer 2018, a survey of thousands of respondents in 28 countries, as a result of a lack of trust in the media’s ability to safeguard the quality of information 56% of people do not know which politicians to trust, 42% do not know which companies or brands to trust, and 59% are not sure what is true and what is not. While 75% of respondents expressed trust in the technology sector, that was a slight decline compared with the prior year. There is an urgent need for a faster, more agile approach to governing emerging technologies - and the business models and social interaction that they enable. A shared understanding of acceptable behaviour is the foundation of trust in any society; the rule of law, and governance, whether related to matters of significance or to something as simple as the colour coding of traffic lights, enable people to pursue their goals with confidence. The architecture and nature of traditional governance mechanisms are inherently challenged when it comes to responding to digital technologies and the internet - due to mismatches in terms of structure and the rate of change. For example, as recently as a couple of years ago, some national digital strategies did not include any reference to artificial intelligence. These challenges call for an evolution of institutional architecture, which should become more adaptive, human-centred, inclusive, and sustainable. Beyond policy and regulation, the evolution of other instruments such as contract law, codes of practice, and industry self-regulation could better provide adequate rules of the road. Priorities for collaboration: Developing innovative governance protocols to keep pace with technology development Trying novel approaches like policy labs and regulatory sandboxes Crowdsourcing policy decisions

name: Infrastructure
description: Ghana’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of railroad density, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 10.00, resulting in a rank of 76th out of 100 countries; in terms of the efficiency of train services where it has a progress score of 15.70 that results in a rank of 122nd out of 137 countries; in terms of the liner shipping connectivity index where it has a progress score of 16.30 that results in a rank of 69th out of 107 countries. Other indicators reflect a better performance: exposure to unsafe drinking water, where it has a progress score of 59.40 that results in a rank of 129th out of 139 countries; in terms of electric power transmission and distribution losses where it has a progress score of 81.90 that results in a rank of 116th out of 124 countries; and in terms of electrification rate where it has a progress score of 84.10 that results in a rank of 103rd out of 140 countries.

name: Infrastructure Gap
description: Colombia’s overtaxed infrastructure must be addressed, in order to sustain the country's economic growth and competitiveness. Colombia ranked 109th out of 137 economies in terms of quality of overall infrastructure in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018; it ranked 110th in terms of quality of roads, and 79th in terms of quality of electricity supply. The country has low road network density compared with others in the region, and depends heavily on road transportation to move freight as the development of rail and river transportation is at an early stage. This translates into relatively high shipping costs, high commodity prices, and high prices for consumer products - all of which undermines productivity and competitiveness. After a long period of neglect, Colombia has seen a recent increase in both public and private infrastructure investment. Key projects have included the Ruta del Sol highway that connects the nation’s capital with large urban areas in the country's interior, and with the Caribbean coast. The Colombian government created the Financiera de Desarrollo Nacional, a semi-public finance institution, which is designed to support infrastructure. The government has also developed a new regulatory framework for public-private partnerships, while steps have been taken to better facilitate capital deployment to public infrastructure, as well as to bolster efficiency and transparency in the bidding for projects.. In 2013, the government introduced the so-called fourth-generation (4G) program, which involves more than 30 concession projects, and the construction of more than 1,200 kilometres of highway. As part of the programme, the government set investment targets of approximately $25 billion for road infrastructure, and up to $100 billion for transport infrastructure, by 2021. In early 2018, a number of related projects were awarded, and the government expects them to help reduce travel times by up to half while boosting Colombia's GDP growth by 1.5% per year. In order to support the 4G programme, the infrastructure sector must be increasingly professionalized, regulations must be modified to unlock additional investment capital, and solid guarantees must be provided to long-term investors.

name: Infrastructure Investment
description: The travel and tourism industry contributes roughly 10% of global GDP, and accounts for about 300 million jobs, according to a report published by the World Travel & Tourism Council in 2017. However, private and public infrastructure investments in airport development, accommodation, roads, railways, and communication technologies lag behind industry growth, leading to significant bottlenecks and limiting potential development and employment opportunities. Airports and border controls need to become smarter, and travel infrastructure must become leaner, in order to meet the needs of travellers who want to move around securely and seamlessly. The World Economic Forum's Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report emphasizes the importance of infrastructure for every country’s travel and tourism competitiveness. Some notable improvements among countries assessed in the latest, 2017 edition of the report included India, which moved up 12 places compared with the previous edition due in part to improved ground transportation infrastructure, which has traditionally been a challenge there, and Viet Nam, which moved up eight places and was cited for improvements in information technology infrastructure. There is a need for greater dialogue between the public and private sectors in every country, in order to ensure an integrated infrastructure strategy.

name: Infrastructure Technology and Innovation
description: More actively embracing new technologies is not only a way to potentially improve existing infrastructure, but also a key potential means of closing an infrastructure investment gap expected to reach $22 billion in India, $100 billion in China, and $162 billion in the US by the year 2030, according to the Global Infrastructure Hub. Due to the economic and political importance of infrastructure projects, and related sensitivities, developers and investors are often hesitant to incorporate emerging technology into their planning. As a result, the engineering and construction industry remains among the least digitally transformed, leading to project delays, poor design, environmental damage, and ballooning costs. This is happening even as emerging technologies have the potential to transform entire infrastructure systems through the use of advanced materials, robotics, 3D printing, the Internet of Things (which strings devices and appliances together via an internet connection), and data analytics. Examples of the impact of technology on construction include China-based Broad Sustainable Building’s construction of a 57-story tower in just 19 days in 2014 - in part by using advanced prefabrication techniques. Building Information Modeling (BIM) is another example of helpful innovation, thanks to the way it enables developers to create data-based, digital 3D models of projects so that architects, engineers, and contractors can simultaneously collaborate. This potentially increases efficiency and quality, while reducing errors, delays, and costs. Better integrating new technology into infrastructure development could not only result in more badly-needed infrastructure, but also in more sustainable and efficient infrastructure. Drone deliveries could take vehicles and related emissions off the road, autonomous vehicles could boost road capacity, and more digital tracking of road use could help to better predict the need for new infrastructure, according to a report published by the McKinsey Global Institute in 2016. However, new regulatory and business models will need to be created in order to pave the way for new technologies, while the general thinking about infrastructure development should shift to more strongly emphasize connectivity between mobility and utility systems, and between living and work spaces (particularly in urban environments).

name: Infrastructure as a Geopolitical Tool
description: By early 2019, China’s Belt and Road initiative, unveiled roughly five years earlier, had spawned projects including a $3 billion railway between Budapest and Belgrade, several nuclear reactors in Pakistan, and a $2 billion industrial park in Kenya, according to the think tank Bruegel. Some analysts see the initiative as an unsettling extension of China’s rising power, according to a report published by the Council on Foreign Relations. The report noted that more than 60 countries, accounting for two-thirds of the global population, had signed on to Belt and Road projects or had expressed an interest in doing so by early 2019, and it cited estimates that China may spend $1.3 trillion on the initiative by 2027. The report detailed a significant potential return on that investment in the form of an increased ability to shape international norms and institutions, and to generally assert China’s interests more aggressively on the global stage. However, there has been some pushback; an analysis published by Bruegel in 2019 flagged particularly negative public perception of the initiative in several countries that are home to Belt and Road projects, including Poland and Ukraine.  Interference with the ability of firms from overseas to participate in infrastructure-building can also be wielded as a geopolitical tool. The US, for example, has sought in recent years to discourage other countries from selecting China-based Huawei to build important telecommunications infrastructure. The US has argued that equipment supplied by Huawei, which is a leader in terms of the technology and intellectual property required to deploy next-generation 5G networks, represents a security threat - though the company has denied that. The US campaign has managed to help dissuade governments in Australia and New Zealand from pushing ahead with projects that use Huawei gear, though Germany has signaled an openness to deploying technology from the company, and the United Kingdom has reportedly approved the use of Huawei products in non-core parts of its 5G infrastructure. The wrangling over infrastructure vendors can have far-reaching geo-economic effects; after Canada arrested a senior Huawei executive in 2018 at the behest of the US for allegedly violating sanctions against Iran, China banned imports of Canadian canola and potentially eliminated a significant portion of Canada’s global exports of the seed that totaled $8.6 billion in 2018.

name: Infrastructure at Capacity
description: Switzerland has been known for its innovative, high quality infrastructure since the railroad boom of the 19th century - when the Gotthard railway was laced through the Swiss Alps. When the country’s infrastructure networks were designed (the highway system in the 1960s, the airports in the 1940s), they included relatively generous capacities. By 2010, the Swiss infrastructure network consisted of 1,790 kilometres of highway, 3,011 kilometres of federal railway tracks, 2,137 private railway tracks, three national airports (Zurich, Geneva, and Basel), 532 hydro power stations, five nuclear power stations, 6,696 kilometres of high voltage supply lines, in addition to a high pressure gas network and communications network. The condition of national infrastructure networks is still generally good, which contributes to Switzerland’s competitiveness. But most of the networks also have critical capacity issues. The country’s train system is one of the most highly utilized in the world, and the Zurich airport has one of the highest rates of delayed flights - while many hours are wasted in traffic jams on the country’s congested motorways. While neighbouring countries have developed new infrastructure networks featuring high speed train systems and new motorways and airports, Switzerland’s plans to accommodate its expanding population do not include a major capacity increase in form of major new infrastructure. Significant capacity constraints are projected for air transport, as the country has only three international runways, of which two are not independently operable. The government’s strategy involves maintaining existing infrastructure networks, which can be optimized using new technologies such as digitalization to relieve capacity problems. Important exceptions include the two new Alpine tunnels crossing beneath the Lötschberg and Gotthard mountains, as part of a European corridor stretching from north to south. Meanwhile significant investments are being made in public transportation systems in big cities, in order to extend commuter railway and tram systems; this should have a positive impact on the cities’ places in the knowledge economy, while helping to maintain the quality of life.

name: Innovation Capability
description: Bolivia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the number of patent applications made with collaborators from other countries, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 0.00, resulting in a rank of 125th out of 125 countries; in terms of the prominence and standing of local research institutions where it has a progress score of 0.00 that results in a rank of 112th out of 112 countries; in terms of the number of patent applications filed relative to population size where it has a progress score of 1.10 that results in a rank of 102nd out of 129 countries. Other indicators reflect a better performance: the diversity of the workforce, where it has a progress score of 48.40 that results in a rank of 114th out of 139 countries; in terms of the number of trademark applications made relative to population size where it has a progress score of 60.10 that results in a rank of 87th out of 124 countries; and in terms of the number of published scientific papers and the degree to which they are cited elsewhere where it has a progress score of 69.10 that results in a rank of 93rd out of 140 countries.

name: Innovation Drive
description: China has managed to develop one of the biggest innovation economies in the world. The country promotes innovation-driven growth by dedicating relevant resources, and providing government policy support for upgrading value chains and improving technology. Significant progress has been made in terms of research & development expenditure, the quantity of awarded patents, and the establishment of scientific demonstration parks and zones. Gross domestic spending on R&D as a percentage of GDP rose to about 2.1% in China by 2016, from 0.9% in 2000, according to Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development data; by way of comparison, spending the US over the same period rose only slightly, to about 2.7% from 2.6%, according to the data. E-commerce, social media, and financial technology (or fintech) are all contributing to China’s accelerating innovation. China has also improved local institutional elements such as intellectual property rights, technology transfer (or the bringing of new technologies to market), educational opportunities that emphasizes creativity and critical thinking, and facilitation for entrepreneurs. This institutional development is taking place at the national, provincial and city level; one example is Shenzhen, where the city’s government functions as a service provider and coordinator of innovation, and gives entrepreneurs freedom to be creative. Technology parks and startup incubators and accelerators also play key roles in China, by connecting local resources to entrepreneurs. Related investment has also been directed abroad, with several accelerator programs that mentor and develop startups focused on the Chinese market established in Silicon Valley by 2018 (some of which work directly with the Chinese government); examples include the ZGC Innovation Center. Within vocational and higher education, an increasing number of programs are focusing on entrepreneurship. Some large enterprises are meanwhile incubating entrepreneurial units, in order to develop new products and services, while independent small firms are driving change with their relative speed, agility, and potentially disruptive innovation. However, China is also confronted with challenges, including a relatively low quality of innovation, a talent shortage, inefficient capital markets and resource allocation, a relative lack of management capability at the executive level, a slow transformation of state-owned enterprises, and a top-down innovation model (and mindsets). This key issue is curated in partnership with Han Jian, Co-Director, Centre on China Innovation, China Europe International Business School.

name: Innovation Readiness
description: An ageing global populace calls for innovation geared towards care for older populations. Ageing has immense health-related, social, and economic impacts; left unaddressed, it will create complex and unprecedented burdens for individuals, healthcare systems, and entire countries. Those countries that embrace innovation stand a better chance of coping. The phrase “Innovation Readiness” refers to identifying where innovation in relation to ageing is now happening, and clarifying the barriers to that innovation. It encourages collaborative, public-private efforts, while tapping ageing experts from the realms of science, public policy, advocacy, and industry. The International Chamber of Commerce published a set of principles in late 2015 intended to support the development of policy that enables aging-related innovation, and reduces inefficiency. These include: building investor confidence, training skilled workers in an environment that promotes the exchange of knowledge, opening markets to trade and investment, and ensuring intellectual property. Governments need to adopt long-term strategies that facilitate collaboration among different ministries, and cultivate effective coordination among academia, the public sector, and the private sector. The private sector, however, will only be able to maximize its contribution if governments incentivize innovation with robust and predictable regulation, provide targeted financial support such as tax incentives for research, and ensure sufficient intellectual property rights. Digital health solutions like remote patient monitoring can generate helpful data; the collection and proper use of this information presents opportunities to better predict and meet the challenges of ageing. Meanwhile the cooperation of both domestic and international market participants can accelerate innovation cycles, and efficiency. However, collaboration can be hampered by a lack of agreed-upon standards for data protection, concerns about cost-effectiveness, and ambiguous legal and regulatory frameworks. In the health industry, the integration of different care providers and health services can be challenging - though greater integration of data can enable higher-value medical interventions, and help prioritize decision-making. Innovation can also help ensure the sustainability of health care systems through more efficient use of resources. For example, earlier detection, diagnosis, and enrolment in clinical trials can help expedite research and more effective interventions when it comes to Alzheimer’s disease, and may ultimately lead to a cure.

name: Innovation Systems
description: Innovation tends to involve a lot of players; innovation systems are composed of research institutions, universities, national laboratories, hospitals, corporations, startups, venture capitalists, and patent attorneys. The public sector can play a key role, in the form of funding bodies and intermediary organizations like technology transfer offices and accelerators (programs designed to turn raw startups into young companies). The ways in which these participants interact are complex, and subject to local quirks like tax breaks, regulations, patent treaties, and competition rules. They are also influenced by factors including the availability of codified knowledge (publications and standards). A lot of innovation policy has focused on filling institutional voids, improving innovation capability, and strengthening networks; in some countries, there are dedicated innovation agencies that aim to serve as system fixers by addressing failures in markets and networks, often without preference for specific technologies or sectors. Enterprise Singapore, for example, was formed in the city state in 2018 to champion entrepreneurial innovation while overseeing standards and accreditation. A systemic view can be useful at the local level; people working with startups often refer to "startup ecosystems," for example, to describe the networks of organizations, both private and public, from which young enterprises can draw resources. Many efforts to improve entrepreneurship have focused on enriching these ecosystems with measures designed to facilitate connections and improve density. Innovation systems also exist in a narrower sense - many collective intelligence tools, such as wikis (websites developed and overseen by communities) and prediction markets enable people to make judgments that may be better than otherwise possible. It’s important to note that the notion of an “innovation system” is different from “systems innovation” - the latter refers to the challenges of innovating by re-configuring complex systems, like national health care systems or financial systems, and is often challenging because it requires coordinated action by multiple actors while creating complex feedback loops that lead to unpredictable, and sometimes unintended consequences.

name: Innovation and Access to Credit
description: Peru was able to muster investment in research & development (both public and private) equal to only about 0.12% of the country’s GDP as recently as 2015, according to World Bank data. That was less than a third of the 0.38% of GDP spent in its southern neighbour Chile during that same year, and exactly half of the figure registered in its northern neighbour Colombia. About one third of Peru’s R&D investment comes from the private sector, which is below the Latin American average of 40%. The country ranked 113th out of 137 economies in terms of innovation in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018, and 80th in terms of business sophistication. In addition to relatively low levels of investment in R&D, the country suffers from issues with the quality of its so-called human capital (or, the relative value of its workforce). The proportion of researchers in the country’s labour force is about one third of the average for Latin America, and a small fraction of the average for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, according to the Network for Science and Technology Indicators – Ibero-American and Inter-American (RICYT). The relatively small size of companies operating in Peru has also constrained its innovation capacity. According to the country’s Ministry of Production, very small ”micro-” and small enterprises account for 99% of all Peruvian businesses, and employ 60% of the country’s economically-active population. In the broader region surrounding Peru, only between 30% and 40% of the population was employed by micro-enterprises, according to the International Labour Organization’s World Employment and Social Outlook 2015. Peruvian firms generally have difficulty raising financing, due in part to their small size. The country’s so-called financial depth, or contributions of financial institutions to overall GDP, is relatively low. According to a 2015 report published by the World Bank, the cost of credit for small- and medium-sized firms in the country is relatively high; overall, the average lending rate was 16% as of 2013, according to the report, which was high compared with countries at similar stages of development. Overcoming these obstacles for Peruvian companies will require sounder corporate governance.  The increased use of grants to finance innovation efforts could help improve the outlook in Peru, as could better encouragement of joint enterprises between firms and research institutions. Increased incentives could meanwhile help attract talent, and help to bolster domestic innovation.

name: Innovation and Business Sophistication
description: Chile’s transition to a high-income economy will require a more sophisticated, diversified economic structure. A decisive leap forward in research & development capability could be helpful in this regard, though Chile has yet to make innovation a key element of its economic development. The country spent the equivalent of 0.4% of its GDP on R&D as of 2015, which was the lowest among Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries and ranked 71st among 110 economies assessed in the Global Innovation Index 2017. Chile scored its lowest marks in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report 2017-2018 in the areas of business sophistication and innovation - placing 50th and 52nd, respectively, out of 137 economies. Placement was similar in terms of university-industry collaboration in R&D (58th), and quality of scientific research institutions (43rd). The country ranked significantly lower in terms of company spending on R&D (99th) and government procurement of advanced technology products (110th). The Inter-American Development Bank has identified a need for Chile to strengthen its National Council on Innovation for Competitiveness, to clarify the roles and responsibilities of its Inter-Ministerial Council for Innovation, and to improve inter-agency coordination. In addition, it is important for the country to adopt policies that promote innovation among small- and medium-sized enterprises, and to integrate a science, technology and innovation agenda into its long-term development plans.

name: Innovation and Entrepreneurship in Switzerland
description: Switzerland features four languages (German, French, Italian, and Romansh) and distinct cultures, and connects surrounding European countries via its historic traffic routes through the Alps. It has developed a strong education system that combines world-leading post-secondary institutions with a unique vocational training (apprenticeship) system. The Swiss education system represents a healthy balance between bottom-up (market-driven) and top-down (federal) initiatives. While the vocational system is predominantly driven by professional organizations, the post-secondary system is driven by cantons (the state jurisdictions within Switzerland) and by the federal government (when it comes to the federal institutes of technology). The education system is funded by a mix of federal and cantonal subsidies, industry financing, and student contributions. According to the World Economic Forum’s Global Human Capital Report 2017, Switzerland benefits from the high quality of its education system, strong vocational training and a high level of skills diversity. The country ranked 3rd in the overall Human Capital Index (behind Norway and Finland), and was rated best in terms of know-how, and second-best in terms of development. The strength of the Swiss education and training system was demonstrated during the financial crisis, when youth unemployment rates soared in many European countries but remained relatively stable in Switzerland, Germany, and Austria. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Switzerland’s market-driven, vocational and professional education and training system benefits from the strong influence of employers. However, vocational and on-the-job training is becoming less attractive for young people. As a result, various initiatives have been launched to promote dual-education and fight youth unemployment. According to the 2016-2017 Times Higher Education’s World University Rankings and ShanghaiRanking’s Academic Ranking, Swiss institutions such as the two Swiss Federal Institutes of Technology (ETH Zurich and EPF Lausanne) are among the best worldwide. This has contributed to a relatively high proportion of international faculty members and students, which further strengthens the system. However, it has been projected that Switzerland will suffer from a significant lack of skilled employees in the near future. Changes in the job market and dramatic shifts in skills requirements have played a role. The skills mismatch is not unique to Switzerland; the World Economic Forum’s 2017 white paper Realizing Human Potential in the Fourth Industrial Revolution recommends addressing the situation by ensuring there is a sufficient science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education to deliver strong digital skills.

name: Innovation and Productivity
description: Rates of productivity around the world have either declined or remained flat during the past decade, despite exponential increases in both technological progress and investment in innovation. In the US, according the Bureau of Labor Statistics, labour productivity measured in output per hour grew an annual average of 2.4% between 1948 and 1983, then rose to 2.7% between 2000 and 2007, and later fell to 1.3% between 2007 and 2015. In his 2016 book The Rise and Fall of American Growth, the economist Robert Gordon argues that this disconnect between innovation and productivity is the result of innovation that is less beneficial for an economy than the dramatic developments of past industrial revolutions - which revamped entire sanitation, energy, and transportation systems. However, it is also possible that the impact of the Fourth Industrial Revolution on productivity has not yet become fully apparent because it is increasing efficiency in ways that cannot be accurately measured by traditional means. Many new goods and services are non-rival, meaning that they can be repeated again and again without generating more costs; they may also have zero marginal cost to begin with, or they may use digital platforms to lower prices in highly competitive markets. Under these conditions, traditional productivity statistics may fail to capture real increases in value, given that any related price benefit for consumers is not well reflected in corporate sales and profit figures. Another possible explanation: the world has yet to fully experience the productivity explosion being created by the new technologies at the heart of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. This revolution has not yet reached many of the two billion people still disconnected from the global economy, who may ultimately benefit the most from it. Many of the technologies and processes being created to help better manage negative forces like the environmental impact of climate change have not yet been widely implemented. After all, we are still at the beginning of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, and few organizations have so far reorganized themselves to take full advantage of it. As with the digital revolution, and other previous industrial revolutions before that, realizing the full benefit of the Fourth Industrial Revolution may take time, and require new organizational forms, new skills, and new mindsets.

name: Innovation for Nature
description: Whether it’s citizen-scientists using cellphones to report on water quality, or drones that warn elephants away from a poacher’s snare, technology can be a powerful means to improve the ways that we manage natural resources. The Fourth Industrial Revolution, which is being propelled by a convergence of technologies, offers new opportunities to shape society’s relationship with nature and create a more sustainable bioeconomy. It also presents significant risks. This industrial revolution has sweeping implications, not least for biotechnology - in particular in terms of the potential for biomimicry (sustainable innovation that mimics nature) and bioprospecting (the use of natural materials to create new products), as well as for improved environmental monitoring and industrial ecology. It also presents opportunities to increase awareness of the need to shift to more sustainable production models, and awareness of the value that nature provides. For example, natural areas and organisms should be valued not just for the materials they provide, but also for the knowledge they confer; the value of compounds found in woodland fungi that provide a blueprint for new antibiotics, for example, may outweigh the value generated by harvesting a forest. By better conserving natural systems that represent billions of years of acquired, biological problem-solving ability, we can enable a Fourth Industrial Revolution that translates knowledge into economic and social value. In order to enable a truly sustainable bioeconomy, however, bold vision is required when it comes to dealing with associated risks - including environmental degradation as a result of economic activity, increased political instability and inequality, and potential bio-piracy. While technologies such as blockchain can improve supply chain monitoring, for example, they can also consume excessive amounts of energy (the energy costs of cryptocurrency mining via blockchain exceed those of traditional mining of metals like gold and copper, according to a study published in Nature Sustainability in 2018). Fostering dialogue among stakeholders will be key for both identifying and avoiding pitfalls, as will tech hubs, education initiatives, and both public and private investments directed at protecting biodiverse areas. It will only be by maintaining safeguards through effective regulation, innovative monitoring, remote sensing, and citizen science that we will be able to realize the opportunities presented by the Fourth Industrial Revolution - and to respect nature’s limits.

name: Innovation for Social Benefit
description: Examples of social innovation are all around us; they include everything from kindergartens and hospices to more modern innovations like Wikipedia and microfinance (small loans made to entrepreneurs in the developing world without access to traditional bank loans). Social innovation is often defined as innovation that aims to both tackle social problems and upgrade the means used to address those problems. This can take the form of new products, services, initiatives, organizational models, or simply novel approaches to accessing public goods - often achieved by creatively re-combining already-existing elements. The field has developed rapidly in recent years, as new sources of funding, public policies, academic research, and networks are developed in service of it. The everyday work of social innovation typically happens within social enterprises (organizations trying to solve social problems by using practical, market-based approaches), charities, non-governmental organizations, social movements, or patient groups. Universities, large companies, and governments can also play important roles, particularly in terms of validating and scaling-up valuable ideas; past examples of this scaling-up include the expansion of the kindergarten movement to privately-run nurseries, the construction of public playgrounds, and the commercialization of open source software developed by communities). One particularly interesting area of social innovation involves the development of tools used to support digital democracy, or “civic tech,” designed to encourage broader civic engagement - by, for example, promoting political campaigns, working to stop corruption, or helping communities self-organize. Social innovation faces barriers that are different than those standing in the way of other kinds of innovation, however. The lack of immediately-apparent commercial incentives in social innovation typically makes it more difficult to raise the capital needed to support it, for example, and some innovation can threaten existing power structures - which may respond accordingly. In order to cope with such challenges, the people driving social innovation may sometimes deploy “frugal innovation”; closely tied to the Indian concept of “jugaad innovation,” frugal innovation involves doing more with less in order to reach normally-overlooked consumers, or to make scarce public resources stretch further. One example of this is the M-Pesa mobile phone-based payment and microfinancing service, which has been deployed in countries in Africa, Asia, and eastern Europe to enable people to access banking services on an everyday device - without requiring access to an actual bank.

name: Innovative Manufacturing and Materials
description: While the dramatic increase in the use of additive manufacturing, often referred to as 3D printing, has generated new opportunities in many industries, the aerospace sector has been at the forefront of this revolution. 3D printing has given rise to a new, design-centric paradigm, enabling the manufacture of high-performance components with previously un-realizable geometries that consolidate functional features, and significantly reduce both weight and part count in aircraft systems. This increase in design flexibility, coupled with related cost and time-savings, continues to drive the adoption of 3D printing by key aerospace players. The application of 3D printing has meanwhile spurred further research in measurement sciences, in turn challenging existing regulatory frameworks and creating new opportunities for technological disruption at many points along the supply chain.  While most recent progress in manufacturing aerospace components has been focused on metals, 3D printing of long carbon fibre composites has the potential to enable even greater design possibilities - by enabling greater control of the fibre orientation within a part. Though development in this area is still nascent, it is nonetheless an exciting prospect. Another recent trend is the use of non-renewable materials in certain aircraft components, despite growing demand for the extraction and recycling of materials into new components - something that must be aggressively pursued. Functional materials, or materials with distinct properties or functions such as magnetism, have the potential to make aircraft smarter, increasingly resilient, and lighter. Their adoption has been relatively rare, however, and opportunities exist to use them in order to rethink how we design aircraft. They could also enable significant cost-savings for the industry, and potentially cut down on aircraft development time - which is currently one of the key issues affecting the sector. A good example is the ability to incorporate functional materials that are self-healing and can therefore increase aircraft longevity, while reducing downtime required for maintenance.

name: Institutional Efficiency and Public Finance
description: Colombia suffers from relatively poor government efficiency, lacklustre management of public investments, public utilities that fall short, and an inadequate civil service. Despite its relatively healthy GDP per capita, Colombia placed well below other developing countries such as Chile, South Africa, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Turkey in terms of public-sector performance in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018. This is has direct impact on public faith in the government; the results of a 2017 YanHaas survey in Colombia showed that 70% of respondents did not have a positive opinion of government institutions, and that they believed the country’s Supreme Court of Justice was not doing a good job. In addition, 80% of respondents had a negative opinion of congress. According to Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures, Colombia collected far less in taxes as a percentage of GDP than the OECD average in 2015. Tax evasion is a significant problem in Colombia, and is estimated to equate to 4% of GDP even when only taking into account income and value-added tax. Due to a decline in oil revenue, the Colombian government has been forced to implement tax increases. A comprehensive tax reform in 2016 increased the value-added tax (VAT) rate, and taxed dividends - while reducing corporate tax rates in a bid to encourage investment. Colombia must look for ways to broaden its base of taxpayers, introduce e-invoicing (in order to combat VAT evasion), and increase inspections and audits of taxpayers. Only by addressing tax evasion will it be possible to progressively increase government revenues in Colombia that can provide fiscal sustainability and support growth.

name: Institutional Pluralism
description: Traditionally, global governance has been centred on interstate diplomacy and formal, intergovernmental organizations - like the United Nations, or the World Bank. But as the interdependence of nations and regions has deepened, an array of sometimes competing institutions has emerged as players in world politics. While the World Trade Organization remains at the centre of the global trade regime, for example, the proliferation of preferential trade agreements since the end of the Cold War has given countries alternative means of securing economic cooperation. Similarly, the rise of liquidity swap lines and other arrangements between central banks has called the International Monetary Fund’s traditional position as the global lender of last resort into question. While state-centric, formal institutions remain critical, companies, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and other private actors now often set regulatory standards, arbitrate disputes, and otherwise help govern the global economy. In addition, networks of domestic government officials - mayors, legislators, judges, and regulators - regularly collaborate with their peers across borders, providing a new take on traditional diplomacy. And, states and international organizations often seek to advance their goals not only through diplomacy and treaty-making, but also by orchestrating partnerships between public entities and private businesses in order to pursue shared goals. While these trends are widespread, they are not evenly distributed. In some realms, like decision- and policy-making related to addressing and adapting to the effects of climate change, or related to global health issues, governance has become highly diversified among a broader mix of entities. Other areas, such as traditional security issues, remain firmly within the remits of central governments. The proliferation of institutions that are engaged in global governance has led to the frequent overlap of public and private entities tackling similar issues. Sometimes, this leads to a fragmentation that limits the overall effectiveness of global governance. In other cases, however, it involves the creation of new forms of institutions and more innovative and adaptable global governance - and more effective problem-solving.

name: Institutions and Alliances
description: One consequence of the new, multipolar and multi-conceptual geopolitical era is weakened support for core institutions like the United Nations and the World Trade Organization. Proponents of multilateralism, or the idea that countries can actually work together to achieve shared goals, lament this erosion of a framework designed to enable the world to take on global challenges collectively, and to settle differences peacefully. On the other side of the argument, some critics say the world’s legacy institutions are too closely aligned with a small number of states, and no longer meet the needs of a world of diverging interests and values. Another recent strand of criticism (made notably in the US) suggests that multilateralism runs counter to the domestic interests of even those relatively privileged states that have been at the heart of the multilateral system - including the US. A result of frayed support for multilateralism is the emergence of a more ad-hoc approach to international cooperation; a shift from rules to deals, and from global to regional and bilateral agreements. Institutional competition has also increased, as countries attempt to create alternative centres of gravity, such as the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, or the Russia-centred Eurasian Economic Union. There are arguments to be made in support of more distributed global governance: greater responsiveness to local conditions could better foster resilience, for example. But with institutional fragmentation now taking place alongside a deepening of geopolitical fissures, a narrowed space for global problem-solving is likely to be a source of fragility. Developments in the political and economic arena have been echoed in the security realm, amid a loss of faith in collective security mechanisms. This has been most evident in the form of transatlantic disputes about NATO, a traditional cornerstone of the geopolitical order that took shape following World War II. Although these disputes have centred on NATO members’ relative defence spending, with the US accusing its allies of free-riding at its taxpayers’ expense, the knock-on effects have raised fundamental questions about the status of NATO's mutual defence provisions. This is not an isolated example. As the world’s geopolitical tectonic plates have shifted, it has caused many states to reconsider security strategies, to hedge against possible future abandonment by their traditional allies, and to explore the acquisition of new weapons capabilities.

name: Institutions and Public Services
description: Public sector management in Peru has not kept pace with the country’s recent socio-economic progress. The World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018 ranked Peru 116th out of 137 countries in terms of institutions, due to the impact of corruption scandals and a related decline in public trust. Peru ranked nearly last in terms of trust in local government (only besting Haiti) in the Latin American Public Opinion Project’s (LAPOP) AmericasBarometer 2016-2017. The LAPOP report also noted that a lack of security is perceived as one of the biggest problems for Peruvians; more than 30% of the report’s respondents had been victims of a crime in the previous year.  The availability of education in Peru is above average for Latin America, according to the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB). Primary school attendance is roughly consistent across regions, between genders, and regardless of mother tongue or socio-economic status. However, the quality of education throughout the country remains relatively low; the quality of primary education ranked 129th out of 137 economies in the Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018. Less than half of the second graders in Peru reach a satisfactory level in reading comprehension, and only one in four do so in mathematics. In addition, at the secondary school level, young people in rural areas who have indigenous mother tongues (indigenous languages in Peru include Quechua and Aymara), and live in extremely poor households, suffer from lower educational outcomes. According to World Bank Development Indicators for 2017, public spending per primary school pupil in Peru is equal to 13% of GDP per capita, below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of 19%. Rates of infant mortality vary widely in different regions of Peru. In metropolitan Lima, it is 12 deaths per 1,000 infants, though it rises to 25 per 1,000 in more rural, forested areas. A growing prevalence of chronic, non-communicable diseases such as cancer, diabetes and hypertension has created a new source of inequality. Health services are oriented around the provision of maternal and child care, and have not yet evolved to adequately address chronic disease, according to the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation’s report Global Burden of Disease 2013. The general quality of health services in the country is low, and hospital waiting times and appointment scheduling delays are long. According to World Bank Development Indicators for 2017, health spending per capita in Peru is $360, lower than the Latin American average of $712. About 3 million Peruvians, or nearly 10% of the population, lack access to safe water, according to a 2018 estimate from the non-profit organization Water.org. Roughly 5 million Peruvians lack access to improved sanitation, according to Water.org, and while sanitation coverage is higher in urban areas than in rural areas, many rapidly growing, so-called peri-urban areas on the outskirts of Peru’s cities face limited access to such services. According to the IDB, improving the effectiveness of public services in Peru will require lower levels of corruption, and increased transparency. Current delays in public investment have only heightened the need for improved public-sector management in the form of cutting red tape, simplifying regulations, introducing e-government tools, and promoting greater public access to information.

name: Institutions that Work for Africa
description: Africa has benefited from improving macroeconomic policy, the increased frequency of peaceful transitions of political power through democratic elections, and greater numbers of active and engaged citizens. Increased foreign direct investment, remittances from workers abroad, and evolving tax systems have also helped. However, greater accountability is necessary to improve governance and tax administration. The challenge of good governance is particularly pressing in resource-rich and fragile states, and the capacity of institutions in most African countries remains weak. Transparency International’s 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index rated sub-Saharan Africa as the worst-performing region in the world, though it also noted that several countries in the area made notable progress; highlights included Rwanda, where President Paul Kagame enforced a strict leadership code, and Cote d’Ivoire, which made strides under President Alassane Ouattara, according to the index. Liberia, meanwhile, declined significantly between 2012 and 2018, according to the index. Decades after decolonization, one of the key lessons learned in Africa is that successful implementation of government programs requires viable institutions, and effective service delivery. Examples of effective public institutions abound. Since 2011, for example, healthcare delivery in Ethiopia has benefited from an organized army of female workers who provide health education, vaccines and other necessities - enabled by a government supervisory structure and information management system, and by empowered policy-makers. Meanwhile deepening democracy in countries like Nigeria has helped begin to build greater confidence in institutions (though problems have been persistently cited regarding excessive bureaucracy in Nigeria, which have only been exacerbated by relatively low oil prices and correspondingly lower government revenue in the oil-rich country). Regional governments are the next frontier for Africa; institutions such as public accounts committees should be strengthened, in order to better ensure that government investment delivers results. The success or failure of efforts to improve the functioning of city governments and regional institutions in Africa will ultimately determine the shape of the continent’s future.

name: Integrating Migrants
description: The effective integration of migrants can lead to economic, social, and security benefits for everyone - not just for migrant communities. There should be a fuller recognition of successful integration policies and programs in some countries (such as traditional immigration countries like Australia, Canada, and the US) - and of the ongoing challenges in other countries (including some European Union members). The Migrant Integration Policy Index, most recently published in 2015 by the Barcelona Centre for International Affairs and the Migration Policy Group, measures policies for integrating migrants in EU member states and other countries including the US, Canada, and Japan. Some key findings of the 2015 index included an average six-percentage-point decline in employment among non-EU citizens in the EU between 2008 and 2014, coupled with a four-percentage-point increase in their risk of poverty or social exclusion over the same period - to a level twice that of EU citizens. Sweden ranked first on the 2015 index, with a score of 78 (a score of 100 indicated the most favourable possible environment for migrants), while the US ranked 9th, the UK was 15th, and Turkey came in last.  There has been greater recognition in recent years of the positive role that local governments can play in attracting and integrating migrants - both those who have moved within their country, as well as internationally. The innovative use of technology, often developed by migrants themselves, has helped to support effective integration services. The German government, for example, has implemented its “Asyl Online” digital platform as a means to more efficiently transfer information among various authorities involved in processing applicants for asylum, including the federal criminal police. Germany provides a good example of the increasingly irregular patterns of large-scale displacement and migration; the country had received about 890,000 asylum seekers in 2015, 280,000 in 2016, and about 187,000 the following year. Irregular waves of migrants have triggered concerns about inadequate integration policies and the risks they pose to both migrants and receiving communities. Inadequate integration can potentially bolster public support for far-right, anti-immigration political efforts, for example, which in turn makes it more difficult to promote a balanced narrative about migration. Other extreme, but nevertheless potential risks include the religious radicalization of second- and third-generation migrants who have been marginalized in host societies due to poor integration efforts.

name: Intellectual Property
description: The electronics market is directly affected by the nuances of the international intellectual property regime; an ability to leverage IP rights for competitive advantage is essential. The World Economic Forum’s 2013 report Intellectual Property Rights in the Global Creative Economy noted that the purpose of IP is to promote progress and innovation, by safeguarding ideas and entrepreneurship. The global IP system should therefore be a tool to facilitate the trading of information and knowledge in innovative, creative goods and services. Intellectual property rights are hotly contested within the electronics industry, where innovation is relentless and even small technological and design advantages can result in large profit margins. Striking the right balance between IP that is open to the public, and IP that is protected for rights holders, is critical if innovation is to flourish. However, the issue has been clouded by companies that have emerged solely to create, purchase, and lease IP, and by discrepancies among countries in terms of their ability and willingness to enforce patent protections. Intellectual property can create new revenue streams, jobs, and economic growth. Traditionally, governments have encouraged the creation of IP by bolstering laws that protect innovation. For example, in Hong Kong SAR the government has solicited information from public companies about how IP is utilized in transactions like mergers; this information can include useful details about the transfer of IP titles and their monetary value, and may help distribute knowledge about IP accounting. Meanwhile Singapore has been working with banks to extend loans to entrepreneurs who use IP as collateral, and in 2014 the government introduced a scheme to guarantee a portion of such loans. Some Singaporean government agencies have also provided test bed facilities to startups. There is still much to be done to advance international collaboration. Governments can work with one another, or with bodies such as the World Intellectual Property Organization, to develop models and best practices. This can help clarify the value of IP assets for investors and government officials. In addition, accounting firms could be better encouraged to nurture related specialists. For those applying for patent protection, delays in receiving a decision can negatively affect future earnings - to help speed the process, higher priority could be given to those patents with the potential to deliver public benefits, such as those related to green technology or medications.

name: Intelligence Augmentation
description: Recent breakthroughs in wearable robotic systems may enable humans to perform physical feats that would have once been impossible, like walking extreme distances or carrying heavy loads. In addition, research is underway that could result in better prosthetic limbs that are equipped with sensors and sophisticated algorithms, and are capable of receiving commands directly from the human nervous system. These technologies could one day mean the end of physical disability - or the enhancement of existing brain functions. In addition to systems that are worn on the body, smart robotics systems have been developed to assist humans in tasks that require dedicated precision and repetition, such as surgery. Meanwhile so-called telepresence robotics enables people to be “present” for meetings or activities via a mobile video screen. Other forms of human enhancement include augmented reality devices that help people perceive their environment with richer relevant information. Google’s Glass eyewear drew attention as one of the first such devices that could be worn in everyday situations, though the technology was widely panned due to privacy issues and aesthetic appeal. Microsoft’s Hololens wearable device can similarly map a user’s environment and display data, though it is seen as bulky and uncomfortable. ﻿These types of devices will generally become suitable for daily use, however. Google and other companies have also developed automatic, real-time translators; once mocked, they can now provide accurate translation at lightning-fast speeds thanks to recent advances in deep learning, which mimics the functions of a human brain to help computers absorb information. When combined with mobile phones or augmented reality devices, these tools could potentially eliminate the need for human translators (there may even be less of a need for people to continue trying to learn foreign languages entirely). Some have envisioned neural implants that directly connect such technology to a human brain in order to aid not only in translation, but also computation and memory. Some prosthetics are already controlled directly by a human nervous system - cameras can be linked to human brains in order to provide visual information to blind people, for example. While artificial intelligence systems will greatly increase our ability to interact with our environment, many jobs will be affected.
