That includes those that have generally been considered safe from the invasion of robotic workers, like travel guides and news anchors.

name: Interconnected Risks
description: A cluster of interconnected environmental risks, including extreme weather events, climate change, and water crises, have consistently featured among the top-ranked risks in the World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report. Each risk is tied to other categories; changing weather patterns or water crises can therefore trigger or exacerbate geopolitical and social issues, like domestic or regional conflict and involuntary migration - particularly in politically fragile areas. Likewise, the ineffective management of the oceans, atmosphere, and climate systems can have local as well as global consequences that extend well beyond the environment. While non-environmental risks have typically flared and then subsided as conditions vary, or as the international community mobilizes to manage them, environmental issues consistently remain among the top global risks from year to year - pointing to a systemic problem. Responding effectively has proven to be a challenge. While the Paris Agreement on climate change was ratified by 122 countries as of January 2017, for example, just about six months later the US, one of the world’s biggest sources of carbon dioxide emissions, announced plans to withdraw.   As noted in a 2016 report published by the United Nations Environmental Programme, even if countries deliver on their Paris Agreement commitments, the world will still warm by as much as 3.2°C, far above the targeted level of 2°C. The impacts of this are spreading. According to the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, an annual average of 25.3 million people were displaced by climate- or weather-related events between 2008 and 2016, and the Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters has estimated that 96 million people were affected by natural disasters in 2017. Communities in Alaska, Fiji, and Kiribati have already had to be relocated, or are making plans to do so amid rising sea levels. A 2016 World Bank report suggested that water stress may trigger extreme societal problems in regions such as the Middle East and the Sahel - where water scarcity could affect as much as 6% of GDP by 2050. The same report projected that water availability in cities could decline by as much as two-thirds between 2015 and 2050, as a result of climate change and increased competition within the energy and agriculture sectors.

name: International Frameworks
description: The unanimous adoption by the United Nations Human Rights Council of the Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights in 2011 is generally considered a landmark in the regulation of the relationship between business and human rights. However, it remains unclear how the Guiding Principles can be most effectively implemented. On this point, there is divergence across states and in specific industries and companies. On one hand, progress has clearly been made in some states and sectors. On the other, as put in the 2015 Chatham House research paper on Business and Human Rights: Bridging the Governance Gap, there remains a lack of capacity and awareness in some firms, as well as incentives which frustrate the drive to comply. In other words, even if we recognize the normative significance of the Guiding Principles, increased state, private and civil society engagement is needed. Since the adoption of the Guiding Principles, the debate moved forward in a number of ways. Two are worth emphasizing. First, there has been a significant degree of domestic activity in a number of states – both in a hard regulatory sense, and in the incorporation of human rights standards into procurement and tender processes. Notably, more than 30 countries have developed or are in the process of developing National Action Plans on business and human rights. A central point of contestation – and one area in which many argue that the Guiding Principles do not go far enough – concerns whether states have an obligation to regulate the extraterritorial conduct of corporations present within their jurisdiction. For example, the Maastricht Principles on Extraterritorial Obligations of States in the Area of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, issued by a group of international experts in 2011, explicitly endorse the idea that states are required to prevent extraterritorial rights violations. Even if no international law duty on states has crystallized, there appears to be normative development in this direction. At this stage, however, states are generally unwilling to agree that any extraterritorial obligation to regulate the external activities of corporate nationals exists. Second, and more generally, the relationship between self-regulation in the private sector and legally binding measures continues to provoke debate. On one level, of course, there is the temptation to say that complementary approaches are possible. That is certainly the case in a basic sense; it is likely that a mix of hard and soft measures will lead to better results over time, and the practical limitations of hard law should be taken into account. Initiatives including the Kimberley Process, the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, and the Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights seem to suggest that soft law initiatives can achieve moderate levels of success. On another level, however, some express concern that the development of self-regulatory regimes may undermine the push for harder processes, even where these are necessary. In undermining those efforts, little is then done to address the lack of accountability of private actors. This contested background informs a central current debate. In 2014, a resolution put forward in the United Nations Human Rights Council by South Africa and Ecuador called for steps to be taken towards the negotiation of an international treaty on business and human rights. As with any treaty, there is the overarching question of political will – which states would be willing to ratify and which obligations will they be willing to undertake. In addition, critics of the treaty path have reiterated their doubt that harder measures necessarily lead to better outcomes, and also wondered whether the variable subject matter is suited to a single treaty. For instance, John Ruggie, the Berthold Beitz Professor in Human Rights and International Affairs at Harvard’s John F. Kennedy School of Government, argued in a 2014 Kennedy School note that the category of business and human rights includes bodies of national and international law which address different problems, deal with different interests, and are underpinned by different institutional arrangements, all of which undermine the feasibility of a treaty. It remains to be seen how the political debate plays out.

name: International Investment Dynamics
description: In 2018, global foreign direct investment flows fell by nearly a fifth compared with the prior year, matching a low reached in the wake of the global financial crisis, according to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. At the same time, global assets under management had risen sharply to $79.2 trillion by 2017, from $48.2 trillion in 2007, according to the consultancy BCG. Clearly, there is no lack of capital available to fund sustainable development, but rather a shortage of capital that actually manages to flow into profitable projects. This needs to change, as an estimated $2.5 trillion in additional, annual financing is believed necessary in order to achieve the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals adopted in 2015. International investment agreements have come under intense scrutiny of late related to whether or not they have an impact or not on investment flows, and related to the topic of investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) - a mechanism that can give foreign investors the option of pursuing international arbitration instead of taking claims to host-state domestic courts. ISDS has been particularly controversial, and has stirred debate on related issues including its legitimacy, cost, and potential for conflicts of interest. Individual countries are responding to it in different ways, sometimes concluding agreements without ISDS, or with features that limit it. The European Union, for example, is pushing for a multilateral investment court, and Canada and the US are reassessing their own approaches; the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which was designed to replace the former North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), omits ISDS between the US and Canada - while keeping it (in restricted form) between the US and Mexico. Recently, another international investment issue has drawn attention: investment facilitation, which is intended to improve the transparency and predictability of investment measures, and to speed up administrative procedures. In addition to enhancing international cooperation and information sharing, it is important to improve the sustainability impact of international investment so that it genuinely benefits local communities.

name: Internet Access
description: Increasing global access to the internet could help information flow more freely. However, making access more widely available remains a challenge. As of 2017, nearly 80% of the total population of Europe was using the internet, compared with about 68% in the Americas, nearly 44% in Asia & Pacific and Arab States, and about 22% in Africa, according to the International Telecommunications Union (ITU). Those percentages were significantly greater among those between 15 and 24 years of age; about 96% of young people in Europe were online in 2017, 90% in the Americas, 72% in Asia & Pacific, 64% in Arab States, and roughly 40% in Africa, according to the ITU. Socio-economic status remains a significant potential barrier to internet access, according to the ITU. While more than 84% of households in the developed world had internet access in 2017, that figure fell to just under 43% for the developing world - and to less than 15% for so-called least developed countries, according to ITU figures. Barriers to access are also based on gender; the global internet penetration rate for men was nearly 51% in 2017, according to the ITU, and slightly less than 45% for women. The gender gap in terms of internet use actually increased between 2013 and 2017, the ITU said, widening from 11% to nearly 12%. While private companies such as Google and Facebook have made efforts to expand internet access, governments have also played important roles. Both public and private efforts will continue to be vitally important for broadening internet use, and in turn potentially bolstering transparency and facilitating inclusive economic growth.

name: Investing in Climate Action
description: Investments in green transportation, sustainable agriculture, and climate-resilient infrastructure can have a multiplier effect; according to the Business Commission for Sustainable Development, investing $320 billion annually in sustainable business models in developed economies could unlock $2.3 trillion in additional annual investment by 2030. A 2017 report published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development found that better integrating economic and climate action could increase average economic output in G20 countries by almost 3% by the year 2050. In addition, the International Finance Corporation has identified nearly $23 trillion in climate-smart investments in emerging markets through 2030. Globally, new investment in clean energy reached $334 billion in 2017; China led the way ($133 billion), followed by the US ($57 billion) and Japan ($23 billion), according to Bloomberg New Energy Finance. Corporations are signing long-term, large-scale renewable energy contracts that leverage incentives, and local financing is playing a growing role in these deals in developing countries. As of 2018, $10.3 billion had been pledged to the international Green Climate Fund - though that is far short of the $100 billion that had been targeted to be available annually by 2020. Governments can catalyse private investment in climate resilience, by providing incentives and funding innovation. Businesses can reinforce government action in turn, by making climate-smart investments and by supporting the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. According to the New Climate Economy report published in 2018 by the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate, $90 trillion will be spent globally through 2030 on new infrastructure, which exceeds the value of all current infrastructure stock. Developing countries are expected to account for roughly two-thirds of this new infrastructure investment, which can be made sustainable and compatible with climate goals through only modest additional upfront costs. Ultimately, these upfront costs can be more than offset by efficiency gains and fuel savings. The potential rewards are enormous; the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate’s report projects an economic gain of $26 trillion through the year 2030 if investments are made in low-carbon technologies and resilient infrastructure, rather than conducting business as usual. Such investments offer an unprecedented opportunity to leapfrog the wasteful, polluting infrastructure of the past, and accelerate the global transition to efficient, climate-resilient, and low-carbon economies.

name: Investing in Development
description: An estimated $7 trillion a year is thought to be needed in order to adequately invest in infrastructure, clean energy, water, sanitation, and agriculture - and to achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, which were adopted in 2015 and designed to guide global development through 2030. Governments alone will not be able to manage this; it will require unprecedented cooperation with the private sector and civil society organizations. The overall development finance system may need to be recalibrated, in order to ensure that institutions like development banks can elicit private sector involvement. Projects must be structured appropriately for early-stage capital investment, and approaches like “blended finance,” or the strategic use of development finance and philanthropic funds to mobilize private capital flows to emerging and frontier markets, must be deployed. Increasingly, perceptions are changing, and the financing of sustainable development is seen less as the sole preserve of governments or charities; it is now accepted as a legitimate, potentially profitable component of mainstream investment strategies. This has been helped by a growing general awareness that the global economic system operates in a closed loop, indelibly linking society and the environment. In addition, the sheer size of the investment opportunity is becoming better understood. An analysis released in 2018 by the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate estimated that bold action on climate change could create a $26 trillion economic boost from now through 2030, on top of what would be generated simply by conducting business as usual. The challenge will be to adequately reconfigure the investment landscape for both the public and private sector, in such a way that ensures sufficient funding.

name: Investing in India’s Human Capital
description: The Indian government’s 2018-19 Economic Survey highlighted a central problem for the economy: a need for greater investment in social infrastructure. While there has been some progress in terms of improving the country’s "human capital" (shorthand for a workforce’s skills and abilities), significant shortfalls remain. If they are not addressed, growth will continue to disappoint and it will not be inclusive. Due to the lack of “soft” and “hard” health infrastructure, for example, many people either have no access to health care or cannot afford it. According to National Sample Survey Office data from 2014, about 86% of the rural population and 82% of the urban population was not covered under a health expenditure scheme. This creates a medical poverty trap ensnaring nearly 7% of the country’s total population. Gender is an important component of this healthcare problem. Based on the government’s National Family Health Survey 2015-16, it is apparent that maternal health, education, and economic empowerment are deeply linked - and without the last two, women lack reproductive control. The health problems that result from this impose significant costs on the economy, and shrink the female labour force. In terms of education, India has fared somewhat better. According to the Annual Status of Education Report 2018 published by the non-governmental organization Pratham, the overall enrolment of children aged between six and 14 has been over 96% since 2010, and trends indicate that children are staying in school. However, learning levels show that there is still some distance to go. Nationally, about half of all children can read, and less than a third can do basic arithmetic. These gaps in foundational skills affect learning at later stages, and can degrade the quality of the labour force. The government’s flagship social infrastructure schemes, such as Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan and Ayushman Bharat, are important remedial measures. However, broader and deeper social infrastructure reform is needed. With government spending on public healthcare and public education now equal to 7.5% of GDP, India lags behind its peers. A relatively weak state capacity and weak incentive structures for service providers only add to the problem. As a result, the quality of public services is generally poor - which translates into poor human capital outcomes.

name: Investing in Infrastructure
description: The United Arab Emirates punches above its weight when it comes to infrastructure; the country ranked 1st in the Middle East and North Africa region and 15th worldwide in terms of infrastructure in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index. Cars and trucks are able to reach destinations in the UAE quickly and efficiently, its ports have significant capacity, and air transportation is facilitated by a relatively high number of available seats per week thanks to two highly-rated national carriers: Emirates Airlines, and Etihad Airways. The quality of the country’s infrastructure creates a positive environment for businesses (ranked 1st regionally on this metric and 9th worldwide in the Forum’s index) and facilitates access to jobs; it is not uncommon for individuals living in Dubai to work more than 100 kilometres away in Abu Dhabi, or vice versa. The World Bank, in a report published in spring 2018, described the UAE’s federal government budget and the budgets for individual emirates that year as expansionary; Dubai’s contained a notable uptick in infrastructure spending in preparation for Expo 2020 - a planned, six-month-long world fair expected to draw 25 million visitors and generate more than 275,000 jobs. The UAE’s infrastructure development has also focused on information and communications technology. The country has one of the highest rates of ICT adoption in the world, according to the Forum’s competitiveness index, comparable with that of economies like Sweden and Singapore. The UAE’s ranking for ICT adoption helped to place it among the top 10 economies in the world in terms of “future-readiness,” a measure of ability to adapt to economic and technological disruption, in the Forum’s index. In addition, the country has the highest mobile-broadband subscription penetration rate in the world, at 243%, positioning it at the frontier of 5G - a new generation of mobile communications technology seen as a key enabler of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Etisalat, an Emirati telecoms multinational, has announced more than $800 million in 5G-related infrastructure upgrades for 2018. The challenge for the UAE will be to transform sizeable infrastructure investment and technological readiness into increased innovation capability - on this metric, the country lagged behind most advanced economies in the Forum’s index, by placing 35th.

name: Investing in People
description: The World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index ranked the UAE 2nd in the Middle East and North Africa region in terms of the quality of its labour market. However, in terms of the “future-readiness” of its workforce, or the ability of workers to act as forces for change rather than becoming the victims of change, the country ranked below all of its Gulf neighbours - and well below most advanced economies in the index. The Emirati economy is labour-intensive, and relies largely on relatively inexpensive, low-skilled foreign labour. According to UAE government data, nearly 90% of the country’s population, and 99% of its private-sector workforce, are made up of non-citizens. Most Emiratis are drawn to better-paying jobs available in the public sector, or lack the qualifications to take on well-paid, highly-skilled jobs outside of government. According to the Forum’s index, the quality of the UAE’s “human capital” remains a constraint on economic growth. Members of the current workforce have on average less than 10 years of schooling, and the segmentation of the workforce, with little mobility among different areas, adds to the rigidity of the labour market and reduces the utilization of available talent. A key weakness shared by the UAE with the wider region is the participation of women in the workforce; the UAE ranked 117th out of 140 economies in the index, while Qatar ranked 101st and Saudi Arabia placed 131st. In order to create a more future-ready economy, the UAE is attempting to transition to a knowledge- and services-based economy that feeds on innovation rather than natural resources - and which depends less on low-skilled foreign labour. This will require significant investment in higher education and greater efforts to leverage local talent, including women. The Emirate of Dubai has had related measures in place for more than a decade. Meanwhile the Emirate of Abu Dhabi has worked with foreign academic institutions including the Sorbonne and New York University to establish local branches, and the federal government in 2017 rolled out standardized, innovation-oriented curricula for schools across the country. The country’s openness to new approaches to boosting education is illustrated by a law spearheaded by the UAE Ministry of Culture and Knowledge Development in 2016 that mandated free time for employees during work hours in order to enable them to read.

name: IoT Value Creation and Business Models
description: The Internet of Things can improve efficiency and productivity as it connects everyday machines via the web - but it cannot create value out of nothing. It requires significant innovation, greater investment, and broader participation in every industry where it is poised to have an impact. The IoT draws from multiple disciplines in order to build something greater than would be possible through siloed innovation; as a result of its deployment, technology providers can see increased hardware and service sales, marketing firms can grow through improved analytics, and consumers can directly benefit through improved health and wellness monitoring, or by reducing monitored fuel consumption. While there is a continual need to innovate via the IoT, and to capitalize on its power to disrupt, its greatest potential is to create sustainable, shared value. For example, smart thermostat providers can turn a profit through an initial sale and subsequent offering of data analytics, while the homeowner buying the device can reap monthly savings from smart energy management and improved consumption data. Meanwhile so-called conversational commerce conducted with businesses by that homeowner via devices on his or her walls and shelves, can drive retail sales and create ongoing customer relationships. Vehicles that are connected via the Internet of Things can collect data about themselves, help dealerships proactively schedule required maintenance, and improve efficiency while streamlining auto manufacturers’ spare parts supply chains. Governments can meanwhile partner with technology companies to form public-private partnerships to draw capital investment needed to build infrastructure that utilizes the IoT to improve public services. An important part of drawing this investment is an ability to change conventional business models. For example, what was once a one-time sale can become a service models; for proof of this, look no further than to the IoT-fueled transition from selling individual vehicles, to car sharing, to shared mobility services, and eventually towards autonomous mobility services. Subscription-based services can also pair seemingly dissimilar technologies together to create more value both for the companies selling them and for the people buying them - for example, by coupling an internet-enabled smoke detector with a home security webcam. Data analytics is another disruptive business model ingredient stemming from the IoT, where so-called “information exhaust” (the data footprints we leave online by using sites and services) can be turned into insights to develop better products or target ad campaigns. To be sure, though, only a balanced and transparent approach to making use of this data is appropriate.

name: Italy's Innovation Drive
description: Research and development spending as a percentage of GDP in Italy was 1.35% in 2017, according to Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development data - below the OECD average of 2.37%. Still, Italy’s figure represents a increase compared with prior decades, when it was as low as 1.09% (2006) and 0.95% (1996). In order to better harness the benefits of entrepreneurship and the promise of digital transformation, Italy must strengthen its innovation capacity, improve the readiness of its workforce, and expand the availability of financing. The government that was appointed in 2018, and which collapsed in August 2019, did not seem to have innovation at the forefront of its political agenda; the word “productivity” did not appear in its so-called “Contract for the Government of Change." However, there is much work yet to be done - while Italy’s spending on R&D is about 7.6% of the total for the European Union, for example, the country’s number of patents filed concurrently in the EU, Japan, and the US has been noticeably lower, according to OECD data. This may be linked to relatively low spending by private businesses on research and development relative to public spending. About 95% of Italian firms had fewer than 10 employees as of 2015, according to Eurostat data, and small- and medium-sized enterprises accounted for 78.6% of employment and “value added” in the country in 2016 - far higher than the 53.5% in the United Kingdom, for example, or the 63.2% in France, according to a report published by the European Commission. Meanwhile the proportion of workers who are highly skilled and educated has remained relatively low in Italy, according to OECD data. Italy also has one of the lowest adult participation rates in so-called lifelong learning activities, at 25%, compared with the OECD average of 50%. The adoption of more appropriate innovation and education policies is required, in order to increase the country’s ability to embrace new technologies in a socially sustainable way. Again, the erstwhile coalition government that came to power in 2018 seemed to have little regard for this issue prior to its collapse.

name: Italy’s Banks
description: Italy’s post-2015 economic recovery has helped improve balance sheets at the country’s banks. The flow of new, non-performing bank loans is back to pre-financial crisis levels, while the existing stock of non-performing loans has fallen - though individual banks are in various states of health. The completion of several capital increases at local lenders has improved the sector’s profile compared with those in other European countries, though it still suffers from a funding gap; a eurozone liquidity crisis would create severe problems. According to the Bank of Italy, margins at the country’s banks actually increased during early 2018, thanks to higher fees and lower staff costs. The sector’s restructuring is at an early stage, however. Technology developments and new services pose major challenges to traditional players, which need to reinvent their businesses to match leaner cost structures. A series of mergers and acquisitions could restructure the system, but would face obstacles including regional differences and opaque governance. In terms of savings and cooperative banks specifically, past governments have sought to strengthen their capitalization, though related reforms have been incomplete. Soon after the arrival of a populist government in 2018 (which collapsed in August 2019), government bond yields, a measure of the perceived risk for creditors, rose sharply. This threatened to raise the cost of credit for banks and, eventually, for borrowers. According to the Bank of Italy, as of early 2018 Italian banks were continuing to make net redemptions, with the volume of bond issuance declining. Dedicated plans for tackling the interdependence of the country's banks and sovereign bonds are required; the amount of Italian government bonds that these banks hold is excessive, and hinders their flexibility to make more productive loans to firms. However, enacting regulation that sets strict limits on banks’ holdings of domestic sovereign debt could result in bond fire sales, and turbulence in debt markets. Less extreme, more practical solutions could involve simply decreasing the government’s debt load, European-wide regulation that sets capital ratios for banks’ holdings of riskier sovereign debt, introducing nearly risk-free euro securities, and packaging sovereign bonds from various countries within the eurozone.

name: Job Creation and Entrepreneurship
description: The pace of global job creation has been sluggish. In addition, when new jobs are created they are often not of a high quality, or the related process is not inclusive, according to the International Labour Organization’s 2017 World Employment and Social Outlook report. Emerging economies, where an estimated 3.6 million additional people joined the ranks of the unemployed between 2016 and 2017, have been particularly affected. Job creation in these countries will need to keep pace with local demographic dynamics (such as relatively youthful populations, and expanding middle classes), and better attention must be paid to providing safe, quality employment. Young people continue to be disproportionately affected by global unemployment; the unemployment rate for youth is nearly three times higher than it is for the adult population, according to the International Labour Organization's report, while in sub-Saharan Africa alone an estimated 12.4 million young people will enter the labour force during the next four years. In order to ensure that as many young people as possible are able to productively enter the workforce, and keep pace with rapid technological change, existing job creation strategies need to be complemented by new models and approaches. In addition, there should be a greater focus on promoting entrepreneurship - a crucial driving force behind job growth, which will only become more prominent as the Fourth Industrial Revolution proceeds. The 2012 report Why Becoming Large Matters: How Scalable, High-Growth Entrepreneurs Can Help Solve the Jobs Crisis, published by Omidyar Network and Endeavor Insight, estimated that high-growth entrepreneurial firms, on average, create more than 200 jobs as they expand. That is significantly more than traditional small- and medium-sized enterprises. Enabling startups to quickly scale up in size is therefore one of the most important mechanisms for policy-makers and business leaders to focus on, in order to help solve the global job creation crisis. One particular tool that has drawn interest from governments in many regions is the so-called startup accelerator, or a program designed to help early-stage companies develop business plans and funding opportunities, while they receive mentorship and corporate introductions. A report published by the government in the United Kingdom in 2017 found that there were 163 accelerator programs active in the UK alone.

name: Keeping Populations Healthy
description: The surplus of data being generated every day through the use of mobile phones and social media can be used to better track and contain the outbreak of illness and disease. A report published by researchers at Northeastern University in 2017 showed that Twitter posts can be monitored in order to predict the spread of seasonal flu in real time, for example, while mobile phone data has been used to track the contacts of people with Ebola in order to contain its spread in West Africa. While the quality of available data can help decision-makers respond more efficiently, improved communications efforts can help keep people better informed. Officials in the US have struggled in recent years to communicate effectively about health threats, according to a report published in the journal Health Security in 2017; during the 2014 Ebola outbreak, some depictions of the threat posed to the US caused unnecessary public concern, according to the report, which recommended being more explicit about uncertainty, and avoiding the phrase “out of an abundance of caution.”       Increasing life expectancy will lead to a doubling of people in the world who are at least 60 years old by 2050, and then a tripling of that age group fifty years after that, according to the United Nations. This is triggering a number of healthcare-related concerns. The current global healthcare workforce is rarely trained to work with older people to ensure they can increase control over their own health, according to a report published by the World Health Organization in 2016. In addition, there is a lack of sufficiently qualified instructors in gerontology and geriatrics, according to the report, and a general lack of funding for related training. In addition, as people live longer they are being afflicted with a growing number of non-communicable diseases such as cancer and diabetes. In the Americas, the projected home to 200 million older adults by 2020 (compared with about 100 million as of 2006), non-communicable diseases are responsible for seven out of 10 deaths among people aged 70 or older, according to the Pan American Health Organization and the WHO; in the US, more than 90% of older adults have at least one chronic disease. The PAHO and WHO are supporting related efforts to strengthen prevention, increase early detection, and ensure universal access to quality care.

name: Labour Informality
description: Peru’s level of labour informality, or grey market employment that falls outside of government regulation and supervision, is among the highest in the region; 73% of employed Peruvians worked in the grey market in 2017, according to data from the country’s National Institute of Statistics and Informatics. International comparisons suggest that labour informality in Peru is between 10 and 20 percentage points higher than what might be expected for a country with its income levels. In rural areas, about 95% of the economy is informal, and in urban areas the figure is 66.5%, according to a 2015 report from Peru’s Ministry of Production. More than half of the country’s small and medium-sized enterprises operate informally, according to the report. More than one third of the Peruvian labour force is self-employed, according to the Inter-American Development Bank’s (IDB) 2015 report Jobs for Growth, while 70% of the formal work contracts in the country are temporary. Turnover rates are high; about 35% of workers stay in their jobs for less than a year. These figures reflect a misallocation of resources, and a low level of labour market productivity. The IDB’s report also notes that only 28% of the country’s workers contribute to its pension system as a result of labour market distortions, which is significantly lower than the average of 45% among Latin American countries. This situation can be explained by a combination of the relatively high cost of running a formal, regulated business, contrasting labour, tax and social security regimes, and a lack of workers with necessary skills. Dismissal costs, or a company’s costs related to employee protections against being fired or laid off, are equivalent to 13% of the average annual salary in Peru, the highest level in the region, according to IDB data. In addition, the country’s social insurance system creates perverse incentives, and fuels both informality and self-employment.  The types of education and vocational training available in Peru are generally disconnected from the needs of businesses in the country. Nearly half of all Peruvian firms face difficulties when it comes to finding workers with appropriate skills, according to the results of a 2016-2017 survey published by staffing firm ManpowerGroup, compared with a global average of 40%. Peru placed next-to-last among 15 countries ranked in terms of student performance in financial literacy in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) published in 2017.

name: Labour Market
description: Bolivia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the costs related to terminating a redundant worker, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 0.00, resulting in a rank of 138th out of 138 countries; in terms of active policy support for low-skilled workers and the unemployed (referred to as "active labour policies" in the competitiveness index) where it has a progress score of 13.80 that results in a rank of 134th out of 140 countries; and in terms of the flexibility granted to companies to hire and fire workers where it has a progress score of 20.20 that results in a rank of 139th out of 140 countries. Other indicators reflect a better performance: workers' rights, where it has a progress score of 71.10 that results in a rank of 60th out of 116 countries; in terms of regional mobility for workers (referred to as "internal labour mobility" in the competitiveness index) where it has a progress score of 73.40 that results in a rank of 7th out of 140 countries; and in terms of labour taxes paid by companies as a percentage of profits where it has a progress score of 85.00 that results in a rank of 86th out of 140 countries.

name: Labour Market Demographics
description: Global demographic shifts are having a tremendous impact on the global economy, and on the ways in which individual countries must develop their respective labour forces. While populations in countries with large, established economies like Germany and Japan are rapidly ageing, for example, developing regions of the world such as the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa have large, burgeoning populations of young people (while more than 21% of Germany’s population was older than 65 as of 2017, according to World Bank data, that figure slipped to just 3% for Ghana, Benin, Cameroon, and the Republic of the Congo). Much of the value in any one economy is produced by its human capital, or the individuals who possess the skills needed to drive economic growth. Yet, these differing population structures in different countries are striking. One constant among countries in terms of population is typically gender; however, while women may form roughly half of any given country’s population, the dividends of female talent are often diluted by the structural challenges that women face when they enter the workforce.  Talent pools, or the skilled population in any one economy, can shrink and expand in tandem with changing demographic structures. Aging economies regularly experience shortages in skilled personnel, for example. Some such economies - for example, Japan - are looking to automation to bridge emerging gaps, while others such as Germany and Italy have considered boosting their populations by encouraging immigration flows (which has in turn aggravated debates about immigration policy, and fuelled the rise of populist political parties). In younger countries, it is critical to ensure that primary and secondary school education systems are well funded, and effective at providing necessary skills for future labour forces. When a country’s working population is poised to remain fairly consistent for the foreseeable future - with no large influx or outflux of talent anticipated - lifelong learning initiatives can ensure a consistent supply of individuals with skills that match labour market demand. Varying labour demographics across economies mean there is no single model for ensuring consistent talent pools; specific, targeted policy interventions and planning are therefore necessary.

name: Labour Market Participation
description: A low rate of labour force participation (the number of people employed or actively looking for work relative to an entire population), triggered by ageing workers, mandatory retirement rules, cultural barriers to women in the workforce, and weak rates of job creation, can undercut a country’s social protection systems. In the US, for example, the participation of men in their prime in the labour force has been in decline for more than a half a century, according to a report published by the Brookings Institution in 2017 (masked in part by the influx of women into the country’s labour force in record numbers, until 1990). This decline has contributed to stagnation in terms of rising (or, not rising) incomes, and has also impacted the tax base - as fewer employees generate payroll taxes, and more people require public assistance. The global labour force participation rate among those 15 years of age or older in the US fell to 61.9% as of 2017, from 65.4% as of 1990, according to data published by the World Bank; that roughly mirrored a global decline, to slightly less than 62% from 65.7% over the same period, according to World Bank data. As of 2017, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, there was a broad range of labour force participation rates around the world, from 58% in Turkey, to 74.2% in Russia, and 88% in Iceland. In the United Kingdom, the labour force participation rate has actually increased in recent years, to 78.5% in 2017 from 76.3% as of 2010, according to OECD data. One potential reason for this is heavy immigration from other European Union member states - which may be impacted by the UK’s plans to leave the EU following the Brexit referendum in 2016. Another cited cause is change to UK employment regulation - which, for example, has made it easier to be a working parent. This is just one example of a recent, broader shift from passive income support (like unemployment benefits) to more creative, proactive approaches. The UK is not alone. Increasing labour market participation has been proven to trigger economic growth, and better integrating older workers in particular is a hot topic in many countries.

name: Labour and Education Dynamics
description: Labour market data indicate that the Italian economy has been on an uneven path to recovery in recent years. The proportion of those who are actively looking for work but are nonetheless unemployed dropped to below 11% by the end of 2017, according to Eurostat, from a peak of 13% in 2014. Still, the overall unemployment rate in Italy remains relatively high, at 9.9% as of July 2019, compared with the 6% registered before the crisis in 2007 (by way of comparison, the rate for Germany as of mid-2019 was 5%, while Spain’s was 13.6%). In the past, Italians (particularly women, and young people from the south), were not known for actively seeking work. In most cases, this was simply because they were discouraged by their odds of finding a job. Yet, this is gradually changing. Since 2014, the fraction of people actively looking for a job has increased, for example, though it remains lower than the eurozone average. Employment data show many of those looking for a job managed to find one; in summer 2017 the number of people working in the country topped 23 million for the first time since 2008. Labour market data in northern regions of Italy are relatively similar to what can be found in the most developed European areas. In the southern Italian regions and the country’s islands, however, unemployment rates as of 2016 ranged between 12% (in Abruzzo) and 23% (in Calabria), according to Eurostat data, or between three and four times higher than those in the north. In 2014, the Italian government adopted a “Jobs Act” that encouraged hiring by temporarily making the government responsible for social security contributions for those firms that hire new, permanent employees. Yet, recent data do not reflect a qualitative shift. According to Istat employment data, the proportion of short-term employees in the overall workforce has actually increased. In 2018, a newly-installed government issued a “Dignity Decree” aimed at discouraging short-term contracts, by making their renewal costlier and more tightly regulated (the issue of whether the decree, which has since been converted into law, will really deliver the intended outcome of making work less precarious has been the subject of heated debate).

name: Leadership and Governance
description: Saudi Arabia's high-profile legal crackdown on corruption can be viewed as part of a broader commitment to address the problem. The kingdom ushered in a new generation of leadership when King Salman named his then 31-year-old son crown prince in 2017. Now, Mohammed bin Salman is in a position to reshape Saudi Arabia for decades to come. The government’s “Vision 2030” plan calls for the diversification of the country’s oil-dependent economy, and other structural transformation; the crown prince has touted the plan as a means to turn Saudi Arabia into an investment powerhouse that is both transparent and open about its shortcomings, and a hub connecting Asia, Europe, and Africa. According to the World Bank’s Worldwide Governance Indicators published in 2017, Saudi Arabia’s best scores were in regard to the “Rule of Law,” “Government Effectiveness,” and “Control of Corruption”; its core weakness, meanwhile, was a low score in terms of “Voice and Accountability.” On that metric, the kingdom scored significantly below the average both for its neighbours, and for non-Organisation for Economic Co-operation Economic and Development (OECD) members that are also high-income countries. In addition to a lack of accountability, challenges facing Saudi Arabia include often-outdated regulations, and lingering corruption. The country will have to work around an entrenched, mid-level bureaucracy that may be resistant to change, and the general population requires clear communication about why the change is happening - and why they are being directly affected as a result. Saudi efforts to modernize the economy have meant the reduction of public subsidies, for example. A plan to cut salaries and benefits for the roughly 60% of Saudis who are government employees had to be reversed in the face of persistent discontent expressed online, according to Saudi Arabia in Transition, a paper published by the Harvard Kennedy School’s Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs in 2017. Increased social buy-in could help foster the kingdom’s efforts to remake itself. To that end, the Saudi government is planning a system of financial allowances, in order to help low- and middle-income households better cope with the costs of economic reform programs.

name: Legal Technology
description: The use of technology to deliver the components of legal infrastructure, including regulation, analysis, and adjudication, is growing - and may grow even more rapidly in the future, as regulatory limits on legal technology are relaxed. This technology has the potential to address the lack of access to justice pervading both rich and poor countries, and is already being used to deliver basic legal information. While expensive legal research technologies such as LexisNexis and Westlaw have been in use for decades, the cost of accessing legal information is dropping. Google and other search engines are providing greater access to statutes, regulations, and court decisions, and applications for mobile phones are being developed that provide quick access to both basic legal information, and online visualization tools to bolster the understanding of complex legal rules. Legal technology is progressing to the point where it can provide analysis of legal materials, in order to provide customized advice; artificial intelligence can analyse large, complex bodies of law, and help predict regulatory treatment and the outcomes of adjudication. While more advanced technology is now mostly available only to large corporations, that should change in the near future.  Legal technology is in development that can deliver representation services, such as filing forms or petitions, while so-called “legal bots” are available to help challenge parking tickets, file immigration documents, and lodge complaints against mobile phone providers or credit agencies. These technologies may help reduce corruption in areas such as applications for construction permits and licensing. Other developments include the use of machine learning (computers that self-learn) to review contracts and compliance, and computer-based tools to assess large volumes of documents in connection with litigation. Legal technology tools are likely to gain in sophistication and provide more strategic assistance, and suggest courses of action. Artificial intelligence is already being used by government institutions to decide on bail amounts and sentencing, and to predict criminal behaviour; this is likely to raise questions about algorithmic bias, privacy, data protection, and potential abuse of government power. As economic and social complexity increase, we are likely to see greater need to develop legal technology that is directly engaged in regulation. Ultimately, the role of legal technology may go beyond implementing existing laws and regulations, to devising and executing limits on autonomous agents.

name: Leveraging Renewable Energy
description: Despite nearly two decades of steady economic growth, Africa still suffers from power shortages and a lingering energy dependence on biomass that undermine efforts to reduce poverty. Only an estimated 43% of people in sub-Saharan Africa have access to electricity, according to the World Bank, and there is also a lack of access to clean, non-polluting cooking facilities. About 80% of sub-Saharan Africans rely on biomass (such as charcoal) for household needs including cooking. As a result, about 600,000 people in the region die each year of household air pollution, of which nearly half are children under the age of five. The use of traditional biomass is also a key driver of deforestation, which in turn exacerbates the impacts of climate change. And while hydropower is a major source of energy in a number of African countries, that is being affected by climate change and related drought. According to a report published by the Africa Progress Panel, frequent power cuts resulting from hydropower shortages have reduced revenue at large firms by an estimated 6%, and at smaller entities operating in the prevalent informal, grey economy by as much as 16%. While climate change presents serious health and infrastructure challenges for Africa, high temperatures and steady amounts of sunshine provide the continent with abundant renewable energy resources. These consist of concentrated solar power, photovoltaics, wind energy, geothermal energy, and bioenergy. According to the International Renewable Energy Agency, Africa’s total theoretical energy potential from concentrated solar power, photovoltaics and wind energy combined is equal to about 1,590 Petawatt hours (by way of comparison, one Petawatt hour is equal to three times the amount of electricity Mexico consumes in a year, according to the Inter-American Development Bank). Renewable energy systems could reduce the use of biomass, improve productivity, reduce carbon emissions, and improve living standards. Although the prices of these systems have been falling steadily, the initial capital costs remain high - and are a major barrier to entry. However, innovative business models are being deployed to improve affordability. One good example is M-KOPA Solar in Kenya, a company that brings affordable solar energy to off-grid communities using mobile phone technology. African governments can meanwhile boost much-needed private investment in legacy energy systems, by reforming highly-indebted, corrupt, and inefficient state-owned power utilities.

name: Lifecycle Protection
description: Thanks to improvements in health care, nutrition, and combatting disease, life expectancy in most countries is increasing. By 2015, global life expectancy at birth had reached 73 years for women (compared with 69 years as of 2005), and 69 years for men (compared with 65 years as of 2005), according to a United Nations report published in 2017; the sharpest increases were found in Africa. This trend has led to a number of substantial cultural and policy changes, such as increases in designated legal retirement age in some countries. In the United Kingdom, for example, the State Pension age for women is increasing to 65 from 60, and there are plans to further, gradually increase the State Pension age for both men and women through 2028. For insurance companies, this demographic shift has created significant uncertainty about how long insurance customers will live, and the assumptions underpinning actuarial models for mortality are increasingly vulnerable to error - potentially leading to higher pay-out ratios than anticipated. Actuaries have a specific term for this phenomenon: “longevity risk.” In the US, insurers have developed market-based fixes to spread related risk around. For example, a so-called longevity bond can be issued by reinsurers, which pays interest relative to a specific group of people; as the mortality rate of that group increases, payments made by insurers to bondholders decline.   Shifting norms when it comes to the structure of families also have implications for the insurance industry. The growing global population of single and divorced people, for example, has resulted in changing needs for insurance products. The fastest-growing type of household in Europe between 2006 and 2016 was composed of a single person, registering a 3.4 percentage point increase during the period, according to Eurostat data (the share of households with children decreased by more than two percentage points over the same period). A Pew Research Center report published in 2014 estimated that by the time Americans who were then young adults reach their mid-40s to mid-50s, one quarter of them are likely to never have been married. The declining number of people getting married and having kids will result in fewer adult children available as care providers for elderly parents; a research article published in the journal Health Economics in 2015 explored how that may boost demand for long-term care insurance, for example.

name: Lifelong Learning Pathways
description: As career paths are altered by large-scale labour market disruptions, there is an increasing need for lifelong learning - at all ages, both inside and outside of schools. Adult training is vital for ensuring that those already in the workforce, and their employers, are able to navigate the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Adaptive re-skilling, or helping employees gain new skills, will be a key way to alleviate unemployment, unequal access to resources, and inactivity. A dynamic training environment has the potential to provide deeply fulfilling careers to workers and to encourage social cohesion, as noted in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization’s 3rd Global Report on Adult Learning and Education. In nearly every industry, technological and socio-economic changes are limiting the adequacy of employee skill sets. To best facilitate this, education systems need mechanisms to motivate individual engagement with active learning. While nearly 84% of the world’s talent under the age of 25 is being optimized through education, that figure falls to 45% for those over 25, as calculated by the World Economic Forum’s 2017 Global Human Capital Report. Developing countries have made great progress in expanding human capital investment in education for younger generations. However, education systems around the world continue to emphasize the front-loading of learning during an early stage of life, leaving older generations with educational attainment only as a memory from their youth. Skills decline when they are not used, as noted in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s Survey of Adult Skills. Understanding the typical lifecycle is key for mapping the points where people will likely have a need to refresh their skills, whether for re-entering the workforce after caring for a family member, or after having taken a career break after an illness. Fostering lifelong learning requires a focus on certification, and qualifications. Related systems should provide a range of appropriate credentials, the possibility to take short- and long-term options to re-train, and opportunities to explore adjacent, in-demand skills. A truly relevant education system cannot be delivered by the public sector or private sector alone; working together, governments, educators and the private sector should be able to develop the infrastructure required to enable learning and training opportunities for workers at all stages of their careers.

name: Limits of Monetary Policy
description: In an attempt to boost economic growth, central banks around the world have turned to unconventional monetary policy to reignite their economic engines. The US Federal Reserve, the Bank of England, the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan have all pursued unprecedented levels of quantitative easing in the form of bond buying and bank lending. In most cases the massive intervention and use of unconventional tools was a byproduct of the 2008 global financial crisis and the havoc it wreaked on developed economies. Central banks tried to use traditional methods to spur economic growth, but with interest rates near, or at, zero, and economic growth still not satisfactory, these banks turned to new tools. The unconventional monetary policies pursued by the big developed country central banks have had a fairly significant impact on both the financial markets and real economy of developed countries, and have also affected the financial markets of developing countries who did not directly participate in quantitative easing. According to the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs 2013 working paper on The Spillover Effects of Unconventional Monetary Policies in Major Developed Countries on Developing Countries, the impact of changes to long-term yields resulting from quantitative easing mean that the average GDP growth over 5 years would have been 1.88% less in the US, .70% less in Japan, .63% less in the Euro Area and, on average, .77% less in the BRIC (Brazil, China, India, Russian Federation) countries. The programs, however, are beginning to run out of steam, with many, including former central bank heads, believing that further stimulus via central banks will not be as effective, due to already low - and in some cases negative - interest rates and their effects on bank profitability and income for savers, the complexity of easing announcements, and market distortions. Many, including former central bankers, now thing it is time to move more towards fiscal stimulus tools.

name: Livability and Tourism in Switzerland
description: Zurich, Basel and Geneva regularly rank among the best cities in the world to live, and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has reported that Switzerland performs above average in terms of providing for well-being, jobs, income, health, environmental quality, and education. Those factors have bolstered Switzerland’s standing as a tourist destination (the country was among the first in Europe to develop a modern tourism industry). Switzerland ranked 10th overall in the World Economic Forum’s Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report 2017, 4th in terms of ground transportation, 6th in tourist service infrastructure, and 11th in air transport infrastructure. A finely-meshed public transportation network enables access even to relatively remote Alpine areas. “Swissness” can be a powerful marketing tool, both for tourism and for products sold both domestically and internationally. An image of pristine Alpine nature and healthy lifestyles has been reinforced by literature and advertising for decades. According to research published in 2016, between 52% and 89% of consumers worldwide were willing to pay a premium for Swiss products. However, Switzerland's tourism business faces challenges. The country dropped four places in the Forum’s 2017 Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report compared with 2015. This was related to poorer performance in terms of natural resources, diminished effectiveness of marketing, and the fact that Switzerland remains a relatively expensive destination; the country ranked last among 136 countries in terms of price competitiveness. In addition, Switzerland has encountered more difficulty in hiring foreign labour compared with previous years, according to the report, though an easing of tourist visa policy could help it regain competitiveness. The country’s more remote mountain regions and resorts are largely overshadowed by a few select destinations, like the Jungfrau region or Zermatt. There has also been an increasing gap between the development of top economic centres like Zurich, Geneva, and Basel, and second or third-tier cities that struggle to maintain competitiveness as places to live and work. Associated gaps in real estate prices, salaries, and educational levels may present a challenge to Switzerland’s system of direct democracy, which relies upon a certain level of homogeneity and mutual understanding. In addition, the concentration of population growth in Switzerland’s biggest cities places pressure on infrastructure in those locations. This threat has been largely mitigated thanks to good public transportation services, quality healthcare and education - and by a system of financial equalization across cantons (the state districts within Switzerland) designed to reduce disparities.

name: Local Arctic Communities
description: At the heart of the changing Arctic is a local population of about 4 million people representing over 40 different ethnic groups and more than a dozen languages. About 10% of the region’s inhabitants are members of indigenous communities, which are present in every Arctic country except for Iceland. Relatively recent and dramatic environmental changes have left no part of local life untouched. The melting sea ice both makes traditional hunting more difficult and transportation on ice roads connecting villages more risky, thereby decreasing food security and increasing isolation. In addition, the thawing permafrost (frozen ground) that rests under much of the region’s infrastructure has made it necessary to rebuild schools and other vital community structures - or, in the worst cases, relocate whole communities with dramatic social and economic consequences. These developments can exacerbate mental health challenges that have long been prominent in the Arctic, and are often related to rapid social change, limited local opportunities, and the historic oppression of indigenous people. The extent to which future development projects share benefits and empower local communities will largely determine whether these local cultures can continue to thrive. Some Arctic communities struggle not only with prevalent mental health issues, but also a lack of resources to provide health care. Initiatives like the Arctic Mental Health Working Group, coordinated by the US Arctic Research Commission, are trying to address these challenges. One example of an unexpected consequence of economic development in the Arctic is a high male-to-female ratio in some regions, mainly due to two trends: an emphasis on traditional male occupations such as fishing and resource extraction, and local women becoming more educated and interested in jobs outside of the area. Due to the expanding footprint of resource extraction in the Arctic, these imbalances may continue. In order to help young people better connect with their communities, share their voices, and provide their perspectives to Arctic decision-makers on trends like these, opportunities have been created including the Arctic Youth Ambassador Program. There is a general need to focus on education and innovation in the region as a corollary to resource development - in order to support sustainable, culturally-thriving, and vibrant Arctic communities.

name: Logistics Property and Infrastructure
description: The online retail boom is spurring new logistics infrastructure development. Prologis, the world’s biggest owner of distribution centres and logistics properties, estimates that for every €1 billion in annual online retail sales, 72,000 square metres of floorspace is required at fulfilment centres. Much of this space is being newly built, and not simply converted from existing warehouses. Online retailers also increasingly require local satellite depots both in and around urban areas, to provide same- or next-day delivery. These facilities are currently in short supply in many cities, raising the possibility of conventional retail space in shopping malls being converted for the logistics of online selling. In response to the surge in e-commerce, Prologis itself agreed in April 2018 to buy logistics property owner DCT Industrial Trust for $8.4 billion. In addition to online retailing, logistics real estate is also being restructured in response to the upgrading of transport infrastructure. More rapid and reliable transport leads to the centralization of inventory in fewer and bigger warehouses, clustered around motorway intersections or in the vicinity of freight terminals. While this process is well advanced in developed countries, in emerging markets it is creating new demand for logistics property in strategic locations. In many cities, a process known as “logistics sprawl” has dispersed logistical activity to the urban periphery, where land values are lower and transport connections are generally superior. Companies are becoming more interested in logistics facilities that combine good road access with rail or waterway connections, and expand their choice of transport mode. Logistics capacity is also likely to migrate away from floodplains and low-lying coastal locations that are exposed to the extreme weather events and sea level rise caused by climate change. In addition, warehouse buildings are being influenced by automation, 3D printing and the wider digitalization of supply chains. Logistics is now considered one of the most lucrative sectors of the commercial property market, thanks to good growth prospects and healthy long-term yields. Governments and municipal authorities that traditionally took a negative view of warehouses now promote them, in recognition of their employment generation and local economic impact. The growth of services in warehouses has meanwhile blurred the traditional distinction between warehousing and manufacturing, enabling logistics firms to compete more effectively for industrial-zoned land. Logistics hubs also play a key role in regional development strategies, often built around the nucleus of a major port or airport.

name: Logistics Skill Shortages
description: Logistics is labour-intensive, and its increasing technical sophistication is creating a need for new skills. A study by the Kühne Logistics University and the World Bank published in 2017 found that in many countries, these skills requirements are not being met. It revealed, for example, that in developing countries the skills shortage was most acute at the managerial level, while in the developed world many businesses struggle to find enough operational staff. The most widely publicized skills shortage relates to truck drivers, in countries including the US, Germany and the United Kingdom. It is estimated that the US will be short of 175,000 drivers by 2026, and Germany short of 150,000 drivers within 10 to 15 years. The problem is not confined to developed countries; truck driver shortages have been reported in South Africa, India and Brazil. The lack of qualified truck drivers is already impairing the quality and efficiency of road freight operations, and the situation is likely to worsen. Roughly 70% of supply chain practitioners in a recent Supply Chain World survey found it to be somewhat or extremely challenging to hire and retain talent. Meanwhile a third of businesses surveyed by Capgemini Consulting and Penn State University had settled into a “low skill equilibrium,” or changed their business models, because of a lack of supply chain talent.   There are numerous reasons for the inability to attract skilled employees: the poor public image of the logistics sector; uncompetitive wages and working conditions; a lack of logistics-related topics in school and university curricula; and inadequate training and apprenticeships. Intense competition and thin profit margins in logistics businesses such as road haulage have limited the ability to increase wages. In addition, efforts to professionalize employment have been counteracted by the so-called gig economy, which has fostered a pool of casual, part-time logistics workers. Labour shortages in the industry could ultimately be alleviated by automation. An Oxford University study estimated that the computerization and automation of 14 logistics occupations over the next 20 years could cut related employment in the UK by 41%. While the automation of trucks is currently being promoted as a means to ease the driver shortage, fully driver-less operation is unlikely for the foreseeable future.

name: Logistics and Delivery
description: The ability to deliver medical supplies via drone has already saved lives throughout East Africa, and is beginning to find a place in urban environments thanks to advances in control and reliability. While intense competition for existing delivery and logistics systems is not imminent, traditional logistics firms, startups and large technology companies are all making significant investments in drone delivery research & development. In order for drone delivery to become economically feasible, however, significant regulatory change is required that allows both for drone flights beyond a visual line of sight, and for multiple aircraft per single human operator. Companies such as Zipline, a San Francisco-based drone startup, have proven their ability to deliver blood products to rural hospitals in Rwanda, according to media reports. An early-stage project in 2017 helped hospitals in that country to cut average blood order and distribution time from eight hours to 45 minutes, decrease the wastage of blood from 6% system-wide to zero, and impact the lives of thousands of patients, including women who may have otherwise died due to hemorrhaging during childbirth. Meanwhile humanitarian organizations including UNICEF are working on drone-enabled medical supply chains in Malawi and Vanuatu. For more consumer-focused drone delivery systems, technology giants and traditional logistics companies are investing heavily in options for customers in the belief that people are willing to pay more for deliveries that can be made in less than 30 minutes. Amazon, DHL, UPS, and Google are all designing and manufacturing their own branded drones to deliver goods to their customers. Urban environments are the next frontier for drone delivery. In September 2017, the startup Matternet launched the first autonomous delivery drone to fly in an urban environment with official approval, in Switzerland. Japan has set an ambitious target for drone delivery within Tokyo by 2020, in time for the Summer Olympics that will be held there. Delivery in urban environments will likely require specialized infrastructure, both for launching drones and receiving packages, due to a lack of the large open areas that most current aerial delivery systems require. Many other unanswered questions remain about expected carbon emissions benefits, the impact on street traffic, and the potential to further exacerbate the existing divide between haves and have-nots.

name: Long Term Investing
description: In 2016 alone, life insurers collected about $2.6 trillion in premiums, according to reinsurer Swiss Re - making the industry one of the biggest wealth managers in the world. All insurers must carefully invest premiums, in order to ensure the companies can match liabilities and pay out on claims when the need arises. Life insurers, in particular, have a natural inclination towards long term investment, as claims are only likely to materialize after lengthy periods of as much as 50 years after a policy is acquired. Historically, insurers matched these liabilities by investing in annuities, or high yield, long term government bonds that pay out relatively well based on factors including interest rates. However, in the years following the financial crisis roughly a decade ago, many central banks have pursued monetary policies that involve low, and sometimes even negative interest rates. That has forced insurers to move into new investments, like high yield corporate bonds (debt raised by companies that involves a relatively high degree of risk), securitized credit (different kinds of loans packaged into a single, tradable instrument), emerging market assets, and infrastructure including the financing of roads, bridges and real estate.    Still, bonds have remained the most popular element of insurance companies’ portfolios, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which said in a report published in 2017 that 33 of the 43 companies it reviewed held more than half of their assets in bonds. And, amid the ongoing global economic recovery, central banks are more likely to shift direction on interest rate policies. According to Swiss Re’s annual review of, and outlook for the insurance industry published in November 2017, moderate global economic growth is expected for 2018, and long term government bond yields are expected to rise modestly as central banks raise policy rates - with a 3.2% rise anticipated in the US, for example. As central banks phase out low-interest-rate strategies, insurance companies will have to carefully manage their existing long term investments, in order to assess whether returning to a greater emphasis on government bonds is a viable option - or, if a mix of a greater variety of investments has become their new normal.

name: Long-Term Vision, Short-Term Needs
description: There is a commonly-held view that investors pursue short-term profit at the expense of long-term value. According to the results of a survey published by the Rock Center for Corporate Governance at Stanford University in 2019, 70% of CEOs and CFOs at S&P 1500 Index companies were facing pressure to maximize short-term returns at the expense of long-term growth. When firms focus on the short term, it often translates into lower investment in the long-term sustainability of a company at the expense of other stakeholders. Management has to be able to both articulate a long-term strategy and deliver sufficient short-term returns in order to ensure support and continued investment. Consistent metrics for measuring the success of long-term strategies are important. Corporate governance can play an important role in this regard by implementing incentives and pay aligned with these long-term metrics. Another means to tilt the balance towards a longer-term approach has been the increased adoption of Environment, Social and Governance (ESG) criteria in corporate strategies and investment decisions - which can draw the attention of shareholders zeroing in on firms with a longer-term, socially-conscious approach. According to a white paper published by the World Economic Forum in 2019, quarterly reporting requirements are not the sole reason for short-termism - though corporate leaders describe them as a “necessary evil.” According to the white paper, these leaders must become better storytellers about their companies, by framing each quarter as a step in a longer-term story. Management and their boards must engage in constant conversation about how the company will grow, and the risks it will take to get there. Leaders of global companies have been signing a World Economic Forum compact for responsive and responsible leadership, committing them to ensure that their boards oversee the definition and implementation of corporate strategies that pursue sustainable long-term value creation, to encourage the periodic review of corporate governance, long-term objectives and strategies at the board level, to promote meaningful engagement between the board, investors, and other stakeholders that builds mutual trust and promotes the highest possible standards of corporate conduct, and to implement policies, practices, and long-term strategies aimed at cultivating sustainable growth for the benefit of all stakeholders.

name: Long-term Incentives and Mandates
description: Institutional investors often have relatively long-term investment goals, put in place in order to adequately fund liabilities, preserve endowments, and provide for future generations. For some of these asset owners, especially pension and retirement funds, these goals reflect the long-term needs of individual plan members - who rely on these institutions to safeguard and augment savings they will rely on down the road. Ensuring that assets are managed in line with these long-term horizons is critical. This presents a challenge, however, as asset owners may have specific objectives tied to return goals and risk tolerance, while asset managers have internal incentives for portfolio managers and business leaders that tend to reward short-term performance - which can lead to excessive risk taking. The relationship between asset owners and managers is therefore often a time-horizon mismatch.  Ideally, there is an alignment of incentives and goals, often over a long period. Institutional investors’ best tool for this is an investment mandate that governs relationships, lays out specific terms, and can serve as a mechanism to align behaviours and objectives. Shaping these mechanisms with provisions oriented to long-term goals can help build stable, lasting investment partnerships and improve long-term performance. Translating long-term objectives into investment mandates can involve re-thinking the key performance indicators used to evaluate asset managers.
