While a company's quarterly financial performance provides an easy measuring stick, for example, it is unlikely to provide much information about future prospects over the duration of a long-term investment mandate. In designing long-term contracts, institutional investors should address whether or not fees and fee structures reward a long-term focus, to what extent benchmark-relative returns capture a specific strategy’s performance, and whether a contract encourages long-term commitment and protects against overreacting to short-term downturns. The asset manager should be able to commit to the long-term strategy, while maintaining the liquidity needed to meet permissible redemptions - and reporting tools should address long-term priorities. Starting a relationship with a shared, long-term mindset is more likely to lead to a mutually beneficial results for institutional investors and their managers.

name: Longevity
description: The United Nations has reported that the portion of the population over the age of 80 in developed economies increased by 62% between 2000 and 2015. Japan stands out among its ageing peers, as home to the oldest population on the planet; nearly 27% of its population was 65 or older as of 2017, compared with 15% in 1997, according to the World Bank. Projections indicate that the greying trend will only become more dramatic in the future, coupled with a dwindling population - according to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Japan’s total population is expected to decline by as much as 24% between 2010 and 2050, while the portion of those over the age of 65 is expected to increase to 40% by the end of that period. These trends may be more advanced in Japan, but are likely to also impact other developed and developing countries. Japan faces both a challenge and opportunity when it comes to transforming its systems to better adapt to longevity. Innovation in terms of service delivery for ageing consumers, creating barrier-free urban design and mobility, bolstering social security and pension systems, and developing more advanced healthcare delivery are all possible. Thanks to enabling technologies such as the Internet of Things (which is expanding the connectivity of everyday devices) and robotics, Japan could develop into a global hub for longevity.

name: Low Productivity in Mexico
description: Mexico’s rate of labour productivity has been 60% below the average for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, and 70% below that of the US in particular, according to a 2015 OECD report (the report cited such a broad dispersion of industrial activity across both high- and low-productivity sectors that it has lessened overall productivity, and undermined income equality). The country’s rampant informal, grey economy has persistently weighted on official productivity rates, according to an OECD forecast published in late 2018. The Mexican government created a National Productivity Committee in order to better coordinate policies and increase access to (and the quality of) education, while increasing legitimate, regulated job opportunities and bolstering investment in research & development. According to a 2016 Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) working paper, in order to increase its income per capita Mexico should prioritize productivity policies that zero in on infrastructure, the rule of law, and financing for both private enterprise and public health. While a shift to more legitimate economic activity could drive productivity and growth, more than half of employees and self-employed workers in Mexico remain informally employed, according to an outlook for the country published by the OECD in 2018 (the outlook suggested that Mexico introduce unemployment insurance - which could in turn make formal employment more attractive). According to the OECD, the gap between average OECD member productivity levels and those in Mexico is particularly significant for small- and medium-sized enterprises. In addition to hindering productivity, informality also impedes the broader collection of tax revenue; according to the country’s Secretariat of Finance and Public Credit, total tax revenue in Mexico was equal to 13% of GDP in 2017, compared with the OECD country average of 34.3%. Other factors impeding productivity include unfair or inadequate regulation, and the manipulation of public policy. The OECD has suggested that in addition to introducing unemployment insurance Mexico could improve productivity by increasing the consistency with which regulations are applied, lifting restrictions on foreign investment in sectors like transportation and banking, and easing licensing requirements in the retail trade.

name: Low Return Environment
description: All investors are confronted by the reality - currently and for the foreseeable future - of low returns. For alternative asset managers the biggest challenge ahead will be to prove their skill to their clients, and hunt down the best deals and the highest returns. This low-yield environment is largely a byproduct of the state of the global economy. National economies, already saddled with record levels of debt, are reluctant to continue borrowing at the levels of previous years, and slow growth around the globe has reduced the appetite to create the types of investment opportunities that allow investors to make the high returns of previous years. With investors all looking for sources of superior return, there is a danger of first, un-deployed capital, as investors wait for the right opportunity and second, of a herd mentality, seen in investors rushing to areas showing promise of superior returns in this climate. This has already been exhibited by institutional investors flocking to hedge funds post-2008 and then withdrawing, and most recently the keen interest that investors of all stripes have taken in Silicon Valley start-ups.

name: Machine Cooperation and Coordination
description: There are entire fields of research focused on enabling robots to cooperate. If robots are needed outside of controlled environments like factory floors, for example, they have to be able to quickly adapt to their surroundings in order to work both with other robots and with humans. Visual sensors help the machines to understand complex environments, while artificial intelligence aids their understanding of human gestures, facial expressions and even intentions. One of the forerunners in this area is Baxter, an industrial robot developed in 2011 that can be easily taught new tasks, thanks to natural language processing and synthesis using so-called deep learning, or training computers to learn in a way that is similar to a human brain absorbing information. This variety of robot can be easily communicated with using voice commands, and can be visually taught in a way that is much faster than the traditional method of entering commands into a handheld device. In addition to staffing an assembly line, robots can be useful as companions. Their powerful processors and advanced sensors allow them to recognize faces, understand voice commands, and do some pretty neat tricks. Amazon’s Alexa and Google Home are examples of potentially helpful companion robots, as is Jibo, developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, while Pepper, a humanoid robot from SoftBank, is designed to perceive human emotions. In recent years, robots have begun to compete against each other in soccer games, by autonomously adapting offensive and defensive strategies. One of the greatest advantages that robots have is a capability for high-speed communications. Whereas a typical human can speak 130 to 200 words per minute, which would translate into tens of bytes per second, robots can communicate as fast as one gigabyte (1 billion bytes) per second. Groups of robots can wirelessly work together even when separated by great distances, and can be synchronized by GPS technology with a great degree of accuracy. Extreme computation speed (more than one trillion operations per second) can enable these machines to cooperate regardless of the size of their grouping, or the distance between them, making humans far less competitive when it comes to many jobs. Just as data servers have made some aspects of traditional archives and libraries obsolete, robots - like data servers that can move around and behave autonomously - promise to impact our daily lives beyond anyone’s imagination.

name: Machine Learning and Predictive Systems
description: Machine learning involves creating algorithms that can recognize patterns in large, evolving data sets, and drawing conclusions from past experience by using that data - in order to make machines smarter. When people refer to “artificial intelligence,” they often really mean machine learning. Examples of technologies that make use of it include internet search engines, spam filters, and self-driving cars. Recently, an aspect of machine learning dubbed “deep learning algorithms” has received a lot of attention. That is because advances in computing power and masses of large-scale data, referred to as big data, have led to deep learning-based algorithms that are faster and more accurate than the human eye. In 2015, DeepMind, a UK-based firm that shares a parent company with Google, put the power of such algorithms on display when it pitted its AlphaGo computer program against a top human player of the board game Go. The computer program won. More recently, in 2018, a company called Preferred Networks became the most valuable startup in Japan, as investors including Toyota bet that the company’s deep learning algorithms can eventually be applied to a number of manufacturing uses.  Machine learning is expected to have a profound impact on the job market. Experts predict that both menial and professional jobs will be taken over by computers and robots equipped with learning algorithms. According to a study published by researchers from Carnegie Mellon University and MIT in the journal Science in 2017, evidence suggests that machine learning can do a better job of detecting skin cancer than a dermatologist, for example - though it would do a significantly poorer job of explaining to a patient why a lesion is cancerous or not. The potential advantages of the technology are clear, however: once machines learn they never forget; a learning pattern can be efficiently copied from one machine to another; and, learning can be done in a parallel manner in order to improve and share. For example, if one unit masters the art of driving, that learning pattern can be copied into millions of other cars within a very short time. Cars connected through a network can therefore continuously share experiences to improve overall performance. Humans, on the other hand, take a long time to learn. Their experiences cannot be shared in the same way, and the value of their individual knowledge and experience can perish at death.

name: Macroeconomic Management
description: Following the end of the apartheid era in 1994, prudent fiscal, trade, and monetary policies contributed to a sound investment environment for South Africa. The country achieved moderate to strong economic growth until the 2008 financial crisis, when it experienced its first recession in 17 years. GDP growth slipped to 0.8% in 2018, according to Statistics South Africa, or Stats SA, compared with 2.5% growth as recently as 2013. Part of this slowdown is related to declines in prices for the commodities on which South Africa's economy depends. Other concerns have been related to systemic corruption, and to drought. Meanwhile the Rand has depreciated, as the exchange rate has moved from about R8.50 to the US dollar as of the end of 2012 to more than R14 as of early 2019. The currency depreciation has in turn contributed to a significant debt accumulation. Public debt as a percent of GDP is expected to increase to 53.2% by 2023, according to the National Treasury’s Budget Review for 2018, from 41% in 2012. The country’s macroeconomic situation has significantly influenced investment conditions; foreign direct investment peaked in 2016, and has since taken a downturn. The South African government has struggled to invest in development strategies because of substantial social welfare transfers, and a high wage bill. Together these accounted for around 50% of government spending in 2016, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. This has left relatively little for investment in infrastructure and education. Social transfers have alleviated poverty, though a new national minimum wage may shift related costs to the private sector. A lot of South Africa’s physical infrastructure is managed by state-owned enterprises, which have attracted public criticism for gross mismanagement, swelling debt levels, and vulnerability to corruption. The National Treasury has bailed out the national airline, and the ailing national electricity provider has been cited as a threat to the country’s sovereign credit ratings. According to the Association for Savings and Investment South Africa, achieving inclusive economic growth will require significant additional foreign and domestic private investment. The challenge remains to create an economic and socio-political environment that can better facilitate this.

name: Macroeconomic Stability
description: Ghana’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of debt dynamics, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 40.00, resulting in a rank of 113th out of 140 countries. One indicator reflects a better performance: inflation rate, where it has a progress score of 69.70 that results in a rank of 132nd out of 140 countries.

name: Macroeconomic Stability in Argentina
description: Argentina's economic performance during the first part of the 21st century has been volatile. Between 2003 and 2011, the country’s annual GDP growth averaged 6.4%; since 2012, however, there has been virtually no growth, as periodic improvement has been offset by recession. In addition to persistent inflation and growing macroeconomic imbalances, Argentina’s recent currency crisis and a prolonged drought have only worsened public finances. In 2018, the country, which has one of the largest economies in Latin America, turned to the International Monetary Fund for a $57 billion bailout in order to ease investor concerns about a decline in the value of the peso - and the government’s related ability to make debt payments. In late 2018, the government won approval for austerity measures including severe cuts to spending on public works, which are intended to help jump-start a slumping economy. The Argentine economy is expected to continue to contract in 2019, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, before returning to 2.3% annual growth in 2020. The country’s recovery will be led by exports, as domestic consumer demand will be blunted by tight monetary and fiscal policy, according to the OECD. While tight monetary policy may stifle consumer spending, it is also a key ingredient in the Argentine economy’s stabilization - alongside rapid fiscal consolidation. The government is now committed to eliminating its primary fiscal deficit (which registered at 2.4% of GDP for 2018) in 2019, and to attaining a primary fiscal surplus equal to 1.1% of GDP in 2020. The government is also aiming to maintain a consistent exchange rate policy (the peso remained volatile as of early 2019 and some analysts projected that it would remain so until national elections slated for October). Inflation remains persistently high, and the government announced controversial price controls in early 2019 in order to try to contain it. The October elections represent an “important uncertainty,” according to an IMF report published in April 2019, as they could raise doubts about the government’s ability to achieve its fiscal targets. In order to mitigate these risks, according to the report, government policy plans must be steadfastly executed, and clearly communicated with both financial markets and the general public.

name: Macroeconomic Vulnerability in Latin America
description: Latin America’s economy is expanding but at a slower rate than anticipated, according to a report published by the International Monetary Fund - which noted that GDP growth for the region is expected to be 2% for 2019, and 2.5% the following year (up from 1.1% in 2018). US-China trade tensions, a related tightening of global financial conditions and weakened commodity prices are to blame for the region’s lacklustre outlook, according to the report (growth was also hampered in some countries by tightened monetary policy). In Brazil, which has the region’s biggest economy, annual GDP growth is expected to top 2% in 2019 for the first time in six years thanks to the election of a “market-friendly” administration, though Mexico (the region’s second-biggest economy) has revised growth expectations lower due to uncertainty about its new administration’s policies, according to the IMF report; when excluding Venezuela, which has suffered from political upheaval and hyperinflation, GDP growth for the region as a whole in 2019 would be 2.3% (instead of the anticipated 2%), according to the report. A 2016 Inter-American Development Bank publication, Saving for Development, described national saving as a vehicle through which Latin America could become stable and confident in its own future. However, countries in Latin America and the Caribbean were saving less than 20% of their national incomes - less than in any other region of the world except for sub-Saharan Africa, and far less than the roughly 35% in high-growth countries in East Asia, according to the publication. The reasons for this low savings rate included a lack of trust in financial institutions, and a relatively high cost of doing business with banks, according to the publication; only about 16% of the population in Latin America reported saving through a bank, compared with 50% in advanced economies. In addition, countries in the region suffer from public spending “leakage” that benefits the rich at the expense of the poor, amounts to an average of about 2% of GDP, and is essence public saving that is foregone, according to the publication.

name: Maintaining Trust
description: The legacy of the invasion of Iraq in 2003, coupled with the collapse of the global financial system just a few years after that, may have contributed to an erosion of trust we have yet to recover from. This seems particularly true in developed economies, where, theoretically, governance and institutions are relatively sophisticated. For example, the percentage of Americans who have faith in their federal government’s ability to handle both domestic problems (35%) and international problems (41%) is the lowest it has been in more than two decades, according to a Gallup poll in January 2019. At a very basic level, many people have become disillusioned with the way things operate, and how decisions are made, as former assumptions about fairness, social values, and expectations for the future have disappeared. Specific examples from individual countries tell a downbeat story: according to the 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer, the percentage of the population in the United Kingdom expressing trust in business was 43%; the percentage expressing trust in government was even lower, at 36%. The repercussions of this erosion of trust are significant. An OECD report published in 2017 noted that the loss of trust in leaders can result in wilful public resistance even to measures that may be in the public’s best interest. In Brazil, an erosion of trust in government in recent years has been the backdrop for a swing from the socialist policies of former Presidents Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and Dilma Rousseff to the election of current President Jair Bolsonaro. In the US, following the election of President Donald Trump, the results of a Gallup poll in 2019 showed just 22% of Democrats feeling “extremely” proud to be Americans, down from 45% a decade earlier (in 2018, for the first time in Gallup's 18-year history of asking adults irrespective of their political affiliation how proud they are to be American, less than half had reported being "extremely proud”). Meanwhile efforts among some elements of the US government to make a case for more aggressive foreign policy targeting Russia, following that country’s alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election, have been undermined by a broader questioning of US credibility - particularly in light of the inaccurate allegations that the US made regarding weapons of mass destruction in Iraq prior to its invasion of that country in 2003.

name: Making Urban Areas Inclusive
description: By 2050, the United Nations estimates 70% of the global population will live in cities. Cities have long provided an escape from poverty, though as they have grown (there are now 33 “megacities” with at least 10 million inhabitants) they have stirred debate about their role in addressing global issues like climate change and migration. Some local officials have developed related solutions. For example, Rotterdam, the second-biggest city in the Netherlands which mostly sits below sea level, is adapting its infrastructure to live with more water, and bolstering social cohesion with experimental housing and public spaces. Barcelona, Spain has meanwhile established a process to collaborate with hundreds of civic associations to focus on housing, education, and the treatment of immigrants. Confronted by the estimated two billion people expected to migrate to informal settlements by 2030, some officials are responding with innovative ideas. In Iquique, Chile, for example, the government engaged architects to design quality housing for migrants in a local informal settlement that is both built to increase in value over time, and is half-constructed - so that residents can use their own labour and resources to complete their homes in a way that further improves the community. More than 60% of the world’s workers toil in the “informal,” or unregulated economy and lack basic protections. In response, architects commissioned by Durban, South Africa have sought to design safer conditions for the roughly 5,000 informal traders converging daily at a local transportation hub. Providing young people with a quality education regardless of their ability, race, language, religion, gender, or economic status is also a fundamental part of an inclusive urban society. In Pune, India, the Door Step School program has been addressing the transience of many workers’ families by sending out a bus-based classroom to pick up students and provide a mobile (yet stable) setting to learn. Technology innovation can be used to make cities smarter, safer, and more inclusive; accessible Olli, for example, is a self-driving shuttle designed to help people with disabilities and the elderly navigate urban areas with wheelchair ramps, software that can process sign language, and simplified displays for people with memory loss. The United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals provide an important reference point for efforts to make urban areas more inclusive, with their call to make cities safe, resilient, sustainable and inclusive by 2030. This key issue was curated in partnership with Cynthia E. Smith, Curator of Socially Responsible Design at Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum.

name: Making Way for Homegrown Aid
description: Local, on-the-ground aid groups should get a far bigger slice of the humanitarian funding pie - as a matter of principle, and as a means to cut costs. While that is already the policy of major donor countries and aid agencies, it has proven difficult to implement. In 2017, IRIN News, the non-profit humanitarian newsroom based in Geneva, found that two thirds of international relief funding (some $14 billion) went to just 12 international organizations. Meanwhile grassroots non-governmental organizations with local knowledge and networks are at the bottom of a sub-granting chain, providing frontline relief but not getting the recognition or financing they deserve. Some claim they feel more like disposable sub-contractors than partners, as international groups hog resources. As a result, grassroots organizations are unable to mature as organizations in their own right, especially as their staff are frequently poached. There is plenty to value in the internationalism of emergency aid, so an equilibrium needs to be reached - because local aid groups that can rapidly operate at scale are not always present during humanitarian situations, and often need greater skills and expertise, and because neutral, external organizations may be more ideal for helping civilians during conflicts. Relief aid should be as local as possible and as international as necessary, according to a World Humanitarian Summit resolution and the Grand Bargain - an alliance of donors and international aid groups. The alliance has set a target to increase funding to local groups to 25% from less than 3% by 2020. Big donors aiming to help must overcome barriers. For example, the European Commission’s humanitarian department is restricted to funding European Union entities, and stringent donor reporting requirements and financial rules present a steep learning curve to smaller NGOs. Also, the donor civil servants who approve grants argue they do not have the capacity to sign up dozens of smaller new partners. As a result, donors are increasing their contributions made through UN-administered pooled funds, which can funnel cash to local NGOs. Some countries find a balance. Indonesia has said it does not need new international relief groups to deploy there, and instead calls in specific aid such as airlift capacity as needed. After the Sulawesi earthquakes and tsunami in 2018, Jakarta’s local NGOs and faith-based groups took the lead, alongside the government and the Indonesian military.

name: Making the Rules for a Beneficial IoT
description: The rapid but relatively uncoordinated evolution of the Internet of Things, a technology that makes our essential machines and devices smarter by connecting them to the web, has led to decentralized systems that lack proper governance. In order for the IoT to realize its potential, these fragmented systems have to find a way to effectively interact with one another. This requires governance that takes stock of the broader context. While the IoT does benefit from a certain level of governance, it is not at a level that can foster sustained growth. There is technical governance in the form of standards, for example, yet over-standardization has led to as many problems as it has tried to solve by spawning infighting and incompatibility. One of the IoT’s biggest opportunities is therefore also one of its biggest challenges: diversity. One, single set of standards must be created that works equally well for dishwashers, autonomous cars, and smartwatches. The obstacles to this are considerable, however; every object, service, or network has its own design considerations, and within any given industry there may be several conflicting standards.    There is therefore a serious need for both corporate and international governance in the world of the Internet of Things. The real challenges are to determine how much governance is too much, and to create the right incentives to bring all interested parties to the table. The IoT requires a significant amount of investment to be of real use, and as a result it is primarily being deployed in relatively wealthy, well-resourced places - even though it is the less well-to-do areas that truly stand to benefit from the efficiency improvement and cost savings the IoT can facilitate. Anyone working to boost the adoption of the technology has to try to ensure that the IoT tide lifts all boats, rather than sending a tidal wave of disparity in the direction of the most vulnerable. Ultimately, the Internet of Things could create societal value that aids progress in achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, established in 2015 to guide responsible global development until 2030. Mobility services powered by the IoT can reduce vehicle ownership, fuel consumption, and emissions, for example, while IoT-enabled monitoring of agriculture and supply chains can ensure that the food being produced is not wasted, and gets to the people who need it most.

name: Mapping the Brain
description: Each of our brains contains about 100 billion brain cells that are interconnected by over 150,000 km of cellular wiring to create a network with over 100 trillion interconnections. Knowing what types of cells in the brain are involved in a different mental process and how they are they connected to each other is now an important barrier to understanding all types of brain function. Many forms of mental illness are thought to arise from defects in the way the brain is wired up, but detailed information about brain circuits has long been beyond the reach of scientists, leaving theories about most brain disorders and even normal brain function as purely speculative. Mapping the brain at different levels – from the molecular to cell-to-cell connections within larger networks – will provide a foundation for understanding how the brain functions across a lifespan and the differences between healthy and unhealthy brains. Understanding on this front is advancing rapidly based on new brain mapping technologies. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) allows scientists to monitor the activity throughout the human brain while subjects view different stimuli, retrieve different memories, or think about different concepts. These functional maps provide insights on how different parts of the brain contribute to different mental states and how they interact to produce coherent thoughts and actions. Closely related technologies are providing an overall picture of how different brain regions are interconnected in different individuals. Other technologies will make it possible to extract complete wiring diagrams from post-mortem human brains. Methods for imaging brain tissue at high enough resolution to see the vanishingly small connections between brain cells are being automated and greatly speeded-up, making it feasible to visualize all the connections in small volumes of brain tissue. Even so, the amount of data needed to represent an entire human brain at a sufficiently high resolution to see individual connections is almost unimaginable: 1.3 trillion gigabytes – a number approaching the capacity of all the hard disk storage on the planet. Moreover, reconstructing detailed circuits based on those raw data would exercise the world’s supercomputers for years. But a complete brain circuit is not needed. The ability to compare small volumes from healthy and unhealthy brains is likely to provide critical insights into the computations performed by normal brain circuits and how they go awry in various mental illnesses. The number and size of brain circuits that can be reconstructed will grow rapidly in the coming years. As they do so, they will provide scientists with critical new views on the workings of the brain

name: Market Divergence
description: Demand for vehicle ownership is shifting to emerging markets. In China, for example, there were still only 124 vehicles per 1,000 people in 2015, according to a report in China Daily - compared with 793 vehicles per 1,000 people in the US in the prior year, based on data from IHS Markit. Rising income levels in China and elsewhere have already begun to close that gap. While registrations or sales of new vehicles in the US rose by about 12.5% between 2013 and 2016, according to data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufactures, registrations or sales rose by about 27.5% in China over that same period. Chinese firms have been able to increase their domestic market share. Shanghai Automotive now sells more units in China than Mazda, and Dongfeng Motor Corporation is bigger locally than Mitsubishi. However, these domestic players have so far been unable to successfully compete globally, by establishing their brands abroad and meeting relatively strict safety standards in the US and Europe. Increasingly, these standards create a dividing line between emerging and developed economies, alongside contrasting customer requirements and development speeds. While developed economies may have exhausted their sources of volume sales growth, they remain home to most of the research and development underpinning the automotive sector. The financing required for topflight automotive R&D remains at levels that only mature, well-funded manufacturers and suppliers can afford. This dynamic has led to both chronically low profitability for manufacturers in developed markets such as Europe, and the increasing use of mergers and acquisitions to acquire technology developed abroad.

name: Mass Extinction
description: As far as life on land is concerned, we are rapidly approaching what scientists have dubbed the “Sixth Mass Extinction” - as human-caused extinction rates approach levels last experienced during the era that saw the end of many dinosaur lineages. The situation in the oceans is a little brighter, for the moment. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature, about 17 ocean animal extinctions have occurred in the last 500 years (during the same period, more than 500 land animal extinctions have occurred due to human activity). A 2016 report in the journal Science projected that rates of extinction in the oceans could increase dramatically, however - particularly as climate change accelerates. Ocean animals that are under threat include Monk Seals (both the Hawaiian monk seal and the Mediterranean monk seal), Blue Whales (which were depleted in the early 1900s), and all six species of sea turtle found in US waters. Without a change to business as usual in ocean management, we could therefore soon initiate an additional Sixth Mass Extinction in the oceans. An industrial revolution is beginning in the oceans, with parallels to the industrial revolutions that have taken place on land. This involves a rapid expansion of marine industries such as ocean farming, marine energy, and marine transport, and a nearly five-fold increase in the amount of ocean area being explored for deep sea mining. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature, by May 2018 the International Seabed Authority had issued 29 contracts for the exploration of deep-sea mineral deposits, and more than 1.5 million square kilometres of international seabed (about the size of Mongolia) had been set aside for mineral exploration in the Pacific and Indian oceans and along the mid-Atlantic ridge. Mining in international water is expected to begin in 2025, according to the IUCN. On land, animal extinction rates began accelerating rapidly during the first two industrial revolutions, when there was much less awareness of the link between human health and the environment. Now, the oceans present an opportunity to intelligently move a marine industrial revolution forward without associated spikes in animal extinction that would compromise the oceans’ nourishing resources.

name: Maximizing Public Capital
description: The limited availability of public funds, philanthropic grants, and official development assistance in emerging and frontier markets has restricted the implementation of projects that can transform infrastructure and significantly enhance peoples’ lives. Blended Finance is an increasingly popular mechanism used to unlock necessary funds from the private sector, and finance projects that would not otherwise be deemed commercially viable. The mechanism relies on three principles: leverage, impact, and risk-adjusted returns. It leverages public and philanthropic funds to catalyse private capital, uses capital to fund projects that drive social, environmental and economic outcomes, and adjusts risk-return ratios in order to ensure a viable proposition for commercial investors. A 2015 Blended Finance survey led by the Redesigning Development Finance Initiative, a joint initiative of the World Economic Forum and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, found that public and philanthropic capital that is committed to Blended Finance funds and facilities is able to attract up to 20 times more corresponding, additional capital from private sector sources than would otherwise be possible. Studies by other institutions have identified similar results. An analysis of 67 investment projects that incorporated principles of Blended Finance, conducted by the International Finance Corporation, found that private investment in the transactions exceeded the so-called concessional funds (financing made on relatively generous terms, often by governments) that were also committed by more than a factor of ten. In addition, a 2016 OECD survey identified $81.1 billion in private investment that had been mobilized by official development finance using Blended Finance mechanisms between 2012 and 2015, making use of guarantees, syndicated loans, credit lines, and collective investment vehicles provided by the donor community.

name: Media Consumer Behaviour
description: People in the US are now spending about $2 billion every month on subscription-video services, according to a report published by Deloitte in 2019, and companies ranging from traditional cable TV providers to social networks are scrambling to accommodate them. As media business paradigms change, media and entertainment companies are shifting decisively to direct-to-consumer relationships. This is being driven by ubiquitous internet connectivity, and by shifting consumer habits (a good deal of content is now being digested in abbreviated form on mobile social-networking apps, for example, according to the Deloitte report). Increasing investment in network technology such as 5G has enabled instant access to content, increasingly via smartphone, and often on popular platforms like Facebook (which now reports that more than 90% of its advertising revenue is derived from mobile devices). Greater demand requires greater investment; Netflix alone spent $12 billion on content in 2018, and analysts estimate it will spend $15 billion in 2019. Increased content spending comes as more players enter an “over-the-top” content-streaming market that includes Hulu, Amazon Prime, HBO Now, Disney+ and Apple TV Plus. As a result of this shift in the nature of demand and means of delivery, consumers are increasingly cancelling their TV subscriptions and switching to over-the-top platforms to consume video. In the US, 55% of households now subscribe to paid streaming services, according to the Deloitte report, and almost half of all American consumers were already streaming content daily or weekly by 2017. People everywhere are increasingly embracing a more transient identity, and no longer necessarily consider themselves mere audience members - they no longer want one-size-fits-all experiences decided upon by television networks, media conglomerates or publishing company executives. The growth in demand for tailor-made content means that distributors must constantly vie for attention, shifting the balance of power to users. Many of these users, having cancelled their TV subscriptions and shifted to streaming services, are now finding they have too many subscriptions and related bills to keep track of, according to the Deloitte report (this will likely prompt content providers to “reaggregate” offerings, according to the report). One constant will likely be interest among these users in seeing manifestations and representations of themselves in content - which distributors may be able to produce by leveraging user data.

name: Media Governance and Policy
description: There are currently about 95 million photos and videos published on Instagram, 500 million tweets, and 5 billion YouTube video views on a daily basis. Governing this sheer amount of content is difficult, and only becomes more so as the ease with which anyone can create and share increases. While trending hashtags and live video might enable users to reach a wide audience, they can also spur calls for closer regulation - the live-streaming in 2019 of deadly attacks on mosque worshippers in Christchurch, New Zealand is a case in point. Despite repeated urgent requests for its removal made by the New Zealand government, video of the attacks continued to appear online long after the incident. Live video streaming has also exposed wrongdoing - such as when Philando Castile was shot by a policeman in the US in 2016 as his girlfriend filmed. Facebook is using artificial intelligence tools as well as human moderators to combat the spread of violent content and fake news, and its task (along with the self-monitoring efforts of other online platforms) will be crucial as people increasingly go online for information and entertainment.  Governments have taken varied approaches to regulating content. After bombings in Sri Lanka in April 2019 left nearly 300 people dead in churches and hotels, that country’s government moved swiftly to temporarily ban social media sites and services including Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, WhatsApp, Snapchat and Viber - in an effort to curb the spread of inflammatory misinformation. In China, the country’s roughly 1,900 newspapers, 2,600 radio stations and 9,000 magazines are all owned by the government, and operate under the watchful eyes of 2 million people employed as censors. Whether regulation is applied by governments or popular platforms themselves, a respect for free speech is critical. Net neutrality, the principle that any lawful content should be made readily available online without bias or interference from an internet service provider, has become a hotly-debated topic - as governments could theoretically allow service providers to inhibit content presenting controversial viewpoints, while content providers could start paying to enable preferable treatment of their own sites and services. While efforts to restrict net neutrality have gained traction in the US and Canada in recent years, India approved regulations in 2018 that support net neutrality and bar any type of online data restriction.

name: Media and Emerging Technologies
description: Possibly no industry has been more disrupted by technology than media and entertainment - as artificial intelligence, augmented and virtual reality, and blockchain affect the ways we communicate, behave, learn, and work. The digital portion of the global media and entertainment industry’s income is projected to reach nearly 57% by 2022, up from less than 37% in 2013, according to a report published by PwC. While “AR/VR” is transforming gaming by integrating audio and visuals into a player’s surroundings in real time, blockchain is enabling companies to more accurately monitor content assets and measure the impact of digital advertising. Meanwhile AI promises perhaps the most serious industry disruption, with its pattern recognition and predictive analytics algorithms that can enable businesses to guess the future. For example, as users produce increasing amounts of data related both to the content they consume and to the time they spend consuming it, marketers use that data to try to better automatically provide what they might want next; the algorithms deployed by Spotify and Netflix to suggest songs or shows are examples of this. AI is also impacting digital print media, where content increasingly sits behind a paywall, by enabling flexible paywalls alongside tools to evaluate the likelihood that a reader allowed inside a paywall for free will convert to a paid subscriber. Automated content is also increasingly common; The Los Angeles Times, for example, uses a tool called Quakebot to report nearly in real time on earthquakes, while the Associated Press automates the production of short articles about corporate earnings. Voice-enabled digital assistants, like Amazon’s Alexa, are also shaping the industry, as are automated “bots” (as much as 15% of active Twitter accounts are estimated to be bots disguised as real users). Sophisticated algorithms have also given us “deepfakes,” or videos designed to mislead an audience into believing a high-profile person said or did something (a notable example was a faked 2018 video making it seem like former US President Barack Obama was disparaging his successor). Discussion about the ethical implications of these technologies has focused on their impact on jobs and the distribution of inaccurate information, amid calls for a careful balance between regulation and innovation.

name: Media and the Global Social Good
description: The need to foster greater social cohesion has perhaps never been greater - and the extent to which media outlets either choose to play a constructive role in this or not could have lasting consequences, whether it is in the form of damaged public trust, high levels of crime, poor public health, or a general lack of well-being. As once-independent media companies continue to converge under the ownership of a small handful of conglomerates reorganizing in order to better compete (the flurry of media deals kicked off in 2018 included the $71 billion merger of Disney and 21st Century Fox), a decentralization and democratization is occurring - enabling people to more freely create and distribute content to inform or entertain. This content plays an increasingly pivotal role in shaping the social fabric; media outlets are being used to facilitate discussion on societal ills, and social media has the potential to further awaken our collective conscious about inequality when it comes to race, gender, and wealth - and to foster a more active (and healthy) dialogue about mental health issues that could pave the way to increased cultural acceptance and understanding. The impact of media on mental health, however, has been a source of growing concern. An experiment conducted by neuroscientists from the University of Southern California and Southwest University in Chongqing, China, for example, found that Facebook stimulates the same section of the brain activated by gambling and substance abuse. In addition, overuse of social media has been linked to feelings of anxiety, depression, and social isolation. A survey conducted by the United Kingdom-based Royal Society for Public Health found that people between the ages of 14 and 24 in the country believe that Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, and Twitter make them vulnerable to bullying, exacerbate body-image concerns, and trigger high levels of “FOMO” (“fear of missing out”). Still, social media has had some positive impact on this same demographic’s general awareness of health issues, and its capacity to organize and express itself. The growth of media platforms has also helped create global communities now better able to connect on issues such as rare physical diseases, or divergent belief systems. Governing the distribution of accurate related information will be a challenge, however, as media platforms continue to expand their influence.

name: Medical Biotechnology
description: Medical biotechnology is a rapidly developing means to rejuvenate the elderly and regenerate ageing or diseased organs - a potentially helpful development for the many countries with greying populations (nearly 8.7% of the global population was aged 65 or older by 2017, up from 6.7% in 1997, according to World Bank data). The use of “induced pluripotent” stem cells, which do not have to be derived from human embryos, has shown promise for regenerating an injured heart (while avoiding the ethical issues tied to the use of human embryonic stem cells), for example. Biotechnology tools are also being used for the diagnosis and treatment of human disease in a personalized way. We are currently able to modulate each layer of biology, from genes to proteins and cells. When it comes to the immunological treatment of cancer, the clinical development of protein- or antibody-based therapeutics is advancing, and the range of biological targets is expanding. In addition, genetically modified immune cells are being developed as immuno-oncology drugs, including chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-T cells and T-cell receptor (TCR)-transduced T cells. Regenerative medicine will be accelerated by gene-editing technology. CRISPR-Cas9, for example, enables the direct modification of genes in the interest of preventing and treating disease - though there are significant ethical issues related to altering the human genome in ways that will be passed from one generation to the next (a Chinese scientist stunned the world in 2018 when it was revealed that he had engineered the world’s first gene-edited babies in a bid to make them resistant to their father’s HIV infection). Tissue engineering has also evolved, thanks to organoid (a miniaturized organ produced in vitro) technology, novel biomaterials, and 3D printing. In general, a more personalized application of medical biotechnology is necessary, to enhance therapeutic efficacy and minimize unwanted side effects. And, the most important personal factor is the genome - in terms of genetic and acquired diseases. Integrating genome information into medical data is an important component of precision medicine, and is being aided by artificial intelligence. Personalized cancer vaccines, and drug tests using surrogates, are also major elements of precision medicine.

name: Mental Disorders
description: Mental disorders come in many forms, including anxiety disorders, developmental disorders, major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder and schizophrenia, among many others. Collectively, these disorders are so pervasive that they represent the leading cause of lost workplace productivity. Depression and anxiety disorders alone are thought to lead to more than $1 trillion in lost productivity worldwide each year, according to research from the World Health Organization published in The Lancet Psychiatry in 2016. Moreover, the prevalence of common mental disorders is increasing everywhere. The aforementioned study suggests that a scaling-up of treatment for mental disorders would not only relieve human suffering, but would more than return that investment in improved productivity. Neuroscience research also has an important role to play in improving the prevention of mental disorders. We still have only a partial understanding of how and where psychiatric treatments act in the brain. Major research efforts are underway to understand the mechanistic basis of mental disorders, and to find treatments that might help prevent or reverse them. Studies of closely related individuals have shown that autism, schizophrenia, bipolar and attention deficit disorder are heritable to some degree. Consistent patterns of genes associated with psychiatric disorders can help reveal underlying problems. Molecular and cellular impairments can be investigated by culturing stem cells that carry the risk-causing mutations. Advances in the ability to map the neuronal circuits that serve higher brain functions will also provide important new bases for understanding how mental disease affects the nervous system. Unfortunately, many major pharmaceutical companies are withdrawing from research on psychiatric treatments. As discussed at a workshop organized by the Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders of the US National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine in 2016, this decline in research is driven by a very high failure rate for candidate drugs in clinical trials. Without a clear path to developing profitable drugs, pharmaceutical firms have lost motivation for investing in neuroscience research. Mental disorders remain poorly understood at the molecular, cellular and systems levels, making progress on treatments difficult. Without new research insights, new drugs tend to resemble existing medicines that are cheaper and therefore favoured by insurers.

name: Mental Health and Machine Learning
description: The possibilities presented by machine learning (an application of artificial intelligence where programmes self-learn how to predict patterns using complex data), have multiplied in recent years - not least in terms of brain health research. According to a report published by the World Economic Forum’s Global Agenda Council on Mental Health in 2016, there is a possibility that machine learning could be used to identify signals of disease risk and treatment response, using massive amounts of amassed biological and behavioural data. Machine learning algorithms are also being developed that could use behavioural data to detect at an early stage when patients might deteriorate due to conditions such as bipolar disorder, depression, and psychosis. Other technologies enabled by machine learning include improved speech recognition software that could facilitate new methods of patient interaction, according to the report. However, some are uneasy about the prospect of machine-derived decisions replacing human expertise and judgment. These concerns must be properly addressed, in order to realize true potential of machine learning in the field of mental health. The need for new tools based on artificial intelligence that have the potential to boost mental wellness is particularly pressing in the US, which faces a mental health epidemic, according to an article published in Harvard Business Review in 2018. Nearly one in five adults in the country suffers from a form of mental illness, suicide rates are at an all-time high, and 115 people die every day from opioid abuse, according to the article; at the same time, the country is faced with a critical shortfall of psychiatrists and other mental health specialists (more than 60% of US counties are without a single psychiatrist). While there are concerns about the impersonal nature of digitized mental health services, in some cases these techniques could benefit patients embarrassed to reveal problems to a therapist they have never met before, according to the article, which cites the company Ginger.io, a provider of an app that enables chatting with an “emotional health coach,” as an example of a potentially effective digital solution. A year-long survey found that among Ginger.io users, 72% reported clinically significant improvements in symptoms of depression, according to the article.

name: Mental Health in the Workplace
description: At any point, nearly one in five members of the working-age population in the UK has a mental health problem, according to a report prepared for the UK government by the RAND Corporation in 2014, and more than 40% of sickness benefit claims in the country cite a mental or behavioural disorder as a primary condition. However, a subsequent RAND Corporation report published in 2018 identified a number of potential wellbeing interventions related to mental health in the workplace, based on standards developed by the innovation and social-policy-intervention foundation Nesta (ranging from a “1” for articulating a clear logic, to a “5” for showing evidence of consistent, reliable results). For example, Be Mindful, a four-week online course that involves mindfulness meditation audio and video-led sessions aimed at reducing stress, depression and anxiety (and received a rating of “3”), had been implemented in 17 organizations for about 11,000 people annually, and showed statistically significant beneficial effects. In general, however, the tools and practices in place for occupational mental health, as well as the degree of access to mental health support in the workplace, remain insufficient. In response, in 2017 the World Economic Forum’s Global Agenda Council on Mental Health published a set of seven steps that people can take to foster a healthier workplace. These include exploring ways to modify existing workplace practices in a way that could promote better mental health (keeping in mind that every workplace is unique), taking the time to learn from leaders and employees who have been successful in promoting better mental health in the past, borrowing successful models from other firms (the council provided case studies from companies including Bell Canada and British Telecom Group), making an effort to better understand the opportunities and mental health needs of your colleagues, building the internal and external partnerships needed to provide educational material and training necessary for successful mental health initiatives, and creating a culture where colleagues will not hesitate to ask for help (and will know exactly where to direct their questions).

name: Mexico’s Infrastructure Needs
description: Like other places in Latin America, Mexico has faced difficulties when it comes to financing public works - and relying on the private sector to bridge the gap has not met the country’s needs. According to the Inter-American Development Bank’s 2016 report Saving for Development, countries in Latin America and the Caribbean need to invest the equivalent of at least 5% of their annual GDP in infrastructure, for a prolonged period, in order to spur economic growth. However, the study noted that infrastructure investment in Mexico averaged just 1.8% of GDP between 2008 and 2013, and that the average for Latin America during that same period was 3.8% of GDP. In terms of the quality of overall infrastructure, Mexico ranked 49th out of 140 countries in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index for 2018, slipping 13 places compared with the previous year’s report (the country ranked 15th specifically in terms of airport connectivity in the 2018 index, however). The Mexican government has pushed for structural reforms aimed at strengthening the legal framework for public-private partnerships, and for drawing more institutional investors to a pipeline of well-structured, bankable infrastructure projects. The benefits of Mexico’s economic growth have not been widely shared across the country, resulting in economic and social inequality among its 32 states. The benefits of the country’s most successful economic policy direction to date, namely trade openness and the fashioning of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), have mostly been limited to the North and the central corridor - regions that enjoy natural geographic or logistical advantages. New technologies and skilled workers have generally not reached the country’s southern and southeast regions, affecting their ability to compete both nationally and globally. Regional disparities are also evident when it comes to labour productivity, the prevalence of unregulated, “informal” economies, and household income; the North enjoys an income per capita that is 44% higher than in the South, for example, while the poverty rate in the North is just roughly 28% compared with about 80% in the South. Industrial and development policies are required that better share prosperity countrywide, and help close infrastructure gaps that are particularly glaring in southern states.

name: Mexico’s Systematized Corruption
description: Mexico ranked 105th out of 140 countries in terms of the strength of its institutions in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2018 - which cited corruption, organized crime, and homicide rate as particular impediments to doing business in the country. Meanwhile Transparency International’s Corruption Perceptions Index 2018 noted that Mexico was among a few countries in the region with scores that have declined sharply since 2012; basic rights including press freedom have been curtailed, and without a free media to oversee the country’s government the ability to prevent and denounce corruption is limited, according to the report. According to a study published by the Mexican Institute for Competitiveness, as much as 95% of corruption-related crime goes unpunished, and about 14% of average annual household income in the country is used to pay bribes. According to Transparency International’s 2017 Global Corruption Barometer, slightly more than half of all Mexicans have paid a bribe to access public services. Amid growing social unrest related to this situation, in 2016 the General Law on the National Anti-Corruption System was approved, focused on three areas: oversight (or accountability), administrative responsibility, and criminal responsibility. The Mexican government has taken steps in the past to become more open. In 2014, the country became the first in Latin America to chair the Open Government Partnership, which seeks commitments on transparency. Mexico has also launched an official government open-data website, and has promoted open public procurement and a national digital strategy to promote transparency. These moves have demonstrated some political will to tackle unethical behaviour, and restore trust in businesses and institutions. This is important not least because important social services and programs cannot succeed amid widespread corruption and low levels of trust. A 2017 report published by the World Economic Forum’s Partnering Against Corruption Initiative found that trust had decreased among all stakeholders in Mexico, compared with levels enjoyed just five to 10 years earlier. The same report identified a particularly severe lack of trust in the judicial system. For Mexico, combatting corruption is key for improving stability, bolstering economic growth and competitiveness, attracting foreign investment, and increasing both equality and security.

name: Mexico’s Trade Diversification
description: Mexico is a party to 12 different free trade agreements with 46 countries, in addition to numerous other economic and financial arrangements. The country is an active member of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), for example, in addition to the Latin American Integration Association (ALADI), the Pacific Alliance, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), and the World Trade Organization. In late 2018, US President Donald Trump, former Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau signed the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), a replacement for NAFTA, though it must be ratified by all three governments before it can be implemented. The USMCA includes changes for automakers (like new wage requirements) and intellectual property (including increased copyright protections), more provisions aimed at environmental protection, and some digital trade provisions. All told, its various trade deals give Mexico access to more than one billion consumers and nearly 60% of the world’s economic activity. Still, Mexico has struggled to diversify its trade away from the US, the destination for more than 81% of its exports, according to the National Institute of Statistics and Geography. Mexico ranked 36th out of 140 countries in terms of trade openness in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2018; however, it ranked 65th specifically in terms of trade-weighted average tariff rate. The country’s regulatory environment for foreign investment is relatively favourable, as is the ease with which companies can hire foreign workers (though the cost for companies to comply with export procedures remains high). The country’s infrastructure, particularly in terms of access to ports and airports, rates relatively highly, and there are other hopeful signs; Mexico has been deeply involved in the development of the Pacific Alliance, for example, which is an initiative involving Chile, Colombia and Peru to facilitate increased trade with the Asia-Pacific region. The initiative also promotes a regional system for innovation and entrepreneurship, with support from international organizations such as the Inter-American Development Bank (its goals include having a social impact and alleviating poverty). Still, it is necessary for Mexico to further democratize trade by expanding the number of participants, ideally with a particular emphasis on the small- and medium-sized firms that represent the country’s largest source of employment.

name: Middle Class and Inequality
description: With an estimated 49 million inhabitants as of 2017, Colombia is the third most populous country in Latin America behind Brazil and Mexico. Colombia’s middle class grew to 28% of the population by 2016, from 15% in 2006, according to Family Legacy, a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) in 2017. However, despite recent achievements in poverty alleviation, almost 28% of Colombians still live under the national poverty line, and the country continues to have one of the world’s highest rates of economic inequality. A 2015 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) report noted that income for the top 10% of the population was 37 times greater than the income drawn by the bottom 10%, and that Colombia’s severe inequality is being driven by persistently high unemployment, a large informal (unregulated, or grey) economy, and a broad variation of wage levels within the formal economy. The recent expansion of the country’s middle class is partially explained by an increase in formal employment, due to fiscal and labour market reforms. These reforms have also pushed unemployment in the country to historic lows. The middle class expansion is also due to strong recent economic growth in Colombia, which the IDB estimated was responsible for more than 90% of the reduction of extreme poverty that occurred between 2002 and 2013. Targeted government loans and social programs have also played a role in the positive trend, which could be furthered by boosting the redistributive impact of the country’s tax system, and by implementing more targeted social spending. The prevalence of the informal economy in Colombia hinders poverty reduction efforts, and the growth of the country’s middle class. According to the results of a 2016 survey conducted by Colombia’s National Administrative Department of Statistics, only 38% of all workers were accounted for in the regulated, formal economy at that time, while around 42% were self-employed (a category that includes a significant amount of informal work). According to research published by the IDB, rampant informality in the country is caused by the relatively high cost of official labour, a skills gap due to weaknesses in the job training system, and an ability to frequently rotate between formal and informal work. Informality curbs contributions to Colombia’s pension system, and may also pressure employer-funded retirement schemes by deepening tax distortions. Pension reform is necessary; the system in Colombia has problems with adequacy and coverage, and it runs a deficit equivalent to about 3.5% of GDP annually. Contributory pensions, where employees contribute funding to a scheme, only cover 32% of Colombian workers, a lower level than in other Latin American countries. About 92% percent of pension subsidies in the country benefit just the top 40% of Colombia’s earners, due to issues with fragmentation and administrative costs. Based on the current system, by 2050 a lack of retirement savings in Colombia could affect between 50% and 80% of people older than 65.

name: Middle-Class Advantage
description: By the year 2030, China and India will account for 40% of global middle-class consumption, while Europe and North America will only represent 30%, according to an estimate published by the Brookings Institution in 2017. The multinational companies based in these increasingly wealthy regions may be able to use them as fuel, to expand their global presence. The shift in middle-class consumption will have other, far-reaching effects; the rules of global competition, in particular those that have to do with product standards, may change. The packaging of all smartphones, for example, displays two very important acronyms: FCC and CE. These are stamps of approval from regulators in the two largest markets in the world: the US and the European Union, respectively. If companies do not meet the product standards set by these two entities, they cannot sell products in their markets. By the year 2030, China, and perhaps India, are likely to issue their own product standards. Companies around the world will then have no option but to comply with these standards, if they wish to sell their wares in what will by then be the largest consumer markets in the world. Similarly, while rules for global banks are now under the influence of Europe and the US, by 2030 China and India may have their own standards in place. In the future, no company will be able to be a global number one or two in its industry unless it is number one or two in China and India. The problem for American and European companies is that while their markets have historically been relatively open to foreign competition, those in Asia are not. Emerging multinationals from China and India will therefore enjoy an advantage as they expand internationally. It is important to note that by 2040, the Indian middle-class consumer market will likely overtake China’s in terms of size - based on data published by the United Nations. India is poised to have a much younger population than China, for example, and people still in their thirties and forties are the main purchasers of homes, automobiles and other durable consumer goods. Meanwhile the Indian economy is growing fast, largely driven by domestic consumption, while the Chinese economy continues to grow through exports and investment. Established and emerging multinationals alike would therefore be wise to focus their efforts on the Indian market.

name: Migrant Rights
description: The odds for migrants are not good; more than 6,000 deaths and disappearances related to migration were recorded during 2017 alone, according to the International Organization for Migration’s Missing Migrants Project, and nearly 26,000 related fatalities have been recorded since 2014 (the IOM notes this is likely a fraction of the total number of deaths, as most go unrecorded). Migrants also face an inordinate risk that their basic human rights will be violated; those traveling along the so-called “Western Mediterranean” route leading from Morocco and Algeria to Spain, for example, have been the victims of human rights violations including physical abuse, trafficking, and forced labour, according to the International Organization for Migration’s World Migration Report 2018. In addition, migrant workers in South-East Asia in the fishing, agriculture and construction industries have faced the threat of forced labour, according to the report. People migrating for safety and protection reasons are especially vulnerable. In South Sudan, for example, many migrants have been targeted for human rights abuses based on their ethnicity or presumed political allegiances, according to a report published by the UN Refugee Agency in 2017. There is a strong focus on migrants’ rights in the New York Declaration for Refugees and Migrants, which was adopted by the UN General Assembly in 2016. The declaration provides a basis for the so-called global compact for safe, orderly and regular migration, which is expected to be adopted by UN member states in September 2018 and is designed to establish a framework for cooperation on migrants and human mobility. The work of governments to address migrant rights has been complicated by the proliferation of non-state actors, however. In addition, real and perceived increases in irregular migration are further diminishing migrants’ rights, while some states have not met their obligations to fully respect the fundamental human rights of migrants at all times. In 2017, for example, the UN Committee on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers heard statements from non-governmental organizations from Indonesia about their concerns regarding the government of that country’s failure to protect Indonesian female domestic workers from abuse and exploitation in destination countries. The committee also heard statements from civil society representatives from Mexico, who described institutions in that country as being very weak - leading to serious human rights abuses, including the criminalization and prosecution of migrants, and their restricted access to health care.

name: Migration Flows
description: The number of Venezuelans migrating abroad rose from roughly 437,000 in 2005 to 1.6 million by 2017 - when more than half of the Venezuelan population living outside of the country was scattered throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, according to data published by the International Organization for Migration. Colombia, the primary destination for Venezuelans in South America and a key transit point to other locations, was home to about 600,000 Venezuelans as of 2017, and 870,000 by mid-2018, according to the IOM. By late 2018, as political conditions in the country worsened and hyperinflation persisted, roughly 2.6 million Venezuelans were living abroad, including 2 million within Latin America and the Caribbean, according to the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), which noted that Venezuelan children were among the 430,000 in Colombia, Brazil, Guyana, Trinidad and Tobago, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama who were in need of assistance. Although migration flows have a long history in Latin America and the Caribbean, the current acceleration poses a major development challenge to the region. Communities in many countries have sought to respond to this humanitarian crisis with solidarity and compassion. Latin American countries receiving migrants are faced with a corresponding demand for development investment that can help improve social services. Particular attention needs to be paid to better coordinating border management, developing adequate migration registration and documentation (including recognizing educational and professional accreditation), improved security, expanded access to basic services such as clean water and sanitation, health care, education, and employment services - as these migrants are likely to be away from their country of origin for a long time. Some countries have sought to adapt their laws to better accommodate the displaced. Colombia, for example, created a “Special Permit of Permanence” which can be used by Venezuelans to access the Colombian health system, according to the IOM; during the first half of 2018, Venezuelans used the system for help with nearly 48,000 emergencies, and to receive more than 150,000 doses of vaccines.

name: Mobilising Action for Inclusive Societies
description: No Description Available.

name: Mobilizing for Impact
description: The emergence of the 24-hour news cycle, the predominance of social media, abbreviated political cycles, an overwhelming focus on quarterly corporate financial reporting, and the increasingly ephemeral nature of employment have only increased our tendency to rely on short-term thinking. This has created real challenges when it comes to helping people personally connect to the long-term targets enshrined in the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals - which were adopted in 2015, in order to help guide global development until 2030. The issue of plastic in the oceans illustrates the power of raising greater public awareness of the goals, and encouraging leaders to take action on them. After the World Economic Forum and the Ellen McArthur Foundation released an analysis in 2016 showing that there may be more plastic than fish (by weight) in the oceans by 2050, numerous efforts to raise public awareness of the issue were undertaken by media outlets, documentary filmmakers, and civil society organizations. Amid this growing awareness, leaders were able to do things that may have previously been politically or financially unpopular. More than 60 countries have now banned or introduced fees on single-use plastics, and companies are working on more systemic solutions. In order to effectively mobilize action at a pace sufficient to deliver on all of the Sustainable Development Goals (which include lofty targets like eliminating poverty, in addition to preventing marine pollution), they must become strategic priorities for companies and governments once awareness of pressing issues has been raised. The Taskforce on Climate-related Financial Disclosure, initiated by the G20, demonstrates the value of bringing together diverse stakeholders to build understanding; it has convened financial experts, standards bodies, insurers, and climate scientists to develop recommendations for ensuring that the financial risk posed by climate change will become better understood by governments, companies, and investors. More than 500 companies have now agreed to adopt the recommendations of the taskforce.

name: Modern Discovery and Design
description: Our ability to visualize matter in extreme detail, down to the atomic level, has improved dramatically in recent years. Just within the last decade, advances in imaging techniques have enabled researchers to observe materials’ behaviour, yielding great gains in the understanding and improvement of functional parameters. For example, high-resolution, real-time tomography (presenting a cross-section of an object) can yield a 3D view of a device’s architecture, and show how it changes relative to its environment. Progress in widening the experimental conditions required for the observation of materials is also being made in more traditionally stringent techniques, such as high-resolution electron microscopy (both scanning electron microscopy, "SEM," and transmission electron microscopy, "TEM") or X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy ("XPS"), which are the workhorses of materials characterization. Similarly, advances in computing power and data visualization are impacting the design phase of materials-based applications, via more accurate computer simulations and approximations. Distributed manufacturing, where production is dispersed well beyond a centralized factory, will create new patterns of demand for new raw materials, specifically for use in increasingly prevalent 3D printing. It may also enable greater data gathering, and the more efficient harnessing of creativity and capabilities throughout the world (in a way similar to the Materials Genome initiative, which is a public, multi-agency effort underway in the US to assist in more quickly developing and deploying advanced materials). The continuous optimization of characterization techniques may result in a greater understanding of materials problems, and also in shorter feedback loops (where output from one process is used as input for another), thereby reducing the time needed to address these problems. The approach that has evolved as we transition from milli- to micro-, and then to nano-scale, is now entering a period of multi-scale design, where properties at many different levels are increasingly well understood.

name: Modern Mining Workforces
description: Constantly evolving technologies and business models will require mining company employees to develop new skills.
