Mining companies in general will have to help frontline employees become “protean” workers who embrace self-directed careers and developing new abilities, according to a report published by Deloitte in 2017; management will have to prepare employees for work that is not repetitive, but instead involves more complex tasks like remotely operating machinery, or monitoring efficiency metrics. In addition, as it seeks to attract top talent to drive digitalization and automation initiatives, the mining sector will have to increasingly compete with fast-growing technology firms. Entire fleets of self-driving trucks can already be operated remotely by a single person, and further technology-aided efficiency is on the horizon, according to a report published by the International Institute for Sustainable Development and the Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment in 2016. Governments and companies will have to work together to help workers who can no longer find their place in a more automated mining sector, by providing retraining programs. The speed at which mining companies are able to roll out new technologies at their mine sites will be closely linked to the willingness of local governments and labour unions to accept the fact that these technologies may lead to reduced employment and procurement opportunities. Local policy-makers and unions must therefore be included in the decision-making on transitioning to new technologies and strategies, and should develop policies that support workers who are negatively affected. Many regulatory frameworks will also have to be adapted in order to better encourage the private sector to implement only those innovative models that provide for social wellbeing - and impose penalties on those that unleash negative consequences. In addition, contracts will have to be adapted in order to reflect mining's new, technology-focused value proposition. Governments themselves will also need technical assistance, as they seek to maintain political and legal stability in mining areas.

name: Modernizing Latin American Institutions
description: Corruption and the lack of transparency in Latin America reflect weaknesses in judicial, legislative, and executive branches of government throughout the region. Recent scandals have eroded confidence in government institutions, and threaten the region’s economic well-being and political stability. In three of its four largest economies, Brazil, Colombia, and Mexico, corruption ranks among the top three most problematic factors for doing business in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index published in 2017; the subsequent Competitiveness Index published in 2018 ranked the three countries in the bottom half of all 140 assessed in terms of incidence of corruption. The Expert Advisory Group on Anti-Corruption, Transparency and Integrity in Latin America and the Caribbean, convened by the Inter-American Development Bank, reported in 2018 that the region’s average scores for nearly all “Worldwide Governance Indicators” were below the global median; it had particularly poor ratings in the implementation of the rule of law, personal security, and common crime. Transparency International, in its Corruption Perceptions Index published in 2018, noted strides that had been made by Latin America in recent years - though Transparency nonetheless scored the region relatively poorly in the index, and suggested that the lack of overarching policies that address historic and structural causes of corruption there has been problematic. Latin America appears to be falling further behind its peers in terms of controlling corruption. In general, trust in public institutions is at a low in the region; according to an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report published in 2018, this lack of trust has only deepened further since the global financial crisis roughly a decade ago, with about 75% of the Latin American population indicating little or no trust in government. This comes despite long periods of economic and social progress in the region that resulted in a sustained reduction of inequality and poverty, according to the OECD report - and has prompted added pressure from civil society organizations and the private sector to modernize public institutions.

name: Modernizing the Workforce
description: France has been dealing with structural unemployment for more than three decades, as the unemployment rate has consistently registered above 7%. Its unemployment rate was 9.3% as of August 2018 according to Eurostat, more than twice that of Germany and well above the European Union average of 6.8%. Meanwhile France’s ranking in the OECD’s Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) dropped to 26th by of 2015, from 14th in 2000. Students’ socio-economic status has a greater effect on their academic performance in France than in any other OECD country. Addressing weaknesses in the French education system, not least by minimizing the negative effects of social circumstances, is critical (related reforms should focus on early childhood). As students graduate and join the workforce, they encounter a complex labour code that creates France’s so-called insider-outsider system - where employees with open-ended job contracts enjoy a high degree of job security, while others struggle from one fixed-term contract to another. More than eight jobs in 10 that are created in France every year are attached to less attractive, fixed-term contracts, according to the country’s Directorate of Research, Studies and Statistics Coordination (DARES). The French government has sought to overhaul and simplify the labour code by capping pay-outs for unfair dismissal, granting small- and medium-sized firms more flexibility to hire and fire, and allowing firms with fewer than 20 employees to negotiate directly with their staff and local unions - bypassing national, sector-level union officials. A significant challenge for France is its need to help workers adjust to the shifting demands of the economy throughout their careers. The emergence of new skills and jobs as a result of the Fourth Industrial Revolution will affect the French labour market and its education system. According to the World Economic Forum’s 2017 paper Accelerating Workforce Reskilling for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, in order to address the potential disconnect between its education system and the modern workplace, France needs to reform curricula in order to better prepare workers for jobs in an innovation-driven economy. This will involve reviewing core linguistic, mathematical, and technological literacies, and working to ensure the mastery of information and communications technology. As an ageing country, France should also consider investing in the re-skilling of older workers, and help these workers understand the benefits of participating in related training opportunities.

name: Molding New Talent
description: Emerging multinationals may be able to successfully ride the waves of change upending global education and knowledge systems. Many come from countries with relatively young populations, and nascent systems of vocational and higher education. Evidence presented in the 2013 book Emerging-Markets Rule shows that emerging multinationals therefore have an opportunity to actively shape the way in which vocational schools and universities in their home countries grow, by engaging them in conversations about the evolving skills that companies require. For example, in India and in China, companies are making significant investments in new educational institutions, and are frequently partnering with existing institutions, in an attempt to better meet talent needs. China enacted a law in 2017 that enables universities to establish themselves as for-profits, and is intended to address the need for more relevant skills training. Companies, and governments, are realizing that the single biggest bottleneck in the global economy involves talent. While unemployment and underemployment remain high in several parts of the world, especially among the young, companies and governments consistently report that they cannot find enough people with the skills they need. However, schools generally, and universities particularly, are institutions that change very slowly - and require years of planning and implementation in order to boost innovation and investment. Governance of education systems is the subject of heated debates, in virtually every country in the world, about the correct balance of influence among the public, private, and non-profit sectors. These debates tend to be dogmatic, and to centre on the issue of whether access to a quality education is a right or a privilege. A better way to approach the problem might be to think about education as an essential tool for developing a society that is politically, socially, and economically prepared to deal with the challenges ahead. Technology adoption has been a slow process in education systems generally. However, adequately matching demand to supply is how a market economy can best function, and given the long-term investments now required of education systems in order to start producing more qualified job candidates, their greater use of innovative technology could provide crucial assistance.

name: More Sustainable Mobility
description: In 2015, the “Dieselgate” scandal revealed that diesel vehicles were producing as much as 40 times more pollution than had been detected during testing, due to widespread cheating. Four years later, despite changes made to systems for measuring emissions and the recall of more than 10 million vehicles, the positive impact in the European Union has been minimal, according to a report published by the European Court of Auditors in 2019. It may take many years to improve city air quality in the EU, according to the report, given the large number of highly-polluting cars that remain on the roads. In the US, the number of vehicle miles driven has been increasing dramatically, from about 1.5 trillion in 1980 to 3.2 trillion by 2017, according to the US Department of Transportation. While the advent of ride-sharing services like Uber has encouraged people to drive less, those services may be less beneficial for the environment than anticipated; a study published by the San Francisco County Transportation Authority in 2018 found that ride-sharing services accounted for about half of the increase in local traffic congestion between 2010 and 2016. Companies are continually working to find new ways to improve the sustainability of cars, ships and aircraft. The 3D printing of relatively lightweight parts has played a related role in the aerospace industry, for example. Global governance can also play a constructive role; the International Air Transport Association’s annual general meeting in 2019 approved a resolution calling on governments to fully implement a carbon offsetting and reduction scheme designed to cap net carbon dioxide emissions from international aviation as of 2020 (which had been agreed through the UN’s International Civil Aviation Organization). In addition, growing consumer awareness can be a factor. In Sweden, for example, “flygskam,” or “flight shame” has become a means of socially engineering people away from emissions-heavy air travel, while “tagskryt,” or “train bragging” has emerged as a local corollary. However, measures to combat climate change by adopting more sustainable mobility practices still fall short of what is necessary. To call further attention to the need to travel smarter, climate activist Greta Thunberg journeyed from England to the UN Climate Action Summit in New York in summer 2019 via a carbon-free sailboat.

name: Multi-Stakeholder Collaboration
description: Collaboration, co-creation, and co-production will become more permanent fixtures of government operations and service delivery. The Open Government Partnership, launched in 2011, already convenes public sector reformers and civil society leaders to try to make government more inclusive and accountable. The partnership now includes nearly 80 countries and 20 sub-national governments. Meanwhile the US, Australia, and Singapore have all recently experimented with more consultative and deliberative policy-making, including through citizen juries (representative samples of people tasked with considering particular community issues) and deliberative polling (asking people to deliberate on potential policy moves), in order to feed a wider range of perspectives into policy decisions and implementation. Care must be exercised in picking and choosing where to collaborate, and there is already an extensive track record to examine; nearly 2,000 public-private partnerships worth about €336 million were developed in the European Union between 1990 and 2016, according a 2018 European Court of Auditors report. Unfortunately, the potential benefits of many of these infrastructure-related partnerships in the EU often failed to materialize. As multi-stakeholder approaches will become increasingly necessary, leaders in every sector will need to learn how to operate more effectively across complex networks, and build trust with one another in the process. That is because the daunting challenges facing humanity cannot be solved by any single sector alone; governance must become a multi-stakeholder endeavour. As governments and policy-makers increasingly scramble to react and respond to technological innovation, it creates new opportunities for the private sector, civil society groups, community groups, the media, and academia to work alongside public officials and provide expertise on technologies they themselves have developed, including on their applications potential consequences. In the case of truly cutting-edge technologies where expertise is particularly thin, non-governmental actors will be particularly important partners helping to anticipate potential risks and opportunities.

name: Multi-omics Science
description: We are increasingly recognizing that our individual variations in the form, function, and complexity of the interaction of our biomolecular parts translate into unique health requirements - and risk of disease. Even diseases once presumed to be simple, in the sense that a specific gene was thought to cause the disease, are now being recognized as more complex in terms of both severity, and in terms of potential for treatment in light of environmental factors like diet. Accordingly, the precision-based and personalized maintenance of health, and the diagnosis and treatment of disease, requires the coordinated collection and analysis of so-called “multi-omics” datasets that are culled from tissue. “Omics” approaches to biomedicine (involving fields that end in “-omics”) comprehensively assess biomolecules like genes and proteins at a scale equal to entire cells and organisms. That means that while genetics is the study of the form and function of specific genes, genomics is a high-throughput interrogation of all of the genes in an organism; transcriptomics is meanwhile the system-wide study of gene expression, while metabolomics relates to metabolites (the products of metabolism, such as amino acids), and proteomics are tied to proteins. The application of machine learning and other statistical pattern-recognition tools to multi-omics datasets can facilitate a shift from reactive medicine to a fundamentally proactive form of predictive and precision health.

name: Multicultural Identity
description: Australia is a nation of immigrants. The Aboriginal First Peoples migrated to the country around 65,000 years ago, from Maritime Southeast Asia and New Guinea. It was not until 1778 that European settlement began, with the establishment of British penal colonies. Until the mid-twentieth century, the country continued to be characterized as a British outpost. The end of World War II saw a second wave of European migrants, this time from southern and eastern Europe as well as from Britain. With the abolition in 1973 of the infamous “White Australia Policy,” which had effectively barred people of non-European descent from the country, there has been a steady increase in immigrants from Asian, Africa, and the Middle East. By 2017, nearly half the country’s population was either born overseas or had at least one parent born abroad. While English is the national language, an estimated 300 others (including Indigenous languages) are spoken in Australian homes; the most common include Mandarin, Cantonese, Arabic, Italian, and Greek. Increasing numbers of schools are now providing instruction for children in at least some of these languages; the Australian National University now offers courses in more than 25 languages, including Mongolian, Thai, Vietnamese, and Tibetan. Although the government claims to have an open-door policy allowing people from any country to migrate to Australia regardless of ethnicity, culture, religion, or language, in practice successful applicants are limited. Intake for 2017-18 was capped at 190,000, unchanged from 2016-17. More than two thirds of the available places are for skilled migrants. In addition, with the exception of around 500 slots per year, sponsorship by relatives already living in Australia is required. Surveys of Australian attitudes towards multiculturalism have consistently registered an approval rating of around 86%, reflecting a belief that it makes the country stronger. This has not always translated into tolerant behaviour. In 2016, a survey showed that one in five respondents had experienced discrimination on the basis of skin colour, ethnic origin, or religion during the previous decade. Of equal concern are the survey’s findings of an increasing concentration of overseas-born ethnic groups in suburban areas, especially in Sydney and Melbourne. The key challenge here is a need to better understand if these suburbs are evolving into closed communities, which run counter to notions of an inclusive and multicultural national identity - and to what extent we must better promote the integration of new Australians.

name: Multinationals and Hidden Champions
description: Home-grown multinationals and the local operations of large, international companies are major assets for the Swiss economy. In per capita terms, tiny Switzerland has one of the highest concentrations of Fortune 500 companies in the world. Sectors that are represented include commodity trading and mining (Glencore), pharmaceuticals (Roche and Novartis), food and beverage (Nestle), Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ABB), luxury goods (Richemont), reinsurance (Swiss Re) and banking (UBS and Credit Suisse). At the same time, Switzerland is also home to a large number of “hidden champions,” or companies that are highly competitive on the global market (number one in Europe in their segment, or among the top three in the world), yet are relatively little-known and have annual revenue of less than $4 billion. Switzerland has more than 100 such companies, including bicycle components firm DT Swiss, and medical compression garment maker Sigvaris. Switzerland is attractive to businesses because of its relatively well-educated workers, quality of life, reliable and efficient government, stable economic environment, flexible labour market, good infrastructure, and competitive tax system. However, according to a report published by KPMG in 2016, Clarity on Business Location Switzerland, the country is at risk of losing the advantages it offers to multinational corporations. There is growing international competition from countries such as Singapore, which offer comparably attractive conditions. In addition, high labour costs in Switzerland are a key challenge for companies, particularly mid-sized firms. There is also uncertainty regarding the Swiss franc exchange rate, which can elevate the cost of having operations based in Switzerland. Companies are concerned about recent changes in Swiss labour regulations, which threaten flexibility, while the rejection by Swiss voters of a proposed, potentially business-friendly corporate tax reform in 2017 created further uncertainty. It is likely that the traditionally favourable tax conditions for multinationals operating in Switzerland will not persist, as the country further aligns its policies with the neighbouring European Union and loses more of the differentiation that has made it attractive. If Switzerland wants to maintain its allure for international corporations, it must strengthen its core assets, such as its stable political environment, relatively limited income inequality, high quality of life, dual education system that fosters vocational training, and high-quality workforce.

name: Multiple and Indirect Functionality
description: The expanding requirements of the most dynamic scientific and commercial exploration call for a new, higher level of performance at the materials level. The materials sector is responding, by accelerating its shift to the realm of multi-functionality, where a deeper understanding of fundamental properties is enabling a more bottom-up, bespoke design of materials that can deliver performance in many areas simultaneously, while minimizing compromises. For example, needs residing at the intersection of biology, medicine, and materials will require the integrated design of the physical spaces used to deliver healthcare, so that they include a range of potential solutions. Surfaces will increasingly combine biocidal activity (the destroying or preventing the harmful effects of organisms) with other control mechanisms (for example, implants that provoke tissue regeneration). Meanwhile a combination of bio-compatibility, thermo-responsiveness, and self-signalling properties will open up new avenues when it comes to regenerative medicine. Essentially, materials will be increasingly designed to combine both structural and functional properties. Biology continues to be a challenging but enriching model for advanced materials. Just like the biological systems that deliver activity and selectivity through the coordinated action of multiple agents, we will soon design cooperative systems in which the combination of multiple materials will yield unique functions. Fast and sophisticated experimentation will also propel applications of indirect functionality where, for example, drug-like activity is displayed by the action of ionic species in processes such as cell stimulation or induced turnover. The precise synthesis of catalytic nanoparticles will need to be complemented with biological and other functionalities to break through the existing barriers presented by photo-induced waste degradation. Biology is also showing us how to design better structural composites and materials, which display a degree of autonomy previously only seen in devices. This is happening not through the development of novel algorithms, but rather by mastering basic principles of self-healing, self-cleaning, and self-assembly - and through bio-mimicry, structural self-deprecation, and renewal.

name: Multipolar, Multi-conceptual
description: The geopolitical landscape is in the midst of a profound transformation, giving rise to a world order that is both multipolar and multi-conceptual - not only has global power shifted, but differences in norms and values among geopolitical heavyweights have become more important. The period following World War II, first characterized by the bipolarity of the Cold War and then the unipolarity of US hegemony, has given way to a phase in which power is more diffused among states and blocs. At the centre of this upheaval is an evolution of the roles played by the US and China, and a changing relationship between the two economic behemoths. Meanwhile patterns of influence, cooperation, and competition are also changing among a broader group of countries, including Russia, India, and a number of states in Europe and the Middle East. What is distinctive about the current geopolitical moment is not its multipolarity. The period before World War I was multipolar, after all - but it was also largely uniconceptual. Now, multipolarity is coinciding with a fraying of the idea that the world order can be shaped by shared or converging fundamental political values. More than a quarter century ago, the political scientist Francis Fukuyama predicted that in the wake of the Cold War, liberal democracy would prove to be “the” model for governance the world over. Similar assumptions about a convergence on Western norms have underpinned many geopolitical and geo-economic developments. This has masked persistent differences, which have become increasingly prominent. Many of today’s emergent (or resurgent) centres of power have diverse political values, governance systems, historical legacies, and societal conventions (consider, for example, the contrasting narratives of China, India, Russia, Saudi Arabia and Turkey). This constrains the extent to which some influential states are willing to sign up to a world order that appears to grant primacy to the values and governance systems of legacy powers. It also informs how shared challenges are addressed - as manifested in the current difficulties plaguing many multilateral institutions. This not simply a story of the West against the rest; the multi-conceptual turn in world politics is also evident in Western disagreements about core political values, such as hardening differences among members states of the European Union. Many of the institutions that have shaped global politics and economics since the middle of the 20th century must be reimagined, for a multipolar and multi-conceptual 21st century.

name: Natural Resource Needs
description: As the ranks of the middle class and urban populations grow in emerging markets, demand for natural resources is heating up. Natural resources are a key factor in global competitiveness; they help to attract investment, generate trade, and spur technological innovation, ultimately contributing to the disruption of industries and emergence of new players. As countries scramble to meet their energy needs, the most significant constraints include safety and perception issues associated with nuclear power, slow progress in developing in carbon-capture technologies, and limited hydroelectric and biofuel production (however, wind and solar power are becoming more cost competitive, and natural gas is becoming more plentiful). The home countries of many emerging multinationals face formidable challenges in terms of energy sufficiency, raw materials procurement, and water security. These firms therefore have an incentive to invest and innovate in related areas. In Brazil, for example, local companies have become global leaders in terms of sustainability, while Chinese firms have made great inroads in wind and solar energy. Emerging multinationals promise to play ever larger roles in the race to more efficiently consume and leverage natural resources. The need to address demands for greater sustainability will affect the ways that emerging multinationals operate and serve customers. Massive energy demand will force significant changes in consumer behaviour; estimates published in the 2014 book Green Power indicate that improved consumer habits could reduce demand for electricity and fuels by as much as 30%. In addition, the sharing economy, especially in big cities, could bring about a rationalization of demand for transportation, while electric cars will reduce the demand for fossil fuels. Meanwhile developments in materials science could limit the need for emerging multinationals to look abroad for partnerships as a means to secure resources that are unavailable at home - and may instead enable them to engineer their own materials necessary to meet production needs. Materials science is making so much progress that our dependence on staples such as aluminium, copper, and coal might be drastically reduced. Composite materials are replacing metals on aircraft, in automobiles, and in buildings, while nanotechnologies offer the possibility of smart materials engineered to be more flexible or more heat resistant.

name: Nature and Human Health
description: Good human health depends on nature to provide a steady supply of nutritious food, clean air, water, and spiritual and cultural enrichment that boost mental well-being. Green spaces can reduce the incidence of non-communicable diseases such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes, according to a report published in 2018 by the World Health Organization, and exposure to biodiverse green space provides a connection to nature that could benefit the 700 million people estimated to be affected by mental health issues. While human activity and the loss of vegetation in urban areas makes them hotter than surrounding rural areas, urban green infrastructure such as parks and trees can help filter out air pollution, reduce noise, and provide cooling and shade that reduce this heating effect (and help cities adapt to climate change). Biodiversity is also a source of genetic information valuable for research into new medicines, and into ways of bolstering food security by reducing dependence on a small number of staple crop varieties. The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) estimated in a 2019 report that roughly 821 million people face food insecurity in Asia and Africa alone. The IPBES report also warned that negative trends in biodiversity will undermine efforts to achieve United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, including the goal of ensuring a healthy a life for everyone. Biodiversity loss and reduced human contact with the natural environment threaten to reduce diversity in human microbiota, which may lead to a weakening of immunity and the onset of non-communicable disease, according to the WHO’s 2018 report. Other health risks tied to the degradation of nature include vector borne diseases. Malaria, one of the largest causes of death in the Southern Hemisphere, is aggravated by deforestation and poorly-built and -designed water systems; as the climate changes and forests are degraded, mosquitoes are increasingly traveling to new areas while carrying vector-borne diseases like malaria, dengue fever, and Zika. Greater public awareness needs to be raised about the dependence of human health on healthy ecosystems, in order to boost collective action and avoid related risks. The IPBES report made clear that only “transformative” change will reverse biodiversity loss - its recommendations included better protecting natural habitats, and introducing more green infrastructure into cities.

name: Nature-Based Solutions
description: While conventional development often depletes natural resources and uses up vast amounts of energy-intensive materials, nature-based solutions can be applied to related problems in a sustainable way that benefits both people and biodiversity. For example, protecting and restoring forest ecosystems in upper river catchments (where rainfall collects) can reduce the risk of floods and landslides, prevent soil erosion, and improve water quality. This type of natural flood management can also be combined with engineered infrastructure in order to deal with severe rainfall events. Other nature-based solutions include “biomimicry,” or using nature as the inspiration or blueprint for products like medicines and advanced materials; self-cleaning paints inspired by the natural ability of the lotus leaf to remain pristine, for example, now generate hundreds of millions of dollars in annual revenue. This harvesting of knowledge from nature is a key element of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. In a distinct but related way, nature-based solutions can also play a vital role in mitigating climate change - by locking up stores of carbon in the biomass making up forests, wetlands and other ecosystems. Nature can also help absorb the impacts of climate change via urban parks, street trees, and green walls and roofs that can cool cities, reduce flooding, and filter out pollution - with less environmental impact than traditional solutions like air conditioning and concrete flood defences. While engineered solutions can be costly and require long-term maintenance, the costs of nature-based solutions are offset by multiple benefits. Coral reefs protect hundreds of millions of people from coastal flooding, for example, so their restoration is ultimately significantly cheaper than building and maintaining artificial breakwaters. In the US alone, coral reefs provide $1.8 billion-worth of free flood risk reduction every year, according to a report published by the US Geological Survey in 2019, while also serving as fish nurseries, tourist attractions, and carbon stores. Still, the potential for nature-based solutions to enhance natural habitats and restore and regenerate ecosystems is not always fully realized; carbon storage strategies often involve monoculture planting of non-native tree species, for example, which have little-to-no benefit for biodiversity. Only through evidence-based project design, sound governance, and greater awareness can we use nature to cost-effectively tackle both climate change and the biodiversity crisis.

name: Nature’s Limits
description: It has recently become clear that as the global economy expands, we are exceeding environmental limits on the supply of key resources like fish stocks and fertilizer, and on the natural world’s capacity to absorb the waste products of economic activity like carbon dioxide emissions, pollution, and plastic waste in rivers and oceans. Plastic pollution has increased tenfold since 1980, according to a report published in 2019 by the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES), and as much as 400 million tons of heavy metals, solvents, toxic sludge and other waste from industrial facilities is being dumped annually into global waters. In addition, according to the report, fertilizers entering coastal ecosystems have generated more than 400 ocean “dead zones,” or areas where the oxygen required to sustain marine life has been depleted, which cover nearly 250,000 square kilometres - an area greater in size than the United Kingdom. Negative trends like this are expected to continue until the year 2050 and beyond, barring “transformative” policy change, according to the report. Traditionally, discrete parts of the world have often dealt with their respective environmental limits by externalizing consumption and shifting waste management to other regions. However, those options are not available when dealing with planetary limits. A better understanding of the dynamics of these planetary limits can help inform business planning, and reduce the risk of the collapse of cod fisheries, or of the disease-induced collapse of agricultural products such as bananas and coffee. There are opportunities to work in a way that is more in tune with nature, in order to both reduce the negative impact of economic activity and to facilitate adaptation. The IPBES report estimated that as a result of unprecedented rates of habitat loss and the over-exploitation of resources, one million species are now under threat of extinction. However, the report noted that it is not too late to reverse this trend by reducing consumption and moving to sustainable production methods. Agriculture, for example, should protect biodiversity while it provides food security; both the public and private sectors should become more engaged in conserving the diversity of crop and livestock breeds, and in empowering consumers to make sustainable choices.

name: Neural Tools
description: Advances in sophisticated and wearable technology to monitor brain health are revolutionizing efforts in the early detection of neural disease. A new generation of devices is being created to improve and enhance the quality of life. Smartwatch-based devices can now monitor epilepsy patients, and notify family members and caretakers when seizures occur. Other devices are being developed for recording with great precision the motion of patients with Parkinson’s disease or multiple sclerosis. Such wearable devices should greatly improve care by providing comprehensive monitoring with objective and sophisticated analysis of symptoms in real time. Surgically-implanted neurostimulators are now widely used to treat a broad range of brain disorders. Neurostimulators are devices that use microelectrodes to deliver non-damaging electrical pulses to restore activity in brain circuits that have lost their normal inputs. The most widely used and arguably most effective neurostimulators are cochlear implants that restore some level of hearing in deaf patients. Hundreds of thousands of patients worldwide have received these implants. Deaf children who receive an implant before they are 18 months old can develop language skills similar to their hearing peers. Another application of neurostimulators is in deep brain stimulation (DBS), which is used to treat an ever-increasing range of conditions. DBS has been employed most extensively in Parkinson’s disease, where it can provide relief of tremor, stiffness and walking problems. DBS is also emerging as an important treatment option for chronic pain, depression, essential tremor and obsessive-compulsive disorder. The ways in which DBS leads to clinical improvements are not yet understood. Another area where neural tools will make an important contribution is in brain-machine interfaces (BMIs). BMIs link brains to computers using arrays of many microelectrodes. In some cases, the computer operates like a cochlear implant, using the microelectrodes to activate specific brain cells to produce sensations such as touch or sight. Preliminary successes suggest that with further development such BMIs will improve the lives of amputees and blind patients. For example, pilot experiments led by the University of Pittsburgh have used stimulation of the somatosensory cortex to give a patient with spinal cord injury a rudimentary sense of touch when using a special robotic prosthetic. In other cases, signals from the brain are interpreted by the computer and used to control external devices, such as a robotic arm. Technologies such as these have the potential of restoring mobility to paralyzed patients.

name: Neuroethics
description: While we can anticipate impressive progress in neuroscience over the coming years, those advances will not be as dramatic as suggested in movies or in current fiction. In particular, brain-machine interfaces that make it possible to transfer the entirety of a person’s memories or personality into a computer, or to experience a lifelike virtual world created by a computer, will not be a reality in the foreseeable future. The inner workings of the brain are far too intricate and inaccessible to allow the sort of precise and comprehensive access that would be needed for such elaborate brain-machine interfaces. But, while we can defer full consideration of the ethical issues related to mind-extraction or mind-insertion, there are many important ethical issues that arise even with the current progress in neuroscience. Advances from neuroscience are being used to alter human behaviour. In most cases, those alterations are unequivocally good: effective drugs can relieve the burden of pain, depression, anxiety and other nervous system disorders, and the ethics related to these treatments have been long-discussed and understood. However, in the near future technological advances will introduce new legal and social issues that will require attention and discussion. Many issues related to neuroscience are closely aligned to general bioethics, but some issues are distinctively associated with manipulation of the human brain. It is becoming routine for normal healthy individuals to use drugs and devices that enhance their attention, creativity, mood or personality. Questions exist about the safety of such enhancers, but the efficacy and safety of such drugs could easily improve in the future. Perhaps more important are questions about whether these enhancers are entirely beneficial. Critics argue that they violate human nature and authenticity. Differential access to cognitive enhancers might also increase the gap between rich and poor. Similarly, development is proceeding on drugs that can dampen memories. These may offer great relief by easing the pain associated with traumatic memories, or reducing the associations that lead to drug-seeking, but neuroethicists are concerned about whether the use of such drugs will decrease a person’s sense of identity, and they might be abused in many ways. Widespread access to brain imaging tools has enabled the development of forensic psychiatry and methods that can probe mental states more effectively than other psychological or physiological approaches. As behaviours become more tightly linked to specific brain functions or dysfunctions, concepts about agency and responsibility of individuals are likely to evolve, with implications for the practice of both medicine and the law.   In most cases, the benefits of drugs and other interventions on the nervous system are very likely to outweigh the social, personal and philosophical problems that they might cause. But because the brain is the mechanism of agency and self, it is particularly important that informed discussion among all relevant parties be a part of the process as new interventions are developed. This discussion will need to include practitioners from many fields, including medicine, psychology, law and public policy.

name: Neurological Disorders
description: Neurological disorders are diseases of the brain, spinal cord or nerves. They include disorders involving the loss of healthy brain cells. Such loss might be widespread, as occurs with traumatic brain injury or with dementias such as Alzheimer’s disease. Alternatively, the loss might affect specific brain structures, as occurs with brain trauma, stroke or movement disorders such as Parkinson’s disease. Neurological diseases also include malfunctioning of the brain and nerves, as in epilepsy or chronic pain. Neurological disorders, like mental disorders, have a profound effect on quality of life and economic productivity. The World Health Organization lists stroke by itself as the second most prevalent cause of death worldwide, second only to ischaemic heart disease. Research published in the Annals of Rheumatic Diseases in 2014 found that lower back pain causes more global disability than any other condition. Fortunately, rapid advances in genetics and regeneration biology have produced new tools that are revolutionizing the study of the molecular mechanisms that are critical for keeping brain cells healthy.

name: New Business Models
description: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) boasts a growing market of more than 600 million consumers. ASEAN’s five leading economies, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Thailand, have a collective GDP per capita of $4,390, according to the International Monetary Fund; less than half of that of China, but more than twice the value registered for India. However, making a profit in ASEAN may not be easy, as buyers there are particularly price sensitive and demanding. Local businesses operate on low margins, and with low labour costs, making them formidable competitors to foreign rivals. Innovation is particularly important for the region in relation to underdeveloped institutions and infrastructure, which complicate the delivery of products and services. Companies must deliver value to customers under relatively difficult conditions, and at low cost for consumers with limited spending power. Mobile technology can be particularly useful for creating solutions that compensate for weak infrastructure; Wing, a Cambodian firm, uses relatively simple mobile technology and a network of local agents to provide payment services to customers who need to work around an underdeveloped banking infrastructure, for example. Similarly, Indonesia’s Go-Jek provides a ride-sharing service adapted to the local transportation environment by using motorcycles. Companies can also innovate in the sourcing of raw materials. The Prostheses Foundation in Thailand did exactly that when it developed affordable, artificial legs fashioned from recycled plastic yogurt bottles, which can be sold for less than $100. The foundation kept costs low by using amputees as technicians, rather than trained professionals, and it managed to find a spot in the Guinness Book of World Records for donating the most prosthetics from a single organization (864 artificial legs over 13 days in 2012). A single business model is unlikely to work equally well across all ASEAN countries, given the cultural and economic diversity of the region. Government support can help ensure that companies are encouraged to innovate, by reducing their potential costs related to failure. This can be done with a so-called “light touch” regulatory approach, which fosters creativity and entrepreneurship. One example: the Monetary Authority of Singapore provides a “sandbox” innovation space for financial technology startups, within which financial institutions and innovators can test new products. As banks grapple with a new regulatory environment, a new breed of alternative providers of capital has emerged: so-called shadow banks, which function as intermediaries but are not necessarily regulated. These have included everything from hedge funds, to payday lenders, peer-to-peer lenders, and crowdfunding platforms. They challenge traditional financing models, while incurring relatively lower costs than traditional banks. They also pose greater risk to general financial stability. According to a report published by the Basel, Switzerland-based Financial Stability Board in 2018, the “narrow measure of shadow banking,” which includes non-bank financial entities that are considered to pose financial stability risks, rose by 7.6% in 2016, to $45.2 trillion, in 29 jurisdictions measured. That amount represented 13% of all global financial assets for the period, according to the report - and more than 75% of related assets were in just six jurisdictions. The addition of China alone to the mix of jurisdictions increased the narrow measure by $7 trillion, according to the report. For many banks around the world, the recent past has been marred by the commoditization of their products and services, and by a pressing need to shrink balance sheets and scale back on lending - in order to comply with post-crisis regulations. This pullback has curbed profitability, especially in businesses like fixed income (trading in instruments like debt, which are tied to interest rates), and currency and commodities trading. Policymakers’ push during the past decade to centralize clearing on many tradable products has also impacted banks’ bottom lines. While advances in technology have enabled more automation and cost cutting at banks, these same advances have also activated new potential competitors. Specialized, financial technology-focused (FinTech) firms can now offer products and services at a much lower cost than most traditional banks. This is pushing these traditional financial institutions to press ahead with significant overhauls of their business models in response - and to cultivate better ties with startup communities in order to gain insight into relevant innovation and launch new services. Global investment in fintech startups reached nearly $58 billion during the first half of 2018 alone, exceeding the total amount registered during the prior year, according to a report published by KPMG.

name: New Disruptive Technologies
description: Digital disruptions are rapidly changing the socioeconomic landscape. Rapid advances in artificial intelligence (AI), the cloud, the so-called Internet of Things, data analytics and quantum computing promise to create tremendous value. At the same time, they will also fundamentally alter the way we live, work and interact with one another. The human brain has inspired new developments in artificial intelligence. A recent study published in Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience suggested that because human intelligence can be mapped using relatively simple mathematical logic dubbed  ”Power-of-Two”-based permutation logic,  AI will outpace human capability. For now, the types of AI being deployed are extremely limited, despite the technology’s wide-ranging potential. Virtually all recent AI developments are the same type, characterized by input data being translated into a quickly-generated, simple response. But this trend will not last.  When it comes to the Internet of Things, exciting breakthroughs have been made that enable communication between devices, like a phone talking to a washing machine. As these devices process larger amounts of data in order to maximize their performance, it will in turn require greater data processing capabilities. The use of so-called big data analytics to analyse all of that information is becoming increasingly important. According to the 2015 report Deep Shift: Technology Tipping Points and Societal Impact, issued by the World Economic Forum Global Agenda Council on the Future of Software & Society, big data analytics will enable businesses and governments to provide efficient, real-time support for everything from customer service to filing taxes.

name: New Economic Thinking
description: While there are significant disparities from place to place, no country in the world currently has a life expectancy rate lower than the highest rate as of 1800. During the past century, the global population living in absolute poverty has declined from 82% to just 9%, while the number of functioning democracies has increased to 123 from 16 - in addition, the global literacy rate has jumped to 85% from 32%. Economic growth has been at the heart of these improvements. However, we are seeing troubling signs; for many people in the world, life has stopped getting better. According to the Lancet Commission on pollution and health, an initiative started by the medical journal The Lancet, the Global Alliance on Health and Pollution, and the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, environmental pollution has reduced annual global economic output by 6.2%, and caused roughly 9 million premature deaths. Workers in some cities now spend an average of one to two work weeks per year stuck in traffic jams, inequality among the rich and the poor is increasing, and levels of personal, corporate, and sovereign debt are reaching new highs. Meanwhile the geopolitical landscape has shifted to a multi-conceptual framework, where traditional, singular ideas about how best to look after world affairs have splintered into multiple approaches, and often-conflicting agendas. The increased prevalence of protectionist trade policies, and a broad decline of commitments to rules-based multilateralism are threatening to exacerbate tensions. The innovations fuelling the Fourth Industrial Revolution are also raising questions about traditional economic assumptions - in relation to productivity, work, education, and the use of data. In the face of these trends, we must explore ways to update our economic models and systems, in order to ensure they deliver positive outcomes for humanity as a whole for the coming century and beyond.

name: New Leadership
description: There are a variety of international agreements on the environment and sustainability, including the Paris Agreement on climate change, an amendment to the Montreal Protocol intended to decrease hydrofluorocarbon gases, and an International Civil Aviation Organization agreement to ensure zero net growth in carbon emissions from international aviation starting in 2020. Now, the focus has shifted from negotiating these agreements to implementing related commitments. As this unfolds, new players have emerged to take on leadership roles. These players include national, state, and city governments, and corporate decision-makers. China in particular is emerging as a leader on environmental action (particularly on climate change), and the extent to which it matches its international commitments with domestic action will have significant, global implications. China joined the US in taking a leadership role on negotiating and ratifying the Paris Agreement on climate action, for example - and while the US subsequently announced in 2017 that it intends to withdraw from the deal (countries are technically unable to leave until 2020), China has continued to reaffirm its commitment. Analysts expect China to reach peak carbon dioxide emissions before 2030. Much of the country's reduction of emissions and coal consumption in recent years has actually been the result of an economic slowdown. Still, China has proactively introduced laws to tax corporate pollution, and it has issued its first green bond (debt raised specifically for the funding of environmental projects). Other countries are also developing strong domestic policies to match their international commitments; in 2016, Canada released a Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change, which includes a national carbon price, a phasing out of coal-fired power, and cleaner fuel standards. Combined with the actions being taken by individual states in the US such as California (where the state legislature approved legislation in 2018 that requires 100% of electricity to come from carbon-free sources), this suggests that climate action will continue in North America, despite recent challenges. Meanwhile in Indonesia, a moratorium was issued on the conversion of peatland, which could help prevent forest fires and reduce emissions. Decisive action on the part of such leaders will be essential for achieving many United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, which were adopted in 2015 as a way to guide development through 2030.

name: New Norms of Collaboration
description: By better connecting academic researchers, private sector organizations, non-profits and government agencies, the transmission and shared analysis of big data can lead to more fruitful discoveries. However, data collaboration will only remain viable if it can be done securely. This entails data anonymization that minimizes so-called re-identification, and international collaboration among lawmakers and law enforcement agencies. As the cyber world increasingly inserts itself into to the physical world, there is a hunger for new ways to collaborate. Consumers, for example, are looking for different ways to collaborate with both with each other and with the businesses they patronize. Meanwhile the increased prevalence of cyberattacks has pushed governments and businesses to seek out more productive ways of collaborating in order to better protect themselves. According to the results of a survey of thousands of executives in more than 100 countries published in 2017 by the consultancy PwC, 44% said they do not have an overall information security strategy, even as the tools for conducting cyberattacks are proliferating around the world. Though attempts have been made to establish cyber security frameworks, such as the European Union’s Cyber Security Strategy, there is a general lack of understanding about how states and organizations should conduct themselves in cyberspace. Each industry is susceptible to different kinds of cyberattacks; the financial industry must often deal with phishing emails, for example. Data sharing within an industry can therefore help afflicted organizations better understand the most pertinent threats. Other types of cyberattacks, like ransomware, which can hold an internet user’s personal data hostage, are directed at all industries. Researchers studying such threats in both academia and the private sector need to be able to operate with relatively low risk. Organizations like the Canadian Cyber Threat Exchange can help facilitate related discussions, and provide secure forums for information exchange. In addition, international legal organizations such as Interpol should continue to be fine-tuned, in order to better take into account the international nature of cybercrime. A white paper published by the World Economic Forum’s Global Agenda Council on Cybersecurity in 2016 recommended that the public and private sectors explore new ways of collaborating that leverage the perspectives of governments, companies, civil society and academia.

name: New Patterns of Consumption
description: Many of our notions about consumption must be rethought. The consumption of retail goods is still an omnipresent driver of the global economy, though new forces are at work that challenge us to think differently about retail and consumption patterns. Consumer Expenditure data from the US Bureau of Labour Statistics suggest that spending among those with the highest incomes has shifted in the post-financial crisis period, with less emphasis on material goods. Instead, people in this group are now more interested in buying experiences, and in key, long-term investments like retirement and education. And while the middle class is still spending significantly on material goods, economists point to wage stagnation as a significant hindrance for people in this group living in developed countries including the United Kingdom and the US. According to a report published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in 2018, annual nominal hourly wage growth in OECD countries has fallen to 2.1% in recent years from 4.8% in the pre-financial crisis period. The UK actually experienced a decline in annual average real wages between 2007 and 2017, according to OECD data.  The importance of spending by the global middle class on cars and other material goods cannot be overstated. Given the median wage stagnation for the middle class in a number of high-income countries, the expanding middle class in developing countries has had to take up the slack. In 2015, North America accounted for 18% of global middle class consumption, though that is expected to fall to 10% by 2030, according to a report published by the Brookings Institution in 2017; meanwhile Europe’s share is expected to decline from 31% to 20%. Over the same period, the middle class spending accounted for by the Asia Pacific region is expected to grow to 57% from 36%, as China replaces the US as the largest contributor to the global consumer economy, according to the report. Meanwhile in terms of spending among the wealthy elite, the rise of experience-driven consumerism was well documented in Chrystia Freeland’s 2012 book Plutocrats - a portrait of a global super-elite who enjoy far greater wealth than that enjoyed by their (also wealthy) predecessors only a few decades earlier.

name: New Technologies
description: Technology and innovation have been associated with the developed world for centuries. Now, they have become significant elements of emerging markets, thanks in large part to the multinational corporations that are cropping up those regions, according to a report published in 2016 by Cornell University’s SC Johnson College of Business. According to the Global Innovation Index 2017, published by Cornell, INSEAD, and the World Intellectual Property Organization, up-and-coming countries in terms of innovation development include Viet Nam, Indonesia, and the Philippines, while agricultural research & development has reached a high standard in countries including China, India, and Brazil. China, which ranked 22nd on the 2017 index (one notch ahead of Australia), has spawned technology champions including e-commerce firm Alibaba, and newer entrants such as payments firm Ant Financial. New technologies associated with the Fourth Industrial Revolution are disrupting entire industries, and making it easier for emerging multinationals to succeed - by breaking old clichés regarding trade-offs between quality and cost, and by changing the way we think about the interaction between humans and their environment. Historically, the most important way in which technology transformed an economy was by changing the cost and productivity of capital and labour. Now, developments like machine learning might erase the distinction between manual and cognitive labour entirely, while the use of big data and 3D printing may transform supply chains and healthcare. Many emerging markets now have better-than-average rates of internet and mobile phone use, and people there are becoming more digitally literate - at a time when related skills can be applied to cutting-edge fields including nanotechnology, which promises to develop stronger materials, and nanomedicine, which promises new diagnostic tools and treatments. Already, mobile banking and payments are more prevalent among Asian and African consumers than in Europe and the US. Emerging multinationals are poised to take advantage of these trends and technologies to a greater extent than established companies, because they can leap-frog from intermediate to advanced technologies without being weighed down by historical legacies. They may also be more used to interacting with consumers virtually in their home markets, and could be in a better position to gather data from them. However, the potentially negative consequences of increased technology use and automation include greater wealth inequality, mounting political populism, and other ethical issues likely to keep scholars and regulators busy for a long time.

name: New Ways to Finance Mining
description: After the commodity boom in the first decade of the 21st century - a phenomenon triggered by demand from China and other emerging economies often dubbed the “super cycle” - prices collapsed. Mining companies were forced to focus on reducing debt ratios, and generally improving their balance sheets. Meanwhile traditional equity and debt markets relied upon to fund the industry dried up, so companies have had to seek out new means to restoring financial health. One avenue has been to improve productivity through greater automation and digitalization. Another is the adoption of “lean” and “design” thinking approaches, which involve developing a lean startup culture, maintaining budget flexibility, and pursuing multiple opportunities that vary in terms of time horizon, risk, and value but are strategically aligned. Companies can also devise alternative financing solutions. These could include bulking up on both royalty and metal streaming agreements; the first involves providing cash for a project in return for a regular royalty payment (calculated as a percentage of sales) once the project starts producing or making returns, while the second has investors receive minerals purchased at a pre-agreed price generally below market rate. These novel financing methods create the benefit of not burdening a mining company’s balance sheet, while transferring both risk and reward to investors interested in gaining more exposure to the minerals market. Even as mineral prices rise, it is likely that these solutions will nevertheless persist -  because they can be attractive options for relatively high-risk, capital-intensive mining projects that require significant amounts of time to provide a return. For traders, the metal streaming approach can be a particularly attractive option for securing metal supplies. Mining companies may also increasingly seek to develop joint ventures similar to those favoured by the oil and gas sector, which can reduce exposure to individual projects and jurisdictions. To further limit their exposure, mining companies may even develop service agreements, where governments in countries where they operate, or other third-party investors, own and finance a project while the mining company itself only provides services for a pre-agreed fee.

name: New Ways to Make, Do and Buy
description: Virtual and augmented reality have been readily adopted across manufacturing operations to improve efficiency, safety, and connectivity in product development, maintenance and repair. In product design, remote collaborations are possible, and products can be experienced before they are even made, increasing the product quality for consumers. In 2016, the MIT Technology Review reported how employees at a commercial construction company were using augmented reality technology to avoid problems before beginning work on a site. A review of the project undertaken via Microsoft’s HoloLens computer uncovered some inconsistencies in measurement that could still be fixed before implementation, allowing for cost savings on the eventual delivery of the building and a smoother delivery process. While virtual reality (VR) can help businesses pre-visualize store layouts before they are built, augmented reality (AR) can fundamentally change the way retailers deliver their products to consumers. The functionality and quality of products can be assessed from anywhere, anytime. A September 2016 Harvard Business Review article presented several possible use cases: virtually trying on clothing in the comfort of one’s own home; testing out the look and fit of furniture directly in one’s house; or possibly allowing friends in different locations to shop for goods together. The free AR app KabaQ, released in 2017, can render compelling 3D models of food allowing customers to preview their meals using a tablet device before ordering. AR may prove to be the easiest option for retailers seeking to explore this sphere, given that AR can be accessed on any smartphone. VR on the other hand still requires special equipment and may be more suitable for businesses rather than consumers at the moment. Nevertheless, VR shopping will likely take off once the technology matures.

name: New Work Models
description: Unlike full-time, permanent employment, temporary, part-time and independent contracting work is often not adequately accounted for in traditional labour statistics (in both advanced and developing economies). This is a pressing issue, given that recently-published research in the US demonstrated that a significant proportion of net employment growth since 2005 has occurred in the independent or self-employed category - meaning that what was long deemed “non-standard” work is becoming the new norm. Worker classification and related labour regulation need to be updated in order to match the needs of growing segments of the global workforce. By 2027, for example, it is estimated that more than half of the roughly 145 million working Americans will fall within the “independent workers” category - yet, current legal standards in many countries for what constitutes an actual employee rather than a contractual worker are vague. Clearly, a broader range of work models needs to be formally recognized. It is also critical that more related data, research, and information be made available, and that relevant terminology and measurement standards are harmonized within and across countries. The online “gig economy,” for example, which is creating new digital channels for freelance work and generating novel economic activity, is poorly captured in current statistics. Data published by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics in 2017, for example, actually showed a surprising decline in American workers with “alternative work arrangements” compared with 2005, according to a report published in 2018 by the Brookings Institution. Most related studies have been piecemeal, relying on relatively few digital talent platforms to share data, and relatively few countries have completed comprehensive labour market analyses that include these new forms of work. In the contemporary workplace, managers are more likely to oversee diverse, geographically-dispersed teams, to assess worker performance with new types of analytics, and to expand their searches for new recruits to non-traditional environments. Future readiness and productivity will depend on an ability to reform workplaces; by 2022, more than half of all employees in the world will require re- and upskilling, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2018 The Future of Jobs report.

name: Nigeria’s Infrastructure Needs
description: Nigeria’s relatively lacklustre economic development can be attributed at least in part to its infrastructure; the country was ranked 124th out of 140 economies in terms of infrastructure in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index. While Nigeria may have the second-largest economy in Africa (after South Africa), it remains heavily constrained due to its infrastructure situation. In 2016, the Lagos Chamber of Commerce and Industry estimated that the country’s infrastructure deficit amounts to roughly $300 billion - more than 10 times the size of the entire national budget for 2018. In terms of quality of roads, Nigeria ranked 132nd out of 140 economies in the Forum’s Competitiveness Index, while its efficiency of train services ranked 127th (of the roughly 3,500 kilometres of railway inherited from the British after colonization, only a small portion is now operational). The country’s electricity sector is also lagging; it ranked 114th in terms of electrification rate in the Forum’s index. Barring significant basic infrastructure improvement, it is difficult to see how Nigeria’s economy can meaningfully expand. Comparing its infrastructure needs to the extent of Nigeria’s significant government revenue can be a depressing exercise; it can sometimes be difficult to find evidence that funds earmarked for the purpose have actually been spent on infrastructure, which suggests mismanagement. Nigeria’s growth potential is immense, given its large population, abundant resources, and entrepreneurial spirit. In order to address the infrastructure deficit, Nigeria’s government has initiated policies including power sector reforms and the Petroleum Industry Bill (passed in parliament in 2017, to jumpstart growth in the sector by increasing transparency). The electricity sector is being privatized, and the government has implemented a bid to meet 30% of the country’s energy needs with renewables by the year 2030. The government has also sought to collaborate with international institutions and foreign governments in order to better address its infrastructure needs. For example, a number of infrastructure development projects have pushed ahead in collaboration with Chinese companies; China Civil Engineering Construction Company is involved in projects in the country including the Lagos airport expansion, road building, urban light-rail construction, and contract worth a reported $11 billion to build a railway connecting Lagos to Calabar, according to a report published in 2018 by the United States Institute for Peace.

name: Nigeria’s Talent Pool
description: Nigeria’s nearly 200 million inhabitants, almost one-sixth of Africa’s total population, are largely under the age of 40. The country’s youthful demographics could help propel economic diversification and growth. However, limited growth and recession, unstable oil revenue, trade deficits, poorly-funded schools, inadequate infrastructure, and poor health mean that Nigeria’s large population of unemployed youth may pose its most serious internal security threat. In 2018, Nigeria replaced India as the country with the largest number of people living in extreme poverty, according to World Poverty Clock data. As of May 2018, about 87 million people in Nigeria were living in extreme poverty, and six people in the country were being reduced to extreme poverty every minute, according to the data. In the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index, Nigeria was ranked 118th out of 140 countries in terms of healthy life expectancy, and 135th in terms of the skillset of its school graduates. Still, despite the poor state of the economy, and the relative lack of government support, Nigerian entrepreneurs have managed to thrive in a number of areas; not least in the film business, as evidenced by the global popularity of Nigeria’s burgeoning “Nollywood” movie industry (which makes up the bulk of an arts sector that accounted for 2.3% of the country’s GDP in 2016, according to a report published by PwC). A starting point for better developing Nigeria’s human capital would be increasing the budget for education to at least the 26% of the national budget recommended by United Nations (education is currently allocated about 7% of the 2018 national budget). Special attention needs to be devoted to the development of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) skills, at every level of the education system (from nursery to tertiary). In order to ensure the effective utilization of the skills, there should be regular collaboration among schools, the private sector, and the government. In the absence of such cooperation and focused leadership, however, Nigeria’s abundant but neglected human capital might actually become a serious liability that threatens the country’s unity. While investment in Nigeria’s “hard” infrastructure could significantly increase economic productivity and engender sustainable growth, that will only become possible if the country also prioritizes investing in its greatest asset: the knowledge and skills of its people.

name: Non-State Actors
description: Environmental decision-making and leadership is expanding beyond national governments and international organizations. While national governments set the policy context for efforts like the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, and the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change, it will largely fall to businesses and state and local leaders to drive related changes. The UN Global Compact’s 2016 Status Report noted that a broad and geographically diverse base of investor and corporate support has emerged for private-sector initiatives that are focused on climate issues and sustainable development. The Alliance of CEO Climate Leaders, for example, is addressing carbon pricing, renewable energy, green finance, and infrastructure. Meanwhile the European Union’s Covenant of Mayors and Compact of Mayors joined forces to mitigate the impacts of climate change in 2016; as of late 2018 the combined organization had received commitments from more than 9,000 cities representing about 10% of the global population. In addition, in 2018, the state of California (which boasts the world’s fifth-biggest economy) hosted a Global Climate Action Summit, bringing together non-state actors to showcase examples of innovative climate action. The UN’s Non-state Actor Zone for Climate Action website had registered more than 19,000 “actions” as of late 2018, from more than 2,400 companies, about 9,500 cities, and more than 350 investors. New platforms will be needed to facilitate and boost cooperation among stakeholders, enable a broader, systemic view of connected challenges, and get a larger and more diverse set of actors involved. The Tropical Forest Alliance 2020 provides a promising example; it advances new approaches to help reduce deforestation within global commodity supply chains. The alliance spawned the Africa Palm Oil Initiative in 2015, which brings together companies, governments, local communities, indigenous groups, and civil society groups in nine African countries in order to reduce deforestation and ensure sustainable palm oil production. Meanwhile the 2030 Water Resources Group has established partnerships involving more than 300 public sector, private sector, and civil society organizations. The group is helping to close the gap between water supply and demand, by changing the ways that water resources are managed in water-stressed developing countries like Bangladesh, India, Kenya, Mexico, and Viet Nam.

name: Nutrition and Health
description: There has been a growing focus among businesses and governments on quality rather than quantity when it comes to agriculture and food systems. This is at least in part a response to rising rates of obesity (even as hunger persists in many parts of the world). More than 672 million adults in the world, or one in eight, are now obese, according to the 2018 edition of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization’s report the State of Food Insecurity and Nutrition in the World. While the problem is most significant in North America, according to the report, it is worrying that Africa and Asia are also experiencing an upward trend. Meanwhile the number of undernourished people in the world is also increasing, to 821 million by 2017, according the report; undernourishment, coupled with severe food insecurity, appears to be increasing in nearly all subregions of Africa as well as in South America. Poverty remains the main underlying cause of malnutrition. In many countries, nutrient-rich foods are significantly more expensive than unhealthy foods, and there is a lack of understanding about the components of a healthy diet. In developing countries, this can trigger “nutrition transition,” where populations simultaneously face rising obesity levels and undernutrition. A broad shift towards western-style diets high in calories, protein, fats, sugars and ultra-processed foods has resulted in unbalanced, unhealthy diets and an increased incidence of micronutrient deficiencies; a report published by the Global Panel on Agriculture and Food Systems for Nutrition in 2015 noted that this affected more than 2 billion people worldwide. The report warned that if current trends continued, the number of overweight and obese people would reach 3.28 billion by 2030, or about one third of the projected total world population for that year. Extensive research on the potential health effects associated with being overweight or obese point to higher risks of cancer, cardiovascular disease, osteoarthritis, and diabetes. A related study published in Diabetes Research and Clinical Practice in 2011 found that the number of adults with diabetes in Nigeria would likely double between the years 2011 and 2030, to 6.1 million. There is also a financial cost to consider - a 2014 report published by the McKinsey Global Institute estimated the global economic costs of overweight and obesity to be roughly $2 trillion per year, or equivalent to about 2.8% of annual global GDP.

name: Oil and Gas Innovation
description: Technology development in the energy sector is constantly evolving, often with profound implications for markets. Technological innovation can increase the efficiency of oil use, reduce the environmental impact of the oil and gas industry, and better enable the use of new alternative energy sources. It can also aid in the exploration and discovery of new sources of oil and gas, and make the exploitation of these resources more profitable. This can work in both competing and complementary ways that complicate market forecasts. For example, technological innovation has played a critical role in unleashing unconventional new sources of oil and gas supply in the US, which has reshaped global energy markets. At the same time, technology has enabled significant cost reductions in generating wind and solar energy - which, coupled with supportive public policies, have propelled more rapid deployment of renewables. Ultimately, technology is helping spur more competition among potential energy sources.
