description: Finding private sources of financing to meet the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, including the goal of developing reliable and sustainable infrastructure, has been a priority at least since 2015 - when the UN released its Addis Ababa Action Agenda emphasizing the importance of blending public with private capital to fund development. Private financing has steadily flowed into public infrastructure projects; according to the World Bank, in developing economies alone there was nearly $1.8 trillion in private sector investment made in infrastructure between 1990 and the first half of 2018. However, after experiencing high-profile failures, many countries that had once enthusiastically embraced the public-private financing model dismantled or seriously reconsidered their programs. In Southern Europe, for example, governments that drew private co-financing for infrastructure over the past decade later got stuck with the bill when the infrastructure failed to generate sufficient revenue, according to a podcast published in 2018 by Wharton finance professor Joao Gomes. The scrutiny placed on private sector involvement in financing and managing public infrastructure as a result of such failures has mirrored a rising suspicion of globalization and multinational corporations more generally. Many scandals have also illustrated the dangers of poor oversight and regulation of public-private partnership schemes. In 2018, the United Kingdom did away with public-private partnerships, for example, following the collapse of construction firm Carillion - which resulted in project delays and hundreds of millions of pounds in costs for taxpayers. Similar issues are causing a re-evaluation of programs even in countries where the model had been deemed successful, including Australia and Canada, and are forcing countries more generally to reconsider public-private partnerships as a means to alleviate pressure on stretched public finances. Many governments, traditionally tasked with financing infrastructure, are dealing with growing liabilities ranging from high social-security and healthcare-related costs in countries with ageing populations, to costs related to providing education and jobs in countries with young, rapidly growing populations. As a result, private financing will almost certainly be required in order to close yawning infrastructure development gaps without also sacrificing crucial government programs. Winning greater public buy-in to the concept of public-private partnership programs will therefore be crucial.

name: Private Legal and Regulatory Systems
description: Private organizations have long influenced the legal and regulatory environment; private security forces and prisons have been part of the enforcement landscape in the US for decades, for example. The role of private organizations is growing, and will continue to grow, as governments struggle to keep pace with technology innovation, global business models, and increasingly diverse populations. Private participation in regulation can occur when an internet search engine is required to adjudicate claims under Europe’s “right to be forgotten,” for example. In some cases, government rules incorporate standards developed by organizations that have private businesses as members, such as the US-based technology group IEEE. Large corporations have long set the rules governing their own obligations to consumers and employees; the volume of this so-called private regulation has skyrocketed. Private regulation is also growing within organizations, as private, global supply chain contracts often include requirements for suppliers, particularly those in parts of the world where government regulation is lacking, to monitor and eliminate child labour and improve workplace safety. Global businesses want clear, reliable regulatory frameworks, in order to better plan. Some of this desire stems from strategic corporate efforts to pre-empt or shape government regulation, and some is simply a response to a failure of governments to act. Private sector participation is essential to help address the lack of access to justice now confronting people and businesses in both rich and poor countries alike. In both settings, governments are increasingly unable or unwilling to fund access to legal assistance. This is prompting efforts to build access through community paralegals, alternative dispute resolution, and legal technology. However, this growing role for the private sector brings substantial related challenges; abuses perpetrated within private prisons have gained increased visibility in recent years, for example, while in the developing world the number of people employed in private security forces is now greater than those in public police forces. Our increased reliance on private sector regulators is largely taking place without thoughtful oversight by politically accountable officials. Regulated entities are often designing the terms on which they will choose to protect the environment, or privacy - with only the free market or company employees imposing constraints. A major challenge for the foreseeable future will be reconciling our need to turn to the private sector for help, with the need to ensure that private sector regulators are responsive and accountable to the public.

name: Production Regulation and Governance
description: In the US, the Food and Drug Administration has reviewed hundreds of 3D printed medical devices, including knee replacements and implants, and has set up 3D printing facilities on its own campus in a bid to better understand the implications of this technology. Governments everywhere have to change their approach to regulation, in order to better account for the quickening pace of innovation. They are also responsible for ensuring that the Fourth Industrial Revolution, a period of dramatic change that is being propelled by the fusion of technologies changing the ways that we interact and create value, produces fair and sustainable outcomes for as many people as possible. As noted in Professor Klaus Schwab’s 2016 book The Fourth Industrial Revolution, government officials, together with business leaders, must carefully weigh benefits and risks of new technology developments - particularly those that could ultimately escape our control, such as artificial intelligence. Ideally, regulation should provide us with resilience as we deal with uncertainty, and should align with the public interest in terms of security, privacy, and intellectual property rights - also while fostering the development of well-functioning and accessible digital infrastructure. Small and medium-sized enterprises in particular should receive the support they need to adopt new technologies; they are a significant source of employment, and often have a relatively greater potential to adopt disruptive technologies than their more-established peers. Technologies brought about by earlier industrial revolutions and still in widespread use, such as the combustion engine, need to be regulated with clear foresight. Potential technological alternatives to these legacy inventions, such as electric vehicles, need to be taken into account by regulators as they as pursue greater sustainability. Ultimately, effective oversight and enforcement is also necessary, in order to protect consumers. And while oversight is necessary, it should not blunt the investment necessary to enable technological progress and to foster competition.

name: Production Risks and Circularity
description: Many companies have taken note that a traditional linear economy, where raw materials are perennially required to make products that are then disposed of, increases their exposure to resource price volatility and supply disruption. A high degree of resource price volatility can dampen economic growth, by increasing uncertainty and discouraging businesses from investing; a report published by the McKinsey Global Institute has noted that the decade between 2001 and 2011 saw higher price volatility for metals and agricultural output than in any single decade during the previous century. Risks inherent in a linear economy are not only related to raw materials - they also stem from long, elaborately structured global supply chains. For example, many parts of the world possess few natural, non-renewable resources of their own, and so rely heavily on imports. In 2015, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources reported that the European Union’s imports of materials and natural resources were six times greater than its related exports; the US Energy Information Administration reported that same year that Japan imported nearly all of its petroleum and and natural gas.. Shifting the way in which we use resources, through the application of so-called circular principles (that is, reusing materials for the production of goods), can address both resource challenges, and environmental issues - including land degradation, the loss of biodiversity, ocean pollution, and climate change. While linear industrial methods generate significant amounts of waste, and have contributed to environmental and health hazards, the manufacturing and production processes in a circular economy can limit the creation of waste. Manufacturing methods such as 3D printing, for example, can reduce much of the waste in the production process, and in situations where by-products are unavoidable, a focus can be placed on exploring possible useful applications for waste. One example: the spent grains from a brewery could be sold to fish farmers, and the livestock sector more generally, to be used as a feed supplement. More broadly, the circular economy, where waste is designed out of the system intentionally, can be applied across the entire supply chains, from product design to production.

name: Productivity
description: Chile is one of only two Latin American countries that have achieved full Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) membership, and it boasts the region’s highest GDP per capita: $13,576. However, economic growth has slowed since 2013, and reduced productivity over the past 15 years has become a concern. In the 1990s, the country’s so-called total factor productivity, a measure of efficiency, grew 2.3% annually; but between 2000 and 2015 it only grew 0.1% annually, according to the Chilean National Commission on Productivity’s 2016 annual report. This decline has limited the country’s potential to improve living standards as quickly as it has in the past, and reflects the challenges of the so-called middle-income trap, a common affliction where economies that have attained increased income levels struggle to spur further growth and innovation. In addition, there are development bottlenecks that are specific to Chile. Nevertheless, Chile remains the most competitive country in Latin America and the Caribbean, ranking 33rd out of 137 economies in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report for 2017-2018. Its strengths include a solid macroeconomic environment (36th), its financial market development (17th) and its institutions (35th). However, ratings for the sophistication of the country’s business environment and innovation capacity remain relatively low. The biggest challenges identified in the report related to doing business in the country include a limited availability of qualified human capital (particularly outside of big cities), uncertainty related to new labour regulations, a lack of land-use planning and less-than-efficient government bureaucracies. Chile has sought to better integrate into the global economy through international agreements. The country is a world leader in mining; it is number one in copper mining, and accounts for nearly one third of global output. This sector has been fundamental to the country’s economic development, and has regularly represented more than half of its exports (65% in 1962, for example, and 55% in 2012, according to the Observatory of Economic Complexity). However, Chile requires structural reforms that will support the development of a more productive, diversified, and knowledge-based economy. A study published in 2016, A Common Vision and Four Proposals to Boost Productive Development in Chile, showed the country’s capacity to develop new export products consistently decreasing since the 1990s. The study also noted that Chile’s traditional economic activities like forestry and salmon fishing have meanwhile drawn increasing pressure from environmentalists and created social conflict. Chile’s primary development challenge is to boost productivity growth and achieve a level that is on par with other OECD countries. According to the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB)’s 2014-2018 country strategy for Chile, this will require better fostering innovation, globalizing domestic firms, taking better advantage of sources of power and water, and reducing inequality.

name: Productivity and Competitiveness
description: In 2017, International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that living standards around the world could be lowered if the rate of global productivity did not pick up. The following year, the IMF noted in its annual World Economic Outlook survey that a proliferation of new trade barriers only risked a further reduction in productivity, by slowing the spread of new technologies. Productivity levels are a key reason why different countries enjoy different degrees of prosperity; the world’s most competitive economies, such as the US and Germany, are three times more productive than emerging economies like Mexico or South Africa, for example, and seven times more productive than large developing countries like Nigeria, according to data published by the Conference Board. This at least partly explains why US GDP per capita is over $60,000, and Germany’s is over $50,000 - while Mexico’s remains at roughly $20,000, and Nigeria’s is about $6,000. While a decoupling between a country’s GDP growth and the benefits enjoyed by the workers in that country has occurred over the past few decades, when productivity levels reach a certain depth there is simply not enough income to properly distribute. As former US president Barack Obama put it, without a faster-growing economy, it is impossible to generate the wage gains people want - regardless of how wealth is divided. Global productivity has actually been decelerating since the early 2000’s. Between 1985 and 2000, productivity as measured by GDP per hour worked rose within Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries by nearly 41%; it then rose by just 19% between 2001 and 2016, according to OECD data. Following the global financial crisis, many countries actually experienced productivity declines, which in turn affected wages. According to the IMF, in economies where unemployment rates were below their historic averages before the so-called Great Recession that followed the financial crisis, slow productivity growth after the Great Recession accounted for nearly two-thirds of a slowdown in nominal wage growth that occurred at the same time. In order to secure prosperity, governments need to consider new ways to monitor the evolution of their productivity, which is complex and difficult to measure directly. The advent of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and associated technology developments have altered traditional aspects of productivity and their relative importance to economic development, only making accurate measurement even more difficult.

name: Productivity in Latin America
description: Between 1960 and 2017, countries in Latin America and the Caribbean invested the average equivalent of about 12% of their GDP into things like factories and machinery, only slightly behind the 13% of GDP spent on average in the rest of the world, according to a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank in 2018. However, Latin America’s total factor productivity, a measure of efficiency, actually declined by 0.11% during that same period (as it rose by 0.25% for the rest of the world), according to the report - pointing to the primary reason behind the region’s mediocre economic performance. Others include: financial market flaws, uneven taxation, poorly-enforced labour market regulations, inadequate or insufficient infrastructure, and other barriers to competition. Persistent skills gaps, gender inequality, and a relative lack of innovation have also played a role. According to the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Report, the region's economic recovery that started in 2017 remains fragile. According to the Forum’s report, specific risks for Latin America include growing trade protectionism on the part of the US, and the potential for a spillover of Venezuela's humanitarian and economic crisis. The region generally lags in terms of the adoption of information and communications technology, according to the report, with the exception of Uruguay (which topped countries including Switzerland and Taiwan

name: Promise of Precision Medicine
description: Through the harnessing and analysing of genetic data, precision medicine promises to improve health outcomes and decrease costs. Precision medicine, also referred to as personalized medicine, could for example cut down on unnecessary costs tied to unnecessary and expensive diagnostic procedures. According to a report published in 2016 by healthcare software company Orion Health, 30% of our health is determined by our genome (all the genetic material in a cell), and the cost of sequencing a genome was expected to fall from $1,000 per person to $10 per person by 2020. Yet, the infrastructure required for using genomic sequencing to genuinely benefit patients remains embryonic. Issues yet to be adequately addressed include a lack of widespread availability of the necessary sequencing technology and attendant storage, of expertise required to use this new technology at the patient level, of the sufficient development of related economic models, and of evidence-based research that supports widespread adoption. There are serious ethical issues presented by the growing prevalence of precision medicine. The genomic and other biological data in a person’s medical record for the purposes of treatment could be misused, for example, and expose patients to privacy violations or worse. In addition, the genomic information in someone’s medical profile could also, theoretically, be used to subject that person to discrimination or make it difficult or impossible for him or her to obtain certain types of insurance. The so-called secondary use of a patient’s data for research purposes also raises the potential for privacy violations, without adequate safeguarding. Another significant potential ethical issue to consider is the impact of granting someone advance knowledge that they have an untreatable condition through the use of precision medicine - and thereby potentially hindering the person’s quality of life. Policy-makers and business leaders need to work together to develop responsible rules for the use of precision medicine, which is poised to become far more prevalent. Governments are investing significant amounts in related research and development; in China, for example, the government made precision medicine part of its five-year plan for 2016-2020, which should involve related investments worth more than $9 billion.

name: Property Rights in Viet Nam
description: The rights of ownership in Viet Nam, particularly those related to land, are not particularly secure. Although land users are technically given full rights, ultimately the government decides on land use and related financial matters. The relatively weak protection of property rights in the country is the source of land disputes that are occurring with greater frequency. According to a report published by the US Embassy in Viet Nam in 2017, the arrest and detention of people protesting land seizures had been a serious problem the previous year, and complaints and clashes related to the government confiscation of land to make way for infrastructure projects were prevalent. A survey conducted by the World Bank in 2014 found that land disputes accounted for as much as 80% of all complaints received every year by government agencies. Administrative distribution and conversion is a primary way for state-owned companies and well-connected private businesses to amass land at below-market prices; the lack of transparency when it comes to land acquisition and land use policies has therefore not only led to complaints, but also corruption. This has increased wealth inequality, and hindered sustainable development. Land holding restrictions have meanwhile contributed to the fragmentation of agricultural production, hampering productivity. Viet Nam had a relatively meagre 0.075 hectares of arable land per person as of 2015, compared with 0.211 hectares in Myanmar, and 0.229 in Thailand, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Bank. In order to try to overcome land fragmentation and expand production, many localities in the country have been concentrating land through focused land use policies, which have had some success in reducing transaction costs, and in improving both productivity and efficiency. However, in order to increase the land area available for large-scale commodity production, it is necessary to accelerate the accumulation of suitable agricultural land. In addition, in most localities, the land rental market has not sufficiently developed due to the relatively small size of available plots, and to high transaction costs.

name: Public Awareness and Education
description: Public awareness of the extent and nature of corruption, and of corruption’s impact, is crucial for generating the necessary political will to address the problem. Often, however, when it comes to corruption, the information environment is crowded and conflictual. The challenge is therefore to not merely communicate reliable information to the public, but to foster discernment and trust. A 2010 publication from the World Bank and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, Building Public Support for Anti-Corruption Efforts: Why Anti-Corruption Agencies Need to Communicate and How, contains many still-relevant suggestions for how public anti-corruption agencies can work productively with independent media. However, the importance of social media platforms has increased since the publication appeared, and they have opened up new opportunities to communicate directly with people in order to improve their understanding of corruption. Often, ordinary citizens are remarkably good at distinguishing among news and information sources based on credibility. A 2016 paper published in the Journal of Politics, for example, found that the vast majority of Brazilians update their beliefs about corruption cautiously, and are able to evaluate information that comes from political parties differently than they evaluate more objective information that comes from a federal audit agency. Numerous studies have demonstrated the benefits of educating the public about the extent of corruption. Citizens in many countries have kicked corrupt incumbents out of positions of power in elections that follow well-publicized corruption scandals. Voters in Italy did so in response to the mani pulite (“clean hands”) scandal in the 1990s, while voters in the UK did so in reaction to the parliamentary expenses scandal that erupted in that country in 2009. In Brazil, this dynamic has been shown to be stronger in municipalities that have a radio station capable of facilitating the dissemination of information about what, exactly, the local mayor has done, for example. Countries are also incorporating discussions about corruption and integrity into school curricula. As of 2017, 34 countries had submitted reports on these activities to the United Nations’ Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on the Prevention of Corruption. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime has meanwhile developed open-source educational materials on anti-corruption, ethics, and integrity; its Model Academic Course on the UN Convention Against Corruption is available in several languages, and is designed to be adapted to local contexts by university lecturers.

name: Public Governance in Viet Nam
description: Corruption constrains healthy economic activity, and kills dynamism. However, Viet Nam’s institutional fragmentation - the diffusion of authority, decision-making and supervision among central and regional government officials - has rendered anti-corruption efforts in the country largely ineffective. One example of this fragmentation: virtually all of the provinces along Viet Nam’s coast have sought to push plans forward to build sea ports, and many localities want to build new airports, regardless of the relative proximity of these planned projects or their expected overall benefit to national economic development. According to Transparency International’s Corruption Perceptions Index for 2017, where a score of 100 means very clean and zero is equal to deep-rooted, systemic corruption, Viet Nam scored a 35 - a slight improvement from its score of 33 in the previous year. A report published in 2017 by Transparency International and the non-profit organization Towards Transparency cited positive signs for the country including recent anti-corruption efforts made by the government; in 2016, for example, the government passed the Law on Access to Information, which guarantees equal access to information from state agencies. Yet, the report also cited survey results showing that 58% of respondents felt that corruption levels had increased during the past year, while more than half believed the police are highly corrupt, nearly half believed tax officials are highly corrupt, and 32% believed government officials are highly corrupt. For the ruling Communist Party, implementing institutional reforms is difficult, as they can affect the interests of both incumbent leaders and retired elites. The party must strike the right balance between its own authority, and the country’s economic performance, in order to maintain its legitimacy. Meanwhile public pressure is needed in order to push difficult institutional reforms forward, and increase both transparency and accountability. The news media in Viet Nam is increasingly using online social networks to gather information and push democratization in the country forward - potentially changing the government from one that commands, to one that enables.

name: Public Perception
description: Improving the public's understanding of the industry continues to be a challenge for the chemical and materials sector. More favourable public perception is necessary if the industry is going to be able to successfully advance new technologies and products. Improved perception could help drive early development and technologies to commercialization, and nurture the systems needed to better foster innovation. Negative perception meanwhile threatens to dramatically delay or interrupt development, while potentially ill-informed regulation can create significant business risk that can quickly morph into broader economic and social risk. Consumers are demanding greater amounts of information about the manufacturing processes behind the products they buy, which has prompted a need for the sector to describe its processes using clearer and more accessible language. People also expect at least a certain degree of social and environmental responsibility, and both intentional and accidental transgressions by companies are now subject to greater scrutiny. The power of social media is at anyone’s fingertips, and mass media covering the industry can potentially be ill-informed. Published stories have in the past contributed to a slanted view of the sector and of its potential global benefit. The industry in general needs to make greater efforts to improve public communication about its contributions to sustainability, and about its historic contributions to many peoples' relatively high standards of living. Otherwise, it risks a pervasive lack of interest from young people headed towards careers in science and technology, a lack of skilled employees needed to move the sector forward, and most importantly, a lack of public trust and partnerships needed to help solve some of the world’s greatest challenges.

name: Public Sector Performance
description: Bolivia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the efficiency of the legal framework in settling disputes, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 17.70, resulting in a rank of 138th out of 140 countries; in terms of the burden of government regulation where it has a progress score of 18.30 that results in a rank of 137th out of 140 countries; and in terms of the "future orientation" of the government related to technological, economic, social, and demographic change where it has a progress score of 20.90 that results in a rank of 134th out of 140 countries. One indicator reflects a better performance: the government's use of the internet to provide information to the public (referred to as "e-participation" in the competitiveness index), where it has a progress score of 57.90 that results in a rank of 93rd out of 138 countries.

name: Public Trust
description: The 2008 global financial crisis led to a significant loss of public trust in banks. Causes of the crisis included poorly designed incentive systems at these financial firms, inadequate or unenforced fiduciary standards, lax corporate governance, and weak internal controls - in addition to unethical and illegal activity. A seemingly endless flow of legal probes and large fines in the wake of the crisis has only reinforced negative public sentiment. This has been costly for both the reputations of banks, and for society in general; now, the average household may be reluctant to participate in the financial system, absent additional government guarantees. The 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer, based on an online survey conducted in 28 countries in late 2017, showed that financial services ranked among the least trusted industry sectors (alongside automotive and consumer packaged goods), with 54% of respondents expressing trust in the sector. The figure showed no improvement from the prior year’s barometer, which also reflected a 54% trust level in financial services. By way of comparison, 75% of respondents expressed trust in the technology industry, according to the barometer.  Significant pressure has been placed on governments post-crisis to more strictly regulate financial entities, in the hope of avoiding a repeat. The risk here is that we spawn a regressive, over-regulated financial system; it is important that governments work together with financial firms to find the right way forward. A lingering lack of trust in banks can negatively affect an economy’s long-term development, and there have been efforts to simply shift financial systems away from an over-reliance on banks. For example, the European Union’s Capital Markets Union action plan, launched in 2015, aims to improve risk-sharing by diversifying financing sources beyond the banking system. According to a report published by the consultancy PwC in 2014, trust in banks was at an all-time low. As a result, the report projected that by 2020, retail banks would begin organizing themselves around customers, rather than products, that they would evolve their customer experience to become more female-friendly, and that they would view social media (rather than traditional media) as the primary means for connecting with customers and providing information about offerings. Paramount for rebuilding trust, according to the report, will be a greater focus among retail banks on cyber security.

name: Public-Private Collaboration
description: Public sector funders of development projects, and private sector investors, have traditionally operated in parallel - as each tries to achieve their own, distinct objectives. Unfortunately, in relatively complex, emerging and frontier markets, neither public capital aimed at development, nor private capital driven by returns, has been able to efficiently realize respective objectives. This has limited economic growth, and led to missed investment opportunities. While there is a projected $94 trillion in global infrastructure investment need between 2007 and 2040, we are currently only on track to make $79 trillion in necessary investment, according to the Global Infrastructure Hub, an organization started by the G20. Globally, according to the organization, infrastructure funding gaps range from about $526 billion in India, to $1.2 trillion in Brazil, and $3.8 trillion in the US. On a proportional basis, which takes into account a region’s specific economic characteristics, areas faced with the most acute funding gaps are developing countries like Guinea, Cote D’Ivoire, and Ghana, according to a report published in 2018 by the Global Infrastructure Hub and Oxford Economics. Guinea, for example, has a projected need for investment that is more than 80% greater than what is being spent under current trends, according to the report. Blended Finance is an increasingly prevalent mechanism used to address such shortfalls; it uses multi-stakeholder collaboration to better align the interests of public and private investors, and ensure the credibility, reputation, and positive impact of development projects in emerging and frontier markets. While public institutions can leverage their connections to assume specific risks, private capital providers generally bring with them structuring expertise and an ability to fast track the delivery of projects with significant development impact.

name: Public-Private Cooperation for the Bioeconomy
description: The cost of unchecked biodiversity loss on ecosystem services (like climate control and pollination) may reach $14 trillion annually by 2050, an amount equal to nearly one-fifth of current global GDP, according to some estimates. The strong economic case for conserving biodiversity is spurring related investment in research and development, subsidies for more sustainable practices, and the setting of aspirational targets. Many countries, even those with legacies of unsustainable fossil fuel use, can reduce related risk by making public procurement commitments to sustainable, bio-based products, and by strengthening related intellectual property rights enforcement. Governments are often reluctant to apply strict regulations, and instead prefer voluntary certification schemes - essentially ceding leadership to the private sector. Yet, while private landowners have been incentivized to practice more sustainable cultivation, their ability to focus on locally-relevant species could be enhanced by greater support from local authorities (and by greater investment in technical capacity). Government-established markets like biodiversity banks, for example, enable landowners to earn conservation credits for enhancing ecological value - which can ultimately be sold to land developers. However, such trade-off schemes allow for “less bad” outcomes that still result in net biodiversity losses. Several countries (and companies) are now moving towards requirements for “Biodiversity Net Gain,” or ensuring that biodiversity health improves after development. The United Kingdom, for example, opted in 2019 to make Biodiversity Net Gain mandatory. Businesses and business coalitions (such as those mobilized by We Mean Business, a non-profit group that aims for a zero-carbon economy) have meanwhile encouraged governments to set climate change-related targets. A society-wide push for change, co-led by private organizations and individuals, can enable companies to focus on adapting to a new climate reality even as they seek to boost profits and operational efficiency. Currently, there is no single global target for biodiversity conservation. However, there are 20 Aichi Biodiversity Targets, established in 2010 under the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity, which encourage individual governments to hit goals by 2020 - including the creation of biodiversity action plans, and ensuring adequate conservation areas. According to a report published by the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services in 2019, “good” progress had been made on just four of the 20 targets, however. Better public-private co-operation is therefore essential to ensure a sustainable bioeconomy.

name: Pushing Ahead in the 4IR
description: Thanks to significant investments in technology, and to innovation-enabling policies, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) has become a leading technology hub in the Middle East and North Africa region - and is relatively well-positioned to embrace the opportunities of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Non-oil revenue for the UAE government climbed to nearly 21% of the total by 2018, from 13% in 2008, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, and technology and innovation are critical for the country as it seeks to further shift away from oil dependence. The country’s tech sector could be a powerful engine of growth that expands employment opportunities, which is particularly important in light of an expanding youth demographic, and significant youth unemployment throughout the region. The World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index ranked the UAE 33rd out of 140 economies in terms of its “innovation ecosystem,” and 12th in terms of the growth of innovative companies - ahead of both Japan and Ireland. The UAE has unveiled a national strategy for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, in order to help it better take advantage of related opportunities; it has appointed the world’s first government minister for artificial intelligence, and aims to have half of all government transactions conducted using blockchain by 2021. The UAE boasts an active startup scene that accounts for about one third of the region’s total startup investment. Government-funded incubators and accelerators, regulatory sandboxes, and technology parks and tax free zones are attracting foreign talent and helping to nurture entrepreneurship. The UAE has also attracted academics from abroad to bolster local development; the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, for example, has consulted on the development of Masdar City in Abu Dhabi, which is designed to run on renewable energy sources and to serve as a hub for green technology companies. While the UAE has become an attractive destination for many investors and entrepreneurs, it is not without challenges. A number of regulatory barriers exist, such as a ban on free, voice over internet protocol (VoIP) services like Skype, which can make opening and running a startup difficult. In addition, the Middle East region suffers from a relatively high rate of cyberattacks, according to Kaspersky Lab’s Cyberthreat Real-Time Map (the UAE is the 17th-most attacked country in the world, according to the map), prompting a need for a greater focus on security.

name: Quality Basic Education
description: Around the world, educational provision remains uneven. Most countries are able to provide adequate primary education, but many struggle with increasing its quality. In addition, many places struggle to provide appropriate secondary (high school or its equivalent) education. The quality and breadth of educational provision are particularly concerning in sub-Saharan Africa, and deeply uneven in the Middle East, North Africa, and in parts of Southeast Asia, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2017 Global Human Capital Report. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) found in a 2016 report that more than 263 million children and young people between the ages of six and 17 are not attending school worldwide. Meanwhile inequality in education is increasing, particularly among the poorest and most disadvantaged. While nearly two-thirds of all countries have attained gender parity in primary education, girls are still less likely than boys to start secondary education. Basic education should provide a broad foundation for future learning and re-skilling. Unequal access to education leads to unequal access to opportunity and can permanently hinder students’ potential to learn new skills in the future. As well as providing access to education, concerted efforts will be needed to improve the quality of basic education worldwide. This can be addressed in part by introducing clear, recognized global standards that benchmark measurable learning outcomes. The cost of providing basic education is a persistent barrier that contributes to unequal provision. According to UNESCO’s final review of the United Nations Millennium Development Goals in 2015, an additional $22 billion in funding is needed - every year - in order to meet basic education targets for 2030. This gap demonstrates that there is an acute need for new financing models, particularly in developing countries. Technological innovation could be one possible way to address the issue.

name: Quality of Russian Institutions
description: As the Russian Federation seeks to become an advanced, industrialized economy, it has an opportunity to drive growth through the improvement of its institutions. Despite increased government spending, the quality of the country’s health, education and other infrastructure has stagnated. The ways in which the government addresses, or fails to address, barriers to growth posed by red tape will profoundly impact the Russian Federation’s economic development. Leadership style plays a significant role in both the public sector (at both federal and regional levels), and in the country’s private sector. How its leaders reconcile their short- and long-term priorities will affect the country’s future direction. The Russian Federation ranked 83rd out of 137 economies in terms of its institutions, according to the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018; the country ranked 116th specifically in terms of property rights, according to the index, and corruption was cited as the most problematic factor for doing business there. Inefficient or ambiguous bureaucratic processes can increase transaction costs at every stage of commercial development, from opening a business to fulfilling customs procedures. Uncertainty about the enforcement of regulations and the protection of property rights has an equally paralysing effect. Due to the country’s institutional unpredictability, much of the capital that flows into the economy via energy revenue is not retained and put to productive use. Capital flight, or the flow of money out of the country due to political or economic anxieties, has been a continuous problem. However, in the World Bank’s annual ratings for doing business, Russia improved to 35th place in 2017 from 40th in 2016, as it adopted three key business reforms intended to improve its investment climate and create jobs. Access to credit was strengthened by the adoption of a law meant to improve the collateral registry system, while cross-border trade was facilitated by the opening of a new deepwater port on the coast of the Gulf of Finland, as an alternative to the Port of St. Petersburg, and registering property was potentially made easier by decreasing the time required to apply for title transfers. Further development of the country’s institutions represents a significant economic opportunity. Local governments within the Russian Federation are generally more supportive of private business than federal institutions. Competition among the regions for private investment may further increase that divergence in the future, particularly if federal government funding for the regions declines.

name: Race and Inequality in America
description: The US ranked first in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index for 2018, thanks largely to its entrepreneurial culture. But the Forum’s full competitiveness report published that year told a more nuanced story. According to the report, the percentage of all income going to the richest 1% of people in the US more than doubled in the past few decades (to about 20%), while the share going to the middle class fell. Growing wealth inequality threatens to aggravate a long-standing racial divide; according to the Institute for Policy Studies, the median black family in America saw their wealth decrease by more than half between 1983 and 2016, while the wealth for median white households increased by 33% over the same period; if the recent trajectory continues, by 2050 the median white family in the US will have $174,000 in wealth, compared with $600 for the median black family (and $8,600 for the median Latino family). Inequality can also mean unequal access to health care; the US placed behind most advanced economies on the Health pillar of the Forum’s index, and in terms of healthy life expectancy the country ranked behind Sri Lanka and China.       While America’s institutional framework remains strong, according to the Forum’s competitiveness report, a weakening social fabric and a deteriorating security situation have taken their toll. The country has a homicide rate five times the average for advanced economies, according to the report. Meanwhile lingering race-based division threatens to limit the benefits of America's economic progress, according to a paper published in 2018 by the Hamilton Project - which illustrates the ways that black populations tend to remain not only in regions that suffer from relatively low income levels, but also statistically lower odds of upward economic mobility. Race has also played a role in efforts to undermine democracy in the country. Russia’s Internet Research Agency has launched an ongoing attack on the US by spreading online propaganda that is targeted to specific racial and ethnic groups, and is intended to misinform and polarize voters, according to a report published in late 2018 by the University of Oxford and the research firm Graphika. The Russian agency’s efforts have included Facebook messages with a race-based appeal that refer to immigrants as “parasites,” and convey anti-refugee and anti-Muslim sentiments, according to the report.

name: Radicalization and Violent Extremism
description: Violent extremism emanating from the Middle East and North Africa shook the world when the Islamic State, or ISIS, took control of territory equal to the size of Britain in 2014 and launched a terror campaign marked by the slaughter of religious and ethnic minorities and the destruction of historic sites in Iraq and Syria. At its peak, ISIS had an estimated 40,000 recruits from 100 countries, and considerable oil resources. However, after the group lost the cities of Raqqa and Mosul in 2017, the Syrian Democratic Forces declared the territorial defeat of ISIS in the eastern Syrian town of Baghouz in early 2019 - though not without sending the world a warning about its continued ideological and financial strength. ISIS’s ideology and propaganda enabled it to flourish in a region increasingly defined by social polarization and disaffected youth. Though it has lost control of territory, more needs to be done to prevent its resurgence. A systemic approach that addresses the root causes of its emergence is needed, as is a sustainable process of reconstruction that focuses not only on economic recovery but also on mending the social fabric. Violent extremist groups have generally been able to thrive by harnessing communication platforms and social media in ways that outpace traditional policy and community responses. It is difficult, if not impossible, to control the digital space as a tool for recruitment and radicalization; an entire generation of digital natives is engaging with extremist worldviews via just a few clicks. Terrorist cells inspired by ISIS’s message have wreaked havoc around the world, striking twice in Paris in 2015, then in Brussels, Orlando, Nice and Berlin in 2016, and in Manchester, London and Barcelona in 2017. Also in 2017, Russia’s FSB announced it had arrested suspected followers of ISIS for plotting terror attacks in St. Petersburg, and in 2019 ISIS claimed responsibility for suicide bombings in Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday that killed more than 350 people. There is an urgent need to understand the mind-set and motivation behind such attacks, in order to pre-empt violent extremism, save lives, and prevent further economic impact. According to the 2018 Global Terrorism Index published by the Institute for Economics & Peace, the global economic impact of terrorism in 2017 declined by 42% compared with the prior year - but still totalled $52 billion.

name: Real Estate Finance
description: The real estate sector is intimately intertwined with the development of financial and capital markets. In addition to the large volume of plain-vanilla transactions in the global real estate market, there are an increasing number of innovations when it comes to real estate financing, investment and risk mitigation. Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs), or firms that provide investors with ways to tap into real estate-related revenue, derivative financial instruments, and public-private partnerships, are enabling new funding sources for the industry while making it possible for mom and pop investors to buy into property portfolios and diversify their wealth. In addition, they are providing access to new sources of capital for corporations. As of 2018, global REIT market capitalization had reached $1.7 trillion, a 7% increase over the prior year, according to a report published by the consultancy EY. In addition to structures like REITs, the growth of financial technology, or fintech, has also encouraged greater real estate finance-related innovation and entrepreneurship. Between 2008 and 2017 cumulative investment in real estate fintech startups rose to more than $31 billion from about $2 billion, according to a report published by Deloitte. While fintech, crowdfunding, peer-to-peer lending, and venture capital are not new concepts for the real estate industry, they can all be used in new and innovative ways to facilitate the evolution of a more efficient market.

name: Real Estate Regulation and Governance
description: In the real estate world, regulation that can adequately protect against spiralling asset prices is imperative to ensure that financial bubbles do not have wider, systemic implications. According to a report published by the Swiss bank UBS, the cities at greatest risk of real estate price bubbles as of 2018 were Amsterdam, Hong Kong, London, Munich, Toronto, and Vancouver. Global house prices increased by 35% between 2008 and 2018, according to the report, and buying a 60-square-metre in most cities now exceeds the budget of most people who earn an average salary in the highly-skilled service sector. The pace of transformation in the real estate market, spurred by technology innovation, may necessitate a fine-tuning of rules that require firms to minimize the risk of collapse - in order to ensure continued stability for the broader financial system. Measures such as limiting, or lowering, loan-to-value ratios in order to potentially reduce costs, placing caps on the amount of time required to repay loans, increasing capital gains taxes that apply when properties are sold, and limiting the purchase of multiple properties for investment and speculation could be some of the speed-bumps used to slow the growth of a bubble. Apart from the real estate market, the strengthening of the stability of banks’ balance sheets is also important for alleviating fears of another financial contagion more than a decade after the real estate-related subprime mortgage crisis in the US spurred widespread recession and unemployment.

name: Reaping Africa’s Dividend
description: Africa has yet to experience the kind of demographic transition that injected large numbers of people into the workforce in East Asia and fuelled both corresponding economic growth in that region, and increased investment in education. In Africa, a combination of education- and skills-related challenges have so far resulted in what could be regarded as demographic headwinds (growing populations, but stagnant workforces). However, a demographic dividend on the continent, where 30% of an expected population of 3 billion people by 2065 should be between 15- and 24-years-old, could yet result in an additional $500 billion in annual economic growth over a 30-year period - which in turn could empower women, improve health, and bolster education (particularly for young girls), according to a report published by Agence Française de Développement in 2017. But in order to realize this demographic dividend, sub-Saharan Africa will have to create an average of 18 million high-productivity jobs a year until 2035 - six times the current rate of job creation of 3 million jobs a year. While a demographic dividend is within reach for Africa, it has been slow in coming. A few countries (such as Tunisia) have made strides by reducing fertility rates as their working-age populations grow, though others are stuck with relatively high fertility. And while a 1% increase in the working age population in Africa can result in a 1.4% increase in GDP, female labour force participation has been blunted by childcare responsibilities - and related policy support is required. In addition, while relatively well-educated people from wealthier African countries tend to migrate overseas, migration within Africa has largely been informal and not captured by legitimate economic sectors, according to a report published by the Brookings Institution in 2018. In order to create a sufficient number of productive jobs, sustained annual economic growth of 8% to 9% is required, and policy-makers should focus on sectors including agriculture and agro-processing, wholesale and retail trade, and tourism - based on their current growth rates and multiplier effects. Ultimately, the inclusive growth required to reap a demographic dividend calls for the transformation of Africa’s economies - and a sustained focus on family planning.

name: Recognizing India’s Urban Future
description: While the idea that India lives in its villages is accepted wisdom that shapes public policy, it is not necessarily true. It also masks real policy challenges related to managing Indian urbanization, and governing the cities that generate up to 70% of the country’s GDP. Countries define urban settlements in different ways. India, per the 2011 census, is 31% urban. According to other definitions, the country is 26% urban. Both estimates may well be off by a fair distance. India’s human capital and growth targets fall into a chasm between “official” and true urbanization. While Rural Local Bodies (RLBs) govern areas classified as rural, Urban Local Bodies (ULBs) that govern urban areas have different powers under the Constitution. For example, ULBs are mandated to provide goods such as sewage lines and arterial roads, while RLBs are not. This means that areas that are officially classified as rural, but have the density of urban settlements, do not receive critical amenities. Physical infrastructure such as roads and water supply is only one part of this equation - people living in areas governed by ULBs are also significantly more likely to be able to access education and healthcare.  This sort of disparity affects about 250 million people, and has wide-ranging implications for both India’s health burden and costs, and the quality of its labour force. There are worrying fiscal implications, too. The share of tax revenue raised by ULBs is estimated to be 8.5 times higher than that of RLBs, even though RLBs preside over roughly three times the number of people. The Indian state is already stretched for resources needed to improve infrastructure, and by failing to recognize (real) urbanization it is further depriving itself. People migrate to cities seeking jobs and other opportunities - and well-functioning and diverse cities give rise to beneficial, “agglomeration” economies that drive productivity and growth. Poorly-run cities, however, have their agglomeration economies undercut by rising congestion, worsening air quality, soaring house prices, and inadequate public services - and more often than not, Indian cities fall into this category, as ULBs spend only about 28% of what they need for the efficient delivery and management of services. Acknowledging the extent of India’s urbanization, and effectively managing it by reforming urban governance are key for improving the country’s quality of life and human capital, while boosting economic growth.

name: Reconciliation and Development
description: Since the end of a decades-long war with Tamil Tiger separatists in 2009, Sri Lanka has made gradual progress on post-conflict reconciliation. Meaningful reconciliation, however, requires that economic and political power be restored to people in former conflict zones in the north and east of the country. Prior to the presidential election in 2015, the government’s focus had been on heavy capital expenditure, with a preference for large infrastructure projects. This was motivated by a need to improve transportation connections between former conflict areas and the rest of the country. However, infrastructure building, in the absence of economic and political empowerment, did not translate into sustainable reconciliation. Faced with international backlash over alleged human rights violations committed by the Sri Lankan army during the last stages of the civil war, Sri Lanka’s government lost preferential concessions granted by the European Union to developing countries, and had to turn to China for the financing required to back its infrastructure investment. Following the 2015 elections, however, the government made a fresh commitment to accountability and reconciliation measures. Considerations have since been made about restoring land rights, demilitarization, and investigating allegations made against the army - though progress has been impeded by flareups of violence. The country has more recently dealt with violent extremism without apparent connection to its historic ethnic strife; the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the suicide bombings of churches and hotels on Easter Sunday 2019 that killed more than 350 people. During the civil war, areas of the north and east in Sri Lanka enjoyed minimal economic growth and received little to no investment. Amid early post-conflict resettlement and infrastructure development efforts, the government came under heavy scrutiny for the militarization of these former conflict zones, and for the appropriation of minority-owned land. This contributed to ethnic tension, and reconciliation stagnated. The government must now revitalize the process. The Office for National Unity and Reconciliation, established in 2015, has been tasked with formulating related policies and programmes. The passage of the Right to Information Act of 2016, which grants citizens a right to know how public money is being spent, and the establishment of an Office of Missing Persons in 2017, were considered positives for reconciliation - though progress has been hindered by populist nationalist sentiment and sporadic ethnic tensions.

name: Redefining Health and Disease
description: Nosology, the medicinal science that deals with the classification of disease, is embracing the technological revolution of omics: the fields that end in “-omics.” Genomics, for example, is emerging as a powerful tool that can be used in the classification of disease, and builds on previous technological advances that utilized anatomy and microbiology to define pathologic disease. Genomic information (about an individual’s genetic makeup) can enable us to categorize disease, understand pathology, and target treatment accordingly. Knowledge of each person’s unique DNA sequence is bound to further personalize healthcare and treatment decisions. With advances in genomic science, ailments that once seemed dissimilar are being joined together under a single focus. And, what were once thought to be uniform diseases are being differentiated. For example, we can now define cancer based on aberrant genomic signatures, rather than simply on the anatomical origin of a tumour. Another example: cystic fibrosis can result from more than 900 mutations in the CTFR gene, and a drug has been developed that is particularly effective at addressing a specific, cystic fibrosis-related mutation. Rapid and relatively inexpensive genome sequencing, along with bioinformatics tools, are driving the new Personalized Medicine paradigm. The challenge will be to efficiently incorporate this genomic information into routine healthcare.

name: Refugees and Migration
description: If all of the people now living outside of the country of their birth united to form their own state, it would have a population of more than 240 million - making it the fifth-largest country in the world, according to the United Nations International Migration Report 2015. Migration is a defining topic of our time, and the countries that succeed in harnessing its potential by attracting the best and brightest, or by utilizing diasporas to advance their foreign interests, can benefit tremendously. However, the migration crisis in Europe has challenged solidarity and cohesion. The European Union has shown it is unable to take advantage of migration flows, and has instead on several occasions become vulnerable to foreign threats to control refugee and migrant flows to advance political ends; examples include former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi’s 2010 threat that Europe would “turn black” if he did not receive aid to help stop the flow of migrants from Africa, or Turkey’s role in the current migrant crisis.  EU members generally do not see themselves as immigration countries, despite the fact that as of 2015 more than 10% of marriages in the bloc involved at least one foreigner, according to Eurostat figures. This mentality influenced their stance during the migrant crisis in 2015, when about 1 million refugees, predominantly from Syria and Afghanistan as well as from sub-Saharan African countries, made their way into the EU, according to United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees data. Germany unilaterally decided in 2015 to open its borders and take in the majority of refugees seeking to make a new home there; at least 700,000 refugees arrived before the end of that year, according to the German Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, putting a strain on resources. Germany’s move frustrated European leaders who interpreted it as disregarding their own wishes, and coming at their expense. Resistance formed in particular in eastern member states, where many accused German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government of enticing foreigners to prop up an ageing German society. Though migrant numbers have fallen, Europe must still reconcile calls for anti-immigrant policies and closed borders in mainstream politics with the practical necessity of embracing newcomers. Despite concerted efforts, reaching a comprehensive, durable accord on migration within the EU seems unlikely. One point of agreement, however, is that it is best to help people to not have to become migrants in the first place.

name: Regional Cooperation
description: After four years of downturn, 2017 marked a recovery for exports from Latin America and the Caribbean - their value rose by 12.2% compared with the prior year, and then proceeded to grow by 9.9% in 2018. However, the Inter-American Development Bank’s Trade and Integration Monitor 2018 warned that the region is vulnerable to the instability of external demand, the appreciation of the dollar, and the effects of global trade tensions; this vulnerability is made particularly acute by the relatively low sophistication (a measure of technical and other characteristics) of Latin American exports. In addition, Latin America has actually lost export market share within the region itself - especially in more sophisticated sectors - due to a lag in competitiveness relative to global rivals. This points to an urgent need for the region to adopt policies that better promote the quality of exports and to focus on improving regional trade integration.  Since the mid-1990s, trade barriers have been significantly reduced between Latin American and Caribbean nations. Of the 284 physical regional trade agreements currently in effect worldwide, 57 include South American countries, and 38 include Central American countries - resulting in trade agreement coverage of more than 80% of all trade in Latin America and the Caribbean, according to World Trade Organization figures. Latin American countries have made some progress in harmonizing their cross-border integration procedures and regulation. However, as global competition increases and global value chains grow in complexity, better alignment of national policies and a revamping of institutions will be vital to promote the quality, sophistication, and compatibility of the region’s exports. Transport and logistics costs constitute one of the most significant obstacles to trade integration. According to the Latin American Integration Association, these costs are significantly higher in the region than those in the developed world as a consequence of limited and relatively inefficient infrastructure.

name: Regional Cooperation in Africa
description: It is now widely accepted both that the earth’s climate is changing, and that Africa is the most negatively impacted continent on the planet - mainly due to high vulnerability levels, low adaptive capacities, and widespread poverty. Even as Africa bears the brunt of climate change impact, it contributes the smallest share among all continents to the global greenhouse gas emissions (3.8% of global emissions, compared with 23% for China), according to a report published by the Brookings Institution in 2016. As a result of climate change, by the year 2020 as many as 250 million people in Africa are expected to be exposed to increased water stress, and yields from rainfed agriculture could be reduced by up to 50%, according to the United Nations Environment Programme. In light of these challenges, cooperation among countries in the region could be an effective tool to bolster and share in economic development. Cooperation between African countries is currently underpinned by the African Union’s eight Regional Economic Communities (including Arab Maghreb Union in the north, and the Intergovernmental Authority on Development in the east). However, there are other regional organizations in Africa that deal with public goods like infrastructure; five are concerned with energy, 15 with rivers and lakes, three with peace and security, and one with the environment. When it comes to the environment, cooperation has been perceived as inadequate - which is unfortunate. According to a 2017 paper published in the International Journal of Climate Change Strategies and Management, regional efforts are at least eight times more effective than individual country approaches when it comes to developing responses to climate change (while international cooperation is 3.9 times more effective). On the other hand, cooperation among African countries focused on infrastructure has improved. The African Infrastructure Development Index reflected improved scores for virtually all countries in 2018, and the continent as a whole saw its score rise to 28.44 from 27.12 in 2016. Above all, there is a need for a more concerted, holistic, continent-wide approach to addressing climate change, particularly in relation to food security, safety, and the protection of water resources, in order to help stem related impacts, scarcity, and mounting illegal migration to Europe.

name: Regional Digital Economy
description: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) region is home to about 640 million people, and more than half are both under the age of 30 and relatively tech savvy. In a report published in late 2017, Google and Temasek (Singapore’s state-owned investment firm) noted that the growth of the internet economy in Southeast Asia had exceeded expectations, having reached $50 billion in size that year while remaining well on track to reach $200 billion by 2025. The region added more than 70 million new internet users between 2015 and 2017, according to the report, and its population was already spending more time on the mobile internet than anywhere else in the world; Thailand topped the list of countries by time spent, at 4.2 hours per day, while Indonesia registered 3.9 hours per day. By way of comparison, time spent in the US was just 2 hours per day, while in the United Kingdom it was 1.8 hours, according to the report. In combination with the transformative impact of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, these trends have the potential to help stimulate new industries, leapfrog legacy business models, and fundamentally change lives. Digital trade can better connect the ASEAN region’s small- and medium-sized enterprises to regional and global markets, while the emergence of digital capabilities such as finance tools tied to blockchain technology could enable further opportunities for these firms. That in turn could make the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) trade bloc more vibrant and inclusive. One good example of the impact that digital trade can have on regional economic growth is the low-cost airline Air Asia, which has deployed digital tools to enable it to sell cheap tickets and boost operational efficiency. A number of ambitious internet firms have emerged in the region, such as Singapore-based online retailer Lazada, which sold a controlling stake to Chinese internet giant Alibaba in 2016 for $1 billion; in 2018, Alibaba invested a further $3 billion in the firm, in order to bolster the relationship. However, technology adoption differs greatly among ASEAN countries, and there is a need to build regional internet infrastructure. In order to attract the necessary investment for this, easing the flow of data across national borders and taking steps to bolster cyber security are essential.

name: Regional Economic Context
description: Annual GDP growth in the Middle East and North Africa region is projected to rebound to an average of 2% in 2018 (up from 1.4% the prior year), and is on track to improve to 2.8% by the end of 2020, according to the World Bank. The rebound is mostly attributed to the recent uptick in oil prices, which has benefited the region’s exporters. In order to better realize the economic potential of this part of the world, a credible reform agenda for inclusive growth is vital - one that addresses access to financing for small businesses, the removal of trade barriers, and the free movement of labour and capital. Measures to bolster industry and improve competitiveness have already generated results in Egypt, for example, which has moved up in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index ranking between 2015 (116th out of 140 economies) and 2018 (94th out of 140). While Egypt has dealt with significant public debt and inflationary pressure, its government has sought to stimulate private sector investment in energy, infrastructure, and transportation (while implementing reforms including exchange-rate liberalization, and energy subsidy reductions). By way of contrast, Jordan, which has implemented a “Vision 2025” program to try to improve its competitiveness, has actually slipped lower in the Forum’s index - to 73rd place in 2018, from 64th in 2015. Meanwhile ongoing conflict in countries like Iraq, Libya, Syria, and Yemen is having a negative effect on infrastructure and local economic health. While the oil-rich countries in the Gulf have enjoyed growth and macroeconomic stability, they also face problems with unemployment and a mismatch between current labour force skills and the skills actually needed by employers. Uncertainty about efforts to shift away from oil dependency in the Gulf Cooperation Council countries (the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia) has affected their competitiveness to varying degrees; while a decline in oil prices had led Kuwait to experience its first budget deficit in 2016 following 16 consecutive years of surplus, prices recovered in 2018. Despite the fragmented competitiveness landscape, the two non-oil-related industries in the region that are growing across the board are healthcare and education.

name: Regional Relationships
description: The Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) was formed in 1967, with an agreement among five original founding nations (Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand) to organize for the sake of peace, stability and cooperation. The group provided an important means to push back against the constraints of the then-bipolar world order that resulted from the Cold War. ASEAN added Brunei Darussalam in 1984, Viet Nam in 1995, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (or Laos) and Myanmar in 1997, and Cambodia in 1999. Currently, Timor-Leste (or East Timor) is forging closer ties with ASEAN and hoping to join the bloc. ASEAN has sought to better ensure regional security with efforts such as a 1997 treaty banning nuclear weapons, and the region is located at a strategically important junction between two of the world’s most populous rising economic powers, China and India, making it a geopolitical and geo-economic focal point. All ASEAN member states have now signed the founding document for the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which was established in 2015 to provide both an alternative to Western-led efforts such as the World Bank, and regional competition for the Japanese-led Asian Development Bank. India, meanwhile, changed its longstanding “Look East” policy in 2014 to an “Act East” policy, by engaging ASEAN member Myanmar as a possible bulwark against Chinese influence. ASEAN member states are also enmeshed in territorial disputes with interested powers. China’s claim to territories in the South China Sea, for example, overlaps with competing claims by Brunei Darussalam, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Viet Nam. A 2015 Centre for Strategic & International Studies report noted that ASEAN members generally respond to challenges with a united front, though individual national interest can still take precedence - as is the case with the South China Sea dispute, the most serious geopolitical issue in the region. This tension between unity and national interest can be attributed in part to the broad spectrum of linguistic and religious traditions within ASEAN, home to Muslims, Christians, Buddhists, Hindus and followers of other religions. It can also be viewed as a natural growing pain for formerly-colonized countries working to forge their own strong political institutions.

name: Regulation and Circularity
description: Governments have started to stimulate and reward the adoption of circular business models, which emphasize the reuse of materials in order to eliminate waste. Japan, in particular, has distinguished itself in this regard; in 2000, the Japanese government passed the Law for the Promotion of Efficient Utilization of Resources, which requires businesses to cut their generation of by-products and encourages them to use recyclable resources (Japanese manufacturers are also required to run disassembly plants, and to recover material). In 2001, the Chinese Government began turning its industrial parks into eco-industrial parks, by incentivizing practices such as industrial symbiosis - where by-products from one factory can be used by another. Examples include a paper plant that receives its wood supply from a lumber mill, and in turn supplies sludge for use in fertilizer. In 2008, China adopted its Circular Economy Promotion Law, to support more effective use of resources. The European Commission has meanwhile adopted a “Circular Economy Package,” which includes proposals such as a common European Union target for recycling 65% of all municipal waste, and 75% of all packaging waste, by 2030. International policy agendas are also increasingly taking the circular economy into account. The International Resource Panel, consisting of scientists and hosted by the United Nations Environment Programme, was founded in 2007 to provide advice on natural resources, sustainability, and production, and to help separate economic growth from accompanying environmental degradation. According to the panel, institutions that have made use of its work include the European Commission and the African Development Bank. In 2015, the leaders of the Group of Seven (G7) countries formed an Alliance on Resource Efficiency, as a platform for knowledge-sharing about reducing environmental pollution. The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, which went into effect in 2016 to guide UN Development Program policy and funding, include a specific call (goal 12) for responsible consumption and production; at the UN High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development held in New York in 2018, progress made to date on goal 12 was reviewed, and speakers including the European Union and France advocated for a circular economy approach to the issue, while Belgium and Estonia presented their plans for their countries to become circular economies.

name: Regulation and Corporate Adaptation
description: A wide variety of legal and regulatory environments have been constructed around the world; the OECD Corporate Governance Factbook contains information about nearly 50 different national institutional, legal, and regulatory frameworks. Some institutional and legal settings have proven to be more conducive to effective corporate governance than others. Enhancing governance reform in the many places where it is lacking is a potential source of value creation both for individual companies and broader economies. One example of legal governance reform is 2002’s Sarbanes-Oxley Act in the US, which expanded disclosure and auditing requirements and the responsibilities of the boards at all publicly-traded companies. Sarbanes-Oxley triggered similar reforms around the world: Australia in 2004, India in 2005, and Japan in 2006. Since then, other important reforms have been put in place - such as the Dodd-Frank Act enacted in 2010, in response to the banking industry excesses that resulted in the financial crisis, and the Jumpstart Our Business Startups, or JOBS Act, which was designed to facilitate the funding of small businesses in the US by exempting them from certain regulatory requirements.  The right mix of legislation, regulation, and self-regulation depend on a country’s specific circumstances, history, and culture. The corporate governance structures developed in response typically cover the ownership of publicly-listed companies and stock exchanges, shareholder rights and responsibilities, takeover rules, board structures and composition, and information disclosure. Technological progress has created situations where regulatory needs are not necessarily black and white. Services like Uber and Lyft, for example, have made it unclear if drivers should be treated like regular employees or contractors under the law.
