Legislation passed in California in 2019 requires these ride-sharing platforms to treat drivers in that state as employees when it comes to wage and benefit protections, creating uncertainty about the financial prospects of the broader “gig economy” amid the possibility that other states and countries might follow suit. This shift could impact many boards and the ways they approach compliance, risk management and corporate strategy. Other areas of technological development with significant corporate governance implications include artificial intelligence, blockchain, the Internet of Things, and biotechnology - all of which are likely to trigger new regulations and corporate governance needs.

name: Regulatory Complexity
description: In the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018, half of the economies ranked in the overall top ten also took top spots specifically in terms of the burden (or lack thereof) of government regulation, and transparency of government policy-making. The regulatory complexity that hinders performance is driven by economic and social complexity; new products and services, and novel ways of doing business, challenge existing regulatory regimes. Are Uber drivers employees or independent contractors, for example, and is Facebook a broadcaster or a public utility? Other prompts for new and evolving regulation include search engines, self-driving cars, drones, and digital currencies. Our abilities to gain access to bigger sets of data and more closely track behaviour call for more targeted regulation, and greater transparency. Yet, laws, regulations, and contracts are becoming longer, harder to interpret, and subject to more cross-referencing and potential conflicts. The first piece of major federal legislation in the US, the Interstate Commerce Act of 1887, was 15 pages long; the Affordable Care Act passed in 2010, known as Obamacare, was 907 pages long. According to an analysis by the US-based law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, the Dodd-Frank Act, US financial legislation that was 848 pages long when passed in 2010, produced 22,000 pages of regulations by 2015. Meanwhile in Venezuela, opening a legal business requires completing 20 procedures that collectively consume an average of 230 days (compared with one procedure requiring half a day in New Zealand). Regulatory complexity can impact our everyday activity; researchers estimated in 2012 it would take the average person 244 hours a year to read all of the privacy policies they agree to online. Regulatory complexity is only growing, as rules and decisions governing economic activity appear. A New York Times review in 2017 found that more than 50 countries had passed new laws since 2012 related to operating on the internet, for example. Complexity follows, when rule-making in one jurisdiction overlaps or conflicts with that in another, or when jurisdictions seek to apply their rules outside of their territory. The United Nations World Investment Report for 2017 noted that investment policy-making is becoming more complex, uncertain, and divergent - reflecting the impact of sustainable development goals and diverse responses to globalization.

name: Reign of Uncertainty
description: Humanity has a way of aggravating natural uncertainty; the calamitous wildfires that swept across Northern California in 2018 after being triggered by activities like barbecuing and repairing power lines (and then amplified by the effects of climate change) were just one example. Technology in particular can trigger an uptick in the sort of low probability, potentially high impact events that can push governments to rethink the way they plan. Disruptive trends like the powerful influence of social media can make long term policy planning difficult, particularly if decision-makers expect to be able to make clear calculations of costs versus benefits, or to have a complete set of information on hand before decisions have to be made. The Arab Spring, which saw a number of protests organized spontaneously via social media, illustrated how suddenly disruption can occur when traditional political and administrative institutions are seen as no longer adequately meeting public needs. This has become a particularly acute risk, now that global wealth is concentrated in the hands of relatively few people - fuelling the politics of resentment and feeding the rise of populist demagogues. With uncertainty and ambiguity only likely to increase, it will become more important to build resilience into governance systems, instead of relying on brittle and narrowly-conceived policy solutions. This calls for building stronger foresight ability into every aspect of governance, whether it is in the public or private sector; collaborative, multi-stakeholder, and digitally-enabled processes that can tap into the broad-based wisdom of the crowds could be helpful in this regard. Building resilience should mean not just that systems can bounce back from crisis and shock, but that they can change and transform in response for the better. Some examples the power of building foresight for troubled communities include the Global Business Network’s work with stakeholders in South Africa on developing future scenarios, and the efforts of Reos Partners to organize collaborative work on the peace process in Colombia.

name: Relations with the European Union
description: The popularity of the European Union has dramatically declined in Italy during the past few years. This trend, in one of the six founding members of the European Economic Community (the EU’s precursor), is a consequence of a recession that followed the European debt crisis, and an influx of refugees. For many Italians, the austerity policies implemented in 2012 and 2013 were linked to the adoption in 2012 of the Fiscal Compact - a European intergovernmental treaty that governs budgetary targets, and limits Italy’s government spending. The popularity of the EU is also undercut by a perception that Italy is bearing the brunt of the refugee crisis, with insufficient support from fellow EU members. While many migrants and refugees who reach Italy flee to other countries soon afterward, those who remain often find it challenging to integrate. Many newcomers are unable to find jobs, and end up working in the illicit economy. In 2018, European leaders forged an agreement that involves sending asylum seekers to centres in both Africa and EU countries. Questions remain about the feasibility of the plan, and human rights advocates have criticized it for potentially exposing migrants to abuse. The erstwhile populist coalition that came to power in Italy in 2018, composed of right-wing parties the League and the Five Star Movement, sparred with European leaders over issues ranging from migration to the very future of the EU. The cabinet included Minister for European Affairs Paolo Savona, a professor of economics known for detailing a plan to leave the euro. Savona, who had initially been tapped to serve as Economy Minister but was vetoed due to his views on the euro, rarely disappointed Eurosceptics and regularly expressed sharp criticism of the way Europe and the eurozone are organized. While former Economy Minister Giovanni Tria took a less confrontational approach, he has since been replaced in a new government by Roberto Gualtieri, who is also the chairman of the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. The most controversial appointment in the more recently-elected, more conciliatory coalition government is Foreign Minister Luigi Di Maio, who is the head of the Five Star Movement. Polls have consistently shown that despite mounting Euroscepticism, and persistently high public opinion of an adversarial approach to the EU, Italians remain strongly against the idea of leaving the political bloc.

name: Relevant Specialized Education
description: Employers are increasingly warning of widening gaps between the skills that are in demand, and those that are available - highlighting the need to foster more technical talent if countries want to remain competitive. There is a considerable skills mismatch between university graduates and the needs of employers in most economies. Without adequate modifications to education and training systems, this gap between supply and demand is projected to grow significantly. To address this, it will be critical to re-align global talent pipelines with market needs. Closing this gap will become more complex, as skills requirements change at an accelerating pace - particularly in fields such as information technology. This will require the collaboration of the public and private sectors. In particular, more needs to be done to better balance the focus of policy-makers, investors, and politicians between academic training, and technical and vocational education and training. There is a need to better understand the linkages between the two, and ways they can be complementary for individuals, businesses and economies (as noted in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization’s Education Strategy 2014-2021). High quality, timely career advice, and guidance can support the successful transition of young people from their school years to employment, by ensuring that they understand their options based on real labour market data and demand. Proactive career guidance can also help circumvent the gender stereotypes and socio-economic opportunity gaps that often hold young people back from choosing certain occupations. Technical and vocational education and training is underutilized, and often treated with neglect by education systems as a second-best option. Such training and education can be a key driver of economic growth, and can provide the skills required for jobs that will have real staying power in future labour markets. Technical qualifications are best designed through collaboration between employers and industry groups, and particular attention should be paid to fostering their evolution based on sets of agreed-upon standards.

name: Religion in Ethics and Law
description: Ethics and values based on religion shape laws and policies, and factor into global governance. The United Nations, for example, launched the so-called Fez Plan of Action in 2017, to help religious leaders use their influence to prevent violent atrocities. In order to fully understand systems of law and governance, and to build consensus on taking action on global challenges, one must consider how religion factors into local, national, and international identities, and into responses to complex issues. The intersection of law and religion continues to be a source of friction for many countries, as domestic courts consider questions about the free exercise, establishment, and accommodation of diverse religious practices. For example, in 2018, both the United Kingdom Supreme Court and the US Supreme Court considered cases where a bakery had refused to produce a cake associated with support for same-sex marriage on religious grounds. Legal conflicts (and related remedies) are also increasingly occurring across borders, and among culturally and religiously diverse participants including individuals, governments, corporations and non-governmental organizations. Understanding and adjudicating such challenges requires a sustained engagement with religion, ethics, political theory, and theories of globalization. Similarly, issues like nuclear proliferation, climate change, and the refugee crisis have raised questions about responsibility sharing and shared governance; an understanding of how morality, ethics, and religion influence the related policies and approaches of multinational institutions is essential for consensus building and action. Questions to be considered include whether there is a shared set of values across national borders (for example, a universal understanding of human rights) upon which joint action can be based, and how religion can help, or harm, such consensus building. Drawing lessons from the displacement narratives associated with religions, like the Exodus for Judaism, the flight of the new-born Jesus with Mary and Joseph to Egypt for Christianity, and the migration of Muhammad from Mecca to Medina for Islam, could help spur action on the forced displacement of refugees from the Middle East and North Africa, for example. Many of the first responders and aid workers in conflict and crisis situations are already religiously motivated, though, ironically, populist political movements in the West based on religious or socioeconomic identity often thwart international efforts to address global issues. Religion factors into the fundamental ways that political and legal systems are legitimated - and it must be taken into account in order to make real progress on our shared challenges.

name: Resource Scarcity
description: Resource scarcity – situations where the demand for resources outstrips supply – is already a central challenge in global governance. To take water as an example, the World Economic Forum’s 2016 Global Risks Report noted that 40% of the world’s population suffers water shortages lasting for at least one month during a given calendar year. The United Nations’ (UN) Sustainable Development Goals seek to change the existing situation in which 2.4 billion people lack access to basic sanitation. The challenges that currently exist, difficult as they are, will only be exacerbated by changes to the climate. The Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development’s Environmental Outlook to 2050, published in 2012, predicted that by 2050 nearly half of the world’s population will live under severe water stress. A similar story can be told in respect of other resources. It has long-been recognized that resource scarcity has the potential to contribute to conflict – with the manifest damage that inevitably follows to rights. Short of conflict, resource scarcity makes it difficult for states, and particularly developing states, to secure basic social and economic rights for their citizens. Over the last few decades, there has been increasing recognition of the equal importance of social and economic rights as part of the basic needs of individuals. On the normative level, international and national frameworks now more often seek to protect rights of access to, for example, land, water of a sufficient quality, and food. For instance, the UN’s human rights architecture includes a Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food and one on Safe Drinking Water and Sanitation. The UN Human Rights Council’s Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, adopted in 2011, include, within the core set of authoritative rights against which the human rights impact of businesses are assessed, those enshrined in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. In other words, businesses are required to consider how their acts affect social and economic rights. Moreover, the UN Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, through its monitoring procedures and General Comments, has fleshed out meaning of the rights themselves. However, whatever developments there have been on the normative level are threatened in practice by the increasing pressure on resources. The causes range and are related – bad governance, failure to address and mitigate the effects of climate change, and exploitative practices. Moreover, resource scarcity often particularly affects the rights of vulnerable groups and magnifies existing inequalities. To a degree, more equitable allocative decisions can improve the situation. More fundamentally, though, it is necessary to come to terms with the many causes of resource scarcity in the first place. This will require cooperation among and between states and business. Due to its limited natural resources, Japan imports much of its critical material from abroad. Its self-sufficiency when it comes to food has dropped significantly over the past few decades, from 79% of domestic calories consumed produced in Japan as of 1960, to 38% by 2016. Meanwhile its energy self-sufficiency rate dropped from 58% as of 1960 to just 6% by 2014. Some of the country’s business sectors, such as electronics, are fully reliant on imports for their most critical components - such as the rare earth minerals that are used in manufacturing advanced devices.  The spectre of resource scarcity has led to developments such as the so-called Top-Runner programme, which establishes energy efficiency standards. The program was last amended in 2013 and now applies to product categories including passenger vehicles, air conditioners, and TV sets, according to the International Energy Agency. Japanese companies have gained global recognition for their energy efficiency, technology, and advanced business models, and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been supportive of developing more sustainable, circular economic models.

name: Resource Sustainability
description: A growing global population and expanding middle class are increasing demand for food, and placing agricultural land, forests and water resources under greater amounts of strain. At the same time, farm systems are increasingly vulnerable to climate change and related weather volatility. As temperatures and sea levels rise at an accelerated pace, experts suggest that failing to limit global warming to 2°C above pre-industrial temperature levels would lead to irreversible damage. The global food value chain, including growers, producers and sellers, accounts for roughly 30% of global energy consumption, and generates greenhouse gases estimated at 10 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent every year, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations’ 2017 report The State of Food and Agriculture. Agriculture uses 11% of the world’s land surface for crop production, accounts for 70% of total freshwater withdrawals, and is responsible for about 80% of global deforestation, according to the report. The combined effect of climate and carbon dioxide change is as likely as not to increase food prices by as much as 45% by 2050, according to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change published in 2014. There will also likely be a significant increase in related packaging; the production of plastics used in the packaging of food products is expected to nearly quadruple by 2050, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2016 report The New Plastics Economy. Developing more sustainable systems could have significant social and economic impacts, particularly in developing economies poised to leapfrog traditional, “take-make-dispose” approaches already prevalent elsewhere. In general, the plastics and agribusiness sectors must work together with multiple stakeholders, in order to maximize resource sustainability. Greater efforts at increasing sustainability are also called for when it comes to food produced in the oceans. Nearly one third of global fish stocks are being overfished, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations’ 2016 report State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture, jeopardizing economic and environmental security. Improved fishery management could both help to address overfishing, and create significant economic opportunity; research published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA in 2016 estimated that strong fisheries management techniques could increase the annual global catch by more than 16 million tonnes, while creating $53 billion in additional profit.

name: Responsibility and Accountability
description: Leadership during the Fourth Industrial Revolution brings with it an opportunity to redefine economic systems, and to take necessary steps to address inequality. According to the 2018 World Inequality Report published by the Paris School of Economics, income inequality has increased rapidly since 1980 in North America, China, India, and Russia. Meanwhile the share of total national income accounted for by a country’s top 10% of earners has reached as high as 47% in the US and Canada, 55% in sub-Saharan Africa, Brazil, and India, and 61% in the Middle East. A starkly unequal share of income is only the most obvious indicator of inequality; related gaps are also building within other intersecting dimensions, like gender, skills, and opportunity. In a technology-driven future that places a high demand on social capital (relationships and shared norms) and skills, the ties between these varying dimensions may only grow closer. Meanwhile emerging technologies are chiselling authority away from governments and handing it to companies and non-state actors, altering the traditional view of governance. A report published in 2018 by the World Economic Forum described how technology pioneers are increasingly developing their own private rules, certification schemes, standards, and policies which end up as a default means to govern societies spanning across national borders. If governments alone can no longer govern emerging technologies, these or other sources of authority will fill the void, according to the report. This places significant responsibility on technology pioneers, who have so far operated on the margins of traditional accountability. Public discontent over specific issues such as the way many companies behind major technological advances effectively avoid taxes has grown into a broader concern about the disruptive power these companies can wield over politics and economies. While new models are needed to expand governance beyond existing public institutions, the private sector must meanwhile demonstrate leadership that goes beyond concern for the bottom line, and takes a systemic view of impact and influence. One example of taking a broader view is the independent foundation established by software firm Zendesk with proceeds from its IPO when it moved into an economically-challenged area of San Francisco; the foundation works to address poverty and the digital divide (separating those with internet access from those going without), and it demonstrates how the benefits of disruptive technology can be harnessed for the good of multiple stakeholders without necessarily creating a new set of losers.

name: Responsible Data Use
description: The growing pool of consumer data being deposited online presents opportunities to improve media products, and to increase the relevance of advertising-supported content. However, media content is often used simply as bait to gather user data, and careful scrutiny is called for when it comes to privacy and consumer protection. In the European Union, the General Data Protection Regulation was implemented in 2018 to prevent companies from exploiting or retaining the personal data of internet users without their consent; companies in violation can be fined up to €20 million or 4% of their annual revenue, whichever is higher. Google was fined €50 million in France in early 2019 for failing to comply with GDPR obligations to provide full details to users about its data consent policies, and to provide sufficient control over how personal information is being used. In the US, legislators and regulators have been criticizing Facebook for failing to adequately protect its users’ data. Facebook can use this data in many different ways in order to enable advertisers to target their messaging, though in 2018 the company said it would remove thousands of targeting options that could be used to discriminate based on race or religion.      Traditional media outlets are increasingly competing for audience attention with newer platforms like Facebook, and with new content producers. Data monetization, done properly, could contribute to the economic sustainability of the existing media industry. A blog post published by Adobe in 2017 included data showing projected spending on digital ads increasing by about 76% between 2015 and 2019, compared with just a 10% increase for TV ad spending over the same period (with digital ads surpassing TV ads in value for the first time in the US in 2016); the post argued that if TV is to maintain the value of its content relative to digital channels, TV providers must tap into data to start delivering more value to advertisers. While some traditional news publishers have begun tapping new revenue streams by selling their users’ personal data, most have avoided the practice, according to research published by eMarketer in early 2019. These companies have opted to refrain from doing so either because the sale of even anonymized data could result in privacy violations and a breach of trust, because such a move risks selling off a competitive advantage, or because developing an ability to do so would simply cost too much money.

name: Responsible Governance
description: Since the opening of China’s economy in 1979, every echelon of society has undergone momentous change. The country has experienced unprecedented migration from inland areas to coastal cities, from rural to urban areas, and from farm work to factories - and then on to service sector jobs. This has shaken up social hierarchies, which are being redefined by an urban-rural split and an emerging middle class that the consultancy McKinsey has estimated will make up 40% of the population by 2020. Now, middle income, urban, and increasingly connected Chinese are demanding more than the basic necessities of life; they yearn for better jobs, better education, more affordable healthcare and housing, social security entitlements, a cleaner environment, and readily accessible entertainment. In the face of this, the Chinese government has adapted. As China’s population ages, for example, the government has abolished the "one child" policy, it has pushed forward reforms of healthcare and pensions, and it has reformed its household registration ("Hukou") system in order to improve access to social welfare benefits for migrant workers streaming into urban areas. China has also allowed for greater access to information, albeit while maintaining centralized control. In 2015, China launched the Belt and Road Initiative, an ongoing, globally-ambitious infrastructure investment project that touches more than 60 different economies. Sina News has reported that this effort is projected to have an impact on nearly one quarter of all global exports of goods and services, equal in value to about $21 trillion. In a related development, in the past 15 years or so, China has become a significant investor in Africa’s infrastructure. As the country’s economy and the size of its middle class expands, responsible governance is essential in terms of both international and domestic affairs. Local people's congresses in Chinese cities have been granted an ability to adopt their own local laws and regulations, as long as these do not contradict national and provincial law. At the same time, in 2018, the National People’s Congress (NPC), China’s federal legislature, adopted an amendment to the constitution that removes term limits for the country’s president and vice president.

name: Responsible Innovation
description: The onset of Fourth Industrial Revolution has brought with it a rapid evolution of technology, with development accelerating at a speed never before witnessed. While this brings with it tremendous opportunities, there are also new risks. Social structures and assumptions are in a state of flux, and we are facing big questions about data, in particular, in terms of ownership, quality, access, and use. It is imperative to avoid creating technology-related global inequality. While inequality has actually been decreasing in developing countries where digital communications systems are contributing to greater financial inclusion in places with limited infrastructure, in high- and middle-income countries inequality is worsening. In these countries, labour-saving technology has begun to replace decently-paid blue collar jobs, and the workers who once held those jobs may now be employed in retail-related or other roles, where the pay is typically lower. We need to maintain awareness of the potential for technology to exacerbate inequality, environmental damage, and social tension, and ensure that technology improves, rather than degrades, human and environmental well-being. In this regard, the concept of agile governance has become increasingly prevalent, as it emphasizes policy-makers and regulators working together with private developers, industries, and civil society organizations in order to exercise more responsible digital leadership, and in order to be able to more quickly adapt to changing circumstances. There is still, however, a risk of public backlash against technology. More dialogue and cooperation among companies, regulators, investors, consumers, and workers will be essential for earning and sustaining public trust.

name: Restructuring Global Value Chains
description: For many years, the fastest-growing category of international trade was “intermediate” trade between the nodes in global supply chains, adding value incrementally. This generated higher levels of freight movement, and helped the value of international trade grow at least two or three times faster than global GDP. After the global financial crisis, however, this so-called “trade multiplier” dropped to 1.5, as trade growth slowed. The potential for future growth has meanwhile been constrained by the failure of World Trade Organization (WTO)’s Doha round of negotiations, and a significant net increase in trade-restrictive measures. Long term progress towards trade liberalization may now reverse, following US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and renegotiation the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) - while the Trump administration’s tariffs applied in response to what it regards as unfair trade may result in trade wars. The United Kingdom’s decision to withdraw from the European Union is also likely to inhibit trade and disrupt cross-border supply chains. On the other hand, a recent agreement by 44 African states to form a Continental Free Trade Area shows that trade liberalization is still very much alive at the regional level. Some observers had forecast significant reshoring (or nearshoring) of manufacturing from low-labour-cost countries back to North America and Europe, due to wage inflation in emerging markets, rising transport costs, shortening order lead-times, and increased concern about supply chain risk. The increasing automation of production facilities in developed countries, and technologies such as 3D printing, which can shift the production of goods closer to the people who buy them, have also raised the prospect of significant reshoring. However, some companies may instead respond to wage inflation in places such as China and India by further shifting production to even lower-labour-cost countries. Regional trade agreements mean that production shifts and trade growth may occur more on a continental than a global scale. The reconfiguration of value chains may therefore be more pronounced at a regional level, potentially intensifying trading links between emerging markets. While trade liberalization has been faltering, trade facilitation has continued apace. For example, the so-called “single windows” that centralize procedures for customs and border compliance have proliferated. In addition, it is estimated that full implementation of the Trade Facilitation Agreement reached by WTO members in Bali in 2013 could generate $1 trillion of additional trade.

name: Rewiring the Indian State
description: India has been described as a 21st-century economic and diplomatic entity powered by a 19th-century state - as the capacity of institutions has failed to keep pace with wider changes in the economy. The country underperforms on even basic measures; it has an average of just 1.4 civil servants per 100 people, for example, compared to the OECD average of 7.7. The ratio of police-to-citizens is meanwhile 129 per 100,000, with only Uganda faring significantly worse on this metric. The judiciary has a backlog of 33 million cases, most of them stuck in the lower courts, and the law commission says an additional 70,000 judges are needed. And, this country of more than a billion people has only 970 diplomats, or as many as New Zealand (population 5 million). A related issue is the lack of fiscal capacity needed to help the state fund its public goods, development, and welfare commitments without putting public finances under stress. India has a narrow direct tax base that forces the government to impose high indirect taxes, and fiscal modernization is a work in progress. The country's income tax-to-GDP ratio is still less than 3%, below the average for similar developing economies.   India has taken some recent steps - both technological and technocratic - to bridge the state capacity gap. The “Aadhaar” digital identity programme, for example, has spearheaded a drive towards greater digital governance. Meanwhile related programmes are underway such as digitization of land records, direct income transfers through bank accounts, and biometric attendance checks at health and administrative facilities - which could all help improve governance. The government has also attempted technocratic solutions, as detailed in reports from the second Administrative Reforms Commission (which is intended to revamp public administration). Its recommendations range from allowing lateral entry into the top echelons of the bureaucracy, to rethinking roles and responsibilities at the lower levels. India’s score in Transparency International’s Corruption Perceptions Index has improved slightly in recent years, though it still ranked 78th out of 180 countries as of 2018. World Bank indicators reflect similar rankings in terms of government effectiveness and rule of law, pointing to an urgent need for India to re-assess its institutional capability and the governance structure of the state - if it wants to remain a thriving market economy that derives political legitimacy from its citizens, while delivering on its basic promises to them.

name: Rights of Artists
description: The freedom of expression is recognized in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the United Nation General Assembly in 1948, and in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights adopted in 1966 - and it is often taken for granted. Still, many artists cannot create or disseminate their art for fear of reprisal or prosecution. A report published by the international organization Freemuse registered 553 cases of violations of artists’ rights, in 78 countries, for 2017. On average, one artist per week was prosecuted for expressing themselves during the year, according to the report; the list of top 10 countries found to have censored the most in terms of art works and banned artists included the US, Ukraine, France, and China. Attacking artists and their creative practices is equivalent to attacking freedom of expression. It is imperative that creative voices remain free to speak out and produce work without the threat of retribution, in order to develop a global society with a plurality of voices and respect for the basic tenets of democracy - and to counter intolerant and illiberal societies. Freedom of expression contributes to the safeguarding of the freedom of information, and can ensure that citizens have access to broad-ranging, useful, uncensored and thought-provoking knowledge. A key aspect of artists’ rights is intellectual property protection. At a moral level, this can help individuals and communities to be properly recognized for their creativity, and to remain in control of its use. It also provides an important source of income for artists. While the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works, adopted in 1886, established a framework for artists and creators to control how their works are used, the more-than-100-year-old structure is ill adapted to the complexities of the modern world and new technologies. The rise of digital platforms and streaming has disrupted existing business models, and raises numerous issues regarding the right to be compensated for creative work. The nature of sharing on these platforms has taken most property rights away from the artists themselves, leaving many with little to no resulting income. Technologies like blockchain may yet enable creators to engage more directly with fans, however, and develop platforms that protect the value chain of creative output. This key issue was curated in partnership with Huib Schippers, Director of Smithsonian Folkways Recordings at the Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage.

name: Rise of Non-State Actors
description: The rising power of non-state actors is transforming international security. According to a 2015 report on Armed Non-State Actors by the Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces, conflict today is mostly a matter of two or more non-state actors fighting within the borders of a state. These actors come in the form of insurgent, separatist, pirate and local- or globally-affiliated terrorist organizations, often acting in collaboration with organized crime. Another factor empowering non-state actors is the tendency for external state involvement to take a form of proxy war, such as clandestine or deniable support for some form of non-state actor operating inside the target country.  The decision by the Pentagon to open a Silicon Valley office in 2015 recognized a power shift: private sector research and development budgets have soared above those of state defence agencies, and are producing dual-purpose technologies in artificial intelligence and robotics with huge weapons potential, yet are obtainable on the open market. A 2015 study on the Future Operating Environment 2035 by the UK Ministry of Defence estimated that such “off-the-shelf” commercial technologies are likely to become dual-use or reverse engineered, and employed by a spectrum of actors. Advances like additive manufacturing (3D printing) can increase the amount of illicit and unregulated technology transfer, exacerbating security threats. This so-called “democratization of destruction” empowers non-state actors through increased access to critical enablers previously reserved to advanced states. Hard encryption enables secret communication of market-sensitive information and operational plans. Social media offers powerful marketing opportunities, and also gives political movements new ways to recruit and propagandize.  So long as non-state actors’ capabilities fell far behind those of states, the sophistication of an attack suggested evidence of who was behind it. But as the capability gap closes, it becomes harder to quickly determine who is behind an attack, and to gain public trust and support for collective action. An attack on state institutions by non-state actors is becoming harder to distinguish from a state-sponsored attack by proxy, especially in a digitised social media environment that is vulnerable to manipulation. Whether it is “little green men” appearing in Ukraine, or highly capable “hacktivist” groups on a mission to expose hypocrisy, however selectively, the line between inter-state conflict and civil war is increasingly blurred.  From the so-called Islamic State (ISIS) to Al Qaeda, Boko Haram or the Nusra front, violent extremist groups draw on local grievances and state fragility to carve out a physical base, as described in the World Economic Forum 2016 Global Risks Report, but they operate in a global network of shifting allegiances, logistics and inspirational propaganda. The International Institute for Strategic Studies assessed in 2016 that ISIS had formalised relationships with groups in eight countries from Africa, the Caucasus, South Asia and Southeast Asia, as well as the Middle East. The metaphor the former head of the UK’s Secret Intelligence Service used to describe the result is that when you squeeze the (terrorist) balloon, you see it bulging out in multiple new locations. While non-state actors exploit the infrastructure created for legitimate economic and social interaction across borders, public policy to counter them necessarily involves closer coordination with the private sector. Meanwhile, businesses, cities and civil society organizations are increasingly developing in-house security capabilities to fend off hacking attacks. These non-state actors are enhancing their ability to manage political risk, and there is a burgeoning discussion about “foreign policy” for private sector actors, especially via start-ups that begin their business life at the transnational level. This suggests the scale of unexplored potential for effective cooperation among legitimate non-state actors, such as commercial enterprises, city-level government and non-governmental organizations, on security matters.

name: Rise of Populism
description: Globalization, growing inequality, immigration, and a lack of trust in public institutions have given rise to numerous populist movements, which in many cases blend nationalist, xenophobic appeals with an opposition to government and big business. These movements generally express scepticism of elites, and put their faith in the wisdom of the masses. However, right-wing versions of these movements also tend to have an authoritarian bent, and a belief in a strong leader to speak for those masses. Europe has spawned more than a dozen right-wing, populist parties, from Jobbik in Hungary to UKIP in the United Kingdom, while US President Donald Trump successfully used populist messaging in the 2016 election. Populist movements typically appeal to those worried about their social status, job loss, the arrival of new immigrants, and shifting cultural mores; their supporters believe that globalization has been hurtful, immigration is a threat to their safety, that free trade has reduced job options and that big institutions cannot be trusted. They often harken back to a mythical “better” time when their nation’s values were purer, people like themselves were respected, and common sense ruled the day. Their policy positions tend to deal with the symptoms of problems, like halting immigration when it reaches the border, and tend to ignore uncomfortable truths such as climate change by rejecting the views of recognized experts. What is happening now has occurred in the past. Experts on the temperance movement to end alcohol use in the US, for example, have noted that many supporters focused their criticisms on catholic immigrants from Italy and Ireland who may have taken a more liberal approach to alcohol than protestants, for example. Temperance was therefore partly an attempt to assert moral superiority over these newcomers, in a bid to have them abide by one version of “American” values. Another historical parallel: many supporters of Adolf Hitler were those whose wealth had evaporated with Germany’s hyper-inflation in the 1920s, and were particularly anxious about their professional and social status. These movements can generate outcomes such as reduced immigration or trade curbs that are only temporary palliatives, and can actually hinder economic growth. That in turn can lead to growing authoritarianism, increasing distrust of institutions, and a fetish for simplistic solutions to complex problems like the elimination of central banks, or closing off societies completely to trade and immigration.

name: Rising Consumerism
description: After decades of export-driven growth, China aims to shift its economy by boosting domestic consumption. Chinese consumer confidence has been resilient; the value of the country’s fast-moving consumer goods market rose by 4.3% in 2017, compared with 3.6% growth in the prior year, according to a report published by Bain & Company and Kantar Worldpanel. In 2016, the Economist Intelligence Unit projected that private consumption in China would grow in real terms by 5.5.% a year on average until 2030, at which point it will account for nearly half of the overall economy. Urbanization has boosted consumerism; nearly 60% of China’s population lived in a city as of 2018, according to estimates, and the country’s urban population is increasing by an estimated 2.4% annually, steadily convening greater numbers of middle-class shoppers in places with accessible retail outlets. China’s dynamic e-commerce market is also addressing rising consumption demands. In 2015, the Chinese agency responsible for internet affairs reported 668 million internet users in the country, of which 594 million were connected using smartphones. According to a report published in late 2017 by the McKinsey Global Institute, China accounted for 42% of global e-commerce, and processed 11 times more mobile payments than the US. Home-grown retailers in China are increasingly competitive, and adept at adapting to local market needs. The country’s services sector, which now accounts for more than half of the country’s economy, will become increasingly important as domestic demand for entertainment, recreation, and healthcare increases. Consumer behaviour in China is also generating larger numbers of outbound tourists. According to the World Tourism Organization, the number of outbound Chinese tourists surpassed 100 million in 2014, after more than a decade of double-digit annual percentage growth. In addition, Chinese tourists spent $261.1 billion in 2016, a 4.5% increase compared with the prior year and more than any other nationality, according to a report published in 2017 by Nielsen. A potential limiting factor for Chinese consumption, however, is the country’s high savings rate (that could be addressed, if the Chinese government provides better healthcare and pension coverage). In addition, a recent anti-corruption crackdown has dampened consumer appetite for luxury goods.

name: Rising Cost of Law
description: As the complexity of law and regulation increases, so do legal costs. Law has a tendency to accumulate; contracts become longer as lawyers add specific concerns, or account for new court decisions. Statutes and regulations, meanwhile, become longer as new circumstances or efforts to address unanticipated responses to the law arise. And, court decisions become longer as judges try to reconcile large bodies of pre-existing case law. Law can also become more complex as the diversity of interests and viewpoints grows, while legislation grows more intricate as political deals are implemented. Researchers have found that US Supreme Court opinions become harder to interpret as the number of judges signing onto a majority opinion increases. Longer, more ambiguous legal materials, and more complex procedures, have the effect of raising the cost of law by requiring more time and expertise. It is routine for the parties to litigation in the US to spend more on legal costs than the amount at stake in the case, for example. Indirect costs are also raised by increased legal complexity and uncertainty, while globalization can also increase the cost of law as international entities need to learn about an increasing number of jurisdictions; even startups can incur related costs, when they use teams that collaborate online from multiple locations. Higher legal costs impact government budgets, through the cost of financing courts and prosecutors, and due to the cost of financing legal aid. Complexity is not the only reason for higher legal costs; restrictive professional rules governing who can practice law, and where, and using what technology, business model, and contractual arrangement, can also contribute. The US and Canada, for example, require all legal work to be done by licensed lawyers with graduate training that can be prohibitively expensive, and prohibit these lawyers from forming arrangements with technology companies that could reduce costs. Many countries require lawyers to be licensed locally, increasing the cost of operating in multiple jurisdictions. Other countries prohibit lawyers from opening offices in multiple locations, or in partnership with non-lawyers, or under advertised brand names. All of these restrictions raise the cost of law, and threaten the development of technologies that could both increase quality and cut costs.

name: Rising Multipolarity
description: As globalization has spurred higher levels of economic growth around the world, new countries have emerged as major powers in world politics. This marks an extraordinary advance in terms of human development, as hundreds of millions of people escape poverty and join the middle class. At the same time, however, the economic rise of Brazil, China, India, and other emerging markets has upended the traditional power balance among countries - along with traditional structures of global governance. Whereas in the past a few large, industrialized countries could set the rules for the global economy, today a much broader consensus among nations is required. This is reflected in the increased importance of the G20 (as opposed to the more exclusive G7) as a critical venue for international economic coordination, and in the emergence of greater numbers of institutional investors from emerging markets who now wield global influence, such as the Beijing-based Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which began operations in 2016. Rising multi-polarity, or the distribution of power among a greater number of countries and entities, raises the possibility of a more balanced, and ultimately more legitimate form of global governance; more places can now have more of a say on the critical global issues that affect their respective citizens. However, this wider dispersion of global power has also created new sources of friction and risk, and even in some cases the greater possibility of armed conflict. That is due in part to the fact that the decision-making processes that underpin global governance do not tend to adapt and change as quickly as the relative influence of the countries involved. There is therefore an urgent need to find new ways to facilitate decision-making and international coordination, in order to ensure that global challenges can be met effectively. As greater numbers of more diverse countries must now reach agreement on how to best address global issues, the potential gridlock that could result would benefit no one. The ways in which emerging powers engage with existing structures of global governance, and the ways that established powers react to these changes, will define world politics in the 21st century.

name: Risk and Uncertainty
description: Many emerging multinationals can actually thrive in high-risk environments. In regions such as sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia, for example, rapid population growth is a potential asset for the future, but also generates tension due to high rates of youth unemployment; meanwhile political and legal institutions in these areas tend to be relatively weak, mostly as a result of a disastrous colonial heritage, ethno-religious conflicts, civil wars, and pervasive corruption. These also happen to be parts of the world that collectively hold as much as 70% of global fossil fuel and mineral reserves. As these countries and their consumer markets further integrate into the global economy, it will be crucial to understand the inherent risks that they pose. Many emerging multinationals were born in environments characterized by high levels of economic and political risk. They grew up in a context that forced them to cope with these risks, and even to capitalize on them. No wonder that many have therefore been able to aggressively expand into high-risk markets. Political risk is not confined to developing markets. In 2018, Chinese telecommunications giant ZTE was hit with a US government ban on its purchase of equipment from American firms, and carriers in the United Kingdom were warned against using its products, due to political and security concerns. Uncertainty is generally considered inimical to economic activity; consumers lose confidence, companies become reluctant to invest, and investors run for cover. One key source of geopolitical risk has to do with the deterioration of democratic practices. According to a report published  the Center for Systemic Peace in 2017, the number of countries designated “anocratic regimes,” which lack a capacity to manage conflict and foster social integration, and are vulnerable to autocratic rule, has nearly doubled since the end of the Cold War. Meanwhile failed states, such as Libya or South Sudan, where governments have lost control over part or all of their territory, have spawned chaos, lawlessness, and anarchy. Unintended fallout from the Arab Spring uprisings, and armed conflict throughout sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, account for most of the world’s anocracies and failed states. Given the present realities of geopolitical risk, companies that can cope relatively well will enjoy a competitive advantage, as distinctions between mature and volatile markets are increasingly blurred.

name: Risk-Return Ratios
description: Political stability, currency volatility, and a general lack of familiarity with a foreign environment can all generate significant real and perceived risks relative to the expected returns from development projects in emerging and frontier markets. Banks, asset managers, and other private capital providers have a fiduciary duty to ensure that capital is preserved, and so must ensure that any returns are risk-appropriate; if the risk premium for deals in developing countries is considered too high, private institutions will often opt to keep their investments in more familiar, developed markets. However, if projects in emerging markets can be efficiently structured and de-risked through Blended Finance, they can become more attractive investment options. Assessments can be skewed by uncertainty, however, and cautious investment behaviour. For example, the majority of infrastructure debt securities issued between 1983 and 2014 by corporate issuers outside of North America were investment grade, according to a report published by Moody’s Investors Service in 2015, and recent studies have actually found lower relative default rates for such bonds originating in emerging markets. Still, only a fraction of total institutional capital finds its way to projects in emerging and frontier markets, because of fundamental misperceptions about the associated risk. The challenge for projects in developing countries is therefore to try enhance returns for some capital tranches, while appropriately transferring risk to those interested parties best suited to manage it. Blended Finance addresses this challenge by pooling investors with different capital and risk profiles, in order to create commercial tranches that are each tailored with an appropriate balance of risk and return - in order to make a project bankable. This allows financiers to overcome real and perceived market failures, in order to support investment in projects that can deliver significant, positive development impact.

name: Risks to Space Sustainability
description: Since the start of the so-called Space Age in 1957, activity in space has expanded to an extent that threatens the sustainability of orbits (the natural pathways for satellites that circle Earth) - even as most countries have yet to launch a satellite. More than 95% of space debris in Earth’s orbit is composed of used materials, dead satellites, rocket parts, propellant residues, and nuts and bolts. About 23,000 pieces are tracked by the US Air Force, while more than 300,000 smaller, untracked objects pose a threat to active satellites (some of which have been destroyed) and astronauts; a US National Research Council Report published in 2011 noted that space debris had already reached a tipping point. Meanwhile risks resulting from the growing numbers of satellites include interference with radio signals. An increasing number of private satellite operators, lower launch costs, and governments’ inability to enforce sustainability guidelines mean these risks will become more pressing as the militarization of space increases. Private companies (mainly from the US) are preparing to launch thousands of low-earth orbit satellites, primarily to provide internet connectivity. Most will have limited maneuverability and short lifespans, and will add considerable traffic to already busy orbits; there is no universal, effective traffic management system to control this.  The International Space Station, the largest crewed spacecraft, already actively avoids space debris on a regular basis. Even if we were to stop sending new objects into space, debris would still increase due to chance collisions - because as large pieces collide, they produce more pieces. While technologies exist to start removing the most volatile pieces of debris, international cooperation is needed to finance this and account for related legal aspects. The Satellite Industry Association has estimated that about $127 billion in annual revenue from satellite services is vulnerable to debris, and the defence sector has expressed related concerns. Some attempts have been made to control debris. The Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee and the United Nations Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space have adopted related mitigation guidelines, for example. However, due to their non-binding nature and inability to address the removal of existing debris, these efforts may not fully address space sustainability. The World Economic Forum’s Global Future Council on Space Technologies has developed a “Space Sustainability Rating” meant to support existing guidelines, by publishing ratings of individual mitigation efforts - and thereby increasing transparency.

name: Robots at Work
description: Robots have long been used on factory floors for welding and painting. Now, they’re making custom-ordered hamburgers, navigating through crowded hotel lobbies, hopping on elevators, and delivering room service. Amazon has been at the forefront of introducing robots to our daily lives, with its clerk-free markets that enable automatic payment via credit card, Kiva merchandise handling systems, and drone delivery. Robots also enable exploration, by probing the depths of the ocean floor, deep space, the moon, and asteroids. The latest space-ready robots can work side-by-side with astronauts in the International Space Station, and US and Russian teams are working on robo-astronauts that could explore other planets. Robots are also being developed to perform crucial jobs during humanitarian crises. For example, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) Robotics Challenge is developing robots that would have been capable of saving lives during the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan. Other robots in development may perform hazardous deep mining jobs, work with toxic substances, and clean sewers. Drones in particular have captured the popular imagination; they are a popular option for aerial photography, and Amazon and others are testing their use for delivery.  In less dramatic fashion, robots can use an electronic brain located in the cloud to become trustworthy butlers, silently and faithfully listening to queries about traffic, the weather, and turning on the air conditioning. Next-generation robots will be performing tasks that require even more complex decision-making, aided by continuously increasing computing power. In January 2016 the company Nvidia unveiled a supercomputer capable of up to 24 trillion operations per second, equal to the power of 150 MacBook Pro notebook computers. This could enable a car to learn to drive by itself, through so-called reinforcement learning, rather than the conventional approach of finding a safe path by using real-time optimization. As related technologies mature, self-driving cars will become common, and will likely fundamentally change the job market by eliminating occupations like bus driver. Critical tasks that go beyond physical labour, such as reading x-ray films and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, are already being performed by computers. Discovering new medicines might even be a possibility; after all, artificial intelligence is already helping to dispense financial advice to many people, with considerable accuracy and speed.

name: Rule of Law and Enforcement
description: An effective, impartial and efficient legal system is the necessary foundation for efforts to curb corruption. Enforcing laws against officials who demand petty bribes, for example, has the instantaneous impact of removing an invisible tax levied on citizens seeking basic healthcare, or on businesses seeking simple documentation. It also makes a longer-term impact by shifting incentives; officials become more cautious about making such demands, because the risk associated with doing so has risen. Meanwhile citizens and businesses may start to refuse to pay bribes, because they see an opportunity to avoid related costs while still successfully interacting with the state. The confidence that can be inspired by such a legal framework can encourage companies to set up operations in a particular jurisdiction, rather than taking their business elsewhere. An economic analysis published in the journal World Development found that checks on corruption and “private capture” (the manipulation of public laws by private firms or individuals) had a stronger empirical relationship to economic growth than the protection of property rights in all 74 economies studied. Effective oversight of an independent judiciary is critical for establishing strong rule of law and public trust. The World Justice Project produces annual rankings of the rule of law in different countries. In December 2017, it published an evaluation of changes made to Mexico’s procedures for investigating crime, prosecution services, and trial organization. By the deadline for implementation of the new system, only about half of the country’s municipalities had complied, which is unfortunate as survey data has found that judges are far more likely to be present during court hearings under the new system - most likely because they are more frequently recorded. Corruption can be exported by multinationals operating in jurisdictions where the rule of law and law enforcement are relatively weak. The US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the UK Bribery Act of 2010 seek to clamp down on this phenomenon, as does the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) Anti-Bribery Convention. According to a Transparency International report on the subject published in 2015, the OECD convention is actively enforced in only two countries outside of the US and the UK: Germany and Switzerland. In addition, the convention was only moderately enforced in six more countries, according to the report, and the countries that enjoy active or moderate enforcement of the OECD convention account for less than a third of global exports.

name: Rural Development and Sustainability
description: Nearly 14% of the rural population in Peru, which overwhelmingly depends on agriculture for its economic well-being, is affected by extreme poverty, according to a 2016 report from the country’s National Institute of Statistics and Informatics; that compares with just 1% of Peru’s urban population, according to the report. Overall, nearly one quarter Peru’s employment as of 2017 was related to agriculture, which nonetheless accounted for less than 8% of the country’s GDP as of 2016, according to World Bank data.  Agriculture productivity in Peru lags behind that of other Latin American countries in part due to limited access to land and water. Only about one quarter of the country’s farmers owned officially-registered land as of 2012, according to the country’s National Agricultural Census (CENAGRO), which in turn limits farmers’ access to credit. According to the CENAGRO data, only about one in 10 farmers who sought a loan were able to obtain one. Agricultural loans represented just 5.5% the total loans granted in Peru during 2017, according to the country’s Superintendency of Banking, Insurance and Private Pension Funds. In addition, CENAGRO data showed that most farmers neither use improved seeds nor have received training or technical assistance. In order to increase agricultural productivity, the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) has recommended policy initiatives that emphasize the provision of rural infrastructure, clearer property rights, improved access to financing, and greater fostering of innovation. In addition to technical, land and credit issues, risks related to climate change also hamper Peru’s agriculture sector, according to research published in 2016 by the IDB. Peru ranked 64th out of 180 countries assessed in the 2018 Environmental Performance Index (EPI) produced by Yale University and Columbia University in collaboration with the World Economic Forum, below Uruguay, Colombia, and Costa Rica. Increased agricultural production has been linked to 130,000 hectares of deforestation annually in the Amazon region, where Peru has more than 73 million hectares of natural forest - equivalent to about 60% of the country’s total national territory - according to its Ministry of the Environment. Peru is one of the world’s leading producers of copper, silver, tin, zinc, lead and gold. As recently as 2012, more than half of the foreign currency entering the country was accounted for by the mining sector, according to the Peruvian Economy Institute, as well as one fifth of the country’s fiscal income, and 11% of overall GDP. However, the role of mining in Peru’s economy has declined in recent years. The country’s mineral rents as a percentage of GDP, or the difference between the value of their production at global market rates and the cost of production, fell from about 11% as of 2011 to about 5.4% as of 2015, according to World Bank data. The sector generates a significant amount of social and environmental conflicts, and broader, related multi-stakeholder dialog is called for in order to better develop its economic potential.

name: Safety and Security Risks
description: The recent rise in both physical and digital terrorism has been coupled with a surge in populism and xenophobia. This new global landscape has significant implications for the movement of people across borders, and for a travel and tourism industry that is responsible for the safety of millions of air travellers every day. Air travel is one of the safest modes of transportation. However, air travel security shocks have at times led to measures that have merely soothed the public - rather than contributing to the creation of a more secure environment. Opportunities to enhance travel safety and security exist through the use of data sharing technologies, and better collaboration among governments, international institutions and the private sector. Contrary to popular perception, travellers are willing to share their personal data in exchange for enhanced security and efficiency.﻿ Global leaders need to fundamentally rethink the policy framework governing the ways people move across international borders, in order to better ensure safety. The World Economic Forum’s 2017 report Digital Borders presented a vision for the future of travel where eligibility is based on the individual, rather than on the individual’s country of origin, and where technology is implemented to move from physical borders to digital borders that include digital identification and authentication, biometrics, and digitally-enabled security devices that increase accuracy and efficiency. In order to move from existing bilateral or multilateral travel facilitation programmes to a global system, a number of areas need to be addressed: the harmonization of intelligence and data-sharing; the global implementation of common standards set by the International Civil Aviation Organization; and a shift to secure digital processes. Countries should expand their existing multilateral agreements, and move towards a single application system for traveller programmes. These shifts would require greater cooperation and collaboration among governments, international organizations and travellers. By moving border management to a wholly automated, electronic platform that is built on verified biometric data, the international movement of people will not only become more efficient, but will also enable public safety officials to direct more of their attention and resources to the identification of genuine threats.

name: Safety, Security and the IoT
description: The Internet of Things, which is stringing the world around us together via the web, is melding the digital and the physical realms in a way that creates threats that have not been anticipated by conventional cyber security systems. The IoT’s breadth of scale and uses pose significant challenges by exposing large areas to unconventional attacks. Energy utilities, infrastructure, transportation, commerce, and peoples’ homes are all now interconnected and remotely addressable, creating an unprecedented potential for security breaches; the same interconnectivity that can create value also means that compromising a single node could trigger cascading social and economic effects. Not all security challenges are obvious, and the unintended consequences of connectivity are always possible. For example, a smart home makes life easier not just for its occupants, but for criminals as well. A voice-activated home assistant paired with a smart, IoT-connected lock is a great way to open a door without having to get up from the couch; it is also a great means for a thief to simply shout through an open window while homeowners are away in order to let himself in. Authentication, or an ability to clearly identify and trust both digital and physical data sources, is a critical when developing the reliable, real-time systems that make the Internet of Things valuable. The days of trusting “security through obscurity,” or relying on a general ignorance of the flaws in a system, are numbered - as the advent of the IoT has now placed the blueprints of formerly inaccessible systems all over the internet. What would once have simply been thought of as a safety oversight can now be a potent weapon, if placed in the wrong hands. As a result, security must be integrated into system design from the start. Systems must be hardened against worst-case scenarios and upgradable over the air, even if it means increased costs. A so-called “Cognitive Firewall” is one method of scalable, upgradable protection; it forms a self-learning system, capable of placing the commands it receives in context, and allowing only safe commands to pass from the cloud to a device for execution. Many people are unwitting participants in the Internet of Things, potentially unaware, for example, that their personal data can be exposed to the world by means of a coworker’s unsecured “smart” light switch. A comprehensive safety education for everyone is therefore essential.

name: Secure Data Transmission
description: Next-generation digital networks are expected to make broadband connectivity a reality anywhere, anytime. Every facet of our lives is going to be digitalized and networked, as governments around the world push initiatives involving self-driving vehicles, environmental monitoring and online payments. This will increase the exchange of sensitive data across networks, and the networking of critical assets. The key to the success of these initiatives is therefore the protection of data integrity, and of data privacy. Since the World War II, increasingly robust and diverse cryptographic techniques, used to essentially write sensitive information in code, have been deployed to keep the data on networks secure. State-of-the-art cryptographic techniques are based on the exchange of widely available public keys, and undisclosed private keys, both of which function like passwords and are related through complex mathematical expressions. Due to ever-increasing computing power, however, these keys may become vulnerable to so-called brute-force attacks, which involve testing all the possible combinations of characters in a key through extensive trial and error, in order to decrypt information. Traditionally, a dedicated security layer within a network’s protocol stack, or the software that sets the rules for a network’s interconnectivity, is used to provide secrecy - while the physical layer of networking equipment is limited to tasks related to signal processing and transmission. However, it has recently been discovered that the physical layer can also be used to potentially provide security. Emerging cryptographic techniques like quantum cryptography, which relies on physics rather than math in order to encode information using elements such as light particles, deserve attention; the first quantum transaction, in 2004, used entangled photons to transfer money into a bank account. Blockchain is another networking paradigm gaining traction, as a distributed, cryptography-based service enabler. Privacy is not necessarily guaranteed through blockchain, but the integrity of data can be ensured using the technology, which can also reduce transaction costs - and is expected to be adopted for a wide variety of applications in the near future. Policy-makers and system architects must take these new paradigms into account, when conceiving the next generation of communications infrastructure. In addition, communities focused on open source software, developers, industry groups must seek to ensure that proposed solutions are affordable, and can be widely adopted.

name: Securing People and Processes
description: Cyberthreats challenge our ability to harness the full benefits of the digital economy. Cyberattacks result in an annual loss of more than $400 billion for the global economy, according to Our Shared Digital Future, a report published by the World Economic Forum in 2018, while the average cost of a data breach is $3.62 million. In the first half of 2018 alone, more than 4 billion data records were compromised by malicious actors worldwide, according to the report; this translates into more than one million records that are lost or stolen every hour. In addition to resulting in data theft or loss, inadequate security can put the integrity of data into question - because malicious actors with network access can insert or remove any relevant data that are used for decision-making, for example, or for industrial processes. Although criminal activity is the source of the vast majority of cyberattacks, there has been a growing incidence of nation state-sponsored intrusions onto critical networks. Nation-state-sponsored and hacktivist-driven attacks on so-called Industrial Internet of Things systems in the utilities, oil and natural gas and manufacturing industries are increasing, according to a report published by Accenture in 2018; 66% of IT managers in the oil and natural gas industry surveyed for the report said digitization has made them more vulnerable. Such state-sponsored attacks, deployed as clandestine statecraft, can erode both public trust and sovereign authority. They also re-direct public resources to build tools that may eventually wind up in the hands of criminals, exacerbating the already significant threat posed to businesses and individuals. These activities actually threaten innovation itself, by depriving peaceful actors of trusted technology platforms for the development of new business and social models. Due to the inability of any one nation or company to solve these issues on their own, it is vital to consider security a global public good - and to act in concert to better ensure safe digital networks through global cooperation and commitments. Priorities for collaboration: Strengthening regulation that promotes transparency and security Training more cybersecurity professionals Informing and empowering decision-makers Boosting related innovation while advancing (public and corporate) cyber strategies Increasing intelligence sharing among actors

name: Securing the Environment
description: As a result of an acceleration of human economic activity since the mid-20th century, scientists say our planet is now entering a period of unprecedented environmental change. Biodiversity, the oceans, fresh water resources, and air quality are all under severe threat, creating the risk of irreversible environmental change. The World Economic Forum’s Global Risks Report has highlighted the strong connections that exist between the ineffective management of the global environmental commons and economic and other risks. The degradation of the environment not only poses risks to be dealt with in the future - it is already affecting human health and well-being, and creating negative economic feedback. Unusual precipitation amounts, for example, a greater likelihood of extreme storms, rising sea levels, coastal inundation, and heatwaves are now directly affecting our security, economic well-being, and health. In 2017, the world experienced 710 geophysical, meteorological, hydrological, and climatological “natural loss events,” or catastrophes, which was almost triple the number that had occurred in 1980. These events caused roughly $330 billion in damage, of which less than half was insured. They also displaced 23 million people from their homes. About 91% of the global population lives in places that fail to meet World Health Organization air quality guidelines, and the Lancet Commission (an initiative started by the medical journal The Lancet, the Global Alliance on Health and Pollution, and the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai) has found that roughly 7 million people die annually from exposure to air pollution - equal to roughly one in eight global deaths every year. In addition, water scarcity is already a reality for 1.9 billion people around the world, hindering human health, food production, and energy generation. In the face of these challenges, we need to redesign systems and business models to better reflect and manage the links between our environments, societies, and economies.

name: Security
description: Kenya’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of organized crime, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 48.10, resulting in a rank of 114th out of 140 countries; and in terms of the reliability of police services where it has a progress score of 52.90 that results in a rank of 81st out of 140 countries. Other indicators reflect a better performance: homicide rate, where it has a progress score of 85.20 that results in a rank of 89th out of 140 countries; and in terms of the incidence of terrorism where it has a progress score of 87.00 that results in a rank of 125th out of 140 countries.

name: Security and Conflict
description: The Fourth Industrial Revolution will dramatically affect the scale and character of conflict. Already, distinctions between war and peace, and between combatants and non-combatants, are becoming blurred. Meanwhile new technologies are making the battlefield both local and global. Groups such as the Islamic State may physically operate in defined areas, but can recruit fighters from hundreds of different countries, largely through social media.
