Modern conflict is increasingly hybrid in nature, combining traditional battlefield techniques with elements previously associated with armed, non-state actors; the internet is becoming as much a theatre of engagement as land, sea, and air. It is inevitable that future conflict will include an online dimension, as combatants disrupt, confuse, and destroy communications and decision-making capabilities. This will not only lower the threshold of what constitutes war, but will also blur the distinction between war and peace; any network or connected device, from military systems to electricity grids, can be hacked and attacked. The traditional concept of an adversary is also affected. You may have far less certainty about who is attacking you, or even if you have been attacked at all. Autonomous warfare involving the deployment of military robots and artificial intelligence-powered weaponry will play a transformative role. The ocean floor and space are also likely to become increasingly militarized, as more actors, both government and commercial in nature, gain an ability to launch satellites and mobilize unmanned, underwater vehicles capable of disrupting communications. Criminal gangs are already using off-the-shelf drones to spy on and attack rivals. Autonomous weapons that are capable of identifying targets and deciding to open fire without human intervention will become increasingly feasible; while neurotechnologies that can interact with a human brain are currently being employed to solve medical problems, in the future they could have military uses. A computer system attached to brain tissue could enable a paralysed patient to control a robotic limb, and it could also be used to direct a bionic soldier. Another possible scenario: brain devices for treating Alzheimer’s could be strategically implanted in soldiers in order to erase memories, or create new ones. Governing security and warfare in the Fourth Industrial Revolution is as complex as the technologies that are driving the revolution forward. Concerned stakeholders will need to cooperate in new and more comprehensive ways in order to control potentially damaging developments. Ideally, this can be done without impeding innovation and economic growth.

name: Security and Violence
description: Latin America and the Caribbean make up the most violent region in the world, home to just 9% of the global population but about one third of all homicides, according to a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank in 2018. As of 2015, the region had a homicide rate of 24 per 100,000 that was four times the global average, according to the report. A 2017 study published by the IDB estimated that the direct costs of crime in Latin American countries (including losses for victims, the loss of income for prisoners, private spending on corporate and household security, and public spending on police, prisons and criminal justice systems) equalled an average of 3% of GDP - or twice what the average cost is in developed countries. Issues including organized crime, drug trafficking, money laundering, and impunity on the part of corrupt officials have not been tackled, as urban populations continue to grow. According to the United Nations Population Division, 80% of the Latin American and Caribbean population lived in cities as of 2014, which is expected to increase to 85% by 2030. Relatively high rates of youth unemployment contribute to increased crime. According to the Igarapé Institute, as of 2016, a 1% increase in unemployment among men in Brazil contributed to a 2.1% increase in the murder rate, for example. The same institute reported in 2016 that roughly 13% of the young people in Latin America and the Caribbean were unemployed, or nearly three times the percentage for adults. Those young people who are employed are largely working in the informal, unregulated economy. This means that more than 20 million young people in the region are part of the so-called “neither-nor” generation: neither enrolled in formal education or training, nor employed. Organized crime and drug trafficking particularly affect parts of Central America and Mexico, where poverty and a lack of opportunity mean that young people more easily slip into these illicit activities. In Venezuela social and political unrest have spiked and are undermining security, while other countries such as Brazil have seen some related improvement - but may be in danger, in light of economic downturns and increased unemployment.

name: Security and Violence in Mexico
description: Since the beginning of the Mexican government’s so-called war on drugs in 2006, the country has experienced a severe uptick in violence and suffered from a wide-ranging security crisis, according to a report published by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. The proximity and size of the consumer market in the US - the main destination for narcotics in the region - has made Mexico both a place of origin and a transit route. This has triggered widespread violence, particularly in cities along Mexico’s northern border. As a consequence of the violence, the military has played a prominent role in seeking to maintain public security and confront organized crime - undercutting an already fragile institutional framework for combating illicit activity by spreading further violence (in 2018, homicides in the country rose by more than 15% compared with the prior year, to a record 33,341, according to the country’s Secretariat of Security and Citizen Protection). This increased violence has spawned human rights violations such as denying the accused access to justice, forced disappearances, and threats made against both human rights defenders and journalists. Mexico ranked 147th out of 180 countries in the 2018 World Press Freedom Index. Drug-related violence has had a direct effect on Mexico’s economy. A 2013 Inter-American Development Bank working paper on the economic consequences of drug violence in Mexico noted that between 2002 and 2010, an increase of 10 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants led to a two-percentage-point reduction in employment over the same period at the municipal level. It also led to a 1.5% increase in unemployment, a nearly 0.4% decline in business ownership, and a 1.2% decline in wages. In 2018, the overall economic impact of violence in the country rose by 10% compared with the prior year, to the equivalent of about $268 billion, according to a report published in 2019 by the Institute for Economics and Peace. That was equal to 24% of Mexico’s GDP, according to the report, and on a per person basis amounted to roughly 41,000 pesos - or more than five times the average monthly salary of a Mexican worker. The government now faces the daunting task of breaking the cycle of official and criminal impunity, by effectively investigating, processing, and sanctioning those responsible for human rights violations and organized crime.

name: Security in Nigeria
description: While Boko Haram terrorists have been somewhat curtailed, other groups have been kidnapping, robbing, and marauding at a rate that poses a serious threat to Nigeria’s social fabric and economy. In particular, nomadic Fulani herdsmen who have clashed with mostly Christian farmers, and Niger Delta militants, threaten both the country’s unity and two key sectors of its economy: oil and gas, and agriculture. Violence between the herdsmen and farmers killed more than 1,300 people during the first half of 2018, according to a report published by the International Crisis Group, and has evolved from spontaneous provocations to deadlier, planned attacks. Meanwhile the Niger Delta militants have destroyed oil pipelines and facilities; during some months in 2016, production capacity fell from a projected 2.2 million barrels of crude oil a day to just 800,000 as a result. This destruction has cut into government revenue, and unsettled potential foreign and local investors. One widely-acknowledged reason for the persistent threat of violence is the longstanding exploitation of oil-producing communities, by both the government and companies. While agencies such as the Niger Delta Development Commission have been formed to address development problems in the region, their impact has so far been limited (and sometimes mired in corruption and mismanagement). In search of food and water for their cattle, the nomadic Fulani herdsmen move from the arid north to the south during the dry season. They lack designated grazing areas, and their clashes with local farmers often lead to property destruction and death. The increased frequency of these attacks has led to a widely-held perception that the government is too weak or indifferent to deal with the problem. This has led to calls for the transfer of some government responsibilities, such as internal security, from the federal government to the regions. The inadequate number of security officers for a country of nearly 200 million people is a major constraint; according to Nigeria Police Force, the country has about one police officer for every 538 Nigerians. It is not just the economy that is at risk - the unity of the country is at stake. Ways to best address the problem include more focused and sustainable development of the Niger Delta, more appropriate legislation and enforcement for the cattle ranching, greater education and employment opportunities for young people, more security personnel, and a strengthening of the legal system.

name: Security of Things
description: The so-called Internet of Things ties everything together, from our cars to our phones, to our medical devices and our houses, through internet connectivity. As devices more deeply penetrate our lives, we face new privacy and security vulnerabilities. With so much data being created, transferred and analysed, questions about consumer consent, compensation, and hidden costs must be addressed. The research firm Gartner has estimated that the total number of connected “things” will more than double to 20.4 billion by 2020 from 8.4 billion in 2017, while security spending related to the Internet of Things will reach $1.5 billion in 2018, a 28% increase compared with the prior year. The proliferation of related devices brings educational and other benefits, but also creates security concerns and raises ethical questions - such as, for example, to what degree insurance companies should be able to use personal biometric data to calculate premiums, particularly from unconsenting customers. Even Barbie Dolls now collect and analyse data. In 2015, the toy company Mattel released a Wi-Fi connected "Hello Barbie" doll that uses speech-recognition software and progressive learning features to “talk.” As developers have sought to meet the growing demand for the Internet of Things, they have failed to adequately provide security and protect customer privacy. This will become an immense problem, as manufacturers depend on accurate shipping information, militaries depend on maintaining full control of armed drones, and patients depend on properly functioning, wireless insulin pumps. All could put privacy, money and lives at risk. When it comes to privacy, for example, the rules governing how customers can be treated by companies, based on personal characteristics, need to be more clearly defined; clear consent, information, and possibly even compensation should be exchanged. In terms of manufacturing, privacy and security must be implemented as fundamental features, as devices are designed. In 2016, Dyn, one of a number of DNS providers that enable the basic infrastructure of the internet, was attacked by thousands of compromised Internet of Things devices - resulting in downtime for many major websites in Europe and North America. Not only was this attack massive in terms of scale and impact, it was also notable for the ease with which it was mounted, as it only utilized a fraction of the total number of devices that had been compromised.

name: Self-driving Cars
description: Self-driving vehicles will save lives. More than 90% of crashes can be tied to human choice or error (as opposed to vehicle malfunction or an environmental factor), according to the results of a US National Motor Vehicle Crash Causation Survey published in 2015. The use of intelligent, self-driving car technology could therefore result in 90% fewer road accidents, according to the consultancy BCG. Self-driving vehicle technology could also lead to a 40% improvement in fuel economy, according to a study published by BCG and the World Economic Forum in 2014. In addition, self-driving vehicles could help elderly populations remain mobile, which may become more important due to demographic shifts; the number of people in the world aged 60 or above is expected to more than double between 2017 and 2050, from 962 million to 2.1 billion, according to the United Nations. Self-driving vehicles are already being put to the test around the world. Their adoption will require a large-scale re-purposing of urban space, including parking areas and traffic lanes. However, challenges related to legislation, cyber-risk, liability issues, infrastructure and technology are slowing their rate of commercialization. Increasingly autonomous transportation of people and goods will have major ramifications for employment and job skill requirements. Nearly 3% of all workers in the US are employed in driving occupations, which are generally deemed good jobs because they keep people above the poverty line, according to Stick Shift, a report published by the Center for Global Policy Solutions in 2017. More than 1.5 million people were employed as drivers in the road haulage sector in 19 European countries surveyed in a study produced in 2015 for the European Parliament, while in the US, there are about 3.5 million truck drivers, according to the American Trucking Associations. All are in danger of having their livelihoods fundamentally altered.

name: Setting the Financial Rules
description: The advent of new laws and regulations can sometimes benefit financial firms; the US Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, for example, which was passed in 2017, meant that net income for the US banking industry increased by $12.1 billion in 2018 compared with the prior year, rather than increasing by just $5.6 billion (according to a report published by Deloitte). However, other new rules place significant requirements on banks. The European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation, which went into effect in 2018, has had a significant impact on banks; it requires them (and other companies) to be transparent with clients about what personal data they are collecting and why, and to delete that data when a client moves on to another bank. They face fines equal to as much as 4% of their global revenue for any breaches. As more banks seek to outsource IT management (as a means to cut costs), that exposes more of their client data to third parties - and elevates risk of a GDPR breach. In addition, the EU’s Revised Payment Service Directive, or PSD2, creates new competitive challenges, by enabling companies that do not traditionally provide financial services to do so. So-called crypto-assets, or digital currencies like Bitcoin that are protected by cryptography, have stirred speculation about their viability for everyday financial transactions (while also stirring simple speculation; the price of Bitcoin fell by roughly 70% during 2018, after rising by nearly 1,400% in 2017). The growth in interest in crypto-assets has spurred regulators to take a closer look at related trading and financing. The Financial Stability Board said in 2018 that “vigilant monitoring” of crypto-assets is needed, in light of the speed at which the market has developed. Some regulators have taken a flexible approach; Switzerland allows crypto-related startups to take in up to 100 million francs in deposits before they require a banking license, for example. When it comes to regulating individual banks, Switzerland is an example of a relatively active regulator (its probes have related to everything from alleged FIFA corruption to the Petrobras scandal). In the US, the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul after the financial crisis was meant to move away from microprudential supervision of individual banks, to a macroprudential approach aimed at broader stability; the Trump administration has since sought to ease some aspects of Dodd-Frank.

name: Shaping Societies
description: Mobile chat applications like WhatsApp and social media platforms like Twitter have created tremendous opportunities for people to cooperate, and for businesses to promote themselves. But they have also atomized societies, and made entire communities vulnerable to political manipulation. A need to manage the resulting impact will likely be an enduring policy challenge for government decision-makers. The Fourth Industrial Revolution brings with it opportunities to challenge and change existing assumptions behind policies, cultures, and values. The technology developments driving this industrial era can be designed in ways that either bolster inclusion of the traditionally underrepresented, or exclude vast swathes of the population and amplify existing problems. While sharing economy services ranging from ride-hailing to home repair have outmanoeuvred regulators by leveraging technology, and transformed many thousands of unemployed or under-employed people into small-scale entrepreneurs, this model has also displaced regulated, relatively well-paid and secure jobs in transportation and other sectors. An ability to look beneath the surface of attractive statistics like productivity increases, or increased values for investor portfolios, is therefore a key leadership trait. Leaders must try to assess how it is that major technological advances are shaping societies in less-than-obvious ways, creating potential long-term problems with inequality, driving new or increased consumer needs, producing market inefficiencies, and feeding on policy gaps - in order to help uncover the new and disruptive ideas that can positively shape economies, societies, and governments. One way to encourage people to reconsider values that feed inequality, and to foster a wider, systemic impact is to build a more inclusive global economy. In its World Economic Outlook report published in late 2018, the International Monetary Fund cited rising inequality is among the most prominent obstacles for global economic growth. Low-income countries in particular require greater investment in physical infrastructure, and an enabling environment for competition and trade, according to the report. A willingness on the part of both private sector and public sector leaders to engage with actors who have differing views on these issues is critical in the midst of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, which demands careful, consensus-based responses to best shape governance in a way that takes diverse values into account.

name: Shifting Demographics and Lifestyles
description: People are both living longer, and suffering more dramatically from the effects of their bad habits. The world’s current population of 7.6 billion is expected to increase to 8.6 billion by 2030 - and then jump to 9.8 billion by 2050, according to the United Nations’ 2017 revision of The World Population Prospects. Meanwhile increasing life expectancy will lead to a doubling of people in the world who are at least 60 years of age or older by 2050, and then a tripling of that age group fifty years after that. Much of this population expansion will be the result of reductions in mortality, both from infectious disease and for those under five years old. However, it is being offset by the rise of non-communicable diseases, which are often linked to unhealthy behaviour as people age. The World Health Organization has reported that as of 2015, these diseases accounted for 70% of all deaths worldwide, and three quarters of them occurred in low- and middle-income countries. Nearly half of non-communicable, disease-related deaths in these countries occur before the age of 70, and are therefore considered premature - and the majority result from cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, diabetes and cancer stemming from tobacco use, excessive alcohol use, poor diet, and a lack of physical activity. The health care costs and reduced productivity associated with these non-communicable diseases force millions of people into poverty every year, and stifle development in vulnerable regions. Adequately responding to the twin challenges of these diseases and ageing populations, not to mention increases in mental health disorders and violence, will require major changes to health care systems, especially in low- and middle-income countries. Primary prevention, detection, screening, and treatment of non-communicable diseases, and palliative care for the terminally ill, are all often missing from health systems in these countries, which are more often designed to respond to acute infections. Potential low-cost solutions for reducing risk factors (such as comprehensive control of tobacco products) exist for both governments and the private sector. Innovative partnerships across sectors including health, finance, transportation, education, and agriculture will be required.

name: Shifting Demographics, Growing Wealth
description: The world’s emerging market and developing economies accounted for more than 59% of global GDP by late 2018, up from about 36% in 1988, according to data published by the International Monetary Fund. Over that same period, advanced economies saw their contributions to global GDP slip to about 41% of the total from roughly 64%, according to the data. China has been on pace to overtake the US as the world’s biggest economy by 2030, according to an analysis published by HSBC in 2018, and there are abundant examples of other fast-growing emerging markets; the five fastest-growing economies in 2018 were Dominica (with 8.8% annual GDP growth), India, Bhutan, Anguilla, and Ethiopia. As developing economies expand, there are implications for global monetary policy and international governance. For example, UBS published research in mid-2018 noting that because China had been tightening monetary policy for more than a year, it was having the knock-on effect of slowing global growth - a dynamic that other monetary policy-makers would likely have to contend with. China’s development of the Asian Infrastructure Bank and New Development Bank has meanwhile raised questions about the future relevance of the World Bank.      China is now number two in the world when it comes to number of dollar millionaires, (behind the US, and ahead of Japan), and is also second in terms of ultra-high net worth individuals, according to a report published in 2018 by Credit Suisse. When it comes to the middle class China also dominates, according to the report; among people endowed with “mid-range” wealth, or a net worth between $10,000 and $100,000, China accounted for nearly half the total global population. The growing global middle class, fuelled by emerging economies, is changing the ways that trade is conducted and goods are sold. It is also shifting the focus of global banks. Dozens of foreign banks have begun operating in China, in hopes of tapping into the biggest consumer and retail banking market in the world. However, they maintain relatively few branches there, and are subjected to significant financial regulations and capital controls that limit their ability to fund their operations from abroad.

name: Shifting Ocean Governance
description: The oceans have always been difficult to govern; they cover 90% of the habitable space on the Earth, creating an immense, supranational domain with unique regulatory challenges. Unlike most natural assets on land, many ocean resources (such as the bluefin tuna that is prized for sushi) regularly swim across jurisdictional boundaries. In addition, damage incurred within one nation’s jurisdiction (like plastic pollution) can impact nations many thousands of kilometres away. Meanwhile climate change is driving seafood stocks towards the planet’s poles, to escape warming waters. This can create worrisome volatility in less-developed regions - as fish travel out of the reach of countries that need them most. Unfortunately, policies that can properly address these issues have been deferred. Two thirds of the oceans are on the high seas, or outside of the jurisdiction of any single country. The United Nations has committed to developing a first-of-its-kind, legally-binding treaty to better manage biodiversity and resources on the high seas by 2020. If it is successfully implemented, this could be a significant boon for ocean biodiversity. The cross-border migration of valuable seafood has the potential to not only deprive developing economies of resources, but also spur regional conflict. Research published in the journal Science in 2018 suggested that as many as 70 countries will see new fish stocks in their national waters by the year 2100, as a result of climate change. New international agreements are needed to govern the sharing of fishery resources, and to prevent countries from overharvesting stocks when they realize their assets are migrating beyond their borders. One positive development in the world of ocean governance has been the establishment of marine protected areas. These can buy time for at-risk ecosystems to better adapt to climate change. However, based on a review of 144 studies, researchers at the University of York have concluded that about 30% of the oceans would need to be placed within protected areas in order to meet ocean health management goals - though just over 7% is currently protected. The United Kingdom has protected an area of ocean larger than the country’s own land mass, and Chile, the US, and Kiribati have established protected areas that are collectively larger than Italy - now, other countries need to catch up.

name: Shifting Trade Environment
description: A belief in free trade is central to the European Union, which derives much of its strength and stability from trade relationships. Economic relationships formed the foundation on which the union was based; by linking European means of production it was hoped that war between European states would no longer be an option. As of 2016, intra-European trade in goods was valued at €3.1 billion, while trade between Europe and external countries was valued at just €1.8 billion, according to European Commission figures. More than on any other issue, the EU has a single voice when it comes to trade; it represents member states at the World Trade Organization, negotiates free trade agreements, and regulates tariffs. The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), and a formerly planned EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) point to EU trade priorities. However, US President Donald Trump’s decision in 2018 to announce the imposition of tariffs on steel and aluminium from the EU cast a shadow over longstanding trade relations between allies. The EU has existing free trade agreements with Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries, Japan, Mercosur (Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) and Mexico.  As free trade increasingly comes under attack in the Western world, most concerning for the EU is the current US administration’s anti-free trade stance. Many of President Trump’s supporters have designated globalization as a prime enemy, and the president has frequently spoken out against free trade. EU officials have brought a case against the US's use of a national-security justification for steel and aluminum tariffs to the WTO. As the US under the Trump administration is unlikely to bow to a WTO ruling, however, a trade war with the EU could be on the horizon. Even within the EU, belief in free trade is weakening, as it is challenged by populists and as unions prove to be unable to soften the blow of globalization for workers. The TTIP between the EU and the US had already faced considerable criticism within Europe before the Trump administration decided to not pursue it. Reconciling increased public criticism of free trade with the demands of globalization will be a key challenge for the EU in the future.

name: Shrinking Space for Civil Society
description: In many parts of the world, legal systems have been used to stifle dissent, and prevent members of civil society from speaking out on issues and mobilizing constituents. When civil society organizations question policy implications, or undertake advocacy to directly influence government action, they tend to face challenges to their legitimacy. That in turn can have implications for the private sector. In Turkey, the non-governmental organization Freedom House has noted that since 2013, many critics of the government have been subjected to intrusive tax and regulatory inspections, and companies in the country associated with the outlawed Gülen movement have been confiscated - particularly following an attempted coup in 2016. According to media reports, negative perceptions of the Turkish government’s ability to balance its authority with the effective management of the economy have hurt the value of the country’s currency, with the lira falling to record lows compared with the US dollar during 2018. Venezuela has faced similar issues, according to Freedom House, which noted in its 2018 Freedom in the World report that property rights in the country have been affected by price controls and nationalizations, and politicized hiring within state-owned enterprises is common. A robust civil society is usually an indicator of a correspondingly healthy business environment, with greater transparency, lower levels of corruption, and more robust rule of law. That’s because a vocal civil society can be a barometer of a government’s confidence and stability - which is likely important for businesses looking to invest in a particular region or country. The economic effects of squelching civil society can be far-reaching, and dramatic. According to blog post published by the American think tank the Center for Strategic & International Studies in 2017, Hungary’s government has moved in recent years to diminish the independence of democratic institutions like the media and the judiciary, as a means of solidifying control. During the same period, Hungary’s regional economic competitiveness has declined, according to a report published by the US Department of State’s Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs in 2017. In industries including media and retail, unpredictable regulatory policies in Hungary have favoured national and government-linked companies, according to the report, while the Hungarian government’s withdrawal from the transparency-focused Open Government Partnership has raised concerns, and its strong anti-migrant rhetoric has made it more difficult for Hungarian subsidiaries of US multinationals to obtain approval for new investment in the country.

name: Skill Building for Infrastructure
description: Delivering infrastructure may be vital for economic growth and improving standards of living, but it is being hindered by a talent shortage. The gap between the investment in infrastructure that the world needs, and what is actually being invested, is projected to grow from about $500 billion per year in 2020 to $800 billion just twenty years later; much of that lag results from a lack of appropriate skills in both developed and developing economies. According to a report published by the African Development Bank in 2018, most pension funds in Africa lack the technical skills to assess complicated infrastructure projects, for example, and public-private partnership agreements are often poorly structured and drafted due to a lack of relevant skills among government employees. In developed economies, companies are finding it challenging to attract talent, in particular to the engineering and construction field. Companies that develop infrastructure are often perceived as innovation laggards in a world where tech and finance have become more prominent. According to a report published in 2017 by the construction company Kier Group in the United Kingdom, construction, development, and related services are all having trouble attracting people to fields perceived as muddy, manual, male dominated, poorly paid, and non-academic. To help developing economies build the skills base they need to work with international partners and deliver infrastructure projects, programs have been developed recently including the Africa Infrastructure Fellowship Programme, which is led by the World Economic Forum, the Global Infrastructure Hub, which was created by the G20, and Meridiam, which trains African civil servants on public procurement best practices. In developed economies, the private sector has taken the lead. AECOM, one of the world’s largest engineering firms, said in a report published in 2018 that one quarter of the “civil infrastructure decision makers” in North America that it surveyed cited skills and talent shortages as obstacles to progress, and one fifth of those surveyed said difficulty finding the right talent caused major delays. In response, the company created its “Skills 2030” manifesto to try to help spur industry-wide change, disrupt traditional management and training practices, and attract the engineers it needs for the future.

name: Smart and Innovative Cities
description: The increased use of technology and data analysis is enabling the development of “smart” cities, and revolutionizing urban settings. The nature of urban transportation and logistics is changing rapidly as a result of the sharing economy, for example, while e-commerce and e-payment systems are shifting more businesses out of brick-and-mortar real estate and into the virtual realm. This phenomenon has triggered the so-called "retail apocalypse" in the US, which began roughly a decade ago and has involved record numbers of brick-and-mortar store closures; there were 8,500 store closures in the country during 2017, according to a report published by Cushman & Wakefield, surpassing the number closed during the Great Recession, and closures during 2018 were expected to meet or exceed that level. One key element of smart cities is cashless payments - which bring with them a need for enhanced security and governance. Overall, the general increase in the interactivity of urban services necessitates smart planning that can enable maximum efficiency. Co-working spaces, ubiquitous science and technology parks and “knowledge corridors” will likely become the norm for cities everywhere. The increasing speed with which know-how is disseminated via these developments will likely further revolutionize how we think about ways to best enable efficient use of real estate space in the future.

name: Smarter Infrastructure for Mobility
description: Throughout the 20th century, countries focused on the development of physical infrastructure like roads, ports, and railways in order to boost economic development. Now, the focus has shifted to digital infrastructure needs. Still, even as digital and other types of infrastructure are recognized as essential for the movement of people and goods, and for the basic functioning of economies, infrastructure the world over has languished - resulting in a global annual total infrastructure funding gap of close to $800 billion, according to a McKinsey Global Institute report published in 2016. That came even as the world had spent $9.5 trillion (equivalent to 14% of global GDP) during the prior year on infrastructure - primarily related to transportation, social infrastructure like education and healthcare, and real estate, according to a subsequent McKinsey Global Institute report. Transportation alone accounted for nearly $1.1 trillion during the year, according to the subsequent report, and a number of impending technology disruptions promise to shape transportation in ways that cannot yet be predicted, like increased electrification and autonomous vehicles. The better integration of emerging digital infrastructure into the broader infrastructure landscape will be key for developing smart and sustainable mobility systems. However, the cost of developing digital infrastructure remains high; the launch of a single satellite can require several hundred million dollars. As a result, there is an increasing need to attract more private funding. In addition to digital infrastructure, there is a corresponding need to develop dependable, basic infrastructure geared for fostering the burgeoning digital economy. According to a report published by the consultancy BCG, about 3 billion people and organizations were already using the internet every day to shop and interact by 2015. Amazon alone has been the source of hundreds of warehouses, and tens of thousands of delivery vans, and is now estimated to deliver nearly half of the orders made through the site on its own; recent additions to its delivery capability include the rental of dozens of Boeing jets. Amazon’s Prime service in particular, which involves faster and free shipping for members, has spurred an expanded need for infrastructure - and resulted in increased wear and tear.

name: Social Cohesion
description: France has a long history of immigration, beginning in earnest during the second half of the 19th century. Although the size of France's foreign-born population is on par with that of other European countries, it has one of the highest proportions of immigrant descendants. However, French law prohibits the collection of official statistics based on ethnicity - which makes it difficult to draw an accurate picture of the country’s true diversity. While only 25% of French people perceive social cohesion in the country as being strong, according to the Directorate for Research, Studies, Evaluation and Statistics, 93% of citizens report feeling integrated. A joint survey conducted by two national institutes found that the vast majority of the children of immigrants in the country have obtained French citizenship, and demonstrate a strong sense of national identity; yet nearly half of immigrants with French nationality, and one-quarter of the children of immigrants, feel they are not perceived as French. Clearly, diversity has not yet been fully incorporated into the idea of “Frenchness.” The arrival of many thousands of asylum seekers to France since 2015 has turned immigration policy and asylum for migrants into hot political issues. Despite the country’s equality imperative, France granted refugee status to only about 13,000 people in 2017, according to the European Council on Refugees and Exiles, compared with nearly 124,000 for Germany. As a result of growing levels of wealth and income inequality in France, globalization is increasingly perceived as only benefiting the few. According to the French Observatory of Inequalities, a private organization, the richest 10% of the population receive more than 25% of overall income, while half the population enjoys only 8% of the nation’s wealth. The limited possibilities for upward social mobility are increasing tension and weakening social cohesion, which contributed in 2018 to an outpouring of public anger by the gilets jaunes (“yellow vests”) - a broad movement that has successfully opposed some of President Emmanuel Macron’s economic reforms. In order to try to bring together social, political, and economic actors in France to revamp civic participation - and increase local participatory democracy - President Macron announced in early 2019 plans for a “grand debate” on issues like taxes, climate change, and public services. In order to succeed, this approach must take into account rural areas of the country, where significant concerns include gaining better connections to major hubs, access to digital tools, and adequate public and social services. The Russian Federation’s middle class has grown significantly, but much of the recently-created wealth in the country has been unequally distributed. Thanks to greater mobility and connectedness, Russians have increased expectations for their socioeconomic well-being, and there is growing popular discontent with the delivery of public services. Perceived impediments to professional success and restraints on political and press freedoms add to discontent, while also fuelling nationalism and a distrust of outsiders. Some metrics reflect significant improvements for Russian society. Average life expectancy in the country reached 71.9 years in 2016, according to government statistics. That is a significant increase from 67.8 years as of 1992, though still lags behind the European Union average of 83.3 years as of 2015. Other metrics are less encouraging. While the Russian Federation’s birth rate per 1,000 people had been roughly even with its number of deaths per 1,000 people in 2016, for the first half of 2017 the number of deaths per 1,000 people was 12.9, compared with 11.3 births, according to data published by the country's Federal State Statistics Service.

name: Social Entrepreneurship
description: Social enterprises can be non-profits (like Goodwill thrift shops in the US), for-profits (like Ethiopia-based fair trade footwear maker Oliberté), or a hybrid of both. They are entrepreneurial organizations designed to solve problems in innovative ways, and produce benefits that blend positive social and environmental impacts with financial returns. They also try to provide innovative solutions for big, societal problems in a self-sufficient way by using market-based mechanisms - and tend to maximize resources for the greatest possible impact, while placing a social mission at the core of their business. Much like traditional entrepreneurs, social entrepreneurs often have a unique ability to sense and act on opportunities by applying creative thinking, and they can benefit from a tireless determination to create new products, services, and markets. What distinguishes a social entrepreneur is his or her targeting of underserved populations, and their commitment to disrupting the status quo by generating social impact at a grand scale.  Social enterprises deploy a diverse range of models and focus on a variety of different areas. In their 2008 book The Power of Unreasonable People, John Elkington and Pamela Hartigan, founding partners of the consultancy Volans Ventures and leading figures in the field of social innovation, defined several possible models for social enterprises: a Leveraged Non-Profit makes innovative use of financial and other resources in order to respond to social needs; a Hybrid Non-Profit is willing to use profits generated by some activities to sustain other operations that have a social purpose; and a Social Business Venture is set up as a for-profit business designed to spur social change. Because the public sector is the primary provider of social services to the poor, many social entrepreneurs partner with governments in roles such as service providers, providers of technical assistance to public employees while teaching them new skills, and as advocates that help craft new laws and policies. While the field is growing, social entrepreneurs still face significant challenges. They are often plagued by a lack of funding, a shortage of business skills, problems with scalability, and a dearth of supportive regulation. Because their business ideas include bold, novel concepts, investors often assign them a high-risk profile.

name: Social Fragmentation in Pakistan
description: Pakistani society is a blend of cultures, languages, ethnicities, beliefs - and social classes. Since the 1980s, the country has been transformed into a state that values security above all else, in contrast to the vision of Pakistan’s founder Muhammad Ali Jinnah - who sought to establish a people-centric, inclusive welfare state where all are treated as equal citizens. This has led to fragmentation and deprivation. The country’s ruling elite does not seem ready to accept the fact that if society remains fragmented along ethnic, social, economic, gender, and religious lines, it will lead to conflict, social exclusion, and exploitation, often motivated by religion or politics. However, if society is tolerant, and pluralistic in approach, it will be strengthened by greater social cohesion. Social bonds in Pakistan seem weak, as the divide between haves and have-nots has widened. The government’s Economic Survey of Pakistan 2017-18 showed that the country’s poverty rate had declined to 24.3% from 50.4% in 2005-06; however, independent sources suggest the rate is actually much higher than 24.3%, based on the situation on the ground and how poverty is being defined. The exploitation of the poor, and related structural imbalances, sustain social polarization. While the government led by Prime Minister Imran Khan has taken on a reform agenda, the electioneering that led to the formation of the government aggravated fragmentation and sharply divided people along political lines; social media helped to fuel related abuse. Meanwhile religious fanaticism is on the rise, which has damaged the fabric of Pakistani society. More active promotion of inclusion and tolerance could help. To that end, the government in 2018 launched the ”Paigham-e-Pakistan” initiative (“paigham” means “message” in Urdu), condemning all forms of religious extremism and acts of terrorism, and calling on all citizens to be tolerant. It is backed by thousands of religious scholars across the country, in addition to many other stakeholders, and may eventually help to bridge divides based on ethnicity and religion. Ultimately, however, Pakistan needs to build a culture of political tolerance and interfaith harmony from the ground up, and put an end to social deprivation by expanding engagement with, and influence over, society and politics.

name: Social Impact-Driven Entrepreneurship
description: In recent years, there has been a significant increase in social entrepreneurs who are driven by a desire to help the disadvantaged, solve social problems like access to affordable health care, and alleviate poverty. A number of tech-savvy entrepreneurs are applying their skills to business models that can have a positive impact - and in a financially sustainable way. That’s an important new twist on the traditional social enterprise, which largely relied upon charity or public funding. This new class of entrepreneurs is enabled by so-called impact-investors and venture-philanthropists, who apply the discipline of the traditional venture capital investment model, but are also willing to accept lower financial returns in exchange for having an impact. The proliferation of socially-conscious consumers in advanced economies should accelerate the development of social-impact driven entrepreneurship. New organizational forms, such as the so-called "B Corps" and "Benefit Corporations" that are certified to meet a standard of social and environmental performance and take into account both the financial and social bottom lines, also support this trend. There are thousands of registered benefit corporations in the world, including ice cream maker Ben & Jerry's, and e-commerce website Etsy.

name: Social Inclusion and Development in Argentina
description: Poverty and inequality have continued to be serious problems for Argentina, even after the country enjoyed a significant increase in household income during the first decade of the 21st century. Real median household income in Argentina rose from $4.78 per day in 2001, to $12.35 per day by 2011, according to a 2015 Pew Research Center report. In addition, there was a decrease in the portion of the population with unmet basic human needs from 37% in 2003 to 23.1% in the first half of 2017, according to the Socio-Economic Database for Latin America and the Caribbean. However, the percentage of Argentinians affected by poverty rose slightly in the first half of 2018 compared with the second half of 2017, to 27.3%, according to data from the National Institute of Statistics and Census (INDEC). In addition, income levels for the top 20% of earners in the country have been nearly 10 times higher than those for the bottom 20% - a discrepancy that is more than twice as high as the average for advanced economies, according to a report published by the World Economic Forum. In light of its ongoing issues, and despite the country’s difficult recent fiscal situation (Argentina received an International Monetary Fund bailout in 2018), the country had continued to distinguish itself in terms of progressive social spending - though that may now end in the face of austerity measures, according to an Oxfam report published in late 2018. Argentina was ranked 34th on Oxfam’s 2018 Commitment to Reducing Inequality index for 2018, one notch behind Switzerland, though that did not yet reflect the impact of austerity measures. In spite of Argentina's fiscal situation, its bailout agreement with the IMF does include a social safeguard that guarantees a floor for social spending - which would increase by an equivalent of an additional 0.2% of GDP if socio-economic conditions worsen. As it focuses on poverty reduction, the Argentinean government must also contend with a relatively high rate of youth unemployment (nearly 19%, according to INDEC data). However, it remains unclear how much the government will be able to spend on related mitigation efforts; the IMF has projected that late 2018 would mark a peak for Argentina's government debt level, at the equivalent of 81.2% of GDP.

name: Social Inclusion in Brazil
description: Brazil has made significant progress on reducing poverty and inequality since the beginning of the 2000s. However, the recession that lasted from 2014 to 2016 revealed that many of these social gains cannot be sustained without corresponding productivity growth, and some level of economic dynamism. Also essential: efficient public spending that genuinely improves the quality of public services, and benefits the most vulnerable. In 2017, Brazilian respondents to the Latinobarometer survey ranked “improving social policies and social inclusion” and “ensuring equal opportunities for all” as the two most important development issues for the country. According to data from the country’s National Household Sample Survey compiled by the Institute for Applied Economic Research, the portion of Brazilians living in poverty declined from 35.7% in 2003 to 13.3% in 2014. However, according to a report published by the World Bank in 2018, related progress came to a halt in 2015. Between 2015 and 2016, the mean labour income for the poorest 30% of the population actually decreased, even as it increased for everyone else. Inequality in Brazil decreased significantly between 2000 and 2014 thanks to higher employment rates, higher real wages, and redistributive social assistance programs. According to a World Bank working paper published in 2014, Decomposing the Recent Inequality Decline in Latin America, Brazil’s improvement in labour income had accounted for nearly half of the reduction in inequality up to that point, as measured by the Gini coefficient; meanwhile government policies directed at education, health, and social assistance accounted for much of the improved conditions for Brazilians living in poverty during the period. Recent reductions in labour income, caused by a slowdown in economic growth, may therefore undermine efforts to maintain and advance equality in the country. Bolstering structural elements that can support long-term, sustainable improvements in living standards, such as the quality of education, the amount of household savings and investment, and the allocation of labour and capital markets, will be critical for spurring healthy economic growth and sustainable development.

name: Social Inclusion in Latin America
description: Latin America’s economic growth and public policy-making resulted in considerable social gains from the beginning of the 1990s to 2016; extreme poverty decreased by half, the rate of infant mortality dropped by 65%, and average life expectancy at birth increased by nearly eight years, according to a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank. Income inequality also declined during the period, while primary school attendance became practically universal, the availability of safe water expanded to reach nearly 96% of households in the region, and two-thirds of women of working age began actively participating in the labour market. These positive changes have increased demand for quality products and services, including those that are provided by the public sector. However, the region’s ageing population is threatening the long-promised “demographic bonus” (in the form of large numbers of young people entering the workforce) that once characterized Latin America - and the social security systems meant to support the elderly are becoming a heavy burden for young people paying into them, who often lack economic and employment opportunities. One of the biggest challenges for the coming decade will be to preserve the lingering momentum behind positive social transformation in Latin America, and to do so in a more difficult economic environment - particularly for countries still relying heavily on the export of commodities that have lost value on global markets.

name: Social Progress in Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka has made significant economic progress following a long civil war that ended in 2009; the percentage of the country’s population living in extreme poverty fell to 0.7% by 2016, from 3.8% in 2006, according to the World Bank, while the percentage of people living below the national poverty line slipped to 4.1% from 15.2%. However, Sri Lanka has been less successful in addressing regional disparities, and pockets of poverty dot the country. Income inequality as measured by the Gini coefficient, where zero equals perfect equality and 100 is perfect inequality, rose from 32.4 in 1990 to 39.8 in 2016, according to World Bank data. In addition, about 60% of the country’s workforce was employed in the informal, or unregulated, economy as of 2015, according to the Department of Census and Statistics, and the general population is projected to have an unusually large share of over-60-year-olds by 2050 for a developing country. A 2015 United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific report found that only 13% of those over 60 in the country were covered by a social security scheme, while 42% of the working age population was not enrolled in a pension scheme.  As Sri Lanka seeks greater economic growth and technological progress, it will result in increased demand for skilled workers, widened wage gaps, and new sources of inequality. Reforms must be enacted that enable sufficient public funding to improve access to, and the quality of, education, health care, and social protections. An inadequately educated workforce was listed as among the most problematic factors for doing business in the country in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report 2017-2018, as was poor public health. Attention must also be paid to increasing social harmony by strengthening institutional governance structures, the rule of law, and basic human rights. The World Report 2018 published by Human Rights Watch noted that action had stalled on the country’s pledges to the United Nations Human Rights Council to address accountability and political reconciliation following the civil war. For Sri Lanka, a country with a recent and intense history of socio-political conflict, economic growth that is both inclusive, and sustainable, is essential.

name: Social Protection
description: Adequate safety nets can offer people at least short-term buffers against periods of unemployment, obsolete skills, and the emergence of new forms of work. These protections are critical for ensuring human dignity in the face of large-scale economic and social disruption. Currently, however, only 29% of the world’s population has adequate social security coverage for weathering labour market disruption, according to the International Labour Organization’s World Social Protection Report 2017-2019. The relationship between learning, earning, and working has undergone a major shift during the past decade, and will see further transformation amid the changes brought about by the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Given the wide-scale changes underway, it will be critical to review safety nets where they exist in order to ensure that labour market changes do not worsen levels of inequality - and to better ensure the efficiency and utility of employee benefits, which have generally suffered as workers now switch jobs with greater regularity, and have become more likely to take on part-time gigs. Current systems vary in terms of the ways in which they balance the responsibility for workforce protection between employers and governments. Government-provided social safety nets, where they exist, are often outdated. Employer-based systems for health insurance, unemployment insurance, and retirement savings are likewise not well suited for new modes of work, where workers are no longer closely affiliated with a single employer throughout their careers. Labour market shifts call for more agile and portable social safety nets, which can support workers during career transitions and during moments of need, and which apply equally to those employed in both traditional and new forms of work. People engaged in independent forms of work often have less access to affordable healthcare, family leave, and retirement savings plans, for example - while people with more traditional employment can contribute to benefit accounts with paycheck deductions. The development of new instruments and new incentives could lead to greater related innovation. Critical indicators of the success of these new tools would include the ability to ensure minimum income security and to guarantee human dignity. A key question for many policy-makers looking to reform existing approaches will be how to introduce efficiencies while re-structuring broader, existing benefits systems.

name: Social Welfare Programs
description: In light of increased longevity and declining birth rates, current financial and healthcare systems are no longer relevant or sustainable. Government policies and systems require structural changes, and more opportunities to engage the private sector must be explored. Pension reform is essential; a rapidly aging global population means there will ultimately be more people past traditional retirement age than those still working, threatening the solvency of existing pension models particularly in countries where the official retirement age is not increased. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report OECD Pensions Outlook 2014, defined benefit pension funds, which guarantee employer-funded amounts at retirement, are exposed to risk because they rely on historical life expectancy calculations that undershoot more recent projections - so accumulated assets will not cover liabilities. For defined contribution pension funds, which rely on employee contributions, assets have also been accumulated based on outdated expectations for longevity. Adjustments to official retirement ages, and a changing conception of retirement, could better reflect reality and address impending shortfalls. In addition, personal pension plans obtained outside of work will likely become increasingly important. Policy-makers play a central role in ensuring financial protection for consumers, as they coordinate with financial institutions to assess the changing retirement landscape. The long-term sustainability of annuity products, in particular, which can help consumers manage longevity risk, must be addressed by providing incentives that encourage appropriate risk management on the part of annuity providers, and consistent parameters to ensure a level playing field. Every country must be committed to increasing financial literacy, and to informing individuals both about public pension systems and tools such as private pension plans. Governments should also address access to quality health care services, and aim to enable everyone to access the medical services and medicines they need without undue financial hardship. This includes access to rehabilitation services, which are becoming increasingly important due to the prevalence of non-communicable diseases among ageing populations. There should be a focus on prevention, not just on treatment, and on serving the most vulnerable populations - which increasingly include older adults. Streamlining and harmonizing regulatory processes can contribute to greater efficiency and help avoid duplication. To better map the sustainability of healthcare systems, governments should work together to identify proven, successful healthcare financing frameworks that can meet the needs of an ageing global society.

name: Social Welfare Spending
description: Concerns linger about the South African government’s ability to effectively administer social welfare programmes - particularly as there is no sign that a heavy public dependence on these programmes will decline any time soon. This, along with an unfavourable economic growth outlook, could means that South Africa will come under increasing strain as it seeks to provide adequate social protection. According to the non-profit fact checking organization Africa Check, the number of social grants disbursed in South Africa increased from an estimated 4 million in 1994 to more than 17 million by February 2017. Social security spending amounted to R165 billion (roughly $11.4 billion) for the 2016-2017 fiscal year, and accounted for around 15% of all government expenditure during the period - a level where it is expected to remain for the next five years. It is questionable whether this level of spending on social welfare is sustainable for the long term. Regardless of their financial cost, grants have had a noticeably positive impact on poverty in South Africa. They have been well targeted at very poor households, with 76% of government spending on social grants received by the poorest 40% of the population. Between 2005 and 2010, more grants for the elderly and child support were added, significantly increasing expenditures for the poor. The child support grant has meanwhile had a positive impact on women’s empowerment in very poor communities (where 96% of beneficiaries are women), as well as on school attendance and access to health care. According to the Development Policy Research Unit (DPRU) at the University of Cape Town, South Africa’s persistent income inequality across households would be even more severe in the absence of social grants; if they were not made available to the poor, income inequality as measured by the Gini coefficient would have been 0.74 in 2010 (where a score of 1.0 equals maximum inequality), instead of the actual figure of 0.70. In addition, during the period between 1995 and 2010, had grants not been available, real household income would have declined significantly. Concerns have been raised about the South African Social Security Agency’s takeover of the distribution of grants from a private service provider. A failure to actively discharge these responsibilities could leave the more than 17 million South Africans who receive social grants, and their households, without necessary government support.

name: Society and Governance
description: The ability of public programs and policies to improve collective well-being and prosperity ultimately depends on how the intended beneficiaries respond. The design of health, safety, financial, education and other public systems and services may benefit from taking into account the psychological traits of the people these systems are meant to be assisting. Past approaches to policy-making often relied too much on financial rewards and punishments, though the behavioural science toolkit has expanded significantly since the early 2000s; it now includes social incentives and so-called “nudges,” or subtle changes in the environment that gently push people to make better decisions, while retaining their freedom of choice. These behavioural tools take into account the fact that decisions do not always result from a purely rational weighing of cost versus benefit, but are instead often influenced by simplistic reasoning, intuition, and social motives. Behavioural designs are often more effective, and less costly, than traditional approaches that rely on financial incentives or persuasion. For example, millions of people in the United Kingdom and the US have increased their retirement savings in response to a simple change in the way certain pension plans are being presented to them. These new “Save More TomorrowTM” plans, developed by behavioural economists Richard H. Thaler and Shlomo Benartzi, have people commit to allocating a portion of future salary increases towards their retirement savings. The sting of these paycheck reductions is dulled, as they only kick in after raises, making people much more willing to agree to them. Behavioural science can also help increase civic participation, by motivating people to volunteer, donate, sign petitions, participate in rallies, interact with their government representatives, and vote. Leveraging people’s sense of identity can increase voter turnout, for example. In a study published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in 2011, researchers demonstrated that when items in a pre-election survey were phrased to invoke the respondent’s identity (by asking, “How important is it to you to be a voter in the upcoming election?” as opposed to, “How important is it to you to vote in the upcoming election?”), respondents expressed greater interest in registering to vote, and were in fact more likely to vote, according to records associated with two state-wide elections in the US. Another study on increasing voter turnout, published in 2010 in Psychological Science, was based on the 2008 US presidential election; it showed that if calls made to potential voters not only encouraged them to vote but also prompted them to make a specific plan for casting their ballot, turnout increased among single-eligible-voter households by 9%. Other ways that the behavioural sciences can inform the design of better-functioning societies include motivating people to pay their taxes, preventing people from dropping out of college, increasing vaccination rates, and promoting recycling and the consumption of healthier food. Further collaboration between behavioural science researchers, governments, and civil society institutions could foster a more successful journey through the Fourth Industrial Revolution.

name: Soft Power
description: The regional upheaval that followed the Arab Spring prompted the UAE to more than double its military spending between 2007 and 2017, or the fastest rate of increase during the period in the world, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. In early 2017, however, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum, Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and the Emir of Dubai, launched a “Soft Power Council” - in recognition of the limits of traditional power. In late 2017, the council published a “Soft Power Strategy” that involves efforts to burnish the UAE’s global reputation through investment in education, sports, tourism, culture, art, and science. UAE Deputy Prime Minister Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed al Nahyan has suggested that the country’s strong economy and world-class infrastructure could help it to “leapfrog” into a leading global position when it comes to soft power. The opening in 2017 of the Louvre Abu Dhabi (under a 30-year contract with France’s Louvre Museum) made headlines around the world. Two other significant local museum launches are planned: the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, designed by Frank Gehry, and the Sheikh Zayed National Museum (supported by a 10-year contract with the British Museum). In 2017, the UAE became the world’s top provider of development assistance per capita, by dedicating 1.31% of its total economic output to aid - a significantly higher rate of giving per GDP than those of traditional humanitarian powers like Sweden and Norway. Abu Dhabi and Dubai’s sovereign wealth funds collectively control an estimated $1 trillion in assets around the world, and the country’s financial clout may help it to further project its soft power globally. Meanwhile Dubai is preparing to host Expo 2020, a world fair expected to last for several months and to draw 25 million visitors, while showcasing the UAE as a global hub for technology and innovation and potentially positioning Dubai as a leading cultural centre. Regionally, the UAE has been able to draw the attention of a relatively young population; for several consecutive years, the country has topped the Arab Youth Survey as the most desirable place to live. While the UAE has increased its focus on soft power, however, it is also pursuing more traditional means to develop its geopolitical influence - the country plans to have a spacecraft orbiting Mars by 2021.

name: South African Governance
description: In 1994, following the end of apartheid in South Africa, institutions were established to protect people from government abuse, including the Public Protector, the South African Human Rights Commission, and the Commission for Gender Equality. Between 1948 and 1994, South Africa’s decentralized governance system had been racially-segregated into white local authorities, and black local authorities. White authorities enjoyed a high degree of fiscal autonomy, while black authorities were severely resource-constrained. Post-1994, the central government wanted to provide services in disadvantaged areas, and the resulting strategy involved amalgamating apartheid-era municipal structures in order to benefit black authorities. Overall service delivery has since improved, although backlogs remain - particularly in rural areas. In addition, due to low levels of economic activity in most non-urban areas, these areas rely heavily on federal government transfers. Meanwhile the post-1994 task of transforming state-owned enterprises (SOEs) in South Africa so that services can be provided equally has been difficult. According to a presidential review committee, SOEs accounted for 8.7% the country’s GDP in 2016, or nearly half the amount accounted for by all government services. While SOEs present an opportunity for economic growth, they also face challenges related to corruption - particularly when it comes to procurement. Corruption poses a threat to public trust and sustainable development. Forms of corruption particularly prevalent in South Africa include cronyism, and abuses of both government tender processes and of Black Economic Empowerment policies (designed to redress apartheid era policies). Transparency International's 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index assigned South Africa a score of 43 out of 100 (where zero equals highly corrupt), compared with Botswana’s score of 61 and Sierra Leone’s 30. Former South African Public Protector Thuli Madonsela’s state capture report published in 2016 provided evidence of corruption among senior officials; evidence has shown that private sector companies have been complicit in this corruption, which needs to be addressed through the rule of law. The experience of apartheid has made South African society more in need of a transparent and accountable government than it would be otherwise. Non-profit organizations like Corruption Watch have played a positive role in this regard, along with other civil society organizations and the news media's active coverage of related stories. Better addressing crime that impacts the cost of doing business will be key for South Africa, if it wants to avoid further economic stagnation.

name: Space Conflict
description: As space-based technology becomes increasingly critical, the unwillingness of space powers to play by a common set of rules is a potential source of problems. In 2014, roughly one year after China test fired an anti-satellite missile to the height of geosynchronous orbit, or an altitude of about 30,000 kilometres, the US declassified details about a similar program - and launched a pair of satellites capable of rendezvousing with other satellites at an altitude of about 30,000 kilometres. In late 2018, Russia launched an object perceived by some US officials to be capable of destroying satellites (though some experts are not convinced), and perhaps the most serious possibility of conflict in space arose when the Trump administration announced plans that same year for a "Space Force" meant to secure US dominance. The US effort comes as Russia and China are developing an ability to disable or destroy US satellites, and as space becomes a war-fighting domain like land, sea, and air. However, the Space Force is believed to a bad idea, because it could encourage other countries to follow suit, lead to a space arms race, and worsen space debris.  Until recently, questions about the basic rules governing conflict in space could be settled by the relatively few states wealthy enough to have access to space. Now, the situation is more complex; roughly 60 countries have satellites in space, and both low- and high-Earth orbits are brimming with scientific and commercial activity. In 2018, delegates to the UN General Assembly’s First Committee explored new rules to help keep outer space conflict-free; South Africa’s speaker expressed concern about an arms race in space, while Egypt’s representative (speaking for the Arab Group, the African Group, and the Non‑Aligned Movement), said space must not be allowed to turn into another battlefield. In 2018, the US deviated from past practice by voting “no” on all resolutions dealing with space conflict and security adopted by the First Committee (it used to vote for resolutions on transparency and confidence building measures, and abstain from those calling for the prevention of a space arms race). While international cooperation on preventing space conflict has been regressing, since 2016 a team of international experts has been developing the McGill Manual on International Law Applicable to Military Uses of Outer Space (MILAMOS), an effort that may dissuade the use of force and help avoid future conflict (and, potentially, future wars).

name: Space Policy and Governance
description: The United Nations-initiated Outer Space Treaty, which entered into force in 1967, holds governments responsible for the actions of private entities in space. Many countries have therefore established laws to regulate space-related companies. Those laws have become increasingly important amid a proliferation of firms such as communications satellite developers like Intelsat and Eutelsat, and commercial ventures seeking to explore and exploit space resources. Still, there is a lingering reluctance on the part of governments to develop international, legally-binding rules for space. Instead, governments tend to prefer non-binding agreements - though these generally include imprecise guidelines, and rights and obligations cannot be firmly established through non-binding promises. An all-inclusive, rules-based global space governance system is therefore called for, composed of binding treaties, best practices, and a means to coordinate national regulations and policies - in order to ensure that everyone is aware of their responsibilities.   Outdated regulation is another issue. When the American firm DigitalGlobe was able to capture full-quality images of forest fires through dense smoke in Alberta, Canada in 2016, the company was nonetheless prohibited from providing them to Canadian firefighters - because of a US regulation requiring such images to be degraded before their release to commercial customers. This regulation is a relic from an era when most countries (much less companies) had not yet built Earth observation satellites, and it unnecessarily hinders competition. There is no single, global institution that oversees space-related matters, though it is worth considering whether the UN’s influence should be expanded - or if a new international organization should be created. Without the establishment of international norms, an increasing number of unilateral actions that run contrary to the interests of other countries is possible, similar to the US SPACE Act of 2015, which allows American citizens to explore and exploit space resources, and a similar law that was passed in Luxembourg in 2017. These two actions threaten global governance mechanisms like the Outer Space Treaty, which has been signed by more than 120 countries. During the 2018 session of the Legal Subcommittee of the United Nations Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, several countries raised concerns that the actions could lead to misunderstanding and devastating conflict.

name: Spatial Integration
description: South Africa’s history of racial segregation and marginalization has resulted in significant, spatially-biased economic disparities. Until the 1990s, there was extensive government intervention in the process of urbanization, including racially discriminatory controls on land ownership and restrictions on access to urban areas for non-white South Africans - who could be forcibly removed. While these restrictions have been lifted, spatial planning in South Africa remains as a remnant of apartheid. The majority of poor, non-white households are in rural areas or on the periphery of cities and economic hubs. These places are characterized by high rates of poverty and unemployment, poor service delivery, and generally poor living conditions. Spatial-based transformation could therefore function as a driver of economic development, and reduce inequality. Although there have been improvements to the country’s spatial issues, significant negative aspects remain. There is a glaring mismatch between where a big part of the labour force lives, and where much of the productive economy is located. In addition, the quality of service delivery is highly uneven, resulting in significant disparities in the quality of life across regions. “Spatial mismatch” refers to a state where large distances separate substantial segments of the labour market (in the case of South Africa, non-white populations) from job opportunities. Workers living far from economic hubs face high transportation costs, and long commute times. South Africa’s relatively poor transportation systems present further challenges, including a lack of safety and reliability. The challenge of spatial mismatch is heightened by a lack of affordable housing in urban centres. According to South Africa’s National Treasury, the limited access in rural areas to basic municipal services such as water, sanitation, and electricity, and the lack of good quality social services such as education and health care, compound the challenges already presented by poverty and unemployment. The provision of more reliable, affordable, safe, and extensive transportation infrastructure will be key for overcoming spatial mismatch. Increased access to affordable housing in and around economics hubs could also improve employment and welfare outcomes for workers and their households.
