In addition, improving services delivery in rural, peripheral communities could improve welfare outcomes in these areas, specifically in terms of health care and education.

name: Spurring Growth via Space
description: The total value of the space-related industry may grow from roughly $350 billion as of 2018 to about $2.7 trillion during the following 30 years, according to research published by Bank of America Merrill Lynch. This is being made possible by the declining cost of access to space, and by increasing amounts of financing from more than 80 different countries, according to the research. Already, people in virtually every country utilize satellite telecommunications for everything from TV entertainment to emergency communications. In developing countries, satellites provide an essential link to telecommunications network nodes - the important equipment that take the raw data being received and send it along to internet users or TV viewers. They are also a key element in most maritime and aviation communications systems for both civilian and military services, and are vital for safety and navigation - in addition to simple online booking for anyone trying to take a flight or rent a car. Satellite companies such as O3b Networks and OneWeb seek to provide internet connectivity even in remote locations (for companies operating in these places, this can mean better communicating with staff and exchanging information). The growing web of space-based communication is made up of hundreds of high-altitude geosynchronous equatorial orbit satellites, and thousands of low-Earth orbit satellites - in addition to constellations of small satellites that can weigh less than 10 kilograms. According to a 2018 report published by National Sky Research, 6,500 small satellites are expected to be launched by 2027, yielding $37 billion in cumulative revenue. However, it remains challenging to develop cost-effective launch vehicles. India has positioned itself as a low-cost service provider; the Indian Space Research Organization has used a launch vehicle to put hundreds of small satellites including those from other countries into orbit. In 2017, a single launch in India included 104 satellites (103 of them weighed less than 10 kilograms), and most were from Austria, Belgium, Latvia, Lithuania, and Slovakia. The global space industry is also an important catalyst for other industries, like telecommunications, transportation, banking, and mining. As of late 2018, according to the Brookings Institution, for the first time ever more than half of the world’s population had attained at least middle class status - and the space industry played a significant role in making that happen.

name: Sri Lanka's Digital Transformation
description: Sri Lanka is at an early stage of digital transformation. In 2017, the country’s Telecommunications Regulatory Commission reported an internet penetration rate of 27% of the population; meanwhile the think tank Freedom House reported that the smartphone penetration rate as of 2017 was 36%, up from 20% in of 2014. As the country develops its digital potential, it is also fostering a more digitally savvy workforce. Sri Lanka’s adult literacy rate as of 2015 was 92.6%, according to United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) figures. Meanwhile the overall national computer literacy average was 27.1%, according to Department of Census and Statistics figures - and 58.7% for those aged between 15 and 19, which bodes well for the future. The country ranked 63rd out of 139 economies in the World Economic Forum’s Network Readiness Index 2016, ahead of other South Asian peers. The value added to Sri Lanka’s economy from telecommunications activity rose 12% in 2017 compared with 2016, according to the annual report published by the country’s Central Bank. Meanwhile IT programming consultancy and related activities rose 4.2% in 2017, according to the report - a slowdown relative to 7.1% growth in the prior year. Growth in private consumption expenditure on communication in Sri Lanka also slowed in 2017, to 4.4% from 9.8% in the prior year, according to the central bank’s report, though the import volume and value of telecommunication devices increased during 2017, and overall internet connection growth remained roughly steady, at about 20% compared with the prior year. Sri Lanka excels in software development, as well as in information technology-enabled services such as business process outsourcing. In 2017, the country ranked 11th in A.T. Kearney’s Global Services Location Index, which evaluates locations based on financial attractiveness, available talent, and business environment. However, digital transformation also introduces social, political, and economic issues. Now is the ideal time to begin regulating this area in a way that addresses the needs of all stakeholders - including customers and employers. Related, forward-looking policy initiatives include Sri Lanka’s Right to Information Act, implemented in 2017, which enables citizens to access data held by authorities. In addition, e-government digitalization initiatives were commenced in 2018.

name: Sri Lanka's Trade Competitiveness
description: Sri Lanka’s government has sought to better integrate the country into the global economy, due to its limited domestic market of 20 million consumers and modest per capita income. In 2017, Sri Lanka regained a significant trade concession from the European Union, the GSP Plus, which removes import duties on Sri Lankan exports such as textiles in exchange for a commitment to implement international conventions on human rights and labour conditions. The Sri Lanka-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, which was implemented in 2018, covers trade in goods, services, and investment relative to telecommunications, e-commerce, government procurement, competition policy, intellectual property rights, and transparency. Sri Lanka is also negotiating comprehensive trade agreements with India and China, while considering agreements with Bangladesh, Malaysia, South Korea, and Thailand, and a proposed Economic and Technology Cooperation Agreement could deepens links to India. These developments have been accompanied by measures to mitigate the adverse effects of trade liberalization, such as the Anti-dumping and Countervailing Duties Act and efforts to deal with import surges. The government has also formulated a New Trade Policy framework, which aims to increase competitiveness. The country’s Board of Investment, an investment promotion agency, is taking steps to accelerate the investment approval process, and improve coordination among government agencies. A comprehensive national export strategy launched in 2017 focuses on sectors including wellness tourism and boat building, and aims to increase Sri Lanka’s value of exports in goods and services to $28 billion by 2022. The Trade Information Portal launched in 2018 collects regulatory information relating to cross-border transactions in one place, while the National Single Window should enable the entry of standardized documents at a single point. These have been developed in order to fulfil Sri Lanka’s commitments under the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), which came into effect in 2017. The government is also gradually phasing out para tariffs, which are fees charged in addition to tariffs. While the country’s international trade situation is improving, there are still a number of domestic challenges, such as a relatively high cost of production, and a lack of skilled labour.

name: Sri Lankan Agricultural Reform
description: Sri Lanka’s agricultural sector is comprised of a well-developed, export-oriented plantation sector that produces tea, rubber and coconut on medium- and large-sized estates, and a less developed, only partially market-oriented food crop sector that produces rice, vegetables, and fruit via generally small land holdings. Agriculture remains a vital sector for the country’s economy, as it provides income, foreign currencies, food, and essential raw materials. It accounts for nearly a third of all employment in the country, primarily in the production of rice and tea. Agricultural land made up nearly 44% of the country’s total land area as of 2015, according to World Bank data - compared with 60% in India, and 47% in Pakistan - and is the backbone of the rural economy. However, the domestic agricultural sector as a whole is plagued by low productivity, inefficient resource use, food insecurity, poor market linkages, and unsustainable practices, while the plantation sector in particular is in crisis owing to volatile commodity prices and high production costs. In addition, the looming threat of global climate change means that agricultural industry growth should be low-carbon and climate resilient. The government in Sri Lanka is aiming for inclusive and sustainable economic growth, while ensuring food security. The Department of Agriculture’s national food production programme for 2016-2018 consists of promoting the production of rice and other food crops, and home gardening. The government has also initiated programmes for developing the dairy industry, modernizing fisheries, developing agricultural “mega zones” (designed to better integrate smallholder farmers into value chains, and enable them to access larger markets), developing public-private producer partnerships, and modernizing irrigation. The Agriculture Sector Modernization Project for Sri Lanka, a World Bank-funded development scheme, aims to increase agriculture productivity and help the country close the gap between it and South and East Asian peers in terms of developing competitive exports. A number of development initiatives have also been undertaken to mitigate climate risks and enhance resilience in agriculture, and to ensure sustainable food production systems. These include micro irrigation programmes and an index-based agriculture insurance programme (which is different from traditional, loss-based insurance, in that it pays out claims based on environmental conditions measured via satellite).

name: Stabilizing Economies, Keeping Protections
description: The global financial crisis roughly a decade ago, and Europe’s subsequent debt crisis, abruptly pushed governments around the world into a situation where large parts of their economies and financial systems had to be restructured. This was often done in ways that drew criticism from people who felt their social benefits and protections were being unfairly sacrificed as a result. In Greece, for example, where officials at one point were forced to disclose that the deficit was twice as high as what had previously been announced, controversial austerity measures were implemented beginning in 2010 that slashed government employee salaries and pension payments. According to a study subsequently published by researchers at the University of Portsmouth, for every 1% decline in Greek government spending, there was a 0.43% increase in suicides among men - and more than 500 men had killed themselves solely because of austerity during the early stages of the measures. In addition to financial bailout programs, Greece, like other countries following the financial crisis, also restructured its sovereign debt - that is, it pressed creditors to trade in existing sovereign bonds for new bonds with far lower face value, granting the country much-needed fiscal relief.      Many other countries have pursued sovereign debt restructuring. However, the process has created some controversy, as poorer countries may have difficulty enforcing terms of a restructuring deal on large investors; this can ultimately hinder the ability of these countries to use the process to fully recover financially. In addition, "vulture” investors can cheaply buy up old bonds that a country is seeking to exchange, and then pursue litigation with that country in hopes of ultimately receiving 100% of the bonds' face value. A restructuring first implemented by Argentina after its sovereign default in 2001 was only fully resolved in 2016, after a lengthy legal battle with investors. In a policy paper published in 2016, the scholars Martin Guzman and Joseph Stiglitz noted that since 1970, more than half of restructuring episodes with private creditors were followed by another restructuring or default within five years. The scholars called for a “soft law regime” to govern sovereign debt restructurings built on United Nations principles, and reliant on social norms and market acceptance rather than legal force. In 2018, Guzman noted in an article published by the Institute for New Economic Thinking that the framework for restructurings remained fraught with perverse incentives.

name: Stormy Financial Seas
description: Almost as soon as voters in the United Kingdom approved a 2016 ballot proposal to leave the European Union, speculation about the resulting impact on the UK’s vaunted financial services industry - not to mention on the global financial system - began in earnest. The financial services industry accounts for about 7% of the UK’s GDP, directly employs more than 1 million people in the country, and contributes a significant portion of overall tax revenue, according to a survey co-published in 2018 by the Association of Foreign Banks. Some foreign banks operating in the UK that participated in the survey reported that the local talent pool had shrunk following the Brexit vote, and that they were receiving fewer applications to work in the country. One quarter of the banks reported spending as much as £2.5 million on Brexit preparations, even as they had a lack of clarity on the ultimate shape of the split. There are also financial issues related to the UK’s trade position post-Brexit to consider; the EU accounted for more than half of UK imports in 2017, and 44% of exports, according to a parliamentary briefing.    Regardless of the eventual outcome of the UK-EU divorce, the unease it has already triggered demonstrates how populism can upend ways that finance, business, trade, and monetary systems are managed. In addition, in several European countries successful populist political movements have questioned retaining the euro. Populist parties have attacked the common currency for destabilizing their country’s public finances (mostly in the North), or for directly causing economic crises (mostly in the South), according to a report published by CESifo Group in 2017; the report noted that in Eastern Europe, even countries that have enjoyed relative economic progress during the past decade, like Hungary and Poland, have seen populists come to power. Meanwhile in the US, Donald Trump, who won election as a populist, has criticized Federal Reserve policy members as they have raised interest rates in a bid to keep the economy on an even keel (raising rates can disrupt stock market gains as they cool an economy). Trump has also expressed a desire to “win” on trade, particularly with China. As they vie geo-economically, countries often seek out technology-based competitive advantages; when it comes to financial technology, for example, China has now surged ahead of the US, with half of the top ten entries in KPMG’s list of the most innovative fintech firms published in 2018.

name: Strategic Industries
description: Countries tend to consider an industry to be strategic either because it is critical for an economy, such as energy, or because it adds a military advantage; examples include the production of materials and technologies used to make stealth aircraft or submarines. When it comes to the strategic use of energy, in the 1970s, for example, oil-rich OPEC nations manipulated global oil supply to pursue foreign policy interests. More recently, developments like fracking have unlocked new sources of energy, curbing OPEC Rare earth elements can be critical for the production of high end technologies, like jet engines or semiconductors - and can therefore also become the subject of geo-strategic gamesmanship. In 2010, it was reported that China had blocked the export of minerals used in hybrid cars and guided missiles to Japan, as a result of a dispute over Tokyo's detention of a Chinese fishing boat captain (Beijing has denied the claim). So-called “dual use” technologies, which are developed for civilian applications but can also be used militarily, have become a concern for public officials wary of related foreign investment. Meanwhile foreign investment in basic infrastructure, like ports or telecommunications networks, is increasingly being subjected to political intervention. European governments, for example, have been divided on the issue of when it is appropriate to block foreign investment from Chinese and Russian investors on the basis of national security. Of course, it is also debated whether or not national security is a genuine motivation in the case of intervention, or if it is being used as cover for more mundane protectionism.

name: Strongman Politics
description: Populism has spread globally. In Latin America, leftist populism has been more widespread, while in Europe right-wing parties have achieved both popularity and significant electoral victories - including in Turkey. Populist governments, regardless of their ideological inspiration, have at least two things in common: an appeal made to “ordinary” voters as opposed to elites, and an effort to exploit problems related to inequality and corruption. Populists also frequently attempt to convince voters that their fight against elites requires a strong leader, and that an erosion of checks and balances is therefore justified. For many observers, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan’s rise to power in 2002, and the political transformation he has overseen in since then (including in the wake of an attempted coup in 2016), represents this sort of backsliding of democracy (an EU Commission report published in 2019 cited “serious backsliding” on human rights, the rule of law, and economic policy). To be sure, as is the case with other instances of populist transformation, inequality has declined in Turkey as a result (as measured by the Gini coefficient) - but at a cost.   According to Freedom House, Turkey’s “Democracy Score” has consistently decreased since 2010 - and in 2018, the country’s status was changed from “partly free” to “not free” for the first time since Freedom House began its assessments. In 2019, Freedom House said the government’s “authoritarian nature” had been fully consolidated, following the attempted coup - which was itself followed by a 2017 constitutional referendum that saw voters approve a system that increased executive authority. Strongman politics is a common reaction to public frustration with inequality and corruption, and involves the empowerment of elected authorities; in the case of Turkey, this took on a legal form with the referendum, and a resulting shift from a parliamentarian system to one where the president now enjoys greater influence over other state institutions including parliament and the judiciary. In fact, Turkey fits in with a broader global trend towards strongman politics, as evidenced to varying degrees in places like Russia, the Philippines, Hungary, and the US.

name: Structural Rigidity
description: The Republic of Korea (South Korea) is home to a dynamic society and has set a pace of development that is the envy of many other nations. However, further progress is being inhibited by a deeply rooted rigidity, both in terms of socioeconomic structures and mentalities. The bulk of South Korea's economic productivity is highly concentrated within a few large corporations, known as “chaebols,” which has limited the competitive potential of local startups. In addition, the country’s labour market is sharply divided, with unionized, highly-protected workers on one end, and a growing number of more vulnerable workers in non-regulated areas of the economy on the other, which blunts the vitality of the economy and hinders social cohesion. In the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018, South Korea ranks 26th out of 137 economies overall, but 73rd in terms of labour market efficiency. Relative ethnic homogeneity in the country is becoming a source of concern, at a time when openness to diverse new talent and a rethinking of immigration policy could enable greater economic growth. In addition, the country’s ruling elite has been destabilized by controversy; the parliament voted to impeach former President Park Gyun-hye in late 2016, she stepped down in 2017, and in 2018 she received a 24-year prison sentence for abuse of power, bribery and coercion. Now, as the country regains its footing, it must continue to seek to break away from its structural rigidity and embrace new ways of thinking.

name: Supply Chain Disruption
description: Since the advent of the first industrial revolution, manufacturing has spawned global activity that increasingly feeds into layers of dispersed and multi-tiered supply chains. Now, new platform business models are challenging and disrupting these established supply chain structures. These digital platforms connect suppliers, buyers, technology developers, and service providers so they can exchange capacity (like computing power), capabilities, products, and services directly - avoiding any middle men. Amazon’s Amazon Web Services offering, for example, connects vendors directly to on-demand cloud computing services. Amazon Web Services, or AWS, is now one of the company’s fastest-growing businesses; the unit reported 41% net sales growth in the first quarter of 2019 compared with the same period a year earlier, and its customers include Volkswagen and Lyft. Microsoft’s Azure business, a rival to AWS, reported a 73% gain in revenue in the first quarter of 2019.  Platforms enable the gig economy, which includes ride-sharing companies like Lyft and where independent workers who offer up their talents for limited periods and can help address specific production issues. Increased data sharing via platforms has facilitated more open innovation, whereby companies that may have once operated in isolation are tapping into external technology - while also making their own innovation externally available. However, with increased connectivity there are increased cyber risks. High-profile ransomware attacks including LockerGoga (2019), WannaCry (2017) and NotPetya (2017) have targeted industrial firms including Nissan, Mondelez, and many others. In March 2019, a LockerGoga attack on Norwegian aluminium manufacturer Norsk Hydro had such a swift, severe effect on operations that it forced the company to shift its modern factories back to manual operation.

name: Supply Chain Sustainability
description: Businesses are coming under increasing pressure from regulators, shareholders, employees, and customers to make their supply chains more sustainable; environmental aspects merit particular attention in light of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, declared in 2015. The wider societal impacts of supply chains were explored in detail in the World Economic Forum’s 2014 report Beyond Supply Chains, which examined ethical issues related to sourcing, production, distribution, working conditions, impacts on local economies, and the empowerment of decision-makers to meet social and environmental objectives. Many firms’ corporate social responsibility policies now address these subjects, and specifically include supply chain sustainability. Logistics is responsible for significant pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, noise, and accidents. In many countries, the situation has improved. Decades of tightening controls on exhaust emissions from new trucks in North America and Europe substantially improved air quality, for example, though the adoption of such measures in the developing world has been slow (and the US announced plans in April 2018 to ease vehicle-emissions standards). One particularly encouraging sign: globally, the maximum sulphur content permitted in ship fuel will drop from 3.5% to 0.5% in 2020. The decarbonization of logistics will be difficult, because of expected growth in freight traffic and a heavy dependence on fossil fuels. Modelling by the International Transport Forum at the OECD suggests that the total amount of global freight movement may increase three-fold by 2050. Dramatic reductions in the average carbon intensity of logistics will therefore be required, in order to meet the demands of the Paris Agreement signed in 2015. The Science Based Targets initiative, a collaboration between the United Nations Global Compact and other organizations, is helping logistics companies set carbon reduction targets in line with the latest climate science. Some companies are setting ambitious targets; DHL, for example, aims to be carbon neutral by 2050. Meanwhile the International Maritime Organization aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping in half between 2008 and 2050. The greening of supply chains can be achieved in many ways: by rationalizing patterns of freight movement, improving the energy efficiency of freight vehicles, switching freight to lower-carbon modes, raising vehicle load factors, and using cleaner energy sources. Many of these measures can be justified on economic as well as environmental grounds - though they alone are unlikely to deliver the cuts in emissions needed over the next few decades.

name: Supply Risk and Recovery
description: Supply chains are vulnerable to a broad range of threats, including extreme weather, cyberattack, political and military crises, and bankruptcies. A 2017 survey conducted by the Business Continuity Institute (BCI) found that 65% of responding companies had had at least one supply chain disruption during the previous year, with one quarter incurring a loss of over €1 million from a single incident. The vulnerability of supply chains has been highlighted by major incidents such as the collapse of Hanjin Shipping in 2016, which stranded $14 billion worth of cargo on its vessels, the Petya cyberattack in 2017, which severely disrupted the operations of shipping giant Maersk and the TNT division of delivery firm FedEx, and the multiple hurricanes that hit the US in 2017 causing an estimated $200 billion in damage. Ironically, the susceptibility of supply chains has been heightened by what have long been considered good business practices. The single sourcing of supplies, inventory centralization, just-in-time replenishment, and the concentration of freight traffic at hub ports and airports all improve economic performance, but also create greater risk exposure and lower resilience. As a result of the globalization of supply chains and the tighter coupling of logistical processes, the damaging effects of disruptions now spread much further and faster than before - and increasingly prevalent security threats are having a broader impact. The human cost of supply chain disruption can also be high. In addition to the direct loss of life during natural disasters and military conflicts, death and suffering can occur when supply chains relied upon to deliver medical and essential supplies are fractured. Humanitarian-related logistics activity is steadily increasing, partly in an effort to improve the living conditions of those who have been geographically displaced. In the corporate world, the management of supply chain risk is being given greater priority. Risk auditing and business continuity planning are now widespread, particularly among larger companies. 74% of the companies that responded to BCI’s 2017 survey had business continuity arrangements in place for their supply chains. In some countries, publicly-traded companies have a regulatory obligation to monitor and report business risk. However, strategic risk is not always adequately addressed at an operational level - and there is little evidence that companies are effectively reversing the long-term trends that have made their supply chains more vulnerable.

name: Sustainability
description: Rampant growth in global tourism has had a negative impact on the environment, which must be mitigated in order to both help address the effects of climate change and to ensure the industry’s long term sustainability. Air travel presents some of the most pressing related challenges - the total number of air travellers is expected to jump to 7.8 billion by 2036, from about 4 billion in 2017, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA), producing a related increase in particulates contributing to climate change. According to the United Nations Environment Programme, the tourism industry overuses water resources on things like swimming pools and golf courses, resulting in shortages and the generation of greater volumes of waste water. The number of cruise ship passengers is projected to grow to more than 25 million by 2020 (from about 18 million as of 2010), according to the organization TourismConcern - which also reported that older vessels used for cruise tourism generate more greenhouse gas emissions per capita than other forms of travel, as they power on-board facilities such as laundry, refrigeration and air conditioning.  The travel and tourism industry is working to find solutions to reduce its oil dependency, by improving aircraft and airport operations, aircraft design, and its use of materials - and by considering alternative sources of energy. The IATA has set targets to reduce carbon emissions by 2050 to half of what they were in 2005, and to build zero-emissions aircraft by 2057 (based on a 50-year goal set in 2007). The Air Transport Action Group, a coalition of industry organizations and companies, has committed to an annual average improvement in fuel efficiency of 1.5% between 2009 and 2020, and to stabilizing net aviation emissions in 2020. Meanwhile the International Tourism Partnership (ITP) has launched the Hotel Carbon Measurement Initiative, a tool to measure and report on carbon emissions. The ITP estimates that the hotel industry must reduce its carbon emissions by 66% by 2030, in order to contribute to the widely-held goal of limiting global temperature increase to below 2°C higher than pre-industrial levels.

name: Sustainability and Behaviour Change
description: The need for more sustainable use of the planet’s resources calls for a long-term, global perspective. Humans often struggle to act in their own future selves’ best interests, or in the interests of those outside of their physical vicinity. They may aspire to consume less, save more energy and water, and purchase more sustainable products, but they nonetheless often fall back on bad habits and preferences. Traditional approaches to tackling this so-called “intention-behaviour gap” often fail. Simply informing people about the importance of sustainability is often not enough to affect their behaviour, as decision-making is often guided by more ephemeral influences like mood, short-term desire, or habit. More often than not, people are also lazy, in the sense that they do not consider all available information when making decisions, or prefer convenient and accessible options over rational ones. To circumvent this, behavioural scientists investigate not only how persuasion can be more effective, but also how subtle changes to one’s environment, or so-called “nudges,” can make it easier for people to act in line with their aspirations. Such nudges always allow for the retention of consumers’ freedom of choice. For example, the Flemish government in Belgium was able to increase sales of local regional and seasonal foods by up to 30% simply by placing them at eye level for shoppers. Meanwhile presenting smaller portions of meat next to larger sizes resulted in a decrease of meat purchases by 20%. Defaults can also work as powerful nudges; a 2008 study by researchers from the Max Planck Institute for Human Development and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology published in the Journal of Environmental Psychology showed that the proportion of people choosing a green, sustainable energy source over a less expensive, less sustainable source like coal can be substantially increased by simply making the green option the default in a registration form. People do not like deviating from what is displayed as the default, possibly because they think it indicates a recommendation, or prevailing norm. Information about established norms is also effective in nudging people to behave more sustainably. A 2008 study published in the Journal of Consumer Research described guests at a US hotel re-using their towels more frequently, if a sign informed them that the majority of guests in the same room had re-used their towels. Meanwhile a 2011 study published in the Journal of Public Economics showed that providing US citizens with monthly reports about their energy consumption, alongside comparisons to that of their neighbours, reduced their energy consumption by about 2% relative to a baseline. Even small, behaviourally-informed changes to the environments in which we make our decisions, or to the narratives we use to make sense of the world around us, can help us better act in accordance with the planet’s best interests.

name: Sustainability of Social Protection
description: By the year 2050, the portion of the global population aged 65 or older will double from 10% to 20%, and about 80% of the elderly will be living in low-income countries, according to figures published by the World Bank in 2018. Yet, only about one third of the collective population in these low-income countries currently has formal retirement income, according to the figures. The dynamic created by an ageing population and a lack of available retirement funding is also concerning in developed countries; about half of the workforce in private industry in the US has no private pension coverage, while there will only be 2.2 active workers for each Social Security beneficiary by 2035, down from 2.8 workers currently, according to a bulletin published by the Social Security Administration. China’s population ageing problem is even more severe than those in other countries, due to its one-child policy which was discontinued in 2016, according to a study published in the Journal of Policy Modeling. If the Chinese government does nothing to reform its social security system, the accumulation of related debt will be explosive, according to the study. As public finances around the world are impacted by population ageing and fiscal crises, it raises questions about how public systems will be able to continue providing protections for large numbers of people. Governments everywhere are faced with difficult decisions. Social protection systems were designed around the idea of a single, full-time employment relationship; according to a report published in 2018 by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, it is unclear how growing numbers of those who are self-employed or change jobs regularly fit into standard frameworks. According to the OECD report, one interesting approach to this is the so-called artists’ insurance scheme in Germany, which covers artists and writers for health and pensions - but not for unemployment. More broadly, untying social protection from employment (by granting entitlements based on residency) could close future coverage gaps, according to the report. Countries receiving significant numbers of migrants must also determine how best to offer protections to these people; more than one in five labour migrants is not covered by a social protection scheme, according to a briefing published by the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation in 2017, while more than half of migrants cannot take social protection benefits back to their home country.

name: Sustainable Communications Infrastructure
description: The amount of electricity consumed by information and communications technology networks rose 31% between 2010 and 2015, while related operational carbon emissions rose 17%, according to a study published in 2018 by the Centre for Sustainable Communications at the KTH Royal Institute of Technology. That trend is expected to continue unabated, as internet users, devices, and data rates increase, and networks expand. More energy-efficient infrastructure can directly result in a reduction in carbon emissions; this is a particularly pressing need as the world braces for the fourth industrial revolution, which is a result of a combination of emerging technologies related to digital communications, including cloud computing, data analytics, artificial intelligence, and drones. This mix of technologies may also lead to a related mix of standards - and to a resulting fragmentation of valuable resources and capacity. Greater adaptability of infrastructure, in a world of diverse wireless standards, is essential; however, current, state-of-the-art communications networks, including emerging Long Term Evolution (LTE) networks, are based on rigid, centralized architecture. Blockchain-style distributed networking, where users are able to communicate through direct, peer-to-peer links, could improve service quality by reducing latency, and cut energy costs. Software-defined networking, which enables a network administrator to quickly manipulate traffic and services independent of hardware, and network functions virtualization, where things like intrusion detection can be done through software rather than having to rely on hardware, are being touted as the future of networks. According to a white paper published by the World Economic Forum in 2017, these technologies are being used to replace traditional, hardware-based platforms, and increase efficiency while reducing both operating costs and energy consumption. Another way to cut energy consumption, and to increase environmental sustainability, is to replace telecom networks powered by the electricity grid and batteries. Renewable energy can be problematic due to the intermittent nature of the related energy supply. However, due to the evolution of advanced power storage technologies, sustainable power generation is expected to emerge as a reliable alternative to fossil-fuel-based power in the near future. When it comes to Internet of Things networks, for example, energy harvesting sensors can provide a sustainable alternative to battery-powered sensors. The digital communications industry should make efforts to optimize accordingly.

name: Sustainable Community Design
description: Designing for a climate-challenged environment necessitates a systemic shift; an ability to absorb and recover from disaster is now paramount. In Los Angeles, a dry city where water must be transported over long distances to reach the population, an initiative called Divining LA engages city planners and low-income residents in identifying stormwater capture opportunities. Meanwhile in the Philippines, the “Design Against the Elements” competition was launched in 2010 to solicit designs for multi-use structures that can withstand increasingly-prevalent extreme weather events. Destructive storms, heatwaves, polluted air and drought caused by global warming exacerbate environmental injustices that have often located highways, power plants, hazardous waste landfills, and polluting industries in poor neighbourhoods. Yet, design can also act as a catalyst for positive change; Detroit Future City, for example, is a non-profit group stewarding a 50-year plan to use blue infrastructure (landscapes that capture and clean stormwater) and green infrastructure that harnesses nature to transform neglected parts of this shrinking, post-industrial city. In addition, in Detroit and other cities the Farm Hack online platform supports a more resilient food system by sharing best practices and designs for open-source, affordable farming tools. By addressing pollution, designers can also generate economic activity. The political and architectural practice Estudio Teddy Cruz + Fonna Forman, for example, working in partnership with local residents, has proposed functional public spaces for under-used areas along the Tijuana-San Diego border that can clean and protect the river and estuary in the area. In Kibera, a large informal settlement in Kenya, the Kibera Public Space Project was formed in 2006 to design and develop micro-enterprises, a community pavilion, a playground, and composting gardens on once-polluted areas. Innovative related forms of ownership are also sprouting up; inspired by the Mondragon Cooperatives in Spain, which prioritize people over profits, Cleveland, Ohio-based institutions including universities and hospitals are engaged in a bold experiment to create returns from the green economy for low-income residents by opening employee-owned Evergreen Cooperatives that offer these residents living-wage jobs. Meanwhile in the western US the Oglala Lakota Nation has designed a more regenerative community to counteract decades of poverty, diminishing life expectancy, and inadequate housing. Based on self-sufficiency, economic self-determination, and environmental resilience, this community is a living laboratory for developing ways to overcome systemic poverty. This key issue was curated in partnership with Cynthia E. Smith, Curator of Socially Responsible Design at Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum.

name: Sustainable Consumption
description: There were about 3.2 billion people in the middle class as of 2016, already spending a total of roughly $35 trillion annually - and roughly 140 million people are now joining the middle class every year, according to a 2017 report published by the Brookings Institution. Nearly 90% of these new entrants are in Asia, according to the report. Consumers in emerging economies in Asia and elsewhere aspire to high-consumption, western lifestyles. Efforts to encourage sustainability therefore need to expand beyond a focus on production, and pay greater attention to this growing consumer group. Only about 13% of consumers are willing to pay more for green products, according to the results of a study published in 2017 by the Network for Business Sustainability. Meanwhile about one third of the food produced for human consumption is lost or wasted globally (or about 1.3 billion tons per year), according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Companies must try to shift consumer behaviour towards greater sustainability. The World Economic Forum’s Engaging Tomorrow’s Consumer project spawned the “Collectively” digital platform, which featured founding companies including Coca-Cola and Unilever and was designed to inspire young people with stories about a more sustainable future. According to data published in the Forum’s Engaging Tomorrow’s Consumer Project Report 2015, 93% of millennials say they would buy a product because it is associated with a cause. The Fourth Industrial Revolution, which is being fuelled by converging strains of rampant technology innovation, is enabling business models that can better drive sustainability - such as the so-called sharing economy model exemplified by Uber’s ride-hailing service, or Airbnb’s rental service. The sharing economy is expected to grow in value from $14 billion as of 2014 to $335 billion by 2025, according to the Brookings Institution.

name: Sustainable Development and Universal Coverage
description: The World Health Organization has estimated that about 1.2 billion people around the world are living in extreme poverty - a significant cause of poor health outcomes, as people with limited resources face greater exposure to risks and disability due to inadequate sanitation, food, shelter, and medical care. The cost of health care is also a major contributing factor to poverty; according to a 2016 WHO fact sheet, 100 million people were being stricken with poverty due to health care costs every year, and 150 million people were suffering financial catastrophe every year because of out-of-pocket expenditures on health services. In addition, a 2017 report published by the World Bank estimated that roughly 800 million people are spending more than 10% of their household budget on health care, while nearly 200 million people must spend one quarter of their household budget on health care. The cyclical nature of poverty and sub-optimal health outcomes is evident in both high- and low-income countries. A major contributing factor is the rise of non-communicable diseases (NCDs), such as cancer or diabetes, and related risk factors that can burden individuals, their families, and entire communities; these include impoverishment from long-term treatment and care costs, and a loss of income due to reduced productivity. In 2015, the United Nations adopted Sustainable Development Goals in order to help the global community address complex, interconnected issues related to poverty, global health, human rights, economic growth, environmental sustainability, and equality. The third development goal features targets including the reduction of the burden of NCDs, and achieving universal health coverage by 2030 - including access to quality health services, effective and affordable essential medicines and vaccines, and protection from related financial risk. In a progress report on the Sustainable Development Goals published by the UN in 2017, it noted that it will be necessary to avert an anticipated shortfall of about 18 million health workers by 2030, if it is to remain possible to achieve and sustain universal health coverage by that point; major shortages of such workers are a serious concern in nearly all of the countries in sub-Saharan Africa, according to the report.

name: Sustainable Digital Transformation
description: In every industry, digital transformation is pushing companies to re-evaluate their business models, and new, technology innovation-driven market entrants are transforming the strategic landscape. Dramatic levels of disruption in media, entertainment, communications, and retail in recent years highlight the susceptibility of other sectors including healthcare, insurance, banking, energy, and automotive. How they will respond to digital disruption is an existential question for organizations around the world; successful transformations are rare. In 2018, more than $1.2 trillion will be spent by companies on digital transformation efforts, according to Our Shared Digital Future, a report published by the World Economic Forum in 2018, and only 1% of these efforts will actually achieve their goals. In addition, as much as 70% of new value created over a ten-year period is likely to be based on data-driven, digitally-enabled networks and platforms. With most digital assets in the hands of the private sector, it is the behaviour of the global business community that will shape the new digital social contract that is poised to emerge. According to the 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer, a survey conducted in 28 countries, public trust in the technology sector declined slightly compared with the prior year. In a supplementary report published by Edelman, the public relations firm noted that trust in technology among the “informed public” actually fell sharply in regions including the US, Hong Kong, and France; according to the supplementary report, a fear of fake news being used as a weapon was on the minds of seven in 10 respondents, and trust in newer, emerging technologies such as blockchain and self-driving cars commanded less public confidence than more established technologies. In addition to privacy and security concerns, there are broader ethical questions about the ways that organizations have used digital technology in a way that threatens to erode trust in institutions. There are also concerns about the effects of new digital technologies on the environment, related to power-hungry data centres, electronic waste, and the significant amounts of energy needed to power blockchain. Establishing new norms of ethical behaviour regarding digital technology, and attaining higher levels of customer trust, will be critical for a successful digital transformation. Priorities for collaboration: Developing shared strategies and roadmaps Empowering boards and employees Building networks of informed, responsible leaders

name: Sustainable Energy in the US
description: As the US approaches energy independence, thanks to record levels of domestic production, a key issue will be how, and how much, to incorporate renewables into the overall mix. Renewable energy has long been poised to impact the way Americans work, drive and play. The International Renewable Energy Agency reported in 2015 that the US was the second largest energy consumer in the world, and according to US government data, the country’s production and use of biofuels and non-hydroelectric renewable energy sources doubled between 2000 and 2014; about 10% of the energy consumed by Americans in 2014 was derived from renewable sources. However, there are concerns about the future of sustainable energy policies in the US. The Donald Trump presidency will have a decisive impact on how - and even whether - the US energy system will continue to evolve in the coming years. In 2017, Trump announced the US would withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, an international accord that aims to combat climate change. (In addition, in 2018, the US Environmental Protection Agency disclosed plans to ease vehicle emissions standards so that new cars sold would have to average about 36 miles per gallon by 2025, rather than the previously-mandated 50 miles per gallon). The renewable energy industry has proven its ability to create new jobs, and the general rise of renewables has created an economic ripple effect across US industries. The Union of Concerned Scientists 2009 report Clean Energy, Green Jobs noted that by 2025, national renewable electricity standards could generate $263.4 billion in new capital for renewable technologies, $13.5 billion in new biomass production revenue and wind land lease payments, and $11.5 billion in additional property tax revenue at the local level. A switch to renewables could also stabilize electricity prices, and lower prices (and demand) for natural gas and coal by increasing competition. Another critically important implication of this potential change to renewable energy: the US would rely less on foreign sources for its energy needs.

name: Sustainable Growth in Bangladesh
description: Bangladesh is one of the most vulnerable countries in the world to the impacts of climate change. In the southern region of the country, 40% of productive land is projected to be lost if sea levels rise 65 centimetres by the 2080s, according to a World Bank study. A government study noted that changes in crop production due to the impact of climate change will increase the number of people living in poverty, and about 20 million people in coastal areas are already affected by salinity levels in drinking water. Rising contamination of both groundwater and surface water are causing widespread diarrhoea outbreaks in some regions and the country, where only about 11% of the land was covered by forests as of 2015, is losing precious forest land. In order to achieve United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (established by agreement in 2015, to guide responsible global development until 2030) in Bangladesh, the country has implemented a number of new initiatives; the Bangladesh Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan was formulated by concerned stakeholders, and the National Sustainable Development Strategy was prepared with support from the United Nations Environment Programme. The government’s Seventh Five Year Plan, an economic growth program, emphasizes the sustainable use of resources - for example, by promoting the use of surface water instead of ground water for agriculture, and by supporting investment in agricultural research on crop varieties resistant to salinity, flooding, and cold. While measures have also been put in place to incentivize the import and use of environmentally-friendly technologies, Bangladesh must further strengthen its climate change adaptation and mitigation. Some positive signs include the establishment of the Bangladesh Climate Change Trust Fund, to address food security, social protection, health, disaster management, infrastructure, mitigation, and institutional strengthening. Steps have also been taken to promote so-called social forestry, and to establish new forests. Still, environmental groups have questioned land-use policies in the country, in addition to its energy strategy (which still relies heavily on fossil fuels), its lack of measures to protect water bodies, insufficient regulation of industrial waste management, and lack of protection for forests including the Sundarbans - the world’s largest mangrove forest. Bangladesh needs to better avail itself of assistance from the Green Climate Fund (a UN mechanism), and must boost its institutional capacity for implementing and enforcing government plans.

name: Sustainable Land Use
description: About one quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions result from agricultural activity on the nearly 50 million square kilometres of land now under cultivation - an area roughly the size of Asia. Growing and increasingly wealthy populations in developing countries will require even more agricultural acreage, often obtained through the sort of deforestation that adds to greenhouse-gas emissions. Supply must be increased to meet these demands, while at the same time land degradation is curbed and forests are somehow preserved. A tally published in the journal Nature in 2015 counted 3 trillion trees on Earth, which were being cut down at a rate of about 15 billion trees per year (researchers have estimated that the global count has dropped by nearly half since the advent of agriculture). Tropical Forest Alliance 2020, a global partnership of governments, corporations, and civic organizations, promotes sustainable forestry by subtracting deforestation from the process of cultivating products like palm oil, pulp and paper. Innovation could further reduce the environmental impact of land use, while bolstering carbon storage, water flow regulation, and biodiversity. However, in developing countries where land and water resources are under the most stress, financing new innovation is constrained by limited public budgets, and private sector investment is needed. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has found that investment in land-use R&D can generate rates of return that are between 30% and 75%. Innovation that promotes sustainable land use is a key part of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, an era when technologies like satellites, drones, and autonomous vehicles with advanced sensors can monitor soil and water conditions and crop health, big data can be analysed by software capable of sending timely recommendations to a local farmer’s mobile phone, biotechnology can breed more resilient crops, renewable energy generation can be distributed, and financial technology (or “fintech”) can be delivered to communities. The World Economic Forum’s New Vision for Agriculture, in partnership with the G7, has engaged roughly 600 organizations to work towards the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Effective innovation and collaboration, promoted through the Forum’s Innovation with a Purpose initiative, are essential for creating sustainable land use that helps mitigate climate change while feeding the world’s growing population.

name: Sustainable Production and Operation
description: The aerospace industry consumes a significant amount of fuel and materials, and the rate of production of aircraft only continues to increase. This growth should be sustainably managed for the long term; the increased use of biofuels, lightweight materials, and electrical propulsion to reduce emissions could help make this a reality. One example of lightweight material is the latest iteration of aerogel, which is able to withstand high temperatures and offers superior sound-proofing. A significant reason for the growing interest in biofuels is aviation’s substantial carbon footprint. Supplementing aviation fuel with greater amounts of biofuels could help cut down significantly on air pollution, and achieve a more sustainable mode of transport. Hybrid electrical propulsion is also being invested in by industry players, both big and small. Equipping short- to medium-range commercial passenger jets with hybrid technology could provide numerous benefits, including increased fuel efficiency (though on-board generators will likely still exist, in order to top-up batteries for electric engines), noise reduction, and simplified maintenance.

name: Sustainable Society
description: Demographic trends are on course to pose serious challenges to Korean society. In 2015, the Republic of Korea (or South Korea) had the lowest fertility rate in the world, according to World Bank data: 1.2 births per woman, down from 6.1 in 1960. The country also has an ageing population, according to the data, with 13.1% over 65 years of age as of 2015, compared with the global average of 8.27%. Women are poorly integrated into the labour force, per the data: 50% of women over the age of 15 are in the workforce, compared with 72% of men. These trends paint a picture of a country likely to struggle to sustain its economic growth. Greater immigration could provide a solution. Integrating foreigners into a highly homogenous, relatively closed society would likely be a challenge. Still, the country’s desire to continue on a positive trajectory makes more inclusive growth imperative.

name: Swiss Education and Talent
description: Switzerland features four languages (German, French, Italian, and Romansh) and distinct cultures, and connects surrounding European countries via its historic traffic routes through the Alps. It has developed a strong education system that combines world-leading post-secondary institutions with a unique vocational training (apprenticeship) system. The Swiss education system represents a healthy balance between bottom-up (market-driven) and top-down (federal) initiatives. While the vocational system is predominantly driven by professional organizations, the post-secondary system is driven by cantons (the state jurisdictions within Switzerland) and by the federal government (when it comes to the federal institutes of technology). The education system is funded by a mix of federal and cantonal subsidies, industry financing, and student contributions. According to the World Economic Forum’s Global Human Capital Report 2017, Switzerland benefits from the high quality of its education system, strong vocational training and a high level of skills diversity. The country ranked 3rd in the overall Human Capital Index (behind Norway and Finland), and was rated best in terms of know-how, and second-best in terms of development. The strength of the Swiss education and training system was demonstrated during the financial crisis, when youth unemployment rates soared in many European countries but remained relatively stable in Switzerland, Germany, and Austria. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Switzerland’s market-driven, vocational and professional education and training system benefits from the strong influence of employers. However, vocational and on-the-job training is becoming less attractive for young people. As a result, various initiatives have been launched to promote dual-education and fight youth unemployment. According to the 2016-2017 Times Higher Education’s World University Rankings and ShanghaiRanking’s Academic Ranking, Swiss institutions such as the two Swiss Federal Institutes of Technology (ETH Zurich and EPF Lausanne) are among the best worldwide. This has contributed to a relatively high proportion of international faculty members and students, which further strengthens the system. However, it has been projected that Switzerland will suffer from a significant lack of skilled employees in the near future. Changes in the job market and dramatic shifts in skills requirements have played a role. The skills mismatch is not unique to Switzerland; the World Economic Forum’s 2017 white paper Realizing Human Potential in the Fourth Industrial Revolution recommends addressing the situation by ensuring there is a sufficient science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education to deliver strong digital skills.

name: Swiss Trade Trends
description: In 2016, Switzerland’s trade openness, measured as the sum of imports and exports of both goods and services, amounted to 120% of the country’s GDP, or six percentage points higher than it had been the previous year. Switzerland’s economy is among the most highly developed in Europe, with a trade openness that ranks behind only Luxembourg, Belgium, and the Netherlands. Switzerland’s trade surplus shrunk from 12% of GDP in 2013 to 8% of GDP by 2016, as a result of the growth of imports relative to exports. The country, which is home to pharmaceutical giants such as Roche and Novartis, engineering giant ABB, several watchmakers, and other large manufacturers, had exports as of 2016 that were concentrated in chemical and pharmaceutical products (44.8% of the total), machines and electronics (14.7%), and watches (9.2%). In real terms, exports declined by 0.8% between 2015 and 2016, with the decline most pronounced for the struggling watch industry (watch exports fell 15.3% in real terms). The destinations of Swiss exports changed substantially between 2005 and 2016; the share headed to the European Union fell from 63% of the total to 48% during the period. Within the EU, Switzerland`s key export destinations in 2016 were Germany (14.3%), the United Kingdom (10.7%), and France (6.1%). Outside the EU, Swiss exports mainly went to the US (12.1%) and mainland China (9%). The origin points of Switzerland’s imports have changed dramatically since 2005, when 80% came from the EU; by 2016, that figure fell to 56%. Meanwhile Switzerland has increased imports from the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, and the US. Data from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development show considerable production sharing between Switzerland and Germany as of 2011 (the most recent available). This reflects a significant amount of intermediates being traded between Germany and Switzerland for further processing, and highlights the intricate supply chain network binding the two countries. Production sharing also takes place between Switzerland and Italy, though to a much less significant degree.

name: Synergies and Collaboration
description: The inflow of talent to many industries has been threatened by a decline of interest in careers related to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), particularly in countries that have well-established legacies and capabilities in the materials field. This trend may only become more prominent, if universities and other places where our work forces are developed fail to recognize that increasingly interconnected professional fields require a new type of professional who is capable of thinking, creating, and operating in a collaborative fashion, devoid of the boundaries that may have traditionally protected an industry like materials. This in-demand ability to work as part of a dynamic ecosystem poses challenges to the supply of talent not only in technical disciplines; it is particularly important when working to develop smarter regulation, more effective risk management, and more productive stakeholder relations. Only a truly dynamic and nimble regulatory system can provide the support and oversight necessary for the fast past-paced technical progress anticipated in the materials field. This is especially true in the case of biological materials, where extended approval processes may have not only a detrimental effect on the time to commercialization for innovations, but more importantly, may dis-incentivize truly disruptive innovation to begin with, by discouraging risk-taking. It may also result in developers cutting corners and compromising on the quality of the discovery process. In parallel, schemes that can facilitate the more effective deployment of capital at all stages, whether it is for funding basic research, or for scaling up entrepreneurial, emerging businesses that fuel disruption in the form of venture capital or other private equity financing, should also better adapt to the growing complexity of risk presented by the blurring boundaries that once safely separated disciplines. These challenges call for the establishment of more collaborative platforms, where the protection of investors, consumers, and others all along the value chain receives a greater amount of resources (financial and otherwise), and the attention of a broader range of actors. Ultimately, risk must be more carefully distributed according to each actor’s ability and role, and must not be allowed to blunt the tireless search for new business models.

name: Synthetic Biology
description: Civilization has largely set course for a more resource-efficient and sustainable global economy. One of the ultimate goals is to reconcile demand for chemical materials needed to treat human disease, develop sustainable agriculture and fisheries, bolster food security, and power industrial applications with the need to ensure biodiversity and environmental protection. In order to help achieve this, many countries have leveraged advances in synthetic biology and metabolic engineering by using natural biological processes to produce important chemicals - and making use of standardized, intelligent “cell factories” (collections of microbial cells, often built from bacteria or yeast, that can function like a chemical production facility). The consequences of this could be as significant as the impact of alchemy on chemistry millennia ago, with enormous and as perhaps unimaginable implications for medicine and materials science. The range of potential applications is vast, encompassing, and not limited to: diagnostics, therapeutics, sensors, environmental remediation, energy production, and biomolecular and chemical manufacturing. Studies have shown, for example, the potential to deploy bacteria-based cell factories to sustainably produce ethanol and butanol - which could in turn be used to de-carbonize transportation. Following the emergence of recombinant DNA technology, which mashes up DNA from different species to produce combinations that have value for medicine or industry, biological systems have become widely used in industries such as chemicals and pharmaceuticals. However, the cell factories underpinning these processes often encounter systemic failure and suffer from instability. Synthetic biology and metabolic engineering can be applied to these problems by developing cells specifically designed for predictable, efficient, and streamlined production. Synthetic biology and metabolic engineering also enable the development of new biological systems capable of efficiently producing industrial chemicals and materials while consuming relatively less time, labour, and money. Some examples of this trend include reported advances in the microbial production of gasoline, terephthalic acid (an organic compound used to make clothing and plastic bottles), 1,4-butanediol (used to make fibres such as Spandex), and aromatic polyesters. In 2016, systems metabolic engineering was selected as one of the Top 10 emerging technologies by the World Economic Forum, for the ways that it can be used to more sustainably and affordably produce chemicals by using plants instead of fossil fuels.

name: Systemic Risk and Resilience
description: Just as a country with extensive borders must fortify a relatively greater number of potential points of entry, the growing expanse of digital networks has multiplied the amount of digital ground that must be placed under surveillance. It is now easy to become overwhelmed by the amount of security data being received, and by the frequency of false alarms produced by computer sensory systems. So-called data fusion, or methods by which organizations can collect, filter, and identify disparate intrusion information, must be constructed in such a way that they maximize cyber-situational awareness. Governments and businesses can use data fusion to test defense systems and more accurately identify cyberattacks, in order to rapidly respond. Meanwhile the people analysing raw cyber security data can benefit from greater automation - which can highlight data patterns that indicate a potential intrusion. However, this presents new challenges, as cyber security professionals now have to determine just how precise their warning systems are; automation that produces false alarms, and fails to detect actual threats, jeopardizes cyber security. In order to properly mitigate security risks and maximize resilience, information must be efficiently and accurately processed. Computer scientist George Tadda has outlined specific metrics that can be used to continually examine automation procedures and calculate a system’s purity, cost utility, and timeliness - such as recall, precision, and fragmentation. By making incremental changes to pattern recognition and human assessment, organizations can optimize their system resilience. A report published by the World Economic Forum in 2017, Advancing Cyber Resilience; Principles and Tools for Boards, outlined a cyber-attack in 2016 that blocked access to services including Twitter and the New York Times’ website; the attack took advantage of specific strategic choices that had been made by the companies involved, including a “speed-to-market” strategy for hardware that made a significant number of devices vulnerable to hackers, and a decision to concentrate resources on one or a few servers rather than spreading the load across several. The report laid out a series of principles for bolstering resilience, including having corporate boards accurately gauge risk appetite, and ensuring that one, fully-authorized corporate officer is accountable for reporting on the organization’s capability to manage the implementation of cyber resilience.

name: Systems Change
description: Social entrepreneurs have posted a string of successes, whether it has been through VisionSpring’s provision of eyeglasses to millions of poor people in developing countries, or the more than 160 million books and other essentials provided to educators of children in need by First Book. Yet, the social innovation sector is coming to terms with the limits of incremental growth, according to Beyond Organizational Scale: How Social Entrepreneurs Create Systems Change, a report published by the World Economic Forum in 2017. Society’s needs are significant, and models for scaling up in size to meet them are still too narrow, or take too long to implement. While simply replicating private sector service delivery models is often ineffective, some forward-thinking social innovators are moving towards a model of systems change - meaning, transformation on a broad scale that even small organizations can help facilitate. True systems change requires an inclusive approach that focuses on the connections that link an ecosystem together, rather than focusing on delivering a predefined solution to intended beneficiaries. Social innovation has helped transform beneficiaries into actors who can help expand a business, as clients or employees. Social innovators need to adapt to the local environment. A continuous flow of data and evidence is necessary in order to create feedback mechanisms in systems, according to the Forum’s report; the monitoring and evaluation enabled by this flow can serve as tools for continuous improvement and reassessment, potentially enabling social entrepreneurs to alter course as needed. Systems change also requires developing a shared understanding of problems facing a multitude of different stakeholders, with differing motivations. For systems change to occur, social innovators must convene these disparate players, who are often from sectors that may not have worked together previously. Governments, in particular, can be a crucial partner for achieving large-scale, systemic change. Social innovators therefore need to develop skills such as coalition building, and negotiating legislative reform - and organizations need to either create new roles for people who have these skill sets, or invest in educating existing employees.

name: Systems Leadership
description: “Systems leadership” is about leading in a situation where power is diffused, and where the consequences of decisions are magnified and less predictable as their impact progressively ripples across domains. It requires cultivating a shared vision for change, and empowering innovation and collaborative action. According to a report published by Harvard Kennedy School’s Corporate Social Responsibility Initiative in 2016, systems leadership is needed to address complex problems related to food security, climate change, and gender equality - which cannot be solved with a top-down, pre-planned approach that focuses on one area to the exclusion of others. Instead, these problems call for the engagement of diverse stakeholders from multiple sectors. Systems leadership done right also means balancing short- and long-term goals in order to optimize value for everyone, not only for the loudest, wealthiest, or most influential. By cultivating a shared vision, according to the Harvard Kennedy School report, nimble systems leadership can galvanize a diverse array of interested parties and help ensure that their efforts align, potentially producing better results in faster way than would otherwise be possible. The attributes of an individual “systems leader” include humility, integrity, an interest in the system over one’s self, and an ability to facilitate constructive dialogue. The Harvard Kennedy School report cited as an example the World Economic Forum’s New Vision for Agriculture initiative. Following the food crisis of 2007 and 2008, which saw the price of food staples like rice, corn, and wheat rise dramatically to the detriment of many people in the developing world, the Forum’s initiative brought together stakeholders from business, government, and civil society to build greater resilience into the food supply chain - a highly complex, fragile system vulnerable to external shocks, over which no single actor can exercise meaningful control. As part of the initiative, 17 companies, including food manufacturers, commodity traders, and beverage producers, came together with key government representatives and civil society members in a neutral space to map out issues, system linkages, and opportunities for action. More than 500 different organizations are now participating in related efforts, according to the report; these include working with farmers’ groups to build more sustainable value chains for specific commodities, and sharing farmers’ needs with financial institutions so appropriate credit and insurance products can be developed.

name: Talent Patterns
description: The global competition for workers with desirable skills is intense. China’s strategic focus on developing a highly-skilled, science- and innovation-focused workforce will place increasing pressure on the ability of other countries to tap related talent, for example. Meanwhile Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) member states, including Qatar and Saudi Arabia, are seeking to fill entire market sectors with migrant workers, both unskilled and skilled. As governments re-think their migration and labour policies, it can have far-reaching effects. The GCC’s Council of Labour and Social Development Ministers, for example, has announced plans to unify the bloc’s labour market, and to provide avenues for the naturalization of migrant workers. And in Bahrain, which has seen irregular flows of migrant workers mostly from South Asia since the 1970s, and where an estimated more than 60% of the country’s workforce is made up of overseas workers, the government opted in 2016 to implement a regularization program intended to curb the abuse of migrant workers and of the country’s work visa system, in part by providing tens of thousands of official work permits to foreign workers without sponsors. Another example is Malaysia, which relies heavily on migrant workers from countries including Bangladesh, and has sought to bolster its regulations on foreign labour in order to conform with the standards of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. In the US, there has been increased scrutiny of the use of so-called H-1B visas - which are issued to skilled workers from abroad (many in the technology sector), and have been criticized by President Donald Trump as a tool for American firms to use relatively cheap foreign labour. Proponents counter that the visas help companies tap the best possible talent. The percentage of H-1B visa petitions that are rejected rose to 41% in fiscal 2017 (ended in June 2017), from 13% in the prior year, according to US Citizenship and Immigration Services data. Most beneficiaries of H-1B petitions, or 247,927 out of a total of 336,107, were from India, according to the data, while the next-largest group of petitioners was from China. It remains to be seen whether multi-national corporations and governments will ever be able to fully exploit technology in order to realize decades-old conceptions of a virtual global workforce - which could enable people to reap the benefits of migration remotely, without being affected by political trends.

name: Targeting the Poor
description: In 2014, the World Bank reported that despite Bangladesh spending the equivalent of roughly 2% of its GDP on social safety net programs, about 70% of the country’s poor people were still not receiving any safety net support - largely due to shortcomings in identifying beneficiaries, and weak administration. In developing countries, the design of social insurance and poverty alleviation programs must enable the accurate targeting of the poor, and the adequate enforcement of related regulations. This is particularly true in regions where employment in the unofficial, grey economy is extensive, and where information for targeting purposes is therefore limited. In Iraq, for example, where development has been undercut by decades of conflict and economic decline, overall progress towards poverty reduction stalled after 2007, according to a report published by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in 2016. The report noted that a targeting system in Iraq for providing cash transfers to nearly 1 million households resulted in only 11% of the poor receiving their benefits. In response to Iraq’s challenges, according to the report, the World Bank coordinated a knowledge exchange program with other countries including Turkey and Lebanon, which shared details about their respective cash transfer and targeting programs. Iraq has now developed a Social Protection Strategic Roadmap through 2019, according to the report. The need for better targeting is not confined to developing economies. According to an article published by Eurostat, the number of people in the European Union at risk of poverty or social exclusion in 2016 was higher than it had been in 2008 - despite a European target of reducing this population by 20 million, by the year 2020.
