Within individual EU member states, the effectiveness of social benefit programs for helping those at risk of poverty varied greatly, according to the article; while Finland was able to use such social transfers to decrease its poverty rate, in Romania transfers were far less successful, according to the report. Differences in the effectiveness of social protection spending can result from the underlying poverty levels before related programs begin, but they can also result from the design of that spending, according to the report.

name: Taxation
description: In its World Economic Outlook published in late 2018, the International Monetary Fund noted that a recent US tax overhaul was likely to widen the country’s fiscal deficit - which had already been under pressure due to spending on support for the country’s ageing population. While deficit expansion has provided a short-term boost to economic activity in the US, according to the IMF report, it has also piled onto already-unsustainable public debt, and created elevated risk not only for the US economy but for other global economies as well. In early 2018, the US Congressional Budget Office projected that the country’s deficit will surpass $1 trillion by 2020, two years sooner than had been previously estimated. The fiscal pressure comes as the US administration has signaled that it would like to move ahead with long-planned and significant spending on infrastructure. A country’s priorities, fiscal policies, and ways that its government collects taxes and spends public resources can all play major roles in boosting sustainable development, reducing poverty, and addressing inequality. However, priorities vary significantly from country to country. While France spent the equivalent of 31.5% of its GDP on social spending (defined as resources redistributed to low-income households, the elderly, the young, the unemployed, the disabled, or the sick) in 2016, South Korea spent the equivalent of 10.4%, according to data published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development; the OECD spending average for 2016 was 21% of GDP, while the figure for the US was the equivalent of 19.3% of GDP. Taxation can provide a means of directly addressing market inequalities, as long as it is designed to minimize loopholes, ensures a progressive system where high earners pay a larger share, and provides for funding to reach those most in need without dampening their incentive to work. Meanwhile government-funded social safety nets can mitigate the effects of external economic shocks, and help the chronically poor benefit from growth. For the most vulnerable groups of people with no other means of adequate support, such as single-parent households and the disabled, cash transfers can be a viable option. One example of a cash transfer program, in Zambia, was cited by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations for reducing extreme poverty by reaching about 150,000 households between 2003 and 2014.

name: Tech and Connectivity in Latin America
description: Advancements in terms of information and communications technology vary across different parts of Latin America; infrastructure development and penetration rates differ greatly between countries, between urban and rural areas, and between multiple urban areas within the same country. According to the World Bank, as of 2017 there were 107.4 mobile cellular subscriptions per 100 people in Latin America and the Caribbean, compared with the global average of 104.5. Digital literacy among the region’s population remains low, however, and most of the technology being used is imported. According to a report published by the GSMA in 2018, 57% of people in Latin America are covered by a mobile broadband network but do not subscribe, while one in 10 people live outside of mobile broadband coverage. In addition, mobile internet service in Latin America often lags in terms of quality. According to a report published by the Inter-American Development Bank in 2018, only an average of 17% of the populations in Latin American countries has adopted 4G technology - which is at least 10 times faster than previous mobile technologies and is essential for accessing most applications and services, including secure online payments. Low broadband quality also limits access to cloud-computing services, which could enable companies in the region to access higher computing capacity at lower costs. Young people in Latin America who are online are relatively active, and hungry for both new information and outlets for expression; yet, their digital economy skills are falling behind employer demands. Private initiatives with government support aimed at addressing this gap could help ensure that Latin America fully benefits from the digital economy.

name: Technological Arms Race
description: Major world powers are concerned about a new arms race. Chinese President Xi Jinping told China's second World Internet Conference in 2015 that "each country should join hands and together … fight against a cyberspace arms race". At the 2016 meeting of the G20 in Hangzhou, China, US President Barack Obama warned that while the US has significant offensive and defensive capacities for cyber warfare, the country’s intention is not to escalate into an arms race, as had happened in the past. The China-US agreement on cyber intrusions reached in 2015 has been hailed as a good first step, but progress on international accords in other fields, such as lethal autonomous weapons, is moving very slowly. The United Nations discussion on Lethal Autonomous Weapons Systems held in 2016 resulted in a suggestion that states agree to establish a group of experts to make further recommendations. Meanwhile, even though killer robots may be some way off, a degree of autonomy (enabled by artificial intelligence – AI - software) is creeping into platforms that deliver lethal effects. The Anti-Submarine Warfare Continuous Trail Unmanned Vessel, under development at the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), is a drone designed to track and ultimately destroy an enemy submarine. A new Long Range Anti-Ship Missile is being developed to semi-autonomously track and destroy enemy targets at long ranges. There is a growing awareness that technology can disrupt strategic stability when new types of weapons offer a way to level the playing field or tip the balance in another direction. For example, a swarm of autonomous drones might neutralize a super-power`s nuclear deterrence capabilities, and create conditions where a sudden conventional attack might succeed. Research on the military potential from bioengineering, gene therapy, nano-engineering and neuroscience may be less visible, but history suggests that it has not escaped attention. Ethical concerns that might otherwise be a restraining factor are often compromised when it comes to defence. When science fiction predicted the invention of the aircraft could lead to mass bombing, the notion was rejected on the basis that people would never be so immoral as to target civilians en masse. Even after the end of the Second World War human beings were used as guinea pigs for the development of chemical, nuclear and biological weapons.   It is important to note that competition to develop new technologies has benefits. Aerospace and defence industry investments in research into new forms of energy for their platforms have the potential to deliver advances in green energy. Much of the technology relevant for security is dual purpose, and this creates problems that can only be solved by effective public-private partnership. That requires a common understanding that just as technology has the potential to re-shape war, security policy will also be shaping the development and use of new technologies. Technology may offer ways to control and even tame conflict. Miscalculation is always a factor in war, and belligerents seldom start a fight knowing they will lose. But superior analytical accuracy from big data and machine learning could demonstrate – both to decision-makers and to those they represent - that the costs of war are likely to exceed the potential gain. For instance, Integral Mind Technologies, an AI company, recently introduced cogSolv, an AI system designed to understand how people from other groups view the world, simulate their reactions, and combine this with knowledge of the real world to avoid unintended offense, find persuasive negotiation win-wins and provide peacekeeping decision tools. The Fourth Industrial Revolution could deliver new forms of transparency to neutralize the advantage of surprise attacks, dispel unjustified fear and discourage aggression.

name: Technological Barriers
description: Virtual and augmented reality (VR and AR)  have been key technologies in niche markets such as flight simulation, automobile manufacturing and military training since the 1980s. While in the past science fiction novelists envisioned that we may one day access an alternate world based on a VR simulation, visors, and haptic devices (those that a user can virtually touch and feel), mass adoption was then unthinkable due to limited real-time graphics capabilities, computing power, and the high cost of hardware. With the democratization of high resolution displays, mobile processing, and the advancement of high-end gaming engines, VR and AR are poised to make a global impact beyond entertainment and gaming, with applications in education, health, business, retail, social media and communication in general. Facebook’s acquisition of Oculus in 2014 certainly played a significant role in accelerating the emergence of this technology. Other internet, software, and telecommunications companies such as Google, HTC, Sony, Microsoft, Huawei, Tencent, Apple and Snap are hoping for VR/AR to finally take off. In early 2016, Strategy Analytics estimated that early adoption of VR headsets would generate $895 million in revenue in the course of 2016, while cautioning that VR technology may not be ready yet. Not even a year later - in spring 2017 – Forbes reported that the interest and number of VR/AR sold units was substantially below expectation, especially when compared to predictions made for smartphones when they were first introduced. This slow growth is mainly caused by technological barriers and a lack of content and successful applications. While the price of technology will continue to drop, VR headsets are facing obvious hardware limitations such as their uncomfortable and bulky shapes and unnatural user interfaces. Insufficient display resolutions, frame rates and latency can cause cyber-sickness to the user and prevent extended usage. The development of this technology does not seem to be fast enough, and the creation of high quality virtual content is still difficult and expensive. While important progress in position tracking and optics is expected in coming years, studies reported in The Guardian and the Wall Street Journal have shown that current devices and VR experiences can cause physical side effects such as motion sickness, nausea, disorientation and headaches. Long-term effects such as seizures and poor hand-eye coordination have been documented, and researchers have raised concerns that there is still limited knowledge about how VR will affect children’s developing brains. The challenges and costs of producing and delivering enticing VR content is another critical reason for the slow adoption. Despite aggressive initiatives from operators such as Oculus, HTC and Google to engage the developer community to prioritize high-quality VR content, many producers and game publishers are not yet convinced that existing VR systems can provide a superior experience. Nevertheless, Silicon Valley and Chinese venture capitalists are not shying away from its potential, and are heavily betting on technology startups such as Jaunt VR, 8i, and Felix & Paul Studios for VR content creation. While specialized spherical 3D camera solutions and multi-view capture techniques are often involved for recording live action VR content, truly interactive and immersive experiences in VR still depend on conventional game development pipelines, which are expensive and slow. It will still take years until technologies for scalable content creation will become accessible for end consumers, but recent advances in computer graphics and machine learning are promising. In the meantime, film studios such as Disney and Fox and prominent Hollywood filmmakers such as Jon Favreau are exploring VR as a medium and tool for rapid virtual production and storytelling to increase the turn-around times in traditional film pipelines.

name: Technological Competition
description: In 2017, while talking to students about the “colossal” opportunities and threats presented by artificial intelligence, Russian President Vladimir Putin suggested that whoever, or whichever country, is able to become dominant in the field could rule the world. The rapid evolution of new technologies is already influencing the geopolitics of our multipolar, multi-conceptual world, where power has shifted and political ideas and values have fractured. This upheaval raises questions about how we should think about, and prepare for, war in the midst of the Fourth Industrial Revolution. In the same way that the first industrial revolution (the advent of manufacturing) created a decades-long progress gap between Britain and even its closest rivals, and the second (rapid industrialization) and third (digitalization) industrial revolutions helped spawn a period in which the US was globally pre-eminent, the Fourth Industrial Revolution and its convergence of digital technologies will have a marked influence on geopolitics. There are likely to be two primary channels for this. The first is through the economic gains that will flow to countries that emerge as technology leaders, particularly as a winner-takes-all dynamic characterizes many key technologies today. The second is through the application of new technologies to new types of weapons, and new types of conflict. For example, cyberattacks on critical infrastructure, drone swarms, or new methods of disrupting an adversary’s domestic political system could alter the global balance of power in unexpected ways. According to a McKinsey Global Institute paper published in 2018, the scramble to secure the high ground in terms of the technologies of the Fourth Industrial Revolution is unfolding at a frenetic pace and it has largely become a two-horse race; the 20 largest technology companies in the world are now either American or Chinese. In terms of artificial intelligence, for example, the rest of the world lags behind these two countries on key indicators such as patents, funding, and talent. And while a 2018 report written by researchers at Oxford’s Future of Humanity Institute found that China still trails the US in every AI driver except for data, this could change. The Chinese government issued a strategy document in 2017 resolving to position the country as the global leader in AI by 2030, by funnelling a large amount of public funding into the sector and by helping startups attract more venture capital.

name: Technological Innovation
description: Some innovation, like the development of new pharmaceuticals, has an obvious and direct link to novel scientific research; other types may result from using existing technology in a new way, or even from developments in unrelated fields. Many companies behind the sharing economy, for example, are essentially offshoots of existing internet and smartphone technologies. While emerging technologies like drones and 3D printing may create new markets and disrupt existing value networks, radical technical innovation in the form of so-called "general purpose" technologies has the potential to disrupt entire groups of industries; examples include the steam engine, the automobile, the computer, the internet and, potentially, artificial intelligence - all of which have had profound consequences for society. Technological innovation encompasses more than research and development. However, since research and development is key, many policy-makers have been keen to focus on ways in which it can be improved. Common areas of focus include national systems for research funding, systems for awarding and protecting patents (which are sometimes state-subsidized), the improvement of translating university research into value for the private sector; and tax incentives for innovative firms (such as R&D tax credits, or special tax regimes for revenue derived from intellectual property). R&D tends to be heavily concentrated. The Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development’s Science, Technology and Industry Scoreboard 2017 reported that the 50 largest R&D performers account for 40% of all business R&D efforts in Canada and the US, and for more than half of such efforts in Germany and Japan. In addition, according to the report, the headquarters of the top 2,000 R&D corporations worldwide are concentrated mostly in the US, China, and Japan; about 70% of these firms’ total R&D spending is concentrated within just 200 firms. Organizations undertaking technical research may not have the expertise or the desire to bring new products to market, so innovation often entails transferring knowledge and technology from universities and research groups to other entities - often in conjunction with the licensing of intellectual property. An alternative route to market, which may be preferable where no suitable organization already exists or where there is an opportunity to capture more value, is to form a startup or spinoff. In order to facilitate technological innovation in specific industries, some countries have established intermediary institutions, like Germany’s Fraunhofer Society institutes and the United Kingdom’s Catapult Centres.

name: Technological Symbiosis
description: Now, more than ever before, the interaction among advanced technologies plays a critical role in each of their respective development paths. For example, materials technologies and related issues are playing a defining role in the development of computing (via control of the laws of physics at the level of individual components, such as memory, circuits, or data storage devices), human enhancement (in terms of bio-compatible assemblies, optical devices, and skeletal components), and space technologies (from propulsion and communications systems to vehicle structures). Progress in advanced materials has in turn benefited greatly from rapid developments in computing, which offers powerful tools for modelling and visualization, data manipulation, and analysis, thereby enabling the bottom-up design of materials and optimization through feedback loops (where output from one effort is used as input for another). The next generation of materials development will likely incorporate emerging technologies such as robotics and artificial intelligence in integrated discovery processes - from experimental design, to rapid prototyping, to automated data acquisition and analysis, decision-making abilities, and self-optimizing pathways to solutions. Boundaries will continue to blur, and materials will evolve systemically. This is true not only of the application of, and inter-relations between technologies, but also of other important inputs to the development process. Data scientists, programmers, and algorithm designers will increasingly work hand-in-hand with material scientists and representatives of more traditional disciplines - spurring expertise deployment, and cross-nurturing. However, while a virtuous cycle may be formed among certain technologies and their paths to progress, deceleration or arrested development may compromise systemic evolution. For example, overly stringent regulations governing the use of materials may hinder other, adjacent sectors’ abilities to confront and conquer their most pressing challenges. These risks can be greatly minimized by working to increase the efficiency of collaboration, by broadening the education and interests of scientists and engineers, and by involving all stakeholders (public and private) in decision-making.

name: Technology Access and Inclusion
description: More than half of the global population is now using the internet. However, digital access and adoption have not been evenly distributed; according to the International Telecommunications Union, only 24.4% of Africa’s population was online as of 2018, even as Europe boasted a 79.6% internet penetration rate, while in the Americas penetration registered at 69.6% (more promising statistics show that growth during recent years in both mobile cellular subscriptions and mobile broadband subscriptions has been driven by countries in Asia and Africa). Creating more inclusive digital communities is essential for reducing this digital divide - by not only bolstering affordability and public access, but also by increasing digital skills and awareness. Greater digital inclusion can also improve public services and participation; for example, Maputo, Mozambique, which has a serious solid waste management problem and where a majority of residents live in informal settlements, has deployed a participatory monitoring platform (MOPA) and encouraged citizens to use it to report waste issues and to keep track of waste management services - in a bid to help improve service delivery. By gaining access to increasing amounts of digital content, people can become better able to understand and navigate the digital systems increasingly relied upon to deliver services related to health care, education, employment, and civic participation. Vulnerable communities like the exploding population of refugees and internally displaced people (as of June 2019, the UN Refugee Agency estimated there were nearly 26 million refugees worldwide, and more than 41 million internally displaced people) can particularly benefit from greater digital inclusion. Mobile phones are essential for refugees to coordinate travel and communicate with family; in 2016, Turkcell, a Turkish telecommunications company, launched its Hello Hope (“Merhaba Umut”) mobile app to help Syrian refugees in the country with basic language training and the provision of important basic information in Arabic and Turkish. Greater digital accessibility also presents an opportunity to better empower communities with more specific needs, like indigenous people, rural communities, people with disabilities (via assistive technologies like voice-recognition software), women and girls, and young people who have been historically disenfranchised.

name: Technology Adoption
description: Ethiopia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of fibre internet subscriptions, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 0.70, resulting in a rank of 106th out of 114 countries; and in terms of fixed-broadband internet subscriptions where it has a progress score of 1.10 that results in a rank of 115th out of 140 countries. One indicator reflects a better performance: mobile-cellular telephone subscriptions, where it has a progress score of 49.70 that results in a rank of 130th out of 140 countries.

name: Technology Governance
description: Powerful digital tools like artificial intelligence are swiftly disintermediating entire markets - which has taken influence away from traditional regulators and unskilled workers, and given it to corporations and skilled labour. Governments are being challenged to move beyond simply understanding major technological advances, to mitigating, shaping, and harnessing them in order to govern better, and to become more accessible, transparent, and trustworthy. Soon, governments will be forced to entirely change their approaches to creating and enforcing regulation, not least in order to better stimulate rather than stymie innovation. Potentially, governments will have to create brand-new instruments to cope with the spread of new technologies, either by nurturing internal expertise or working with the private sector. Governments that are agile will be able to find ways to reinvent themselves so they can better understand what they are regulating; close collaboration with businesses and civil society organizations will likely be necessary to make that happen. Faster, 5G networks are making digital communication more ubiquitous, while increasing processing power and storage capacity are boosting the scope of knowledge immediately available to any computer user. This, coupled with the increased availability and quality of data communicated through visualization and other analytic techniques, has the potential to fundamentally reshape public services so that they can respond more directly to citizen needs. But there is also a dark side to be managed. According to Cisco’s 2018 Annual Cybersecurity Report, cyber attackers targeting governments have developed increasingly sophisticated and threatening malware, and can cover their tracks with encryption while exploiting new vulnerabilities in cloud computing and the Internet of Things. Rules such as the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation, which came into effect in 2018, are critical for managing the consequences of such threats - but will also introduce new complexity to governing.

name: Technology Investment in Turkey
description: Compared with other countries, Turkey has come up short when it comes to developing and integrating new technologies. According to World Bank data, despite steady improvement over the years, R&D spending as a percentage of GDP had only reached 0.88% by 2015 - far short of the 4.3% registered for Israel that year, and the 3.3% for Japan, and still well short of both the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 2.4% and the global average of 2.1% (though more recent data from the OECD show Turkish investment climbing to 0.96% of GDP by 2017). One bright spot might be procurement, an area where Turkish companies are close to the European average in terms of how many processes have been digitized, as the country has demonstrated significant “investment appetite” for related technologies like blockchain, according to a report published by the consultancy PwC in 2019. About 43% of service sector procurement in the country is digital at this point, compared with 63% in Belgium, 52% in Italy, and 45% in France, according to the report. Turkey is home to dozens of artificial intelligence-related startups, and the Turkey Artificial Intelligence Initiative was established in 2017 as a common platform for promoting AI applications and improving local awareness. Cybersecurity has also become a major focus; according to an International Telecommunication Union Global Cybersecurity Index report published in 2018, which measures the cybersecurity “commitment” of member states, Turkey ranked 20th - one slot ahead of Denmark, and one behind Finland. This level of commitment is merited; the number of cyberattacks in Turkey rose by 24.9% in the first half of 2018 compared with the same period a year earlier, which followed a 21.9% annual increase during 2017, according an executive from Kaspersky Lab cited in Turkish media. In 2017, the Turkish government established the Turkish Cyber Security Cluster project in order to foster cooperation and healthy competition in the cybersecurity market. The project has attracted hundreds of members, including electronics and appliance maker Vestel, KoçSistem (a digital division of the conglomerate Koç Holding), and military electronics maker Aselsan.

name: Technology Leadership
description: The Fourth Industrial Revolution, a new era characterized by emerging technologies fusing the physical and digital worlds at a potentially disconcerting pace, is opening up competitive gaps among economies and global businesses. Seven of the world’s 10 largest companies by market capitalization are now technology firms, most of which were founded less than a generation ago, and all of which are based in just two countries: the US and China. As they shred old assumptions about how businesses can create value, the ascendance of these market-dominating, often technology-driven firms appears inexorable, creating unforeseeable economic and political consequences. The uncertainties and opportunities that major technological advances generate will have a dramatic effect on the legitimacy (and effectiveness) of both private sector and political leaders. “Technology leadership” describes the way that these leaders can harness change, in order to meet strategic goals, generate value, and create an inclusive economy. Technology leadership is not only an ability to operate in the space between technology development, and traditional public and private structures; it is about being comfortable delving into both realms. Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, for example, must not only understand the nuts and bolts of his product, but also grasp the impact that this platform has on free speech and news dissemination. The International Telecommunications Union estimates that less than half of the global population is now connected using some form of internet-enabled device. This reflects the stubborn digital divide separating those with internet access from those who remain without. Connectivity growth has been moving in the right direction in the world’s least developed countries, however, with internet user penetration in these areas projected to reach 17.5% by 2017, from 15.6% the prior year, according to an ITU report. The varying pace at which powerful tools like internet access and artificial intelligence are spreading sharpens existing divides and creates challenges for regulators - by removing parts of existing markets from under their purview, and creating new, unregulated sectors (traditional economic actors and workers are also affected). In addition, the blurring of traditional boundaries separating sectors imposes demands on leadership teams, which must go beyond simply understanding major technological advances to understanding how to mitigate their impact on traditional organizational structures.

name: Technology and Digitalization
description: Technology and digitalization have transformed our lives, and have often made them more efficient, comfortable and connected. Technology also continues to be an important force for enabling changes in behaviour, particularly in terms of boosting productivity and supporting active lifestyles. Fitness trackers can help motivate people to exercise, for example, especially when paired with social media platforms. Brightly-coloured graphics and tactile interfaces enable the gamification of challenges that otherwise might be more difficult to overcome. One example: the sudden and dramatic increase in the playing of “Pokémon go” several years ago, which managed to get millions of people off of the couch and outside, even if just for a little while. In order to reap the maximum benefit of these technologies, their design must encourage seamless interaction. The so-called “uncanny valley” effect of human representations that are less than 100% convincing, for example, can cause feelings of revulsion. Behavioural sciences can inform the design of technologies - mobile apps, avatars and robots, and driverless cars - based on knowledge about how users think and make decisions. Which designs appeal to humans? Which can be intuitively understood? By providing answers to these questions, the interplay of humans and machines can result in maximum benefit. In addition, behavioural scientists can help provide answers to pressing questions about the risks of increasing digitalization, such as what is the cost of monitoring and quantifying every aspect of our personal lives, how will this affect our well-being, and will we feel like autonomous beings any more if technology takes over so many of our daily tasks. And, of course, will we feel more disconnected as human interaction increasingly moves from physical to virtual, and what are the consequences of the digital footprints we leave behind. According to a 2013 academic paper, Private Traits and Attributes are Predictable From Digital Records of Human Behavior, artificial intelligence can predict, with a high degree of accuracy, private traits like sexual orientation or political and religious views, from just a few Facebook likes. This is potentially alarming, given that in some parts of the world people can be legally prosecuted for their homosexuality or political views. A 2017 paper by faculty at the University of Nottingham suggested that artificial intelligence could do a better job than established algorithms in predicting, based on medical records, the likelihood that a patient will suffer a heart attack - potentially making it easier to educate at-risk populations about precautionary measures. Artificial intelligence’s potential to be a curse or a cure depends in large part on whether policy makers manage to adequately define the boundaries of its use.

name: Technology and Innovation for Production
description: The development of a web of interconnected technologies is swiftly transforming production systems. Connectivity technologies like Wi-Fi and ZigBee, artificial intelligence technologies like speech recognition and biometrics, and flexible automation (equipment that can be refigured according to what it is being used to make) allow for radical innovation when it comes to production and related business models. Meanwhile concepts including the Internet of Things and mobile computing, and developments in data storage and processing, are enabling companies to access and analyse data from across their supply chains nearly in real-time. Managing this tsunami of accessible data will be a key challenge for the advanced manufacturing sector going forward; according to current estimates, only between 1% and 5% of all data collected is currently being utilized, which is an amount poised to increase drastically in the near future. This need to make better use of data creates a corresponding need for effective governance of key enabler technologies, such as 5G networks. Over the course of the past decade, the cost of sensors has been cut in half, bandwidth costs have become 40 times cheaper, and processing costs have become 60 times cheaper. Now, by integrating “big” data (the fast, efficient analysis of massive sets of data in order to generate insights) into their operations, manufacturers should be able to cut their product development and production costs in half, according to a McKinsey Global Institute projection. Meanwhile developments in flexible automation have spawned entire networks of multi-purpose machines, capable of outperforming single-purpose machines in terms of quality, speed and agility. In addition, additive manufacturing (commonly known as 3D printing) is reinventing production processes. According to a report published in 2016 by the consultancy EY, about a third of plastics, automotive, aerospace, pharmaceutical and medical companies were already using 3D printing to make actual components or products, as opposed to limiting their use to rapid prototyping. In order to take advantage of related opportunities, governments and manufacturers need to swiftly identify how to best leverage such new technologies.

name: Technology and the Law
description: As cyber threats evolve, public officials must stay up-to-date. Lawmakers are struggling to keep up with the realities of 3D-printed weapons, for example, and drone interference with aircraft, not to mention the staggering rate of change in terms of increased global internet use. An inability to stay ahead of the curve creates the risk of abuses (through ignorance or malice) with no legal recourse - and may leave entire nations without the ability to make an informed response to cyberattacks. Unlike many other areas, such as traditional security, government officials are often not well-versed in the nuances of cybercrime and cyberwarfare. This lack of understanding is exacerbated by the already challenging task of identifying a suspected party and their intent. The process of identifying the cause, scope and perpetrator of an attack falls under the category of cyber forensics, which involves numerous legal hurdles. For example, cloud computing, or using remote servers to host data online, has become a major obstacle to prosecuting cybercrime, as it creates a jurisdictional nightmare. As a team from the University of Glasgow noted in a 2014 article in the International Journal of Digital Crime and Forensics, it is now incredibly easy for malicious agents to store incriminating digital evidence on servers that physically exist outside of the reach of investigators. Even if evidence of a crime can be obtained in the cloud, the related chain of custody can be difficult or impossible to preserve - making evidence potentially inadmissible in court. Those in charge of implementing the law must be aware of these difficulties, and work with cybersecurity experts in government, industry and academia to minimize them. Not-for-profit groups such as the National Cyber-Forensics & Training Alliance in the US and Canada facilitate this sort of collaboration, by bringing together experts from different domains. Traditional borders mean little to cybercriminals, and the laws they break must transcend physical boundaries. Standards must be developed to harmonize different legal definitions of cybercrime, and to facilitate cross-jurisdictional cooperation among nations. Evolving technology must be continuously monitored, and legislators must be properly informed regarding cybersecurity in order for them to create logical and effective laws and policies. The time to establish precedent is now, before cybercrime becomes more problematic. Failure to do so may result in legal quagmires and long winded debates over issues that should have already been settled, as regulators struggle to play catch-up.

name: The Asian Century
description: Public debate about the relationship between Australia and the US, and how a pivot to Australia’s regional neighbours in Asia should be balanced with traditional ties to the world’s dominant superpower, has intensified. Australia’s relationship with the US will remain the bedrock of the nation’s foreign policy for the foreseeable future. However, the hardening of US policy in relation to longstanding allies under the presidency of Donald Trump presents challenges. A choice does not need to be made between the continued special relationship shared by Australia and the US, and greater engagement with Asia. Rather, it is a question of in which direction Australia should turn at any given time for the most dynamic economic opportunities. The backdrop for this is the notion of the coming Asian Century, when the region promises to emerge as the world’s foremost economic powerhouse centred on China and India. Over the past 20 years or so, these countries have increased their economic size almost six-fold, and tripled their share of the global economy. If this momentum is maintained, by 2050 Asia will be home to most of the world’s middle-class consumers, and could account for half of all global economic output. As a wealthy, well-regulated country on Asia’s doorstep, Australia has the potential to make a significant regional contribution. A government paper has noted that Australia is the only major developed economy with preferential access to all major North Asian markets. China’s $1 trillion Belt and Road Initiative, which aims to link Eurasia, Africa, and Oceania via massive investment in infrastructure, presents tremendous economic opportunities. While dozens of nations have signed up to the initiative, Australia has yet to do so. Critics fear increased Chinese political influence. Still, in the roughly 40 years since Gough Whitlam became the first Australian prime minister to visit China, the country’s relations with Asian countries have become more open. The country receives more tourists from China than the United Kingdom and the US, and as of 2017 roughly 2.4 million Australians were of Asian descent, while all but 3.5% of the nearly 700,000 international students in Australian schools and universities were from Asian countries. Still, while the majority of universities in the country have courses or institutes for Asian studies, the number of students learning an Asian language remains small - despite government efforts to increase interest.

name: The Case for Gender Parity
description: While the economic case for gender parity has been made again and again since the release of the first edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Gender Gap Report in 2006, more attention must be paid to the issue - in order to ensure adequate, wide-scale support for addressing inequalities. There is a clear, values-based case for promoting gender parity: women make up half of the world’s population and deserve equal access to health, education, earning potential and economic participation, as well as to political decision-making. Gender parity is a fundamental part of thriving societies, and increased gender parity in education can lower infant and child mortality rates, increase labour force participation and earnings, and foster greater investment in children’s education. Meanwhile in the political sphere, women’s engagement in public life has been proven to have a broad, positive impact on social inequality. In an effort to determine the most pressing gender-related issues that need to be addressed, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development distributed questionnaires in 2016. The following year, the OECD published the results; the most commonly-selected issue was violence against women, which, the OECD noted, remains a pandemic, as an estimated 35% of all women worldwide have experienced physical or sexual intimate partner violence, or non-partner sexual violence. According to the OECD, the second-most-commonly selected issue in the questionnaire was women being paid less than men for the same work. As highlighted in the Forum’s 2017 edition of the Global Gender Gap Report, ensuring the full participation of half of the world’s talent pool affects the economic growth, competitiveness, and future-readiness of businesses and entire economies. According to PwC’s Women in Work Index 2017, achieving economic gender parity could add an additional $250 billion to the United Kingdom’s GDP, $1.75 billion to that of the US, $320 billion to that of Japan, and $310 billion to the GDP of Germany. China, meanwhile, could add $2.5 trillion to its GDP by 2020 by closing its gender gap, according to a report published by McKinsey & Company in 2015. For business leaders, addressing barriers to gender equality can unlock new opportunities. In the Forum’s 2016 Future of Jobs survey, for example, business leaders reported that addressing parity issues within their workforces could better match the changing gender composition of their customer base, and therefore enhance corporate decision-making and innovation.

name: The China Effect
description: China is now the largest market for the chemical and materials industry, and the most important source of growth for chemical demand. By 2013, China accounted for one third of the global chemicals market, and that figure is expected to reach 40% by the year 2020. At that point, in terms of total value, China’s chemicals market is expected to be worth roughly $2 trillion (out of a total of roughly $5 trillion in global market value). The chemicals behemoth that would result from the anticipated merger of China’s Sinochem Group and China National Chemical Corporation (ChemChina) would control more than $100 billion in assets, and boost the already substantial role of China in the industry. Despite the country’s ongoing trade friction with the US and broader economic deceleration expected for 2019, the near-term outlook for the chemicals industry in China appears to be solid - and it is expected to remain the world’s largest and fastest-growing. Not long after ChemChina’s $43 billion purchase of Swiss agrochemical giant Syngenta in 2017, marking China’s biggest overseas takeover at that point, a number of countries began to more aggressively limit their openness to acquisitions by Chinese firms. Germany and other European Union countries have established mechanisms to review foreign investments, and in late 2018 Germany implemented rules that enable the government to intervene in the public interest if a non-European purchaser buys a stake in a domestic company of 10% or more. China’s chemical and materials industry is delving into more specialized markets and is becoming more selective about growth (a growing number of domestic Chinese companies are entering the specialty chemicals market). In addition, the tightening of environmental regulation, and more importantly of the implementation of this regulation (with the backing of the emerging urban middle class), is profoundly influencing the industry’s strategic decisions. Meanwhile the localization of production, procurement, and especially research and development are likely to continue to create greater value and locally-adapted products, and further boost competitiveness.

name: The Common Good
description: There are positive signals to be found in surveys of young people. Survey results published by the consultancy Deloitte in 2017, for example, based on questions posed to people born after 1982 in 30 different countries, showed that 74% believed multinational companies have the potential to help solve global challenges, nearly nine in 10 believed the success of a business should be measured by more than just its financial performance, and more than half felt personally accountable for the protection of the environment. Increasingly, and particularly among young people, the notion of a narrowly defined shareholder economy, based on investor demands and the bottom line, is being replaced with the concept of a broader, multi-stakeholder economy, where the interests of workers, consumers, community groups, governments, and environmental advocates all have a say in economic decision-making. Companies that pursue positive contributions to society are acting on more than a desire for global well-being; evidence suggests companies that actively value more than just profit find it easier to recruit and retain staff, and can also financially outperform businesses whose sole stated purpose is to maximize shareholder value. According to a study published in 2017 by the consultancy BCG, consumer packaged goods companies with socially-responsible sourcing had gross profit margins that were 4.8 percentage points higher than their peers, while biopharmaceutical companies that were top performers in terms of expanding access to drugs had margins that were 8.2 percentage points higher than peers. Individual business leaders stand to benefit from an association with social or environmental responsibility; in 2015, the Harvard Business Review began factoring in an “environmental, social and governance,” or ESG element in scoring for the publication’s annual Best Performing CEOs in the World list. The winner for 2017, Inditex CEO Pablo Isla, was elevated to the top spot thanks to his ESG score (ESG-rating rating firms had singled out for praise Inditex’s transparency when it came to managing, monitoring and auditing its supply chain).

name: The Cost of Climate Change
description: The environmental impacts of climate change are already evident in Australia, in the form of an accelerating increase in average seasonal temperatures, the vulnerability of coastal areas, and a growing number of extreme weather events. Climate change has brought an increase in flooding and violent storms, more intense tropical cyclones, and a greater number of hot days that have wrought out-of-control bushfires. Meanwhile shifting patterns of rainfall have been linked to prolonged drought. These changes have exceeded natural variability, and their effects on agricultural production, cattle and sheep farming, water and energy supplies, and housing and infrastructure have ranged from severe to catastrophic. For example, the Millennium Drought in South Eastern Australia, from 1996 to 2010, has been described as the worst in the country’s recorded history. The region’s inland river system collapsed into a series of sandy, shallow ponds, and has yet to fully recover; crop production declined dramatically, and the normally lucrative cotton-growing industry suffered; populations of native and farm animals were decimated; and the densely-populated eastern seaboard resorted to rationing water. There were also increasing incidences of drought-related suicides and mental illness, especially in rural areas. Ultimately, federal government funding for drought assistance amounted to AUD 4.5 billion. In 2016, Australia ratified the Paris climate change agreement and the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, after having submitted a self-designated target for the reduction of emissions by 2030. Australia’s government has implemented a “Direct Action Plan” for the phasing out of potent synthetic greenhouse gases (including hydrofluorocarbons in refrigerators and air conditioners), the planting of millions of trees, mandating more efficient cars, and improving the utilization of sustainable energy. However, Australia’s climate change researchers have almost unanimously condemned the government’s Direct Action Plan as falling short of necessary emission reduction targets. The Climate Council, an independent, Australia-based non-profit, has pointed out that government calculations mask the bleak realities of climate change. The organization has advised that in order to have a 75% chance of staying below the widely-recognized threshold of a two degree centigrade rise in temperature above pre-industrial levels, Australia would need to reduce its emissions by 60% by 2030. Anything greater than a two degree increase could mean a melting Greenland ice-sheet, which may result in the inundation of most of Australia’s major cities. According to researchers, imaginative initiatives are needed that build on existing renewable energy technologies, and can navigate political and financial obstacles.

name: The Cost of Precision Medicine
description: Although Precision Medicine, also referred to as Personalized Medicine, is unlikely to significantly reduce health care costs in the near future, there have been notable exceptions that provide a glimpse of its potential. The genomic characterization of certain cancers, for example, has led to improved molecular diagnostics and specific therapeutics that target unique tumour susceptibilities, illustrating a path forward to delivering more cost-effective, high-quality care. The increasingly routine use of genomic data, accurate clinical phenotyping (measuring the interaction between one’s genetic makeup and the environment), novel biomarkers of disease, and precise target-based therapies all promise to transform the healthcare sector. That in turn should improve health outcomes, lead to a better understanding of disease risks, and eliminate the use of imprecise, expensive diagnostic procedures and ineffective therapies. Ultimately, these changes will likely decrease overall health care costs, and enhance value. However, we have yet to develop a reliable way to routinely integrate these technologies. While the capability and cost of generating high-quality DNA sequence information has improved exponentially, the annotation of genes, regulatory elements, DNA variants, and post-translational protein modifications lag behind. In addition, our understanding of the complex molecular pathways occurring within cells and organs, and their relationships to human development, ageing, disease, and environment remain rudimentary.

name: The Demography, Skills and Migration Nexus
description: Germany has a particularly weak demographic outlook; its population is not only shrinking, it is also getting older. According to the World Bank, 21.5% of Germany’s population was aged 65 or older by 2017 (surpassed only by Japan and Italy), compared with 14.6% of the population in 1987. Key factors behind Germany’s greying population are one of the world’s lowest annual population growth rates - slightly less than 1.2% as of 2016, according to World Bank data - and an above-average life expectancy of nearly 82 years as of 2015, which was above the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 80 years. According to the United Nations’ 2017 revision of its World Population Prospects report, Germany’s fertility rate, or live births per woman, is projected to be 1.47 between 2015 and 2020, below the average level of 2.1 required for replacement of the population. Germany’s overall population is expected to fall to about 71 million by 2100, according to the report, from about 82 million in 2017. However, the UN report also noted that Germany will be among the top six countries in the world in terms of net receivers of international migrants between 2015 and 2050. This could alleviate pressure on a shrinking workforce. It would also significantly affect Germany’s ethnic makeup. Amid a recent surge in immigration fuelled by conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa, Germany granted more than 524,000 positive decisions on asylum applications in 2017, or 60% of the total for all European Union members that year, according to Eurostat. While Chancellor Angela Merkel may have spearheaded the so-called “Wilkommenskultur” (welcoming culture) for refugees, domestic opposition and popular dissent have tempered this stance. Controversy tied to immigration has persisted; it contributed to a disappointing result for Merkel’s Christian Democrats in 2017 federal elections, and ultimately helped lead to her resignation as party leader in 2018. The Christian Social Union (CSU), the Bavarian sister-party of Merkel’s Christian Democrats, heads the federal Interior Ministry and oversees immigration matters - and has been willing to jeopardize the governing coalition in order to demonstrate a tougher stance (though this strategy led to poor results in the 2018 Bavarian regional elections, and to the party leader’s resignation).

name: The Digital Age
description: The digital revolution has ushered in a new era in which power, and the means to acquire and retain it, is being drastically redefined. Europe has largely missed out; the absence of European champions that can vie with the likes of Facebook or Uber, or hardware firms that make the most popular mobile phones, is glaring. A few European stars, such as Spotify or e-commerce firm Zalando, may address this imbalance, though when it comes to “unicorns,” or start-ups privately valued at over $1 billion, the European Union lags behind both the US and China. Many EU member states have reacted to this dynamic with protectionism, by either forbidding or extensively regulating services such as AirBnB and Uber in order to protect existing industries and interest groups. But this is not a long-term answer. The internet has become the most important infrastructure element of the global economy. Within the next five to ten years, the internet will also be the infrastructure upon which all other infrastructures are based, and digital influence has become both a force in foreign policy and an economic mainstay. The European Commission has estimated that an effective digital single market could annually contribute €415 billion to Europe’s economy.  One area in which the EU appears strong is data protection. The EU-US Privacy Shield, and the General Data Protection Regulation implemented in 2018, have built a foundation for protecting the online rights of EU citizens. However, the EU lacks compelling vision for the internet and the digital economy. Because it is still not a fully integrated digital market, the EU is ill-prepared to compete on geopolitical and geo-economic issues. Innovation is the most important aspect of future economic growth in the EU, as it seeks to address the shrinking size of its workforce. Young people need the technology skills necessary to adapt to changing employer needs, and there is a case to be made for flexible education models that allow for life-long learning. The World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index for 2017-2018 pegged Europe’s median score for innovation well below its performance in areas such as health and infrastructure. In light of the speed of technology-driven change occurring around the globe, Europe must embrace its digital future sooner rather than later, in order to maintain its global competitiveness. The creation of a single digital market, for example, could present new opportunities for growth and job creation.

name: The Disempowered Citizen
description: New technology tools for expressing views and demanding public accountability are increasingly finding their way into the hands of an opinionated populace. However, the corresponding indifference of governments and policy-makers has led to the advent of the so-called “(dis)empowered” citizen. A study published by the European Commission in 2016 showed that 81% of public services in the European Union had been made available online, while Twitter has garnered more than 300 million monthly active users and provides a popular platform for people advocating for everything from Black Lives Matter to presidential succession in Zimbabwe. Yet, while individuals may feel empowered by technology that makes it easier to gather information about issues, communicate, and organize social movements, they also increasingly feel unable to have their voices heard by traditional institutions. According to the 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer, a survey conducted in 28 countries, less than half of the general population expressed trust in government institutions and the media, while only slightly more than half expressed trust in businesses and non-governmental organizations (in the US, the portion of the general population expressing trust in government tumbled to 33% from 47% in the prior year). The disempowerment of a citizenry making increased use of technology can also take the form of disinformation. In early 2018, it was revealed that Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm that uses data to influence behaviour and had been hired by Donald Trump’s presidential campaign, was able to improperly keep and use data about Facebook users; allegations have meanwhile been raised about Russian efforts to manipulate US voter opinion online, including on Facebook. In order to counter the negative effects of disempowerment, public officials and institutions have developed potential solutions designed to enable people to take a more active role in public life. So-called “citizen science,” for example, can help people actively participate (offline and online) in collecting and assessing the information that is ultimately used to develop policies. In the US, NASA, for example, said in 2018 it had selected a handful of citizen science projects for development, which should enable volunteers from the public to collect observations to be shared with established researchers as open data; an animal biodiversity project, for example, uses mobile phones to record bird sounds, which are fed onto a cloud-based platform and combined with satellite data in order to produce maps of species’ presence, and assess how fires affect bird communities.

name: The Economic Value of Digital Identity
description: In a study of seven countries published in 2019, the McKinsey Global Institute estimated that providing digital identities could result in added economic value equal to as much as 13% of GDP by 2030, save 110 billion hours via e-government services, and help the estimated 1.7 billion people who remain without access to formal financial services - often as a result of a lack of documentation. Businesses could meanwhile benefit from improved efficiency, lowered costs and fraud reduction, and save up to $1.6 trillion thanks to digital identities, according to the study. Estonia, for example, facilitates public services including healthcare, banking, and voting via a digital identity system; in 2014 alone it was used over 80 million times for authentication and 35 million times for digital transactions, it saves people an estimated five days per year that would otherwise be spent dealing with bureaucracy, and it cuts costs equivalent to 2% of GDP. Meanwhile India’s “Aadhaar” digital identity system is a centralized, national means to promote social inclusion and access to government services - as of 2017, it covered 95% of the population and had saved the government an estimated $9 billion by reducing fraud, according to Deloitte and the Center for Global Development. The travel and tourism industry in particular should see economic benefits from the use of digital identities. As international air arrivals increase by an expected 50% between 2016 and 2030, according to the World Tourism Organization, concepts like Known Traveller Digital Identity, developed by a group of governments and businesses, could ease the pressure by using biometric and biographical data to quickly assess risk and verify identities. In the supply chain industry, digital identity can help combat counterfeit goods, which constitute about 3% of global trade, according to the OECD; companies including BMW and IBM are members of the Mobility Open Blockchain Initiative, for example, which uses blockchain to reduce the use of counterfeit replacement parts in order to enhance safety and increase transparency. Digital identities can also be used to verify businesses online; Singapore created “CorpPass” to help facilitate digital transactions between businesses and the government, and the governments of British Columbia, Ontario, and Canada created the “Verifiable Organizations Network” to digitize government-issued credentials for businesses like registrations, permits, and licenses. Stakeholders in every sector and industry should be investing in digital identity as a foundational infrastructure, designing flexible solutions, and unlocking more identity use cases.

name: The Environment and Oil
description: Environmental concerns are driving energy-related public policies aimed at addressing climate change by decarbonizing. The Paris Agreement on climate change, ratified in 2016 as hundreds of national governments made voluntary related commitments, could have a broad impact; however, the Paris Agreement commitments are widely seen as insufficient to achieve the deal’s stated goal of capping temperature rise well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. This in turn has spurred calls for more policy action (there is growing interest in carbon-pricing policies like a carbon tax or carbon-permit trading, for example). The COP24 global climate talks in Poland in late 2018 did not do much to address concerns raised by the Paris signatories related to a report that had just been published by the UN scientific panel on climate change - which warned of dramatic consequences from just 1.5°C of warming. These concerns were tied to efforts by oil and gas exporters Russia, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the US to weaken a statement endorsing the UN panel’s report, to the need to reduce fossil fuel use in countries where alternative energy supplies may be unavailable, and to a need for the developed world to help fund decarbonization in the developing world. Local environmental concerns have prompted policies that have attracted international media attention - like the targets set in France, the United Kingdom, and Norway to entirely eliminate internal combustion engines in the next few decades. Efforts with a similar intent can vary widely, however, depending on an individual country’s level of development, degree of economic diversification, and existing energy mix. Local sentiment will have a big influence on the types of policies that can be adopted; the gilets jaunes (“yellow jackets”) protests that pushed France to scrap a fuel tax increase in late 2018, and the failure of the state of Washington in the US to pass a carbon tax, underlined the fact that people are deeply concerned about the personal cost of cleaner energy and a cleaner environment. Major international oil and gas corporations increasingly recognize the importance of transitioning to more sustainable energy in the future. Spurred by shareholders and public sentiment, these companies have invested greater amounts in renewable energy, and have launched initiatives to promote more sustainable and environmentally responsible oil and gas development and production (such as the Oil and Gas Climate Initiative, an effort organized by the World Economic Forum in partnership with more than a dozen oil and gas companies).

name: The Flowering of Financial Technology
description: There has been an explosion of investment in financial technology, or fintech, designed to digitalize and democratize everything from payments to lending. Global investment in fintech companies totaled $57.9 billion in the first half of 2018 alone, according to a report published by KPMG; that included a single, $14 billion round of funding round for Chinese payments firm Ant Financial. Investment was distributed around the world, according to the report, with a firm in Brazil reaching $1 billion-valuation-status and top venture deals in Europe spread across five countries - though much of the activity was centered in China. That country saw four different, $100 million-plus venture capital rounds in fintech firms in the first half of 2018, according to the report, and local fintechs have started shifting focus to Southeast Asia as a next growth step. On the flip side of this entrepreneurial activity, many established banks have begun making efforts to tap into novel facets of fintech - by partnering with accelerator programs that foster startups, for example, in order gain exposure to talent and develop pilot programs based on artificial intelligence, the Internet of Things, and robotics.   Quantum computing, which involves manipulating quantum bits that can store more information than standard computer bits, has drawn particular interest from banks (and other companies) due to its potential to crunch information hundreds of thousands of times faster than traditional computing. Banks including JP Morgan Chase, Barclays, and Mizuho have joined IBM’s Q Network, a quantum computing system unveiled in 2017 that can potentially be used to accelerate trading and risk analysis. Distributed ledger technologies, like blockchain, have also drawn significant interest. Blockchain, which can provide a comprehensive record of transactions where every change is recorded for all to see, is being explored by banks including UBS, which together with other institutions founded a blockchain-based global trading platform called Batavia. Meanwhile HSBC announced in 2018 that together with ING Bank it had successfully executed a live trade financial transaction using blockchain tied to the shipment of soybeans from Argentina to Malaysia. Ultimately, many institutions are interested in using multiple technologies to create platforms - which strengthen every time they draw in a new user. Successful examples of platforms include Stripe, the payments service that provides technology and fraud prevention infrastructure.

name: The Future of Democracy
description: Much political debate in Australia is centred on the issue of whether democratic norms continue to form the bedrock of the country’s cultural life. According to doomsayers, the liberal values and attitudes essential to a healthy democracy are in terminal decay. It is true that the mood of voters is one of alienation from traditional political parties, including the centre-right Labor Party, the conservative Liberal Party, and the centre-left Greens. While voting in Australia is compulsory, there has been a decline in turnout. This reflects growing public sentiment that parliamentary leadership is self-serving and directionless, and incapable of crafting a hopeful vision of the future. For pessimists, the widening of fault lines in democratic governance is reflected in a corresponding decline of trust in institutions such as the church, trade unions, political parties, universities, the media, and major banks, all of which have historically been looked to as emblematic of an open, stable culture. Only about 8% of the population attends church weekly, amid findings by a government commission of institutional corruption and paedophilia. Trade unions and banks are meanwhile perceived as vulnerable to corruption and the abuse of power. The mainstream media, which must compete for attention with social media, is widely regarded as superficial. Meanwhile universities are often deemed to be out of touch and preoccupied by revenue demands. Overall, there is a perception that contemporary Australia is now fragmented, and that it is more sympathetic to the xenophobic, racist views of extremist political parties such as One Nation. Many Australians, however, perceive conservative nostalgia for a secure past that never was as nonsense. They see democracy as a dynamic process of backsliding and advances. Like other countries, Australia has a long history of racism and homophobia, which have been addressed by anti-discrimination legislation. In 2017, a plebiscite on legalizing same sex marriage saw around two thirds vote in favour. Meanwhile there has been widespread condemnation of Australia’s offshore detention of asylum seekers. While many Australians may share a perception that their country is badly governed, this does not necessarily indicate they are alienated from democracy. Rather, it calls for more imaginative policies. After all, Australians are generally a talented, adaptable people who have managed to navigate the global economic and political upheaval of the last quarter century relatively unscathed.

name: The Gamification of Life and Reality Distortion
description: Augmented reality (AR) means that our daily life has the potential to expand beyond what is visible to the human eye. In his concept film, Hyper Reality, designer Keiichi Matsuda explored how the contours of urban environments can extend beyond physical structures to include a superimposed virtual layer made up of digital information. Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook posited that AR games would have a more enduring commercial appeal than virtual reality ones over time in a February 2017 interview with The Independent. He may have been thinking about the immense success of Niantic’s Pokemon GO augmented reality game, released in mid-2016. The game, which turned people’s everyday lives into a playing field, sparked both positive and negative media coverage. Some heralded the software as clever for reintroducing physical activity into our often sedentary digital lives; others highlighted how nefarious figures were taking advantage of and robbing the immersed game players. Game designer Raph Koster has called for virtual and augmented reality game designers to heed the lessons of games past because in creating a game, a designer is actually creating a virtual community or society, and without a well-thought out design, there is the potential for human behaviour to go awry. In 2017, the social media company Snap extended its popular face filters with a new feature called, World Lenses, in which game-like 3D stickers can be added into video messages, blending real and virtual content seamlessly for the purpose of communication and experience sharing. As computing power continues to grow and new algorithms are being developed, visual effects-quality AR alterations are foreseeable in the near future. In a few years, we will no longer need a traditional expensive visual effects pipeline to create any type of content for AR. Also, when this technology becomes widely-available – for example, perhaps as widely available as any smartphone integrated video editor - the lines between physical and virtual reality will continue to blur. In the meantime, researchers from the University of Southern California, Stanford University and the University of Washington are advancing video manipulation techniques to alter facial expressions, lip motions and dialogues, fostering the ability to generate believable fake news and cyber propaganda.

name: The Geo-economic and Trade Impacts of 5G
description: 5G is designed to be a foundation connecting billions of devices and enabling better ways of doing things. The total number of 5G subscriptions is projected to reach 2.6 billion by 2025 - prompting optimism about its practical uses, and a need for device manufacturers to adapt strategy. Those countries able to take a leading position in the deployment of 5G are expected to enjoy relatively greater economic growth - though exact implementation will depend on unique national priorities and challenges. According to a report published in 2019 by GSMA, a trade organization for mobile operators, 5G services provided on millimetre wave (“mmWave”) spectrum should increase GDP by $5.2 billion in Sub-Saharan Africa by the year 2034, by bolstering vital functions like port logistics and helping to better coordinate the movement of goods. 5G can also be one of many (potentially unrelated) factors behind trade tensions and geo-economic positioning; in 2019, for example, China established a two-year action plan to promote the purchase of consumer goods including 5G handsets as a means to offset the impact of an escalating trade war with the US. In a related geo-economic move, legislation was introduced in the US in 2019 intended to boost the presence of American firms in global industry standards bodies - in a bid to check China’s influence on future 5G networks. 5G is a key factor behind tensions between the world’s two largest economies; the US has expressed security-related concerns about China’s status as a leader in 5G technology development and implementation, and about its acquisition of related intellectual property rights. China is likely to be the first nation to launch a 5G telecom network at scale, and as it plays a significant role in setting global standards both Huawei and ZTE have been among the biggest filers of related patents. Overall, China holds a significant percentage of 5G-related technology patents, and a far higher share than was the case with 3G or 4G at a comparable stage in development. Eventually, China may come to hold nearly a third of global 5G-related patents, according to one estimate, and it continues to participate actively in international standards-setting bodies like the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).

name: The Geopolitics of Mining
description: A growing popular resistance to globalization and free trade is altering politics, and directly affecting the mining and metals sector. For example, policy-makers in the places where mines operate are increasingly trying to enact local content laws and regulations, which require minerals to be processed (and therefore gain in value) before they are exported. Meanwhile import restrictions on semi-finished products such as steel and aluminium have triggered recent trade disputes; full-blown trade wars and increased protectionism would likely lead to lower global commodity demand, and disrupt mining and metals companies, while an increase in local content regulations could increase production costs for individual mining projects. On the flip side, increased protectionism could actually provide opportunities for domestic mining companies, and for those that are vertically integrated (or, in control of multiple stages of a supply chain), as they can provide solutions that go beyond the simple extraction of minerals. Best practices for navigating these and other geopolitical risks include maintaining good relationships with domestic joint venture partners where mines are located, and securing access to countries with high consumer demand. When it comes to minerals that are essential for promising renewable-energy technologies, geopolitical risk has been further complicated by market consolidation. China, for example, has secured its own supply of critical minerals such as lithium, cobalt, and rare earths, while developing a dominant market position by acquiring mining projects, forging resource-for-infrastructure deals with mineral producing countries (one example is an arrangement with the Democratic Republic of Congo to provide billions of dollars worth of infrastructure in exchange for access to copper mining), promoting domestic production, and gaining control of key components of the mineral and technology value chain. Countries that must rely on imports and are wary of supply disruptions have examined ways to hinder Chinese-backed takeovers, and to avoid having to rely on Chinese companies. Further consolidation, geopolitical manoeuvring, and muscle flexing could create challenges for companies that have so far prospered under a system of relatively free trade - while creating opportunities for domestic projects that might not be economically viable without government intervention.

name: The Global Luxury Market
description: By the end of 2017, the global luxury goods market was recovering from economic uncertainty and geopolitical crises, and was approaching an estimated $1 trillion in size, according to a report published by Deloitte. However, while China is expected to remain among the fastest-growing luxury markets, according to the report, the US market may be hindered by a lack of wage growth, and uncertainty looms of the United Kingdom’s market due to Brexit, a weakened pound, and declining purchasing power. These economic and political realities, along with changing luxury consumer demands, are forcing retailers to rethink both the goods that they sell and how they sell them. Luxury sales growth is now being driven by millennials and Generation Z (generally considered to include people born in the mid-90’s and after), according to the report, meaning that these groups must now be catered to with more personalized experiences that blend offline and online offerings - via means including “voice commerce” conducted through the Internet of Things, augmented reality, and artificial intelligence. One example cited in the Deloitte report is Gucci, the Italian fashion house, which saw online sales increase by 86% in 2017 and which now relies on millennials for about half of its total revenue; Gucci has reinvented itself for younger buyers via its “geek-chic” efforts, and redesigned its website in 2016 to provide visual presentations and stories, and personalized customer service through webchat. Much like artisanal manufacturers, luxury brands will need to justify the value of their products based on more than just their appearance and immediate utility. Increasingly, luxury consumers are seeking experiences in the form of travel, hotels, restaurants, and bespoke opportunities (a concept first advanced by B. Joseph Pine and James Gilmore in a 1998 Harvard Business Review article). Luxury travel provider Black Tomato, for example, offers a service that has travellers show up at the airport without knowing where they are headed - before dropping them in a mystery location where they must rely on their “wits and inner steel” in order to complete an expedition.
