Because what starts as a luxury for the elite often goes mainstream, experience and individuation will likely become bigger parts of the broader global retail market.

name: The Great Jobs Challenge
description: India now finds itself in a demographic sweet spot, as a country of roughly 1.3 billion people with more than half of its citizens of working age. The ratio of working age population to non-working age population is expected to peak around 2041, according to the country’s Economic Survey 2018-2019. According to the latest available data, India’s current workforce stands at 473 million, and about 300 million more will be added by 2040 (an estimated one million Indians join the labour market each month, according to Labour Ministry data). Meanwhile millions of people are ditching agricultural work; about 50 million people left farm work behind between 2004 and 2015. The Indian economy must provide quality jobs for new labour market entrants, as well as for those who are transitioning from agriculture. This challenge is even more acute when it comes to women who have left the workforce over the past two decades, and are now trying to get back in. Solutions must also be found for the majority of Indians who are currently either self-employed, or working in the informal, grey economy. India’s job challenge can be seen in terms of three overlapping issues: the quality of human capital, infrastructure, and labour-intensive growth (the first issue is dealt with separately within this Transformation Map). The International Monetary Fund estimates that infrastructure investment equal to roughly 1% of GDP in advanced economies produces a 1.5% GDP increase on average over four years. For India, it has been estimated that increasing infrastructure investment by 0.5% of GDP will boost growth by 1.8% in the medium to long term. So far, India has not been able to replicate the successful, employment-intensive manufacturing found in other Asian countries plugged into global supply chains, such as Viet Nam and Bangladesh. Relatively strict labour laws are one obstacle - these laws also exclude the large section of the workforce employed informally, who are neither entitled to social security benefits nor have access to training. At the same time, highly-productive enterprises are demanding less labour even as they become more capital intensive. Suggestions for reform in this area include legalizing contract labour, and extending the social security net to informal, grey economy workers.

name: The Human Side of Risk
description: Forces like political polarization, rising inequality, and major technological advances are both disrupting the geopolitical landscape and having a heavy impact on individuals. For many people, this is an increasingly anxious, unhappy, and lonely world. Globally, mental health problems now affect an estimated 700 million people, profoundly impacting personal lives. In the face of precariousness caused by social, technological, and work-related transformations, many are experiencing a feeling of loss of control. This has in turn made significant polarization an increasingly prevalent feature of politics in many countries (some of the potential drivers of emotional stress considered in the World Economic Forum’s 2019 Global Risks Report are social, technological, and work-related). Coupled with this increased political polarization, inequality can erode a country’s social fabric in an economically damaging way; as cohesion and trust diminish, economic performance is likely to weaken. In affluent countries, wealth affects well-being in particularly complex ways - the prevalence of anxiety disorders is higher among lower-income groups, for example. But attitudes towards money matter, too - researchers have linked reduced well-being to broad, societal shifts away from motivations related to community feeling and affiliation, and towards motivations related to financial success and social status. Technological change is always a source of stress, but the current wave of change is defined by a particularly unnerving blurring of lines between humans and technology. This is leading to rapid transformations in the workplace, and what happens at work has the potential to affect emotional and psychological well-being everywhere (according to a survey of full-time employees in 155 countries, just 15% felt “highly involved in and enthusiastic about their work”). For many people, one pronounced, recent change has been a blurring of the distinction between work and the rest of life. Work-related emails now often begin long before the start of nominal working hours, and finish long afterwards. Many families juggle multiple jobs with childcare, stressful commuting logistics, and caring for elderly parents. Profound changes in the structure of work and in its place in society are a further source of potential stress. Job security and stability are in decline in many advanced economies, with real earnings growth stagnating as less predictable, “gig economy” work proliferates. In many low-income countries, meanwhile, secure and stable employment has always been the exception; 70% of employment in Sub-Saharan Africa is classified as “vulnerable” by the International Labour Organization.

name: The Human and Environmental Cost of Batteries
description: More than half of the world’s cobalt, a key ingredient in the lithium-ion batteries used to power iPhones and electric cars, comes from the Democratic Republic of Congo - and about one fifth of it is mined by hand, according to a report published in 2017 by Amnesty International. Amnesty said in the report it had documented both children and adults in the country mining cobalt in narrow, man-made tunnels where they risked fatal accidents and lung disease. As the use of electric mobility becomes more mainstream, demand for the raw materials that make it possible will surge. Demand for cobalt, for example, is projected to increase to about 170 kilotonnes per year by the year 2030, according to a report published in 2019 by the International Energy Agency, while demand for lithium is expected to increase to roughly 155 kilotonnes per year. In addition to human rights concerns tied to cobalt mining, there are worries that there simply may not be enough to go around; a 2018 European Commission publication projected that the metal may be in short supply starting in 2025. Efforts are being made to better track the sourcing of the materials necessary to foster the growth of more environmentally-friendly electric transportation, and facilitate digital communication. The World Economic Forum’s Global Battery Alliance, for example, includes members like the African Development Bank, Google, and Honda Motors, and has formed both a cobalt working group focused on the Democratic Republic of the Congo that is designed to ensure small-scale mining does not employ child labour, and a lithium working group focused on Latin America. Efforts are also being made to draw greater attention to the environmental problems associated with mining the elements necessary for the batteries powering cars and electronics. Both miners in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and people living in communities near these mines are often exposed to high levels of toxic metals, and studies have shown a link between the presence of mines and birth defects, according to a report published by the United Nations Environment Programme Finance Initiative and the United Nations Global Compact in 2018.

name: The New Saudi Economy
description: Saudi Arabia is committing significant resources to efforts to diversify away from oil dependence and overwhelmingly public sector-based employment, by fostering the growth of a more dynamic and innovative economy. The fiscal case for diversification is clear; the International Monetary Fund has estimated that the country's government needs the price of oil to be at least $70 per barrel merely in order to hit a fiscal breakeven point. While the price of oil recovered during 2018 so that it surpassed $70 per barrel, it has since dipped lower amid concerns about global economic growth. Saudi Arabia has made efforts to diversify away from oil in the past, though they have generally fallen short. Exceptions include the establishment of “industrial cities” at Jubail and Yanbu, which are centred on petrochemicals production. A key element of the Saudi government’s “Vision 2030” plan, unveiled in 2016, is a move towards further diversification. One option in this regard for Saudi Arabia is to develop greater oil refining capabilities, which could in turn fund the development of new industries. At a more fundamental level, Saudi Arabia needs to ensure that its education system is imparting the skills necessary for graduates to successfully pursue entrepreneurship and innovation. While many young Saudis have studied abroad in locations such as the US and the United Kingdom, the kingdom now envisions an enhancement of local educational institutions - exemplified by the King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, or KAUST, which was founded in 2009 and offers graduate study programs in English. Saudi Arabia is also pursuing the development of a knowledge-based economy by developing four science and technology-focused “economic cities” in Rabigh, Hail, Madinah, and Jazan. In addition, the country is investing an estimated $100 billion to develop the King Abdullah Economic City, which is designed to draw foreign investment focused on fields including manufacturing and pharmaceuticals. Meanwhile the kingdom’s “Neom” project, unveiled in 2017, envisions a massive, metropolitan area that hosts industries including media, biotechnology, and renewable energy. The success of these ambitious projects will depend upon attracting the necessary investment and talent, fostering a culture of innovation, and successfully managing security and political risks.

name: The Oil and Gas Workforce
description: The oil and gas industry faces many challenges related to its workforce: difficulty in attracting and retaining the best talent, a lack of qualified technical professionals in emerging markets, gaps due to cyclical hiring tied to oil price fluctuations, and a need to re-skill its broader talent pool in the era of increasing digitalization. These issues take on varying degrees of significance in different regions around the world - but taken together they create significant amounts of general uncertainty. An adequate university education for a petro-technical professional should include technical skills, project management fundamentals, and professional skills in areas like finance, health, safety, environmental sustainability, and computer science. Analyses have suggested that the quality of engineering undergraduates varies widely based on school and region - mostly due to limited teaching capabilities, inadequate facilities, and a lack of sufficient funding and training programmes in developing countries. The oil and gas industry’s human capital challenge is exacerbated by the under-representation of women in its workforce - which results from gender imbalances in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields at universities, from negative public perception of the industry, and from proven difficulties in retaining mid-career, female talent. The World Economic Forum’s 2016 Future of Jobs report noted that while women accounted for about 35% of all STEM graduates globally, in the energy industry only 24% of junior-level employees, 19% of mid-level employees, and just 11% of senior employees were women. As it seeks to address its gender issues, the industry’s workforce will also be affected by digitalization. Some jobs may disappear, while new opportunities will likely emerge. For example, many roles traditionally filled on offshore rigs can now be done remotely, potentially improving safety while changing the nature of related tasks (well logging and directional drilling are examples of potentially affected work). The Fourth Industrial Revolution promises to require evolving digital skills, even in traditional jobs - making an ability to digitally train and re-train talent critical.

name: The Paris Agreement
description: The Paris Agreement was negotiated at the annual United Nations climate summit in 2015, and provides a means for participating countries to respond to the environmental, social, and economic effects of climate change. The agreement was a significant milestone, because it managed to formulate a consensus on the need to limit the rise in global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. The 181 countries that ratified the deal are expected to submit specific pledges to reduce their contributions to emissions, and to help the places most vulnerable to climate change adapt. One of the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals, which were adopted in 2015 to guide development for the next 15 years, encourages countries to incorporate their climate commitments into national policies, and urges companies to de-carbonize their operations and supply chains. In addition, the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol (on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer) bolsters the Paris Agreement, by preventing the equivalent of an estimated 1 billion tons of carbon dioxide emissions every year (in total, about 35 billion tons of yearly emissions result from human activity). More broadly, the Montreal Protocol has helped to reverse shrinkage of the ozone layer, which protects against harmful radiation from the sun. It is an encouraging example of a multinational agreement that can solve real climate problems. Public commitments targeting greenhouse-gas emissions are generally gaining momentum, but not everywhere. In 2017, the Trump Administration announced its intention to withdraw the US from the Paris Agreement at the earliest allowed date (which under the rules would be in late 2020). Brazil may follow. In 2018, the US Environmental Protection Agency proposed new rules to weaken the emissions limits set for coal-fired power plants in 2015. Despite such setbacks, and a spike in carbon-dioxide emissions in 2017 following a two-year pause, the UN climate summit held in late 2018 in Poland ended on a positive note. Delegates from 195 countries reached an agreement on what counts towards a reported reduction of their emissions, and on assigning responsibility to monitor progress on pledged goals. Developed countries meanwhile made firmer commitments to finance efforts to reduce the growing emissions generated by developing countries, which in turn agreed to uniform tracking standards.

name: The Primacy of Values
description: In developed countries like Germany, Japan, and South Korea, the percentage of the population aged 65 and older is rising sharply - in Japan, that figure jumped to 27% by 2017 from 15% in 1997, according to the World Bank. Meanwhile in the developing world, including India and many parts of Africa, relatively youthful populations mean more young people are joining the workforce. It is values that will shape how governments respond to these trends - by informing how (and even whether) they provide social support and protections, education, and training for the jobs of the future. Values can therefore be essential tools for blunting the impact of populist messages that play on perceptions of inequality. Values will also play an essential role as technology generates ever-larger volumes of potentially accessible personal data; they will shape the privacy regimes determining how that data are used. Human-centred policies will be critical as governments face these kinds of daunting issues, all of which require more than simple templates. Social values will be key for prioritizing well-being as governments guide the development and use of emerging technologies that need to be addressed now, at a relatively early stage. Agility can enable policy-making that is more inclusive and human-centred by involving more stakeholders in the process, and by allowing for successive iteration until the needs of the governed are met. Agile governance can also ensure long-term sustainability by creating mechanisms to constantly monitor and upgrade policies meant to govern new technologies, as well as by facilitating burden-sharing with non-governmental actors - while maintaining necessary checks and balances. Increased agility in policy-making can also address “policy decay” - or the idea that policies inevitably lose their relevance over time, especially as technological development accelerates. Robust and rigorous public discussion about values can help build a collective capacity to assess the ethics of emerging technology, and strong education systems will be key for ensuring that values are absorbed early in life, and transmitted broadly.

name: The Promise of the Internet of Things
description: The Internet of Things connects appliances, gadgets, and devices, enabling them to transmit data online. The increased connectivity of ordinary objects like a dishwasher can facilitate innovation and efficiency, and create new risks. Related questions have emerged about expectations for privacy, and the appropriate use of personal data. More connected devices means that more devices need to be secured against hackers; while hacking the location of a car may be an invasion of privacy, hacking a car’s control system could be life-threatening. Current internet infrastructure was not developed with these security concerns in mind. According to a survey in the World Economic Forum’s 2015 report Industrial Internet of Things, 72% of respondents saw industrial applications of IoT as disruptive, 78% predicted the disruption would be fully felt within five years, and 88% felt businesses were not ready for it. Electronics sector players have to prepare for the increased connectivity of their products, and related risk. According to the Forum’s report, the emergence of the so-called outcome economy means that companies will shift from supplying products, to outcome-based services. This will redefine business models, blur traditional industry boundaries, create new markets and partnerships, increase human-machine collaboration, and potentially enhance efficiency. Related risks for businesses and governments include vulnerability to cyberattacks and espionage, the potential lack of inter-operability among systems, uncertain returns on investment in new technologies, a lack of data governance regulation for cross-border transactions, and a potential shortage of necessary digital skills. The implications for industry leaders are many. While technology providers can develop test beds to share best security practices and safety guidelines, policy-makers should update the rules for traditional industries in order to encourage innovation. Cross-border data flows need to be streamlined, while industry and government should collaborate more on making investments in long-term technology research and development, and in new training programmes to fill digital talent gaps. One sign of industry momentum is the emergence of associations aiming to address the growing need for collaboration on common concerns such as security and inter-operability - such as the Industrial Internet Consortium, the AllSeen Alliance, and the Open Connectivity Foundation. Going forward, telecommunications and automobile companies in particular will be uniquely positioned to influence the industry, given their millions of existing subscriber relationships and decades of experience in driving collaboration.

name: The Regulatory Environment for 5G
description: A number of different countries are trying to influence the regulatory environment for 5G in their respective regions of the world. Japan and China, for example, have focused their efforts on spectrum bands that can potentially ensure compatibility with the US and South Korea, while the European Union has decided to pursue frequencies between 24.25 GHz and 27.5 GHz as a pioneer 5G band. Regulators and governments may want 5G to succeed, but their interpretations of what constitutes network neutrality vary, according to a report published by PwC in 2019 - and governments need to appreciate that 5G requires a new regulatory approach. Operators should engage with regulators by putting forward real-world use cases and pressing for incentives that will justify their 5G-related investments, according to the report. According to the results of a survey published by McKinsey & Company in 2019, nearly a quarter of participating telecom operators flagged regulation as a key stumbling block for 5G rollouts. High on their lists of concerns: spectrum auctions and rollout obligations (Europe, for example, has taken a relatively slow approach to auctioning the millimetre-wave spectrum deemed necessary for very high data rates). With the advent of 5G rollouts around the world, there is an urgent need to strengthen laws related to the testing of new 5G use cases, to closely assess potential social impacts including those related to inclusion and equal access, to bolster related consumer and personal data protection, and to clarify rules for cross-border data monetization and taxation. The use of 5G for things like autonomous mobility, and flying drones in particular, will require dealings with national authorities like federal ministries on matters like air traffic control and road safety department, and with international agencies like the International Telecommunication Union on issues like harmonizing frequencies. The commercial introduction of autonomous vehicles will require timely software upgrades, for example, to ensure error-free operations in tandem with changing infrastructure in any given location. National regulators and policy-makers have a critical role to play in fostering potential 5G-related benefits for their economies, by focusing on the prompt and adequate spectrum allocation for testbeds, the proper incentives for investing in strong networks, and the crafting of helpful data and monetization policies.

name: The Return on 5G Investment
description: 5G has the potential to contribute some $2.2 trillion to the global economy in the next decade and a half, with the bulk of that registering in the manufacturing & utilities and professional & financial services sectors, according to GSMA (a trade organization for mobile operators). However, 5G rollouts will require intensive capital investment reaching as high as $1 trillion worldwide by 2025. The practical impact of 5G has to be enormously significant in order to justify the building of ubiquitous and high-performing 5G network infrastructure (including base stations, mobile backhaul that connects different parts of a network, cloud-computing resources, the core networks themselves, and “end devices” that can include anything from phones and tablets to internet-connected cars). Key challenges for the further development of 5G infrastructure include the limited capacity and availability of fibre backhaul, the cost of deploying fibre across long distances, tapping new funding models for this deployment (and new ownership models), obtaining local permits, and dealing with the fallout of studies on the health impacts of 5G - in Switzerland, for example, the government has sought to assuage public concerns about the health impact of 5G emissions. National authorities can limit the ability of cities to regulate local 5G infrastructure, establish tight deadlines for the approval of equipment installation, or cap the fees for rights of way to access areas to build infrastructure. In terms of hardware, the range of potential 5G devices goes well beyond the smartphones, tablets and modems that underpinned previous generations of mobile networks. 5G devices will not only need to support higher performance levels, but will also have to come in a wider variety of form factors to support different uses - such as the “massive machine-type communication” necessary to power the Internet of Things. One approach designed to ensure maximum return on investment is infrastructure sharing. For example, South Korea’s mobile operators have implemented the sharing of 5G infrastructure, in the interest of saving hundreds of millions of dollars in capital expenditures, accelerating rollouts, and incentivizing the involvement of more industries. However, infrastructure sharing is not the preferred solution in everywhere; for many players, a first-mover advantage is seen as necessary to ensure a sufficient return on investment.

name: The Risk of Mismatching Risk
description: Attracting more private capital to projects via public-private partnerships is one of the most heavily-promoted means of closing an infrastructure funding gap that is expected to grow from $500 billion annually in 2020 to $800 billion annually by 2040, according to the Global Infrastructure Outlook, a tool developed by the Global Infrastructure Hub and Oxford Economics. However, many investors are wary of committing to projects due to what they see as mismatched risk sharing. In Asia, more than 400 million people are still living without electricity, and about 1.5 billion go without basic sanitation, according to a report published in early 2019 by the Asian Development Bank and the Korea Development Institute. And while providing minimum revenue guarantees had been an effective way to draw private sector partners to related infrastructure projects in South Korea, those guarantees created a heavy fiscal burden for the government. As a result, the guarantees were dropped for public-private partnerships in that country in 2009 (albeit while leaving in place existing guarantees worth about $3 billion), according to the report. Even in countries in Southeast Asia energetically promoting public-private partnerships for building infrastructure, like the Philippines, the pace has been sluggish due in part to a lack of public-sector capacity for assessing risk sharing and incentives, according to the Asian Development Bank and Korea Development Institute report. The need for proper risk allocation has become increasingly important, in light of the increased scrutiny placed on public-private partnerships due to high-profile failures that have soured public opinion in some countries. The Asian Development Bank and Korea Development Institute report analysed 41 public-private partnerships in the information and communication technology sector in “developing Asia” between 1991 and 2015, for example, and found that one quarter had been cancelled. While the sources of project failures often extend beyond just risk allocation, spreading risk exposure correctly is crucial. Both the public and private sector tend to believe risk allocation is slanted in the other party’s favour, and so building trust and encouraging transparency could go a long way towards better implementing risk-sharing arrangements.

name: The Silver Economy
description: As the global population grows older and lives longer, it presents inevitable challenges. However, there is an opportunity for the older population to serve as an economic asset, by fostering the so-called silver economy. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s definition, the silver economy is an environment in which people over 60 thrive at work, start innovative companies, are active consumers, and lead active and productive lives. Extending working lives and promoting senior entrepreneurship are increasingly perceived as economic drivers, and both can enable older people to better leverage their institutional knowledge, wisdom, and insights about their peers. In sectors including healthcare, financial services, retail, travel, and entertainment, jobs done by older people that cater to other older people can help capture massive, untapped spending power. An expert consultation organized by the OECD and the Global Coalition on Aging (GCOA) in 2014 concluded that the achievement of a silver economy is not inevitable, however. The private sector will need to create age-neutral workplaces, and life-long learning opportunities, according to the World Economic Forum’s former Global Agenda Council on Ageing’s Guiding Principles for Age-Friendly Businesses. According to the GCOA report Revitalizing Sustainable Growth in Emerging Markets: Insights on Leveraging an Ageing Population, age-friendly businesses recognize that an older workforce is not necessarily less productive, or less valuable. The right policies and programs can enable older employees to drive growth; the auto maker BMW and pharmacy chain CVS, for example, have adapted their work environments in order to better deploy their ageing workforces, and improve efficiency and customer relations. Public policies can also contribute, by incentivizing senior workers. Singapore, for example, enacted the Retirement and Re-Employment Act in 2012, which requires employers to offer re-employment to eligible employees for the first few years after they reach the national retirement age of 62. The GCOA report suggests that governments should use tax incentives, pension flexibility, strong intellectual property rights, and microfinancing vehicles in order to encourage senior social engagement, which can in turn reduce costs associated with unhealthy ageing. While public policies will be pivotal for addressing demographic changes, their success is contingent upon combating prejudices about ageing and life expectancy; as perceptions are changed, alongside policies regarding older employees and consumers, the silver economy opportunity can drive productivity and job creation.

name: The Social Cost of Carbon
description: The cost of carbon-intensive goods like fossil fuel-based energy should reflect the damage they cause. Even a small charge on the emission of carbon dioxide can help insure against climate risk, while providing incentives for the use of (and investment in) clean energy. Economists have identified two forms of carbon pricing as particularly flexible and efficient: emissions trading schemes (or “carbon markets”), and carbon fees or taxes, usually with proceeds that are refunded to the public. The number of related initiatives around the world has doubled during the past decade. According to the Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition, 70 national and sub-national jurisdictions are now pricing about 20% of global emissions. Barriers to taxing carbon at the consumer level, however, remain. In late 2018, France suspended a planned tax hike on gasoline and diesel fuel following violent demonstrations. At about the same time, voters in the state of Washington, one of the most progressive in the US, rejected a proposal to tax carbon dioxide emissions. Clearly, new approaches are needed to gain public support. Pricing carbon is necessary, not just for sound public policy but also for attracting private investment to renewable energy. The High-Level Commission on Carbon Prices, launched in 2016 with support from the World Bank, engages economists and climate change and energy experts in designing effective carbon pricing (a private-sector initiative led by CDP and the We Mean Business Coalition complements this effort). Institutional investors are now paying more attention to carbon risk management, and pushing companies to set an internal price on carbon, assess their exposure to climate-based risks, and allocate capital tailored to a low-carbon economy. A taskforce mandated by the Financial Stability Board has meanwhile published voluntary standards for climate-related financial disclosure, and nearly 1,400 companies reported last year on their practices and plans for pricing carbon. The standards are supported by nearly 300 financial services firms managing about $100 trillion in assets. The Financial Stability Board’s efforts go hand-in-hand with a G20 initiative to reform fossil-fuel subsidies that can lead to wasteful energy consumption. During the past forty years, our understanding of the economic forces underlying climate change has advanced considerably. In recognition of this, the 2018 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded to Yale economist William Nordhaus - for his work integrating climate change and carbon pricing into macroeconomic analysis.

name: The Trump Presidency
description: The election of Donald Trump on a platform of "America First" reflected a US electorate splintered along class and racial lines, and wrestling with disruptive forces brought about by globalization and the Fourth Industrial Revolution. The election result came as voters rejected traditional candidates and embraced outsiders likely to disrupt the status quo. It has heated up the national debate on immigration, due in no small part to Trump’s stated plans to build a wall along the US-Mexico border (conflict over construction of the wall triggered a government shutdown in late 2018), and stirred anxieties about the treatment of minorities and women. Trump’s presidency has reshaped and aggravated an already highly polarized political climate. The midterm congressional elections in 2018 reflected this polarized climate, as Democrats won control of the House of Representatives while Republicans strengthened their control of the Senate. The shift in House control portended a combative period, in which Trump is now faced with new congressional investigations and challenges to his domestic and foreign policies.   Factors that led to the current political polarization include large pockets of unemployment, as blue collar jobs have been sent overseas or replaced by new technologies. Meanwhile the nature of work itself has changed, as much higher premiums are now placed on knowledge and technology know-how. These changes have contributed to increased income inequality. According to data published by Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, while real GDP per capita in the US rose sharply between late 2009 (following the Great Recession) and mid-2018, real compensation per hour in the country remained stagnant during the same period. The erosion of trust between the electorate and traditional political leaders is by no means unique to the US. A similar trend is evident around the world, brought about in part by a ubiquitous and constant flow of information - and misinformation. The fact that policy positions which until recently would have been unimaginable are now a part of mainstream political debate means that the US, and the world, may be poised for dramatic change.

name: The Value of Content
description: As access to digital platforms expands, media companies are striving to develop sustainable ways to create and monetize content - in order to be able to continue to invest in its quality. Both traditional and emerging media companies are exploring new business models (such as monetizing data through analytics), generating new funding sources (like crowdfunding, or advertiser-sponsored content), streamlining the process for projects like bringing a TV series to market, and diversifying into other sectors like education. Some publications have sought to eschew advertising entirely; examples include The Information, a technology industry-focused publication founded in 2013 that charges subscribers $39 per month for access, and De Correspondent, a Dutch startup that has relied on both crowdfunding and subscriptions. Both publications focus on in-depth coverage, rather than the daily news cycle, and both are focused on the concept of membership. The Information, for example, offers subscription plans that include an ability to sit in on conference calls, join a private Facebook group, and access invitation-only meetings and events. Increasingly, media organizations are developing advertising campaigns based on sponsored content - a type of “native advertising” that looks like ordinary content but is paid for and presented by an advertiser (and is marked as such). In the US, spending on native digital display advertising was projected to rise to $41.4 billion in 2019 from $16.7 billion in 2016, according to data published by eMarketer. Over that same period of time, the percentage of all display ad spending dedicated to native advertising will grow to 61.4% from less than half, according to the data. Because of its potential to be mistaken for unbiased content, native advertising has received close scrutiny. According to a US Federal Trade Commission report published in late 2017, even after efforts to improve disclosure of native ads that the FTC used in a study, a significant percentage of participants still did not recognize ads as ads. It is not only media organizations that are finding new ways to monetize content. The size of the “influencer marketing” industry, where people with large audiences on sites like Instagram earn sponsorship money for posts, is expected to grow to $8 billion in value on Instagram alone by 2020, from about $4 billion in 2017, according to influencer marketing software firm InfluencerDB.

name: The ‘Customer’ Knows Best
description: The noble foreign aid worker dishing out sacks of food to dazed survivors is a tired stereotype. Humanitarian givers have long had power over receivers, creating a system ripe for abuse and a lack of accountability. Now, thanks in part to models borrowed from the private sector, and to higher expectations from donors, aid recipients (the term “beneficiaries” has been relegated to the dustbin) are getting more say over how humanitarian response functions. In Jordan, for example, a UN-backed call centre handles 150,000 calls a month from refugees with complaints, questions, or requests for advice. The modest improvements long familiar to conventional customer service are gaining ground in humanitarian work, including simple suggestion boxes, self-service apps, and satisfaction surveys. Some donors require that their grantees be independently audited against humanitarian accountability benchmarks. One result: according to a survey published by aid quality analysts ALNAP in 2018, 36% of humanitarian aid recipients were able to express their opinions on programmes, make complaints, or suggest changes to aid agencies - up from just 19% in 2015. Major aid organizations gathered at the World Humanitarian Summit in 2016 pledged that a “participation revolution” would mean affected people and communities are increasingly included in the process of designing programmes meant to help them. The general aim is to make improvements based on their feedback, and to handle their complaints - including those regarding abuse by aid workers - effectively. This has taken on particular urgency, after scandals related to sexual abuse and harassment committed by aid workers were revealed by the media in 2018. An environment in which aid recipients get to design services, criticize providers, and expose failures will not happen by itself, though. Donors and agencies still tend to call the shots, and affected people are often only asked what they need, not how they need it delivered. Recipient feedback can take a back seat to other matters in an urgent atmosphere, and checks and balances, in the form of police or pharmaceutical testing, may be weak or in disarray - leading to a regulatory vacuum where the chances for waste, irrelevance, and unintended harm are high. The need for accountability is therefore acute, because beneficiaries don’t benefit from goods and services they don’t really want or need.

name: Thematic Investment
description: In the years following the global financial crisis, structural economic changes such as ultra-low interest rates, global deleveraging (the shedding of debt assets), and technological innovation have changed the ways that institutional investors deploy capital. The speed of that change is only accelerating, and institutional investors are questioning traditional frameworks based on relative performance - which may fail to incorporate the secular trends (long-term trends, such as the growing economic and geopolitical influence of China, for example) shaping the global economy. Institutional investors have therefore started to consider thematic investment, which goes beyond strategic asset allocation to hone in on these longer-term, structural, political, and social shifts. A thematic approach can enable investors to generate unusually high returns by focusing on areas where significant amounts of capital may be required. It also provides a flexible way to validate insights. However, thematic investing demands a relatively significant amount of research. Many investors have avoided thematic investing, because they think it is too complex to put capabilities in place to develop distinctive insights related to trends like a growing global middle class, increased lifespans, and lifestyle changes. Recently, though, more investors are creatively implementing thematic investing, usually as a complement to other models. As they gain a better understanding of particular sector exposures and then invest accordingly, institutions can increase their odds of delivering superior returns, and of helping to address pressing economic and social challenges.

name: Trade Facilitation
description: Importing and exporting goods are each frequently delayed by costly bureaucratic red tape - according to a study published by the World Trade Organization in 2015, related costs can be equivalent to being hit with a tariff equal to 134% of a product’s monetary value in high-income countries, and equal to more than three times its monetary value in developing countries. Trade facilitation has therefore become increasingly important in a world of crisscrossing global and regional value chains, where products cross borders several times during their assembly. First agreed upon at the Ministerial Conference of the WTO held in Bali in 2013, the Trade Facilitation Agreement entered in force in early 2017. The agreement includes provisions for accelerating the movement, release, and clearance of goods at borders, requires WTO members to accept e-payments and electronic versions of certain import and export documents when possible, and requires members to establish a National Committee on Trade Facilitation as a means to coordinate and implement the agreement according to their domestic needs.  Paperless customs, in combination with a centralized “single window” system that collects trade documentation in one place, can reduce inefficiency, delays, and uncertainty at the border. The Trade Facilitation Agreement therefore provides for greater cooperation between national customs and other authorities - and a means for developing-country WTO members to simplify, modernize, and harmonize their import and export processes and procedures. The requirements to implement the agreement are linked to a member’s capacity to do so, and a Trade Facilitation Agreement Facility was established in 2014 to ensure that necessary technical assistance is available. The Global Alliance for Trade Facilitation, a public-private partnership co-led by the World Economic Forum, also supports implementation. The WTO estimates that full implementation could reduce trade costs by an average of 14.3%, and increase global trade by up to $1 trillion per year - with developing countries benefitting most. In Colombia, for example, the National Food and Drug Surveillance Institute was able to reduce physical food inspections by 27% as a result of a GATF project, which translated into a reduction in processing time for low-risk shipments from as much as 24 hours to as little as one hour.

name: Trade Openness
description: Ethiopia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the severity of tariff rates, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 8.50, resulting in a rank of 129th out of 140 countries; in terms of the openness of its services sector to trade and competition where it has a progress score of 11.80 that results in a rank of 98th out of 98 countries. One indicator reflects a better performance: the complexity of tariffs, where it has a progress score of 91.70 that results in a rank of 34th out of 140 countries.

name: Trade and Development
description: Roughly 8% of the global population, with the majority in sub-Saharan Africa, is suffering from extreme poverty, according to the Overseas Development Institute. The United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (adopted in 2015) recognize the importance of trade as an engine for more inclusive global economic growth. However, annual global trade volume growth is expected to slow to 2.6% in 2019 from 3% in the prior year, according to the World Trade Organization. And the figures for least-developed countries look particularly bleak - their share of global merchandise exports fell to 0.9% in 2016, from 1.1% in 2013, after having risen from 0.6% between 2000 and 2013, according to the 2018 Sustainable Development Goals Report. One encouraging sign has been the creation of the African Continental Free Trade Area in April, 2019, with the goal of fostering intra-African trade by reducing the many impediments in place (the biggest holdout has been Nigeria, however, which boasts Africa’s biggest economy and is home to more than 90 million people living in extreme poverty). The challenges that have mounted for the WTO are therefore worrying for developing countries that could potentially benefit from healthy, open global trade flows guided by the steadying hand of a respected international organization. The US has pursued openly protectionist trade policies, for example by slapping tariffs on billions of dollars-worth of goods not only from China but also from traditional allies such as Canada - potentially encouraging other world powers to follow suit (in addition, the US has blocked the appointment of WTO Appellate Body members, rendering this dispute settlement mechanism dysfunctional). In this context, a joint statement published by a diverse group of developing countries (from China to Uganda) declared the “pre-eminence of the WTO as the global forum for trade rules setting and governance” in 2019. This group’s view that Special and Differential Treatment provisions for developing-country WTO members must be preserved and strengthened is another area where its positions stand in stark contrast to those of the US and many other Western nations - though there may be room for related compromise, at least regarding the biggest economies that are still within the developing-country designation.

name: Trade and Integration
description: Since the early 1990s, Chile has committed to an increasing openness to trade, a relatively flexible currency policy, and a robust regulatory framework designed to manage foreign investment flows that first sprouted in the mid-1970s. Chile boasts a comprehensive set of bilateral trade agreements; according to the General Directorate of International Economic Relations (DIRECON), the country has signed trade agreements with 64 different partners that combined represent 86.3% of global GDP. Chile also actively participates in multilateral platforms, including the Latin-American Integration Association (ALADI) and the Pacific Alliance - an organization that the country helped to found. Chile’s open approach to international markets has supported the country’s sustained economic growth for last three decades. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) 2015 report Diagnostic on Engagement in Global Value Chains, Chile benefitted from low import tariffs and preferential trading agreements, and ranked among the best economic performers in its region. The World Economic Forum’s Enabling Trade Index 2016 ranked Chile above other OECD economies including the US, Australia, Canada and the Republic of Korea, particularly in terms of foreign market access. Still, the country is primarily a producer of basic commodities, and is particularly dependent on copper. Early success in this market, combined with the commodities price boom of the late 2000s, prevented Chile from pursuing a broader variety of exports. Diversifying Chile’s export structure, and boosting the participation of Chilean firms in more innovative value chains, will be a challenge. The Enabling Trade Index 2016 listed challenges that Chile needs to address related to infrastructure, transport services, and the use of information and communications technology. In addition, the Forum's Executive Opinion Survey 2016 identified problematic factors for the country’s exports including tariff barriers, relatively high costs and delays caused by international transportation, and access to trade finance. The OECD has recommended that Chile expand research and development spending and promotion, and export the country’s copper-related products and technology.

name: Trade and Investment
description: International trade and global supply chains are at the heart of the electronics industry, which sources components around the globe and divvies up production steps in many different countries. Industry leaders must work together with governments and other players to reduce trade barriers, and increase efficiencies. Fostering greater global trade can ignite job growth, create efficient and competitive markets, and put the global economy on the path of stable growth. While simply lowering tariffs can stimulate trade, that pales in comparison to the economic growth that can be created when supply chain-related limitations are reduced, or eliminated. One political complication, however, is that much of the electronics industry is concentrated in Asia; in addition, unstable or poorly functioning governments, and uncertain regulatory environments, can result in trade barriers. Another complication is the importance that national security agencies place on information and communication systems, which can influence and hinder commercial trading relationships. The World Trade Organization’s 2016 World Trade Report noted that innovation is increasingly advanced at export-oriented firms in emerging and developing markets. Shifts like this in the global trade landscape will impact traditional trading routes, influence national interests, and affect product development. As new markets arise, the electronics industry will have to adapt and adjust their supply chains, and better differentiate products for new customers. The US has managed to transform the North America Free Trade Association (NAFTA) into the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), and its trade dispute with the European Union appears to have been resolved. But the US’s trade dispute with China continues to intensify, amid disagreement over the size of current account deficits, steel and aluminium prices, and the alleged theft of intellectual property by Chinese companies (the US has lodged a related complaint with the World Trade Organization against China contesting its potential “market economy status,” a designation that would protect Chinese goods from anti-dumping duties). As it has made good on tariff threats with both traditional allies and adversaries alike, the Trump administration has cited a need to protect domestic manufacturing and fulfil campaign promises. When addressing the international business community at the World Economic Forum’s Annual Meeting in Davos in 2018, President Trump said his “America First” policy does not mean America alone. However, the US has demonstrated scepticism about multilateral agreements generally, and pulled out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which had to be reformulated without the US in 2018 as the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership. The original TPP had been an economic pillar of the Obama administration. China is advancing its own regional goals with its massive Belt and Road Initiative, which involves more than $900 billion in infrastructure projects in various parts of the world that are either planned or underway. In 2017, Chinese President Xi Xinping announced a joint China-Russia development fund, reportedly in part to assuage Russian concerns that the initiative may encroach on Russian spheres of influence. The Chinese leadership has also signalled interest in a Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership that includes the ten Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) members, in addition to Australia, India, and Japan. Meanwhile in Europe French President Emmanuel Macron has called for the better protection of strategic trade interests; both France and Germany are wary of Chinese investment in their domestic transport, defence, technology, and engineering sectors. Some countries have made loans to other countries that create ties which can later be leveraged as needed, in order to advance political priorities or gain strategic footholds. For example, after Sri Lanka was unable to repay a reported $8 billion loan to Chinese state-owned enterprises, China was allowed to sign a 99-year lease to occupy Sri Lanka’s strategic port of Hambantota.

name: Trade and Taxation
description: The growing importance of the digital economy has raised questions about the best ways to tax companies that generate their revenue online. Making related changes, however, can have broad implications for global geopolitics and economic growth. Predominantly internet-based businesses - particularly those big enough to attract a global user base - have drawn criticism for the ways in which they are perceived to avoid taxes. In Europe, for example, some governments have pressed for taxation of the largest internet firms, such as Google and Facebook, based on the revenue they make in a particular location, rather than based on the profit they recognize in relatively low-tax jurisdictions such as Ireland. Meanwhile Amazon.com, which long faced pressure from state governments in the US to charge state sales tax on purchases, has begun applying the tax not only to goods the company sells directly, but also to those sold on the site by third parties. While information and communications technology generally drives productivity growth in both the developed and developing worlds, many countries discourage adoption by imposing discriminatory tariffs and taxes on things like mobile phones, computers, and telecommunications services - which is done simply in order to increase government revenue, or protect domestic companies. Niger, for example, which has one of the lowest mobile broadband adoption rates in Africa, also has taxes on mobile broadband that are equal to 23% of average per capita income, according to a 2017 report published by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. By way of comparison, a number of countries including India, Brazil, Mexico, and Turkey all have taxes on mobile broadband that amount to significantly less than 5% of average income, according to data published in 2016 by GSMA, the industry group that represents mobile operators.

name: Trade and Travel Barriers to Mobility
description: Most mobility-related infrastructure, bureaucracy, and thinking is decidedly dated. Lingering barriers to mobility include the use of trade tariffs - the US-China trade war, for example, has resulted in a series of tariffs that have made parts more expensive for American manufacturers and thereby made it more difficult for them to remain competitive - and onerous visa requirements for travelers. Free trade agreements and an expansion of goods and services moving across borders can have profound economic benefits. However, recent casualties in world of free trade deals include the stalled Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), which would have created a free-trade area between the US and the European Union, and the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which was expected to become the world’s largest free trade deal before the US withdrew in 2017 (other signatories have since forged ahead). Much must still be done to better align the hundreds of regional trade agreements in force; according to the World Bank’s 2014 Doing Business project, a single export was liable to require up to 11 documents and 86 days of shipping due to red tape. In 2018, international tourist arrivals increased by 6% compared with the prior year, to 1.4 billion, according to a report published by the International Organization for Migration - marking the latest upswing in what has been an explosion in travel and tourism in the last few decades. However, in order to truly help many countries bolster their economic competitiveness, more must be done to make it easier for people to visit them, according to the report, which noted that only 21% of the global population did not require a visa when traveling for tourism purposes in 2018. A number of bilateral and regional agreements have been implemented to reduce travel barriers, including the Schengen Agreement, the US Global Entry program, and the APEC Business Travel Card. New technology and digitization can also help make travel a more seamless experience. However, the private sector must take a proactive role in making the case to governments that travel facilitation through technology can bring economic and security benefits.

name: Trade and the Environment
description: Global trade can contribute to environmental sustainability - if it is well regulated. It has a widely-recognized role to play in promoting food security, ocean health, and sustainable energy, and in combatting climate change (it underpins a number of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals). Positive related impacts can result from reducing subsidies for fisheries and fossil fuels, restricting illegal trade in minerals and protected species, and promoting technology that can be used to take climate action. The World Trade Organization provides the sole global framework for cooperation on phasing out fossil fuel subsidies, which are estimated to cost roughly $600 billion annually (though negotiations on the WTO’s Environmental Goods Agreement, which could increase the accessibility of environmental goods, have stalled). In light of often-slow progress in amending multilateral trade rules, regional trade agreements can provide an important alternative. For example, while the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has been panned by environmental groups, it includes provisions prohibiting both subsidies for overfished stocks and illegal fishing, as well as binding commitments on implementing environmental agreements. In general, the environmental chapters of regional trade deals like this often go beyond current WTO rules. International trade has created both challenges and opportunities for environmental regulators. While WTO rules allow for environmental measures (if they are based on environmental performance), for example, domestic climate action can run afoul of the international trade regime if it favours local suppliers. At the same time, the environmental border tax adjustment (domestic environmental taxes on imports from countries without such taxes) admissible under WTO rules can help limit the incentive for countries with stringent environmental policies to outsource activity to countries without those policies; research published in 2018, for example, showed that while Britain had cut emissions within its borders, when including emissions tied to its imports the country’s carbon footprint had actually grown. Ultimately, a consumption-based approach that makes the environmental impact of production clear to consumers could not only trace the effects of international trade, it could also provide information that is at least as valuable as that included in labelling campaigns related to child labour, fair trade, and the endangerment of dolphins as a result of fishing. The desire to make this approach a more common reality has intensified efforts to publish reliable environmental footprint indicators.

name: Training and Certification Systems
description: A greater variety of adult training and learning opportunities will be necessary in order to ensure that the 3 billion people in the current global workforce, and their employers, are able to navigate the Fourth Industrial Revolution. People increasingly need to re-skill throughout their working lives, and can benefit from more modular, diversified learning formats. This calls for a paradigm shift away from the current, front-loaded education model to one that assumes a need for continuous re-skilling throughout a lifetime. In addition, all learning needs to involve a contemporary curriculum, which fosters cognitive flexibility, curiosity, creativity, imagination, and a passion for further learning. Most importantly, participation rates need to improve. According to a report published by the European Association for the Education of Adults in 2017, only about 11% of adults in the European Union aged between 25 and 64 were participating in education and training programs as of 2016; the figure was as low as 1.2% for Romania, and as high as nearly 30% in Sweden.   Distributing learning across lifecycles redistributes the responsibilities of stakeholders including individual learners, businesses and professional associations, examining bodies, universities, unions, community learning centres, and governments. Multi-stakeholder collaboration will be critical for ensuring that strategies aimed at re-skilling individuals are balanced and complementary. Because of shifts in skills demand and industry composition, certification should enable workers to validate their skills within a number of industries and across a number of regions. According to a report published by the McKinsey Global Institute in 2018, as much as 14% of the global workforce may need to switch occupational categories by the year 2030, due to increased digitalization, automation, and advances in artificial intelligence. However, related public spending has been slow to materialize (and has actually fallen steadily for years in most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries), according to the report. Meanwhile a related survey conduction by the Mckinsey Global Institute in 2017 found that about 30% of executives at large companies saw addressing potential skills gaps resulting from digitalization and automation as among their top five priorities.

name: Transatlantic Relations
description: Since the end of World War II, Europe has looked at the world through a transatlantic lens; its relationship with the US has been cherished as its closest, and most important. Though there have been fluctuations in that alliance, it is built on the notion that the partners are fundamentally like-minded, and will always be there for each other in times of crisis. Donald Trump’s presidency could fundamentally reshape this relationship. His view of the European Union is at best ambivalent. At worst, he considers it an enemy in economic warfare. Ted Malloch, once considered a potential US ambassador to the EU under Trump, has compared the EU to the Soviet Union. Trump has made it clear that he will put “America first,” and continues to attack global institutions that the US has helped to build, as he appears to view them as imposing intolerable constraints. Since the end of the Cold War, the world has been held together by American-guaranteed security and European-inspired legal order. But America’s guarantee no longer appears to be reliable. Trump has shown that he has a transactional view of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), for example, by questioning whether the US would defend NATO members if they do not do more to defend themselves.  In May 2018, the US announced it would impose tariffs on steel and aluminium from the EU, and the EU responded in kind with its own tariff announcement - adding yet another complication to transatlantic relations. Europe fears that a Trump administration may actually be kinder to America’s traditional foes. Most challenging for Europeans is Trump’s expressed admiration for Russian Federation President Vladimir Putin. If Trump were to recognize the Russian Federation’s contested 2014 annexation of Crimea, the EU would be placed in a near-impossible position. Traditional communication channels are no longer being used, and fewer personal relationships exist between European governments and the US administration. Meanwhile, deliberations about a sort of European emancipation from the US have become more serious in Paris and Berlin. German Chancellor Angela Merkel made a remarkable speech in a Bavarian beer tent in May 2017, telling the audience - and the world - that Germany had to take its fate into its own hands. Europe will not break with America, but the time when Europeans could rely on a key ally is to some degree over, which should push Europeans toward EU reform.

name: Transformation and Investment
description: The South African economy is one of the most industrialized on the African continent. However, peak manufacturing levels in terms of share of employment were reached in the 1980s - and much of that was achieved due to protectionist policies implemented during the apartheid era. For much of the post-apartheid period, the trend in South Africa has been towards de-industrialization, as manufacturing has declined as a share of employment and added economic value. Manufacturing has become increasingly capital-, skill- and technology-intense, limiting the ability of unskilled labourers to enter the sector. In addition, factors that have hindered the ability of South African firms to compete internationally include the global manufacturing dominance of China. According to a report published by the World Bank in 2018, South Africa’s economic performance is closely tied to commodities that have suffered from declines in demand; coal prices are expected to dip as countries like China switch to greener sources of energy, for example, while China’s shift away from being an investment-driven economy (and towards being consumption-driven) has hurt iron ore prices, and gold prices are seen declining as interest rates are generally poised to increase.      South Africa’s reliance on commodities and commodity-based manufactured products has made it difficult for the country to diversify into other, more complex manufacturing industries. In addition, manufacturing-led structural transformation is not necessarily the only means of driving economic development and employment growth. A project commissioned by the United Nations University World Institute for Development Economics Research, Industries without Smokestacks, argues that service industries can spur employment-intensive growth. Meanwhile advances in robotics, artificial intelligence, sensors, 3D printing, automation, and machine learning, all elements of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, will likely have a significant impact on how goods and services are produced - and on the forms of employment underlying this production. These advances are typically both labour saving and complemented by skilled labour. As such, they are unlikely to positively address the unemployment challenges facing the South African economy, which has a surplus of unskilled labour. According to the World Bank report, prospects for this group have not improved; while skilled employment in the country rose 2.8% in 2017 compared with the prior year, unskilled employment increased by just 1.8%.

name: Transformation of Biological Threats
description: The world is under-prepared for even modest biological threats. We are vulnerable to significant harm to personal  well-being, economic activity, and national security caused by outbreaks of existing or modified strains of pathogens. In the past, naturally emerging infectious diseases have caused extraordinary health-related, economic, and security-related impacts - often fuelled by changing patterns of human behaviour. Many years of global headlines have made some of the biggest threats familiar: Ebola, MERS, SARS, Zika, yellow fever, and each year’s new strain of influenza. The frequency of disease outbreaks has been rising steadily. Between 1980 and 2013, there were 12,012 recorded outbreaks comprised of 44 million individual cases, affecting every country in the world. In June 2018 there were, for the first time ever, outbreaks of six of the eight categories of disease in the World Health Organization’s “priority diseases” list. If any had spread widely, it would have potentially killed thousands and created major global disruption. In addition to naturally occurring risks, emerging technologies are also making it increasingly easy for new biological threats to be manufactured and released - either deliberately or by accident. Driven by scientific advances and market forces, the cost of DNA synthesis has decreased at a rate faster than Moore’s Law; more and more people around the world have access to powerful biotechnologies that were once accessible only to well-established and well-funded scientists. It is possible now for a small research team to conduct experiments with potentially profound global consequences. For example, in 2018 a group of researchers in Canada demonstrated that a budget of $100,000 is enough to synthesize horsepox virus. Horsepox is benign to humans, but a close relative is Variola major, which causes smallpox - a disease that was eradicated in 1980 after having killed 300 million people since 1900. Live samples of smallpox virus now exist in just two highly secure facilities, one in the US and one in Russia. By publishing the synthesis process for horsepox virus, the Canadian research team sharply lowered the barriers to smallpox synthesis, and increased the risk of smallpox being released into the world either accidentally or intentionally. The world is at a critical juncture. If there is one area in which a turn inward by societies could be truly and needlessly destructive, it is global health security. Yet, as new risks emerge, there are early signs that important governance systems and protocols are eroding.

name: Transforming Africa
description: At the end of the Cold War, only three African countries were widely considered legitimate electoral democracies: Botswana, Gambia and Mauritius. Now, according to a 2018 report published by the non-governmental organization Freedom House, 61% of the countries in sub-Saharan Africa are rated as either “free” or “partly free” democracies. Highlights from the region flagged in the report included the exit of former president of Zimbabwe Robert Mugabe, and the dismantling of the family-based power structure in Angola set up by former President Jose Edward dos Santos. While the period between independence from colonial rule in Africa and the end of the Cold War had not seen a single ruler peacefully removed at the ballot box (with the exception of Mauritius), in 2016 there were 12 different presidential elections held during the year. Coupled with advances in health, education and technology, this has helped to generate a new narrative for Africa. According to UNESCO, secondary-school enrolment in the continent rose from 25% of eligible children in 1999 to 41% by 2012, as education programs were expanded and school fees were scrapped. Between 2010 and 2015, according to the World Health Organization, expanded intervention helped reduce malaria incidences by 21%, and malaria mortality rates by 31%. Average annual GDP growth for African countries is expected to reach 3.5% in 2019, according to the World Bank. A consumer explosion driven by the internet and mobile phone use has empowered Africans; Sub-Saharan Africa is home to the fastest mobile phone penetration growth of any region in the world, according to the GSMA, and its 420 million mobile subscribers is expected to grow to more than a half a billion by 2020. However, there is an urgent need to speed up the rate of structural transformation across the continent. Most African economies are still dependent on exports of primary commodities, while the share of manufacturing in national output is less than 10% on average - and is declining in some cases. There is therefore a need to better diversify African economies, with an initial focus on processing of agricultural commodities and minerals. This could kickstart a process of local industrialization, create more jobs in rural areas, and help stem rural-to-urban migration.

name: Transforming Governance and Institutions
description: The relative lack of transparency and high levels of corruption in many countries in the Middle East and North Africa region are obstacles to economic development. Corruption generates significant systemic, economic repercussions; the annual cost of bribery, for example (just one subset of corruption) is estimated to be as much as $2 trillion, or equivalent to about 2% of global GDP, according to a speech delivered by International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde in 2017. A lack of transparency and trust in government, financial institutions, and businesses can undermine development and deter investment. Meanwhile violence and armed conflict can compound this phenomenon, by facilitating illicit trade flows. According to the Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index published in 2018, corruption remains endemic in the MENA region, which is stricken by dictatorships and violent conflict; 19 of 21 Arab states scored below 50 in the index, where zero is highly corrupt and 100 is very clean. A key challenge for governments in the region is to tackle public sector corruption, in particular - and to ensure the separation of, and independence of, the executive and legislative branches. The participation of countries including Tunisia, Morocco, and Jordan in the Open Government Partnership, a platform designed to help reformers make their governments more open and accountable, is a promising sign. Public-sector corruption can only be checked by a mobilized public, and social media can have an important related impact - by empowering citizens and informing them of their rights, and keeping them abreast of government proceedings. Because of the relative youth of the population in the Arab world, the pace and depth of the integration of digital platforms within public service broadcasting in the region - as well as the speed of development of electronic, mobile, and smart government initiatives - can prove to be key for advancing transparency. Governments themselves can meanwhile use these tools to more directly engage with constituents, and become more accessible. In the United Arab Emirates, for example, the introduction of e-governance has been part of an effort to increase transparency; it has also motivated several other Gulf Cooperation Council countries (a group that includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar and Saudi Arabia) to launch their own, similar programs.

name: Transforming Markets
description: No Description Available.

name: Transition to a Low-Carbon Economy
description: While fossil fuels like coal have helped to improve living standards around the world since the 18th century, associated greenhouse gas emissions have led to devastating global warming. In order to avoid reaching temperatures that would have catastrophic consequences for the planet, countries must decarbonize their energy systems by the middle of this century. Companies with coal mines and reserves therefore face a significant risk of stranded assets. However, for minerals considered critical for the green transition - those needed for renewable power plants, energy storage solutions, efficient housing and infrastructure, or related technology and transportation systems - increased demand is likely. With this opportunity comes a series of risks. For example, as final products based on these in-demand minerals become more modular, they will potentially become easier to recycle if the right incentives are in place. While vertically-integrated mining companies (active along the entire "value chain" from mining minerals to selling finished products) in the steel and aluminium sectors are already an important part of recycling systems, a thriving recycling sector might ultimately dampen any demand for minerals generated by the clean energy transition. Transitioning to a low carbon economy will require the mining sector to reduce its environmental footprint. This is especially true now, because energy and water demand related to mining are expected to increase due to declining ore grades (as more energy is needed to produce the minerals that are in demand). Mining, processing, smelting, and transportation are energy intensive, and largely fossil fuel based. Mining companies are increasingly sourcing renewable energy in order to decarbonize; electrifying their operations and investing in alternative fuels to power their equipment will be key for them. Ultimately, companies with low-emission and recycling operations can market themselves at a premium to consumers and corporations increasingly conscious of greenhouse gas emissions. Public procurement programs in OECD countries that promote greener purchasing are evidence of this, as are commitments from companies to rely solely on recycled metals and minerals. Apple, for example, outlined plans in a 2017 report to help reduce the need to mine metals from the earth by only making use of renewable resources or recycled material. The company cited related developments including an ability to melt down iPhone 6 aluminium enclosures to make Mac mini computers for use in its factories.

name: Transitioning to Clean Energy
description: Renewable energy accounted for about 9.5% of all global energy in 2017, a slight increase compared with the prior year, according to the 2018 World Energy Outlook published by the International Energy Agency. The renewables counted in this mix included solar, wind, geothermal, and modern biomass energy, along with traditional hydroelectric power. More importantly, however, are projections for renewables to increase electrical power as a way to decarbonize the world’s energy supply. Thanks to economies of scale, and technologies like efficient solar cells and larger wind turbines, these energy sources now compete with fossil fuels. An analysis by the investment bank Lazard shows that during the past decade the “levelized” cost of electricity from wind farms (its average cost over the farm's lifetime) has decreased by two-thirds, and from utility-scale solar farms by nearly 90%. In many places, wind and solar are now cheaper than coal and natural gas. The emergence of new renewable energy markets has meanwhile reduced operating costs. In developing countries, renewable energy mini-grids are electrifying communities, while in developed countries solar power is reducing reliance on the grid, bolstered by renewable energy credits and tax incentives. Decarbonizing transportation poses the biggest challenge. The United Kingdom, France and China are among the countries that have announced their intention to curb fossil-fuel cars or entirely phase out internal combustion engines, and the number of electric vehicles on the road is projected to increase by more than 7,000% between 2017 and 2030. Still, this will be less than 15% of the nearly 2 billion vehicles expected to be in operation by then. Aviation and shipping are on track to account for nearly 40% of carbon-dioxide emissions by 2050. A report published by the Energy Transitions Commission outlined a plan to cut emissions with smarter logistics that improve efficiency by tempering demand for carbon-intensive transport.
