The high cost of energy storage in batteries is the main barrier preventing widespread adoption of intermittent renewable energy; a massive improvement in energy density is needed for lithium-ion batteries to compete with liquid fuels. Just as important as scaling-up battery technology will be the cleaning up of entire product chains, from working conditions in the mines that supply raw materials for batteries, to the pollution associated with the improper disposal of batteries. The World Economic Forum’s Global Battery Alliance was created in 2017 to address these challenges.

name: Transnational Actors
description: International relations is not only about relations between nations. While sovereign countries remain central actors on the world’s political stage, a host of non-state and transnational actors have inserted themselves into discussions about global governance. Digitalization has reduced communication costs such that businesses, for example, can more easily organize themselves globally and adopt global issues and concerns, while even relatively small civil society groups can connect across borders in order to tackle issues with an international scope. It has become increasingly clear that problems like the negative effects of climate change, heavy flows of migration as refugees flee from armed conflict and economic hardship, a lack of adequate health care in less developed regions, and the depletion of natural resources cannot be adequately addressed within national borders - giving actors previously concerned only with local issues a greater incentive to engage with global governance. These transnational actors include corporations, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), city governments, philanthropic organizations, and trade associations. Some have become extraordinarily influential, such as the Gates Foundation, thanks to its work on solving global health problems, or the C40 network of cities, due to its work related to addressing climate change. Meanwhile multinational corporations often boast annual revenue that is larger than the size of many countries’ GDPs, and large NGOs often have more delegates at international meetings than some medium-sized nations. As the capability of these actors sometimes outweighs that of nation states, it lends them decisive roles in resolving global issues. Their contributions do not necessarily come at the expense of government influence, but they have fundamentally reshaped notions about who matters in world politics. Increasingly, though, transnational actors also include dangerous entities like organized crime syndicates, terrorist networks and paramilitary organizations. Such organizations have benefited from financial globalization and digitalization, and have developed sophisticated communications strategies and clandestine, cross-border networks that can be difficult to track and confront. Particularly in those parts of the world with fragile or corrupt state organizations, these transnational entities can exploit weak governance and evade law enforcement.

name: Transparency
description: Bolivia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the incidence of corruption, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 33.00, resulting in a rank of 96th out of 140 countries.

name: Transparency and Open Government
description: Transparency is essential to hold governments accountable. But a new consensus is emerging that transparency alone is insufficient; without careful contextual considerations, it can lead to unanticipated outcomes. Improving transparency appears to be most effective in societies where corruption is fairly rare to begin with. In places where corruption is systemic, where citizens believe it is impossible to operate in government without becoming embroiled in corruption, transparency may actually engender resignation. In such contexts, greater openness is only more likely to lead to desired changes if accompanied by efforts to encourage citizen participation and alter beliefs about the inevitability of corruption. There have been improvements in terms of laws that promote transparency; the World Trade Organization’s 2013 Bali Package requires customs procedures to be more open, while membership in the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative has grown (according to a 2017 paper published in the Journal of Development Studies, the initiative appears to have shielded participating countries from increased corruption). In addition, as of 2015 about 90 countries had adopted Freedom of Information laws. A study published in 2017 found that while these laws normally increase the level of perceived government corruption immediately after they are introduced, the longer they are retained the more likely perceived corruption is to decline. In order for transparency initiatives to contribute to greater accountability, information needs to be regularly updated and easy to locate. One example is the establishment of so-called Transparency Portals by the Brazilian government, which empower citizens to find data about government salaries and spending. Seoul’s OPEN system (the Seoul Metropolitan Government’s Online Procedures Enhancement for civil applications) has facilitated citizen complaints about fees being charged illegally by government officials. Armed with information, citizens can monitor gaps in the delivery of goods and services that may indicate corruption. In Uganda, data on monthly school transfers of central government education grants were published in local newspapers, empowering parents and teachers to check if their local school had received the funds it was due. This led to a reduction in money lost to local government corruption, and to higher enrolment and test scores at schools in areas with high newspaper penetration. In addition, raising public familiarity with policy-making through “participatory budgeting” has been shown, in some instances, to reduce corruption, as citizens become better placed to ask questions and exert pressure if the goods and services they are anticipating fail to appear.

name: Transparency-Enabling Technologies
description: Innovative technology solutions can bolster anti-corruption efforts and policies, by enabling transparency when it comes to decision-making processes, financial flows, and ownership records. Transparency and accountability rely on processes in order to be effective, while these processes increasingly rely on technology. In the same way that mobile phone technology and the wireless internet have allowed many people in developing countries to leapfrog decades of legacy infrastructure investment made by more developed peers, technology developments related to artificial intelligence, blockchain, digital identity, and the use of big data now have the potential to limit opportunities for many kinds of corruption. Examples of successfully relying on technology to address corruption have proliferated. They include e-governance platforms that enable citizens to access information about the awarding of public contracts, automated decision making that can reduce the potential for conflicts of interest and bribery, artificial intelligence that can quickly scan transactions and develop patterns to identify money laundering schemes, and blockchain technology that can be used to meticulously track the transfer of funds using a dispersed ledger that cannot be surreptitiously altered. Particularly in situations where administrative and bureaucratic infrastructures are insufficient to enforce anti-corruption rules, a greater use of technology can help make significant progress. For example, in India, since 2010, the website ipaidabribe.com has empowered citizens to anonymously detail bribes paid to government officials, including the name of the official, the amount paid, and the service for which it was paid. Even though the site has some shortcomings, there is evidence that it has helped people to avoid having to pay bribes - by enabling them to choose to register their land transactions at offices where relatively few requested bribes have been disclosed. To be sure, technology also has the potential to be misused, in order to facilitate corruption. Technology-supported decision-making processes can also create opacity, by adding complexity or by limiting the number of individuals who are genuinely able to understand how to track the flow of transactions and funds. In addition, all systems and processes that rely on connected technologies can be exposed to hacking and other cyber threats.

name: Travel and Trade Barriers
description: The infrastructure and daunting bureaucracy that 21st century travellers must navigate are decidedly 20th century in nature. Inefficiencies are particularly apparent when seeking to obtain a visa, or navigating an airport. Still, some progress has been made. According to the World Tourism Organization, as of 2016, 58% of the world’s population was required to obtain a traditional visa prior to departure to a foreign destination, a decline compared with 77% in 2008. Travel barriers impede growth and depress job creation. A study published in the Journal of Economics and Finance in 2016 estimated that removing travel visas at the bilateral level between countries could more than triple cross-border travel flows. Meanwhile the World Tourism Organization and World Travel & Tourism Council have estimated that improving visa processes could generate an additional $206 billion in tourism receipts, and 5.1 million jobs over the course of a few years in G20 economies. Solutions implemented to support the reduction of travel barriers include the Schengen agreement, which facilitates movement across the borders of 26 countries in Europe, and the APEC Business Travel Card, which eliminates the need for business travellers from more than a dozen countries in different regions of the world to obtain visas. Other regional agreements are in the process of being negotiated or implemented, including potentially visa-free travel within the Association of Southeast Nations (ASEAN), and possible single passports for the Pacific Alliance (Colombia, Chile, Mexico and Peru) and Africa. A comprehensive model for revamping visa and border processes could revolutionize the travel and tourism sector in the same way that the smartphone has transformed telecommunications and media. The same technologies that enable travellers to book flights and keep their boarding passes on their phones should be applied to enhance border security and travel facilitation, in the form of e-visas and trusted traveller (expedited travel for the pre-approved) programs.

name: Trust Deficit
description: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, the financial industry, including hedge funds and private equity firms, has been the focus of public anger and distrust around the globe. According to the 2016 Edelman Trust Barometer, the financial services industry is globally perceived as the least trustworthy of the 8 industry sectors measured, scoring only 51% on trustworthiness. The 2014 version of same survey found that financial advisory and asset management was the least trustworthy sector within financial services, scoring 46% on trustworthiness. Furthermore, the Edelman surveys of the past few years have found that distrust of financial service institutions is concentrated in the United States and Western Europe, home to developed economies that serve as headquarters to most large financial institutions. A major cause of this trust deficit can be traced back to the bank bailouts after the 2008 crisis, an increase in income inequality and the current political environment. The general public is also weary of the perceived secretive nature of financial institutions, with client information, assets under management and investment strategies often kept strictly confidential. Governance of financial institutions, both within firms and by authorities, is often opaque with different levels of required disclosure depending on size and with very little information required to be shared publicly. This trust deficit partially affects the ability of private investors to attract capital as public sentiment makes big public institutional investments in alternatives, particularly hedge funds, a political liability. A lack of public trust also increases the likelihood of heightened government oversight and more transparency requirements that many private investors argue would endanger their ability to execute their proprietary investment strategies. Finally, the public’s anger has led to a focus on the fee structure of alternative investment firms with carried interest for private equity and the ‘two and twenty’ model employed by hedge funds – wherein hedge fund managers charge 2% of assets managed and claim 20% of any profits - being singled out by both liberal and conservative politicians.

name: Trust and Accountability
description: Tools and platforms like Facebook and Twitter have demonstrated the power of individuals to inform and educate in a shifting media landscape. They have also showcased the pitfalls of enabling that ability. More than half of the respondents surveyed in nearly 40 countries for a report published by the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism and the University of Oxford in 2018 said they were concerned about what is real and fake on the internet - with the highest percentage registered in Brazil (85%) and the lowest in the Netherlands (30%). The report also recorded the first decline in the use of social media for news after years of continuous growth - almost entirely due to a decline in the posting and sharing of news on Facebook. Journalists have a particular responsibility to adapt to this new era of communication, not least because their work is at risk of being drowned out by cacophony, and they themselves are at risk of being manipulated into spreading disinformation, according to a report published by UNESCO in 2018; journalism must distance itself from information that might interest the public, but is not in the public interest. As individuals increasingly participate in content creation and distribution, it raises questions about that content’s validity, and about who is accountable for its accuracy. Journalists are already grappling with how to regain public trust, due to a lack of transparency in the news gathering process. The increasing prevalence of artificial Intelligence and machine learning in the technology industry will only further complicate the matter. A team at OpenAI, a research institute in the US, has developed a program that can generate realistic news stories by feeding it an initial concept, for example. However, OpenAI’s policy director told MIT Technology Review in early 2019 that OpenAI quickly realized that the program was vulnerable to abuse; it could be used to quickly churn out fake news stories (targeted to people based on their online profiles) that would be so prevalent they would be difficult to tune out. The issue of accountability for publishing such material has stirred heated debate. Twitter, for example, has made some efforts to rid itself of bots (and real people) spewing misinformation - though Twitter Chief Executive Jack Dorsey is still regularly asked why he does not ban certain accounts or behaviour. Dorsey testified to Congress in 2018 that he is committed to ensuring that “all voices can be heard.”

name: Trust and Privacy
description: Global dialogue around the governing and safeguarding of personal data is polarized. The often conflicting objectives of governments, businesses and private citizens result in a complicated and often emotional discourse – which hinders informed decision-making. Personal data is increasingly seen as a pervasive, 21st-century asset class, like a stock or bond. That comes as business models are being built around unprecedented opportunities to create value through the flow of such data. According to the 2014 World Economic Forum report Personal Data: The Emergence of a New Asset Class, trust between individuals, governments and companies is necessary in order to fully unlock its potential.  Yet there is a crisis of trust, as stakeholders struggle to agree upon a personal data framework that is reliable and fair. Existing legal frameworks will prove inadequate, due to the speed of change and uncertainty about appropriate rights and responsibilities. The establishment of effective new frameworks must involve a truly democratic approach, if the public’s trust in data governance is to be restored.

name: Trust and Visibility
description: The low-profile approach to communications traditionally taken by family businesses will not work, amid increasing scepticism. A company’s brand and reputation are inextricably linked, and consumers are increasingly ready to boycott businesses they do not believe live up to their own values. Family businesses have a distinct opportunity to draw greater attention not only to the long-term value they create, but also to the values by which they operate. An Edelman Trust Barometer special report on trust in family businesses compiled in 2017 showed that they are trusted more than businesses in general by a 16-point margin. Yet, family businesses are squandering this advantage. Too many stay silent on their value and contributions to society. According to the special report, a majority of family business employees would recommend their company’s products and services to others, and would recommend it as an employer. More than twice as many respondents cited in the special report said they would prefer working for a family business than those who preferred working for another type of business, and nearly half of all respondents were willing to pay more for products or services if they are offered by a family business. Even though between 50% and 80% of all jobs are created by family businesses (according to the Family Firm Institute), fewer than one in three respondents cited in the special report saw family businesses as job creators. Respondents also expressed beliefs that non-family businesses are more innovative, financially successful, and adept at long-term thinking than family businesses. By staying silent and failing to correct these misperceptions, family businesses will fail to capitalize on their trust advantage. They must also take more visible leadership roles on social issues; two-thirds of special report respondents said that if a family business is not afraid to take a stand on controversial issues, it increases their trust in that business (respondents also wanted family businesses to create jobs locally and keep them there, address income equality, and encourage employee volunteerism). It is worth noting that 73% of respondents said knowing a company’s history helped to build trust, and that company founders enjoy a credibility advantage over second and third generation family members, and over non-family CEOs. Family businesses must tell their stories. Now is the time for them to showcase the value of their leadership and contributions.

name: Turkey and the European Union
description: Turkey experienced its biggest-ever inflow of foreign investment at about the same time that it began negotiations for accession to the European Union in 2005. The accession process, and the associated values and standards that it signals, are critical information for any business considering investing in the country. Interruptions to this process have had negative consequences, however - for the economy, transparency, human rights, and the rule of law. While 16 of 35 accession chapters have been opened, only one (related to Science and Research) has been provisionally closed; Turkey’s accession negotiations have therefore effectively stalled. The EU has highlighted concerns regarding the rule of law and fundamental rights, and an unresolved dispute over Cyprus has been a point of contention. In mid-2019, the EU suspended high-level contact with Turkey and shelved financial aid for the country, after it began pursuing gas exploration in Cypriot national waters. Turkey said it would nonetheless continue the exploration, and suggested that the EU is biased on the subject of Cyprus (which has been partitioned between an ethnically Turkish north and ethnically Greek south since 1974). The rift over gas exploration came as Turkey and the EU had been maintaining a steady dialogue. Then-European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, European Council President Donald Tusk and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan met in Bulgaria in early 2018, followed by a High Level Political Dialogue in Ankara later that year. While issues were discussed including counter-terrorism and security policy, with a special emphasis on Syria, Libya, and Iraq, there has been slow progress towards implementing joint action. A healthy relationship is crucial, not least because the EU is Turkey’s top trading partner, while Turkey ranked 5th among EU trading partners in 2018. As it deals with Turkey, however, the EU is meanwhile preoccupied with other challenges including the Brexit process, rising populism, and Euroscepticism. So, while full membership remains Turkey’s ultimate goal, the country’s own domestic political challenges and increasing doubts regarding the future of an integrated Europe have increased uncertainty about joining the bloc. Still, Turkey and the EU share multiple bonds - and maintaining constructive dialogue and cooperation on advancing mutual economic, political, and security interests is crucial.

name: Turkey’s Public Spending and Unemployment
description: Turkey’s Justice and Development Party (AKP), led by President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, owes much of its electoral success to redistributive policies - in the form of social services, free medical clinics, the development of cheap housing, the legalization of squatter settlements, and the distribution of cash, food vouchers, and school stipends to its voter base. As general government final consumption expenditure in Turkey increased to 13.9% of GDP by 2015 from 10.8% in 1995, according to World Bank data, the country’s Human Development Index score (an assessment accounting for everything from poverty to life expectancy) improved to nearly 0.8 from 0.6 over the same period. In addition to the redistribution of public and private funds among the electorate, however, the AKP has embraced a discourse that contrasts the “pure people” and “corrupt elite,” according to a paper published by the LSE Middle East Centre in 2016. As the party has used such tactics to secure public support, voters in turn have tolerated a general decline when it comes to their rights and liberties. The government’s polarizing discourse has helped to justify its intervention in state institutions such as the courts, the central bank, the privatization administration, and procurement authorities - all in the name of preventing manipulation on the part of elites. The divisive rhetoric also comes as the Turkish unemployment rate has followed an upward trend following a 2001 financial crisis in the country, reaching 14% during the 2009 recession and again creeping above 14% as of early 2019. During that same period, youth unemployment followed a similar trajectory, reaching 25.2% by early 2019. What is perhaps most striking is the steep increase in female unemployment rate (amid a relatively low female labour participation rate); the female unemployment rate nearly doubled between 2001 and 2018, to 14%. This increase, and a broader increase in unemployment in general, can be viewed as factors behind widened income inequality in the country - which in turn feeds further polarization.

name: Turkey’s Regional Role
description: When Turkey’s Justice and Development Party (AKP) was founded in 2001, and swept to victory in the 2002 national elections, many people saw it as a possible model for political moderation and democratization in the Muslim world (in 2005, party leader and current President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan described the party’s agenda as “conservative democracy”). However, since then, the party’s increasingly autocratic policies - particularly after 2013, when the government faced a wave of public demonstrations and unrest - have dramatically changed its image. The ongoing civil war in neighbouring Syria has only added a further destabilizing element to Turkey’s domestic situation, while at the same time bolstering the country’s importance to other allies in the conflict supporting rebel forces - including the US, Saudi Arabia, and Qatar. More broadly, Turkey is a valued member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. However, Turkey’s decision in 2019 to purchase a missile-defense system from Russia provoked a rebuke from the US, which has argued that the acquisition is incompatible with NATO systems. Turkey has in recent decades sought to present itself as a strong, decisive player in global affairs - and has seemed willing to play the US and Russia against each other in order to pursue domestic interests. In terms of its regional cooperation, Turkey and the European Union remain significant partners in a turbulent context. The Ankara Agreement of 1964 providing a framework for cooperation, and the EU-Turkey Customs Union established in 1995 remain cornerstones of this arrangement. Healthy cooperation has been particularly crucial amid heavy flows of refugees from the Middle East who are often ultimately headed to Europe; As of June 2019, Turkey was hosting more than 3.6 million registered refugees from Syria, and more than 365,000 “persons of concern” from other countries, making it host to the largest number of refugees worldwide, according to The UN Refugee Agency. While the EU has committed €6 billion to help mitigate Turkey’s heavy financial burden as host to such a large refugee population, as of May 2019 only about €2.2 billion had been disbursed.

name: Turkish Monetary Policy
description: Central bank independence is considered a key pillar of macroeconomic stability. Following Turkey’s 2001 financial crisis, the Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey was granted independence to pursue a mandate of establishing price stability; during a subsequent period of inflation targeting (pulling policy levers to hit a publicized inflation goal), the central bank was able to establish its credibility by implementing relatively tight monetary policy that brought the inflation rate down to 9% by 2004, from 30% in 2002. However, in the following years political pressure mounted to lower interest rates and effectively make money cheaper for the voting public - particularly after 2010. The gap between the inflation target and the actual inflation rate proceeded to widen, with the average inflation rate between 2006 and 2018 settling at 9.4%, or nearly twice as high as the 5% inflation target during the period. The central bank’s ability to control long-term interest rates declined during this time, business cycles grew more volatile, and foreign investment dwindled - even during a post-financial crisis inflow of capital into emerging market economies. In response to this influx of capital, a number of central banks in emerging markets adopted new policy tools and sought to engage in some form of tightening to prevent a dangerously rapid expansion of commercial bank lending. Among the most popular tools used: the setting of reserve requirement ratios, which limit how much commercial banks in a country can lend relative to the reserves that they keep on hand as a cushion for periods of turmoil. Turkey’s central bank raised required reserve ratios after 2010, which enabled it to tighten monetary policy while still keeping interest rates relatively low. Turkey has a chronic current account deficit, however, with imports exceeding the value of exports, due to its dependence on imported oil and intermediate goods (which are combined to form finished products). This deficit, coupled with an increase in borrowing in the post-crisis era, has created challenges for the central bank. For example, in this era of abundant liquidity, setting high interest rates in a bid to target inflation can trigger unwelcome, speculative capital inflows - while keeping rates low can depreciate the local currency.

name: UK Healthcare Delivery
description: According to a survey conducted by Opinium in 2016, more than one third of respondents answered a question about what it is that makes them most proud to be British by citing the National Health Service. Since its creation in 1948, however, the NHS has been both hailed as a reliable source of free care and social cohesion, and criticized as inefficient and expensive. Campaigners for the UK to leave the European Union had suggested in the lead-up to the related popular vote that it could result in £350 million in additional weekly funding for the NHS; the UK’s Health Secretary subsequently clarified in 2017 that this would not be the case. According to the UK’s National Audit Office, the service swung to an £111 million surplus in 2016-2017, from a £1.85 billion deficit in the prior fiscal year - though the office has cautioned that NHS bodies are increasingly reliant on savings they cannot necessarily count on every year. The NHS’s funding issues come as it faces a series of significant challenges, including increasing rates of old-age-related disease among a generally ageing UK population, and increasing customer demand for tailored advice and healthcare.  Polls indicate that the UK public is strongly in favour of preserving the NHS in its current form. Still, a separate survey conducted by Opinium in 2017 found that nearly three out of five respondents felt the NHS was in a worse state than it had been five years earlier, and nearly half said they would be willing to pay higher taxes if they knew it would go directly to the health service. In June 2018, UK Prime Minister Theresa May outlined a long-term funding plan for the NHS, involving taxpayers likely making greater contributions to the service - which would in turn receive an additional £20.5 billion annually through the end of the 2023-24 fiscal year. May also pledged to contribute £1.25 billion more per year to NHS pension costs. Advances in medicine and healthcare technologies helping underpin the Fourth Industrial Revolution, and populations that are becoming more heavily skewed towards the elderly, are both posing financial challenges for entities like the NHS - and creating ethical questions. The NHS’s provision of patient information to the Google-owned company DeepMind, for example, is designed to better identify patients most susceptible to kidney failure, but has also raised privacy concerns.

name: UK Migration Patterns
description: The net migration of European Union citizens to the United Kingdom increased sharply after the 2004 enlargement of the EU, which saw the addition of eight countries in the east - by 2015, annual arrivals from the EU accounted for half of all migration to the UK, according to a report published by the charity Full Fact. This historical shift, from migration primarily sourced from within the Commonwealth to primarily from a roster of EU neighbours that has expanded eastward, was one of the key factors behind the UK vote in 2016 to leave the EU. While immigration from EU countries to the UK picked up in the years prior to the vote, according to the December 2015/January 2016 issue of the CER (Centre for European Reform) Bulletin, those patterns were actually not out of the ordinary within the context of other EU countries. However, British workers’ real wages fell sharply between 2008 and 2014 due to a recession that followed the financial crisis, with low earners suffering the most dramatic decline, according to the CER Bulletin; that created a false link in many peoples’ minds between declining wages and increasing numbers of migrants. According to the bulletin, British employers have historically been more open to hiring people with foreign qualifications than employers in other EU countries, leading to a pool of immigrants in the UK that is actually more skilled than in any other member state - and more likely to be employed than native Britons. The impact of Brexit on British employers’ ability to retain these employees and continue to recruit from the EU may have broad implications for the UK economy. A political declaration accompanying a draft withdrawal agreement that had been endorsed by EU member states in late 2018 included a commitment to establishing "mobility arrangements” for UK and EU citizens and an agreement to consider conditions for entry and stay for purposes like research and youth exchanges - though that draft deal was later rejected by the UK Parliament, ratcheting up the possibility of a no-deal "hard" Brexit that would leave many such issues unresolved. Migration issues in the UK are not solely related to the EU; policy has also become more restrictive towards non-EU migrants, including Commonwealth citizens. In early 2018, the UK government was forced to apologize after deporting Caribbean immigrants who had been in the country for half a century, but were unable to prove they had a right to stay. The UK Home Secretary subsequently resigned.

name: UK Relations with the EU
description: The World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index for 2018 saw the United Kingdom fall two spots compared with the prior year, and noted that Brexit will inevitably weaken the “markets” component of the country’s performance. The ultimate effects of the UK’s departure from the EU, which is slated for October 2019, are unclear. EU leaders approved a draft withdrawal agreement in November 2018, but this was rejected in the UK’s House of Commons in January 2019. The scale of the UK government’s defeat in the Commons - the largest in 95 years - eroded hope for a parliamentary majority in favour of even a renegotiated exit deal, and ratcheted up the likelihood of a potentially traumatic, no-deal "hard" Brexit. The defeated arrangement would have had the UK pay £39 billion to extricate itself from EU liabilities, such as loans that the bloc has collectively made to individual countries. The UK Office for Budget Responsibility has said the payment would have been less than what the country would contribute to the bloc had it remained an EU member - though the UK will also likely pay as-yet-undetermined individual amounts to continue participating in select EU programs post-divorce. The impact of the impending split on the significant trade relationship between the UK and the EU remains unclear; as much as 51% of UK exports go to the EU, and as much as 56% of all UK imports arrive from the EU (as of mid-2018), according to HM Revenue & Customs. The proposed-but-ultimately-doomed departure deal would have protected existing rights for EU citizens to live, work, and study in the UK, and for UK citizens to do the same in EU states - as long as they had moved before the end of a transition period was slated to last until the end of 2020. The proposed deal also addressed the impact of Brexit on the border shared by Northern Ireland (which is inside of the UK) and Ireland (an EU member). Fears have been expressed about the ability of Ireland and Northern Ireland to retain customs-free trade, for example, should the UK not remain in a customs union with the EU. Under the terms of the proposed deal, the UK and EU would have entered into a joint customs area that would have eliminated a need for customs checks between Northern Ireland and Ireland.

name: UK’s Role in the World
description: The United Kingdom’s impending exit from the European Union has fuelled heated debate over what this means for the UK’s global role. Confidence in the country’s ability to make a success of Brexit is based on its plans to expand trade both with emerging economies and within the Commonwealth, on its “special relationship” with the US, and on an assumption that relations with EU partners will remain close. These pillars have become increasingly unsound. India, for example, the Commonwealth member with the world’s fastest-growing large economy, has linked deeper trade with Britain to concessions on immigration - an idea that has been rejected. Meanwhile, relations between Britain and the US have not improved under the Trump administration. The UK could not convince Trump to stay in the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, and another country, perhaps France, could potentially displace the UK as America’s primary European interlocutor. While Britain’s relations with the EU may fare better, a messy, "hard" Brexit that leaves unresolved budget disputes or questions about EU citizens residing in the UK could jeopardize this possibility. Britain’s prestige within international institutions is being closely monitored for signs of wear. In 2017, the country’s failure to elect a candidate to the International Court of Justice, its inability to win support for its position on the Chagos Islands at the United Nations, and its failed bid for sanctions on Russia at the G7 were reported as foreshadowing a post-Brexit decline. Yet, for the foreseeable future, at least, Britain should remain near the top of global economic, defence, and education rankings. In or out of the EU, it is a member of the G7 with the fifth-largest economy in the world. It will likely remain a nuclear power with both a permanent seat on the UN Security Council and some of the highest military spending levels in the world, as well as a participant in the world’s most powerful intelligence network, and the possessor of enviable diplomatic reach. One sign that the country may well retain its geopolitical status was its ability to swiftly rally allies in the wake of the poisoning of a former Russian spy on UK territory, in early 2018.

name: Understanding Climate Risks
description: Nine of the 10 hottest years on record have occurred since 2005. The global average temperature is now about 1°C above the pre-industrial average, and increasing by about 0.2°C per decade. Carbon dioxide released by burning fossil fuels and agricultural and industrial activity has raised the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to more than 400 parts per million - which has intensified the trapping of heat. Global warming is causing sea levels to rise and changing precipitation patterns, with increased rainfall in some regions and more extreme drought in others. Disasters triggered by weather- and climate-related risks are estimated to have been responsible for thousands of deaths and more than $300 billion in losses worldwide in 2017 alone. A National Climate Assessment issued in the US in late 2018 projected yearly losses of a similar magnitude there by the end of this century. A 2012 report published by the US National Academy of Sciences found that a 2°C rise in temperature could expose up to 20% of the world’s population to chronic water shortages (about 5% is now exposed). Under that same 2°C scenario, global agricultural yields by the end of the 21st century could decline by as much as 15% for staple crops such as maize. The Paris Agreement on climate change aims to limit global average temperature rise to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. A 2018 report published by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change highlighted the need to limit warming to no more than 1.5°C; many ocean ecosystems, including the majority of the world’s warm water coral reefs, are likely to disappear if warming exceeds this level. Average global rise in sea level (projected to be about half a metre by 2100 if warming reaches 2°C) could be reduced by 20% by hitting the 1.5°C target, thereby protecting 10 million vulnerable people. A slower temperature rise could also help affected regions better adapt to climate change. In order to meet the 1.5°C target, however, countries must go well beyond their Paris Agreement commitments. And, because carbon dioxide persists in the atmosphere for centuries, models show that these emissions would have to cease entirely by 2050, while emissions of other, less-long-lived greenhouse gases would have to fall significantly. Achieving this will require far-reaching changes to many aspects of modern society, but could also help to create a more sustainable, equitable world.

name: Understanding Inequality and Growth
description: About one in seven children in Japan live in poverty, despite recent improvements in addressing the needs of the country’s poor. According to a 2016 report from the UNICEF Office of Research, Japan ranked 34th among wealthy countries in terms of children living in poor households, one notch ahead of Italy and four behind the US. Income inequality and poverty are relatively less visible in Japanese society than in other countries, and Japan’s assessment in the UNICEF report made a significant impact in the media. Japan has explored new models for developing an inclusive, sustainable economy that look beyond a GDP-centric approach to economic growth. For many years, in fact, Japan's relatively high standard of living has been at odds with public perception of lingering economic malaise. The country's GDP grew 1.7% in 2017, according to the World Bank, and annual growth has not topped 2% since 2010. However, observers have noted that the country's shrinking population means GDP per head has actually been relatively strong. And, as the Financial Times has reported, rough economic statistics may not take into account the difference between an elegant Mitsukoshi department store and a Wal Mart in the US, for example - and instead evenly attribute their respective contributions to GDP.

name: Universal Access
description: In 2015, the United Nations established Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), one of which is to ensure access to affordable, reliable, and modern energy for all by 2030. However, as of 2016, 1.1 billion people still did not have access to electricity, and many others had an inadequate, unreliable supply - primarily in rural areas of sub-Saharan Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. According to the International Energy Agency, present electrification efforts will not keep pace with population growth in sub-Saharan Africa, and the global citizenry that is doing without will become increasingly concentrated there. A lack of investment in generation plants and network infrastructure, subsidized tariffs that do not cover the cost of supply, poor governance, and insufficient legal security have contributed to this situation. Until recently, nearly all of those who had gained access to electricity worldwide did so through new grid connections, and about 70% of those who have received power since 2000 have done so via fossil fuels. In recent years, however, large-scale renewables (mainly hydro and geothermal) have been the source of over one third of new grid connections, while decentralized resources, such as solar home systems and microgrids, have supplied an increasing amount of electricity access. This trend is expected to accelerate. Technology improvements are creating opportunities to make progress on universal electricity access; the declining cost of solar, cheaper and more efficient lighting and appliances, and new business models that make use of digital and mobile platforms have increased the solutions available to those doing without. In order to realize the broader social and economic benefits of electrification, it will require looking beyond household connections and taking into account the electricity used for business and agriculture. The short-term impact of universal electricity access on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change is expected to be minimal, as the overall increase in demand will be relatively small (though the exact modes of electrification will determine long-term impacts). Providing electricity for all by 2030 would require annual investment of $52 billion, or more than twice what has so far been mobilized under current and planned policies, according to a 2017 report published by the International Energy Agency. Of the additional needed investment, 95% must be directed to sub-Saharan Africa, according to the report. Scaling up investment in electricity access requires the right policies and investment frameworks, and approaches that connect existing but uncoordinated initiatives will be needed.

name: Unlocking Human Capital
description: While youth unemployment and a relative dearth of entrepreneurship are common in the Middle East, they are particularly pressing issues in Saudi Arabia. The kingdom is in need of economic modernization, in order to put its fast-growing youth population to work. About 51% of Saudis are under the age of 25, while nearly three quarters are in their mid-thirties or younger. Meanwhile roughly two thirds of Saudis are employed in the public sector. The kingdom’s ability to develop its workforce and endow it with new skills will rely on establishing the necessary infrastructure. According to the World Economic Forum’s 2017 Global Human Capital Report, which ranked workforces according to attributes, Saudi Arabia placed 82nd out of 130 countries, and suffers from a high employment gender gap; according to the International Labour Organization, Saudi Arabia had only a 22% labour force participation rate among women as of 2016. While the World Economic Forum’s Global Gender Gap Report for 2017 ranked Saudi Arabia 138th out of 144 countries, it noted that the country had made some progress. The kingdom’s decision to allow women to drive is expected to significantly augment their ability to work. Another potential asset is the kingdom’s migrant population of roughly 12 million (according to government figures); foreign workers include both high- and low-skilled varieties. The challenge for Saudi Arabia is to provide greater opportunity for these workers, while at the same time weaning itself of some of its traditional dependence on foreign labour. Youth unemployment remains a complex, structural problem that cannot be solved simply by budgeting additional funds. Technology disruption presents an opportunity for Saudi Arabia to get its youth population trained in more relevant skills, though it also presents challenges in the form of increased job automation. An estimated 46% of jobs in Saudi Arabia are susceptible to automation, according to the World Economic Forum’s 2017 report The Future of Jobs and Skills in the Middle East and North Africa. As the kingdom seeks to prepare its traditionally comfortable younger generations for the modern workplace, it must enable them to not only gain degrees, but also to develop critical thinking and entrepreneurial skills - and a willingness to work hard in order to achieve success.

name: Urban Aerial Mobility
description: Nearly all commercial flights now connect cities that are at least 300 kilometres apart. However, drone technologies in development are creating new opportunities for safe, economical aerial human transport both over short-haul routes and within cities. Electric, vertical takeoff and landing platforms - which often look like scaled-up versions of consumer and delivery drones - are being designed to move people around cities; commercial drone taxi services are expected in Dubai and Dallas by 2020. The development of detection and avoidance technologies for drones, and autonomous flight algorithms, can reduce costs by taking pilots out of aircraft. Meanwhile drone system traffic management could enable more intensive, and safer use of airspace. Although questions remain about the feasibility of moving large numbers of people through the air over short distances, increasing road congestion and the opportunity to reduce costs are drawing new related attention and investment from companies and governments. A number of models are emerging for how new types of air travel could be integrated into transportation networks, including personally-owned flying cars, a managed network of on-demand aviation, and a public transit-like system of aircraft flying between designated points on a fixed schedule. In any case, public concerns about noise issues stemming from expanded air traffic in populated areas must be addressed. If the cost of these new modes of air transit can be limited, they have the potential to better link people living in disadvantaged areas to better jobs further afield from their neighbourhoods, potentially reducing inequality. That could be a positive evolution from the current system of intra-city travel, by helicopter, which is primarily for the wealthy.

name: Urban Diplomacy
description: The C40 Cities Climate Change Leadership Group connects 90 cities and more than 650 million people, to facilitate collaboration on addressing climate change. In 2014, Ho Chi Minh City received technical assistance and investment from Rotterdam to better deal with rising sea levels and increasingly severe storms via the C40’s Connecting Delta Cities Network. Cities have increasingly made their presence felt in the global community, in the interest of their specific local needs and as a means to better find solutions to vexing urban challenges. At the 2014 UN Secretary General’s Climate Summit, the so-called Compact of Mayors, an ambitious agreement to commit to deep greenhouse gas emission reductions, was formed. In total, 447 cities, with a collective population of 391 million, committed to the compact. City mayors also played an important role in shaping the Paris Agreement on climate change. In 2016, the Compact of Mayors formally merged with the European Union’s Covenant of Mayors, a climate change initiative launched in 2008, in order to create a more powerful platform to demonstrate the global impact that cities can have. It was inevitable that cities would form closer international connections based on concerns about trade, infrastructure, culture, and migration. Increasingly, municipal leaders are asking why they are not part of discussions related to, for example, the UN Global Compact on Refugees - even as many refugees and internally displaced people end up in urban areas. In 2018, the ASEAN Smart Cities Network was launched, in order to bring together 26 Southeast Asian cities to learn from each other about how to become digital-ready. The twinning of cities is a longstanding practice; according to a UK Government Office for Science study on city diplomacy published in 2016, twinning has evolved to become more strategic, and has spawned multi-city coalitions as localities create joint projects and platforms where businesses can interact. Beijing alone has 47 “sister” cities, according to the report, and launched 114 “concrete cooperations” with 37 of these cities between 2009 and 2014, including shared efforts by the Bank of Beijing and the International Netherlands Group, and between Beiqi Foton Motor Co. and the City of Moscow.

name: Urban Economies
description: Currently, 600 cities generate close to 60% of the world’s economic output - numbers that are expected to remain roughly constant over the coming decade, though the geographical mix of these core urban areas will change significantly. Only a decade ago, roughly half of all global economic output was generated by fewer than 400 cities, all of them in advanced economies, and many in North America. This is projected to change dramatically, as economic power shifts towards Asia and other emerging market regions. Over half of today’s two dozen “mega cities,” or those with more than 10 million inhabitants, are in Asia, and more than half of these are in China. An urban economy is a city’s economic base, or the mix of economic functions that create value and employment. These functions are continually being transformed; though the pace can vary, depending on demographic or migration factors, local and regional fiscal policy, business cycles, and regional development efforts.  In Asia, where the legacy of the developmental state (where economic development is centralized and directed by the government) still looms large, big cities like Seoul have made efforts to transform their economic base by moving large-scale manufacturing to outer regions as they develop more service-oriented economies. Such efforts have been made for years in Hong Kong, and are now gradually being made in Beijing. While policies can transform the trajectory of cities in order to better support growth industries, urban areas also experience restructuring that is brought on by disinvestment, and an exodus of highly-skilled workers; a significant number are trending in this direction. In North America and Europe, for example, there are many examples of cities that are shrinking as their physical and social infrastructures decay. Whether in decline or ascent, cities need to balance their desire for a vibrant culture with a recognition of ways that they can become home to widening disparity. As cities work to embrace the same digital and innovative processes that are transforming business models, and creating economic value, this must be pursued in tandem with stronger social protection and inclusion measures that both help less-skilled and displaced workers find opportunities in expanding sectors, and increase access to the services that matter for households that subsist on stagnating wages.

name: Urban Environment and Resources
description: The ecological footprints of cities, or the productive areas required to supply them with resources while also absorbing their waste, need to be reduced. Cities consume more than 75% of the world’s energy, and are expected to generate more than 2 billion tonnes of waste annually by 2025 - compared with 1.3 billion tonnes of waste in 2012. The urban environment faces multiple threats: air pollution; climate change; and the rapid loss of green space and biodiversity. As they grow, they must therefore become more resource efficient, and protect the environment (including air and water quality) from the negative impacts of urbanization. Overstretched infrastructure plagues many cities, and authorities should implement policies that optimize the use of fresh water, electricity, and fuel. World Bank statistics have shown that electricity loss during transmission is about 5% for developed countries, while in less developed countries, such as Myanmar, that figure reaches as high as 20%; investment in overhauling power grids is therefore urgently needed. In addition, the World Resources Institute has estimated that the number of people living in water-scarce regions will grow from 1 billion presently to 3.5 billion by 2025. Urbanization is also connected to the degradation and loss of forests, grassland, and marine areas (it is estimated that 90% of the wastewater in developing countries is discharged directly into bodies of water). These ecosystems, both within cities (such as urban parks), and near cities (such as watersheds), are vital for sustaining urban areas, as they can improve air quality, provide for recreation, and moderate the effects of flooding and drought. Cities should better integrate both natural and constructed environments in order to form urban ecosystems, supported by related resource-planning and infrastructure policies. There are serious challenges in retrofitting existing cities to meet these goals; as a result, there have been radical attempts to build resource-efficient, green cities from scratch. One example is the proposed New Clark City, which is being constructed about 100 kilometres north of Manila. Two- thirds of this planned urban area would be reserved for parks, farmland, and other green space, and all of its buildings would make use of the latest technology to reduce energy and water use. Other, similar projects include Songdo, a smart city that features waste disposal via pneumatic tube in South Korea (though criticisms of that city’s vibrancy have surfaced), and Dholera, a utopian experiment in India.

name: Urban Governance
description: The concept of what makes for good urban governance is often shaped by the broader economic and political context: in the 1990s, the privatization of public resources like electricity and water occurred regularly, as policy-makers adopted the prevailing economic orthodoxy of an era when it was believed to be more effective to have private entities take over some of the management of cities; meanwhile in some countries a shift towards the decentralization of urban governance has been influenced by prevailing political ideology (most notably in Southeast Asia, where many economies once relied heavily on the centralized governance of urban areas). Urban governance, or the day-to-day management of keeping cities running and planning for their future development, can involve multiple entities. The government, the local business sector, non-governmental organizations, and urban inhabitants themselves can all play a role. Good urban governance, often driven by visionary and dynamic mayors, is an important part of solving urban problems such as poverty, congestion, and environmental pollution. According to the United Nations Human Settlements Program, or UN-Habitat, good urban governance means improving the overall quality of life in cities, particularly among the marginalized. UN-Habitat’s Urban Governance Index is designed to help cities monitor and improve their governance, in terms of transparency, accountability, and inclusivity. Increasingly, a mark of good urban governance is cities’ ability to raise capital; that, in combination with good governance and active civic engagement, can overcome serious challenges. One example of this is Seoul, the 2018 winner of the Lee Kuan Yew World City Prize (a biennial award conferred at the World Cities Summit). In particular, Seoul was recognized for bottom-up processes that had been incorporated into the daily running of the city under its Community Governance Project, an initiative that gives residents a say over local issues that directly affect their communities. Seoul residents are actually given control of 5% of the city’s budget, under the so-called Public Participatory Budget System. Through measures like this, the city has been able to build greater trust with its citizens, and convince them that engagement is not a token act but rather a necessary part of making Seoul a better place for everyone.

name: Urban Infrastructure and Services
description: An estimated more than 700 million urban residents have no access to piped water, and more than one quarter of the world’s urban population continues to live in informal, haphazard settlements that lack the most basic infrastructure and services. Asia alone is projected to require $1.7 trillion per year in infrastructure investment until 2030, in order to address both new and legacy infrastructure needs. Cities require a broad range of basic infrastructure and services in order to be viable: the provision of piped water; sanitation systems; a power grid; roads; a public transportation system; housing; hospitals; and schools. Particularly in developing countries, cities face considerable challenges in providing and maintaining these infrastructure and services. Accelerating infrastructure development is essential for economic growth, as it can create jobs, alleviate poverty, and improve urban liveability and sustainability. Establishing robust infrastructure and services is also necessary to boost resilience, in the face of challenges like climate change and rising sea levels. Currently, the capacity of urban infrastructure is often overwhelmed by the cascading effects of rapid urbanization, sprawl, and demographic shifts. Weak urban governance and capital constraints can exacerbate these issues. As a result, some cities, from Australia and China, and from Europe to North America, have begun to rethink what is possible for the future of urban areas. New conceptions of sustainable urban forms include so-called compact cities, where high residential density and efficient public transportation are emphasized, and eco-cities specifically designed to curb carbon emissions. Some places have been able to harness technology and the non-governmental sector to address their issues. The Australian social enterprise Pollinate Energy, for example, has offered solar-powered products including water filters and clean cookstoves in Indian slums; six years after its founding, Pollinate Energy had provided tens of thousands of products to more than 20,000 families. Meanwhile the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank has financed dozens of infrastructure projects collectively worth about $4 billion in developing countries since it was established in 2016. These include a public train line in Bangalore, slum upgrades in Indonesia, and a broadband infrastructure project in Oman. China is actively pushing its Belt and Road Initiative, which will fund large infrastructure projects throughout cities on a massive scale, such as highways, ports, and IT systems, in order to strengthen ties with other countries in Asia and further afield.

name: Urban Innovation
description: The European Commission has launched a Digital Cities Challenge, China's Xiongan New Area aspires to transform a barren landscape into a digital city powered by blockchain and artificial intelligence, Global Digital Seoul 2020 is focused on developing e-government in South Korea’s capital, and India boasts a Smart City Mission; cities must seek to innovate in order to become more sustainable, advance social well-being, and boost economic competitiveness. The technologies fuelling the Fourth Industrial Revolution can multiply innovation, though potential perils have also multiplied. Technologies can be misused to disrupt economies and splinter societies; jobs can be eliminated; and socio-economic differences can be amplified. To help manage this risk, cities are experimenting with regulatory sandboxes, participatory design, innovation systems, and public-private partnerships. Ultimately, cities must reckon with a potential clash between economic value and societal values. With ride-sharing, for example, supply and demand can be better predicted and matched; but regulatory dust-ups and protests, from Montreal to Montevideo and Melbourne, demonstrate how societal values can be at odds with simple economic value. Cities, and companies, are increasingly sensitive to this potential clash. DeepMind, the artificial intelligence company acquired by Google, formed an Ethics and Society unit in 2017, to help insert ethics in the work of scientists in the field of AI. Singapore has meanwhile announced an Advisory Council on the Ethical Use of AI and Data, and Japan's "Society 5.0" envisions a “human-centric” society transformed by the Fourth Industrial Revolution. While cities innovate in order to compete with one other, they innovate better when they connect and cooperate in an organized way. Taiwan, for example, has designated different cities for different specific test-beds, in order to maximize experimentation and learning. The European Union's Sharing Cities program is testing smart lampposts in several cities, and aims to eventually scatter them across the continent. The ASEAN Smart Cities Network has 26 Southeast Asian cities partnering with companies in order to improve sustainability and competitiveness, and to learn from each other. The most successful cities will not be those that solely focus on innovation at the expense of other needs; they will be those that manage to recognize and adapt to specific local challenges, while pushing innovation forward.

name: Urban Migration
description: China’s economic growth in recent decades has lifted about 700 million people out of poverty, according to government figures. During this period, China also witnessed the largest migration ever from rural to urban areas. About 59% of China’s population lived in a city as of 2018, according to estimates, and the country’s urban population is increasing at a rate of 2.4% annually (compared with 2.4% in India, and less than 1% in the US). This migration trend has created so-called megacities that have populations in the tens of millions, and significant challenges in terms of environmentally sustainable, socially inclusive growth. Migration into cities has led to heightened demand for health insurance, pensions, schools, and housing, as more Chinese leave traditional, family-based support systems. Increasingly congested cities need better urban and transport planning, and more jobs will have to be created, mainly in service sectors, in order to absorb migrants. The Chinese Government has embarked on regional economic planning projects such as the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region, the Yangtze River Economic Belt, and the Pearl River Delta Economic Zone, in order to pool resources and ensure policy coordination on infrastructure and urban planning. Taxi sharing is a good way to cut down on urban congestion and pollution, and it is becoming more prevalent in China due to digital ride-sharing services. According to a 2016 World Economic Forum report, Didi Chuxing passengers were already sharing an average of about 1.1 million rides per day by 2015. Bicycle sharing services are also a major focus; startups like Mobike and Ofo have been founded on the idea that bicycles can provide a cheap, easy, and environmentally friendly way to navigate China’s urban areas, facilitated by smartphone use. From 2005 to 2015, China's high-speed railway development came to account for 60% of the world’s high speed rail capacity, according to a government report. By 2020, China is expected to invest a further RMB 3.5 trillion in an additional 11,000 kilometres of capacity, connecting 250 cities with a total population of 700 million, according to research published by Morgan Stanley. The key to sustainable urbanization in China will be the ability of local and municipal governments to strike the right balance between growth that is visible in financial statistics, and sustainable growth that focuses on improving the quality of life.

name: Urban Resilience
description: The tsunami-triggered Fukushima nuclear plant meltdown, in 2011, forced the Japanese government to address systemic regulatory shortcomings and technological inadequacies in the country’s nuclear sector. While urban areas can become stronger in the aftermath of a catastrophe, it is a less-than-ideal way to bolster resilience. Urban resilience is a measure of how well communities, businesses, and government agencies can withstand both temporary shocks and chronic stress; increasingly, it is an essential goal for urban planners everywhere. The Rockefeller Foundation-funded City Resilience Index provides dozens of indicators that cities can use to measure their resilience, including safe and affordable housing and effective sanitation, and it has been tested in cities including Hong Kong and Liverpool. Meanwhile the World Bank Group’s City Resilience Program is designed to foster investment in viable projects that can enhance resilience. In practice and in theory, urban resilience must go beyond merely managing urban challenges like chronic under-employment, transportation system failures, housing shortages, and social strife by merely reacting to them. Instead, it should focus on proactively anticipating and preparing for potential risks. Still, it is often only following catastrophe that city governments will seriously implement system-wide changes. The distinction between the temporary shocks and chronic, long-term stress that affect urban areas is sometimes unclear. Social upheaval that seems to have been triggered unexpectedly, for example, is often underpinned by longstanding underlying tension. Indonesian riots in 1998, for example, were triggered by multiple systemic and sustained problems in urban centres such as widespread unemployment, food shortages, an escalating cost of living, and an increasingly bifurcated society along class and ethnic lines. Building urban resilience is a difficult, continuous process that requires good governance and significant capital investment. In many cities, resilience is hindered by geography; Jakarta is increasingly vulnerable to floods, as 40% of its land area is below sea level and generally over-developed. Other threats to resilience include viral epidemics (such as the severe acute respiratory syndrome in the early 2000s that killed hundreds of people in Asia) as well as natural hazards exacerbated by poor infrastructure and services (such as Hurricane Katrina in the US in 2005, which claimed thousands of lives). As urban societies become more digitalized and networked, cybersecurity lapses can also compromise resilience; in 2016, Uber admitted that 57 million of its users in the United Kingdom had been affected by a data breach.

name: Urban Society
description: In 2018, the United Nations Department of Social and Economic Affairs reported that 55% of the world’s population was living in urban areas, and estimated that the figure will reach 68% by 2050. This relentless rural-to-urban shift will add 2.5 billion people to cities, coming in search of a better life, new opportunities, and excitement. As a result, cities will face massive challenges, like insufficient decent and cheap housing, expanding waste management needs, growing demand for access to clean water and employment, and worsening traffic congestion. Technology can help, as policy-makers seek to manage diverse populations infused by migrants representing different ethnicities, cultures, and religions, and cope with the needs of ageing populations as they attempt to address inequality. Singapore, for example, is a mosaic of multi-racial and multi-religious communities, carefully managed through the city state’s policies designed to encourage inclusivity - such as the allocation of public housing done in a way that avoids ghettoization, and education and public service programs that foster integration. While the population diversity that must be addressed in developed countries like Singapore is largely attributable to international migration, in developing nations it is mostly a result of internal migration. Internal migration remains a significant feature of East Asian countries in particular, according to the International Organization for Migration’s World Migration Report 2018. Indonesia alone has an estimated 9.8 million temporary internal migrants, according to a UN report, while Malaysia is a heavily urbanized country (at 75% of the population) where internal migration constituted nearly 89% of all migration, and about 40% of Beijing’s population are migrants. Addressing diversity also means not leaving people aged 60 and over behind, as this demographic is expected to double in size by 2050 globally. In Japan, where 27% of the population is aged over 65 (according to the UN), the government has made radical changes to healthcare delivery; long-term health care insurance was introduced there in 2000, to supplement the national pension plan. Japan is also a leader in using robotics to assist the elderly. Another challenge: cities must deal with the inequality between those plugged into globalization and those left behind, particularly in high-tech hubs where growing wealth has left the middle class unable to buy homes, as is the case in San Francisco.

name: Urbanization and Circular Practices
description: The global urban population has grown rapidly; more people now live in urban rather than rural areas, and a report published by the United Nations has projected that an additional 2.5 billion people will be living in urban settings by 2050. This increased urbanization brings many challenges, but also many potential benefits - particularly in terms of the broad shift towards a circular economy (that is, an economy that is based on reusing materials for production, in order to reduce waste and benefit the environment). For example, urbanization enables the more efficient deployment of integrated systems for recovering materials after they are used, such as household food waste. The Belgian startup Cirkle delivers seasonal produce directly to customers’ homes, then takes back waste including recyclables and used cooking oil - which is later used to produce biodiesel. Circle Economy, an Amsterdam-based non-profit, provides a Circle Cities Programme, to help cities transition to a circular economy by tapping related knowledge at universities and research organizations which is then put into practice by member companies. The non-profit notes that two-thirds of global energy is used in cities, as are 70% of all global resources. Cities play a central role in the global economy (Circle Economy also estimates that 80% of global GDP is generated in cities), and present intriguing opportunities for the implementation of circular principles. The centralization and concentration of demand within an urban area can enable more efficient and cost-effective logistics, for example; that is because high population density can facilitate increased collection frequency, and shorter travel distances. So-called reverse logistics in particular, which involves the collection of used products in order to reuse or dispose of them, could better thrive in an urban setting, according to a whitepaper published in 2018 by the World Economic Forum in collaboration with the consultancy PwC. The ability to better centralize the collection of used items like clothing and household goods in a city could provide a boost to such practices, according to the whitepaper, and related models should be relatively inexpensive to test. The same principle can be applied to medical waste; according to the whitepaper, a voluntary group in Coimbatore, India has used a collection box where people can drop off their unused or unopened medicines for later redistribution to people in need at facilities for the elderly.

name: Urbanization and Climate Change
description: The urban population in the Middle East and North Africa region grew four-fold between 1970 and 2010, and is expected to double in size between 2015 and 2050 to nearly 400 million people, according to a report published by the International Organization for Migration. As of 2017, nearly 65% of the entire population in the region lived in cities, compared with a global figure of 55%, according to data published by the World Bank; the figure reached 91% in Jordan, and 86% in the United Arab Emirates. This urban concentration is expected to become more intense as climate change continues to have a devastating impact on rural economies, pushing more people into cities in order to seek out new ways to earn a living. According to a report published by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, by 2025 the southern Mediterranean region will experience a significant rise in average temperature compared with 2007, which will increase aridity, lower soil humidity, and shift seasonal rainfall patterns. These changes have already been the cause of migration from the countryside into cities in Syria, Yemen, and Egypt, where the Nile River is the lifeline of an otherwise arid country. According to an IPCC report published in 2018, a rise in sea level of as much as 77 centimetres is expected by the year 2100, if we can limit global warming to 1.5°C - at a 2°C rise, the rise would be 10 centimetres higher. While 10 centimetres may not seem like much, it would mean exposing up to 10 million more people to related risks, according to the report. In the MENA region, this would spur greater refugee flows into cities, and place an even greater strain on urban infrastructure. High levels of rural-to-urban migration also upend traditional family and community protection mechanisms, replacing them with public benefits, and contribute to social instability - as migrants disconnected from family and patronage networks may be more easily influenced. However, increasing urbanization may also offer opportunities; urban areas in the MENA region could attract greater amounts of talent, investment, and startup activity. That could in turn help cities address issues like limited fresh water availability with desalination, for example, by applying entrepreneurial ideas and technology innovation.

name: Urbanization, Migration and Real Estate
description: A relentless quest for better job opportunities, higher wages and a better quality of life is fuelling increased migration into cities. The United Nations has predicted that the proportion of the global population living in urban areas will grow to 68% by 2050, from 55% as of 2018; that would add another 2.5 billion people to cities, with most of that population growth occurring in Asia and Africa. This will have an inevitable impact on the ways that urban real estate is designed, developed, and sold. For example, as growing urban populations age, developers must consider how best to accommodate them with appropriate designs, and competition for prime assets in key markets will likely increase - which will in turn push investors towards higher levels of risk (and returns) in fast-growing cities, according to a report published by the consultancy EY in 2016. Governments around the world are grappling with the substantial economic, environmental and health effects that urbanization is having on communities. Left unaddressed, the effects that these migratory patterns will have on urban centres will lead to an increase in the cost of housing, elevated social tension, and growing obstacles to building a sense of community. The existing socioeconomic fabric of many cities could disintegrate, and the liveability of urban centres may be compromised. However, urban planners can find sustainable solutions. The real estate sector can play a positive role, by making intelligent use of common spaces, for example, and catering to a broad range of activities and housing requirements in a bid to help alleviate tension and limit price increases. And, the deployment of environmentally-friendly infrastructure (that also facilitates social mobility) can play a significant role in improving the quality of densely-populated urban centres.

name: Using Space to Increase Access
description: About half of the global population is still not using the internet, according to the International Telecommunications Union. Even in countries with relatively high rates of broadband internet penetration, there are often issues with traffic congestion - which will likely only get worse in the future as the global appetite for content like video increases. Satellites are in a position to address this. They can be used alongside Wi-Fi, for example, to deliver high-quality, media-rich content to users while easing congestion. However, the cost of developing the space-based infrastructure required for universal internet coverage would be prohibitive. A number of ways to address this have been proposed by private companies. OneWeb, for example, is a startup planning to put more than 600 satellites in low Earth orbit (at an altitude of about 2,000 kilometres or less), in order to provide global coverage potentially before the end of 2019. Meanwhile Elon Musk’s company SpaceX has requested permission to launch a constellation of 4,000 satellites and up to 1 million earth stations to bolster global internet coverage. The impact of such systems may be profound, with implications for services including distance learning for students unable to physically attend school. The greater availability and resolution of satellite images is enabling new ways to deal with global challenges like climate change.
