Policy changes have helped; the US government’s decision to make Landsat satellite images and other data freely available to the public for scientific and educational use generated estimated benefits of $1.8 billion a year for US-based users, according to the World Bank’s World Development Report on Digital Dividends published in 2016. When made widely available, such data can bolster efforts like the Brazilian government’s monitoring of forest conservation compliance, or efforts to create development assistance mechanisms such as the GiveDirectly project in Kenya and Uganda (which uses machine learning to identify extremely poor villages in satellite images and deliver cash transfers to residents). Public and private entities must strike the right balance between commercial freedom and security, in order to achieve greater cooperation on programs that can expand access to communications networks. Governments everywhere should pay more attention to space as a means to improve connectivity, and the private sector should embrace related discussions. By connecting people everywhere to broadband internet, and better monitoring global change through satellite technology, we can seek to ensure that nobody gets left behind.

name: Value Chain Efficiency
description: Food pricing and supply are increasingly volatile as a result of more frequent extreme weather events, trade restrictions, and commodity market fluctuation. Meanwhile rural, smallholder farmers in developing countries often lack timely information on market prices, agricultural techniques, and weather, and have limited access to traditional financial services - making it relatively difficult for them to adjust production, or expand operations by investing in infrastructure. Smallholder financing opportunities are currently limited; social impact investors have so far met only a small portion of related demand. However, a market estimated to be as large as $450 billion could be tapped if financial services were sufficiently extended to smallholders. New financing structures, like so-called blended finance (where public and private investors carry a tailored amount of risk) could help create a more abundant supply of credit. Investing greater amounts in smallholder agriculture could not only boost productivity and income, it could also help develop local markets and encourage the sustainable management of resources. However, capitalizing on these opportunities requires a supportive regulatory environment. Multinational companies are increasingly relying on smallholder “value chains” (the entire process of adding value to a product) in order to satisfy growing global food demand. Many are supplying technical assistance to support productivity, and creating more awareness of the environmental and social dimensions of food loss and waste. Experts have distinguished between food loss, which results from inadequate technology and poor infrastructure along a value chain, and food waste - which is linked to consumer awareness and behaviour. A Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations report published in 2013 found that roughly one third of food produced for consumption is lost or wasted along the value chain - or 1.3 billion tons of food. The report found significant variations of food loss and waste across regions; more than half in Europe, North America and Oceania occurs at the consumption stage, while in developing countries it takes place during production, handling, and storage (in North America and Oceania, for example, 42% of total food available is lost or wasted, and 61% of this occurs at the consumption stage). It has been estimated that halving the current rate of food loss and waste could close the global “food gap” separating the dietary access of the rich and poor by about 20%, by the year 2050.

name: Value-Based Healthcare
description: The $8 trillion global healthcare sector is beset by costs that are rising at about twice the rate of global GDP growth, and by reimbursement mechanisms that are resulting in substantial waste and underinvestment, according to Value in Health Care, a report published in 2018 by the World Economic Forum in collaboration with The Boston Consulting Group. In response, many industry leaders are embracing so-called value-based healthcare, which prioritizes improved health outcomes without increasing cost, and utilizes systematic measurement to customize intervention and treatment pathways (efforts for a patient based on defined resources). One particular related effort cited in the report is the Atlanta Heart Failure Pilot in the US, which focused on congestive heart failure (a condition that affects about 6 million people in the country, half of whom die within five years of initial diagnosis). Total costs associated with the disease are expected to rise to nearly $70 billion by 2030, from $30.7 billion in 2012 - and there has been significant variation in related outcomes. Lessons from the Atlanta pilot included the need to build a clear case for change, and to enlist strong and visible public-sector leadership. In many parts of the world, ageing populations have added pressure on healthcare systems. In response, efforts to better realize value for this expanding population of patients are underway. According to a report published by the consultancy BDO in 2018, new business models and new types of investment will be needed for value-based elderly care, which facilitate a focus on prevention and rehabilitation - while boosting innovation. Increasingly, hospital stays for the elderly are being replaced by increased outpatient care and recovery either at home or in a nursing home. In the meantime, efforts must be made to develop the professional workforce needed to accommodate ageing populations and their health needs. According to a discussion paper published in 2016 as part of the National Academy of Medicine’s Vital Directions for Health and Health Care Initiative, the number of board-certified geriatricians in the US at the time was estimated at 7,500, or less than half of what was needed - due to factors including a financial disadvantage related to working in fee-for-service systems, where geriatricians must provide more time-intensive care for patients who are on Medicare (a national health insurance program) or both Medicare and Medicaid (a program for those with limited income).

name: Valuing Water
description: The World Economic Forum has consistently ranked water crises among the most prominent issues listed in its annual Global Risks Report (it was ranked fifth in terms of impact in the 2018 edition). Global economic growth is increasingly thirsty; demand for water is rising, in order to meet the needs of growing populations and expanding industries. Unfortunately, however, water is often managed in isolation, and water-intensive sectors such as energy, mining, agriculture, and manufacturing have a tendency to pursue individual plans that are potentially damaging to rivers and aquifers. This fragmentation in planning exacerbates risks for businesses and their investors. CDP, a non-profit research organization that serves institutional investors, and the CEO Water Mandate (an initiative formed by business leaders under United Nations auspices), have consistently found that most companies believe they may be affected by substantial change related to water risk. As a result, more companies in water-intensive sectors are working to improve their understanding of water management challenges, and evaluating their own vulnerability to water scarcity. Some regions of the world could see their economic growth rates decline by as much as 6% of GDP by the year 2050, as a result of water-related losses in agriculture, health, income and property, according to a report published by the World Bank in 2016. However, the report also noted that some regions could see economic growth accelerate by as much as 6% over the same period, thanks to improved water resource management. Advocates of the “circular” economy approach, according to which products are reused rather than discarded, have emphasized economic values that could help reduce the wasteful use of water in production and agriculture. A report published by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation in 2018 presented circular economy-related opportunities for water including capturing greywater (waste water that does not contain sewage) for non-potable use. Water is a cross-cutting issue that affects all sectors of the global economy, and must be managed in a more integrated and holistic way. Increased transparency and community engagement will be important for determining values for water that reflect all social, economic, and environmental interests. If particularly water-intensive sectors can improve the way they work together in order to manage and value this resource, water pricing, trading, and allocation can become more efficient.

name: Viet Nam's Rising Middle Class
description: Viet Nam’s middle class is expected grow to 44 million people (equivalent to nearly half of the current population) by 2020, from 8 million people as of 2012, according to market research firm Nielsen. The expanding middle class is symptomatic of a general increase in prosperity in the country, where GDP per capita reached $2,186 by 2016, thirty years after Viet Nam began opening up its centralized economy as part of the so-called “Doi Moi” reforms, according to the consultancy PwC. Another insight from a PwC report: the population of ultra-high net worth individuals in Viet Nam rose 320% between 2000 and 2016, a faster growth rate than was experienced over the same period in both China and India. As more people in the country join the middle class and attain wealth, it will have profound impacts on consumption levels and the social fabric. As traditional social models are re-shaped due to greater economic mobility, educated, middle-class women, for example, may now find it more difficult to meet a suitable marriage partner, according to Vietnam’s New Middle Classes, a report published by the Nordic Institute of Asian Studies - due to being better schooled and better paid than many men. ﻿Household spending has become an important driver of economic growth in Viet Nam, and has helped to rebalance the economy away from a reliance on exports and towards greater domestic demand. That has provided a potential cushion for periods of global economic slowdown, or for future global financial crises. The growing presence of the middle class in Vietnam is also putting added pressure on existing social structures, by making society more open and prompting calls for greater accountability in the political system. It may also spur demands for greater political freedom. Viet Nam should nurture its middle class, by working to improve health and education systems, upgrading infrastructure, closing the income gap, and creating more educational opportunities. In the meantime the country must also improve its social safety net in order to both protect the most vulnerable, and to help create a healthy balance between the rise of the middle class and broader economic growth.

name: Viet Nam's Startup Economy
description: Aspiring young Vietnamese entrepreneurs were encouraged by the success of Nguyen Ha Dong, a developer from Hanoi who scored a global hit with his mobile game “Flappy Bird” after it was released in 2013. While the Vietnamese government is committed to the idea of supporting the startup community that has sprouted in the country, more supportive infrastructure and policies need to be developed. The word “startup” is heard much more now from the Vietnamese government, in its communication with ministries, with the public, and with other governments. Ministries, for example, have been asked to eliminate licensing or permitting processes that might create unnecessary barriers for aspiring startups. However, the government, and Vietnamese businesses, must be prepared to foster startups in the context of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, which is creating unsettling amounts of change in terms of technology innovation and related social development and employment trends. In 2017, Viet Nam adopted a law on supporting small- and medium-sized enterprises, which lays out principles for facilitating startups and entrepreneurs more generally. Viet Nam’s higher education system, which could serve as an incubator for technology and business innovation, is not currently conducive to a healthy startup environment. The country moved to 84th out of 137 economies in terms of higher education and training in the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index 2017-2018, from 83rd out of 138 economies in the previous year’s assessment. Viet Nam ranked 112th out of 137 countries in the latest Competitiveness Index in terms of availability of latest technologies, and 93rd in terms of firm-level technology absorption. Reforming the country’s overall education system, and higher education in particular, should be a top priority. However, there are some encouraging signs for Viet Nam’s development trajectory. The Forum’s Inclusive Development Index, introduced in 2017, benchmarks countries with indicators related to inclusion (such as poverty rate), growth and development (such as healthy life expectancy), and intergenerational equity and sustainability (such as carbon intensity of GDP). Viet Nam ranked among those countries that scored better on this index than peers with higher levels of GDP per capita - indicating that it has done a relatively good job of making its overall growth process inclusive.

name: Violence and Instability
description: Rising levels of criminal activity in some countries and within certain political systems have given rise to armed violence, destabilized governments, and fuelled armed terrorist groups. According to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime’s Global Study on Homicide published in 2018, organized crime is a leading cause of homicidal violence in some countries in the Americas - which has the highest homicide rate of any region in the world. In Mexico, for example, there were 33,341 murders in 2018, a 7% increase compared with the prior year that was partly a result of the fragmentation of large cartels and the government’s inability to react to smaller gangs killing for greater control of territory, according to the foundation InSight Crime. Conflict and insecurity are major barriers to development; a World Bank World Development Report published in 2011 noted that countries that had experienced relatively high levels of violence between 1980 and 2000 also suffered from an average poverty rate that was 21% higher than in countries with low levels of violence during the same period. Rapid urbanization and glaring income inequality (particularly in the southern hemisphere) have fostered slums beset by crime, violence, and a general lack of security. Cape Town is a prime example. Nyanga, a Cape Town slum, had the highest murder rate in the country as of 2018, according to the South African Government News Agency; the 308 murders reported there during the year ended in March 2018 marked a 9.6% increase compared with the prior period. Stark inequality and a lack of both educational opportunity and jobs have bred a sense of frustration and rage in Nyanga, according to a researcher at the University of Cape Town cited in a 2018 Bloomberg News report. In failed and failing states, fights over access to natural resources like minerals and oil has exacerbated conflict. Meanwhile in conflict zones in the Sahel region and Libya, illicit trafficking in drugs and the smuggling of migrants have served as a means to fund insurgencies. The failure of internationally-sponsored peace and transition processes to address illicit flows and provide a clear distinction between criminal activity and groups that have legitimate grievances, or to protect state institutions from the corrupting influence of the illicit economy, are recognized reasons for the resurgence of conflict and state failure.

name: Volatile Business Cycles and Development
description: Turkish business cycles are more volatile than those in emerging market counterparts, which is a result of both monetary and fiscal policies that have proven ineffective in terms of stabilizing the economy. One continuous, nagging problem is a current account deficit that limits the Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey’s ability to raise interest rates - an inability that can threaten financial stability. The current account deficit partly reflects a production structure in Turkey that relies heavily on imports of intermediate goods, or goods ultimately combined to make finished products. Greater support for the country’s most competitive sectors might reduce this reliance (the central bank’s inability to raise interest rates also further feeds the current account deficit, because unchecked inflation discourages the saving of money and encourages external borrowing). Yet another trigger for relatively volatile business cycles is the frequency of political elections - which are inevitably accompanied by expansionary fiscal policies (lowered taxes, increased public spending) that boost demand to unsustainable levels and lead to sharp, subsequent slowdowns. After Turkey’s 2001 financial crisis, labour productivity increased annually by about 3.2% on average between 2002 and 2009. There was a reallocation of resources from the capital-scarce, low-productivity agricultural sector to higher-productivity sectors such as services, though overall annual productivity growth then slipped to 2.7% in the period after 2009 - as structural reforms were postponed. One consequence of the slowdown in productivity is a reliance on cheaper imports; when domestic productivity growth falls behind that of international counterparts, it becomes cheaper to import from abroad than to produce at home. Other shifts have included an urban renewal process over the past decade that spurred a transfer from industrial production to the construction sector, and led to a significant industrial sector decline. Turkey’s most recent urban development process differs from previous related efforts, by stretching beyond land already in use and penetrating ecologically-sensitive sites such as forests, beaches, drinking-water basins, and historical and agricultural areas - regardless of inevitable controversies.

name: Water Data and Technology
description: The speed and scale of technological advancements propelling the Fourth Industrial Revolution are transforming the global economy at a time when concerns about water have never been greater. This industrial revolution offers an unprecedented opportunity to confront water risk, and seize untapped economic opportunities in both developing and developed countries alike. Developments such as the Internet of Things, big data, artificial intelligence, sensors, advancements in material sciences, and faster computing power are changing the way the world manages its global environmental commons. For example, improvements in aeroponics, a technique of growing plants that does not require soil, has made it possible to reduce water consumption by 95% compared with conventional, soil-based agriculture, while meanwhile preventing environmental runoff (which can carry pollutants and contaminate drinking water). Similarly, advancements in laboratory-grown meat have the potential to eliminate the need for the more than 15,000 litres of water that it takes to produce a single kilogram of beef, according to a report published by the Institution of Mechanical Engineers in 2013. Emerging technologies can also help urban centres to become more resilient when it comes to their water systems. Singapore, for example, announced in 2018 that in order to help its water service cope with increasing demand and costs, the city-state is turning to technology such as artificial intelligence-powered imaging used to detect micro-invertebrates in water samples and trigger related alerts. Other examples of technology and data-driven infrastructure design employed to make water more sustainable include efforts in parts of the United Kingdom to use advanced sensors and connected Internet of Things devices to help identify leaks in water systems - which account for nearly 20% of water loss - and make them easier to repair. If they are implemented on a broader scale, such advancements could dramatically reduce global water demand, both for agriculture and for domestic use, while also helping to reduce related greenhouse gas emissions. Developments in data processing and collection, driven by artificial intelligence, can for example enable consumers, businesses, and governments to better understand their water needs - and eliminate unnecessary use in a way that contributes to more sustainable development.

name: Water Infrastructure
description: Water infrastructure can take many different forms, but it is the essential backbone of a modern economy. Drinking water distribution pipes, treatment plants, sewage reclamation, levees and dams built for flood protection, and canals that irrigate millions of hectares of farmland are all critical for economic growth and human well-being. Beneath the streets of any large city, are thousands of kilometres of water mains. Many of these systems are in need of renewal, in order to ensure water security. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has argued that because global interest rates are historically low, and needs are historically significant, now is an ideal time to scale up investment in water infrastructure - in order to secure well-documented benefits of clean, reliable water including  fewer child deaths from diarrhoeal disease (the second-leading cause of death among children under five years old, according to the World Health Organization), and increased labour productivity. However, current investment levels are insufficient to meet the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals related to drinking water and sanitation established in 2015 - let alone to repair aging municipal water systems in developed countries, expand existing systems to accommodate urban growth, meet stricter water-quality regulations, or adequately prepare for the effects of climate change. Opportunities to improve existing systems abound; it is not uncommon, for example, for large cities in India to lose half their water supply to leaks. According to an estimate published by the McKinsey Global Institute, $11.7 trillion must be invested in related global infrastructure between 2013 and 2030 in order to meet water and sanitation needs. Infrastructure is not only pipes, pumps, and treatment facilities - more decision-makers are recognizing the benefit of using natural systems to slow storm flows, store water, and cleanse runoff. As a complement to traditional, “hard” infrastructure, such green infrastructure options include street swales (vegetated channels used to reduce stormwater flows), wetlands, rainwater harvesting, and grassy roofs. All are small-scale alternatives that are less environmentally damaging than what has been used in the past. Green bonds, or debt raised specifically for environmental purposes, could be used to finance related investment; total issuance of green bonds reached $155 billion in 2017, a 78% increase compared with the prior year, according to a report published by the non-profit group Climate Bonds Initiative.

name: Wellness and Environmental Sustainability
description: There has been a growing sense of urgency about the real estate sector's ability to ensure that communities can be built in such a way that meets expectations for sustainability. Opportunities for these communities to thrive depend in particular on efforts to combat the adverse effects of climate change. The use of green technologies, energy-efficient ways of transporting people and goods, and the construction of energy-efficient homes can form an integrated approach to a healthier urban environment. Some examples of environmentally-responsible design elements include using sustainable, locally-sourced materials, installing rooftop solar panels, and using geothermal heating and cooling. Human-centred real estate design that not only provides comfort but also increases the quality of life for the broader community by improving healthcare delivery, increasing community engagement, and enhancing work environments can ultimately improve productivity. The real estate sector can therefore play a fundamental role in boosting economic competitiveness, by engaging with communities and taking into account the wellness of individuals in order to provide a more sustainable living environment, and by focusing on integrating new and potentially helpful technologies like the Internet of Things - which strings together homes, offices, devices and appliances via the web.

name: Workforce Digitalization
description: The insurance industry was long highly profitable, relatively immune to threats to its traditional business model (underwriting risk, collecting premiums, and paying claims), and the generator of relatively labour-intensive tasks. The result was a sizeable global workforce. In the US alone, the industry still employed more than 2.5 million people as of 2016, and in Switzerland, a country with a total population of roughly 8.5 million, the industry accounted for nearly 50,000 employees that same year. However, declining profit margins, low-yielding assets, and changing customer needs are forcing the industry to embrace technological change and cut costs - not least as both large technology companies and so-called “insuretech” startups provide growing competition. For insurance industry employees, many tasks will increasingly make use of technology developments like artificial intelligence and machine learning; employees will therefore have to become more focused on high-performance, high-skill, high-capacity jobs, according to a report published in 2017 by the consultancy EY. Particular new skills required of insurance industry employees include data analysis, a firm grasp of the behavioural sciences, and familiarity with technology facets like the Internet of Things. In addition, the distribution of insurance products will likely be transformed, as the industry becomes more dis-intermediated and brokers and agents find themselves in unfamiliar territory. A survey of 530 insurance agents conducted by EY in 2016 found that 40% questioned their preparedness to meet the needs of the next generation, and only about one in five felt they understood well how they fit into their carrier’s strategy. For agents generally, there will likely be a shift towards becoming more of a service provider to insurers, by managing claims and even performing underwriting. Overall, however, it will be difficult to re-train a workforce unaccustomed to significant industry disruption. Timing will be critical, and decisions on how best to hire and re-train will need to be taken sooner rather than later. In some countries, labour laws may hinder a timely transition. There will also be more intangible related issues to address, as the insurance industry has a reputation for being stodgy, bureaucratic, hierarchical, and slow moving, according to the EY report published in 2017.

name: Workforce Skills
description: Ethiopia’s performance in this area of the Index shows the greatest room for improvement in terms of the pupil-teacher ratio in primary education, where it has a progress score (ranging from a poor mark of zero to a top mark of one hundred) of 0.00, resulting in a rank of 135th out of 138 countries; and in terms of the number of years of completed education among the adult population where it has a progress score of 19.30 that results in a rank of 132nd out of 140 countries. Other indicators reflect a better performance: the ease of finding skilled employees, where it has a progress score of 44.80 that results in a rank of 102nd out of 140 countries; in terms of the quality of vocational training where it has a progress score of 45.40 that results in a rank of 94th out of 140 countries; and in terms of expected years of schooling for children where it has a progress score of 46.80 that results in a rank of 136th out of 140 countries.

name: Workforce and Skills
description: Given that between 50% and 80% of jobs worldwide are created by family businesses, according to an estimate published by the European Family Businesses federation, it is crucial that family businesses foster a workforce that can thrive indefinitely, by actively skilling (training employees), reskilling (teaching them new skills), and upskilling (improving employees’ existing skills). In order to do so, businesses must first gain a solid understanding of the underlying trends transforming the nature of work. Technological innovation, particularly associated with robotics and artificial intelligence, have machines replacing medium-skilled workers in sectors including banking and retail. In other cases, machines are augmenting the work of humans at professional firms and in medical roles, through the rapid analysis of large data sets. Within the next ten years, the impact of machines will increase dramatically, particularly in lower-skilled work such as food preparation; around 30% of the global workforce will be significantly impacted. Demographic changes are also affecting the workforce. As longevity increases, people will be working into their 80s, while in many regions birth rates have fallen - resulting in an ageing global population (in developed countries, the average age of populations is poised to surpass 40). Family businesses need to anticipate the skills and traits that will become crucial for their operation, and support their development. These include a capacity to be innovative and creative; deep social skills and empathy; and, negotiation and collaboration. Evidence suggests that family businesses tend to be relatively responsible and caring employers, and maintaining a commitment to the long-term development of employees could further distinguish them from non-family-owned peers that may be under more intense, short-term market pressures. As the distinction between traditional gender roles fades, for example, and women take on more senior roles, family firms have an opportunity to proactively position themselves as the employer of choice - by looking more carefully at their selection processes, and promoting flexible working practices. Social transformation has changed the nature of gender and of families, and the father with a career and the mother as caregiver is being replaced by father and mother, or partners, each with a career. The fact that family businesses already employ a relatively high percentage of female leaders bodes well for the future. This key issue is curated in partnership with Lynda Gratton, Professor of Management Practice at London Business School.

name: Workplace and Workforce Change
description: Current work and retirement structures are based on 20th century norms. People now want to work past traditional retirement age, as public policies incentivize them to work in different ways. As of 2014, eight Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries had established official retirement ages over 65, and more were expected to follow. A more flexible approach to retirement is emerging; the 2015 Aegon Retirement Readiness Survey found that more than half of the respondents expected to retire at or after the age of 65, or to not retire at all, and more than half of those 55 and older anticipated a flexible transition into retirement that may involve reduced work hours and pay. Studies have shown that the employment of older people leads to increased employment and higher wages for younger workers. In addition, workers aged 60 or older are also more productive than those under 25, and actually generate productivity comparable to 35 to 54 year olds. The Kauffman Foundation has reported that in the US, the number of entrepreneurs aged between 20 and 34 declined between 1997 and 2015, while new entrepreneurs aged between 55 and 64 grew from 14.8% to 25.8% of the total. Increased rates of work among older populations may help extend pay-as-you-go pension systems such as 401k plans, where employees contribute specific amounts over time. Public pension expenditures are meanwhile expected to consume a significant portion of GDP in European countries by 2050, while China’s Academy of Social Sciences has projected large shortfalls for that country’s national and local pension schemes by 2050. Research published by the Brookings Institution in 2013 found that the trend of delaying retirement could boost general government revenue by as much as $2.1 trillion over three decades. The challenge lies in figuring out how to best transition to 21st century work models. Many people caught between the era of defined benefit pensions, which have offered payments from employers, and increasingly prevalent defined contribution systems, are failing to generate the savings they need. In addition, defined contribution plans remain inaccessible and underutilized. In the US as of 2016, less than half of private-sector workers participated in a retirement plan of any kind, according to data compiled by the Pew Charitable Trusts. These developments present a unique opportunity to re-evaluate entire retirement systems - both public and private - in order to ensure a more sustainable model.

name: World-Topping Energy Demands
description: India will have to manage a careful balancing act between consuming increasing amounts of energy in order to maintain its economic growth, and paying heed to the resulting climate change-related risks. According to the 2018 edition of the government’s annual Economic Survey, energy demand will have to increase fourfold in order to push India into the highest category of the Human Development Index. At the same time, the 2019 Global Climate Risk Index published by German think tank Germanwatch placed India 14th in a list of countries deemed most at risk from climate change. India is already the world’s third-largest emitter of greenhouse gases, after China and the US. As of 2017, 60% of the country’s greenhouse gas emissions were generated by the energy sector, while 22% came from the industrial sector and 15% resulted from the agricultural sector. Currently, some 60% of total energy demand in India is being met by greenhouse gas-emitting thermal power plants, and only about a tenth by renewable sources; the remainder comes from nuclear and hydro power. India has pledged as part of the Paris Agreement on climate change to obtain 40% of its energy capacity from non-fossil fuel sources, and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by between 33% and 35% by 2030. While Indians currently average a third of global per-capita energy consumption, that will have to rise in tandem with living standards. India has taken some steps to help achieve the United Nations’ the Sustainable Development Goals; it has nearly doubled the share of renewables in total energy generation over the past five years, and its renewable capacity is expected to double by 2022, thanks primarily to solar and wind. Among other measures, India has launched a “Perform Achieve and Trade” scheme assigning mandatory energy consumption targets to energy-intensive industries, while the “Standards and Labelling” programme provides consumers with basic information about energy- and cost-saving appliances. It is in India’s best interests to address climate change, as related erratic rainfall, falling groundwater levels, and deteriorating air quality will profoundly affect its people. The challenge will be to do this without compromising the economic growth necessary to pull millions out of poverty.

name: Worsening Impacts
description: Human activity has placed the environment under extreme stress. In 2009, an international group of scientists proposed the concept of “planetary boundaries,” within which humanity can continue to thrive for generations. Disrespecting these boundaries, which are tied to issues including climate change, freshwater use, and chemical pollution, could result in irreversible environmental change. So far, four of these nine boundaries have been crossed. About 400 billion metric tonnes of carbon have been released into the atmosphere due to the consumption of fossil fuels since 1751, and half of these emissions have occurred since the late 1980s, according to the Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center. In addition, 2015, 2016, and 2017 were the three warmest years on record (followed closely by 2018), according to the World Meteorological Organization. Water stress is impacting communities and industries; the World Bank’s 2016 report High and Dry: Climate Change, Water, and the Economy estimated that 1.6 billion people live in countries with physical water scarcity, and that this number is projected to rise to 4 billion by 2050. Without a change in approach, the world could face a serious water deficit by 2030, with knock-on effects for sanitation and health, energy generation, and agricultural production. In 2015, Global Forest Watch reported that some 18 million hectares of tree cover - an area twice the size of Portugal - are lost each year. In 2016, the World Wildlife Fund’s Living Planet Report noted a 58% decline in the vertebrate population between 1970 and 2012, and it has been noted that ocean chemistry is changing faster now than perhaps at any point in the last 300 million years. Acidification is a concern for the tourism and fishing industries, and is potentially accelerating as the ocean’s ability to absorb carbon dioxide declines. According to United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization figures from 2016, nearly one third of the global fish stock is overfished, and illegal fishing removes about 26 million metric tonnes (close to $23 billion in value) of seafood a year. The stresses on the environment and natural resource security have become so great, with most of the impact yet to fully play out, that many academics now report that human activity, mass extinctions, and extensive pollution have demarcated a wholly new epoch for Earth - dubbed the “Anthropocene.”

name: Young People and Technology
description: Despite widespread concern about the disruptive power of automation, an overwhelming number of respondents to the most recent edition of the World Economic Forum’s Global Shapers Survey, a window into how young people view the world, believe technology is creating jobs (78.6%) as opposed to destroying them (21.4%). However, opinion differed based on region; young people in Sub-Saharan Africa and Europe registered the lowest share of votes for “creating” jobs, for example. In general, young people are optimistic about technology and its benefits - not only for their personal lives, but for society in general. According to the survey, they believe sectors such as education, healthcare, and manufacturing will benefit greatly from the adoption of new technologies. There are limits on young peoples’ embrace of technology, however. When asked about the possibility of enhancing their capabilities through skin or brain implants, 44.3% rejected the idea. Far more males than females were open to the idea of an implant, according to survey results, and more than half of young people in low- and lower-middle income countries said a flat “no” to the idea (compared with 42.8% answering “no” in high-income countries). While young people might embrace technology as a means to improve their lives generally, they do not seem to like the idea of robot proxies. According to the survey, just over half of the young respondents could not imagine trusting a robot to make decisions on their behalf. In addition, nearly half of respondents would not support establishing rights for humanoid robots - though in one region of the world, North America, votes for “maybe” on this question actually outnumbered “no” votes. While they may embrace technology, young people are cautious about both the information that they share online, and about the information they receive from online sources, according to the survey. While nearly half of respondents said they had not shared a news item on social media that they later learned was fake, more than one fifth responded that they had likely done so - but without knowing about it. In terms of the “next big technology trend,” most respondents by far said they believe it will be associated with artificial intelligence. In the Middle East and North Africa region, however, respondents chose the Internet of Things as a close second.

name: Young People and Work
description: There is a widely-held assumption that millennials are lazy and entitled, tend to frequently switch jobs, and do not care much about work. However, the World Economic Forum’s most recent edition of the Global Shapers Survey, a measure of how young people see the world, provides a very different portrait. The top three criteria for young people when considering job opportunities are compensation, career growth, and a sense of purpose and social impact, according to the survey. The importance of gaining a sense of purpose underscores the notion that young people actually care about others and the environment, and about having professional opportunities to learn and grow as people. Nearly half of the survey respondents said their employers should ensure a positive work-life balance; in fact, more than one third of those between the ages of 27 and 35 indicated that, “I am willing to sacrifice work and salary to enjoy life.” However, young people are grappling with more fundamental challenges as they try to enter the workforce. According to the survey, they feel they are disadvantaged when seeking out new jobs due to having a lack of experience, a surplus of competition, and a lack of available work. According to survey respondents overall, the most important contribution that businesses make to society is creating jobs. However, in Eurasia the top choice was boosting the economy and attracting foreign investment, while in North America and Oceania, the top choice was improving livelihoods. Young people expect companies to address social and environmental problems. When posed with the statement, “companies should not be involved in addressing social problems that are not related to their business activities,” most respondents disagreed. Respondents highlighted things businesses can do to create a youth-friendly work culture: provide opportunities to contribute to vision and strategy, offer mentoring, and ensure that failure is accepted as a learning experience. Young people are increasingly aware of what they consume and who is providing it, and cautious about forming bonds of loyalty. Millennials tend to look closely at a company's commitment to sustainability and social responsibility, at how a company is covered in the media, and at its financial reports.

name: Youth Unemployment
description: As of 2017, 27% of the people aged between 15 and 24 in the Middle East and North Africa region were unemployed, compared with a global average of 13%, according to World Bank data. Young women have been particularly affected; the rate of youth female unemployment in the MENA region was 41% as of 2017, according to World Bank data, compared with a global figure of 15%. Youth unemployment in this part of the world stems from factors including a skills mismatch - as local school curricula tends to encourage memorization and rote learning, rather than skills more useful for the private sector such as creative thinking. The problem is also related to the incentives offered by the private sector, including salaries and working conditions that are often less attractive than the stability offered by the public sector. Meanwhile relatively rigid labour and other market rules mean that economies in the region suffer from a lack of diversification and development. The absence of bankruptcy regimes in many Arab countries also discourages entrepreneurial risk-taking, further inhibiting innovation. These structural challenges are compounded by massive demographic changes that are underway. A 2015 European Union Institute for Security Studies report, Arab Futures: Three Scenarios for 2025, projected an average of 3.1 births per woman in Arab countries between 2015 and 2020, compared with a global rate of 2.7. That translates into a population in the Arab world of 468 million by 2025, compared with 357 million in 2015. This increase, alongside growing migration within the region due to refugee flows and the impact of climate change, promises to further exacerbate youth unemployment - and in turn to present further risks to social and political stability. Large numbers of unemployed young people can contribute to the sort of polarization and political unrest that discourages foreign investment. Meanwhile a correlation between expanding youth populations and violence has been established; the EU’s 2015 study on Arab Futures noted that between 1970 and 1999, 80% of civil conflict in the region occurred in countries where nearly two-thirds of the population was both under the age of 30 and unemployed. In these countries, every percentage point gain in youth population increased the risk of conflict by 4%, according to the study.

name: Youth Unemployment in Nigeria
description: Nigeria’s relatively lacklustre economic development can be attributed at least in part to its infrastructure; the country was ranked 124th out of 140 economies in terms of infrastructure in the World Economic Forum’s 2018 Global Competitiveness Index. While Nigeria may have the second-largest economy in Africa (after South Africa), it remains heavily constrained due to its infrastructure situation. In 2016, the Lagos Chamber of Commerce and Industry estimated that the country’s infrastructure deficit amounts to roughly $300 billion - more than 10 times the size of the entire national budget for 2018. In terms of quality of roads, Nigeria ranked 132nd out of 140 economies in the Forum’s Competitiveness Index, while its efficiency of train services ranked 127th (of the roughly 3,500 kilometres of railway inherited from the British after colonization, only a small portion is now operational). The country’s electricity sector is also lagging; it ranked 114th in terms of electrification rate in the Forum’s index. Barring significant basic infrastructure improvement, it is difficult to see how Nigeria’s economy can meaningfully expand. Comparing its infrastructure needs to the extent of Nigeria’s significant government revenue can be a depressing exercise; it can sometimes be difficult to find evidence that funds earmarked for the purpose have actually been spent on infrastructure, which suggests mismanagement. Nigeria’s growth potential is immense, given its large population, abundant resources, and entrepreneurial spirit. In order to address the infrastructure deficit, Nigeria’s government has initiated policies including power sector reforms and the Petroleum Industry Bill (passed in parliament in 2017, to jumpstart growth in the sector by increasing transparency). The electricity sector is being privatized, and the government has implemented a bid to meet 30% of the country’s energy needs with renewables by the year 2030. The government has also sought to collaborate with international institutions and foreign governments in order to better address its infrastructure needs. For example, a number of infrastructure development projects have pushed ahead in collaboration with Chinese companies; China Civil Engineering Construction Company is involved in projects in the country including the Lagos airport expansion, road building, urban light-rail construction, and contract worth a reported $11 billion to build a railway connecting Lagos to Calabar, according to a report published in 2018 by the United States Institute for Peace.

name: Youth and Gender Issues
description: A United Nations report published in 2018 noted that less than half of all young people in Pakistan have mobile phones, just 15% have access to the internet, and about 90% suffer from poor access to recreational facilities. In addition, 57% of young people are neither employed nor seeking work. There are 163 universities in Pakistan, though higher education enrolment is just 4% - far lower than in India (11%) and Malaysia (32%). Even when young people receive a good education, they are often unable to find good jobs to utilize their skills - and frequently end up feeling humiliated. As a result, they become more inclined to become depressed, use drugs, and commit crime. The promotion of entrepreneurship among young people should increase, not least because of a culture of family-run businesses predominantly in clothing, food, and retail sectors where control of a single firm is continually transferred from one generation to the next In terms of gender in Pakistan, a gap starts widening during primary education and persists throughout every sphere of life from government policy-making to household decision-making. In the lower house of parliament, for example, men have constituted nearly 80% of representatives. Most women do not work, and instead look after their families. Even after receiving medical degrees, for example, a majority of women leave the profession because of family pressure. Overall, the Labour Force Participation Rate for men is about 69%, while for women it is roughly 28%. More than half of women in rural areas, and about 40% in urban areas, earn less than PKR 5,000 (equivalent to about $40) per month. Meanwhile domestic violence continues to be a serious problem. In Punjab, the largest province by population, reported cases of violence rose to 7,678 in 2017, from 7,313 the prior year, despite extensive public awareness campaigns. Both the Maternal Mortality Rate and Infant Mortality Rate in the country have declined during the past decade, reflecting improvements in the provision of reproductive, maternal, and child health services. Fostering a growing awareness among women about ways to better protect their health, and access health facilities, could help bring these mortality rates closer to zero.

name: “Securitization” and Rhetoric
description: The “securitization” of migration, or the public discussion of migration issues strictly in security terms, rather than in economic, social, cultural, or humanitarian terms, has been fuelled by pivotal geopolitical events like the end of the Cold War and the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The more recent mass movements of Syrian refugees and other migrants to Europe escalated this trend, by more closely linking migration with terrorism in media coverage and on social media. These links, however, are being forged by far-right online activists without regard to accuracy or truth. Research published by Dublin City University in 2018 that analysed nearly 7.5 million tweets from 2015 and 2016, for example, found that during the large-scale migratory flows at that time to and through Europe there was a corresponding surge in far-right online activism. These activists used social media accounts to frame events in negative and racist ways, the research shows - and for the most part, they were successful in influencing the political debate in Europe, and in making it much harder for proportional, reasonable responses to the crisis to be enacted. A 2016 Pew Research Center survey found that a median of 59% of people in 10 European Union countries were concerned that an influx of refugees would increase the likelihood of terrorism - 76% felt this way in Hungary, and 71% in Poland. In Germany, where 61% of survey respondents expressed this view, a subsequent discussion paper published in 2017 by the IZA Institute of Labor Economics identified only very small increases in crime that had actually occurred in the wake of the heavy inflow of migrants and refugees in 2014 and 2015 - equal to about 1.5%. The increasing characterization of migration as a national security threat negatively affects public discourse, and is at odds with reality. Migration poses challenges but also comes with very significant benefits. Politicians (especially those in opposition parties) and far-right activists engaging in divisive campaigns that paint migrants as a criminal element are placing short term gain above longer-term social progress and prosperity. In the lead-up to the adoption of the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration in late 2018, for example, far-right groups incorrectly stated that the agreement poses threats to national sovereignty. This sort of thing has been happening, in Europe and elsewhere, at a time of relative prosperity and peace. There is no global financial crisis, economic fundamentals are strong, diversity has never been greater, social cohesion is largely working - and peace (mostly) prevails, according to the Global Peace Index published by the Institute for Economics and Peace.
